   <TITLE>Chapter 16</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XVI</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>It was a very great relief to Emma to find Harriet as desirous



<P>as herself to avoid a meeting.&nbsp; Their intercourse was painful



<P>enough by letter.&nbsp; How much worse, had they been obliged to meet!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet expressed herself very much as might be supposed,



<P>without reproaches, or apparent sense of ill-usage; and yet Emma fancied



<P>there was a something of resentment, a something bordering on it in



<P>her style, which increased the desirableness of their being separate.--



<P>It might be only her own consciousness; but it seemed as if an



<P>angel only could have been quite without resentment under such a stroke.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She had no difficulty in procuring Isabella's invitation;



<P>and she was fortunate in having a sufficient reason for asking it,



<P>without resorting to invention.--There was a tooth amiss.



<P>Harriet really wished, and had wished some time, to consult a dentist.



<P>Mrs. John Knightley was delighted to be of use; any thing of ill



<P>health was a recommendation to her--and though not so fond of a



<P>dentist as of a Mr. Wingfield, she was quite eager to have Harriet



<P>under her care.--When it was thus settled on her sister's side,



<P>Emma proposed it to her friend, and found her very persuadable.--



<P>Harriet was to go; she was invited for at least a fortnight; she was



<P>to be conveyed in Mr. Woodhouse's carriage.--It was all arranged,



<P>it was all completed, and Harriet was safe in Brunswick Square.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Now Emma could, indeed, enjoy Mr. Knightley's visits; now she



<P>could talk, and she could listen with true happiness, unchecked by



<P>that sense of injustice, of guilt, of something most painful,



<P>which had haunted her when remembering how disappointed a heart was



<P>near her, how much might at that moment, and at a little distance,



<P>be enduring by the feelings which she had led astray herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The difference of Harriet at Mrs. Goddard's, or in London, made perhaps



<P>an unreasonable difference in Emma's sensations; but she could not



<P>think of her in London without objects of curiosity and employment,



<P>which must be averting the past, and carrying her out of herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She would not allow any other anxiety to succeed directly to the place



<P>in her mind which Harriet had occupied.&nbsp; There was a communication



<P>before her, one which she only could be competent to make--



<P>the confession of her engagement to her father; but she would



<P>have nothing to do with it at present.--She had resolved to defer



<P>the disclosure till Mrs. Weston were safe and well.&nbsp; No additional



<P>agitation should be thrown at this period among those she loved--



<P>and the evil should not act on herself by anticipation before the



<P>appointed time.--A fortnight, at least, of leisure and peace of mind,



<P>to crown every warmer, but more agitating, delight, should be hers.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She soon resolved, equally as a duty and a pleasure, to employ half



<P>an hour of this holiday of spirits in calling on Miss Fairfax.--



<P>She ought to go--and she was longing to see her; the resemblance of



<P>their present situations increasing every other motive of goodwill.



<P>It would be a secret satisfaction; but the consciousness of a



<P>similarity of prospect would certainly add to the interest with



<P>which she should attend to any thing Jane might communicate.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She went--she had driven once unsuccessfully to the door, but had



<P>not been into the house since the morning after Box Hill, when poor



<P>Jane had been in such distress as had filled her with compassion,



<P>though all the worst of her sufferings had been unsuspected.--



<P>The fear of being still unwelcome, determined her, though assured



<P>of their being at home, to wait in the passage, and send up her name.--



<P>She heard Patty announcing it; but no such bustle succeeded as poor



<P>Miss Bates had before made so happily intelligible.--No; she heard



<P>nothing but the instant reply of, "Beg her to walk up;"--and a moment



<P>afterwards she was met on the stairs by Jane herself, coming eagerly



<P>forward, as if no other reception of her were felt sufficient.--



<P>Emma had never seen her look so well, so lovely, so engaging.



<P>There was consciousness, animation, and warmth; there was every



<P>thing which her countenance or manner could ever have wanted.--



<P>She came forward with an offered hand; and said, in a low, but very



<P>feeling tone,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"This is most kind, indeed!--Miss Woodhouse, it is impossible



<P>for me to express--I hope you will believe--Excuse me for being



<P>so entirely without words."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma was gratified, and would soon have shewn no want of words,



<P>if the sound of Mrs. Elton's voice from the sitting-room had not



<P>checked her, and made it expedient to compress all her friendly



<P>and all her congratulatory sensations into a very, very earnest



<P>shake of the hand.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Bates and Mrs. Elton were together.&nbsp; Miss Bates was out,



<P>which accounted for the previous tranquillity.&nbsp; Emma could have



<P>wished Mrs. Elton elsewhere; but she was in a humour to have patience



<P>with every body; and as Mrs. Elton met her with unusual graciousness,



<P>she hoped the rencontre would do them no harm.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She soon believed herself to penetrate Mrs. Elton's thoughts,



<P>and understand why she was, like herself, in happy spirits;



<P>it was being in Miss Fairfax's confidence, and fancying herself



<P>acquainted with what was still a secret to other people.



<P>Emma saw symptoms of it immediately in the expression of her face;



<P>and while paying her own compliments to Mrs. Bates, and appearing



<P>to attend to the good old lady's replies, she saw her with a sort



<P>of anxious parade of mystery fold up a letter which she had apparently



<P>been reading aloud to Miss Fairfax, and return it into the purple



<P>and gold reticule by her side, saying, with significant nods,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We can finish this some other time, you know.&nbsp; You and I shall



<P>not want opportunities.&nbsp; And, in fact, you have heard all the



<P>essential already.&nbsp; I only wanted to prove to you that Mrs. S.

admits



<P>our apology, and is not offended.&nbsp; You see how delightfully



<P>she writes.&nbsp; Oh! she is a sweet creature!&nbsp; You would have

doated



<P>on her, had you gone.--But not a word more.&nbsp; Let us be discreet--



<P>quite on our good behaviour.--Hush!--You remember those lines--



<P>I forget the poem at this moment:

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; "For when a lady's in the

case,



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; "You know all other things

give place."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Now I say, my dear, in our case, for lady, read----mum! a word



<P>to the wise.--I am in a fine flow of spirits, an't I?&nbsp; But I want



<P>to set your heart at ease as to Mrs. S.--My representation, you see,



<P>has quite appeased her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>And again, on Emma's merely turning her head to look



<P>at Mrs. Bates's knitting, she added, in a half whisper,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I mentioned no names, you will observe.--Oh! no; cautious as



<P>a minister of state.&nbsp; I managed it extremely well."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma could not doubt.&nbsp; It was a palpable display, repeated on every



<P>possible occasion.&nbsp; When they had all talked a little while in

harmony



<P>of the weather and Mrs. Weston, she found herself abruptly addressed

with,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do not you think, Miss Woodhouse, our saucy little friend here is



<P>charmingly recovered?--Do not you think her cure does Perry the



<P>highest credit?--(here was a side-glance of great meaning at Jane.)



<P>Upon my word, Perry has restored her in a wonderful short time!--



<P>Oh! if you had seen her, as I did, when she was at the worst!"--



<P>And when Mrs. Bates was saying something to Emma, whispered farther,



<P>"We do not say a word of any assistance that Perry might have;



<P>not a word of a certain young physician from Windsor.--Oh! no;



<P>Perry shall have all the credit."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have scarce had the pleasure of seeing you, Miss Woodhouse,"



<P>she shortly afterwards began, "since the party to Box Hill.



<P>Very pleasant party.&nbsp; But yet I think there was something wanting.



<P>Things did not seem--that is, there seemed a little cloud upon



<P>the spirits of some.--So it appeared to me at least, but I might



<P>be mistaken.&nbsp; However, I think it answered so far as to tempt one



<P>to go again.&nbsp; What say you both to our collecting the same party,



<P>and exploring to Box Hill again, while the fine weather lasts?--



<P>It must be the same party, you know, quite the same party,



<P>not one exception."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Soon after this Miss Bates came in, and Emma could not help being diverted



<P>by the perplexity of her first answer to herself, resulting, she supposed,



<P>from doubt of what might be said, and impatience to say every thing.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thank you, dear Miss Woodhouse, you are all kindness.--It is impossible



<P>to say--Yes, indeed, I quite understand--dearest Jane's prospects--



<P>that is, I do not mean.--But she is charmingly recovered.--



<P>How is Mr. Woodhouse?--I am so glad.--Quite out of my power.--



<P>Such a happy little circle as you find us here.--Yes, indeed.--



<P>Charming young man!--that is--so very friendly; I mean good Mr. Perry!--



<P>such attention to Jane!"--And from her great, her more than commonly



<P>thankful delight towards Mrs. Elton for being there, Emma guessed



<P>that there had been a little show of resentment towards Jane,



<P>from the vicarage quarter, which was now graciously overcome.--



<P>After a few whispers, indeed, which placed it beyond a guess,



<P>Mrs. Elton, speaking louder, said,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, here I am, my good friend; and here I have been so long,



<P>that anywhere else I should think it necessary to apologise;



<P>but, the truth is, that I am waiting for my lord and master.



<P>He promised to join me here, and pay his respects to you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What! are we to have the pleasure of a call from Mr. Elton?--



<P>That will be a favour indeed! for I know gentlemen do not like



<P>morning visits, and Mr. Elton's time is so engaged."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Upon my word it is, Miss Bates.--He really is engaged from morning



<P>to night.--There is no end of people's coming to him, on some pretence



<P>or other.--The magistrates, and overseers, and churchwardens,



<P>are always wanting his opinion.&nbsp; They seem not able to do any thing



<P>without him.--`Upon my word, Mr. E.,' I often say, `rather you than

I.--



<P>I do not know what would become of my crayons and my instrument,



<P>if I had half so many applicants.'--Bad enough as it is, for I



<P>absolutely neglect them both to an unpardonable degree.--I believe



<P>I have not played a bar this fortnight.--However, he is coming,



<P>I assure you:&nbsp; yes, indeed, on purpose to wait on you all."&nbsp;

And putting



<P>up her hand to screen her words from Emma--"A congratulatory visit,



<P>you know.--Oh! yes, quite indispensable."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Bates looked about her, so happily!--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He promised to come to me as soon as he could disengage himself



<P>from Knightley; but he and Knightley are shut up together



<P>in deep consultation.--Mr. E. is Knightley's right hand."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma would not have smiled for the world, and only said, "Is Mr. Elton



<P>gone on foot to Donwell?--He will have a hot walk."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! no, it is a meeting at the Crown, a regular meeting.



<P>Weston and Cole will be there too; but one is apt to speak only



<P>of those who lead.--I fancy Mr. E. and Knightley have every thing



<P>their own way."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Have not you mistaken the day?" said Emma.&nbsp; "I am almost certain



<P>that the meeting at the Crown is not till to-morrow.--Mr. Knightley



<P>was at Hartfield yesterday, and spoke of it as for Saturday."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! no, the meeting is certainly to-day," was the abrupt answer,



<P>which denoted the impossibility of any blunder on Mrs. Elton's side.--



<P>"I do believe," she continued, "this is the most troublesome parish



<P>that ever was.&nbsp; We never heard of such things at Maple Grove."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Your parish there was small," said Jane.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Upon my word, my dear, I do not know, for I never heard the subject



<P>talked of."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But it is proved by the smallness of the school, which I have heard



<P>you speak of, as under the patronage of your sister and Mrs. Bragge;



<P>the only school, and not more than five-and-twenty children."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah! you clever creature, that's very true.&nbsp; What a thinking brain



<P>you have!&nbsp; I say, Jane, what a perfect character you and I should

make,



<P>if we could be shaken together.&nbsp; My liveliness and your solidity



<P>would produce perfection.--Not that I presume to insinuate, however,



<P>that some people may not think you perfection already.--But hush!--



<P>not a word, if you please."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It seemed an unnecessary caution; Jane was wanting to give her words,



<P>not to Mrs. Elton, but to Miss Woodhouse, as the latter plainly saw.



<P>The wish of distinguishing her, as far as civility permitted,



<P>was very evident, though it could not often proceed beyond a look.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Elton made his appearance.&nbsp; His lady greeted him with some



<P>of her sparkling vivacity.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very pretty, sir, upon my word; to send me on here, to be an



<P>encumbrance to my friends, so long before you vouchsafe to come!--



<P>But you knew what a dutiful creature you had to deal with.



<P>You knew I should not stir till my lord and master appeared.--



<P>Here have I been sitting this hour, giving these young ladies



<P>a sample of true conjugal obedience--for who can say, you know,



<P>how soon it may be wanted?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Elton was so hot and tired, that all this wit seemed thrown away.



<P>His civilities to the other ladies must be paid; but his subsequent



<P>object was to lament over himself for the heat he was suffering,



<P>and the walk he had had for nothing.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"When I got to Donwell," said he, "Knightley could not be found.



<P>Very odd! very unaccountable! after the note I sent him this morning,



<P>and the message he returned, that he should certainly be at home



<P>till one."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Donwell!" cried his wife.--"My dear Mr. E., you have not been



<P>to Donwell!--You mean the Crown; you come from the meeting at the Crown."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, no, that's to-morrow; and I particularly wanted to see Knightley



<P>to-day on that very account.--Such a dreadful broiling morning!--



<P>I went over the fields too--(speaking in a tone of great ill-usage,)



<P>which made it so much the worse.&nbsp; And then not to find him at home!



<P>I assure you I am not at all pleased.&nbsp; And no apology left, no

message



<P>for me.&nbsp; The housekeeper declared she knew nothing of my being

expected.--



<P>Very extraordinary!--And nobody knew at all which way he was gone.



<P>Perhaps to Hartfield, perhaps to the Abbey Mill, perhaps into his woods.--



<P>Miss Woodhouse, this is not like our friend Knightley!--Can you



<P>explain it?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma amused herself by protesting that it was very extraordinary,



<P>indeed, and that she had not a syllable to say for him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I cannot imagine," said Mrs. Elton, (feeling the indignity as a wife



<P>ought to do,) "I cannot imagine how he could do such a thing by you,



<P>of all people in the world!&nbsp; The very last person whom one should

expect



<P>to be forgotten!--My dear Mr. E., he must have left a message for you,



<P>I am sure he must.--Not even Knightley could be so very eccentric;--



<P>and his servants forgot it.&nbsp; Depend upon it, that was the case:



<P>and very likely to happen with the Donwell servants, who are all,



<P>I have often observed, extremely awkward and remiss.--I am sure I



<P>would not have such a creature as his Harry stand at our sideboard



<P>for any consideration.&nbsp; And as for Mrs. Hodges, Wright holds



<P>her very cheap indeed.--She promised Wright a receipt, and never



<P>sent it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I met William Larkins," continued Mr. Elton, "as I got near



<P>the house, and he told me I should not find his master at home,



<P>but I did not believe him.--William seemed rather out of humour.



<P>He did not know what was come to his master lately, he said, but he



<P>could hardly ever get the speech of him.&nbsp; I have nothing to do

with



<P>William's wants, but it really is of very great importance that I



<P>should see Knightley to-day; and it becomes a matter, therefore,



<P>of very serious inconvenience that I should have had this hot walk



<P>to no purpose."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma felt that she could not do better than go home directly.



<P>In all probability she was at this very time waited for there;



<P>and Mr. Knightley might be preserved from sinking deeper in aggression



<P>towards Mr. Elton, if not towards William Larkins.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was pleased, on taking leave, to find Miss Fairfax determined



<P>to attend her out of the room, to go with her even downstairs;



<P>it gave her an opportunity which she immediately made use of,



<P>to say,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is as well, perhaps, that I have not had the possibility.



<P>Had you not been surrounded by other friends, I might have been



<P>tempted to introduce a subject, to ask questions, to speak more



<P>openly than might have been strictly correct.--I feel that I should



<P>certainly have been impertinent."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh!" cried Jane, with a blush and an hesitation which Emma thought



<P>infinitely more becoming to her than all the elegance of all her



<P>usual composure--"there would have been no danger.&nbsp; The danger



<P>would have been of my wearying you.&nbsp; You could not have gratified



<P>me more than by expressing an interest--.&nbsp; Indeed, Miss Woodhouse,



<P>(speaking more collectedly,) with the consciousness which I



<P>have of misconduct, very great misconduct, it is particularly



<P>consoling to me to know that those of my friends, whose good



<P>opinion is most worth preserving, are not disgusted to such a



<P>degree as to--I have not time for half that I could wish to say.



<P>I long to make apologies, excuses, to urge something for myself.



<P>I feel it so very due.&nbsp; But, unfortunately--in short, if your



<P>compassion does not stand my friend--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! you are too scrupulous, indeed you are," cried Emma warmly,



<P>and taking her hand.&nbsp; "You owe me no apologies; and every body

to



<P>whom you might be supposed to owe them, is so perfectly satisfied,



<P>so delighted even--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are very kind, but I know what my manners were to you.--



<P>So cold and artificial!--I had always a part to act.--It was a life



<P>of deceit!--I know that I must have disgusted you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Pray say no more.&nbsp; I feel that all the apologies should be on

my side.



<P>Let us forgive each other at once.&nbsp; We must do whatever is to be



<P>done quickest, and I think our feelings will lose no time there.



<P>I hope you have pleasant accounts from Windsor?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And the next news, I suppose, will be, that we are to lose you--



<P>just as I begin to know you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! as to all that, of course nothing can be thought of yet.



<P>I am here till claimed by Colonel and Mrs. Campbell."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nothing can be actually settled yet, perhaps," replied Emma,



<P>smiling--"but, excuse me, it must be thought of."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The smile was returned as Jane answered,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are very right; it has been thought of.&nbsp; And I will own



<P>to you, (I am sure it will be safe), that so far as our living



<P>with Mr. Churchill at Enscombe, it is settled.&nbsp; There must be



<P>three months, at least, of deep mourning; but when they are over,



<P>I imagine there will be nothing more to wait for."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thank you, thank you.--This is just what I wanted to be assured of.--



<P>Oh! if you knew how much I love every thing that is decided and open!--



<P>Good-bye, good-bye."



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 02</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER II</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>No misfortune occurred, again to prevent the ball.&nbsp; The day approached,



<P>the day arrived; and after a morning of some anxious watching,



<P>Frank Churchill, in all the certainty of his own self, reached Randalls



<P>before dinner, and every thing was safe.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>No second meeting had there yet been between him and Emma.



<P>The room at the Crown was to witness it;--but it would be better



<P>than a common meeting in a crowd.&nbsp; Mr. Weston had been so very



<P>earnest in his entreaties for her arriving there as soon as possible



<P>after themselves, for the purpose of taking her opinion as to the



<P>propriety and comfort of the rooms before any other persons came,



<P>that she could not refuse him, and must therefore spend some quiet



<P>interval in the young man's company.&nbsp; She was to convey Harriet,



<P>and they drove to the Crown in good time, the Randalls party just



<P>sufficiently before them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Frank Churchill seemed to have been on the watch; and though



<P>he did not say much, his eyes declared that he meant to have



<P>a delightful evening.&nbsp; They all walked about together, to see



<P>that every thing was as it should be; and within a few minutes



<P>were joined by the contents of another carriage, which Emma



<P>could not hear the sound of at first, without great surprize.



<P>"So unreasonably early!" she was going to exclaim; but she presently



<P>found that it was a family of old friends, who were coming, like herself,



<P>by particular desire, to help Mr. Weston's judgment; and they were



<P>so very closely followed by another carriage of cousins, who had been



<P>entreated to come early with the same distinguishing earnestness,



<P>on the same errand, that it seemed as if half the company might



<P>soon be collected together for the purpose of preparatory inspection.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma perceived that her taste was not the only taste on which



<P>Mr. Weston depended, and felt, that to be the favourite and



<P>intimate of a man who had so many intimates and confidantes,



<P>was not the very first distinction in the scale of vanity.



<P>She liked his open manners, but a little less of open-heartedness



<P>would have made him a higher character.--General benevolence,



<P>but not general friendship, made a man what he ought to be.--



<P>She could fancy such a man.&nbsp; The whole party walked about,



<P>and looked, and praised again; and then, having nothing else to do,



<P>formed a sort of half-circle round the fire, to observe in their



<P>various modes, till other subjects were started, that, though May,



<P>a fire in the evening was still very pleasant.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma found that it was not Mr. Weston's fault that the number



<P>of privy councillors was not yet larger.&nbsp; They had stopped



<P>at Mrs. Bates's door to offer the use of their carriage,



<P>but the aunt and niece were to be brought by the Eltons.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Frank was standing by her, but not steadily; there was a restlessness,



<P>which shewed a mind not at ease.&nbsp; He was looking about, he was

going



<P>to the door, he was watching for the sound of other carriages,--



<P>impatient to begin, or afraid of being always near her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Elton was spoken of.&nbsp; "I think she must be here soon," said

he.



<P>"I have a great curiosity to see Mrs. Elton, I have heard so much



<P>of her.&nbsp; It cannot be long, I think, before she comes."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A carriage was heard.&nbsp; He was on the move immediately;



<P>but coming back, said,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am forgetting that I am not acquainted with her.&nbsp; I have never

seen



<P>either Mr. or Mrs. Elton.&nbsp; I have no business to put myself forward."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. and Mrs. Elton appeared; and all the smiles and the proprieties

passed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But Miss Bates and Miss Fairfax!" said Mr. Weston, looking about.



<P>"We thought you were to bring them."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The mistake had been slight.&nbsp; The carriage was sent for them now.



<P>Emma longed to know what Frank's first opinion of Mrs. Elton



<P>might be; how he was affected by the studied elegance of her dress,



<P>and her smiles of graciousness.&nbsp; He was immediately qualifying



<P>himself to form an opinion, by giving her very proper attention,



<P>after the introduction had passed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In a few minutes the carriage returned.--Somebody talked of rain.--



<P>"I will see that there are umbrellas, sir," said Frank to his father:



<P>"Miss Bates must not be forgotten:"&nbsp; and away he went.&nbsp; Mr.

Weston



<P>was following; but Mrs. Elton detained him, to gratify him by her



<P>opinion of his son; and so briskly did she begin, that the young



<P>man himself, though by no means moving slowly, could hardly be out



<P>of hearing.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A very fine young man indeed, Mr. Weston.&nbsp; You know I candidly

told



<P>you I should form my own opinion; and I am happy to say that I am



<P>extremely pleased with him.--You may believe me.&nbsp; I never compliment.



<P>I think him a very handsome young man, and his manners are precisely



<P>what I like and approve--so truly the gentleman, without the least



<P>conceit or puppyism.&nbsp; You must know I have a vast dislike to puppies--



<P>quite a horror of them.&nbsp; They were never tolerated at Maple Grove.



<P>Neither Mr. Suckling nor me had ever any patience with them; and we



<P>used sometimes to say very cutting things!&nbsp; Selina, who is mild

almost



<P>to a fault, bore with them much better."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>While she talked of his son, Mr. Weston's attention was chained;



<P>but when she got to Maple Grove, he could recollect that there were



<P>ladies just arriving to be attended to, and with happy smiles must



<P>hurry away.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Elton turned to Mrs. Weston.&nbsp; "I have no doubt of its being



<P>our carriage with Miss Bates and Jane.&nbsp; Our coachman and horses

are



<P>so extremely expeditious!--I believe we drive faster than any body.--



<P>What a pleasure it is to send one's carriage for a friend!--



<P>I understand you were so kind as to offer, but another time it



<P>will be quite unnecessary.&nbsp; You may be very sure I shall always



<P>take care of them."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Bates and Miss Fairfax, escorted by the two gentlemen,



<P>walked into the room; and Mrs. Elton seemed to think it as much



<P>her duty as Mrs. Weston's to receive them.&nbsp; Her gestures and



<P>movements might be understood by any one who looked on like Emma;



<P>but her words, every body's words, were soon lost under the



<P>incessant flow of Miss Bates, who came in talking, and had not



<P>finished her speech under many minutes after her being admitted



<P>into the circle at the fire.&nbsp; As the door opened she was heard,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So very obliging of you!--No rain at all.&nbsp; Nothing to signify.



<P>I do not care for myself.&nbsp; Quite thick shoes.&nbsp; And Jane declares--



<P>Well!--(as soon as she was within the door) Well!&nbsp; This is brilliant



<P>indeed!--This is admirable!--Excellently contrived, upon my word.



<P>Nothing wanting.&nbsp; Could not have imagined it.--So well lighted

up!--



<P>Jane, Jane, look!--did you ever see any thing?&nbsp; Oh!&nbsp; Mr. Weston,



<P>you must really have had Aladdin's lamp.&nbsp; Good Mrs. Stokes



<P>would not know her own room again.&nbsp; I saw her as I came in;



<P>she was standing in the entrance.&nbsp; `Oh!&nbsp; Mrs. Stokes,' said

I--



<P>but I had not time for more."&nbsp; She was now met by Mrs. Weston.--



<P>"Very well, I thank you, ma'am. I hope you are quite well.



<P>Very happy to hear it.&nbsp; So afraid you might have a headach!--



<P>seeing you pass by so often, and knowing how much trouble you must have.



<P>Delighted to hear it indeed.&nbsp; Ah! dear Mrs. Elton, so obliged



<P>to you for the carriage!--excellent time.&nbsp; Jane and I quite ready.



<P>Did not keep the horses a moment.&nbsp; Most comfortable carriage.--



<P>Oh! and I am sure our thanks are due to you, Mrs. Weston, on that score.



<P>Mrs. Elton had most kindly sent Jane a note, or we should have been.--



<P>But two such offers in one day!--Never were such neighbours.



<P>I said to my mother, `Upon my word, ma'am--.'&nbsp; Thank you, my mother



<P>is remarkably well.&nbsp; Gone to Mr. Woodhouse's. I made her take



<P>her shawl--for the evenings are not warm--her large new shawl--



<P>Mrs. Dixon's wedding-present.--So kind of her to think of my mother!



<P>Bought at Weymouth, you know--Mr. Dixon's choice.&nbsp; There were



<P>three others, Jane says, which they hesitated about some time.



<P>Colonel Campbell rather preferred an olive.&nbsp; My dear Jane,



<P>are you sure you did not wet your feet?--It was but a drop or two,



<P>but I am so afraid:--but Mr. Frank Churchill was so extremely--



<P>and there was a mat to step upon--I shall never forget his



<P>extreme politeness.--Oh!&nbsp; Mr. Frank Churchill, I must tell you



<P>my mother's spectacles have never been in fault since; the rivet



<P>never came out again.&nbsp; My mother often talks of your good-nature.



<P>Does not she, Jane?--Do not we often talk of Mr. Frank Churchill?--



<P>Ah! here's Miss Woodhouse.--Dear Miss Woodhouse, how do you do?--



<P>Very well I thank you, quite well.&nbsp; This is meeting quite in fairy-land!--



<P>Such a transformation!--Must not compliment, I know (eyeing Emma



<P>most complacently)--that would be rude--but upon my word, Miss Woodhouse,



<P>you do look--how do you like Jane's hair?--You are a judge.--



<P>She did it all herself.&nbsp; Quite wonderful how she does her hair!--



<P>No hairdresser from London I think could.--Ah! Dr. Hughes I declare--



<P>and Mrs. Hughes.&nbsp; Must go and speak to Dr. and Mrs. Hughes for



<P>a moment.--How do you do?&nbsp; How do you do?--Very well, I thank you.



<P>This is delightful, is not it?--Where's dear Mr. Richard?--



<P>Oh! there he is.&nbsp; Don't disturb him.&nbsp; Much better employed

talking



<P>to the young ladies.&nbsp; How do you do, Mr. Richard?--I saw you the



<P>other day as you rode through the town--Mrs. Otway, I protest!--



<P>and good Mr. Otway, and Miss Otway and Miss Caroline.--Such a host



<P>of friends!--and Mr. George and Mr. Arthur!--How do you do?&nbsp; How

do



<P>you all do?--Quite well, I am much obliged to you.&nbsp; Never better.--



<P>Don't I hear another carriage?--Who can this be?--very likely the



<P>worthy Coles.--Upon my word, this is charming to be standing about



<P>among such friends!&nbsp; And such a noble fire!--I am quite roasted.



<P>No coffee, I thank you, for me--never take coffee.--A little tea



<P>if you please, sir, by and bye,--no hurry--Oh! here it comes.



<P>Every thing so good!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Frank Churchill returned to his station by Emma; and as soon as Miss



<P>Bates was quiet, she found herself necessarily overhearing the



<P>discourse of Mrs. Elton and Miss Fairfax, who were standing a little



<P>way behind her.--He was thoughtful.&nbsp; Whether he were overhearing

too,



<P>she could not determine.&nbsp; After a good many compliments to Jane



<P>on her dress and look, compliments very quietly and properly taken,



<P>Mrs. Elton was evidently wanting to be complimented herself--



<P>and it was, "How do you like my gown?--How do you like my trimming?--



<P>How has Wright done my hair?"--with many other relative questions,



<P>all answered with patient politeness.&nbsp; Mrs. Elton then said,



<P>"Nobody can think less of dress in general than I do--but upon such



<P>an occasion as this, when every body's eyes are so much upon me,



<P>and in compliment to the Westons--who I have no doubt are giving



<P>this ball chiefly to do me honour--I would not wish to be inferior



<P>to others.&nbsp; And I see very few pearls in the room except mine.--



<P>So Frank Churchill is a capital dancer, I understand.--We shall see



<P>if our styles suit.--A fine young man certainly is Frank Churchill.



<P>I like him very well."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>At this moment Frank began talking so vigorously, that Emma could



<P>not but imagine he had overheard his own praises, and did not want



<P>to hear more;--and the voices of the ladies were drowned for a while,



<P>till another suspension brought Mrs. Elton's tones again distinctly



<P>forward.--Mr. Elton had just joined them, and his wife was exclaiming,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! you have found us out at last, have you, in our seclusion?--



<P>I was this moment telling Jane, I thought you would begin to be



<P>impatient for tidings of us."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Jane!"--repeated Frank Churchill, with a look of surprize and displeasure.--



<P>"That is easy--but Miss Fairfax does not disapprove it, I suppose."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How do you like Mrs. Elton?" said Emma in a whisper.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not at all."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are ungrateful."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ungrateful!--What do you mean?"&nbsp; Then changing from a frown to



<P>a smile--"No, do not tell me--I do not want to know what you mean.--



<P>Where is my father?--When are we to begin dancing?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma could hardly understand him; he seemed in an odd humour.



<P>He walked off to find his father, but was quickly back again with both



<P>Mr. and Mrs. Weston.&nbsp; He had met with them in a little perplexity,



<P>which must be laid before Emma.&nbsp; It had just occurred to Mrs. Weston



<P>that Mrs. Elton must be asked to begin the ball; that she would



<P>expect it; which interfered with all their wishes of giving Emma



<P>that distinction.--Emma heard the sad truth with fortitude.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And what are we to do for a proper partner for her?" said Mr. Weston.



<P>"She will think Frank ought to ask her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Frank turned instantly to Emma, to claim her former promise;



<P>and boasted himself an engaged man, which his father looked his most



<P>perfect approbation of--and it then appeared that Mrs. Weston was



<P>wanting him to dance with Mrs. Elton himself, and that their business



<P>was to help to persuade him into it, which was done pretty soon.--



<P>Mr. Weston and Mrs. Elton led the way, Mr. Frank Churchill and Miss



<P>Woodhouse followed.&nbsp; Emma must submit to stand second to Mrs. Elton,



<P>though she had always considered the ball as peculiarly for her.



<P>It was almost enough to make her think of marrying.&nbsp; Mrs. Elton

had



<P>undoubtedly the advantage, at this time, in vanity completely gratified;



<P>for though she had intended to begin with Frank Churchill, she could



<P>not lose by the change.&nbsp; Mr. Weston might be his son's superior.--



<P>In spite of this little rub, however, Emma was smiling with enjoyment,



<P>delighted to see the respectable length of the set as it was forming,



<P>and to feel that she had so many hours of unusual festivity before her.--



<P>She was more disturbed by Mr. Knightley's not dancing than by any



<P>thing else.--There he was, among the standers-by, where he ought not



<P>to be; he ought to be dancing,--not classing himself with the husbands,



<P>and fathers, and whist-players, who were pretending to feel an interest



<P>in the dance till their rubbers were made up,--so young as he looked!--



<P>He could not have appeared to greater advantage perhaps anywhere,



<P>than where he had placed himself.&nbsp; His tall, firm, upright figure,



<P>among the bulky forms and stooping shoulders of the elderly men,



<P>was such as Emma felt must draw every body's eyes; and, excepting her



<P>own partner, there was not one among the whole row of young men



<P>who could be compared with him.--He moved a few steps nearer,



<P>and those few steps were enough to prove in how gentlemanlike



<P>a manner, with what natural grace, he must have danced, would he



<P>but take the trouble.--Whenever she caught his eye, she forced him



<P>to smile; but in general he was looking grave.&nbsp; She wished he could



<P>love a ballroom better, and could like Frank Churchill better.--



<P>He seemed often observing her.&nbsp; She must not flatter herself that

he



<P>thought of her dancing, but if he were criticising her behaviour,



<P>she did not feel afraid.&nbsp; There was nothing like flirtation between



<P>her and her partner.&nbsp; They seemed more like cheerful, easy friends,



<P>than lovers.&nbsp; That Frank Churchill thought less of her than he

had done,



<P>was indubitable.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The ball proceeded pleasantly.&nbsp; The anxious cares, the incessant



<P>attentions of Mrs. Weston, were not thrown away.&nbsp; Every body



<P>seemed happy; and the praise of being a delightful ball,



<P>which is seldom bestowed till after a ball has ceased to be,



<P>was repeatedly given in the very beginning of the existence of this.



<P>Of very important, very recordable events, it was not more productive



<P>than such meetings usually are.&nbsp; There was one, however, which

Emma



<P>thought something of.--The two last dances before supper were begun,



<P>and Harriet had no partner;--the only young lady sitting down;--



<P>and so equal had been hitherto the number of dancers, that how there



<P>could be any one disengaged was the wonder!--But Emma's wonder



<P>lessened soon afterwards, on seeing Mr. Elton sauntering about.



<P>He would not ask Harriet to dance if it were possible to be avoided:



<P>she was sure he would not--and she was expecting him every moment to



<P>escape into the card-room.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Escape, however, was not his plan.&nbsp; He came to the part of the

room



<P>where the sitters-by were collected, spoke to some, and walked about



<P>in front of them, as if to shew his liberty, and his resolution



<P>of maintaining it.&nbsp; He did not omit being sometimes directly



<P>before Miss Smith, or speaking to those who were close to her.--



<P>Emma saw it.&nbsp; She was not yet dancing; she was working her way



<P>up from the bottom, and had therefore leisure to look around,



<P>and by only turning her head a little she saw it all.&nbsp; When she

was



<P>half-way up the set, the whole group were exactly behind her, and she



<P>would no longer allow her eyes to watch; but Mr. Elton was so near,



<P>that she heard every syllable of a dialogue which just then took



<P>place between him and Mrs. Weston; and she perceived that his wife,



<P>who was standing immediately above her, was not only listening also,



<P>but even encouraging him by significant glances.--The kind-hearted,



<P>gentle Mrs. Weston had left her seat to join him and say, "Do not



<P>you dance, Mr. Elton?" to which his prompt reply was, "Most readily,



<P>Mrs. Weston, if you will dance with me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Me!--oh! no--I would get you a better partner than myself.



<P>I am no dancer."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If Mrs. Gilbert wishes to dance," said he, "I shall have great pleasure,



<P>I am sure--for, though beginning to feel myself rather an old married

man,



<P>and that my dancing days are over, it would give me very great



<P>pleasure at any time to stand up with an old friend like Mrs. Gilbert."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mrs. Gilbert does not mean to dance, but there is a young lady



<P>disengaged whom I should be very glad to see dancing--Miss Smith."



<P>"Miss Smith!--oh!--I had not observed.--You are extremely obliging--



<P>and if I were not an old married man.--But my dancing days are over,



<P>Mrs. Weston.&nbsp; You will excuse me.&nbsp; Any thing else I should

be most happy



<P>to do, at your command--but my dancing days are over."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Weston said no more; and Emma could imagine with what



<P>surprize and mortification she must be returning to her seat.



<P>This was Mr. Elton! the amiable, obliging, gentle Mr. Elton.--



<P>She looked round for a moment; he had joined Mr. Knightley at a



<P>little distance, and was arranging himself for settled conversation,



<P>while smiles of high glee passed between him and his wife.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She would not look again.&nbsp; Her heart was in a glow, and she feared



<P>her face might be as hot.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In another moment a happier sight caught her;--Mr. Knightley



<P>leading Harriet to the set!--Never had she been more surprized,



<P>seldom more delighted, than at that instant.&nbsp; She was all pleasure



<P>and gratitude, both for Harriet and herself, and longed to be



<P>thanking him; and though too distant for speech, her countenance



<P>said much, as soon as she could catch his eye again.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>His dancing proved to be just what she had believed it,



<P>extremely good; and Harriet would have seemed almost too lucky,



<P>if it had not been for the cruel state of things before, and for



<P>the very complete enjoyment and very high sense of the distinction



<P>which her happy features announced.&nbsp; It was not thrown away on

her,



<P>she bounded higher than ever, flew farther down the middle,



<P>and was in a continual course of smiles.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Elton had retreated into the card-room, looking (Emma trusted)



<P>very foolish.&nbsp; She did not think he was quite so hardened as his

wife,



<P>though growing very like her;--she spoke some of her feelings,



<P>by observing audibly to her partner,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Knightley has taken pity on poor little Miss Smith!--Very goodnatured,



<P>I declare."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Supper was announced.&nbsp; The move began; and Miss Bates might be



<P>heard from that moment, without interruption, till her being



<P>seated at table and taking up her spoon.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Jane, Jane, my dear Jane, where are you?--Here is your tippet.



<P>Mrs. Weston begs you to put on your tippet.&nbsp; She says she is afraid



<P>there will be draughts in the passage, though every thing has



<P>been done--One door nailed up--Quantities of matting--My dear Jane,



<P>indeed you must.&nbsp; Mr. Churchill, oh! you are too obliging!



<P>How well you put it on!--so gratified!&nbsp; Excellent dancing indeed!--



<P>Yes, my dear, I ran home, as I said I should, to help grandmama



<P>to bed, and got back again, and nobody missed me.--I set off without



<P>saying a word, just as I told you.&nbsp; Grandmama was quite well,



<P>had a charming evening with Mr. Woodhouse, a vast deal of chat,



<P>and backgammon.--Tea was made downstairs, biscuits and baked apples



<P>and wine before she came away:&nbsp; amazing luck in some of her throws:



<P>and she inquired a great deal about you, how you were amused,



<P>and who were your partners.&nbsp; `Oh!' said I, `I shall not forestall

Jane;



<P>I left her dancing with Mr. George Otway; she will love to tell you



<P>all about it herself to-morrow: her first partner was Mr. Elton,



<P>I do not know who will ask her next, perhaps Mr. William Cox.'



<P>My dear sir, you are too obliging.--Is there nobody you would



<P>not rather?--I am not helpless.&nbsp; Sir, you are most kind.&nbsp;

Upon my word,



<P>Jane on one arm, and me on the other!--Stop, stop, let us stand



<P>a little back, Mrs. Elton is going; dear Mrs. Elton, how elegant



<P>she looks!--Beautiful lace!--Now we all follow in her train.



<P>Quite the queen of the evening!--Well, here we are at the passage.



<P>Two steps, Jane, take care of the two steps.&nbsp; Oh! no, there is



<P>but one.&nbsp; Well, I was persuaded there were two.&nbsp; How very

odd!



<P>I was convinced there were two, and there is but one.&nbsp; I never

saw any



<P>thing equal to the comfort and style--Candles everywhere.--I was telling



<P>you of your grandmama, Jane,--There was a little disappointment.--



<P>The baked apples and biscuits, excellent in their way, you know;



<P>but there was a delicate fricassee of sweetbread and some asparagus



<P>brought in at first, and good Mr. Woodhouse, not thinking the



<P>asparagus quite boiled enough, sent it all out again.&nbsp; Now there



<P>is nothing grandmama loves better than sweetbread and asparagus--



<P>so she was rather disappointed, but we agreed we would not speak of

it



<P>to any body, for fear of its getting round to dear Miss Woodhouse,



<P>who would be so very much concerned!--Well, this is brilliant!



<P>I am all amazement! could not have supposed any thing!--Such



<P>elegance and profusion!--I have seen nothing like it since--



<P>Well, where shall we sit? where shall we sit?&nbsp; Anywhere, so that



<P>Jane is not in a draught.&nbsp; Where I sit is of no consequence.



<P>Oh! do you recommend this side?--Well, I am sure, Mr. Churchill--



<P>only it seems too good--but just as you please.&nbsp; What you direct



<P>in this house cannot be wrong.&nbsp; Dear Jane, how shall we ever



<P>recollect half the dishes for grandmama?&nbsp; Soup too!&nbsp; Bless

me!



<P>I should not be helped so soon, but it smells most excellent, and I



<P>cannot help beginning."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma had no opportunity of speaking to Mr. Knightley till



<P>after supper; but, when they were all in the ballroom again,



<P>her eyes invited him irresistibly to come to her and be thanked.



<P>He was warm in his reprobation of Mr. Elton's conduct; it had been



<P>unpardonable rudeness; and Mrs. Elton's looks also received the due



<P>share of censure.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"They aimed at wounding more than Harriet," said he.&nbsp; "Emma, why



<P>is it that they are your enemies?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He looked with smiling penetration; and, on receiving



<P>no answer, added, "She ought not to be angry with you, I suspect,



<P>whatever he may be.--To that surmise, you say nothing, of course;



<P>but confess, Emma, that you did want him to marry Harriet."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I did," replied Emma, "and they cannot forgive me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He shook his head; but there was a smile of indulgence with it,



<P>and he only said,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I shall not scold you.&nbsp; I leave you to your own reflections."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Can you trust me with such flatterers?--Does my vain spirit ever



<P>tell me I am wrong?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not your vain spirit, but your serious spirit.--If one leads



<P>you wrong, I am sure the other tells you of it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do own myself to have been completely mistaken in Mr. Elton.



<P>There is a littleness about him which you discovered, and which I



<P>did not:&nbsp; and I was fully convinced of his being in love with Harriet.



<P>It was through a series of strange blunders!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And, in return for your acknowledging so much, I will do you the justice



<P>to say, that you would have chosen for him better than he has chosen

for



<P>himself.--Harriet Smith has some first-rate qualities, which Mrs. Elton



<P>is totally without.&nbsp; An unpretending, single-minded, artless girl--



<P>infinitely to be preferred by any man of sense and taste to such



<P>a woman as Mrs. Elton.&nbsp; I found Harriet more conversable than I

expected."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma was extremely gratified.--They were interrupted by the bustle



<P>of Mr. Weston calling on every body to begin dancing again.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Come Miss Woodhouse, Miss Otway, Miss Fairfax, what are you all doing?--



<P>Come Emma, set your companions the example.&nbsp; Every body is lazy!



<P>Every body is asleep!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am ready," said Emma, "whenever I am wanted."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Whom are you going to dance with?" asked Mr. Knightley.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She hesitated a moment, and then replied, "With you, if you will



<P>ask me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Will you?" said he, offering his hand.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Indeed I will.&nbsp; You have shewn that you can dance, and you know

we



<P>are not really so much brother and sister as to make it at all improper."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Brother and sister! no, indeed."



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.03 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 03</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER III</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>This little explanation with Mr. Knightley gave Emma considerable



<P>pleasure.&nbsp; It was one of the agreeable recollections of the ball,



<P>which she walked about the lawn the next morning to enjoy.--She was



<P>extremely glad that they had come to so good an understanding respecting



<P>the Eltons, and that their opinions of both husband and wife were so



<P>much alike; and his praise of Harriet, his concession in her favour,



<P>was peculiarly gratifying.&nbsp; The impertinence of the Eltons, which

for



<P>a few minutes had threatened to ruin the rest of her evening, had been



<P>the occasion of some of its highest satisfactions; and she looked



<P>forward to another happy result--the cure of Harriet's infatuation.--



<P>From Harriet's manner of speaking of the circumstance before they



<P>quitted the ballroom, she had strong hopes.&nbsp; It seemed as if her

eyes



<P>were suddenly opened, and she were enabled to see that Mr. Elton



<P>was not the superior creature she had believed him.&nbsp; The fever



<P>was over, and Emma could harbour little fear of the pulse being



<P>quickened again by injurious courtesy.&nbsp; She depended on the evil



<P>feelings of the Eltons for supplying all the discipline of pointed



<P>neglect that could be farther requisite.--Harriet rational,



<P>Frank Churchill not too much in love, and Mr. Knightley not



<P>wanting to quarrel with her, how very happy a summer must be before

her!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was not to see Frank Churchill this morning.&nbsp; He had told



<P>her that he could not allow himself the pleasure of stopping



<P>at Hartfield, as he was to be at home by the middle of the day.



<P>She did not regret it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Having arranged all these matters, looked them through, and put them

all



<P>to rights, she was just turning to the house with spirits freshened

up



<P>for the demands of the two little boys, as well as of their grandpapa,



<P>when the great iron sweep-gate opened, and two persons entered



<P>whom she had never less expected to see together--Frank Churchill,



<P>with Harriet leaning on his arm--actually Harriet!--A moment



<P>sufficed to convince her that something extraordinary had happened.



<P>Harriet looked white and frightened, and he was trying to cheer her.--



<P>The iron gates and the front-door were not twenty yards asunder;--



<P>they were all three soon in the hall, and Harriet immediately sinking



<P>into a chair fainted away.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A young lady who faints, must be recovered; questions must be answered,



<P>and surprizes be explained.&nbsp; Such events are very interesting,



<P>but the suspense of them cannot last long.&nbsp; A few minutes made

Emma



<P>acquainted with the whole.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Smith, and Miss Bickerton, another parlour boarder at



<P>Mrs. Goddard's, who had been also at the ball, had walked out together,



<P>and taken a road, the Richmond road, which, though apparently public



<P>enough for safety, had led them into alarm.--About half a mile



<P>beyond Highbury, making a sudden turn, and deeply shaded by elms



<P>on each side, it became for a considerable stretch very retired;



<P>and when the young ladies had advanced some way into it,



<P>they had suddenly perceived at a small distance before them,



<P>on a broader patch of greensward by the side, a party of gipsies.



<P>A child on the watch, came towards them to beg; and Miss Bickerton,



<P>excessively frightened, gave a great scream, and calling on Harriet



<P>to follow her, ran up a steep bank, cleared a slight hedge at the top,



<P>and made the best of her way by a short cut back to Highbury.



<P>But poor Harriet could not follow.&nbsp; She had suffered very much



<P>from cramp after dancing, and her first attempt to mount the bank



<P>brought on such a return of it as made her absolutely powerless--



<P>and in this state, and exceedingly terrified, she had been obliged



<P>to remain.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>How the trampers might have behaved, had the young ladies been



<P>more courageous, must be doubtful; but such an invitation for attack



<P>could not be resisted; and Harriet was soon assailed by half a



<P>dozen children, headed by a stout woman and a great boy, all clamorous,



<P>and impertinent in look, though not absolutely in word.--More and



<P>more frightened, she immediately promised them money, and taking out



<P>her purse, gave them a shilling, and begged them not to want more,



<P>or to use her ill.--She was then able to walk, though but slowly,



<P>and was moving away--but her terror and her purse were too tempting,



<P>and she was followed, or rather surrounded, by the whole gang,



<P>demanding more.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In this state Frank Churchill had found her, she trembling



<P>and conditioning, they loud and insolent.&nbsp; By a most fortunate



<P>chance his leaving Highbury had been delayed so as to bring him



<P>to her assistance at this critical moment.&nbsp; The pleasantness



<P>of the morning had induced him to walk forward, and leave his



<P>horses to meet him by another road, a mile or two beyond Highbury--



<P>and happening to have borrowed a pair of scissors the night before



<P>of Miss Bates, and to have forgotten to restore them, he had



<P>been obliged to stop at her door, and go in for a few minutes:



<P>he was therefore later than he had intended; and being on foot,



<P>was unseen by the whole party till almost close to them.



<P>The terror which the woman and boy had been creating in Harriet



<P>was then their own portion.&nbsp; He had left them completely frightened;



<P>and Harriet eagerly clinging to him, and hardly able to speak,



<P>had just strength enough to reach Hartfield, before her spirits



<P>were quite overcome.&nbsp; It was his idea to bring her to Hartfield:



<P>he had thought of no other place.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This was the amount of the whole story,--of his communication and



<P>of Harriet's as soon as she had recovered her senses and speech.--



<P>He dared not stay longer than to see her well; these several delays



<P>left him not another minute to lose; and Emma engaging to give



<P>assurance of her safety to Mrs. Goddard, and notice of there



<P>being such a set of people in the neighbourhood to Mr. Knightley,



<P>he set off, with all the grateful blessings that she could utter



<P>for her friend and herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Such an adventure as this,--a fine young man and a lovely young



<P>woman thrown together in such a way, could hardly fail of suggesting



<P>certain ideas to the coldest heart and the steadiest brain.



<P>So Emma thought, at least.&nbsp; Could a linguist, could a grammarian,



<P>could even a mathematician have seen what she did, have witnessed their



<P>appearance together, and heard their history of it, without feeling



<P>that circumstances had been at work to make them peculiarly interesting



<P>to each other?--How much more must an imaginist, like herself,



<P>be on fire with speculation and foresight!--especially with such



<P>a groundwork of anticipation as her mind had already made.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was a very extraordinary thing!&nbsp; Nothing of the sort had ever



<P>occurred before to any young ladies in the place, within her memory;



<P>no rencontre, no alarm of the kind;--and now it had happened



<P>to the very person, and at the very hour, when the other very



<P>person was chancing to pass by to rescue her!--It certainly



<P>was very extraordinary!--And knowing, as she did, the favourable



<P>state of mind of each at this period, it struck her the more.



<P>He was wishing to get the better of his attachment to herself,



<P>she just recovering from her mania for Mr. Elton.&nbsp; It seemed as

if



<P>every thing united to promise the most interesting consequences.



<P>It was not possible that the occurrence should not be strongly



<P>recommending each to the other.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In the few minutes' conversation which she had yet had with him,



<P>while Harriet had been partially insensible, he had spoken of her terror,



<P>her naivete, her fervour as she seized and clung to his arm, with a



<P>sensibility amused and delighted; and just at last, after Harriet's



<P>own account had been given, he had expressed his indignation



<P>at the abominable folly of Miss Bickerton in the warmest terms.



<P>Every thing was to take its natural course, however, neither impelled



<P>nor assisted.&nbsp; She would not stir a step, nor drop a hint.



<P>No, she had had enough of interference.&nbsp; There could be no harm



<P>in a scheme, a mere passive scheme.&nbsp; It was no more than a wish.



<P>Beyond it she would on no account proceed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma's first resolution was to keep her father from the knowledge



<P>of what had passed,--aware of the anxiety and alarm it would occasion:



<P>but she soon felt that concealment must be impossible.&nbsp; Within

half



<P>an hour it was known all over Highbury.&nbsp; It was the very event



<P>to engage those who talk most, the young and the low; and all



<P>the youth and servants in the place were soon in the happiness of



<P>frightful news.&nbsp; The last night's ball seemed lost in the gipsies.



<P>Poor Mr. Woodhouse trembled as he sat, and, as Emma had foreseen,



<P>would scarcely be satisfied without their promising never to go



<P>beyond the shrubbery again.&nbsp; It was some comfort to him that many



<P>inquiries after himself and Miss Woodhouse (for his neighbours



<P>knew that he loved to be inquired after), as well as Miss Smith,



<P>were coming in during the rest of the day; and he had the pleasure



<P>of returning for answer, that they were all very indifferent--



<P>which, though not exactly true, for she was perfectly well,



<P>and Harriet not much otherwise, Emma would not interfere with.



<P>She had an unhappy state of health in general for the child of such



<P>a man, for she hardly knew what indisposition was; and if he did not



<P>invent illnesses for her, she could make no figure in a message.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The gipsies did not wait for the operations of justice; they took



<P>themselves off in a hurry.&nbsp; The young ladies of Highbury might

have



<P>walked again in safety before their panic began, and the whole



<P>history dwindled soon into a matter of little importance but to Emma



<P>and her nephews:--in her imagination it maintained its ground,



<P>and Henry and John were still asking every day for the story of



<P>Harriet and the gipsies, and still tenaciously setting her right



<P>if she varied in the slightest particular from the original recital.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 17</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XVII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Mrs. Weston's friends were all made happy by her safety;



<P>and if the satisfaction of her well-doing could be increased



<P>to Emma, it was by knowing her to be the mother of a little girl.



<P>She had been decided in wishing for a Miss Weston.&nbsp; She would



<P>not acknowledge that it was with any view of making a match



<P>for her, hereafter, with either of Isabella's sons; but she was



<P>convinced that a daughter would suit both father and mother best.



<P>It would be a great comfort to Mr. Weston, as he grew older--



<P>and even Mr. Weston might be growing older ten years hence--to have



<P>his fireside enlivened by the sports and the nonsense, the freaks



<P>and the fancies of a child never banished from home; and Mrs. Weston--



<P>no one could doubt that a daughter would be most to her; and it



<P>would be quite a pity that any one who so well knew how to teach,



<P>should not have their powers in exercise again.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She has had the advantage, you know, of practising on me,"



<P>she continued--"like La Baronne d'Almane on La Comtesse d'Ostalis,



<P>in Madame de Genlis' Adelaide and Theodore, and we shall now see



<P>her own little Adelaide educated on a more perfect plan."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That is," replied Mr. Knightley, "she will indulge her even more



<P>than she did you, and believe that she does not indulge her at all.



<P>It will be the only difference."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Poor child!" cried Emma; "at that rate, what will become of her?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nothing very bad.--The fate of thousands.&nbsp; She will be disagreeable



<P>in infancy, and correct herself as she grows older.&nbsp; I am losing



<P>all my bitterness against spoilt children, my dearest Emma.



<P>I, who am owing all my happiness to you, would not it be horrible



<P>ingratitude in me to be severe on them?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma laughed, and replied:&nbsp; "But I had the assistance of all



<P>your endeavours to counteract the indulgence of other people.



<P>I doubt whether my own sense would have corrected me without it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do you?--I have no doubt.&nbsp; Nature gave you understanding:--



<P>Miss Taylor gave you principles.&nbsp; You must have done well.



<P>My interference was quite as likely to do harm as good.&nbsp; It was



<P>very natural for you to say, what right has he to lecture me?--



<P>and I am afraid very natural for you to feel that it was done



<P>in a disagreeable manner.&nbsp; I do not believe I did you any good.



<P>The good was all to myself, by making you an object of the tenderest



<P>affection to me.&nbsp; I could not think about you so much without doating



<P>on you, faults and all; and by dint of fancying so many errors,



<P>have been in love with you ever since you were thirteen at least."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am sure you were of use to me," cried Emma.&nbsp; "I was very often



<P>influenced rightly by you--oftener than I would own at the time.



<P>I am very sure you did me good.&nbsp; And if poor little Anna Weston

is



<P>to be spoiled, it will be the greatest humanity in you to do as much



<P>for her as you have done for me, except falling in love with her



<P>when she is thirteen."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How often, when you were a girl, have you said to me, with one



<P>of your saucy looks--`Mr. Knightley, I am going to do so-and-so;



<P>papa says I may, or I have Miss Taylor's leave'--something which,



<P>you knew, I did not approve.&nbsp; In such cases my interference was

giving



<P>you two bad feelings instead of one."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What an amiable creature I was!--No wonder you should hold



<P>my speeches in such affectionate remembrance."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"`Mr. Knightley.'--You always called me, `Mr. Knightley;' and,



<P>from habit, it has not so very formal a sound.--And yet it is formal.



<P>I want you to call me something else, but I do not know what."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I remember once calling you `George,' in one of my amiable fits,



<P>about ten years ago.&nbsp; I did it because I thought it would offend

you;



<P>but, as you made no objection, I never did it again."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And cannot you call me `George' now?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Impossible!--I never can call you any thing but `Mr. Knightley.'



<P>I will not promise even to equal the elegant terseness of Mrs. Elton,



<P>by calling you Mr. K.--But I will promise," she added presently,



<P>laughing and blushing--"I will promise to call you once by your



<P>Christian name.&nbsp; I do not say when, but perhaps you may guess



<P>where;--in the building in which N. takes M. for better, for worse."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma grieved that she could not be more openly just to one



<P>important service which his better sense would have rendered her,



<P>to the advice which would have saved her from the worst of all



<P>her womanly follies--her wilful intimacy with Harriet Smith;



<P>but it was too tender a subject.--She could not enter on it.--



<P>Harriet was very seldom mentioned between them.&nbsp; This, on his side,



<P>might merely proceed from her not being thought of; but Emma



<P>was rather inclined to attribute it to delicacy, and a suspicion,



<P>from some appearances, that their friendship were declining.



<P>She was aware herself, that, parting under any other circumstances,



<P>they certainly should have corresponded more, and that her



<P>intelligence would not have rested, as it now almost wholly did,



<P>on Isabella's letters.&nbsp; He might observe that it was so.&nbsp;

The pain



<P>of being obliged to practise concealment towards him, was very little



<P>inferior to the pain of having made Harriet unhappy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Isabella sent quite as good an account of her visitor as could



<P>be expected; on her first arrival she had thought her out of spirits,



<P>which appeared perfectly natural, as there was a dentist to



<P>be consulted; but, since that business had been over, she did not



<P>appear to find Harriet different from what she had known her before.--



<P>Isabella, to be sure, was no very quick observer; yet if Harriet



<P>had not been equal to playing with the children, it would not have



<P>escaped her.&nbsp; Emma's comforts and hopes were most agreeably carried

on,



<P>by Harriet's being to stay longer; her fortnight was likely to be



<P>a month at least.&nbsp; Mr. and Mrs. John Knightley were to come down



<P>in August, and she was invited to remain till they could bring her back.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"John does not even mention your friend," said Mr. Knightley.



<P>"Here is his answer, if you like to see it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was the answer to the communication of his intended marriage.



<P>Emma accepted it with a very eager hand, with an impatience all alive



<P>to know what he would say about it, and not at all checked by hearing



<P>that her friend was unmentioned.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"John enters like a brother into my happiness," continued Mr. Knightley,



<P>"but he is no complimenter; and though I well know him to have,



<P>likewise, a most brotherly affection for you, he is so far from



<P>making flourishes, that any other young woman might think him rather



<P>cool in her praise.&nbsp; But I am not afraid of your seeing what he

writes."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He writes like a sensible man," replied Emma, when she had read



<P>the letter.&nbsp; "I honour his sincerity.&nbsp; It is very plain that

he



<P>considers the good fortune of the engagement as all on my side,



<P>but that he is not without hope of my growing, in time, as worthy



<P>of your affection, as you think me already.&nbsp; Had he said any thing



<P>to bear a different construction, I should not have believed him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My Emma, he means no such thing.&nbsp; He only means--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He and I should differ very little in our estimation of the two,"



<P>interrupted she, with a sort of serious smile--"much less, perhaps,



<P>than he is aware of, if we could enter without ceremony or reserve



<P>on the subject."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Emma, my dear Emma--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh!" she cried with more thorough gaiety, "if you fancy your



<P>brother does not do me justice, only wait till my dear father is in



<P>the secret, and hear his opinion.&nbsp; Depend upon it, he will be much



<P>farther from doing you justice.&nbsp; He will think all the happiness,



<P>all the advantage, on your side of the question; all the merit



<P>on mine.&nbsp; I wish I may not sink into `poor Emma' with him at once.--



<P>His tender compassion towards oppressed worth can go no farther."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah!" he cried, "I wish your father might be half as easily convinced



<P>as John will be, of our having every right that equal worth can give,



<P>to be happy together.&nbsp; I am amused by one part of John's letter--



<P>did you notice it?--where he says, that my information did not take



<P>him wholly by surprize, that he was rather in expectation of hearing



<P>something of the kind."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If I understand your brother, he only means so far as your having



<P>some thoughts of marrying.&nbsp; He had no idea of me.&nbsp; He seems

perfectly



<P>unprepared for that."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, yes--but I am amused that he should have seen so far into



<P>my feelings.&nbsp; What has he been judging by?--I am not conscious



<P>of any difference in my spirits or conversation that could prepare



<P>him at this time for my marrying any more than at another.--



<P>But it was so, I suppose.&nbsp; I dare say there was a difference when

I



<P>was staying with them the other day.&nbsp; I believe I did not play



<P>with the children quite so much as usual.&nbsp; I remember one evening



<P>the poor boys saying, `Uncle seems always tired now.'"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The time was coming when the news must spread farther, and other persons'



<P>reception of it tried.&nbsp; As soon as Mrs. Weston was sufficiently



<P>recovered to admit Mr. Woodhouse's visits, Emma having it in view



<P>that her gentle reasonings should be employed in the cause,



<P>resolved first to announce it at home, and then at Randalls.--



<P>But how to break it to her father at last!--She had bound herself



<P>to do it, in such an hour of Mr. Knightley's absence, or when it



<P>came to the point her heart would have failed her, and she must



<P>have put it off; but Mr. Knightley was to come at such a time,



<P>and follow up the beginning she was to make.--She was forced



<P>to speak, and to speak cheerfully too.&nbsp; She must not make it a

more



<P>decided subject of misery to him, by a melancholy tone herself.



<P>She must not appear to think it a misfortune.--With all the spirits



<P>she could command, she prepared him first for something strange,



<P>and then, in a few words, said, that if his consent and approbation



<P>could be obtained--which, she trusted, would be attended with



<P>no difficulty, since it was a plan to promote the happiness of all--



<P>she and Mr. Knightley meant to marry; by which means Hartfield



<P>would receive the constant addition of that person's company



<P>whom she knew he loved, next to his daughters and Mrs. Weston,



<P>best in the world.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Poor man!--it was at first a considerable shock to him, and he tried



<P>earnestly to dissuade her from it.&nbsp; She was reminded, more than

once,



<P>of having always said she would never marry, and assured that it



<P>would be a great deal better for her to remain single; and told of



<P>poor Isabella, and poor Miss Taylor.--But it would not do.&nbsp; Emma

hung



<P>about him affectionately, and smiled, and said it must be so; and that



<P>he must not class her with Isabella and Mrs. Weston, whose marriages



<P>taking them from Hartfield, had, indeed, made a melancholy change:



<P>but she was not going from Hartfield; she should be always there;



<P>she was introducing no change in their numbers or their comforts but



<P>for the better; and she was very sure that he would be a great deal



<P>the happier for having Mr. Knightley always at hand, when he were once



<P>got used to the idea.--Did he not love Mr. Knightley very much?--



<P>He would not deny that he did, she was sure.--Whom did he ever want



<P>to consult on business but Mr. Knightley?--Who was so useful to him,



<P>who so ready to write his letters, who so glad to assist him?--



<P>Who so cheerful, so attentive, so attached to him?--Would not he



<P>like to have him always on the spot?--Yes.&nbsp; That was all very true.



<P>Mr. Knightley could not be there too often; he should be glad to see



<P>him every day;--but they did see him every day as it was.--Why could



<P>not they go on as they had done?

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Woodhouse could not be soon reconciled; but the worst was overcome,



<P>the idea was given; time and continual repetition must do the rest.--



<P>To Emma's entreaties and assurances succeeded Mr. Knightley's,



<P>whose fond praise of her gave the subject even a kind of welcome;



<P>and he was soon used to be talked to by each, on every fair occasion.--



<P>They had all the assistance which Isabella could give, by letters



<P>of the strongest approbation; and Mrs. Weston was ready,



<P>on the first meeting, to consider the subject in the most



<P>serviceable light--first, as a settled, and, secondly, as a good one--



<P>well aware of the nearly equal importance of the two recommendations



<P>to Mr. Woodhouse's mind.--It was agreed upon, as what was to be;



<P>and every body by whom he was used to be guided assuring him that



<P>it would be for his happiness; and having some feelings himself



<P>which almost admitted it, he began to think that some time or other--



<P>in another year or two, perhaps--it might not be so very bad



<P>if the marriage did take place.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Weston was acting no part, feigning no feelings in all that she



<P>said to him in favour of the event.--She had been extremely surprized,



<P>never more so, than when Emma first opened the affair to her;



<P>but she saw in it only increase of happiness to all, and had



<P>no scruple in urging him to the utmost.--She had such a regard



<P>for Mr. Knightley, as to think he deserved even her dearest Emma;



<P>and it was in every respect so proper, suitable, and unexceptionable



<P>a connexion, and in one respect, one point of the highest importance,



<P>so peculiarly eligible, so singularly fortunate, that now it seemed



<P>as if Emma could not safely have attached herself to any other creature,



<P>and that she had herself been the stupidest of beings in not having



<P>thought of it, and wished it long ago.--How very few of those men



<P>in a rank of life to address Emma would have renounced their own



<P>home for Hartfield!&nbsp; And who but Mr. Knightley could know and bear



<P>with Mr. Woodhouse, so as to make such an arrangement desirable!--



<P>The difficulty of disposing of poor Mr. Woodhouse had been always



<P>felt in her husband's plans and her own, for a marriage between Frank



<P>and Emma.&nbsp; How to settle the claims of Enscombe and Hartfield had



<P>been a continual impediment--less acknowledged by Mr. Weston than



<P>by herself--but even he had never been able to finish the subject



<P>better than by saying--"Those matters will take care of themselves;



<P>the young people will find a way."&nbsp; But here there was nothing

to be



<P>shifted off in a wild speculation on the future.&nbsp; It was all right,



<P>all open, all equal.&nbsp; No sacrifice on any side worth the name.



<P>It was a union of the highest promise of felicity in itself,



<P>and without one real, rational difficulty to oppose or delay it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Weston, with her baby on her knee, indulging in such reflections



<P>as these, was one of the happiest women in the world.&nbsp; If any thing



<P>could increase her delight, it was perceiving that the baby would



<P>soon have outgrown its first set of caps.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The news was universally a surprize wherever it spread;



<P>and Mr. Weston had his five minutes share of it; but five minutes



<P>were enough to familiarise the idea to his quickness of mind.--
