<P>He saw the advantages of the match, and rejoiced in them with all



<P>the constancy of his wife; but the wonder of it was very soon nothing;



<P>and by the end of an hour he was not far from believing that he



<P>had always foreseen it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is to be a secret, I conclude," said he.&nbsp; "These matters are



<P>always a secret, till it is found out that every body knows them.



<P>Only let me be told when I may speak out.--I wonder whether Jane has



<P>any suspicion."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He went to Highbury the next morning, and satisfied himself on



<P>that point.&nbsp; He told her the news.&nbsp; Was not she like a daughter,



<P>his eldest daughter?--he must tell her; and Miss Bates being present,



<P>it passed, of course, to Mrs. Cole, Mrs. Perry, and Mrs. Elton,



<P>immediately afterwards.&nbsp; It was no more than the principals were



<P>prepared for; they had calculated from the time of its being known



<P>at Randalls, how soon it would be over Highbury; and were thinking



<P>of themselves, as the evening wonder in many a family circle,



<P>with great sagacity.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In general, it was a very well approved match.&nbsp; Some might think

him,



<P>and others might think her, the most in luck.&nbsp; One set might



<P>recommend their all removing to Donwell, and leaving Hartfield



<P>for the John Knightleys; and another might predict disagreements



<P>among their servants; but yet, upon the whole, there was no serious



<P>objection raised, except in one habitation, the Vicarage.--There,



<P>the surprize was not softened by any satisfaction.&nbsp; Mr. Elton



<P>cared little about it, compared with his wife; he only hoped "the



<P>young lady's pride would now be contented;" and supposed "she had



<P>always meant to catch Knightley if she could;" and, on the point



<P>of living at Hartfield, could daringly exclaim, "Rather he than I!"--



<P>But Mrs. Elton was very much discomposed indeed.--"Poor Knightley!



<P>poor fellow!--sad business for him.--She was extremely concerned;



<P>for, though very eccentric, he had a thousand good qualities.--



<P>How could he be so taken in?--Did not think him at all in love--



<P>not in the least.--Poor Knightley!--There would be an end of all



<P>pleasant intercourse with him.--How happy he had been to come and dine



<P>with them whenever they asked him!&nbsp; But that would be all over

now.--



<P>Poor fellow!--No more exploring parties to Donwell made for her.



<P>Oh! no; there would be a Mrs. Knightley to throw cold water on



<P>every thing.--Extremely disagreeable!&nbsp; But she was not at all sorry



<P>that she had abused the housekeeper the other day.--Shocking plan,



<P>living together.&nbsp; It would never do.&nbsp; She knew a family near

Maple



<P>Grove who had tried it, and been obliged to separate before the end



<P>of the first quarter.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 01</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B><FONT SIZE=+1>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; VOLUME

III</FONT></B>



<P><B>CHAPTER I</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>A very little quiet reflection was enough to satisfy Emma as to the



<P>nature of her agitation on hearing this news of Frank Churchill.



<P>She was soon convinced that it was not for herself she was feeling at



<P>all apprehensive or embarrassed; it was for him.&nbsp; Her own attachment



<P>had really subsided into a mere nothing; it was not worth thinking of;--



<P>but if he, who had undoubtedly been always so much the most in love



<P>of the two, were to be returning with the same warmth of sentiment



<P>which he had taken away, it would be very distressing.&nbsp; If a separation



<P>of two months should not have cooled him, there were dangers and evils



<P>before her:--caution for him and for herself would be necessary.



<P>She did not mean to have her own affections entangled again,



<P>and it would be incumbent on her to avoid any encouragement of his.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She wished she might be able to keep him from an absolute declaration.



<P>That would be so very painful a conclusion of their present acquaintance!



<P>and yet, she could not help rather anticipating something decisive.



<P>She felt as if the spring would not pass without bringing a crisis,



<P>an event, a something to alter her present composed and tranquil state.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was not very long, though rather longer than Mr. Weston had foreseen,



<P>before she had the power of forming some opinion of Frank Churchill's



<P>feelings.&nbsp; The Enscombe family were not in town quite so soon as

had



<P>been imagined, but he was at Highbury very soon afterwards.&nbsp; He

rode



<P>down for a couple of hours; he could not yet do more; but as he came



<P>from Randalls immediately to Hartfield, she could then exercise all



<P>her quick observation, and speedily determine how he was influenced,



<P>and how she must act.&nbsp; They met with the utmost friendliness.



<P>There could be no doubt of his great pleasure in seeing her.



<P>But she had an almost instant doubt of his caring for her as he



<P>had done, of his feeling the same tenderness in the same degree.



<P>She watched him well.&nbsp; It was a clear thing he was less in love

than he



<P>had been.&nbsp; Absence, with the conviction probably of her indifference,



<P>had produced this very natural and very desirable effect.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He was in high spirits; as ready to talk and laugh as ever, and seemed



<P>delighted to speak of his former visit, and recur to old stories:



<P>and he was not without agitation.&nbsp; It was not in his calmness that



<P>she read his comparative difference.&nbsp; He was not calm; his spirits



<P>were evidently fluttered; there was restlessness about him.



<P>Lively as he was, it seemed a liveliness that did not satisfy himself;



<P>but what decided her belief on the subject, was his staying only a



<P>quarter of an hour, and hurrying away to make other calls in Highbury.



<P>"He had seen a group of old acquaintance in the street as he passed--



<P>he had not stopped, he would not stop for more than a word--but he



<P>had the vanity to think they would be disappointed if he did not call,



<P>and much as he wished to stay longer at Hartfield, he must hurry off."



<P>She had no doubt as to his being less in love--but neither his



<P>agitated spirits, nor his hurrying away, seemed like a perfect cure;



<P>and she was rather inclined to think it implied a dread of her



<P>returning power, and a discreet resolution of not trusting himself



<P>with her long.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This was the only visit from Frank Churchill in the course of ten days.



<P>He was often hoping, intending to come--but was always prevented.



<P>His aunt could not bear to have him leave her.&nbsp; Such was his own

account



<P>at Randall's. If he were quite sincere, if he really tried to come,



<P>it was to be inferred that Mrs. Churchill's removal to London had



<P>been of no service to the wilful or nervous part of her disorder.



<P>That she was really ill was very certain; he had declared himself



<P>convinced of it, at Randalls.&nbsp; Though much might be fancy, he could



<P>not doubt, when he looked back, that she was in a weaker state



<P>of health than she had been half a year ago.&nbsp; He did not believe

it



<P>to proceed from any thing that care and medicine might not remove,



<P>or at least that she might not have many years of existence before her;



<P>but he could not be prevailed on, by all his father's doubts, to say



<P>that her complaints were merely imaginary, or that she was as strong



<P>as ever.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It soon appeared that London was not the place for her.&nbsp; She could



<P>not endure its noise.&nbsp; Her nerves were under continual irritation



<P>and suffering; and by the ten days' end, her nephew's letter to



<P>Randalls communicated a change of plan.&nbsp; They were going to remove



<P>immediately to Richmond.&nbsp; Mrs. Churchill had been recommended



<P>to the medical skill of an eminent person there, and had otherwise



<P>a fancy for the place.&nbsp; A ready-furnished house in a favourite



<P>spot was engaged, and much benefit expected from the change.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma heard that Frank wrote in the highest spirits of this arrangement,



<P>and seemed most fully to appreciate the blessing of having two



<P>months before him of such near neighbourhood to many dear friends--



<P>for the house was taken for May and June.&nbsp; She was told that now



<P>he wrote with the greatest confidence of being often with them,



<P>almost as often as he could even wish.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma saw how Mr. Weston understood these joyous prospects.&nbsp; He

was



<P>considering her as the source of all the happiness they offered.



<P>She hoped it was not so.&nbsp; Two months must bring it to the proof.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Weston's own happiness was indisputable.&nbsp; He was quite delighted.



<P>It was the very circumstance he could have wished for.&nbsp; Now, it

would



<P>be really having Frank in their neighbourhood.&nbsp; What were nine

miles



<P>to a young man?--An hour's ride.&nbsp; He would be always coming over.



<P>The difference in that respect of Richmond and London was enough



<P>to make the whole difference of seeing him always and seeing



<P>him never.&nbsp; Sixteen miles--nay, eighteen--it must be full eighteen



<P>to Manchester-street--was a serious obstacle.&nbsp; Were he ever able



<P>to get away, the day would be spent in coming and returning.



<P>There was no comfort in having him in London; he might as well be



<P>at Enscombe; but Richmond was the very distance for easy intercourse.



<P>Better than nearer!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>One good thing was immediately brought to a certainty by this removal,--



<P>the ball at the Crown.&nbsp; It had not been forgotten before, but it

had



<P>been soon acknowledged vain to attempt to fix a day.&nbsp; Now, however,



<P>it was absolutely to be; every preparation was resumed, and very soon



<P>after the Churchills had removed to Richmond, a few lines from Frank,



<P>to say that his aunt felt already much better for the change,



<P>and that he had no doubt of being able to join them for twenty-four



<P>hours at any given time, induced them to name as early a day as possible.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Weston's ball was to be a real thing.&nbsp; A very few to-morrows



<P>stood between the young people of Highbury and happiness.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Woodhouse was resigned.&nbsp; The time of year lightened the evil



<P>to him.&nbsp; May was better for every thing than February.&nbsp; Mrs.

Bates



<P>was engaged to spend the evening at Hartfield, James had due notice,



<P>and he sanguinely hoped that neither dear little Henry nor dear



<P>little John would have any thing the matter with them, while dear



<P>Emma were gone.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 15</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XV</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>This letter must make its way to Emma's feelings.&nbsp; She was obliged,



<P>in spite of her previous determination to the contrary, to do



<P>it all the justice that Mrs. Weston foretold.&nbsp; As soon as she



<P>came to her own name, it was irresistible; every line relating



<P>to herself was interesting, and almost every line agreeable;



<P>and when this charm ceased, the subject could still maintain itself,



<P>by the natural return of her former regard for the writer, and the



<P>very strong attraction which any picture of love must have for her at



<P>that moment.&nbsp; She never stopt till she had gone through the whole;



<P>and though it was impossible not to feel that he had been wrong,



<P>yet he had been less wrong than she had supposed--and he had suffered,



<P>and was very sorry--and he was so grateful to Mrs. Weston,



<P>and so much in love with Miss Fairfax, and she was so happy herself,



<P>that there was no being severe; and could he have entered the room,



<P>she must have shaken hands with him as heartily as ever.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She thought so well of the letter, that when Mr. Knightley came again,



<P>she desired him to read it.&nbsp; She was sure of Mrs. Weston's wishing



<P>it to be communicated; especially to one, who, like Mr. Knightley,



<P>had seen so much to blame in his conduct.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I shall be very glad to look it over," said he; "but it seems long.



<P>I will take it home with me at night."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But that would not do.&nbsp; Mr. Weston was to call in the evening,



<P>and she must return it by him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I would rather be talking to you," he replied; "but as it seems



<P>a matter of justice, it shall be done."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He began--stopping, however, almost directly to say, "Had I been offered



<P>the sight of one of this gentleman's letters to his mother-in-law a

few



<P>months ago, Emma, it would not have been taken with such indifference."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He proceeded a little farther, reading to himself; and then,



<P>with a smile, observed, "Humph! a fine complimentary opening:



<P>But it is his way.&nbsp; One man's style must not be the rule of another's.



<P>We will not be severe."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It will be natural for me," he added shortly afterwards, "to speak

my



<P>opinion aloud as I read.&nbsp; By doing it, I shall feel that I am near

you.



<P>It will not be so great a loss of time:&nbsp; but if you dislike it--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not at all.&nbsp; I should wish it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Knightley returned to his reading with greater alacrity.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He trifles here," said he, "as to the temptation.&nbsp; He knows



<P>he is wrong, and has nothing rational to urge.--Bad.--He ought



<P>not to have formed the engagement.--`His father's disposition:'--



<P>he is unjust, however, to his father.&nbsp; Mr. Weston's sanguine



<P>temper was a blessing on all his upright and honourable exertions;



<P>but Mr. Weston earned every present comfort before he endeavoured



<P>to gain it.--Very true; he did not come till Miss Fairfax was here."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And I have not forgotten," said Emma, "how sure you were that he



<P>might have come sooner if he would.&nbsp; You pass it over very handsomely--



<P>but you were perfectly right."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I was not quite impartial in my judgment, Emma:--but yet, I think--



<P>had you not been in the case--I should still have distrusted him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When he came to Miss Woodhouse, he was obliged to read the whole



<P>of it aloud--all that related to her, with a smile; a look;



<P>a shake of the head; a word or two of assent, or disapprobation;



<P>or merely of love, as the subject required; concluding, however,



<P>seriously, and, after steady reflection, thus--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very bad--though it might have been worse.--Playing a most



<P>dangerous game.&nbsp; Too much indebted to the event for his acquittal.--



<P>No judge of his own manners by you.--Always deceived in fact by his



<P>own wishes, and regardless of little besides his own convenience.--



<P>Fancying you to have fathomed his secret.&nbsp; Natural enough!--



<P>his own mind full of intrigue, that he should suspect it



<P>in others.--Mystery; Finesse--how they pervert the understanding!



<P>My Emma, does not every thing serve to prove more and more the



<P>beauty of truth and sincerity in all our dealings with each other?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma agreed to it, and with a blush of sensibility on Harriet's account,



<P>which she could not give any sincere explanation of.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You had better go on," said she.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He did so, but very soon stopt again to say, "the pianoforte!



<P>Ah!&nbsp; That was the act of a very, very young man, one too young



<P>to consider whether the inconvenience of it might not very much



<P>exceed the pleasure.&nbsp; A boyish scheme, indeed!--I cannot



<P>comprehend a man's wishing to give a woman any proof of affection



<P>which he knows she would rather dispense with; and he did



<P>know that she would have prevented the instrument's coming if she could."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After this, he made some progress without any pause.



<P>Frank Churchill's confession of having behaved shamefully



<P>was the first thing to call for more than a word in passing.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I perfectly agree with you, sir,"--was then his remark.



<P>"You did behave very shamefully.&nbsp; You never wrote a truer line."



<P>And having gone through what immediately followed of the basis



<P>of their disagreement, and his persisting to act in direct



<P>opposition to Jane Fairfax's sense of right, he made a fuller pause



<P>to say, "This is very bad.--He had induced her to place herself,



<P>for his sake, in a situation of extreme difficulty and uneasiness,



<P>and it should have been his first object to prevent her from



<P>suffering unnecessarily.--She must have had much more to contend with,



<P>in carrying on the correspondence, than he could.&nbsp; He should have



<P>respected even unreasonable scruples, had there been such; but hers



<P>were all reasonable.&nbsp; We must look to her one fault, and remember



<P>that she had done a wrong thing in consenting to the engagement,



<P>to bear that she should have been in such a state of punishment."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma knew that he was now getting to the Box Hill party,



<P>and grew uncomfortable.&nbsp; Her own behaviour had been so very improper!



<P>She was deeply ashamed, and a little afraid of his next look.



<P>It was all read, however, steadily, attentively, and without



<P>the smallest remark; and, excepting one momentary glance at her,



<P>instantly withdrawn, in the fear of giving pain--no remembrance



<P>of Box Hill seemed to exist.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There is no saying much for the delicacy of our good friends,



<P>the Eltons," was his next observation.--"His feelings are natural.--



<P>What! actually resolve to break with him entirely!--She felt



<P>the engagement to be a source of repentance and misery to each--



<P>she dissolved it.--What a view this gives of her sense of



<P>his behaviour!--Well, he must be a most extraordinary--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nay, nay, read on.--You will find how very much he suffers."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I hope he does," replied Mr. Knightley coolly, and resuming the letter.



<P>"`Smallridge!'--What does this mean?&nbsp; What is all this?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She had engaged to go as governess to Mrs. Smallridge's children--



<P>a dear friend of Mrs. Elton's--a neighbour of Maple Grove; and,



<P>by the bye, I wonder how Mrs. Elton bears the disappointment?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Say nothing, my dear Emma, while you oblige me to read--not even



<P>of Mrs. Elton.&nbsp; Only one page more.&nbsp; I shall soon have done.



<P>What a letter the man writes!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I wish you would read it with a kinder spirit towards him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, there is feeling here.--He does seem to have suffered in finding



<P>her ill.--Certainly, I can have no doubt of his being fond of her.



<P>`Dearer, much dearer than ever.'&nbsp; I hope he may long continue to

feel



<P>all the value of such a reconciliation.--He is a very liberal thanker,



<P>with his thousands and tens of thousands.--`Happier than I deserve.'



<P>Come, he knows himself there.&nbsp; `Miss Woodhouse calls me the child



<P>of good fortune.'--Those were Miss Woodhouse's words, were they?--



<P>And a fine ending--and there is the letter.&nbsp; The child of good

fortune!



<P>That was your name for him, was it?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You do not appear so well satisfied with his letter as I am;



<P>but still you must, at least I hope you must, think the better



<P>of him for it.&nbsp; I hope it does him some service with you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, certainly it does.&nbsp; He has had great faults, faults of



<P>inconsideration and thoughtlessness; and I am very much of his



<P>opinion in thinking him likely to be happier than he deserves:



<P>but still as he is, beyond a doubt, really attached to Miss Fairfax,



<P>and will soon, it may be hoped, have the advantage of being constantly



<P>with her, I am very ready to believe his character will improve,



<P>and acquire from hers the steadiness and delicacy of principle



<P>that it wants.&nbsp; And now, let me talk to you of something else.



<P>I have another person's interest at present so much at heart,



<P>that I cannot think any longer about Frank Churchill.&nbsp; Ever since

I



<P>left you this morning, Emma, my mind has been hard at work on



<P>one subject."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The subject followed; it was in plain, unaffected, gentlemanlike English,



<P>such as Mr. Knightley used even to the woman he was in love with,



<P>how to be able to ask her to marry him, without attacking the



<P>happiness of her father.&nbsp; Emma's answer was ready at the first

word.



<P>"While her dear father lived, any change of condition must be impossible



<P>for her.&nbsp; She could never quit him."&nbsp; Part only of this answer,



<P>however, was admitted.&nbsp; The impossibility of her quitting her father,



<P>Mr. Knightley felt as strongly as herself; but the inadmissibility



<P>of any other change, he could not agree to.&nbsp; He had been thinking



<P>it over most deeply, most intently; he had at first hoped to induce



<P>Mr. Woodhouse to remove with her to Donwell; he had wanted to believe



<P>it feasible, but his knowledge of Mr. Woodhouse would not suffer



<P>him to deceive himself long; and now he confessed his persuasion,



<P>that such a transplantation would be a risk of her father's comfort,



<P>perhaps even of his life, which must not be hazarded.&nbsp; Mr. Woodhouse



<P>taken from Hartfield!--No, he felt that it ought not to be attempted.



<P>But the plan which had arisen on the sacrifice of this, he trusted



<P>his dearest Emma would not find in any respect objectionable;



<P>it was, that he should be received at Hartfield; that so long as



<P>her father's happiness in other words his life--required Hartfield



<P>to continue her home, it should be his likewise.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Of their all removing to Donwell, Emma had already had her own



<P>passing thoughts.&nbsp; Like him, she had tried the scheme and rejected

it;



<P>but such an alternative as this had not occurred to her.



<P>She was sensible of all the affection it evinced.&nbsp; She felt that,



<P>in quitting Donwell, he must be sacrificing a great deal of independence



<P>of hours and habits; that in living constantly with her father,



<P>and in no house of his own, there would be much, very much,



<P>to be borne with.&nbsp; She promised to think of it, and advised him



<P>to think of it more; but he was fully convinced, that no reflection



<P>could alter his wishes or his opinion on the subject.&nbsp; He had



<P>given it, he could assure her, very long and calm consideration;



<P>he had been walking away from William Larkins the whole morning,



<P>to have his thoughts to himself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah! there is one difficulty unprovided for," cried Emma.&nbsp; "I am



<P>sure William Larkins will not like it.&nbsp; You must get his consent



<P>before you ask mine."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She promised, however, to think of it; and pretty nearly promised, moreover,



<P>to think of it, with the intention of finding it a very good scheme.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It is remarkable, that Emma, in the many, very many, points of view



<P>in which she was now beginning to consider Donwell Abbey, was never



<P>struck with any sense of injury to her nephew Henry, whose rights



<P>as heir-expectant had formerly been so tenaciously regarded.



<P>Think she must of the possible difference to the poor little boy;



<P>and yet she only gave herself a saucy conscious smile about it,



<P>and found amusement in detecting the real cause of that violent



<P>dislike of Mr. Knightley's marrying Jane Fairfax, or any body else,



<P>which at the time she had wholly imputed to the amiable solicitude of



<P>the sister and the aunt.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This proposal of his, this plan of marrying and continuing at Hartfield--



<P>the more she contemplated it, the more pleasing it became.



<P>His evils seemed to lessen, her own advantages to increase,



<P>their mutual good to outweigh every drawback.&nbsp; Such a companion



<P>for herself in the periods of anxiety and cheerlessness before her!--



<P>Such a partner in all those duties and cares to which time must be



<P>giving increase of melancholy!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She would have been too happy but for poor Harriet; but every



<P>blessing of her own seemed to involve and advance the sufferings



<P>of her friend, who must now be even excluded from Hartfield.



<P>The delightful family party which Emma was securing for herself,



<P>poor Harriet must, in mere charitable caution, be kept at a



<P>distance from.&nbsp; She would be a loser in every way.&nbsp; Emma could

not



<P>deplore her future absence as any deduction from her own enjoyment.



<P>In such a party, Harriet would be rather a dead weight than otherwise;



<P>but for the poor girl herself, it seemed a peculiarly cruel necessity



<P>that was to be placing her in such a state of unmerited punishment.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In time, of course, Mr. Knightley would be forgotten, that is,



<P>supplanted; but this could not be expected to happen very early.



<P>Mr. Knightley himself would be doing nothing to assist the cure;--



<P>not like Mr. Elton.&nbsp; Mr. Knightley, always so kind, so feeling,



<P>so truly considerate for every body, would never deserve to be



<P>less worshipped than now; and it really was too much to hope even



<P>of Harriet, that she could be in love with more than three men



<P>in one year.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 14</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XIV</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>What totally different feelings did Emma take back into the house



<P>from what she had brought out!--she had then been only daring to hope



<P>for a little respite of suffering;--she was now in an exquisite



<P>flutter of happiness, and such happiness moreover as she believed



<P>must still be greater when the flutter should have passed away.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They sat down to tea--the same party round the same table--



<P>how often it had been collected!--and how often had her eyes fallen



<P>on the same shrubs in the lawn, and observed the same beautiful



<P>effect of the western sun!--But never in such a state of spirits,



<P>never in any thing like it; and it was with difficulty that she could



<P>summon enough of her usual self to be the attentive lady of the house,



<P>or even the attentive daughter.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Poor Mr. Woodhouse little suspected what was plotting against him



<P>in the breast of that man whom he was so cordially welcoming, and so



<P>anxiously hoping might not have taken cold from his ride.--Could he



<P>have seen the heart, he would have cared very little for the lungs;



<P>but without the most distant imagination of the impending evil,



<P>without the slightest perception of any thing extraordinary in



<P>the looks or ways of either, he repeated to them very comfortably



<P>all the articles of news he had received from Mr. Perry, and talked



<P>on with much self-contentment, totally unsuspicious of what they



<P>could have told him in return.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As long as Mr. Knightley remained with them, Emma's fever continued;



<P>but when he was gone, she began to be a little tranquillised



<P>and subdued--and in the course of the sleepless night, which was



<P>the tax for such an evening, she found one or two such very serious



<P>points to consider, as made her feel, that even her happiness



<P>must have some alloy.&nbsp; Her father--and Harriet.&nbsp; She could

not be



<P>alone without feeling the full weight of their separate claims;



<P>and how to guard the comfort of both to the utmost, was the question.



<P>With respect to her father, it was a question soon answered.



<P>She hardly knew yet what Mr. Knightley would ask; but a very short



<P>parley with her own heart produced the most solemn resolution



<P>of never quitting her father.--She even wept over the idea of it,



<P>as a sin of thought.&nbsp; While he lived, it must be only an engagement;



<P>but she flattered herself, that if divested of the danger of



<P>drawing her away, it might become an increase of comfort to him.--



<P>How to do her best by Harriet, was of more difficult decision;--



<P>how to spare her from any unnecessary pain; how to make



<P>her any possible atonement; how to appear least her enemy?--



<P>On these subjects, her perplexity and distress were very great--



<P>and her mind had to pass again and again through every bitter



<P>reproach and sorrowful regret that had ever surrounded it.--



<P>She could only resolve at last, that she would still avoid a



<P>meeting with her, and communicate all that need be told by letter;



<P>that it would be inexpressibly desirable to have her removed just



<P>now for a time from Highbury, and--indulging in one scheme more--



<P>nearly resolve, that it might be practicable to get an invitation



<P>for her to Brunswick Square.--Isabella had been pleased with Harriet;



<P>and a few weeks spent in London must give her some amusement.--



<P>She did not think it in Harriet's nature to escape being benefited



<P>by novelty and variety, by the streets, the shops, and the children.--



<P>At any rate, it would be a proof of attention and kindness in herself,



<P>from whom every thing was due; a separation for the present; an averting



<P>of the evil day, when they must all be together again.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She rose early, and wrote her letter to Harriet; an employment



<P>which left her so very serious, so nearly sad, that Mr. Knightley,



<P>in walking up to Hartfield to breakfast, did not arrive at all too soon;



<P>and half an hour stolen afterwards to go over the same ground again



<P>with him, literally and figuratively, was quite necessary to reinstate



<P>her in a proper share of the happiness of the evening before.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He had not left her long, by no means long enough for her to have



<P>the slightest inclination for thinking of any body else, when a letter



<P>was brought her from Randalls--a very thick letter;--she guessed



<P>what it must contain, and deprecated the necessity of reading it.--



<P>She was now in perfect charity with Frank Churchill; she wanted



<P>no explanations, she wanted only to have her thoughts to herself--



<P>and as for understanding any thing he wrote, she was sure she was



<P>incapable of it.--It must be waded through, however.&nbsp; She opened



<P>the packet; it was too surely so;--a note from Mrs. Weston to herself,



<P>ushered in the letter from Frank to Mrs. Weston.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have the greatest pleasure, my dear Emma, in forwarding



<P>to you the enclosed.&nbsp; I know what thorough justice you will



<P>do it, and have scarcely a doubt of its happy effect.--I think



<P>we shall never materially disagree about the writer again;



<P>but I will not delay you by a long preface.--We are quite well.--



<P>This letter has been the cure of all the little nervousness I have



<P>been feeling lately.--I did not quite like your looks on Tuesday,



<P>but it was an ungenial morning; and though you will never own being



<P>affected by weather, I think every body feels a north-east wind.--



<P>I felt for your dear father very much in the storm of Tuesday



<P>afternoon and yesterday morning, but had the comfort of hearing



<P>last night, by Mr. Perry, that it had not made him ill.



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

"Yours ever,



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

"A. W."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

[To Mrs. Weston.]



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

WINDSOR-JULY.



<P>MY DEAR MADAM,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If I made myself intelligible yesterday, this letter will be expected;



<P>but expected or not, I know it will be read with candour and indulgence.--



<P>You are all goodness, and I believe there will be need of even



<P>all your goodness to allow for some parts of my past conduct.--



<P>But I have been forgiven by one who had still more to resent.



<P>My courage rises while I write.&nbsp; It is very difficult for the



<P>prosperous to be humble.&nbsp; I have already met with such success



<P>in two applications for pardon, that I may be in danger of thinking



<P>myself too sure of yours, and of those among your friends who have



<P>had any ground of offence.--You must all endeavour to comprehend



<P>the exact nature of my situation when I first arrived at Randalls;



<P>you must consider me as having a secret which was to be kept



<P>at all hazards.&nbsp; This was the fact.&nbsp; My right to place myself



<P>in a situation requiring such concealment, is another question.



<P>I shall not discuss it here.&nbsp; For my temptation to think it a right,



<P>I refer every caviller to a brick house, sashed windows below,



<P>and casements above, in Highbury.&nbsp; I dared not address her openly;



<P>my difficulties in the then state of Enscombe must be too well



<P>known to require definition; and I was fortunate enough to prevail,



<P>before we parted at Weymouth, and to induce the most upright female



<P>mind in the creation to stoop in charity to a secret engagement.--



<P>Had she refused, I should have gone mad.--But you will be ready to say,



<P>what was your hope in doing this?--What did you look forward to?--



<P>To any thing, every thing--to time, chance, circumstance, slow effects,



<P>sudden bursts, perseverance and weariness, health and sickness.



<P>Every possibility of good was before me, and the first of blessings



<P>secured, in obtaining her promises of faith and correspondence.



<P>If you need farther explanation, I have the honour, my dear madam,



<P>of being your husband's son, and the advantage of inheriting



<P>a disposition to hope for good, which no inheritance of houses



<P>or lands can ever equal the value of.--See me, then, under these



<P>circumstances, arriving on my first visit to Randalls;--and here I



<P>am conscious of wrong, for that visit might have been sooner paid.



<P>You will look back and see that I did not come till Miss Fairfax



<P>was in Highbury; and as you were the person slighted, you will



<P>forgive me instantly; but I must work on my father's compassion,



<P>by reminding him, that so long as I absented myself from his house,



<P>so long I lost the blessing of knowing you.&nbsp; My behaviour,



<P>during the very happy fortnight which I spent with you, did not,



<P>I hope, lay me open to reprehension, excepting on one point.



<P>And now I come to the principal, the only important part of my



<P>conduct while belonging to you, which excites my own anxiety,



<P>or requires very solicitous explanation.&nbsp; With the greatest respect,



<P>and the warmest friendship, do I mention Miss Woodhouse; my father



<P>perhaps will think I ought to add, with the deepest humiliation.--



<P>A few words which dropped from him yesterday spoke his opinion,



<P>and some censure I acknowledge myself liable to.--My behaviour



<P>to Miss Woodhouse indicated, I believe, more than it ought.--



<P>In order to assist a concealment so essential to me, I was led



<P>on to make more than an allowable use of the sort of intimacy



<P>into which we were immediately thrown.--I cannot deny that Miss



<P>Woodhouse was my ostensible object--but I am sure you will believe



<P>the declaration, that had I not been convinced of her indifference,



<P>I would not have been induced by any selfish views to go on.--



<P>Amiable and delightful as Miss Woodhouse is, she never gave me



<P>the idea of a young woman likely to be attached; and that she was



<P>perfectly free from any tendency to being attached to me, was as much



<P>my conviction as my wish.--She received my attentions with an easy,



<P>friendly, goodhumoured playfulness, which exactly suited me.



<P>We seemed to understand each other.&nbsp; From our relative situation,



<P>those attentions were her due, and were felt to be so.--Whether Miss



<P>Woodhouse began really to understand me before the expiration of



<P>that fortnight, I cannot say;--when I called to take leave of her,



<P>I remember that I was within a moment of confessing the truth,



<P>and I then fancied she was not without suspicion; but I have no



<P>doubt of her having since detected me, at least in some degree.--



<P>She may not have surmised the whole, but her quickness must



<P>have penetrated a part.&nbsp; I cannot doubt it.&nbsp; You will find,



<P>whenever the subject becomes freed from its present restraints,



<P>that it did not take her wholly by surprize.&nbsp; She frequently gave



<P>me hints of it.&nbsp; I remember her telling me at the ball, that I



<P>owed Mrs. Elton gratitude for her attentions to Miss Fairfax.--



<P>I hope this history of my conduct towards her will be admitted



<P>by you and my father as great extenuation of what you saw amiss.



<P>While you considered me as having sinned against Emma Woodhouse,



<P>I could deserve nothing from either.&nbsp; Acquit me here, and procure



<P>for me, when it is allowable, the acquittal and good wishes of that



<P>said Emma Woodhouse, whom I regard with so much brotherly affection,



<P>as to long to have her as deeply and as happily in love as myself.--



<P>Whatever strange things I said or did during that fortnight, you have



<P>now a key to.&nbsp; My heart was in Highbury, and my business was to

get



<P>my body thither as often as might be, and with the least suspicion.



<P>If you remember any queernesses, set them all to the right account.--



<P>Of the pianoforte so much talked of, I feel it only necessary to say,



<P>that its being ordered was absolutely unknown to Miss F--, who would



<P>never have allowed me to send it, had any choice been given her.--



<P>The delicacy of her mind throughout the whole engagement,



<P>my dear madam, is much beyond my power of doing justice to.



<P>You will soon, I earnestly hope, know her thoroughly yourself.--



<P>No description can describe her.&nbsp; She must tell you herself what

she is--



<P>yet not by word, for never was there a human creature who would



<P>so designedly suppress her own merit.--Since I began this letter,



<P>which will be longer than I foresaw, I have heard from her.--



<P>She gives a good account of her own health; but as she never complains,



<P>I dare not depend.&nbsp; I want to have your opinion of her looks.



<P>I know you will soon call on her; she is living in dread of the visit.



<P>Perhaps it is paid already.&nbsp; Let me hear from you without delay;



<P>I am impatient for a thousand particulars.&nbsp; Remember how few



<P>minutes I was at Randalls, and in how bewildered, how mad a state:



<P>and I am not much better yet; still insane either from happiness



<P>or misery.&nbsp; When I think of the kindness and favour I have met

with,



<P>of her excellence and patience, and my uncle's generosity, I am mad



<P>with joy:&nbsp; but when I recollect all the uneasiness I occasioned

her,



<P>and how little I deserve to be forgiven, I am mad with anger.



<P>If I could but see her again!--But I must not propose it yet.



<P>My uncle has been too good for me to encroach.--I must still add



<P>to this long letter.&nbsp; You have not heard all that you ought to

hear.



<P>I could not give any connected detail yesterday; but the suddenness,



<P>and, in one light, the unseasonableness with which the affair burst

out,



<P>needs explanation; for though the event of the 26th ult., as you



<P>will conclude, immediately opened to me the happiest prospects,



<P>I should not have presumed on such early measures, but from the



<P>very particular circumstances, which left me not an hour to lose.



<P>I should myself have shrunk from any thing so hasty, and she would have



<P>felt every scruple of mine with multiplied strength and refinement.--



<P>But I had no choice.&nbsp; The hasty engagement she had entered into

with



<P>that woman--Here, my dear madam, I was obliged to leave off abruptly,



<P>to recollect and compose myself.--I have been walking over the country,



<P>and am now, I hope, rational enough to make the rest of my letter



<P>what it ought to be.--It is, in fact, a most mortifying retrospect



<P>for me.&nbsp; I behaved shamefully.&nbsp; And here I can admit, that

my manners



<P>to Miss W., in being unpleasant to Miss F., were highly blameable.



<P>She disapproved them, which ought to have been enough.--My plea of



<P>concealing the truth she did not think sufficient.--She was displeased;



<P>I thought unreasonably so:&nbsp; I thought her, on a thousand occasions,



<P>unnecessarily scrupulous and cautious:&nbsp; I thought her even cold.



<P>But she was always right.&nbsp; If I had followed her judgment, and

subdued



<P>my spirits to the level of what she deemed proper, I should have



<P>escaped the greatest unhappiness I have ever known.--We quarrelled.--



<P>Do you remember the morning spent at Donwell?--There every little



<P>dissatisfaction that had occurred before came to a crisis.&nbsp; I was

late;



<P>I met her walking home by herself, and wanted to walk with her,



<P>but she would not suffer it.&nbsp; She absolutely refused to allow me,



<P>which I then thought most unreasonable.&nbsp; Now, however, I see nothing



<P>in it but a very natural and consistent degree of discretion.



<P>While I, to blind the world to our engagement, was behaving one



<P>hour with objectionable particularity to another woman, was she



<P>to be consenting the next to a proposal which might have made



<P>every previous caution useless?--Had we been met walking together



<P>between Donwell and Highbury, the truth must have been suspected.--



<P>I was mad enough, however, to resent.--I doubted her affection.



<P>I doubted it more the next day on Box Hill; when, provoked by



<P>such conduct on my side, such shameful, insolent neglect of her,



<P>and such apparent devotion to Miss W., as it would have been



<P>impossible for any woman of sense to endure, she spoke her



<P>resentment in a form of words perfectly intelligible to me.--



<P>In short, my dear madam, it was a quarrel blameless on her side,



<P>abominable on mine; and I returned the same evening to Richmond,



<P>though I might have staid with you till the next morning,



<P>merely because I would be as angry with her as possible.&nbsp; Even

then,



<P>I was not such a fool as not to mean to be reconciled in time;



<P>but I was the injured person, injured by her coldness, and I went



<P>away determined that she should make the first advances.--I shall



<P>always congratulate myself that you were not of the Box Hill party.



<P>Had you witnessed my behaviour there, I can hardly suppose you would



<P>ever have thought well of me again.&nbsp; Its effect upon her appears



<P>in the immediate resolution it produced:&nbsp; as soon as she found

I



<P>was really gone from Randalls, she closed with the offer of that



<P>officious Mrs. Elton; the whole system of whose treatment of her,



<P>by the bye, has ever filled me with indignation and hatred.



<P>I must not quarrel with a spirit of forbearance which has been



<P>so richly extended towards myself; but, otherwise, I should loudly



<P>protest against the share of it which that woman has known.--



<P>"Jane," indeed!--You will observe that I have not yet indulged myself



<P>in calling her by that name, even to you.&nbsp; Think, then, what I

must



<P>have endured in hearing it bandied between the Eltons with all



<P>the vulgarity of needless repetition, and all the insolence of



<P>imaginary superiority.&nbsp; Have patience with me, I shall soon have

done.--



<P>She closed with this offer, resolving to break with me entirely,



<P>and wrote the next day to tell me that we never were to meet again.--



<P>She felt the engagement to be a source of repentance and misery



<P>to each:&nbsp; she dissolved it.--This letter reached me on the very



<P>morning of my poor aunt's death.&nbsp; I answered it within an hour;



<P>but from the confusion of my mind, and the multiplicity of business



<P>falling on me at once, my answer, instead of being sent with all



<P>the many other letters of that day, was locked up in my writing-desk;



<P>and I, trusting that I had written enough, though but a few lines,



<P>to satisfy her, remained without any uneasiness.--I was rather



<P>disappointed that I did not hear from her again speedily;



<P>but I made excuses for her, and was too busy, and--may I add?--



<P>too cheerful in my views to be captious.--We removed to Windsor;



<P>and two days afterwards I received a parcel from her, my own letters



<P>all returned!--and a few lines at the same time by the post,



<P>stating her extreme surprize at not having had the smallest reply



<P>to her last; and adding, that as silence on such a point could



<P>not be misconstrued, and as it must be equally desirable to both



<P>to have every subordinate arrangement concluded as soon as possible,



<P>she now sent me, by a safe conveyance, all my letters, and requested,



<P>that if I could not directly command hers, so as to send them



<P>to Highbury within a week, I would forward them after that period



<P>to her at--:&nbsp; in short, the full direction to Mr. Smallridge's,



<P>near Bristol, stared me in the face.&nbsp; I knew the name, the place,



<P>I knew all about it, and instantly saw what she had been doing.



<P>It was perfectly accordant with that resolution of character



<P>which I knew her to possess; and the secrecy she had maintained,



<P>as to any such design in her former letter, was equally descriptive



<P>of its anxious delicacy.&nbsp; For the world would not she have seemed



<P>to threaten me.--Imagine the shock; imagine how, till I had actually



<P>detected my own blunder, I raved at the blunders of the post.--



<P>What was to be done?--One thing only.--I must speak to my uncle.



<P>Without his sanction I could not hope to be listened to again.--



<P>I spoke; circumstances were in my favour; the late event had softened



<P>away his pride, and he was, earlier than I could have anticipated,



<P>wholly reconciled and complying; and could say at last, poor man!



<P>with a deep sigh, that he wished I might find as much happiness



<P>in the marriage state as he had done.--I felt that it would be



<P>of a different sort.--Are you disposed to pity me for what I must



<P>have suffered in opening the cause to him, for my suspense while



<P>all was at stake?--No; do not pity me till I reached Highbury,



<P>and saw how ill I had made her.&nbsp; Do not pity me till I saw her

wan,



<P>sick looks.--I reached Highbury at the time of day when, from my



<P>knowledge of their late breakfast hour, I was certain of a good chance



<P>of finding her alone.--I was not disappointed; and at last I was



<P>not disappointed either in the object of my journey.&nbsp; A great deal



<P>of very reasonable, very just displeasure I had to persuade away.



<P>But it is done; we are reconciled, dearer, much dearer, than ever,



<P>and no moment's uneasiness can ever occur between us again.&nbsp; Now,

my



<P>dear madam, I will release you; but I could not conclude before.



<P>A thousand and a thousand thanks for all the kindness you have



<P>ever shewn me, and ten thousand for the attentions your heart



<P>will dictate towards her.--If you think me in a way to be happier



<P>than I deserve, I am quite of your opinion.--Miss W. calls me



<P>the child of good fortune.&nbsp; I hope she is right.--In one respect,



<P>my good fortune is undoubted, that of being able to subscribe



<P>myself,



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Your obliged and affectionate Son,



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

F. C. WESTON CHURCHILL.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 04</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER IV</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>A very few days had passed after this adventure, when Harriet came



<P>one morning to Emma with a small parcel in her hand, and after



<P>sitting down and hesitating, thus began:

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Miss Woodhouse--if you are at leisure--I have something that I



<P>should like to tell you--a sort of confession to make--and then,



<P>you know, it will be over."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma was a good deal surprized; but begged her to speak.



<P>There was a seriousness in Harriet's manner which prepared her,



<P>quite as much as her words, for something more than ordinary.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is my duty, and I am sure it is my wish," she continued,



<P>"to have no reserves with you on this subject.&nbsp; As I am happily



<P>quite an altered creature in one respect, it is very fit that you



<P>should have the satisfaction of knowing it.&nbsp; I do not want to say



<P>more than is necessary--I am too much ashamed of having given way



<P>as I have done, and I dare say you understand me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes," said Emma, "I hope I do."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How I could so long a time be fancying myself! . . ."



<P>cried Harriet, warmly.&nbsp; "It seems like madness!&nbsp; I can see

nothing



<P>at all extraordinary in him now.--I do not care whether I meet



<P>him or not--except that of the two I had rather not see him--



<P>and indeed I would go any distance round to avoid him--but I do



<P>not envy his wife in the least; I neither admire her nor envy her,



<P>as I have done:&nbsp; she is very charming, I dare say, and all that,



<P>but I think her very ill-tempered and disagreeable--I shall never forget



<P>her look the other night!--However, I assure you, Miss Woodhouse,



<P>I wish her no evil.--No, let them be ever so happy together,



<P>it will not give me another moment's pang:&nbsp; and to convince you



<P>that I have been speaking truth, I am now going to destroy--what I



<P>ought to have destroyed long ago--what I ought never to have kept--



<P>I know that very well (blushing as she spoke).--However, now I



<P>will destroy it all--and it is my particular wish to do it



<P>in your presence, that you may see how rational I am grown.



<P>Cannot you guess what this parcel holds?" said she, with a conscious

look.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not the least in the world.--Did he ever give you any thing?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No--I cannot call them gifts; but they are things that I have



<P>valued very much."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She held the parcel towards her, and Emma read the words Most



<P>precious treasures on the top.&nbsp; Her curiosity was greatly excited.



<P>Harriet unfolded the parcel, and she looked on with impatience.



<P>Within abundance of silver paper was a pretty little Tunbridge-ware

box,



<P>which Harriet opened:&nbsp; it was well lined with the softest cotton;



<P>but, excepting the cotton, Emma saw only a small piece of court-plaister.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now," said Harriet, "you must recollect."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, indeed I do not."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Dear me!&nbsp; I should not have thought it possible you could forget



<P>what passed in this very room about court-plaister, one of the very



<P>last times we ever met in it!--It was but a very few days before I



<P>had my sore throat--just before Mr. and Mrs. John Knightley came--



<P>I think the very evening.--Do not you remember his cutting his finger



<P>with your new penknife, and your recommending court-plaister?--



<P>But, as you had none about you, and knew I had, you desired



<P>me to supply him; and so I took mine out and cut him a piece;



<P>but it was a great deal too large, and he cut it smaller, and kept



<P>playing some time with what was left, before he gave it back to me.



<P>And so then, in my nonsense, I could not help making a treasure of it--



<P>so I put it by never to be used, and looked at it now and then



<P>as a great treat."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dearest Harriet!" cried Emma, putting her hand before her face,



<P>and jumping up, "you make me more ashamed of myself than I can bear.



<P>Remember it?&nbsp; Aye, I remember it all now; all, except your saving



<P>this relic--I knew nothing of that till this moment--but the cutting



<P>the finger, and my recommending court-plaister, and saying I had none



<P>about me!--Oh! my sins, my sins!--And I had plenty all the while in



<P>my pocket!--One of my senseless tricks!--I deserve to be under a



<P>continual blush all the rest of my life.--Well--(sitting down again)--



<P>go on--what else?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And had you really some at hand yourself?&nbsp; I am sure I never



<P>suspected it, you did it so naturally."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And so you actually put this piece of court-plaister by for his sake!"



<P>said Emma, recovering from her state of shame and feeling divided



<P>between wonder and amusement.&nbsp; And secretly she added to herself,



<P>"Lord bless me! when should I ever have thought of putting by in cotton



<P>a piece of court-plaister that Frank Churchill had been pulling about!



<P>I never was equal to this."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Here," resumed Harriet, turning to her box again, "here is



<P>something still more valuable, I mean that has been more valuable,



<P>because this is what did really once belong to him, which the



<P>court-plaister never did."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma was quite eager to see this superior treasure.&nbsp; It was the

end



<P>of an old pencil,--the part without any lead.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"This was really his," said Harriet.--"Do not you remember



<P>one morning?--no, I dare say you do not.&nbsp; But one morning--I forget



<P>exactly the day--but perhaps it was the Tuesday or Wednesday before



<P>that evening, he wanted to make a memorandum in his pocket-book;



<P>it was about spruce-beer. Mr. Knightley had been telling him



<P>something about brewing spruce-beer, and he wanted to put it down;



<P>but when he took out his pencil, there was so little lead that he



<P>soon cut it all away, and it would not do, so you lent him another,



<P>and this was left upon the table as good for nothing.&nbsp; But I kept



<P>my eye on it; and, as soon as I dared, caught it up, and never



<P>parted with it again from that moment."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do remember it," cried Emma; "I perfectly remember it.--



<P>Talking about spruce-beer.--Oh! yes--Mr. Knightley and I both saying

we



<P>liked it, and Mr. Elton's seeming resolved to learn to like it too.



<P>I perfectly remember it.--Stop; Mr. Knightley was standing just here,



<P>was not he?&nbsp; I have an idea he was standing just here."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah!&nbsp; I do not know.&nbsp; I cannot recollect.--It is very odd,



<P>but I cannot recollect.--Mr. Elton was sitting here, I remember,



<P>much about where I am now."--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, go on."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! that's all.&nbsp; I have nothing more to shew you, or to say--



<P>except that I am now going to throw them both behind the fire,



<P>and I wish you to see me do it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My poor dear Harriet! and have you actually found happiness



<P>in treasuring up these things?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, simpleton as I was!--but I am quite ashamed of it now, and wish



<P>I could forget as easily as I can burn them.&nbsp; It was very wrong



<P>of me, you know, to keep any remembrances, after he was married.



<P>I knew it was--but had not resolution enough to part with them."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But, Harriet, is it necessary to burn the court-plaister?--I have



<P>not a word to say for the bit of old pencil, but the court-plaister



<P>might be useful."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I shall be happier to burn it," replied Harriet.&nbsp; "It has



<P>a disagreeable look to me.&nbsp; I must get rid of every thing.--



<P>There it goes, and there is an end, thank Heaven! of Mr. Elton."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And when," thought Emma, "will there be a beginning of Mr. Churchill?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She had soon afterwards reason to believe that the beginning was



<P>already made, and could not but hope that the gipsy, though she had



<P>told no fortune, might be proved to have made Harriet's.--About a



<P>fortnight after the alarm, they came to a sufficient explanation,



<P>and quite undesignedly.&nbsp; Emma was not thinking of it at the moment,



<P>which made the information she received more valuable.



<P>She merely said, in the course of some trivial chat, "Well, Harriet,



<P>whenever you marry I would advise you to do so and so"--and thought



<P>no more of it, till after a minute's silence she heard Harriet



<P>say in a very serious tone, "I shall never marry."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma then looked up, and immediately saw how it was; and after a



<P>moment's debate, as to whether it should pass unnoticed or not, replied,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Never marry!--This is a new resolution."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is one that I shall never change, however."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After another short hesitation, "I hope it does not proceed from--



<P>I hope it is not in compliment to Mr. Elton?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mr. Elton indeed!" cried Harriet indignantly.--"Oh! no"--and Emma



<P>could just catch the words, "so superior to Mr. Elton!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She then took a longer time for consideration.&nbsp; Should she proceed



<P>no farther?--should she let it pass, and seem to suspect nothing?--



<P>Perhaps Harriet might think her cold or angry if she did;



<P>or perhaps if she were totally silent, it might only drive



<P>Harriet into asking her to hear too much; and against any thing



<P>like such an unreserve as had been, such an open and frequent



<P>discussion of hopes and chances, she was perfectly resolved.--



<P>She believed it would be wiser for her to say and know at once,



<P>all that she meant to say and know.&nbsp; Plain dealing was always best.



<P>She had previously determined how far she would proceed,



<P>on any application of the sort; and it would be safer for both,



<P>to have the judicious law of her own brain laid down with speed.--



<P>She was decided, and thus spoke--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Harriet, I will not affect to be in doubt of your meaning.



<P>Your resolution, or rather your expectation of never marrying,



<P>results from an idea that the person whom you might prefer,



<P>would be too greatly your superior in situation to think of you.



<P>Is not it so?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh!&nbsp; Miss Woodhouse, believe me I have not the presumption to

suppose--



<P>Indeed I am not so mad.--But it is a pleasure to me to admire him



<P>at a distance--and to think of his infinite superiority to all



<P>the rest of the world, with the gratitude, wonder, and veneration,



<P>which are so proper, in me especially."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am not at all surprized at you, Harriet.&nbsp; The service he rendered



<P>you was enough to warm your heart."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Service! oh! it was such an inexpressible obligation!--



<P>The very recollection of it, and all that I felt at the time--



<P>when I saw him coming--his noble look--and my wretchedness before.



<P>Such a change!&nbsp; In one moment such a change!&nbsp; From perfect

misery



<P>to perfect happiness!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is very natural.&nbsp; It is natural, and it is honourable.--



<P>Yes, honourable, I think, to chuse so well and so gratefully.--



<P>But that it will be a fortunate preference is more that I can promise.



<P>I do not advise you to give way to it, Harriet.&nbsp; I do not by any



<P>means engage for its being returned.&nbsp; Consider what you are about.



<P>Perhaps it will be wisest in you to check your feelings while you can:



<P>at any rate do not let them carry you far, unless you are persuaded



<P>of his liking you.&nbsp; Be observant of him.&nbsp; Let his behaviour

be the



<P>guide of your sensations.&nbsp; I give you this caution now, because

I



<P>shall never speak to you again on the subject.&nbsp; I am determined



<P>against all interference.&nbsp; Henceforward I know nothing of the matter.



<P>Let no name ever pass our lips.&nbsp; We were very wrong before;



<P>we will be cautious now.--He is your superior, no doubt, and there



<P>do seem objections and obstacles of a very serious nature;



<P>but yet, Harriet, more wonderful things have taken place, there have



<P>been matches of greater disparity.&nbsp; But take care of yourself.



<P>I would not have you too sanguine; though, however it may end,



<P>be assured your raising your thoughts to him, is a mark of good taste



<P>which I shall always know how to value."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet kissed her hand in silent and submissive gratitude.



<P>Emma was very decided in thinking such an attachment no bad thing



<P>for her friend.&nbsp; Its tendency would be to raise and refine her

mind--



<P>and it must be saving her from the danger of degradation.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 10</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER X</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>One morning, about ten days after Mrs. Churchill's decease,



<P>Emma was called downstairs to Mr. Weston, who "could not stay



<P>five minutes, and wanted particularly to speak with her."--



<P>He met her at the parlour-door, and hardly asking her how she did,



<P>in the natural key of his voice, sunk it immediately, to say,



<P>unheard by her father,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Can you come to Randalls at any time this morning?--Do, if it



<P>be possible.&nbsp; Mrs. Weston wants to see you.&nbsp; She must see

you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Is she unwell?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, no, not at all--only a little agitated.&nbsp; She would have



<P>ordered the carriage, and come to you, but she must see you alone,



<P>and that you know--(nodding towards her father)--Humph!--Can you come?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Certainly.&nbsp; This moment, if you please.&nbsp; It is impossible

to



<P>refuse what you ask in such a way.&nbsp; But what can be the matter?--



<P>Is she really not ill?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Depend upon me--but ask no more questions.&nbsp; You will know it



<P>all in time.&nbsp; The most unaccountable business!&nbsp; But hush,

hush!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To guess what all this meant, was impossible even for Emma.



<P>Something really important seemed announced by his looks;



<P>but, as her friend was well, she endeavoured not to be uneasy,



<P>and settling it with her father, that she would take her walk now,



<P>she and Mr. Weston were soon out of the house together and on



<P>their way at a quick pace for Randalls.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now,"--said Emma, when they were fairly beyond the sweep gates,--



<P>"now Mr. Weston, do let me know what has happened."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, no,"--he gravely replied.--"Don't ask me.&nbsp; I promised my wife



<P>to leave it all to her.&nbsp; She will break it to you better than I

can.



<P>Do not be impatient, Emma; it will all come out too soon."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Break it to me," cried Emma, standing still with terror.--



<P>"Good God!--Mr. Weston, tell me at once.--Something has happened



<P>in Brunswick Square.&nbsp; I know it has.&nbsp; Tell me, I charge you

tell



<P>me this moment what it is."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, indeed you are mistaken."--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mr. Weston do not trifle with me.--Consider how many of my dearest



<P>friends are now in Brunswick Square.&nbsp; Which of them is it?--



<P>I charge you by all that is sacred, not to attempt concealment."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Upon my word, Emma."--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Your word!--why not your honour!--why not say upon your honour,



<P>that it has nothing to do with any of them?&nbsp; Good Heavens!--What

can



<P>be to be broke to me, that does not relate to one of that family?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Upon my honour," said he very seriously, "it does not.&nbsp; It is

not



<P>in the smallest degree connected with any human being of the name



<P>of Knightley."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma's courage returned, and she walked on.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I was wrong," he continued, "in talking of its being broke to you.



<P>I should not have used the expression.&nbsp; In fact, it does not concern

you--



<P>it concerns only myself,--that is, we hope.--Humph!--In short,



<P>my dear Emma, there is no occasion to be so uneasy about it.



<P>I don't say that it is not a disagreeable business--but things might



<P>be much worse.--If we walk fast, we shall soon be at Randalls."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma found that she must wait; and now it required little effort.



<P>She asked no more questions therefore, merely employed her own fancy,



<P>and that soon pointed out to her the probability of its being some



<P>money concern--something just come to light, of a disagreeable



<P>nature in the circumstances of the family,--something which the late



<P>event at Richmond had brought forward.&nbsp; Her fancy was very active.



<P>Half a dozen natural children, perhaps--and poor Frank cut off!--



<P>This, though very undesirable, would be no matter of agony to her.



<P>It inspired little more than an animating curiosity.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Who is that gentleman on horseback?" said she, as they proceeded--



<P>speaking more to assist Mr. Weston in keeping his secret, than with



<P>any other view.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not know.--One of the Otways.--Not Frank;--it is not Frank,



<P>I assure you.&nbsp; You will not see him.&nbsp; He is half way to Windsor



<P>by this time."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Has your son been with you, then?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! yes--did not you know?--Well, well, never mind."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>For a moment he was silent; and then added, in a tone much more



<P>guarded and demure,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, Frank came over this morning, just to ask us how we did."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They hurried on, and were speedily at Randalls.--"Well, my dear,"



<P>said he, as they entered the room--"I have brought her, and now



<P>I hope you will soon be better.&nbsp; I shall leave you together.



<P>There is no use in delay.&nbsp; I shall not be far off, if you want

me."--



<P>And Emma distinctly heard him add, in a lower tone, before he



<P>quitted the room,--"I have been as good as my word.&nbsp; She has not

the



<P>least idea."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Weston was looking so ill, and had an air of so much perturbation,



<P>that Emma's uneasiness increased; and the moment they were alone,



<P>she eagerly said,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What is it my dear friend?&nbsp; Something of a very unpleasant nature,



<P>I find, has occurred;--do let me know directly what it is.



<P>I have been walking all this way in complete suspense.&nbsp; We both



<P>abhor suspense.&nbsp; Do not let mine continue longer.&nbsp; It will

do you



<P>good to speak of your distress, whatever it may be."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Have you indeed no idea?" said Mrs. Weston in a trembling voice.



<P>"Cannot you, my dear Emma--cannot you form a guess as to what you



<P>are to hear?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So far as that it relates to Mr. Frank Churchill, I do guess."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are right.&nbsp; It does relate to him, and I will tell you directly;"



<P>(resuming her work, and seeming resolved against looking up.)



<P>"He has been here this very morning, on a most extraordinary errand.



<P>It is impossible to express our surprize.&nbsp; He came to speak to

his



<P>father on a subject,--to announce an attachment--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She stopped to breathe.&nbsp; Emma thought first of herself, and then



<P>of Harriet.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"More than an attachment, indeed," resumed Mrs. Weston; "an engagement--



<P>a positive engagement.--What will you say, Emma--what will any



<P>body say, when it is known that Frank Churchill and Miss Fairfax



<P>are engaged;--nay, that they have been long engaged!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma even jumped with surprize;--and, horror-struck, exclaimed,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Jane Fairfax!--Good God!&nbsp; You are not serious?&nbsp; You do not

mean it?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You may well be amazed," returned Mrs. Weston, still averting her eyes,



<P>and talking on with eagerness, that Emma might have time to recover--



<P>"You may well be amazed.&nbsp; But it is even so.&nbsp; There has been

a solemn



<P>engagement between them ever since October--formed at Weymouth,



<P>and kept a secret from every body.&nbsp; Not a creature knowing it



<P>but themselves--neither the Campbells, nor her family, nor his.--



<P>It is so wonderful, that though perfectly convinced of the fact,



<P>it is yet almost incredible to myself.&nbsp; I can hardly believe it.--



<P>I thought I knew him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma scarcely heard what was said.--Her mind was divided between



<P>two ideas--her own former conversations with him about Miss Fairfax;



<P>and poor Harriet;--and for some time she could only exclaim,



<P>and require confirmation, repeated confirmation.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well," said she at last, trying to recover herself; "this is a



<P>circumstance which I must think of at least half a day, before I



<P>can at all comprehend it.&nbsp; What!--engaged to her all the winter--



<P>before either of them came to Highbury?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Engaged since October,--secretly engaged.--It has hurt me,



<P>Emma, very much.&nbsp; It has hurt his father equally.&nbsp; Some part



<P>of his conduct we cannot excuse."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma pondered a moment, and then replied, "I will not pretend



<P>not to understand you; and to give you all the relief in my power,



<P>be assured that no such effect has followed his attentions to me,



<P>as you are apprehensive of."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Weston looked up, afraid to believe; but Emma's countenance



<P>was as steady as her words.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That you may have less difficulty in believing this boast, of my



<P>present perfect indifference," she continued, "I will farther tell you,



<P>that there was a period in the early part of our acquaintance,



<P>when I did like him, when I was very much disposed to be



<P>attached to him--nay, was attached--and how it came to cease,



<P>is perhaps the wonder.&nbsp; Fortunately, however, it did cease.



<P>I have really for some time past, for at least these three months,



<P>cared nothing about him.&nbsp; You may believe me, Mrs. Weston.



<P>This is the simple truth."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Weston kissed her with tears of joy; and when she could



<P>find utterance, assured her, that this protestation had done



<P>her more good than any thing else in the world could do.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mr. Weston will be almost as much relieved as myself," said she.



<P>"On this point we have been wretched.&nbsp; It was our darling wish

that you



<P>might be attached to each other--and we were persuaded that it was so.--



<P>Imagine what we have been feeling on your account."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have escaped; and that I should escape, may be a matter of



<P>grateful wonder to you and myself.&nbsp; But this does not acquit him,



<P>Mrs. Weston; and I must say, that I think him greatly to blame.



<P>What right had he to come among us with affection and faith engaged,



<P>and with manners so very disengaged?&nbsp; What right had he to endeavour



<P>to please, as he certainly did--to distinguish any one young woman with



<P>persevering attention, as he certainly did--while he really belonged



<P>to another?--How could he tell what mischief he might be doing?--



<P>How could he tell that he might not be making me in love with him?--



<P>very wrong, very wrong indeed."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"From something that he said, my dear Emma, I rather imagine--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And how could she bear such behaviour!&nbsp; Composure with a witness!



<P>to look on, while repeated attentions were offering to another woman,



<P>before her face, and not resent it.--That is a degree of placidity,



<P>which I can neither comprehend nor respect."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There were misunderstandings between them, Emma; he said



<P>so expressly.&nbsp; He had not time to enter into much explanation.



<P>He was here only a quarter of an hour, and in a state of agitation



<P>which did not allow the full use even of the time he could stay--



<P>but that there had been misunderstandings he decidedly said.



<P>The present crisis, indeed, seemed to be brought on by them;



<P>and those misunderstandings might very possibly arise from the



<P>impropriety of his conduct."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Impropriety!&nbsp; Oh!&nbsp; Mrs. Weston--it is too calm a censure.



<P>Much, much beyond impropriety!--It has sunk him, I cannot say how



<P>it has sunk him in my opinion.&nbsp; So unlike what a man should be!--



<P>None of that upright integrity, that strict adherence to truth



<P>and principle, that disdain of trick and littleness, which a man



<P>should display in every transaction of his life."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nay, dear Emma, now I must take his part; for though he has been



<P>wrong in this instance, I have known him long enough to answer



<P>for his having many, very many, good qualities; and--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Good God!" cried Emma, not attending to her.--"Mrs. Smallridge, too!



<P>Jane actually on the point of going as governess!&nbsp; What could he



<P>mean by such horrible indelicacy?&nbsp; To suffer her to engage herself--



<P>to suffer her even to think of such a measure!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He knew nothing about it, Emma.&nbsp; On this article I can fully



<P>acquit him.&nbsp; It was a private resolution of hers, not communicated



<P>to him--or at least not communicated in a way to carry conviction.--



<P>Till yesterday, I know he said he was in the dark as to her plans.



<P>They burst on him, I do not know how, but by some letter or message--



<P>and it was the discovery of what she was doing, of this very project



<P>of hers, which determined him to come forward at once, own it



<P>all to his uncle, throw himself on his kindness, and, in short,



<P>put an end to the miserable state of concealment that had been



<P>carrying on so long."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma began to listen better.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am to hear from him soon," continued Mrs. Weston.&nbsp; "He told

me



<P>at parting, that he should soon write; and he spoke in a manner which



<P>seemed to promise me many particulars that could not be given now.
