<P>Let us wait, therefore, for this letter.&nbsp; It may bring many extenuations.



<P>It may make many things intelligible and excusable which now are



<P>not to be understood.&nbsp; Don't let us be severe, don't let us be

in



<P>a hurry to condemn him.&nbsp; Let us have patience.&nbsp; I must love

him;



<P>and now that I am satisfied on one point, the one material point,



<P>I am sincerely anxious for its all turning out well, and ready



<P>to hope that it may.&nbsp; They must both have suffered a great deal



<P>under such a system of secresy and concealment."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"His sufferings," replied Emma dryly, "do not appear to have done



<P>him much harm.&nbsp; Well, and how did Mr. Churchill take it?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Most favourably for his nephew--gave his consent with scarcely



<P>a difficulty.&nbsp; Conceive what the events of a week have done



<P>in that family!&nbsp; While poor Mrs. Churchill lived, I suppose there



<P>could not have been a hope, a chance, a possibility;--but scarcely



<P>are her remains at rest in the family vault, than her husband is



<P>persuaded to act exactly opposite to what she would have required.



<P>What a blessing it is, when undue influence does not survive the grave!--



<P>He gave his consent with very little persuasion."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah!" thought Emma, "he would have done as much for Harriet."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"This was settled last night, and Frank was off with the light



<P>this morning.&nbsp; He stopped at Highbury, at the Bates's, I fancy,



<P>some time--and then came on hither; but was in such a hurry to get



<P>back to his uncle, to whom he is just now more necessary than ever,



<P>that, as I tell you, he could stay with us but a quarter of an hour.--



<P>He was very much agitated--very much, indeed--to a degree that made



<P>him appear quite a different creature from any thing I had ever seen



<P>him before.--In addition to all the rest, there had been the shock of



<P>finding her so very unwell, which he had had no previous suspicion of--



<P>and there was every appearance of his having been feeling a great deal."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And do you really believe the affair to have been carrying on



<P>with such perfect secresy?--The Campbells, the Dixons, did none



<P>of them know of the engagement?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma could not speak the name of Dixon without a little blush.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"None; not one.&nbsp; He positively said that it had been known to no



<P>being in the world but their two selves."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well," said Emma, "I suppose we shall gradually grow reconciled



<P>to the idea, and I wish them very happy.&nbsp; But I shall always



<P>think it a very abominable sort of proceeding.&nbsp; What has it been



<P>but a system of hypocrisy and deceit,--espionage, and treachery?--



<P>To come among us with professions of openness and simplicity;



<P>and such a league in secret to judge us all!--Here have we been,



<P>the whole winter and spring, completely duped, fancying ourselves



<P>all on an equal footing of truth and honour, with two people in the



<P>midst of us who may have been carrying round, comparing and sitting



<P>in judgment on sentiments and words that were never meant for both



<P>to hear.--They must take the consequence, if they have heard each



<P>other spoken of in a way not perfectly agreeable!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am quite easy on that head," replied Mrs. Weston.&nbsp; "I am



<P>very sure that I never said any thing of either to the other,



<P>which both might not have heard."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are in luck.--Your only blunder was confined to my ear,



<P>when you imagined a certain friend of ours in love with the lady."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"True.&nbsp; But as I have always had a thoroughly good opinion of Miss



<P>Fairfax, I never could, under any blunder, have spoken ill of her;



<P>and as to speaking ill of him, there I must have been safe."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>At this moment Mr. Weston appeared at a little distance from the window,



<P>evidently on the watch.&nbsp; His wife gave him a look which invited



<P>him in; and, while he was coming round, added, "Now, dearest Emma,



<P>let me intreat you to say and look every thing that may set his



<P>heart at ease, and incline him to be satisfied with the match.



<P>Let us make the best of it--and, indeed, almost every thing may



<P>be fairly said in her favour.&nbsp; It is not a connexion to gratify;



<P>but if Mr. Churchill does not feel that, why should we? and it



<P>may be a very fortunate circumstance for him, for Frank, I mean,



<P>that he should have attached himself to a girl of such steadiness



<P>of character and good judgment as I have always given her credit for--



<P>and still am disposed to give her credit for, in spite of this



<P>one great deviation from the strict rule of right.&nbsp; And how much



<P>may be said in her situation for even that error!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Much, indeed!" cried Emma feelingly.&nbsp; "If a woman can ever



<P>be excused for thinking only of herself, it is in a situation



<P>like Jane Fairfax's.--Of such, one may almost say, that `the



<P>world is not their's, nor the world's law.'"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She met Mr. Weston on his entrance, with a smiling countenance,



<P>exclaiming,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A very pretty trick you have been playing me, upon my word!



<P>This was a device, I suppose, to sport with my curiosity,



<P>and exercise my talent of guessing.&nbsp; But you really frightened

me.



<P>I thought you had lost half your property, at least.&nbsp; And here,



<P>instead of its being a matter of condolence, it turns out to be one



<P>of congratulation.--I congratulate you, Mr. Weston, with all my heart,



<P>on the prospect of having one of the most lovely and accomplished



<P>young women in England for your daughter."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A glance or two between him and his wife, convinced him that all was



<P>as right as this speech proclaimed; and its happy effect on his spirits



<P>was immediate.&nbsp; His air and voice recovered their usual briskness:



<P>he shook her heartily and gratefully by the hand, and entered



<P>on the subject in a manner to prove, that he now only wanted



<P>time and persuasion to think the engagement no very bad thing.



<P>His companions suggested only what could palliate imprudence,



<P>or smooth objections; and by the time they had talked it all



<P>over together, and he had talked it all over again with Emma,



<P>in their walk back to Hartfield, he was become perfectly reconciled,



<P>and not far from thinking it the very best thing that Frank could



<P>possibly have done.



<P>

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 11</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XI</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>"Harriet, poor Harriet!"--Those were the words; in them lay the



<P>tormenting ideas which Emma could not get rid of, and which constituted



<P>the real misery of the business to her.&nbsp; Frank Churchill had behaved



<P>very ill by herself--very ill in many ways,--but it was not so much



<P>his behaviour as her own, which made her so angry with him.



<P>It was the scrape which he had drawn her into on Harriet's account,



<P>that gave the deepest hue to his offence.--Poor Harriet! to be a second



<P>time the dupe of her misconceptions and flattery.&nbsp; Mr. Knightley



<P>had spoken prophetically, when he once said, "Emma, you have been



<P>no friend to Harriet Smith."--She was afraid she had done her nothing



<P>but disservice.--It was true that she had not to charge herself,



<P>in this instance as in the former, with being the sole and original



<P>author of the mischief; with having suggested such feelings as might



<P>otherwise never have entered Harriet's imagination; for Harriet



<P>had acknowledged her admiration and preference of Frank Churchill



<P>before she had ever given her a hint on the subject; but she felt



<P>completely guilty of having encouraged what she might have repressed.



<P>She might have prevented the indulgence and increase of such sentiments.



<P>Her influence would have been enough.&nbsp; And now she was very conscious



<P>that she ought to have prevented them.--She felt that she had been



<P>risking her friend's happiness on most insufficient grounds.



<P>Common sense would have directed her to tell Harriet, that she



<P>must not allow herself to think of him, and that there were five



<P>hundred chances to one against his ever caring for her.--"But, with



<P>common sense," she added, "I am afraid I have had little to do."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was extremely angry with herself.&nbsp; If she could not have been



<P>angry with Frank Churchill too, it would have been dreadful.--



<P>As for Jane Fairfax, she might at least relieve her feelings



<P>from any present solicitude on her account.&nbsp; Harriet would



<P>be anxiety enough; she need no longer be unhappy about Jane,



<P>whose troubles and whose ill-health having, of course, the same origin,



<P>must be equally under cure.--Her days of insignificance and evil



<P>were over.--She would soon be well, and happy, and prosperous.--



<P>Emma could now imagine why her own attentions had been slighted.



<P>This discovery laid many smaller matters open.&nbsp; No doubt it had

been



<P>from jealousy.--In Jane's eyes she had been a rival; and well might



<P>any thing she could offer of assistance or regard be repulsed.



<P>An airing in the Hartfield carriage would have been the rack,



<P>and arrowroot from the Hartfield storeroom must have been poison.



<P>She understood it all; and as far as her mind could disengage itself



<P>from the injustice and selfishness of angry feelings, she acknowledged



<P>that Jane Fairfax would have neither elevation nor happiness beyond



<P>her desert.&nbsp; But poor Harriet was such an engrossing charge!



<P>There was little sympathy to be spared for any body else.



<P>Emma was sadly fearful that this second disappointment would be



<P>more severe than the first.&nbsp; Considering the very superior claims



<P>of the object, it ought; and judging by its apparently stronger effect



<P>on Harriet's mind, producing reserve and self-command, it would.--



<P>She must communicate the painful truth, however, and as soon



<P>as possible.&nbsp; An injunction of secresy had been among Mr. Weston's



<P>parting words.&nbsp; "For the present, the whole affair was to be



<P>completely a secret.&nbsp; Mr. Churchill had made a point of it,



<P>as a token of respect to the wife he had so very recently lost;



<P>and every body admitted it to be no more than due decorum."--



<P>Emma had promised; but still Harriet must be excepted.&nbsp; It was

her



<P>superior duty.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In spite of her vexation, she could not help feeling it almost ridiculous,



<P>that she should have the very same distressing and delicate office to



<P>perform by Harriet, which Mrs. Weston had just gone through by herself.



<P>The intelligence, which had been so anxiously announced to her,



<P>she was now to be anxiously announcing to another.&nbsp; Her heart beat



<P>quick on hearing Harriet's footstep and voice; so, she supposed,



<P>had poor Mrs. Weston felt when she was approaching Randalls.



<P>Could the event of the disclosure bear an equal resemblance!--



<P>But of that, unfortunately, there could be no chance.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, Miss Woodhouse!" cried Harriet, coming eagerly into the room--



<P>"is not this the oddest news that ever was?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What news do you mean?" replied Emma, unable to guess, by look



<P>or voice, whether Harriet could indeed have received any hint.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"About Jane Fairfax.&nbsp; Did you ever hear any thing so strange?



<P>Oh!--you need not be afraid of owning it to me, for Mr. Weston has



<P>told me himself.&nbsp; I met him just now.&nbsp; He told me it was to

be



<P>a great secret; and, therefore, I should not think of mentioning



<P>it to any body but you, but he said you knew it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What did Mr. Weston tell you?"--said Emma, still perplexed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! he told me all about it; that Jane Fairfax and Mr. Frank



<P>Churchill are to be married, and that they have been privately



<P>engaged to one another this long while.&nbsp; How very odd!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was, indeed, so odd; Harriet's behaviour was so extremely odd,



<P>that Emma did not know how to understand it.&nbsp; Her character appeared



<P>absolutely changed.&nbsp; She seemed to propose shewing no agitation,



<P>or disappointment, or peculiar concern in the discovery.&nbsp; Emma

looked



<P>at her, quite unable to speak.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Had you any idea," cried Harriet, "of his being in love



<P>with her?--You, perhaps, might.--You (blushing as she spoke)



<P>who can see into every body's heart; but nobody else--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Upon my word," said Emma, "I begin to doubt my having any such talent.



<P>Can you seriously ask me, Harriet, whether I imagined him attached



<P>to another woman at the very time that I was--tacitly, if not openly--



<P>encouraging you to give way to your own feelings?--I never had



<P>the slightest suspicion, till within the last hour, of Mr. Frank



<P>Churchill's having the least regard for Jane Fairfax.&nbsp; You may

be



<P>very sure that if I had, I should have cautioned you accordingly."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Me!" cried Harriet, colouring, and astonished.&nbsp; "Why should you



<P>caution me?--You do not think I care about Mr. Frank Churchill."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am delighted to hear you speak so stoutly on the subject,"



<P>replied Emma, smiling; "but you do not mean to deny that there



<P>was a time--and not very distant either--when you gave me reason



<P>to understand that you did care about him?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Him!--never, never.&nbsp; Dear Miss Woodhouse, how could you so mistake

me?"



<P>turning away distressed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Harriet!" cried Emma, after a moment's pause--"What do you mean?--



<P>Good Heaven! what do you mean?--Mistake you!--Am I to suppose then?--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She could not speak another word.--Her voice was lost; and she



<P>sat down, waiting in great terror till Harriet should answer.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet, who was standing at some distance, and with face turned



<P>from her, did not immediately say any thing; and when she did speak,



<P>it was in a voice nearly as agitated as Emma's.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I should not have thought it possible," she began, "that you



<P>could have misunderstood me!&nbsp; I know we agreed never to name him--



<P>but considering how infinitely superior he is to every body else,



<P>I should not have thought it possible that I could be supposed



<P>to mean any other person.&nbsp; Mr. Frank Churchill, indeed!&nbsp; I

do not



<P>know who would ever look at him in the company of the other.



<P>I hope I have a better taste than to think of Mr. Frank Churchill,



<P>who is like nobody by his side.&nbsp; And that you should have been



<P>so mistaken, is amazing!--I am sure, but for believing that you



<P>entirely approved and meant to encourage me in my attachment,



<P>I should have considered it at first too great a presumption almost,



<P>to dare to think of him.&nbsp; At first, if you had not told me



<P>that more wonderful things had happened; that there had been



<P>matches of greater disparity (those were your very words);--



<P>I should not have dared to give way to--I should not have thought



<P>it possible--But if you, who had been always acquainted with him--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Harriet!" cried Emma, collecting herself resolutely--"Let us



<P>understand each other now, without the possibility of farther mistake.



<P>Are you speaking of--Mr. Knightley?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"To be sure I am.&nbsp; I never could have an idea of any body else--



<P>and so I thought you knew.&nbsp; When we talked about him, it was as

clear



<P>as possible."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not quite," returned Emma, with forced calmness, "for all that



<P>you then said, appeared to me to relate to a different person.



<P>I could almost assert that you had named Mr. Frank Churchill.



<P>I am sure the service Mr. Frank Churchill had rendered you,



<P>in protecting you from the gipsies, was spoken of."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh!&nbsp; Miss Woodhouse, how you do forget!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear Harriet, I perfectly remember the substance of what I



<P>said on the occasion.&nbsp; I told you that I did not wonder at



<P>your attachment; that considering the service he had rendered you,



<P>it was extremely natural:--and you agreed to it, expressing yourself



<P>very warmly as to your sense of that service, and mentioning



<P>even what your sensations had been in seeing him come forward



<P>to your rescue.--The impression of it is strong on my memory."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, dear," cried Harriet, "now I recollect what you mean; but I



<P>was thinking of something very different at the time.&nbsp; It was not



<P>the gipsies--it was not Mr. Frank Churchill that I meant.&nbsp; No!

(with



<P>some elevation) I was thinking of a much more precious circumstance--



<P>of Mr. Knightley's coming and asking me to dance, when Mr. Elton



<P>would not stand up with me; and when there was no other partner in



<P>the room.&nbsp; That was the kind action; that was the noble benevolence



<P>and generosity; that was the service which made me begin to feel



<P>how superior he was to every other being upon earth."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Good God!" cried Emma, "this has been a most unfortunate--



<P>most deplorable mistake!--What is to be done?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You would not have encouraged me, then, if you had understood me?



<P>At least, however, I cannot be worse off than I should have been,



<P>if the other had been the person; and now--it is possible--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She paused a few moments.&nbsp; Emma could not speak.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not wonder, Miss Woodhouse," she resumed, "that you should feel



<P>a great difference between the two, as to me or as to any body.



<P>You must think one five hundred million times more above me than



<P>the other.&nbsp; But I hope, Miss Woodhouse, that supposing--that if--



<P>strange as it may appear--.&nbsp; But you know they were your own words,



<P>that more wonderful things had happened, matches of greater disparity



<P>had taken place than between Mr. Frank Churchill and me; and, therefore,



<P>it seems as if such a thing even as this, may have occurred before--



<P>and if I should be so fortunate, beyond expression, as to--



<P>if Mr. Knightley should really--if he does not mind the disparity,



<P>I hope, dear Miss Woodhouse, you will not set yourself against it,



<P>and try to put difficulties in the way.&nbsp; But you are too good for

that,



<P>I am sure."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet was standing at one of the windows.&nbsp; Emma turned round



<P>to look at her in consternation, and hastily said,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Have you any idea of Mr. Knightley's returning your affection?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes," replied Harriet modestly, but not fearfully--"I must say



<P>that I have."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma's eyes were instantly withdrawn; and she sat silently meditating,



<P>in a fixed attitude, for a few minutes.&nbsp; A few minutes were sufficient



<P>for making her acquainted with her own heart.&nbsp; A mind like hers,



<P>once opening to suspicion, made rapid progress.&nbsp; She touched--



<P>she admitted--she acknowledged the whole truth.&nbsp; Why was it



<P>so much worse that Harriet should be in love with Mr. Knightley,



<P>than with Frank Churchill?&nbsp; Why was the evil so dreadfully increased



<P>by Harriet's having some hope of a return?&nbsp; It darted through her,



<P>with the speed of an arrow, that Mr. Knightley must marry no one



<P>but herself!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her own conduct, as well as her own heart, was before her in the



<P>same few minutes.&nbsp; She saw it all with a clearness which had



<P>never blessed her before.&nbsp; How improperly had she been acting



<P>by Harriet!&nbsp; How inconsiderate, how indelicate, how irrational,



<P>how unfeeling had been her conduct!&nbsp; What blindness, what madness,



<P>had led her on!&nbsp; It struck her with dreadful force, and she



<P>was ready to give it every bad name in the world.&nbsp; Some portion



<P>of respect for herself, however, in spite of all these demerits--



<P>some concern for her own appearance, and a strong sense of justice



<P>by Harriet--(there would be no need of compassion to the girl



<P>who believed herself loved by Mr. Knightley--but justice required



<P>that she should not be made unhappy by any coldness now,)



<P>gave Emma the resolution to sit and endure farther with calmness,



<P>with even apparent kindness.--For her own advantage indeed, it was fit



<P>that the utmost extent of Harriet's hopes should be enquired into;



<P>and Harriet had done nothing to forfeit the regard and interest



<P>which had been so voluntarily formed and maintained--or to deserve



<P>to be slighted by the person, whose counsels had never led her right.--



<P>Rousing from reflection, therefore, and subduing her emotion,



<P>she turned to Harriet again, and, in a more inviting accent, renewed



<P>the conversation; for as to the subject which had first introduced it,



<P>the wonderful story of Jane Fairfax, that was quite sunk and lost.--



<P>Neither of them thought but of Mr. Knightley and themselves.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet, who had been standing in no unhappy reverie, was yet very glad



<P>to be called from it, by the now encouraging manner of such a judge,



<P>and such a friend as Miss Woodhouse, and only wanted invitation,



<P>to give the history of her hopes with great, though trembling



<P>delight.--Emma's tremblings as she asked, and as she listened,



<P>were better concealed than Harriet's, but they were not less.



<P>Her voice was not unsteady; but her mind was in all the perturbation



<P>that such a development of self, such a burst of threatening evil,



<P>such a confusion of sudden and perplexing emotions, must create.--



<P>She listened with much inward suffering, but with great outward



<P>patience, to Harriet's detail.--Methodical, or well arranged,



<P>or very well delivered, it could not be expected to be;



<P>but it contained, when separated from all the feebleness and



<P>tautology of the narration, a substance to sink her spirit--



<P>especially with the corroborating circumstances, which her own memory



<P>brought in favour of Mr. Knightley's most improved opinion of Harriet.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet had been conscious of a difference in his behaviour ever since



<P>those two decisive dances.--Emma knew that he had, on that occasion,



<P>found her much superior to his expectation.&nbsp; From that evening,



<P>or at least from the time of Miss Woodhouse's encouraging her



<P>to think of him, Harriet had begun to be sensible of his talking



<P>to her much more than he had been used to do, and of his having



<P>indeed quite a different manner towards her; a manner of kindness



<P>and sweetness!--Latterly she had been more and more aware of it.



<P>When they had been all walking together, he had so often come and walked



<P>by her, and talked so very delightfully!--He seemed to want to be



<P>acquainted with her.&nbsp; Emma knew it to have been very much the case.



<P>She had often observed the change, to almost the same extent.--



<P>Harriet repeated expressions of approbation and praise from him--



<P>and Emma felt them to be in the closest agreement with what she had



<P>known of his opinion of Harriet.&nbsp; He praised her for being without



<P>art or affectation, for having simple, honest, generous, feelings.--



<P>She knew that he saw such recommendations in Harriet; he had dwelt



<P>on them to her more than once.--Much that lived in Harriet's memory,



<P>many little particulars of the notice she had received from him, a look,



<P>a speech, a removal from one chair to another, a compliment implied,



<P>a preference inferred, had been unnoticed, because unsuspected,



<P>by Emma.&nbsp; Circumstances that might swell to half an hour's relation,



<P>and contained multiplied proofs to her who had seen them, had passed



<P>undiscerned by her who now heard them; but the two latest occurrences



<P>to be mentioned, the two of strongest promise to Harriet, were not



<P>without some degree of witness from Emma herself.--The first,



<P>was his walking with her apart from the others, in the lime-walk



<P>at Donwell, where they had been walking some time before Emma came,



<P>and he had taken pains (as she was convinced) to draw her from



<P>the rest to himself--and at first, he had talked to her in a more



<P>particular way than he had ever done before, in a very particular



<P>way indeed!--(Harriet could not recall it without a blush.) He seemed



<P>to be almost asking her, whether her affections were engaged.--



<P>But as soon as she (Miss Woodhouse) appeared likely to join them,



<P>he changed the subject, and began talking about farming:--



<P>The second, was his having sat talking with her nearly half an hour



<P>before Emma came back from her visit, the very last morning of his



<P>being at Hartfield--though, when he first came in, he had said



<P>that he could not stay five minutes--and his having told her,



<P>during their conversation, that though he must go to London,



<P>it was very much against his inclination that he left home at all,



<P>which was much more (as Emma felt) than he had acknowledged to her.



<P>The superior degree of confidence towards Harriet, which this one



<P>article marked, gave her severe pain.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>On the subject of the first of the two circumstances, she did,



<P>after a little reflection, venture the following question.



<P>"Might he not?--Is not it possible, that when enquiring, as you thought,



<P>into the state of your affections, he might be alluding to Mr. Martin--



<P>he might have Mr. Martin's interest in view?&nbsp; But Harriet rejected



<P>the suspicion with spirit.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mr. Martin!&nbsp; No indeed!--There was not a hint of Mr. Martin.



<P>I hope I know better now, than to care for Mr. Martin, or to be



<P>suspected of it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When Harriet had closed her evidence, she appealed to her dear



<P>Miss Woodhouse, to say whether she had not good ground for hope.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I never should have presumed to think of it at first," said she,



<P>"but for you.&nbsp; You told me to observe him carefully, and let



<P>his behaviour be the rule of mine--and so I have.&nbsp; But now I seem



<P>to feel that I may deserve him; and that if he does chuse me,



<P>it will not be any thing so very wonderful."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The bitter feelings occasioned by this speech, the many bitter



<P>feelings, made the utmost exertion necessary on Emma's side,



<P>to enable her to say on reply,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Harriet, I will only venture to declare, that Mr. Knightley is



<P>the last man in the world, who would intentionally give any woman



<P>the idea of his feeling for her more than he really does."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet seemed ready to worship her friend for a sentence so satisfactory;



<P>and Emma was only saved from raptures and fondness, which at



<P>that moment would have been dreadful penance, by the sound of her



<P>father's footsteps.&nbsp; He was coming through the hall.&nbsp; Harriet

was



<P>too much agitated to encounter him.&nbsp; "She could not compose herself--



<P>Mr. Woodhouse would be alarmed--she had better go;"--with most ready



<P>encouragement from her friend, therefore, she passed off through



<P>another door--and the moment she was gone, this was the spontaneous



<P>burst of Emma's feelings:&nbsp; "Oh God! that I had never seen her!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The rest of the day, the following night, were hardly enough



<P>for her thoughts.--She was bewildered amidst the confusion



<P>of all that had rushed on her within the last few hours.



<P>Every moment had brought a fresh surprize; and every surprize



<P>must be matter of humiliation to her.--How to understand it all!



<P>How to understand the deceptions she had been thus practising



<P>on herself, and living under!--The blunders, the blindness of her



<P>own head and heart!--she sat still, she walked about, she tried her



<P>own room, she tried the shrubbery--in every place, every posture,



<P>she perceived that she had acted most weakly; that she had been imposed



<P>on by others in a most mortifying degree; that she had been imposing



<P>on herself in a degree yet more mortifying; that she was wretched,



<P>and should probably find this day but the beginning of wretchedness.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To understand, thoroughly understand her own heart, was the



<P>first endeavour.&nbsp; To that point went every leisure moment which

her



<P>father's claims on her allowed, and every moment of involuntary



<P>absence of mind.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>How long had Mr. Knightley been so dear to her, as every feeling



<P>declared him now to be?&nbsp; When had his influence, such influence

begun?--



<P>When had he succeeded to that place in her affection, which Frank



<P>Churchill had once, for a short period, occupied?--She looked back;



<P>she compared the two--compared them, as they had always stood in



<P>her estimation, from the time of the latter's becoming known to her--



<P>and as they must at any time have been compared by her, had it--



<P>oh! had it, by any blessed felicity, occurred to her, to institute



<P>the comparison.--She saw that there never had been a time when she



<P>did not consider Mr. Knightley as infinitely the superior, or when



<P>his regard for her had not been infinitely the most dear.&nbsp; She

saw,



<P>that in persuading herself, in fancying, in acting to the contrary,



<P>she had been entirely under a delusion, totally ignorant of her



<P>own heart--and, in short, that she had never really cared for Frank



<P>Churchill at all!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This was the conclusion of the first series of reflection.



<P>This was the knowledge of herself, on the first question of inquiry,



<P>which she reached; and without being long in reaching it.--



<P>She was most sorrowfully indignant; ashamed of every sensation



<P>but the one revealed to her--her affection for Mr. Knightley.--



<P>Every other part of her mind was disgusting.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>With insufferable vanity had she believed herself in the secret of every



<P>body's feelings; with unpardonable arrogance proposed to arrange every



<P>body's destiny.&nbsp; She was proved to have been universally mistaken;



<P>and she had not quite done nothing--for she had done mischief.



<P>She had brought evil on Harriet, on herself, and she too much feared,



<P>on Mr. Knightley.--Were this most unequal of all connexions to



<P>take place, on her must rest all the reproach of having given it



<P>a beginning; for his attachment, she must believe to be produced only



<P>by a consciousness of Harriet's;--and even were this not the case,



<P>he would never have known Harriet at all but for her folly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Knightley and Harriet Smith!--It was a union to distance every



<P>wonder of the kind.--The attachment of Frank Churchill and Jane



<P>Fairfax became commonplace, threadbare, stale in the comparison,



<P>exciting no surprize, presenting no disparity, affording nothing



<P>to be said or thought.--Mr. Knightley and Harriet Smith!--Such an



<P>elevation on her side!&nbsp; Such a debasement on his!&nbsp; It was

horrible



<P>to Emma to think how it must sink him in the general opinion,



<P>to foresee the smiles, the sneers, the merriment it would prompt at



<P>his expense; the mortification and disdain of his brother, the thousand



<P>inconveniences to himself.--Could it be?--No; it was impossible.



<P>And yet it was far, very far, from impossible.--Was it a new



<P>circumstance for a man of first-rate abilities to be captivated by



<P>very inferior powers?&nbsp; Was it new for one, perhaps too busy to

seek,



<P>to be the prize of a girl who would seek him?--Was it new for any



<P>thing in this world to be unequal, inconsistent, incongruous--or for



<P>chance and circumstance (as second causes) to direct the human fate?

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Oh! had she never brought Harriet forward!&nbsp; Had she left her where



<P>she ought, and where he had told her she ought!--Had she not,



<P>with a folly which no tongue could express, prevented her marrying



<P>the unexceptionable young man who would have made her happy



<P>and respectable in the line of life to which she ought to belong--



<P>all would have been safe; none of this dreadful sequel would have been.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>How Harriet could ever have had the presumption to raise



<P>her thoughts to Mr. Knightley!--How she could dare to fancy



<P>herself the chosen of such a man till actually assured of it!--



<P>But Harriet was less humble, had fewer scruples than formerly.--



<P>Her inferiority, whether of mind or situation, seemed little felt.--



<P>She had seemed more sensible of Mr. Elton's being to stoop



<P>in marrying her, than she now seemed of Mr. Knightley's.--



<P>Alas! was not that her own doing too?&nbsp; Who had been at pains to

give



<P>Harriet notions of self-consequence but herself?--Who but herself



<P>had taught her, that she was to elevate herself if possible,



<P>and that her claims were great to a high worldly establishment?--



<P>If Harriet, from being humble, were grown vain, it was her doing too.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 05</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER V</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>In this state of schemes, and hopes, and connivance, June opened



<P>upon Hartfield.&nbsp; To Highbury in general it brought no material

change.



<P>The Eltons were still talking of a visit from the Sucklings,



<P>and of the use to be made of their barouche-landau; and Jane Fairfax



<P>was still at her grandmother's; and as the return of the Campbells



<P>from Ireland was again delayed, and August, instead of Midsummer,



<P>fixed for it, she was likely to remain there full two months longer,



<P>provided at least she were able to defeat Mrs. Elton's activity



<P>in her service, and save herself from being hurried into a delightful



<P>situation against her will.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Knightley, who, for some reason best known to himself, had certainly



<P>taken an early dislike to Frank Churchill, was only growing to dislike



<P>him more.&nbsp; He began to suspect him of some double dealing in his



<P>pursuit of Emma.&nbsp; That Emma was his object appeared indisputable.



<P>Every thing declared it; his own attentions, his father's hints,



<P>his mother-in-law's guarded silence; it was all in unison;



<P>words, conduct, discretion, and indiscretion, told the same story.



<P>But while so many were devoting him to Emma, and Emma herself making

him



<P>over to Harriet, Mr. Knightley began to suspect him of some inclination



<P>to trifle with Jane Fairfax.&nbsp; He could not understand it; but there



<P>were symptoms of intelligence between them--he thought so at least--



<P>symptoms of admiration on his side, which, having once observed,



<P>he could not persuade himself to think entirely void of meaning,



<P>however he might wish to escape any of Emma's errors of imagination.



<P>She was not present when the suspicion first arose.&nbsp; He was dining



<P>with the Randalls family, and Jane, at the Eltons'; and he had



<P>seen a look, more than a single look, at Miss Fairfax, which,



<P>from the admirer of Miss Woodhouse, seemed somewhat out of place.



<P>When he was again in their company, he could not help remembering



<P>what he had seen; nor could he avoid observations which, unless it



<P>were like Cowper and his fire at twilight,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Myself creating what I saw,"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>brought him yet stronger suspicion of there being a something



<P>of private liking, of private understanding even, between Frank



<P>Churchill and Jane.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He had walked up one day after dinner, as he very often did,



<P>to spend his evening at Hartfield.&nbsp; Emma and Harriet were going



<P>to walk; he joined them; and, on returning, they fell in with a



<P>larger party, who, like themselves, judged it wisest to take their



<P>exercise early, as the weather threatened rain; Mr. and Mrs. Weston



<P>and their son, Miss Bates and her niece, who had accidentally met.



<P>They all united; and, on reaching Hartfield gates, Emma, who knew it



<P>was exactly the sort of visiting that would be welcome to her father,



<P>pressed them all to go in and drink tea with him.&nbsp; The Randalls



<P>party agreed to it immediately; and after a pretty long speech



<P>from Miss Bates, which few persons listened to, she also found it



<P>possible to accept dear Miss Woodhouse's most obliging invitation.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As they were turning into the grounds, Mr. Perry passed by on horseback.



<P>The gentlemen spoke of his horse.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"By the bye," said Frank Churchill to Mrs. Weston presently,



<P>"what became of Mr. Perry's plan of setting up his carriage?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Weston looked surprized, and said, "I did not know that he



<P>ever had any such plan."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nay, I had it from you.&nbsp; You wrote me word of it three months

ago."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Me! impossible!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Indeed you did.&nbsp; I remember it perfectly.&nbsp; You mentioned

it as



<P>what was certainly to be very soon.&nbsp; Mrs. Perry had told somebody,



<P>and was extremely happy about it.&nbsp; It was owing to her persuasion,



<P>as she thought his being out in bad weather did him a great deal



<P>of harm.&nbsp; You must remember it now?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Upon my word I never heard of it till this moment."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Never! really, never!--Bless me! how could it be?--Then I must



<P>have dreamt it--but I was completely persuaded--Miss Smith,



<P>you walk as if you were tired.&nbsp; You will not be sorry to find



<P>yourself at home."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What is this?--What is this?" cried Mr. Weston, "about Perry



<P>and a carriage?&nbsp; Is Perry going to set up his carriage, Frank?



<P>I am glad he can afford it.&nbsp; You had it from himself, had you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, sir," replied his son, laughing, "I seem to have had it



<P>from nobody.--Very odd!--I really was persuaded of Mrs. Weston's



<P>having mentioned it in one of her letters to Enscombe, many weeks ago,



<P>with all these particulars--but as she declares she never heard



<P>a syllable of it before, of course it must have been a dream.&nbsp;

I am



<P>a great dreamer.&nbsp; I dream of every body at Highbury when I am away--



<P>and when I have gone through my particular friends, then I begin



<P>dreaming of Mr. and Mrs. Perry."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is odd though," observed his father, "that you should have had such



<P>a regular connected dream about people whom it was not very likely you



<P>should be thinking of at Enscombe.&nbsp; Perry's setting up his carriage!



<P>and his wife's persuading him to it, out of care for his health--



<P>just what will happen, I have no doubt, some time or other;



<P>only a little premature.&nbsp; What an air of probability sometimes



<P>runs through a dream!&nbsp; And at others, what a heap of absurdities



<P>it is!&nbsp; Well, Frank, your dream certainly shews that Highbury is

in



<P>your thoughts when you are absent.&nbsp; Emma, you are a great dreamer,



<P>I think?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma was out of hearing.&nbsp; She had hurried on before her guests



<P>to prepare her father for their appearance, and was beyond the reach



<P>of Mr. Weston's hint.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why, to own the truth," cried Miss Bates, who had been trying in vain



<P>to be heard the last two minutes, "if I must speak on this subject,



<P>there is no denying that Mr. Frank Churchill might have--I do not



<P>mean to say that he did not dream it--I am sure I have sometimes



<P>the oddest dreams in the world--but if I am questioned about it,



<P>I must acknowledge that there was such an idea last spring;



<P>for Mrs. Perry herself mentioned it to my mother, and the Coles



<P>knew of it as well as ourselves--but it was quite a secret,



<P>known to nobody else, and only thought of about three days.



<P>Mrs. Perry was very anxious that he should have a carriage, and came



<P>to my mother in great spirits one morning because she thought she



<P>had prevailed.&nbsp; Jane, don't you remember grandmama's telling us



<P>of it when we got home?&nbsp; I forget where we had been walking to--



<P>very likely to Randalls; yes, I think it was to Randalls.



<P>Mrs. Perry was always particularly fond of my mother--indeed I do



<P>not know who is not--and she had mentioned it to her in confidence;



<P>she had no objection to her telling us, of course, but it was not



<P>to go beyond:&nbsp; and, from that day to this, I never mentioned it



<P>to a soul that I know of.&nbsp; At the same time, I will not positively



<P>answer for my having never dropt a hint, because I know I do



<P>sometimes pop out a thing before I am aware.&nbsp; I am a talker,



<P>you know; I am rather a talker; and now and then I have let a thing



<P>escape me which I should not.&nbsp; I am not like Jane; I wish I were.



<P>I will answer for it she never betrayed the least thing in the world.



<P>Where is she?--Oh! just behind.&nbsp; Perfectly remember Mrs. Perry's

coming.--



<P>Extraordinary dream, indeed!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They were entering the hall.&nbsp; Mr. Knightley's eyes had preceded



<P>Miss Bates's in a glance at Jane.&nbsp; From Frank Churchill's face,



<P>where he thought he saw confusion suppressed or laughed away,



<P>he had involuntarily turned to hers; but she was indeed behind,



<P>and too busy with her shawl.&nbsp; Mr. Weston had walked in.&nbsp; The

two



<P>other gentlemen waited at the door to let her pass.&nbsp; Mr. Knightley



<P>suspected in Frank Churchill the determination of catching her eye--



<P>he seemed watching her intently--in vain, however, if it were so--



<P>Jane passed between them into the hall, and looked at neither.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was no time for farther remark or explanation.&nbsp; The dream

must



<P>be borne with, and Mr. Knightley must take his seat with the rest round



<P>the large modern circular table which Emma had introduced at Hartfield,



<P>and which none but Emma could have had power to place there and



<P>persuade her father to use, instead of the small-sized Pembroke,



<P>on which two of his daily meals had, for forty years been crowded.



<P>Tea passed pleasantly, and nobody seemed in a hurry to move.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Miss Woodhouse," said Frank Churchill, after examining a table



<P>behind him, which he could reach as he sat, "have your nephews taken



<P>away their alphabets--their box of letters?&nbsp; It used to stand here.



<P>Where is it?&nbsp; This is a sort of dull-looking evening, that ought



<P>to be treated rather as winter than summer.&nbsp; We had great amusement



<P>with those letters one morning.&nbsp; I want to puzzle you again."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma was pleased with the thought; and producing the box, the table



<P>was quickly scattered over with alphabets, which no one seemed so much



<P>disposed to employ as their two selves.&nbsp; They were rapidly forming



<P>words for each other, or for any body else who would be puzzled.



<P>The quietness of the game made it particularly eligible for



<P>Mr. Woodhouse, who had often been distressed by the more animated sort,



<P>which Mr. Weston had occasionally introduced, and who now sat happily



<P>occupied in lamenting, with tender melancholy, over the departure



<P>of the "poor little boys," or in fondly pointing out, as he took



<P>up any stray letter near him, how beautifully Emma had written it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Frank Churchill placed a word before Miss Fairfax.&nbsp; She gave



<P>a slight glance round the table, and applied herself to it.



<P>Frank was next to Emma, Jane opposite to them--and Mr. Knightley



<P>so placed as to see them all; and it was his object to see as much



<P>as he could, with as little apparent observation.&nbsp; The word



<P>was discovered, and with a faint smile pushed away.&nbsp; If meant



<P>to be immediately mixed with the others, and buried from sight,



<P>she should have looked on the table instead of looking just across,



<P>for it was not mixed; and Harriet, eager after every fresh word,



<P>and finding out none, directly took it up, and fell to work.



<P>She was sitting by Mr. Knightley, and turned to him for help.



<P>The word was blunder; and as Harriet exultingly proclaimed it,



<P>there was a blush on Jane's cheek which gave it a meaning not



<P>otherwise ostensible.&nbsp; Mr. Knightley connected it with the dream;



<P>but how it could all be, was beyond his comprehension.



<P>How the delicacy, the discretion of his favourite could have been



<P>so lain asleep!&nbsp; He feared there must be some decided involvement.



<P>Disingenuousness and double dealing seemed to meet him at every turn.



<P>These letters were but the vehicle for gallantry and trick.



<P>It was a child's play, chosen to conceal a deeper game on Frank



<P>Churchill's part.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>With great indignation did he continue to observe him; with great



<P>alarm and distrust, to observe also his two blinded companions.



<P>He saw a short word prepared for Emma, and given to her with a look



<P>sly and demure.&nbsp; He saw that Emma had soon made it out, and found



<P>it highly entertaining, though it was something which she judged it



<P>proper to appear to censure; for she said, "Nonsense! for shame!"



<P>He heard Frank Churchill next say, with a glance towards Jane,



<P>"I will give it to her--shall I?"--and as clearly heard Emma



<P>opposing it with eager laughing warmth.&nbsp; "No, no, you must not;



<P>you shall not, indeed."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was done however.&nbsp; This gallant young man, who seemed to love



<P>without feeling, and to recommend himself without complaisance,



<P>directly handed over the word to Miss Fairfax, and with a particular



<P>degree of sedate civility entreated her to study it.&nbsp; Mr. Knightley's



<P>excessive curiosity to know what this word might be, made him seize



<P>every possible moment for darting his eye towards it, and it was



<P>not long before he saw it to be Dixon.&nbsp; Jane Fairfax's perception



<P>seemed to accompany his; her comprehension was certainly more equal



<P>to the covert meaning, the superior intelligence, of those five letters



<P>so arranged.&nbsp; She was evidently displeased; looked up, and seeing



<P>herself watched, blushed more deeply than he had ever perceived her,



<P>and saying only, "I did not know that proper names were allowed,"



<P>pushed away the letters with even an angry spirit, and looked



<P>resolved to be engaged by no other word that could be offered.



<P>Her face was averted from those who had made the attack, and turned



<P>towards her aunt.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Aye, very true, my dear," cried the latter, though Jane had not



<P>spoken a word--"I was just going to say the same thing.&nbsp; It is

time



<P>for us to be going indeed.&nbsp; The evening is closing in, and grandmama



<P>will be looking for us.&nbsp; My dear sir, you are too obliging.



<P>We really must wish you good night."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jane's alertness in moving, proved her as ready as her aunt



<P>had preconceived.&nbsp; She was immediately up, and wanting to quit



<P>the table; but so many were also moving, that she could not get away;



<P>and Mr. Knightley thought he saw another collection of letters anxiously



<P>pushed towards her, and resolutely swept away by her unexamined.



<P>She was afterwards looking for her shawl--Frank Churchill was



<P>looking also--it was growing dusk, and the room was in confusion;



<P>and how they parted, Mr. Knightley could not tell.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He remained at Hartfield after all the rest, his thoughts full



<P>of what he had seen; so full, that when the candles came to assist



<P>his observations, he must--yes, he certainly must, as a friend--



<P>an anxious friend--give Emma some hint, ask her some question.



<P>He could not see her in a situation of such danger, without trying to



<P>preserve her.&nbsp; It was his duty.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Pray, Emma," said he, "may I ask in what lay the great amusement,



<P>the poignant sting of the last word given to you and Miss Fairfax?



<P>I saw the word, and am curious to know how it could be so very



<P>entertaining to the one, and so very distressing to the other."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma was extremely confused.&nbsp; She could not endure to give him

the



<P>true explanation; for though her suspicions were by no means removed,



<P>she was really ashamed of having ever imparted them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh!" she cried in evident embarrassment, "it all meant nothing;



<P>a mere joke among ourselves."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The joke," he replied gravely, "seemed confined to you



<P>and Mr. Churchill."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He had hoped she would speak again, but she did not.&nbsp; She would



<P>rather busy herself about any thing than speak.&nbsp; He sat a little



<P>while in doubt.&nbsp; A variety of evils crossed his mind.&nbsp; Interference--



<P>fruitless interference.&nbsp; Emma's confusion, and the acknowledged

intimacy,



<P>seemed to declare her affection engaged.&nbsp; Yet he would speak.



<P>He owed it to her, to risk any thing that might be involved in



<P>an unwelcome interference, rather than her welfare; to encounter



<P>any thing, rather than the remembrance of neglect in such a cause.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear Emma," said he at last, with earnest kindness, "do you



<P>think you perfectly understand the degree of acquaintance between



<P>the gentleman and lady we have been speaking of?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Between Mr. Frank Churchill and Miss Fairfax?&nbsp; Oh! yes, perfectly.--



<P>Why do you make a doubt of it?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Have you never at any time had reason to think that he admired her,



<P>or that she admired him?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Never, never!" she cried with a most open eagerness--"Never, for



<P>the twentieth part of a moment, did such an idea occur to me.



<P>And how could it possibly come into your head?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have lately imagined that I saw symptoms of attachment between them--



<P>certain expressive looks, which I did not believe meant to be public."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! you amuse me excessively.&nbsp; I am delighted to find that you



<P>can vouchsafe to let your imagination wander--but it will not do--



<P>very sorry to check you in your first essay--but indeed it will



<P>not do.&nbsp; There is no admiration between them, I do assure you;



<P>and the appearances which have caught you, have arisen from some



<P>peculiar circumstances--feelings rather of a totally different nature--



<P>it is impossible exactly to explain:--there is a good deal of



<P>nonsense in it--but the part which is capable of being communicated,



<P>which is sense, is, that they are as far from any attachment or



<P>admiration for one another, as any two beings in the world can be.



<P>That is, I presume it to be so on her side, and I can answer for its



<P>being so on his.&nbsp; I will answer for the gentleman's indifference."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She spoke with a confidence which staggered, with a satisfaction



<P>which silenced, Mr. Knightley.&nbsp; She was in gay spirits, and would



<P>have prolonged the conversation, wanting to hear the particulars



<P>of his suspicions, every look described, and all the wheres and hows



<P>of a circumstance which highly entertained her:&nbsp; but his gaiety

did



<P>not meet hers.&nbsp; He found he could not be useful, and his feelings



<P>were too much irritated for talking.&nbsp; That he might not be irritated



<P>into an absolute fever, by the fire which Mr. Woodhouse's tender



<P>habits required almost every evening throughout the year, he soon



<P>afterwards took a hasty leave, and walked home to the coolness



<P>and solitude of Donwell Abbey.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 13</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XIII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>The weather continued much the same all the following morning;



<P>and the same loneliness, and the same melancholy, seemed to



<P>reign at Hartfield--but in the afternoon it cleared; the wind



<P>changed into a softer quarter; the clouds were carried off;



<P>the sun appeared; it was summer again.&nbsp; With all the eagerness



<P>which such a transition gives, Emma resolved to be out of doors



<P>as soon as possible.&nbsp; Never had the exquisite sight, smell,



<P>sensation of nature, tranquil, warm, and brilliant after a storm,



<P>been more attractive to her.&nbsp; She longed for the serenity they

might



<P>gradually introduce; and on Mr. Perry's coming in soon after dinner,



<P>with a disengaged hour to give her father, she lost no time ill



<P>hurrying into the shrubbery.--There, with spirits freshened,



<P>and thoughts a little relieved, she had taken a few turns, when she



<P>saw Mr. Knightley passing through the garden door, and coming



<P>towards her.--It was the first intimation of his being returned



<P>from London.&nbsp; She had been thinking of him the moment before,



<P>as unquestionably sixteen miles distant.--There was time only for



<P>the quickest arrangement of mind.&nbsp; She must be collected and calm.



<P>In half a minute they were together.&nbsp; The "How d'ye do's" were

quiet



<P>and constrained on each side.&nbsp; She asked after their mutual friends;



<P>they were all well.--When had he left them?--Only that morning.



<P>He must have had a wet ride.--Yes.--He meant to walk with her,



<P>she found.&nbsp; "He had just looked into the dining-room, and as he



<P>was not wanted there, preferred being out of doors."--She thought



<P>he neither looked nor spoke cheerfully; and the first possible



<P>cause for it, suggested by her fears, was, that he had perhaps been



<P>communicating his plans to his brother, and was pained by the manner



<P>in which they had been received.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They walked together.&nbsp; He was silent.&nbsp; She thought he was

often



<P>looking at her, and trying for a fuller view of her face than it



<P>suited her to give.&nbsp; And this belief produced another dread.



<P>Perhaps he wanted to speak to her, of his attachment to Harriet;



<P>he might be watching for encouragement to begin.--She did not,



<P>could not, feel equal to lead the way to any such subject.



<P>He must do it all himself.&nbsp; Yet she could not bear this silence.



<P>With him it was most unnatural.&nbsp; She considered--resolved--and,

trying



<P>to smile, began--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You have some news to hear, now you are come back, that will rather



<P>surprize you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Have I?" said he quietly, and looking at her; "of what nature?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! the best nature in the world--a wedding."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After waiting a moment, as if to be sure she intended to say no more,



<P>he replied,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If you mean Miss Fairfax and Frank Churchill, I have heard



<P>that already."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How is it possible?" cried Emma, turning her glowing cheeks



<P>towards him; for, while she spoke, it occurred to her that he



<P>might have called at Mrs. Goddard's in his way.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I had a few lines on parish business from Mr. Weston this morning,



<P>and at the end of them he gave me a brief account of what had happened."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma was quite relieved, and could presently say, with a little



<P>more composure,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You probably have been less surprized than any of us, for you have



<P>had your suspicions.--I have not forgotten that you once tried to give



<P>me a caution.--I wish I had attended to it--but--(with a sinking



<P>voice and a heavy sigh) I seem to have been doomed to blindness."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>For a moment or two nothing was said, and she was unsuspicious



<P>of having excited any particular interest, till she found her arm



<P>drawn within his, and pressed against his heart, and heard him



<P>thus saying, in a tone of great sensibility, speaking low,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Time, my dearest Emma, time will heal the wound.--Your own



<P>excellent sense--your exertions for your father's sake--I know



<P>you will not allow yourself--."&nbsp; Her arm was pressed again,



<P>as he added, in a more broken and subdued accent, "The feelings



<P>of the warmest friendship--Indignation--Abominable scoundrel!"--



<P>And in a louder, steadier tone, he concluded with, "He will soon



<P>be gone.&nbsp; They will soon be in Yorkshire.&nbsp; I am sorry for

her.



<P>She deserves a better fate."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma understood him; and as soon as she could recover from the



<P>flutter of pleasure, excited by such tender consideration, replied,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are very kind--but you are mistaken--and I must set you right.--



<P>I am not in want of that sort of compassion.&nbsp; My blindness to what



<P>was going on, led me to act by them in a way that I must always



<P>be ashamed of, and I was very foolishly tempted to say and do many



<P>things which may well lay me open to unpleasant conjectures, but I



<P>have no other reason to regret that I was not in the secret earlier."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Emma!" cried he, looking eagerly at her, "are you, indeed?"--



<P>but checking himself--"No, no, I understand you--forgive me--I am



<P>pleased that you can say even so much.--He is no object of regret,



<P>indeed! and it will not be very long, I hope, before that becomes



<P>the acknowledgment of more than your reason.--Fortunate that your



<P>affections were not farther entangled!--I could never, I confess,



<P>from your manners, assure myself as to the degree of what you felt--



<P>I could only be certain that there was a preference--and a preference



<P>which I never believed him to deserve.--He is a disgrace to the name



<P>of man.--And is he to be rewarded with that sweet young woman?--



<P>Jane, Jane, you will be a miserable creature."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mr. Knightley," said Emma, trying to be lively, but really confused--



<P>"I am in a very extraordinary situation.&nbsp; I cannot let you continue

in



<P>your error; and yet, perhaps, since my manners gave such an impression,



<P>I have as much reason to be ashamed of confessing that I never have



<P>been at all attached to the person we are speaking of, as it might



<P>be natural for a woman to feel in confessing exactly the reverse.--



<P>But I never have."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He listened in perfect silence.&nbsp; She wished him to speak, but he



<P>would not.&nbsp; She supposed she must say more before she were entitled



<P>to his clemency; but it was a hard case to be obliged still to lower



<P>herself in his opinion.&nbsp; She went on, however.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have very little to say for my own conduct.--I was tempted



<P>by his attentions, and allowed myself to appear pleased.--



<P>An old story, probably--a common case--and no more than has happened



<P>to hundreds of my sex before; and yet it may not be the more excusable



<P>in one who sets up as I do for Understanding.&nbsp; Many circumstances



<P>assisted the temptation.&nbsp; He was the son of Mr. Weston--he was



<P>continually here--I always found him very pleasant--and, in short,



<P>for (with a sigh) let me swell out the causes ever so ingeniously,



<P>they all centre in this at last--my vanity was flattered, and I



<P>allowed his attentions.&nbsp; Latterly, however--for some time, indeed--



<P>I have had no idea of their meaning any thing.--I thought them



<P>a habit, a trick, nothing that called for seriousness on my side.



<P>He has imposed on me, but he has not injured me.&nbsp; I have never

been



<P>attached to him.&nbsp; And now I can tolerably comprehend his behaviour.



<P>He never wished to attach me.&nbsp; It was merely a blind to conceal



<P>his real situation with another.--It was his object to blind



<P>all about him; and no one, I am sure, could be more effectually



<P>blinded than myself--except that I was not blinded--that it was my



<P>good fortune--that, in short, I was somehow or other safe from him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She had hoped for an answer here--for a few words to say that her



<P>conduct was at least intelligible; but he was silent; and, as far



<P>as she could judge, deep in thought.&nbsp; At last, and tolerably



<P>in his usual tone, he said,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have never had a high opinion of Frank Churchill.--I can suppose,



<P>however, that I may have underrated him.&nbsp; My acquaintance with



<P>him has been but trifling.--And even if I have not underrated



<P>him hitherto, he may yet turn out well.--With such a woman he has



<P>a chance.--I have no motive for wishing him ill--and for her sake,



<P>whose happiness will be involved in his good character and conduct,



<P>I shall certainly wish him well."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have no doubt of their being happy together," said Emma;



<P>"I believe them to be very mutually and very sincerely attached."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He is a most fortunate man!" returned Mr. Knightley, with energy.



<P>"So early in life--at three-and-twenty--a period when, if a man



<P>chuses a wife, he generally chuses ill.&nbsp; At three-and-twenty



<P>to have drawn such a prize!&nbsp; What years of felicity that man,



<P>in all human calculation, has before him!--Assured of the love of



<P>such a woman--the disinterested love, for Jane Fairfax's character



<P>vouches for her disinterestedness; every thing in his favour,--



<P>equality of situation--I mean, as far as regards society, and all the



<P>habits and manners that are important; equality in every point but one--



<P>and that one, since the purity of her heart is not to be doubted,



<P>such as must increase his felicity, for it will be his to bestow the



<P>only advantages she wants.--A man would always wish to give a woman



<P>a better home than the one he takes her from; and he who can do it,



<P>where there is no doubt of her regard, must, I think, be the happiest



<P>of mortals.--Frank Churchill is, indeed, the favourite of fortune.



<P>Every thing turns out for his good.--He meets with a young woman



<P>at a watering-place, gains her affection, cannot even weary her



<P>by negligent treatment--and had he and all his family sought round



<P>the world for a perfect wife for him, they could not have found



<P>her superior.--His aunt is in the way.--His aunt dies.--He has



<P>only to speak.--His friends are eager to promote his happiness.--



<P>He had used every body ill--and they are all delighted to forgive him.--



<P>He is a fortunate man indeed!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You speak as if you envied him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And I do envy him, Emma.&nbsp; In one respect he is the object of my

envy."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma could say no more.&nbsp; They seemed to be within half a sentence



<P>of Harriet, and her immediate feeling was to avert the subject,



<P>if possible.&nbsp; She made her plan; she would speak of something



<P>totally different--the children in Brunswick Square; and she



<P>only waited for breath to begin, when Mr. Knightley startled her,



<P>by saying,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You will not ask me what is the point of envy.--You are determined,



<P>I see, to have no curiosity.--You are wise--but I cannot be wise.



<P>Emma, I must tell you what you will not ask, though I may wish it



<P>unsaid the next moment."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! then, don't speak it, don't speak it," she eagerly cried.



<P>"Take a little time, consider, do not commit yourself."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thank you," said he, in an accent of deep mortification, and not



<P>another syllable followed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma could not bear to give him pain.&nbsp; He was wishing to confide

in her--



<P>perhaps to consult her;--cost her what it would, she would listen.



<P>She might assist his resolution, or reconcile him to it;



<P>she might give just praise to Harriet, or, by representing to him



<P>his own independence, relieve him from that state of indecision,



<P>which must be more intolerable than any alternative to such a mind



<P>as his.--They had reached the house.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are going in, I suppose?" said he.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No,"--replied Emma--quite confirmed by the depressed manner



<P>in which he still spoke--"I should like to take another turn.



<P>Mr. Perry is not gone."&nbsp; And, after proceeding a few steps, she

added--



<P>"I stopped you ungraciously, just now, Mr. Knightley, and, I am afraid,



<P>gave you pain.--But if you have any wish to speak openly to me



<P>as a friend, or to ask my opinion of any thing that you may have



<P>in contemplation--as a friend, indeed, you may command me.--I will



<P>hear whatever you like.&nbsp; I will tell you exactly what I think."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"As a friend!"--repeated Mr. Knightley.--"Emma, that I fear is



<P>a word--No, I have no wish--Stay, yes, why should I hesitate?--



<P>I have gone too far already for concealment.--Emma, I accept your offer--



<P>Extraordinary as it may seem, I accept it, and refer myself to you



<P>as a friend.--Tell me, then, have I no chance of ever succeeding?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He stopped in his earnestness to look the question, and the expression



<P>of his eyes overpowered her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dearest Emma," said he, "for dearest you will always be,



<P>whatever the event of this hour's conversation, my dearest,



<P>most beloved Emma--tell me at once.&nbsp; Say `No,' if it is to be said."--



<P>She could really say nothing.--"You are silent," he cried,



<P>with great animation; "absolutely silent! at present I ask no more."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma was almost ready to sink under the agitation of this moment.



<P>The dread of being awakened from the happiest dream, was perhaps



<P>the most prominent feeling.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I cannot make speeches, Emma:"&nbsp; he soon resumed; and in a tone



<P>of such sincere, decided, intelligible tenderness as was



<P>tolerably convincing.--"If I loved you less, I might be able



<P>to talk about it more.&nbsp; But you know what I am.--You hear nothing



<P>but truth from me.--I have blamed you, and lectured you, and you



<P>have borne it as no other woman in England would have borne it.--



<P>Bear with the truths I would tell you now, dearest Emma, as well as



<P>you have borne with them.&nbsp; The manner, perhaps, may have as little



<P>to recommend them.&nbsp; God knows, I have been a very indifferent lover.--



<P>But you understand me.--Yes, you see, you understand my feelings--



<P>and will return them if you can.&nbsp; At present, I ask only to hear,



<P>once to hear your voice."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>While he spoke, Emma's mind was most busy, and, with all the wonderful



<P>velocity of thought, had been able--and yet without losing a word--



<P>to catch and comprehend the exact truth of the whole; to see that



<P>Harriet's hopes had been entirely groundless, a mistake, a delusion,



<P>as complete a delusion as any of her own--that Harriet was nothing;



<P>that she was every thing herself; that what she had been saying



<P>relative to Harriet had been all taken as the language of her



<P>own feelings; and that her agitation, her doubts, her reluctance,



<P>her discouragement, had been all received as discouragement



<P>from herself.--And not only was there time for these convictions,



<P>with all their glow of attendant happiness; there was time also to



<P>rejoice that Harriet's secret had not escaped her, and to resolve



<P>that it need not, and should not.--It was all the service she could



<P>now render her poor friend; for as to any of that heroism of sentiment



<P>which might have prompted her to entreat him to transfer his affection



<P>from herself to Harriet, as infinitely the most worthy of the two--



<P>or even the more simple sublimity of resolving to refuse him



<P>at once and for ever, without vouchsafing any motive, because he



<P>could not marry them both, Emma had it not.&nbsp; She felt for Harriet,



<P>with pain and with contrition; but no flight of generosity run mad,



<P>opposing all that could be probable or reasonable, entered her brain.



<P>She had led her friend astray, and it would be a reproach to



<P>her for ever; but her judgment was as strong as her feelings,



<P>and as strong as it had ever been before, in reprobating any such



<P>alliance for him, as most unequal and degrading.&nbsp; Her way was clear,



<P>though not quite smooth.--She spoke then, on being so entreated.--



<P>What did she say?--Just what she ought, of course.&nbsp; A lady always

does.--



<P>She said enough to shew there need not be despair--and to invite him



<P>to say more himself.&nbsp; He had despaired at one period; he had received



<P>such an injunction to caution and silence, as for the time crushed



<P>every hope;--she had begun by refusing to hear him.--The change had



<P>perhaps been somewhat sudden;--her proposal of taking another turn,



<P>her renewing the conversation which she had just put an end to,



<P>might be a little extraordinary!--She felt its inconsistency;



<P>but Mr. Knightley was so obliging as to put up with it, and seek no



<P>farther explanation.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Seldom, very seldom, does complete truth belong to any human disclosure;



<P>seldom can it happen that something is not a little disguised,



<P>or a little mistaken; but where, as in this case, though the conduct



<P>is mistaken, the feelings are not, it may not be very material.--



<P>Mr. Knightley could not impute to Emma a more relenting heart than



<P>she possessed, or a heart more disposed to accept of his.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He had, in fact, been wholly unsuspicious of his own influence.



<P>He had followed her into the shrubbery with no idea of trying it.



<P>He had come, in his anxiety to see how she bore Frank Churchill's



<P>engagement, with no selfish view, no view at all, but of endeavouring,



<P>if she allowed him an opening, to soothe or to counsel her.--The rest



<P>had been the work of the moment, the immediate effect of what he heard,



<P>on his feelings.&nbsp; The delightful assurance of her total indifference



<P>towards Frank Churchill, of her having a heart completely disengaged



<P>from him, had given birth to the hope, that, in time, he might gain



<P>her affection himself;--but it had been no present hope--he had only,



<P>in the momentary conquest of eagerness over judgment, aspired to be



<P>told that she did not forbid his attempt to attach her.--The superior



<P>hopes which gradually opened were so much the more enchanting.--



<P>The affection, which he had been asking to be allowed to create,



<P>if he could, was already his!--Within half an hour, he had passed



<P>from a thoroughly distressed state of mind, to something so like



<P>perfect happiness, that it could bear no other name.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her change was equal.--This one half-hour had given to each the



<P>same precious certainty of being beloved, had cleared from each



<P>the same degree of ignorance, jealousy, or distrust.--On his side,



<P>there had been a long-standing jealousy, old as the arrival,



<P>or even the expectation, of Frank Churchill.--He had been in love



<P>with Emma, and jealous of Frank Churchill, from about the same period,



<P>one sentiment having probably enlightened him as to the other.



<P>It was his jealousy of Frank Churchill that had taken him from



<P>the country.--The Box Hill party had decided him on going away.



<P>He would save himself from witnessing again such permitted,



<P>encouraged attentions.--He had gone to learn to be indifferent.--



<P>But he had gone to a wrong place.&nbsp; There was too much domestic



<P>happiness in his brother's house; woman wore too amiable a form in it;



<P>Isabella was too much like Emma--differing only in those striking



<P>inferiorities, which always brought the other in brilliancy before him,



<P>for much to have been done, even had his time been longer.--He had



<P>stayed on, however, vigorously, day after day--till this very morning's



<P>post had conveyed the history of Jane Fairfax.--Then, with the



<P>gladness which must be felt, nay, which he did not scruple to feel,



<P>having never believed Frank Churchill to be at all deserving Emma,



<P>was there so much fond solicitude, so much keen anxiety for her,



<P>that he could stay no longer.&nbsp; He had ridden home through the rain;



<P>and had walked up directly after dinner, to see how this sweetest



<P>and best of all creatures, faultless in spite of all her faults,



<P>bore the discovery.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He had found her agitated and low.--Frank Churchill was a villain.--



<P>He heard her declare that she had never loved him.&nbsp; Frank Churchill's



<P>character was not desperate.--She was his own Emma, by hand and word,



<P>when they returned into the house; and if he could have thought



<P>of Frank Churchill then, he might have deemed him a very good sort



<P>of fellow.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 07</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER VII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>They had a very fine day for Box Hill; and all the other outward



<P>circumstances of arrangement, accommodation, and punctuality,



<P>were in favour of a pleasant party.&nbsp; Mr. Weston directed the whole,



<P>officiating safely between Hartfield and the Vicarage, and every



<P>body was in good time.&nbsp; Emma and Harriet went together; Miss Bates



<P>and her niece, with the Eltons; the gentlemen on horseback.



<P>Mrs. Weston remained with Mr. Woodhouse.&nbsp; Nothing was wanting



<P>but to be happy when they got there.&nbsp; Seven miles were travelled



<P>in expectation of enjoyment, and every body had a burst of admiration



<P>on first arriving; but in the general amount of the day there



<P>was deficiency.&nbsp; There was a languor, a want of spirits, a want

of union,



<P>which could not be got over.&nbsp; They separated too much into parties.



<P>The Eltons walked together; Mr. Knightley took charge of Miss



<P>Bates and Jane; and Emma and Harriet belonged to Frank Churchill.



<P>And Mr. Weston tried, in vain, to make them harmonise better.&nbsp;

It seemed



<P>at first an accidental division, but it never materially varied.



<P>Mr. and Mrs. Elton, indeed, shewed no unwillingness to mix,



<P>and be as agreeable as they could; but during the two whole hours



<P>that were spent on the hill, there seemed a principle of separation,



<P>between the other parties, too strong for any fine prospects, or any



<P>cold collation, or any cheerful Mr. Weston, to remove.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>At first it was downright dulness to Emma.&nbsp; She had never seen

Frank



<P>Churchill so silent and stupid.&nbsp; He said nothing worth hearing--



<P>looked without seeing--admired without intelligence--listened without



<P>knowing what she said.&nbsp; While he was so dull, it was no wonder

that



<P>Harriet should be dull likewise; and they were both insufferable.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When they all sat down it was better; to her taste a great deal better,



<P>for Frank Churchill grew talkative and gay, making her his first object.
