<P>Every distinguishing attention that could be paid, was paid to her.



<P>To amuse her, and be agreeable in her eyes, seemed all that he



<P>cared for--and Emma, glad to be enlivened, not sorry to be flattered,



<P>was gay and easy too, and gave him all the friendly encouragement,



<P>the admission to be gallant, which she had ever given in the first



<P>and most animating period of their acquaintance; but which now,



<P>in her own estimation, meant nothing, though in the judgment of most



<P>people looking on it must have had such an appearance as no English



<P>word but flirtation could very well describe.&nbsp; "Mr. Frank Churchill



<P>and Miss Woodhouse flirted together excessively."&nbsp; They were laying



<P>themselves open to that very phrase--and to having it sent off



<P>in a letter to Maple Grove by one lady, to Ireland by another.



<P>Not that Emma was gay and thoughtless from any real felicity;



<P>it was rather because she felt less happy than she had expected.



<P>She laughed because she was disappointed; and though she liked him



<P>for his attentions, and thought them all, whether in friendship,



<P>admiration, or playfulness, extremely judicious, they were not winning



<P>back her heart.&nbsp; She still intended him for her friend.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How much I am obliged to you," said he, "for telling me to come to-day!--



<P>If it had not been for you, I should certainly have lost all the



<P>happiness of this party.&nbsp; I had quite determined to go away again."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, you were very cross; and I do not know what about,



<P>except that you were too late for the best strawberries.



<P>I was a kinder friend than you deserved.&nbsp; But you were humble.



<P>You begged hard to be commanded to come."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't say I was cross.&nbsp; I was fatigued.&nbsp; The heat overcame

me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is hotter to-day."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not to my feelings.&nbsp; I am perfectly comfortable to-day."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are comfortable because you are under command."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Your command?--Yes."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Perhaps I intended you to say so, but I meant self-command. You had,



<P>somehow or other, broken bounds yesterday, and run away from your



<P>own management; but to-day you are got back again--and as I cannot



<P>be always with you, it is best to believe your temper under your



<P>own command rather than mine."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It comes to the same thing.&nbsp; I can have no self-command without



<P>a motive.&nbsp; You order me, whether you speak or not.&nbsp; And you

can



<P>be always with me.&nbsp; You are always with me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Dating from three o'clock yesterday.&nbsp; My perpetual influence



<P>could not begin earlier, or you would not have been so much



<P>out of humour before."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Three o'clock yesterday!&nbsp; That is your date.&nbsp; I thought I

had seen



<P>you first in February."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Your gallantry is really unanswerable.&nbsp; But (lowering her voice)--



<P>nobody speaks except ourselves, and it is rather too much to be



<P>talking nonsense for the entertainment of seven silent people."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I say nothing of which I am ashamed," replied he, with lively impudence.



<P>"I saw you first in February.&nbsp; Let every body on the Hill hear

me if



<P>they can.&nbsp; Let my accents swell to Mickleham on one side, and Dorking



<P>on the other.&nbsp; I saw you first in February."&nbsp; And then whispering--



<P>"Our companions are excessively stupid.&nbsp; What shall we do to rouse

them?



<P>Any nonsense will serve.&nbsp; They shall talk.&nbsp; Ladies and gentlemen,



<P>I am ordered by Miss Woodhouse (who, wherever she is, presides)



<P>to say, that she desires to know what you are all thinking of?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Some laughed, and answered good-humouredly. Miss Bates said a great

deal;



<P>Mrs. Elton swelled at the idea of Miss Woodhouse's presiding;



<P>Mr. Knightley's answer was the most distinct.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Is Miss Woodhouse sure that she would like to hear what we are



<P>all thinking of?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! no, no"--cried Emma, laughing as carelessly as she could--



<P>"Upon no account in the world.&nbsp; It is the very last thing I



<P>would stand the brunt of just now.&nbsp; Let me hear any thing rather



<P>than what you are all thinking of.&nbsp; I will not say quite all.



<P>There are one or two, perhaps, (glancing at Mr. Weston and Harriet,)



<P>whose thoughts I might not be afraid of knowing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is a sort of thing," cried Mrs. Elton emphatically,



<P>"which I should not have thought myself privileged to



<P>inquire into.&nbsp; Though, perhaps, as the Chaperon of the party--



<P>I never was in any circle--exploring parties--young ladies--married

women--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her mutterings were chiefly to her husband; and he murmured,



<P>in reply,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very true, my love, very true.&nbsp; Exactly so, indeed--quite unheard

of--



<P>but some ladies say any thing.&nbsp; Better pass it off as a joke.



<P>Every body knows what is due to you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It will not do," whispered Frank to Emma; "they are most



<P>of them affronted.&nbsp; I will attack them with more address.



<P>Ladies and gentlemen--I am ordered by Miss Woodhouse to say, that she



<P>waives her right of knowing exactly what you may all be thinking of,



<P>and only requires something very entertaining from each of you,



<P>in a general way.&nbsp; Here are seven of you, besides myself, (who,

she



<P>is pleased to say, am very entertaining already,) and she only



<P>demands from each of you either one thing very clever, be it prose



<P>or verse, original or repeated--or two things moderately clever--



<P>or three things very dull indeed, and she engages to laugh heartily



<P>at them all."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! very well," exclaimed Miss Bates, "then I need not be uneasy.



<P>`Three things very dull indeed.'&nbsp; That will just do for me, you

know.



<P>I shall be sure to say three dull things as soon as ever I open



<P>my mouth, shan't I? (looking round with the most good-humoured



<P>dependence on every body's assent)--Do not you all think I shall?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma could not resist.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah! ma'am, but there may be a difficulty.&nbsp; Pardon me--but you



<P>will be limited as to number--only three at once."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Bates, deceived by the mock ceremony of her manner, did not



<P>immediately catch her meaning; but, when it burst on her, it could



<P>not anger, though a slight blush shewed that it could pain her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah!--well--to be sure.&nbsp; Yes, I see what she means, (turning to



<P>Mr. Knightley,) and I will try to hold my tongue.&nbsp; I must make



<P>myself very disagreeable, or she would not have said such a thing



<P>to an old friend."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I like your plan," cried Mr. Weston.&nbsp; "Agreed, agreed.&nbsp; I

will do



<P>my best.&nbsp; I am making a conundrum.&nbsp; How will a conundrum reckon?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Low, I am afraid, sir, very low," answered his son;--"but we shall



<P>be indulgent--especially to any one who leads the way."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, no," said Emma, "it will not reckon low.&nbsp; A conundrum of



<P>Mr. Weston's shall clear him and his next neighbour.&nbsp; Come, sir,



<P>pray let me hear it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I doubt its being very clever myself," said Mr. Weston.



<P>"It is too much a matter of fact, but here it is.--What two letters



<P>of the alphabet are there, that express perfection?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What two letters!--express perfection!&nbsp; I am sure I do not know."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah! you will never guess.&nbsp; You, (to Emma), I am certain, will



<P>never guess.--I will tell you.--M. and A.--Em-ma.--Do you understand?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Understanding and gratification came together.&nbsp; It might be a very



<P>indifferent piece of wit, but Emma found a great deal to laugh



<P>at and enjoy in it--and so did Frank and Harriet.--It did not seem



<P>to touch the rest of the party equally; some looked very stupid



<P>about it, and Mr. Knightley gravely said,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"This explains the sort of clever thing that is wanted, and Mr. Weston



<P>has done very well for himself; but he must have knocked up every



<P>body else.&nbsp; Perfection should not have come quite so soon."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! for myself, I protest I must be excused," said Mrs. Elton;



<P>"I really cannot attempt--I am not at all fond of the sort of thing.



<P>I had an acrostic once sent to me upon my own name, which I was not



<P>at all pleased with.&nbsp; I knew who it came from.&nbsp; An abominable

puppy!--



<P>You know who I mean (nodding to her husband). These kind of things



<P>are very well at Christmas, when one is sitting round the fire;



<P>but quite out of place, in my opinion, when one is exploring



<P>about the country in summer.&nbsp; Miss Woodhouse must excuse me.



<P>I am not one of those who have witty things at every body's service.



<P>I do not pretend to be a wit.&nbsp; I have a great deal of vivacity



<P>in my own way, but I really must be allowed to judge when to speak



<P>and when to hold my tongue.&nbsp; Pass us, if you please, Mr. Churchill.



<P>Pass Mr. E., Knightley, Jane, and myself.&nbsp; We have nothing clever

to say--



<P>not one of us.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, yes, pray pass me," added her husband, with a sort of



<P>sneering consciousness; "I have nothing to say that can entertain



<P>Miss Woodhouse, or any other young lady.&nbsp; An old married man--



<P>quite good for nothing.&nbsp; Shall we walk, Augusta?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"With all my heart.&nbsp; I am really tired of exploring so long



<P>on one spot.&nbsp; Come, Jane, take my other arm."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jane declined it, however, and the husband and wife walked off.



<P>"Happy couple!" said Frank Churchill, as soon as they were out



<P>of hearing:--"How well they suit one another!--Very lucky--marrying

as



<P>they did, upon an acquaintance formed only in a public place!--They

only



<P>knew each other, I think, a few weeks in Bath!&nbsp; Peculiarly lucky!--



<P>for as to any real knowledge of a person's disposition that Bath,



<P>or any public place, can give--it is all nothing; there can be



<P>no knowledge.&nbsp; It is only by seeing women in their own homes,



<P>among their own set, just as they always are, that you can form



<P>any just judgment.&nbsp; Short of that, it is all guess and luck--



<P>and will generally be ill-luck. How many a man has committed himself



<P>on a short acquaintance, and rued it all the rest of his life!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Fairfax, who had seldom spoken before, except among her



<P>own confederates, spoke now.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Such things do occur, undoubtedly."--She was stopped by a cough.



<P>Frank Churchill turned towards her to listen.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You were speaking," said he, gravely.&nbsp; She recovered her voice.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I was only going to observe, that though such unfortunate circumstances



<P>do sometimes occur both to men and women, I cannot imagine them



<P>to be very frequent.&nbsp; A hasty and imprudent attachment may arise--



<P>but there is generally time to recover from it afterwards.&nbsp; I would



<P>be understood to mean, that it can be only weak, irresolute characters,



<P>(whose happiness must be always at the mercy of chance,)



<P>who will suffer an unfortunate acquaintance to be an inconvenience,



<P>an oppression for ever."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He made no answer; merely looked, and bowed in submission; and soon



<P>afterwards said, in a lively tone,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, I have so little confidence in my own judgment, that whenever



<P>I marry, I hope some body will chuse my wife for me.&nbsp; Will you?



<P>(turning to Emma.) Will you chuse a wife for me?--I am sure I



<P>should like any body fixed on by you.&nbsp; You provide for the family,



<P>you know, (with a smile at his father). Find some body for me.



<P>I am in no hurry.&nbsp; Adopt her, educate her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And make her like myself."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"By all means, if you can."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very well.&nbsp; I undertake the commission.&nbsp; You shall have a

charming wife."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She must be very lively, and have hazle eyes.&nbsp; I care for nothing

else.



<P>I shall go abroad for a couple of years--and when I return,



<P>I shall come to you for my wife.&nbsp; Remember."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma was in no danger of forgetting.&nbsp; It was a commission to touch

every



<P>favourite feeling.&nbsp; Would not Harriet be the very creature described?



<P>Hazle eyes excepted, two years more might make her all that he wished.



<P>He might even have Harriet in his thoughts at the moment;



<P>who could say?&nbsp; Referring the education to her seemed to imply

it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now, ma'am," said Jane to her aunt, "shall we join Mrs. Elton?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If you please, my dear.&nbsp; With all my heart.&nbsp; I am quite ready.



<P>I was ready to have gone with her, but this will do just as well.



<P>We shall soon overtake her.&nbsp; There she is--no, that's somebody

else.



<P>That's one of the ladies in the Irish car party, not at all like her.--



<P>Well, I declare--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They walked off, followed in half a minute by Mr. Knightley.



<P>Mr. Weston, his son, Emma, and Harriet, only remained; and the young



<P>man's spirits now rose to a pitch almost unpleasant.&nbsp; Even Emma

grew



<P>tired at last of flattery and merriment, and wished herself rather



<P>walking quietly about with any of the others, or sitting almost alone,



<P>and quite unattended to, in tranquil observation of the beautiful



<P>views beneath her.&nbsp; The appearance of the servants looking out



<P>for them to give notice of the carriages was a joyful sight;



<P>and even the bustle of collecting and preparing to depart,



<P>and the solicitude of Mrs. Elton to have her carriage first,



<P>were gladly endured, in the prospect of the quiet drive home which was



<P>to close the very questionable enjoyments of this day of pleasure.



<P>Such another scheme, composed of so many ill-assorted people,



<P>she hoped never to be betrayed into again.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>While waiting for the carriage, she found Mr. Knightley by her side.



<P>He looked around, as if to see that no one were near, and then said,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Emma, I must once more speak to you as I have been used to do:



<P>a privilege rather endured than allowed, perhaps, but I must still



<P>use it.&nbsp; I cannot see you acting wrong, without a remonstrance.



<P>How could you be so unfeeling to Miss Bates?&nbsp; How could you be

so



<P>insolent in your wit to a woman of her character, age, and situation?--



<P>Emma, I had not thought it possible."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma recollected, blushed, was sorry, but tried to laugh it off.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nay, how could I help saying what I did?--Nobody could have helped

it.



<P>It was not so very bad.&nbsp; I dare say she did not understand me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I assure you she did.&nbsp; She felt your full meaning.&nbsp; She has

talked



<P>of it since.&nbsp; I wish you could have heard how she talked of it--



<P>with what candour and generosity.&nbsp; I wish you could have heard

her



<P>honouring your forbearance, in being able to pay her such attentions,



<P>as she was for ever receiving from yourself and your father,



<P>when her society must be so irksome."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh!" cried Emma, "I know there is not a better creature in the world:



<P>but you must allow, that what is good and what is ridiculous are



<P>most unfortunately blended in her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"They are blended," said he, "I acknowledge; and, were she prosperous,



<P>I could allow much for the occasional prevalence of the ridiculous



<P>over the good.&nbsp; Were she a woman of fortune, I would leave every



<P>harmless absurdity to take its chance, I would not quarrel with you



<P>for any liberties of manner.&nbsp; Were she your equal in situation--



<P>but, Emma, consider how far this is from being the case.&nbsp; She is

poor;



<P>she has sunk from the comforts she was born to; and, if she live



<P>to old age, must probably sink more.&nbsp; Her situation should secure



<P>your compassion.&nbsp; It was badly done, indeed!&nbsp; You, whom she

had known



<P>from an infant, whom she had seen grow up from a period when her



<P>notice was an honour, to have you now, in thoughtless spirits,



<P>and the pride of the moment, laugh at her, humble her--and before



<P>her niece, too--and before others, many of whom (certainly some,)



<P>would be entirely guided by your treatment of her.--This is not



<P>pleasant to you, Emma--and it is very far from pleasant to me;



<P>but I must, I will,--I will tell you truths while I can;



<P>satisfied with proving myself your friend by very faithful counsel,



<P>and trusting that you will some time or other do me greater justice



<P>than you can do now."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>While they talked, they were advancing towards the carriage;



<P>it was ready; and, before she could speak again, he had handed her in.



<P>He had misinterpreted the feelings which had kept her face averted,



<P>and her tongue motionless.&nbsp; They were combined only of anger



<P>against herself, mortification, and deep concern.&nbsp; She had not



<P>been able to speak; and, on entering the carriage, sunk back



<P>for a moment overcome--then reproaching herself for having taken



<P>no leave, making no acknowledgment, parting in apparent sullenness,



<P>she looked out with voice and hand eager to shew a difference;



<P>but it was just too late.&nbsp; He had turned away, and the horses were



<P>in motion.&nbsp; She continued to look back, but in vain; and soon,



<P>with what appeared unusual speed, they were half way down the hill,



<P>and every thing left far behind.&nbsp; She was vexed beyond what could



<P>have been expressed--almost beyond what she could conceal.



<P>Never had she felt so agitated, mortified, grieved, at any circumstance



<P>in her life.&nbsp; She was most forcibly struck.&nbsp; The truth of

this



<P>representation there was no denying.&nbsp; She felt it at her heart.



<P>How could she have been so brutal, so cruel to Miss Bates!&nbsp; How

could



<P>she have exposed herself to such ill opinion in any one she valued!



<P>And how suffer him to leave her without saying one word of gratitude,



<P>of concurrence, of common kindness!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Time did not compose her.&nbsp; As she reflected more, she seemed



<P>but to feel it more.&nbsp; She never had been so depressed.&nbsp; Happily

it



<P>was not necessary to speak.&nbsp; There was only Harriet, who seemed

not



<P>in spirits herself, fagged, and very willing to be silent; and Emma



<P>felt the tears running down her cheeks almost all the way home,



<P>without being at any trouble to check them, extraordinary as they were.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 06</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER VI</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>After being long fed with hopes of a speedy visit from Mr. and



<P>Mrs. Suckling, the Highbury world were obliged to endure the mortification



<P>of hearing that they could not possibly come till the autumn.



<P>No such importation of novelties could enrich their intellectual stores



<P>at present.&nbsp; In the daily interchange of news, they must be again



<P>restricted to the other topics with which for a while the Sucklings'



<P>coming had been united, such as the last accounts of Mrs. Churchill,



<P>whose health seemed every day to supply a different report,



<P>and the situation of Mrs. Weston, whose happiness it was to be hoped



<P>might eventually be as much increased by the arrival of a child,



<P>as that of all her neighbours was by the approach of it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Elton was very much disappointed.&nbsp; It was the delay of a great



<P>deal of pleasure and parade.&nbsp; Her introductions and recommendations



<P>must all wait, and every projected party be still only talked of.



<P>So she thought at first;--but a little consideration convinced



<P>her that every thing need not be put off.&nbsp; Why should not they



<P>explore to Box Hill though the Sucklings did not come?&nbsp; They could



<P>go there again with them in the autumn.&nbsp; It was settled that they



<P>should go to Box Hill.&nbsp; That there was to be such a party had been



<P>long generally known:&nbsp; it had even given the idea of another.



<P>Emma had never been to Box Hill; she wished to see what every body



<P>found so well worth seeing, and she and Mr. Weston had agreed



<P>to chuse some fine morning and drive thither.&nbsp; Two or three more



<P>of the chosen only were to be admitted to join them, and it was to



<P>be done in a quiet, unpretending, elegant way, infinitely superior



<P>to the bustle and preparation, the regular eating and drinking,



<P>and picnic parade of the Eltons and the Sucklings.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This was so very well understood between them, that Emma could



<P>not but feel some surprise, and a little displeasure, on hearing



<P>from Mr. Weston that he had been proposing to Mrs. Elton, as her



<P>brother and sister had failed her, that the two parties should unite,



<P>and go together; and that as Mrs. Elton had very readily acceded



<P>to it, so it was to be, if she had no objection.&nbsp; Now, as her



<P>objection was nothing but her very great dislike of Mrs. Elton,



<P>of which Mr. Weston must already be perfectly aware, it was not worth



<P>bringing forward again:--it could not be done without a reproof



<P>to him, which would be giving pain to his wife; and she found



<P>herself therefore obliged to consent to an arrangement which she



<P>would have done a great deal to avoid; an arrangement which would



<P>probably expose her even to the degradation of being said to be of



<P>Mrs. Elton's party!&nbsp; Every feeling was offended; and the forbearance



<P>of her outward submission left a heavy arrear due of secret severity



<P>in her reflections on the unmanageable goodwill of Mr. Weston's temper.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am glad you approve of what I have done," said he very comfortably.



<P>"But I thought you would.&nbsp; Such schemes as these are nothing



<P>without numbers.&nbsp; One cannot have too large a party.&nbsp; A large

party



<P>secures its own amusement.&nbsp; And she is a good-natured woman after

all.



<P>One could not leave her out."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma denied none of it aloud, and agreed to none of it in private.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was now the middle of June, and the weather fine; and Mrs. Elton



<P>was growing impatient to name the day, and settle with Mr. Weston



<P>as to pigeon-pies and cold lamb, when a lame carriage-horse threw



<P>every thing into sad uncertainty.&nbsp; It might be weeks, it might

be



<P>only a few days, before the horse were useable; but no preparations



<P>could be ventured on, and it was all melancholy stagnation.



<P>Mrs. Elton's resources were inadequate to such an attack.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Is not this most vexations, Knightley?" she cried.--"And such weather



<P>for exploring!--These delays and disappointments are quite odious.



<P>What are we to do?--The year will wear away at this rate,



<P>and nothing done.&nbsp; Before this time last year I assure you we had



<P>had a delightful exploring party from Maple Grove to Kings Weston."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You had better explore to Donwell," replied Mr. Knightley.



<P>"That may be done without horses.&nbsp; Come, and eat my strawberries.



<P>They are ripening fast."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>If Mr. Knightley did not begin seriously, he was obliged to proceed

so,



<P>for his proposal was caught at with delight; and the "Oh!&nbsp; I should



<P>like it of all things," was not plainer in words than manner.



<P>Donwell was famous for its strawberry-beds, which seemed a plea for



<P>the invitation:&nbsp; but no plea was necessary; cabbage-beds would

have



<P>been enough to tempt the lady, who only wanted to be going somewhere.



<P>She promised him again and again to come--much oftener than



<P>he doubted--and was extremely gratified by such a proof of intimacy,



<P>such a distinguishing compliment as she chose to consider it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You may depend upon me," said she.&nbsp; "I certainly will come.



<P>Name your day, and I will come.&nbsp; You will allow me to bring



<P>Jane Fairfax?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I cannot name a day," said he, "till I have spoken to some others



<P>whom I would wish to meet you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! leave all that to me.&nbsp; Only give me a carte-blanche.--I am



<P>Lady Patroness, you know.&nbsp; It is my party.&nbsp; I will bring friends



<P>with me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I hope you will bring Elton," said he:&nbsp; "but I will not trouble



<P>you to give any other invitations."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! now you are looking very sly.&nbsp; But consider--you need not

be afraid



<P>of delegating power to me.&nbsp; I am no young lady on her preferment.



<P>Married women, you know, may be safely authorised.&nbsp; It is my party.



<P>Leave it all to me.&nbsp; I will invite your guests."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No,"--he calmly replied,--"there is but one married woman in the world



<P>whom I can ever allow to invite what guests she pleases to Donwell,



<P>and that one is--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"--Mrs. Weston, I suppose," interrupted Mrs. Elton, rather mortified.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No--Mrs. Knightley;--and till she is in being, I will manage



<P>such matters myself."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah! you are an odd creature!" she cried, satisfied to have no



<P>one preferred to herself.--"You are a humourist, and may say what



<P>you like.&nbsp; Quite a humourist.&nbsp; Well, I shall bring Jane with

me--



<P>Jane and her aunt.--The rest I leave to you.&nbsp; I have no objections



<P>at all to meeting the Hartfield family.&nbsp; Don't scruple.&nbsp; I

know



<P>you are attached to them."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You certainly will meet them if I can prevail; and I shall call



<P>on Miss Bates in my way home."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's quite unnecessary; I see Jane every day:--but as you like.



<P>It is to be a morning scheme, you know, Knightley; quite a simple thing.



<P>I shall wear a large bonnet, and bring one of my little baskets



<P>hanging on my arm.&nbsp; Here,--probably this basket with pink ribbon.



<P>Nothing can be more simple, you see.&nbsp; And Jane will have such another.



<P>There is to be no form or parade--a sort of gipsy party.&nbsp; We are



<P>to walk about your gardens, and gather the strawberries ourselves,



<P>and sit under trees;--and whatever else you may like to provide,



<P>it is to be all out of doors--a table spread in the shade, you know.



<P>Every thing as natural and simple as possible.&nbsp; Is not that your

idea?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not quite.&nbsp; My idea of the simple and the natural will be to have



<P>the table spread in the dining-room. The nature and the simplicity



<P>of gentlemen and ladies, with their servants and furniture, I think



<P>is best observed by meals within doors.&nbsp; When you are tired of

eating



<P>strawberries in the garden, there shall be cold meat in the house."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well--as you please; only don't have a great set out.&nbsp; And, by

the bye,



<P>can I or my housekeeper be of any use to you with our opinion?--



<P>Pray be sincere, Knightley.&nbsp; If you wish me to talk to Mrs. Hodges,



<P>or to inspect anything--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have not the least wish for it, I thank you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well--but if any difficulties should arise, my housekeeper



<P>is extremely clever."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I will answer for it, that mine thinks herself full as clever,



<P>and would spurn any body's assistance."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I wish we had a donkey.&nbsp; The thing would be for us all to come



<P>on donkeys, Jane, Miss Bates, and me--and my caro sposo walking by.



<P>I really must talk to him about purchasing a donkey.&nbsp; In a country



<P>life I conceive it to be a sort of necessary; for, let a woman have



<P>ever so many resources, it is not possible for her to be always shut



<P>up at home;--and very long walks, you know--in summer there is dust,



<P>and in winter there is dirt."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You will not find either, between Donwell and Highbury.



<P>Donwell Lane is never dusty, and now it is perfectly dry.&nbsp; Come

on



<P>a donkey, however, if you prefer it.&nbsp; You can borrow Mrs. Cole's.



<P>I would wish every thing to be as much to your taste as possible."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That I am sure you would.&nbsp; Indeed I do you justice, my good friend.



<P>Under that peculiar sort of dry, blunt manner, I know you have the



<P>warmest heart.&nbsp; As I tell Mr. E., you are a thorough humourist.--



<P>Yes, believe me, Knightley, I am fully sensible of your attention



<P>to me in the whole of this scheme.&nbsp; You have hit upon the very

thing



<P>to please me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Knightley had another reason for avoiding a table in the shade.



<P>He wished to persuade Mr. Woodhouse, as well as Emma, to join the party;



<P>and he knew that to have any of them sitting down out of doors



<P>to eat would inevitably make him ill.&nbsp; Mr. Woodhouse must not,



<P>under the specious pretence of a morning drive, and an hour or two



<P>spent at Donwell, be tempted away to his misery.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He was invited on good faith.&nbsp; No lurking horrors were to upbraid



<P>him for his easy credulity.&nbsp; He did consent.&nbsp; He had not been



<P>at Donwell for two years.&nbsp; "Some very fine morning, he, and Emma,



<P>and Harriet, could go very well; and he could sit still with



<P>Mrs. Weston, while the dear girls walked about the gardens.



<P>He did not suppose they could be damp now, in the middle of



<P>the day.&nbsp; He should like to see the old house again exceedingly,



<P>and should be very happy to meet Mr. and Mrs. Elton, and any other



<P>of his neighbours.--He could not see any objection at all to his,



<P>and Emma's, and Harriet's going there some very fine morning.



<P>He thought it very well done of Mr. Knightley to invite them--



<P>very kind and sensible--much cleverer than dining out.--He was not



<P>fond of dining out."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Knightley was fortunate in every body's most ready concurrence.



<P>The invitation was everywhere so well received, that it seemed as if,



<P>like Mrs. Elton, they were all taking the scheme as a particular



<P>compliment to themselves.--Emma and Harriet professed very high



<P>expectations of pleasure from it; and Mr. Weston, unasked,



<P>promised to get Frank over to join them, if possible; a proof



<P>of approbation and gratitude which could have been dispensed with.--



<P>Mr. Knightley was then obliged to say that he should be glad



<P>to see him; and Mr. Weston engaged to lose no time in writing,



<P>and spare no arguments to induce him to come.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In the meanwhile the lame horse recovered so fast, that the party



<P>to Box Hill was again under happy consideration; and at last Donwell



<P>was settled for one day, and Box Hill for the next,--the weather



<P>appearing exactly right.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Under a bright mid-day sun, at almost Midsummer, Mr. Woodhouse



<P>was safely conveyed in his carriage, with one window down,



<P>to partake of this al-fresco party; and in one of the most



<P>comfortable rooms in the Abbey, especially prepared for him by a



<P>fire all the morning, he was happily placed, quite at his ease,



<P>ready to talk with pleasure of what had been achieved, and advise



<P>every body to come and sit down, and not to heat themselves.--



<P>Mrs. Weston, who seemed to have walked there on purpose to be tired,



<P>and sit all the time with him, remained, when all the others



<P>were invited or persuaded out, his patient listener and sympathiser.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was so long since Emma had been at the Abbey, that as soon as she



<P>was satisfied of her father's comfort, she was glad to leave him,



<P>and look around her; eager to refresh and correct her memory with



<P>more particular observation, more exact understanding of a house



<P>and grounds which must ever be so interesting to her and all her family.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She felt all the honest pride and complacency which her alliance



<P>with the present and future proprietor could fairly warrant,



<P>as she viewed the respectable size and style of the building,



<P>its suitable, becoming, characteristic situation, low and sheltered--



<P>its ample gardens stretching down to meadows washed by a stream,



<P>of which the Abbey, with all the old neglect of prospect,



<P>had scarcely a sight--and its abundance of timber in rows and avenues,



<P>which neither fashion nor extravagance had rooted up.--The house



<P>was larger than Hartfield, and totally unlike it, covering a good



<P>deal of ground, rambling and irregular, with many comfortable,



<P>and one or two handsome rooms.--It was just what it ought to be,



<P>and it looked what it was--and Emma felt an increasing respect



<P>for it, as the residence of a family of such true gentility,



<P>untainted in blood and understanding.--Some faults of temper John



<P>Knightley had; but Isabella had connected herself unexceptionably.



<P>She had given them neither men, nor names, nor places, that could



<P>raise a blush.&nbsp; These were pleasant feelings, and she walked about



<P>and indulged them till it was necessary to do as the others did,



<P>and collect round the strawberry-beds.--The whole party were assembled,



<P>excepting Frank Churchill, who was expected every moment from Richmond;



<P>and Mrs. Elton, in all her apparatus of happiness, her large bonnet



<P>and her basket, was very ready to lead the way in gathering,



<P>accepting, or talking--strawberries, and only strawberries,



<P>could now be thought or spoken of.--"The best fruit in England--



<P>every body's favourite--always wholesome.--These the finest beds



<P>and finest sorts.--Delightful to gather for one's self--the only way



<P>of really enjoying them.--Morning decidedly the best time--never tired--



<P>every sort good--hautboy infinitely superior--no comparison--



<P>the others hardly eatable--hautboys very scarce--Chili preferred--



<P>white wood finest flavour of all--price of strawberries in London--



<P>abundance about Bristol--Maple Grove--cultivation--beds when to



<P>be renewed--gardeners thinking exactly different--no general rule--



<P>gardeners never to be put out of their way--delicious fruit--



<P>only too rich to be eaten much of--inferior to cherries--



<P>currants more refreshing--only objection to gathering strawberries



<P>the stooping--glaring sun--tired to death--could bear it no longer--



<P>must go and sit in the shade."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Such, for half an hour, was the conversation--interrupted only



<P>once by Mrs. Weston, who came out, in her solicitude after her



<P>son-in-law, to inquire if he were come--and she was a little uneasy.--



<P>She had some fears of his horse.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Seats tolerably in the shade were found; and now Emma was obliged



<P>to overhear what Mrs. Elton and Jane Fairfax were talking of.--



<P>A situation, a most desirable situation, was in question.&nbsp; Mrs.

Elton



<P>had received notice of it that morning, and was in raptures.



<P>It was not with Mrs. Suckling, it was not with Mrs. Bragge,



<P>but in felicity and splendour it fell short only of them:&nbsp; it was



<P>with a cousin of Mrs. Bragge, an acquaintance of Mrs. Suckling,



<P>a lady known at Maple Grove.&nbsp; Delightful, charming, superior,



<P>first circles, spheres, lines, ranks, every thing--and Mrs. Elton



<P>was wild to have the offer closed with immediately.--On her side,



<P>all was warmth, energy, and triumph--and she positively refused



<P>to take her friend's negative, though Miss Fairfax continued



<P>to assure her that she would not at present engage in any thing,



<P>repeating the same motives which she had been heard to urge before.--



<P>Still Mrs. Elton insisted on being authorised to write an acquiescence



<P>by the morrow's post.--How Jane could bear it at all, was astonishing



<P>to Emma.--She did look vexed, she did speak pointedly--and at last,



<P>with a decision of action unusual to her, proposed a removal.--



<P>"Should not they walk?&nbsp; Would not Mr. Knightley shew them the gardens--



<P>all the gardens?--She wished to see the whole extent."--The pertinacity



<P>of her friend seemed more than she could bear.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was hot; and after walking some time over the gardens in a scattered,



<P>dispersed way, scarcely any three together, they insensibly



<P>followed one another to the delicious shade of a broad short



<P>avenue of limes, which stretching beyond the garden at an equal



<P>distance from the river, seemed the finish of the pleasure grounds.--



<P>It led to nothing; nothing but a view at the end over a low stone



<P>wall with high pillars, which seemed intended, in their erection,



<P>to give the appearance of an approach to the house, which never had



<P>been there.&nbsp; Disputable, however, as might be the taste of such



<P>a termination, it was in itself a charming walk, and the view



<P>which closed it extremely pretty.--The considerable slope, at nearly



<P>the foot of which the Abbey stood, gradually acquired a steeper



<P>form beyond its grounds; and at half a mile distant was a bank



<P>of considerable abruptness and grandeur, well clothed with wood;--



<P>and at the bottom of this bank, favourably placed and sheltered,



<P>rose the Abbey Mill Farm, with meadows in front, and the river



<P>making a close and handsome curve around it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was a sweet view--sweet to the eye and the mind.&nbsp; English verdure,



<P>English culture, English comfort, seen under a sun bright,



<P>without being oppressive.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In this walk Emma and Mr. Weston found all the others assembled;



<P>and towards this view she immediately perceived Mr. Knightley



<P>and Harriet distinct from the rest, quietly leading the way.



<P>Mr. Knightley and Harriet!--It was an odd tete-a-tete; but she was



<P>glad to see it.--There had been a time when he would have scorned



<P>her as a companion, and turned from her with little ceremony.



<P>Now they seemed in pleasant conversation.&nbsp; There had been a time



<P>also when Emma would have been sorry to see Harriet in a spot



<P>so favourable for the Abbey Mill Farm; but now she feared it not.



<P>It might be safely viewed with all its appendages of prosperity



<P>and beauty, its rich pastures, spreading flocks, orchard in blossom,



<P>and light column of smoke ascending.--She joined them at the wall,



<P>and found them more engaged in talking than in looking around.



<P>He was giving Harriet information as to modes of agriculture, etc.



<P>and Emma received a smile which seemed to say, "These are my



<P>own concerns.&nbsp; I have a right to talk on such subjects, without

being



<P>suspected of introducing Robert Martin."--She did not suspect him.



<P>It was too old a story.--Robert Martin had probably ceased to think



<P>of Harriet.--They took a few turns together along the walk.--The shade



<P>was most refreshing, and Emma found it the pleasantest part of



<P>the day.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The next remove was to the house; they must all go in and eat;--



<P>and they were all seated and busy, and still Frank Churchill did



<P>not come.&nbsp; Mrs. Weston looked, and looked in vain.&nbsp; His father

would



<P>not own himself uneasy, and laughed at her fears; but she could



<P>not be cured of wishing that he would part with his black mare.



<P>He had expressed himself as to coming, with more than common certainty.



<P>"His aunt was so much better, that he had not a doubt of getting



<P>over to them."--Mrs. Churchill's state, however, as many were ready



<P>to remind her, was liable to such sudden variation as might disappoint



<P>her nephew in the most reasonable dependence--and Mrs. Weston



<P>was at last persuaded to believe, or to say, that it must be



<P>by some attack of Mrs. Churchill that he was prevented coming.--



<P>Emma looked at Harriet while the point was under consideration;



<P>she behaved very well, and betrayed no emotion.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The cold repast was over, and the party were to go out once more



<P>to see what had not yet been seen, the old Abbey fish-ponds;



<P>perhaps get as far as the clover, which was to be begun cutting



<P>on the morrow, or, at any rate, have the pleasure of being hot,



<P>and growing cool again.--Mr. Woodhouse, who had already taken



<P>his little round in the highest part of the gardens, where no



<P>damps from the river were imagined even by him, stirred no more;



<P>and his daughter resolved to remain with him, that Mrs. Weston



<P>might be persuaded away by her husband to the exercise and variety



<P>which her spirits seemed to need.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Knightley had done all in his power for Mr. Woodhouse's



<P>entertainment.&nbsp; Books of engravings, drawers of medals, cameos,



<P>corals, shells, and every other family collection within his cabinets,



<P>had been prepared for his old friend, to while away the morning;



<P>and the kindness had perfectly answered.&nbsp; Mr. Woodhouse had been



<P>exceedingly well amused.&nbsp; Mrs. Weston had been shewing them all

to him,



<P>and now he would shew them all to Emma;--fortunate in having no other



<P>resemblance to a child, than in a total want of taste for what he saw,



<P>for he was slow, constant, and methodical.--Before this second looking



<P>over was begun, however, Emma walked into the hall for the sake



<P>of a few moments' free observation of the entrance and ground-plot



<P>of the house--and was hardly there, when Jane Fairfax appeared,



<P>coming quickly in from the garden, and with a look of escape.--



<P>Little expecting to meet Miss Woodhouse so soon, there was a start



<P>at first; but Miss Woodhouse was the very person she was in quest of.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Will you be so kind," said she, "when I am missed, as to say



<P>that I am gone home?--I am going this moment.--My aunt is not aware



<P>how late it is, nor how long we have been absent--but I am sure we



<P>shall be wanted, and I am determined to go directly.--I have said



<P>nothing about it to any body.&nbsp; It would only be giving trouble



<P>and distress.&nbsp; Some are gone to the ponds, and some to the lime

walk.



<P>Till they all come in I shall not be missed; and when they do,



<P>will you have the goodness to say that I am gone?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Certainly, if you wish it;--but you are not going to walk



<P>to Highbury alone?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes--what should hurt me?--I walk fast.&nbsp; I shall be at home



<P>in twenty minutes."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But it is too far, indeed it is, to be walking quite alone.



<P>Let my father's servant go with you.--Let me order the carriage.



<P>It can be round in five minutes."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thank you, thank you--but on no account.--I would rather walk.--



<P>And for me to be afraid of walking alone!--I, who may so soon have



<P>to guard others!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She spoke with great agitation; and Emma very feelingly replied,



<P>"That can be no reason for your being exposed to danger now.



<P>I must order the carriage.&nbsp; The heat even would be danger.--You

are



<P>fatigued already."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am,"--she answered--"I am fatigued; but it is not the sort



<P>of fatigue--quick walking will refresh me.--Miss Woodhouse, we all



<P>know at times what it is to be wearied in spirits.&nbsp; Mine, I confess,



<P>are exhausted.&nbsp; The greatest kindness you can shew me, will be

to let



<P>me have my own way, and only say that I am gone when it is necessary."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma had not another word to oppose.&nbsp; She saw it all; and entering



<P>into her feelings, promoted her quitting the house immediately,



<P>and watched her safely off with the zeal of a friend.&nbsp; Her parting



<P>look was grateful--and her parting words, "Oh!&nbsp; Miss Woodhouse,



<P>the comfort of being sometimes alone!"--seemed to burst from



<P>an overcharged heart, and to describe somewhat of the continual



<P>endurance to be practised by her, even towards some of those who



<P>loved her best.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Such a home, indeed! such an aunt!" said Emma, as she turned back



<P>into the hall again.&nbsp; "I do pity you.&nbsp; And the more sensibility



<P>you betray of their just horrors, the more I shall like you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jane had not been gone a quarter of an hour, and they had only



<P>accomplished some views of St. Mark's Place, Venice, when Frank



<P>Churchill entered the room.&nbsp; Emma had not been thinking of him,



<P>she had forgotten to think of him--but she was very glad to see him.



<P>Mrs. Weston would be at ease.&nbsp; The black mare was blameless;



<P>they were right who had named Mrs. Churchill as the cause.



<P>He had been detained by a temporary increase of illness in her;



<P>a nervous seizure, which had lasted some hours--and he had quite given



<P>up every thought of coming, till very late;--and had he known how hot



<P>a ride he should have, and how late, with all his hurry, he must be,



<P>he believed he should not have come at all.&nbsp; The heat was excessive;



<P>he had never suffered any thing like it--almost wished he had staid



<P>at home--nothing killed him like heat--he could bear any degree of cold,



<P>etc., but heat was intolerable--and he sat down, at the greatest



<P>possible distance from the slight remains of Mr. Woodhouse's fire,



<P>looking very deplorable.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You will soon be cooler, if you sit still," said Emma.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"As soon as I am cooler I shall go back again.&nbsp; I could very



<P>ill be spared--but such a point had been made of my coming!



<P>You will all be going soon I suppose; the whole party breaking up.



<P>I met one as I came--Madness in such weather!--absolute madness!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma listened, and looked, and soon perceived that Frank Churchill's



<P>state might be best defined by the expressive phrase of being



<P>out of humour.&nbsp; Some people were always cross when they were hot.



<P>Such might be his constitution; and as she knew that eating



<P>and drinking were often the cure of such incidental complaints,



<P>she recommended his taking some refreshment; he would find abundance



<P>of every thing in the dining-room--and she humanely pointed out



<P>the door.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No--he should not eat.&nbsp; He was not hungry; it would only make



<P>him hotter."&nbsp; In two minutes, however, he relented in his own favour;



<P>and muttering something about spruce-beer, walked off.&nbsp; Emma returned



<P>all her attention to her father, saying in secret--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am glad I have done being in love with him.&nbsp; I should not like

a



<P>man who is so soon discomposed by a hot morning.&nbsp; Harriet's sweet



<P>easy temper will not mind it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He was gone long enough to have had a very comfortable meal, and came



<P>back all the better--grown quite cool--and, with good manners,



<P>like himself--able to draw a chair close to them, take an interest



<P>in their employment; and regret, in a reasonable way, that he



<P>should be so late.&nbsp; He was not in his best spirits, but seemed



<P>trying to improve them; and, at last, made himself talk nonsense



<P>very agreeably.&nbsp; They were looking over views in Swisserland.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"As soon as my aunt gets well, I shall go abroad," said he.



<P>"I shall never be easy till I have seen some of these places.



<P>You will have my sketches, some time or other, to look at--or my tour



<P>to read--or my poem.&nbsp; I shall do something to expose myself."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That may be--but not by sketches in Swisserland.&nbsp; You will



<P>never go to Swisserland.&nbsp; Your uncle and aunt will never allow



<P>you to leave England."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"They may be induced to go too.&nbsp; A warm climate may be prescribed



<P>for her.&nbsp; I have more than half an expectation of our all going

abroad.



<P>I assure you I have.&nbsp; I feel a strong persuasion, this morning,



<P>that I shall soon be abroad.&nbsp; I ought to travel.&nbsp; I am tired



<P>of doing nothing.&nbsp; I want a change.&nbsp; I am serious, Miss Woodhouse,



<P>whatever your penetrating eyes may fancy--I am sick of England--



<P>and would leave it to-morrow, if I could."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are sick of prosperity and indulgence.&nbsp; Cannot you invent



<P>a few hardships for yourself, and be contented to stay?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I sick of prosperity and indulgence!&nbsp; You are quite mistaken.



<P>I do not look upon myself as either prosperous or indulged.&nbsp; I

am



<P>thwarted in every thing material.&nbsp; I do not consider myself at

all



<P>a fortunate person."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are not quite so miserable, though, as when you first came.



<P>Go and eat and drink a little more, and you will do very well.



<P>Another slice of cold meat, another draught of Madeira and water,



<P>will make you nearly on a par with the rest of us."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No--I shall not stir.&nbsp; I shall sit by you.&nbsp; You are my best

cure."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We are going to Box Hill to-morrow;--you will join us.



<P>It is not Swisserland, but it will be something for a young



<P>man so much in want of a change.&nbsp; You will stay, and go with us?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, certainly not; I shall go home in the cool of the evening."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But you may come again in the cool of to-morrow morning."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No--It will not be worth while.&nbsp; If I come, I shall be cross."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then pray stay at Richmond."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But if I do, I shall be crosser still.&nbsp; I can never bear to think



<P>of you all there without me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"These are difficulties which you must settle for yourself.



<P>Chuse your own degree of crossness.&nbsp; I shall press you no more."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The rest of the party were now returning, and all were soon collected.



<P>With some there was great joy at the sight of Frank Churchill;



<P>others took it very composedly; but there was a very general distress



<P>and disturbance on Miss Fairfax's disappearance being explained.



<P>That it was time for every body to go, concluded the subject; and with



<P>a short final arrangement for the next day's scheme, they parted.



<P>Frank Churchill's little inclination to exclude himself increased



<P>so much, that his last words to Emma were,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well;--if you wish me to stay and join the party, I will."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She smiled her acceptance; and nothing less than a summons from



<P>Richmond was to take him back before the following evening.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 12</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Till now that she was threatened with its loss, Emma had never known



<P>how much of her happiness depended on being first with Mr. Knightley,



<P>first in interest and affection.--Satisfied that it was so,



<P>and feeling it her due, she had enjoyed it without reflection;



<P>and only in the dread of being supplanted, found how inexpressibly



<P>important it had been.--Long, very long, she felt she had been first;



<P>for, having no female connexions of his own, there had been



<P>only Isabella whose claims could be compared with hers, and she



<P>had always known exactly how far he loved and esteemed Isabella.



<P>She had herself been first with him for many years past.



<P>She had not deserved it; she had often been negligent or perverse,



<P>slighting his advice, or even wilfully opposing him, insensible of



<P>half his merits, and quarrelling with him because he would not



<P>acknowledge her false and insolent estimate of her own--but still,



<P>from family attachment and habit, and thorough excellence of mind,



<P>he had loved her, and watched over her from a girl, with an endeavour



<P>to improve her, and an anxiety for her doing right, which no



<P>other creature had at all shared.&nbsp; In spite of all her faults,



<P>she knew she was dear to him; might she not say, very dear?--



<P>When the suggestions of hope, however, which must follow here,



<P>presented themselves, she could not presume to indulge them.



<P>Harriet Smith might think herself not unworthy of being peculiarly,



<P>exclusively, passionately loved by Mr. Knightley.&nbsp; She could not.



<P>She could not flatter herself with any idea of blindness in his attachment



<P>to her.&nbsp; She had received a very recent proof of its impartiality.--



<P>How shocked had he been by her behaviour to Miss Bates!&nbsp; How directly,



<P>how strongly had he expressed himself to her on the subject!--Not too



<P>strongly for the offence--but far, far too strongly to issue from



<P>any feeling softer than upright justice and clear-sighted goodwill.--



<P>She had no hope, nothing to deserve the name of hope, that he could



<P>have that sort of affection for herself which was now in question;



<P>but there was a hope (at times a slight one, at times much stronger,)



<P>that Harriet might have deceived herself, and be overrating his



<P>regard for her.--Wish it she must, for his sake--be the consequence



<P>nothing to herself, but his remaining single all his life.



<P>Could she be secure of that, indeed, of his never marrying at all,



<P>she believed she should be perfectly satisfied.--Let him but continue



<P>the same Mr. Knightley to her and her father, the same Mr. Knightley



<P>to all the world; let Donwell and Hartfield lose none of their



<P>precious intercourse of friendship and confidence, and her peace



<P>would be fully secured.--Marriage, in fact, would not do for her.



<P>It would be incompatible with what she owed to her father, and with



<P>what she felt for him.&nbsp; Nothing should separate her from her father.



<P>She would not marry, even if she were asked by Mr. Knightley.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It must be her ardent wish that Harriet might be disappointed;



<P>and she hoped, that when able to see them together again, she might

at



<P>least be able to ascertain what the chances for it were.--She should



<P>see them henceforward with the closest observance; and wretchedly



<P>as she had hitherto misunderstood even those she was watching,



<P>she did not know how to admit that she could be blinded here.--



<P>He was expected back every day.&nbsp; The power of observation would

be



<P>soon given--frightfully soon it appeared when her thoughts were in



<P>one course.&nbsp; In the meanwhile, she resolved against seeing Harriet.--



<P>It would do neither of them good, it would do the subject no good,



<P>to be talking of it farther.--She was resolved not to be convinced,



<P>as long as she could doubt, and yet had no authority for opposing



<P>Harriet's confidence.&nbsp; To talk would be only to irritate.--She

wrote



<P>to her, therefore, kindly, but decisively, to beg that she would not,



<P>at present, come to Hartfield; acknowledging it to be her conviction,



<P>that all farther confidential discussion of one topic had better



<P>be avoided; and hoping, that if a few days were allowed to pass before



<P>they met again, except in the company of others--she objected only



<P>to a tete-a-tete--they might be able to act as if they had forgotten



<P>the conversation of yesterday.--Harriet submitted, and approved,



<P>and was grateful.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This point was just arranged, when a visitor arrived to tear Emma's



<P>thoughts a little from the one subject which had engrossed them,



<P>sleeping or waking, the last twenty-four hours--Mrs. Weston, who had



<P>been calling on her daughter-in-law elect, and took Hartfield in her



<P>way home, almost as much in duty to Emma as in pleasure to herself,



<P>to relate all the particulars of so interesting an interview.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Weston had accompanied her to Mrs. Bates's, and gone through his



<P>share of this essential attention most handsomely; but she having



<P>then induced Miss Fairfax to join her in an airing, was now returned



<P>with much more to say, and much more to say with satisfaction,



<P>than a quarter of an hour spent in Mrs. Bates's parlour, with all



<P>the encumbrance of awkward feelings, could have afforded.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A little curiosity Emma had; and she made the most of it while



<P>her friend related.&nbsp; Mrs. Weston had set off to pay the visit



<P>in a good deal of agitation herself; and in the first place had



<P>wished not to go at all at present, to be allowed merely to write



<P>to Miss Fairfax instead, and to defer this ceremonious call till



<P>a little time had passed, and Mr. Churchill could be reconciled



<P>to the engagement's becoming known; as, considering every thing,



<P>she thought such a visit could not be paid without leading to reports:--



<P>but Mr. Weston had thought differently; he was extremely anxious



<P>to shew his approbation to Miss Fairfax and her family, and did not



<P>conceive that any suspicion could be excited by it; or if it were,



<P>that it would be of any consequence; for "such things," he observed,



<P>"always got about."&nbsp; Emma smiled, and felt that Mr. Weston had



<P>very good reason for saying so.&nbsp; They had gone, in short--and very



<P>great had been the evident distress and confusion of the lady.



<P>She had hardly been able to speak a word, and every look and action



<P>had shewn how deeply she was suffering from consciousness.&nbsp; The

quiet,



<P>heart-felt satisfaction of the old lady, and the rapturous delight



<P>of her daughter--who proved even too joyous to talk as usual,



<P>had been a gratifying, yet almost an affecting, scene.&nbsp; They were



<P>both so truly respectable in their happiness, so disinterested



<P>in every sensation; thought so much of Jane; so much of every body,



<P>and so little of themselves, that every kindly feeling was at work



<P>for them.&nbsp; Miss Fairfax's recent illness had offered a fair plea



<P>for Mrs. Weston to invite her to an airing; she had drawn back and



<P>declined at first, but, on being pressed had yielded; and, in the



<P>course of their drive, Mrs. Weston had, by gentle encouragement,



<P>overcome so much of her embarrassment, as to bring her to converse



<P>on the important subject.&nbsp; Apologies for her seemingly ungracious



<P>silence in their first reception, and the warmest expressions of the



<P>gratitude she was always feeling towards herself and Mr. Weston,



<P>must necessarily open the cause; but when these effusions were put by,



<P>they had talked a good deal of the present and of the future state



<P>of the engagement.&nbsp; Mrs. Weston was convinced that such conversation



<P>must be the greatest relief to her companion, pent up within her own



<P>mind as every thing had so long been, and was very much pleased



<P>with all that she had said on the subject.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"On the misery of what she had suffered, during the concealment



<P>of so many months," continued Mrs. Weston, "she was energetic.



<P>This was one of her expressions.&nbsp; `I will not say, that since I



<P>entered into the engagement I have not had some happy moments; but I



<P>can say, that I have never known the blessing of one tranquil hour:'--



<P>and the quivering lip, Emma, which uttered it, was an attestation



<P>that I felt at my heart."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Poor girl!" said Emma.&nbsp; "She thinks herself wrong, then, for having



<P>consented to a private engagement?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Wrong!&nbsp; No one, I believe, can blame her more than she is disposed



<P>to blame herself.&nbsp; `The consequence,' said she, `has been a state



<P>of perpetual suffering to me; and so it ought.&nbsp; But after all the



<P>punishment that misconduct can bring, it is still not less misconduct.



<P>Pain is no expiation.&nbsp; I never can be blameless.&nbsp; I have been

acting



<P>contrary to all my sense of right; and the fortunate turn that every



<P>thing has taken, and the kindness I am now receiving, is what my



<P>conscience tells me ought not to be.'&nbsp; `Do not imagine, madam,'



<P>she continued, `that I was taught wrong.&nbsp; Do not let any reflection



<P>fall on the principles or the care of the friends who brought



<P>me up.&nbsp; The error has been all my own; and I do assure you that,



<P>with all the excuse that present circumstances may appear to give,



<P>I shall yet dread making the story known to Colonel Campbell.'"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Poor girl!" said Emma again.&nbsp; "She loves him then excessively,



<P>I suppose.&nbsp; It must have been from attachment only, that she could



<P>be led to form the engagement.&nbsp; Her affection must have overpowered



<P>her judgment."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, I have no doubt of her being extremely attached to him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am afraid," returned Emma, sighing, "that I must often have



<P>contributed to make her unhappy."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"On your side, my love, it was very innocently done.&nbsp; But she



<P>probably had something of that in her thoughts, when alluding



<P>to the misunderstandings which he had given us hints of before.



<P>One natural consequence of the evil she had involved herself in,"



<P>she said, "was that of making her unreasonable.&nbsp; The consciousness



<P>of having done amiss, had exposed her to a thousand inquietudes,



<P>and made her captious and irritable to a degree that must have been--



<P>that had been--hard for him to bear.&nbsp; `I did not make the allowances,'



<P>said she, `which I ought to have done, for his temper and spirits--



<P>his delightful spirits, and that gaiety, that playfulness



<P>of disposition, which, under any other circumstances, would, I am sure,



<P>have been as constantly bewitching to me, as they were at first.'



<P>She then began to speak of you, and of the great kindness you



<P>had shewn her during her illness; and with a blush which shewed me



<P>how it was all connected, desired me, whenever I had an opportunity,



<P>to thank you--I could not thank you too much--for every wish and



<P>every endeavour to do her good.&nbsp; She was sensible that you had

never



<P>received any proper acknowledgment from herself."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If I did not know her to be happy now," said Emma, seriously,



<P>"which, in spite of every little drawback from her scrupulous



<P>conscience, she must be, I could not bear these thanks;--for, oh!



<P>Mrs. Weston, if there were an account drawn up of the evil



<P>and the good I have done Miss Fairfax!--Well (checking herself,



<P>and trying to be more lively), this is all to be forgotten.



<P>You are very kind to bring me these interesting particulars.



<P>They shew her to the greatest advantage.&nbsp; I am sure she is very

good--



<P>I hope she will be very happy.&nbsp; It is fit that the fortune



<P>should be on his side, for I think the merit will be all on hers."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Such a conclusion could not pass unanswered by Mrs. Weston.



<P>She thought well of Frank in almost every respect; and, what was more,



<P>she loved him very much, and her defence was, therefore, earnest.



<P>She talked with a great deal of reason, and at least equal affection--



<P>but she had too much to urge for Emma's attention; it was soon gone



<P>to Brunswick Square or to Donwell; she forgot to attempt to listen;



<P>and when Mrs. Weston ended with, "We have not yet had the letter



<P>we are so anxious for, you know, but I hope it will soon come,"



<P>she was obliged to pause before she answered, and at last obliged



<P>to answer at random, before she could at all recollect what letter it



<P>was which they were so anxious for.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Are you well, my Emma?" was Mrs. Weston's parting question.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! perfectly.&nbsp; I am always well, you know.&nbsp; Be sure to give

me



<P>intelligence of the letter as soon as possible."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Weston's communications furnished Emma with more food for



<P>unpleasant reflection, by increasing her esteem and compassion,



<P>and her sense of past injustice towards Miss Fairfax.&nbsp; She bitterly



<P>regretted not having sought a closer acquaintance with her, and blushed



<P>for the envious feelings which had certainly been, in some measure,



<P>the cause.&nbsp; Had she followed Mr. Knightley's known wishes, in paying



<P>that attention to Miss Fairfax, which was every way her due; had she



<P>tried to know her better; had she done her part towards intimacy;



<P>had she endeavoured to find a friend there instead of in Harriet Smith;



<P>she must, in all probability, have been spared from every pain



<P>which pressed on her now.--Birth, abilities, and education,



<P>had been equally marking one as an associate for her, to be received



<P>with gratitude; and the other--what was she?--Supposing even that



<P>they had never become intimate friends; that she had never been



<P>admitted into Miss Fairfax's confidence on this important matter--



<P>which was most probable--still, in knowing her as she ought,



<P>and as she might, she must have been preserved from the abominable



<P>suspicions of an improper attachment to Mr. Dixon, which she had



<P>not only so foolishly fashioned and harboured herself, but had so



<P>unpardonably imparted; an idea which she greatly feared had been made



<P>a subject of material distress to the delicacy of Jane's feelings,



<P>by the levity or carelessness of Frank Churchill's.&nbsp; Of all the

sources



<P>of evil surrounding the former, since her coming to Highbury,



<P>she was persuaded that she must herself have been the worst.



<P>She must have been a perpetual enemy.&nbsp; They never could have been



<P>all three together, without her having stabbed Jane Fairfax's peace



<P>in a thousand instances; and on Box Hill, perhaps, it had been



<P>the agony of a mind that would bear no more.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The evening of this day was very long, and melancholy, at Hartfield.



<P>The weather added what it could of gloom.&nbsp; A cold stormy rain set

in,



<P>and nothing of July appeared but in the trees and shrubs, which the



<P>wind was despoiling, and the length of the day, which only made



<P>such cruel sights the longer visible.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The weather affected Mr. Woodhouse, and he could only be kept tolerably



<P>comfortable by almost ceaseless attention on his daughter's side,



<P>and by exertions which had never cost her half so much before.



<P>It reminded her of their first forlorn tete-a-tete, on the evening



<P>of Mrs. Weston's wedding-day; but Mr. Knightley had walked



<P>in then, soon after tea, and dissipated every melancholy fancy.



<P>Alas! such delightful proofs of Hartfield's attraction, as those



<P>sort of visits conveyed, might shortly be over.&nbsp; The picture which



<P>she had then drawn of the privations of the approaching winter,



<P>had proved erroneous; no friends had deserted them, no pleasures



<P>had been lost.--But her present forebodings she feared would



<P>experience no similar contradiction.&nbsp; The prospect before her now,



<P>was threatening to a degree that could not be entirely dispelled--



<P>that might not be even partially brightened.&nbsp; If all took place



<P>that might take place among the circle of her friends, Hartfield must



<P>be comparatively deserted; and she left to cheer her father with the



<P>spirits only of ruined happiness.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The child to be born at Randalls must be a tie there even dearer



<P>than herself; and Mrs. Weston's heart and time would be occupied



<P>by it.&nbsp; They should lose her; and, probably, in great measure,



<P>her husband also.--Frank Churchill would return among them no more;



<P>and Miss Fairfax, it was reasonable to suppose, would soon cease



<P>to belong to Highbury.&nbsp; They would be married, and settled either



<P>at or near Enscombe.&nbsp; All that were good would be withdrawn; and

if



<P>to these losses, the loss of Donwell were to be added, what would



<P>remain of cheerful or of rational society within their reach?



<P>Mr. Knightley to be no longer coming there for his evening comfort!--



<P>No longer walking in at all hours, as if ever willing to change



<P>his own home for their's!--How was it to be endured?&nbsp; And if he

were



<P>to be lost to them for Harriet's sake; if he were to be thought



<P>of hereafter, as finding in Harriet's society all that he wanted;



<P>if Harriet were to be the chosen, the first, the dearest, the friend,



<P>the wife to whom he looked for all the best blessings of existence;



<P>what could be increasing Emma's wretchedness but the reflection never

far



<P>distant from her mind, that it had been all her own work?

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When it came to such a pitch as this, she was not able to refrain



<P>from a start, or a heavy sigh, or even from walking about the room



<P>for a few seconds--and the only source whence any thing like consolation



<P>or composure could be drawn, was in the resolution of her own



<P>better conduct, and the hope that, however inferior in spirit and



<P>gaiety might be the following and every future winter of her life



<P>to the past, it would yet find her more rational, more acquainted



<P>with herself, and leave her less to regret when it were gone.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 08</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER VIII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>The wretchedness of a scheme to Box Hill was in Emma's thoughts all



<P>the evening.&nbsp; How it might be considered by the rest of the party,



<P>she could not tell.&nbsp; They, in their different homes, and their

different



<P>ways, might be looking back on it with pleasure; but in her view it



<P>was a morning more completely misspent, more totally bare of rational



<P>satisfaction at the time, and more to be abhorred in recollection,



<P>than any she had ever passed.&nbsp; A whole evening of back-gammon with



<P>her father, was felicity to it.&nbsp; There, indeed, lay real pleasure,



<P>for there she was giving up the sweetest hours of the twenty-four



<P>to his comfort; and feeling that, unmerited as might be the degree



<P>of his fond affection and confiding esteem, she could not, in her



<P>general conduct, be open to any severe reproach.&nbsp; As a daughter,



<P>she hoped she was not without a heart.&nbsp; She hoped no one could



<P>have said to her, "How could you be so unfeeling to your father?--



<P>I must, I will tell you truths while I can."&nbsp; Miss Bates should



<P>never again--no, never!&nbsp; If attention, in future, could do away



<P>the past, she might hope to be forgiven.&nbsp; She had been often remiss,



<P>her conscience told her so; remiss, perhaps, more in thought



<P>than fact; scornful, ungracious.&nbsp; But it should be so no more.



<P>In the warmth of true contrition, she would call upon her the



<P>very next morning, and it should be the beginning, on her side,



<P>of a regular, equal, kindly intercourse.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was just as determined when the morrow came, and went early,



<P>that nothing might prevent her.&nbsp; It was not unlikely, she thought,



<P>that she might see Mr. Knightley in her way; or, perhaps, he might



<P>come in while she were paying her visit.&nbsp; She had no objection.



<P>She would not be ashamed of the appearance of the penitence, so justly



<P>and truly hers.&nbsp; Her eyes were towards Donwell as she walked, but

she



<P>saw him not.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The ladies were all at home."&nbsp; She had never rejoiced at the sound



<P>before, nor ever before entered the passage, nor walked up the stairs,



<P>with any wish of giving pleasure, but in conferring obligation,



<P>or of deriving it, except in subsequent ridicule.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was a bustle on her approach; a good deal of moving and talking.



<P>She heard Miss Bates's voice, something was to be done in a hurry;



<P>the maid looked frightened and awkward; hoped she would be pleased



<P>to wait a moment, and then ushered her in too soon.&nbsp; The aunt and



<P>niece seemed both escaping into the adjoining room.&nbsp; Jane she had



<P>a distinct glimpse of, looking extremely ill; and, before the door



<P>had shut them out, she heard Miss Bates saying, "Well, my dear,



<P>I shall say you are laid down upon the bed, and I am sure you are



<P>ill enough."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Poor old Mrs. Bates, civil and humble as usual, looked as if she



<P>did not quite understand what was going on.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am afraid Jane is not very well," said she, "but I do not know;



<P>they tell me she is well.&nbsp; I dare say my daughter will be here

presently,



<P>Miss Woodhouse.&nbsp; I hope you find a chair.&nbsp; I wish Hetty had

not gone.



<P>I am very little able--Have you a chair, ma'am? Do you sit where



<P>you like?&nbsp; I am sure she will be here presently."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma seriously hoped she would.&nbsp; She had a moment's fear of Miss



<P>Bates keeping away from her.&nbsp; But Miss Bates soon came--"Very happy



<P>and obliged"--but Emma's conscience told her that there was not the



<P>same cheerful volubility as before--less ease of look and manner.



<P>A very friendly inquiry after Miss Fairfax, she hoped, might lead



<P>the way to a return of old feelings.&nbsp; The touch seemed immediate.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah!&nbsp; Miss Woodhouse, how kind you are!--I suppose you have heard--



<P>and are come to give us joy.&nbsp; This does not seem much like joy,



<P>indeed, in me--(twinkling away a tear or two)--but it will be



<P>very trying for us to part with her, after having had her so long,



<P>and she has a dreadful headach just now, writing all the morning:--



<P>such long letters, you know, to be written to Colonel Campbell,



<P>and Mrs. Dixon.&nbsp; `My dear,' said I, `you will blind yourself'--



<P>for tears were in her eyes perpetually.&nbsp; One cannot wonder,



<P>one cannot wonder.&nbsp; It is a great change; and though she is



<P>amazingly fortunate--such a situation, I suppose, as no young woman



<P>before ever met with on first going out--do not think us ungrateful,



<P>Miss Woodhouse, for such surprising good fortune--(again dispersing



<P>her tears)--but, poor dear soul! if you were to see what a headache



<P>she has.&nbsp; When one is in great pain, you know one cannot feel



<P>any blessing quite as it may deserve.&nbsp; She is as low as possible.



<P>To look at her, nobody would think how delighted and happy she



<P>is to have secured such a situation.&nbsp; You will excuse her not



<P>coming to you--she is not able--she is gone into her own room--



<P>I want her to lie down upon the bed.&nbsp; `My dear,' said I, `I shall



<P>say you are laid down upon the bed:'&nbsp; but, however, she is not;



<P>she is walking about the room.&nbsp; But, now that she has written



<P>her letters, she says she shall soon be well.&nbsp; She will be extremely



<P>sorry to miss seeing you, Miss Woodhouse, but your kindness will



<P>excuse her.&nbsp; You were kept waiting at the door--I was quite ashamed--
