<P>but somehow there was a little bustle--for it so happened that we



<P>had not heard the knock, and till you were on the stairs, we did



<P>not know any body was coming.&nbsp; `It is only Mrs. Cole,' said I,



<P>`depend upon it.&nbsp; Nobody else would come so early.'&nbsp; `Well,'

said she,



<P>`it must be borne some time or other, and it may as well be now.'



<P>But then Patty came in, and said it was you.&nbsp; `Oh!' said I,



<P>`it is Miss Woodhouse:&nbsp; I am sure you will like to see her.'--



<P>`I can see nobody,' said she; and up she got, and would go away;



<P>and that was what made us keep you waiting--and extremely sorry



<P>and ashamed we were.&nbsp; `If you must go, my dear,' said I, `you must,



<P>and I will say you are laid down upon the bed.'"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma was most sincerely interested.&nbsp; Her heart had been long growing



<P>kinder towards Jane; and this picture of her present sufferings acted



<P>as a cure of every former ungenerous suspicion, and left her nothing



<P>but pity; and the remembrance of the less just and less gentle



<P>sensations of the past, obliged her to admit that Jane might very



<P>naturally resolve on seeing Mrs. Cole or any other steady friend,



<P>when she might not bear to see herself.&nbsp; She spoke as she felt,



<P>with earnest regret and solicitude--sincerely wishing that the



<P>circumstances which she collected from Miss Bates to be now actually



<P>determined on, might be as much for Miss Fairfax's advantage



<P>and comfort as possible.&nbsp; "It must be a severe trial to them all.



<P>She had understood it was to be delayed till Colonel Campbell's return."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So very kind! " replied Miss Bates.&nbsp; "But you are always kind."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was no bearing such an "always;" and to break through her



<P>dreadful gratitude, Emma made the direct inquiry of--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Where--may I ask?--is Miss Fairfax going?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"To a Mrs. Smallridge--charming woman--most superior--to have



<P>the charge of her three little girls--delightful children.



<P>Impossible that any situation could be more replete with comfort;



<P>if we except, perhaps, Mrs. Suckling's own family, and Mrs. Bragge's;



<P>but Mrs. Smallridge is intimate with both, and in the very



<P>same neighbourhood:--lives only four miles from Maple Grove.



<P>Jane will be only four miles from Maple Grove."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mrs. Elton, I suppose, has been the person to whom Miss Fairfax owes--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, our good Mrs. Elton.&nbsp; The most indefatigable, true friend.



<P>She would not take a denial.&nbsp; She would not let Jane say, `No;'

for



<P>when Jane first heard of it, (it was the day before yesterday,



<P>the very morning we were at Donwell,) when Jane first heard of it,



<P>she was quite decided against accepting the offer, and for the



<P>reasons you mention; exactly as you say, she had made up her mind



<P>to close with nothing till Colonel Campbell's return, and nothing



<P>should induce her to enter into any engagement at present--and so she



<P>told Mrs. Elton over and over again--and I am sure I had no more



<P>idea that she would change her mind!--but that good Mrs. Elton,



<P>whose judgment never fails her, saw farther than I did.&nbsp; It is

not



<P>every body that would have stood out in such a kind way as she did,



<P>and refuse to take Jane's answer; but she positively declared she



<P>would not write any such denial yesterday, as Jane wished her;



<P>she would wait--and, sure enough, yesterday evening it was all



<P>settled that Jane should go.&nbsp; Quite a surprize to me!&nbsp; I had

not



<P>the least idea!--Jane took Mrs. Elton aside, and told her at once,



<P>that upon thinking over the advantages of Mrs. Smallridge's situation,



<P>she had come to the resolution of accepting it.--I did not know a word



<P>of it till it was all settled."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You spent the evening with Mrs. Elton?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, all of us; Mrs. Elton would have us come.&nbsp; It was settled

so,



<P>upon the hill, while we were walking about with Mr. Knightley.



<P>`You must all spend your evening with us,' said she--`I positively must



<P>have you all come.'"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mr. Knightley was there too, was he?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, not Mr. Knightley; he declined it from the first; and though I



<P>thought he would come, because Mrs. Elton declared she would not let



<P>him off, he did not;--but my mother, and Jane, and I, were all there,



<P>and a very agreeable evening we had.&nbsp; Such kind friends, you know,



<P>Miss Woodhouse, one must always find agreeable, though every body



<P>seemed rather fagged after the morning's party.&nbsp; Even pleasure,



<P>you know, is fatiguing--and I cannot say that any of them seemed



<P>very much to have enjoyed it.&nbsp; However, I shall always think it



<P>a very pleasant party, and feel extremely obliged to the kind friends



<P>who included me in it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Miss Fairfax, I suppose, though you were not aware of it, had been



<P>making up her mind the whole day?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I dare say she had."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Whenever the time may come, it must be unwelcome to her and all



<P>her friends--but I hope her engagement will have every alleviation



<P>that is possible--I mean, as to the character and manners of the family."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thank you, dear Miss Woodhouse.&nbsp; Yes, indeed, there is every thing



<P>in the world that can make her happy in it.&nbsp; Except the Sucklings



<P>and Bragges, there is not such another nursery establishment,



<P>so liberal and elegant, in all Mrs. Elton's acquaintance.



<P>Mrs. Smallridge, a most delightful woman!--A style of living almost



<P>equal to Maple Grove--and as to the children, except the little



<P>Sucklings and little Bragges, there are not such elegant sweet



<P>children anywhere.&nbsp; Jane will be treated with such regard and kindness!--



<P>It will be nothing but pleasure, a life of pleasure.--And her salary!--



<P>I really cannot venture to name her salary to you, Miss Woodhouse.



<P>Even you, used as you are to great sums, would hardly believe that



<P>so much could be given to a young person like Jane."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah! madam," cried Emma, "if other children are at all like what I



<P>remember to have been myself, I should think five times the amount



<P>of what I have ever yet heard named as a salary on such occasions,



<P>dearly earned."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are so noble in your ideas!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And when is Miss Fairfax to leave you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very soon, very soon, indeed; that's the worst of it.



<P>Within a fortnight.&nbsp; Mrs. Smallridge is in a great hurry.&nbsp;

My poor



<P>mother does not know how to bear it.&nbsp; So then, I try to put it

out of



<P>her thoughts, and say, Come ma'am, do not let us think about it any

more."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Her friends must all be sorry to lose her; and will not Colonel



<P>and Mrs. Campbell be sorry to find that she has engaged herself



<P>before their return?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes; Jane says she is sure they will; but yet, this is such



<P>a situation as she cannot feel herself justified in declining.



<P>I was so astonished when she first told me what she had been saying



<P>to Mrs. Elton, and when Mrs. Elton at the same moment came congratulating



<P>me upon it!&nbsp; It was before tea--stay--no, it could not be before

tea,



<P>because we were just going to cards--and yet it was before tea,



<P>because I remember thinking--Oh! no, now I recollect, now I have it;



<P>something happened before tea, but not that.&nbsp; Mr. Elton was called



<P>out of the room before tea, old John Abdy's son wanted to speak



<P>with him.&nbsp; Poor old John, I have a great regard for him; he was

clerk



<P>to my poor father twenty-seven years; and now, poor old man, he is



<P>bed-ridden, and very poorly with the rheumatic gout in his joints--



<P>I must go and see him to-day; and so will Jane, I am sure, if she



<P>gets out at all.&nbsp; And poor John's son came to talk to Mr. Elton



<P>about relief from the parish; he is very well to do himself,



<P>you know, being head man at the Crown, ostler, and every thing



<P>of that sort, but still he cannot keep his father without some help;



<P>and so, when Mr. Elton came back, he told us what John ostler



<P>had been telling him, and then it came out about the chaise having



<P>been sent to Randalls to take Mr. Frank Churchill to Richmond.



<P>That was what happened before tea.&nbsp; It was after tea that Jane

spoke



<P>to Mrs. Elton."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Bates would hardly give Emma time to say how perfectly



<P>new this circumstance was to her; but as without supposing it



<P>possible that she could be ignorant of any of the particulars



<P>of Mr. Frank Churchill's going, she proceeded to give them all,



<P>it was of no consequence.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>What Mr. Elton had learned from the ostler on the subject, being the



<P>accumulation of the ostler's own knowledge, and the knowledge



<P>of the servants at Randalls, was, that a messenger had come over



<P>from Richmond soon after the return of the party from Box Hill--



<P>which messenger, however, had been no more than was expected;



<P>and that Mr. Churchill had sent his nephew a few lines, containing,



<P>upon the whole, a tolerable account of Mrs. Churchill, and only



<P>wishing him not to delay coming back beyond the next morning early;



<P>but that Mr. Frank Churchill having resolved to go home directly,



<P>without waiting at all, and his horse seeming to have got a cold,



<P>Tom had been sent off immediately for the Crown chaise, and the



<P>ostler had stood out and seen it pass by, the boy going a good pace,



<P>and driving very steady.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was nothing in all this either to astonish or interest,



<P>and it caught Emma's attention only as it united with the subject



<P>which already engaged her mind.&nbsp; The contrast between Mrs. Churchill's



<P>importance in the world, and Jane Fairfax's, struck her; one was



<P>every thing, the other nothing--and she sat musing on the difference



<P>of woman's destiny, and quite unconscious on what her eyes were fixed,



<P>till roused by Miss Bates's saying,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Aye, I see what you are thinking of, the pianoforte.&nbsp; What is

to become



<P>of that?--Very true.&nbsp; Poor dear Jane was talking of it just now.--



<P>`You must go,' said she.&nbsp; `You and I must part.&nbsp; You will

have no



<P>business here.--Let it stay, however,' said she; `give it houseroom



<P>till Colonel Campbell comes back.&nbsp; I shall talk about it to him;



<P>he will settle for me; he will help me out of all my difficulties.'--



<P>And to this day, I do believe, she knows not whether it was his



<P>present or his daughter's."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Now Emma was obliged to think of the pianoforte; and the remembrance



<P>of all her former fanciful and unfair conjectures was so little pleasing,



<P>that she soon allowed herself to believe her visit had been



<P>long enough; and, with a repetition of every thing that she could



<P>venture to say of the good wishes which she really felt, took leave.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 09</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER IX</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Emma's pensive meditations, as she walked home, were not interrupted;



<P>but on entering the parlour, she found those who must rouse her.



<P>Mr. Knightley and Harriet had arrived during her absence, and were



<P>sitting with her father.--Mr. Knightley immediately got up, and in a



<P>manner decidedly graver than usual, said,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I would not go away without seeing you, but I have no time to spare,



<P>and therefore must now be gone directly.&nbsp; I am going to London,



<P>to spend a few days with John and Isabella.&nbsp; Have you any thing

to



<P>send or say, besides the `love,' which nobody carries?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nothing at all.&nbsp; But is not this a sudden scheme?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes--rather--I have been thinking of it some little time."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma was sure he had not forgiven her; he looked unlike himself.



<P>Time, however, she thought, would tell him that they ought to be



<P>friends again.&nbsp; While he stood, as if meaning to go, but not going--



<P>her father began his inquiries.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, my dear, and did you get there safely?--And how did you



<P>find my worthy old friend and her daughter?--I dare say they must



<P>have been very much obliged to you for coming.&nbsp; Dear Emma has been



<P>to call on Mrs. and Miss Bates, Mr. Knightley, as I told you before.



<P>She is always so attentive to them!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma's colour was heightened by this unjust praise; and with a smile,



<P>and shake of the head, which spoke much, she looked at Mr. Knightley.--



<P>It seemed as if there were an instantaneous impression in her favour,



<P>as if his eyes received the truth from her's, and all that had



<P>passed of good in her feelings were at once caught and honoured.--



<P>He looked at her with a glow of regard.&nbsp; She was warmly gratified--



<P>and in another moment still more so, by a little movement of



<P>more than common friendliness on his part.--He took her hand;--



<P>whether she had not herself made the first motion, she could not say--



<P>she might, perhaps, have rather offered it--but he took her hand,



<P>pressed it, and certainly was on the point of carrying it to his lips--



<P>when, from some fancy or other, he suddenly let it go.--Why he should

feel



<P>such a scruple, why he should change his mind when it was all but done,



<P>she could not perceive.--He would have judged better, she thought,



<P>if he had not stopped.--The intention, however, was indubitable;



<P>and whether it was that his manners had in general so little gallantry,



<P>or however else it happened, but she thought nothing became him more.--



<P>It was with him, of so simple, yet so dignified a nature.--



<P>She could not but recall the attempt with great satisfaction.



<P>It spoke such perfect amity.--He left them immediately afterwards--



<P>gone in a moment.&nbsp; He always moved with the alertness of a mind

which



<P>could neither be undecided nor dilatory, but now he seemed more sudden



<P>than usual in his disappearance.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma could not regret her having gone to Miss Bates, but she wished



<P>she had left her ten minutes earlier;--it would have been a great



<P>pleasure to talk over Jane Fairfax's situation with Mr. Knightley.--



<P>Neither would she regret that he should be going to Brunswick Square,



<P>for she knew how much his visit would be enjoyed--but it might have



<P>happened at a better time--and to have had longer notice of it,



<P>would have been pleasanter.--They parted thorough friends, however;



<P>she could not be deceived as to the meaning of his countenance,



<P>and his unfinished gallantry;--it was all done to assure her that she



<P>had fully recovered his good opinion.--He had been sitting with them



<P>half an hour, she found.&nbsp; It was a pity that she had not come



<P>back earlier!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In the hope of diverting her father's thoughts from the disagreeableness



<P>of Mr. Knightley's going to London; and going so suddenly;



<P>and going on horseback, which she knew would be all very bad;



<P>Emma communicated her news of Jane Fairfax, and her dependence



<P>on the effect was justified; it supplied a very useful check,--



<P>interested, without disturbing him.&nbsp; He had long made up his mind

to Jane



<P>Fairfax's going out as governess, and could talk of it cheerfully,



<P>but Mr. Knightley's going to London had been an unexpected blow.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am very glad, indeed, my dear, to hear she is to be so



<P>comfortably settled.&nbsp; Mrs. Elton is very good-natured and agreeable,



<P>and I dare say her acquaintance are just what they ought



<P>to be.&nbsp; I hope it is a dry situation, and that her health



<P>will be taken good care of.&nbsp; It ought to be a first object,



<P>as I am sure poor Miss Taylor's always was with me.&nbsp; You know,



<P>my dear, she is going to be to this new lady what Miss Taylor



<P>was to us.&nbsp; And I hope she will be better off in one respect,



<P>and not be induced to go away after it has been her home so long."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The following day brought news from Richmond to throw every



<P>thing else into the background.&nbsp; An express arrived at Randalls



<P>to announce the death of Mrs. Churchill!&nbsp; Though her nephew



<P>had had no particular reason to hasten back on her account,



<P>she had not lived above six-and-thirty hours after his return.



<P>A sudden seizure of a different nature from any thing foreboded



<P>by her general state, had carried her off after a short struggle.



<P>The great Mrs. Churchill was no more.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was felt as such things must be felt.&nbsp; Every body had a



<P>degree of gravity and sorrow; tenderness towards the departed,



<P>solicitude for the surviving friends; and, in a reasonable time,



<P>curiosity to know where she would be buried.&nbsp; Goldsmith tells us,



<P>that when lovely woman stoops to folly, she has nothing to do



<P>but to die; and when she stoops to be disagreeable, it is equally



<P>to be recommended as a clearer of ill-fame. Mrs. Churchill,



<P>after being disliked at least twenty-five years, was now spoken of



<P>with compassionate allowances.&nbsp; In one point she was fully justified.



<P>She had never been admitted before to be seriously ill.&nbsp; The event



<P>acquitted her of all the fancifulness, and all the selfishness



<P>of imaginary complaints.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Poor Mrs. Churchill! no doubt she had been suffering a great deal:



<P>more than any body had ever supposed--and continual pain would try



<P>the temper.&nbsp; It was a sad event--a great shock--with all her faults,



<P>what would Mr. Churchill do without her?&nbsp; Mr. Churchill's loss



<P>would be dreadful indeed.&nbsp; Mr. Churchill would never get over it."--



<P>Even Mr. Weston shook his head, and looked solemn, and said,



<P>"Ah! poor woman, who would have thought it!" and resolved, that his



<P>mourning should be as handsome as possible; and his wife sat sighing



<P>and moralising over her broad hems with a commiseration and good sense,



<P>true and steady.&nbsp; How it would affect Frank was among the earliest



<P>thoughts of both.&nbsp; It was also a very early speculation with Emma.



<P>The character of Mrs. Churchill, the grief of her husband--her mind



<P>glanced over them both with awe and compassion--and then rested



<P>with lightened feelings on how Frank might be affected by the event,



<P>how benefited, how freed.&nbsp; She saw in a moment all the possible

good.



<P>Now, an attachment to Harriet Smith would have nothing to encounter.



<P>Mr. Churchill, independent of his wife, was feared by nobody;



<P>an easy, guidable man, to be persuaded into any thing by his nephew.



<P>All that remained to be wished was, that the nephew should form



<P>the attachment, as, with all her goodwill in the cause, Emma could feel



<P>no certainty of its being already formed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet behaved extremely well on the occasion, with great self-command.



<P>What ever she might feel of brighter hope, she betrayed nothing.&nbsp;

Emma was



<P>gratified, to observe such a proof in her of strengthened character,



<P>and refrained from any allusion that might endanger its maintenance.



<P>They spoke, therefore, of Mrs. Churchill's death with mutual forbearance.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Short letters from Frank were received at Randalls, communicating



<P>all that was immediately important of their state and plans.



<P>Mr. Churchill was better than could be expected; and their



<P>first removal, on the departure of the funeral for Yorkshire,



<P>was to be to the house of a very old friend in Windsor, to whom



<P>Mr. Churchill had been promising a visit the last ten years.



<P>At present, there was nothing to be done for Harriet; good wishes



<P>for the future were all that could yet be possible on Emma's side.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was a more pressing concern to shew attention to Jane Fairfax,



<P>whose prospects were closing, while Harriet's opened, and whose



<P>engagements now allowed of no delay in any one at Highbury, who wished



<P>to shew her kindness--and with Emma it was grown into a first wish.



<P>She had scarcely a stronger regret than for her past coldness;



<P>and the person, whom she had been so many months neglecting, was now



<P>the very one on whom she would have lavished every distinction of



<P>regard or sympathy.&nbsp; She wanted to be of use to her; wanted to

shew



<P>a value for her society, and testify respect and consideration.



<P>She resolved to prevail on her to spend a day at Hartfield.



<P>A note was written to urge it.&nbsp; The invitation was refused, and

by



<P>a verbal message.&nbsp; "Miss Fairfax was not well enough to write;"



<P>and when Mr. Perry called at Hartfield, the same morning,



<P>it appeared that she was so much indisposed as to have been visited,



<P>though against her own consent, by himself, and that she was suffering



<P>under severe headaches, and a nervous fever to a degree, which made



<P>him doubt the possibility of her going to Mrs. Smallridge's at the



<P>time proposed.&nbsp; Her health seemed for the moment completely deranged--



<P>appetite quite gone--and though there were no absolutely



<P>alarming symptoms, nothing touching the pulmonary complaint,



<P>which was the standing apprehension of the family, Mr. Perry was



<P>uneasy about her.&nbsp; He thought she had undertaken more than she



<P>was equal to, and that she felt it so herself, though she would



<P>not own it.&nbsp; Her spirits seemed overcome.&nbsp; Her present home,



<P>he could not but observe, was unfavourable to a nervous disorder:--



<P>confined always to one room;--he could have wished it otherwise--



<P>and her good aunt, though his very old friend, he must acknowledge



<P>to be not the best companion for an invalid of that description.



<P>Her care and attention could not be questioned; they were, in fact,



<P>only too great.&nbsp; He very much feared that Miss Fairfax derived

more



<P>evil than good from them.&nbsp; Emma listened with the warmest concern;



<P>grieved for her more and more, and looked around eager to discover



<P>some way of being useful.&nbsp; To take her--be it only an hour



<P>or two--from her aunt, to give her change of air and scene,



<P>and quiet rational conversation, even for an hour or two,



<P>might do her good; and the following morning she wrote again to say,



<P>in the most feeling language she could command, that she would



<P>call for her in the carriage at any hour that Jane would name--



<P>mentioning that she had Mr. Perry's decided opinion, in favour



<P>of such exercise for his patient.&nbsp; The answer was only in this



<P>short note:

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Miss Fairfax's compliments and thanks, but is quite unequal



<P>to any exercise."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma felt that her own note had deserved something better; but it



<P>was impossible to quarrel with words, whose tremulous inequality



<P>shewed indisposition so plainly, and she thought only of how she



<P>might best counteract this unwillingness to be seen or assisted.



<P>In spite of the answer, therefore, she ordered the carriage, and drove



<P>to Mrs. Bates's, in the hope that Jane would be induced to join her--



<P>but it would not do;--Miss Bates came to the carriage door, all gratitude,



<P>and agreeing with her most earnestly in thinking an airing might be

of



<P>the greatest service--and every thing that message could do was tried--



<P>but all in vain.&nbsp; Miss Bates was obliged to return without success;



<P>Jane was quite unpersuadable; the mere proposal of going out



<P>seemed to make her worse.--Emma wished she could have seen her,



<P>and tried her own powers; but, almost before she could hint the wish,



<P>Miss Bates made it appear that she had promised her niece on



<P>no account to let Miss Woodhouse in.&nbsp; "Indeed, the truth was,



<P>that poor dear Jane could not bear to see any body--any body at all--



<P>Mrs. Elton, indeed, could not be denied--and Mrs. Cole had made



<P>such a point--and Mrs. Perry had said so much--but, except them,



<P>Jane would really see nobody."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma did not want to be classed with the Mrs. Eltons, the Mrs. Perrys,



<P>and the Mrs. Coles, who would force themselves anywhere;



<P>neither could she feel any right of preference herself--



<P>she submitted, therefore, and only questioned Miss Bates farther



<P>as to her niece's appetite and diet, which she longed to be able



<P>to assist.&nbsp; On that subject poor Miss Bates was very unhappy,



<P>and very communicative; Jane would hardly eat any thing:--



<P>Mr. Perry recommended nourishing food; but every thing they could



<P>command (and never had any body such good neighbours) was distasteful.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma, on reaching home, called the housekeeper directly, to an



<P>examination of her stores; and some arrowroot of very superior quality



<P>was speedily despatched to Miss Bates with a most friendly note.



<P>In half an hour the arrowroot was returned, with a thousand thanks



<P>from Miss Bates, but "dear Jane would not be satisfied without its



<P>being sent back; it was a thing she could not take--and, moreover,



<P>she insisted on her saying, that she was not at all in want of any thing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When Emma afterwards heard that Jane Fairfax had been seen wandering



<P>about the meadows, at some distance from Highbury, on the afternoon



<P>of the very day on which she had, under the plea of being unequal



<P>to any exercise, so peremptorily refused to go out with her in



<P>the carriage, she could have no doubt--putting every thing together--



<P>that Jane was resolved to receive no kindness from her.&nbsp; She was

sorry,



<P>very sorry.&nbsp; Her heart was grieved for a state which seemed



<P>but the more pitiable from this sort of irritation of spirits,



<P>inconsistency of action, and inequality of powers; and it mortified



<P>her that she was given so little credit for proper feeling, or esteemed



<P>so little worthy as a friend:&nbsp; but she had the consolation of knowing



<P>that her intentions were good, and of being able to say to herself,



<P>that could Mr. Knightley have been privy to all her attempts



<P>of assisting Jane Fairfax, could he even have seen into her heart,



<P>he would not, on this occasion, have found any thing to reprove.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 19</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XIX</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>If Emma had still, at intervals, an anxious feeling for Harriet,



<P>a momentary doubt of its being possible for her to be really cured



<P>of her attachment to Mr. Knightley, and really able to accept



<P>another man from unbiased inclination, it was not long that she



<P>had to suffer from the recurrence of any such uncertainty.



<P>A very few days brought the party from London, and she had no



<P>sooner an opportunity of being one hour alone with Harriet,



<P>than she became perfectly satisfied--unaccountable as it was!--



<P>that Robert Martin had thoroughly supplanted Mr. Knightley,



<P>and was now forming all her views of happiness.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet was a little distressed--did look a little foolish at first:



<P>but having once owned that she had been presumptuous and silly,



<P>and self-deceived, before, her pain and confusion seemed to die



<P>away with the words, and leave her without a care for the past,



<P>and with the fullest exultation in the present and future; for, as to



<P>her friend's approbation, Emma had instantly removed every fear of



<P>that nature, by meeting her with the most unqualified congratulations.--



<P>Harriet was most happy to give every particular of the evening at



<P>Astley's, and the dinner the next day; she could dwell on it all



<P>with the utmost delight.&nbsp; But what did such particulars explain?--



<P>The fact was, as Emma could now acknowledge, that Harriet had



<P>always liked Robert Martin; and that his continuing to love her had



<P>been irresistible.--Beyond this, it must ever be unintelligible



<P>to Emma.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The event, however, was most joyful; and every day was giving her



<P>fresh reason for thinking so.--Harriet's parentage became known.



<P>She proved to be the daughter of a tradesman, rich enough to afford



<P>her the comfortable maintenance which had ever been hers, and decent



<P>enough to have always wished for concealment.--Such was the blood



<P>of gentility which Emma had formerly been so ready to vouch for!--



<P>It was likely to be as untainted, perhaps, as the blood of many



<P>a gentleman:&nbsp; but what a connexion had she been preparing for



<P>Mr. Knightley--or for the Churchills--or even for Mr. Elton!--



<P>The stain of illegitimacy, unbleached by nobility or wealth,



<P>would have been a stain indeed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>No objection was raised on the father's side; the young man was



<P>treated liberally; it was all as it should be:&nbsp; and as Emma became



<P>acquainted with Robert Martin, who was now introduced at Hartfield,



<P>she fully acknowledged in him all the appearance of sense and worth



<P>which could bid fairest for her little friend.&nbsp; She had no doubt



<P>of Harriet's happiness with any good-tempered man; but with him,



<P>and in the home he offered, there would be the hope of more,



<P>of security, stability, and improvement.&nbsp; She would be placed in

the



<P>midst of those who loved her, and who had better sense than herself;



<P>retired enough for safety, and occupied enough for cheerfulness.



<P>She would be never led into temptation, nor left for it to find her

out.



<P>She would be respectable and happy; and Emma admitted her to be



<P>the luckiest creature in the world, to have created so steady and



<P>persevering an affection in such a man;--or, if not quite the luckiest,



<P>to yield only to herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet, necessarily drawn away by her engagements with the Martins,



<P>was less and less at Hartfield; which was not to be regretted.--



<P>The intimacy between her and Emma must sink; their friendship must



<P>change into a calmer sort of goodwill; and, fortunately, what ought



<P>to be, and must be, seemed already beginning, and in the most gradual,



<P>natural manner.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Before the end of September, Emma attended Harriet to church, and saw



<P>her hand bestowed on Robert Martin with so complete a satisfaction,



<P>as no remembrances, even connected with Mr. Elton as he stood



<P>before them, could impair.--Perhaps, indeed, at that time she



<P>scarcely saw Mr. Elton, but as the clergyman whose blessing at the



<P>altar might next fall on herself.--Robert Martin and Harriet Smith,



<P>the latest couple engaged of the three, were the first to be married.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jane Fairfax had already quitted Highbury, and was restored to the



<P>comforts of her beloved home with the Campbells.--The Mr. Churchills



<P>were also in town; and they were only waiting for November.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The intermediate month was the one fixed on, as far as they dared,



<P>by Emma and Mr. Knightley.--They had determined that their marriage



<P>ought to be concluded while John and Isabella were still at Hartfield,



<P>to allow them the fortnight's absence in a tour to the seaside,



<P>which was the plan.--John and Isabella, and every other friend,



<P>were agreed in approving it.&nbsp; But Mr. Woodhouse--how was Mr. Woodhouse



<P>to be induced to consent?--he, who had never yet alluded to their



<P>marriage but as a distant event.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When first sounded on the subject, he was so miserable, that they



<P>were almost hopeless.--A second allusion, indeed, gave less pain.--



<P>He began to think it was to be, and that he could not prevent it--



<P>a very promising step of the mind on its way to resignation.



<P>Still, however, he was not happy.&nbsp; Nay, he appeared so much otherwise,



<P>that his daughter's courage failed.&nbsp; She could not bear to see



<P>him suffering, to know him fancying himself neglected; and though



<P>her understanding almost acquiesced in the assurance of both the



<P>Mr. Knightleys, that when once the event were over, his distress



<P>would be soon over too, she hesitated--she could not proceed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In this state of suspense they were befriended, not by any sudden



<P>illumination of Mr. Woodhouse's mind, or any wonderful change of his



<P>nervous system, but by the operation of the same system in another way.--



<P>Mrs. Weston's poultry-house was robbed one night of all her turkeys--



<P>evidently by the ingenuity of man.&nbsp; Other poultry-yards in the



<P>neighbourhood also suffered.--Pilfering was housebreaking to



<P>Mr. Woodhouse's fears.--He was very uneasy; and but for the sense



<P>of his son-in-law's protection, would have been under wretched alarm



<P>every night of his life.&nbsp; The strength, resolution, and presence



<P>of mind of the Mr. Knightleys, commanded his fullest dependence.



<P>While either of them protected him and his, Hartfield was safe.--



<P>But Mr. John Knightley must be in London again by the end of the



<P>first week in November.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The result of this distress was, that, with a much more voluntary,



<P>cheerful consent than his daughter had ever presumed to hope for at



<P>the moment, she was able to fix her wedding-day--and Mr. Elton was



<P>called on, within a month from the marriage of Mr. and Mrs. Robert



<P>Martin, to join the hands of Mr. Knightley and Miss Woodhouse.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The wedding was very much like other weddings, where the parties



<P>have no taste for finery or parade; and Mrs. Elton, from the



<P>particulars detailed by her husband, thought it all extremely shabby,



<P>and very inferior to her own.--"Very little white satin, very few



<P>lace veils; a most pitiful business!--Selina would stare when she



<P>heard of it."--But, in spite of these deficiencies, the wishes,



<P>the hopes, the confidence, the predictions of the small band



<P>of true friends who witnessed the ceremony, were fully answered



<P>in the perfect happiness of the union.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>FINIS



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 18</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XVIII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Time passed on.&nbsp; A few more to-morrows, and the party from London



<P>would be arriving.&nbsp; It was an alarming change; and Emma was thinking



<P>of it one morning, as what must bring a great deal to agitate and



<P>grieve her, when Mr. Knightley came in, and distressing thoughts



<P>were put by.&nbsp; After the first chat of pleasure he was silent;



<P>and then, in a graver tone, began with,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have something to tell you, Emma; some news."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Good or bad?" said she, quickly, looking up in his face.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not know which it ought to be called."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! good I am sure.--I see it in your countenance.&nbsp; You are trying



<P>not to smile."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am afraid," said he, composing his features, "I am very much afraid,



<P>my dear Emma, that you will not smile when you hear it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Indeed! but why so?--I can hardly imagine that any thing which



<P>pleases or amuses you, should not please and amuse me too."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There is one subject," he replied, "I hope but one, on which



<P>we do not think alike."&nbsp; He paused a moment, again smiling,



<P>with his eyes fixed on her face.&nbsp; "Does nothing occur to you?--



<P>Do not you recollect?--Harriet Smith."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her cheeks flushed at the name, and she felt afraid of something,



<P>though she knew not what.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Have you heard from her yourself this morning?" cried he.



<P>"You have, I believe, and know the whole."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, I have not; I know nothing; pray tell me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are prepared for the worst, I see--and very bad it is.



<P>Harriet Smith marries Robert Martin."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma gave a start, which did not seem like being prepared--



<P>and her eyes, in eager gaze, said, "No, this is impossible!"



<P>but her lips were closed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is so, indeed," continued Mr. Knightley; "I have it from Robert



<P>Martin himself.&nbsp; He left me not half an hour ago."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was still looking at him with the most speaking amazement.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You like it, my Emma, as little as I feared.--I wish our opinions were



<P>the same.&nbsp; But in time they will.&nbsp; Time, you may be sure,

will make



<P>one or the other of us think differently; and, in the meanwhile,



<P>we need not talk much on the subject."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You mistake me, you quite mistake me," she replied, exerting herself.



<P>"It is not that such a circumstance would now make me unhappy,



<P>but I cannot believe it.&nbsp; It seems an impossibility!--You cannot

mean



<P>to say, that Harriet Smith has accepted Robert Martin.&nbsp; You cannot



<P>mean that he has even proposed to her again--yet.&nbsp; You only mean,



<P>that he intends it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I mean that he has done it," answered Mr. Knightley, with smiling



<P>but determined decision, "and been accepted."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Good God!" she cried.--"Well!"--Then having recourse to her workbasket,



<P>in excuse for leaning down her face, and concealing all the



<P>exquisite feelings of delight and entertainment which she knew she



<P>must be expressing, she added, "Well, now tell me every thing;



<P>make this intelligible to me.&nbsp; How, where, when?--Let me know it

all.



<P>I never was more surprized--but it does not make me unhappy,



<P>I assure you.--How--how has it been possible?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is a very simple story.&nbsp; He went to town on business three

days ago,



<P>and I got him to take charge of some papers which I was wanting



<P>to send to John.--He delivered these papers to John, at his chambers,



<P>and was asked by him to join their party the same evening to Astley's.



<P>They were going to take the two eldest boys to Astley's. The party



<P>was to be our brother and sister, Henry, John--and Miss Smith.



<P>My friend Robert could not resist.&nbsp; They called for him in their

way;



<P>were all extremely amused; and my brother asked him to dine with



<P>them the next day--which he did--and in the course of that visit



<P>(as I understand) he found an opportunity of speaking to Harriet;



<P>and certainly did not speak in vain.--She made him, by her acceptance,



<P>as happy even as he is deserving.&nbsp; He came down by yesterday's

coach,



<P>and was with me this morning immediately after breakfast, to report



<P>his proceedings, first on my affairs, and then on his own.



<P>This is all that I can relate of the how, where, and when.



<P>Your friend Harriet will make a much longer history when you see her.--



<P>She will give you all the minute particulars, which only woman's



<P>language can make interesting.--In our communications we deal only



<P>in the great.--However, I must say, that Robert Martin's heart seemed



<P>for him, and to me, very overflowing; and that he did mention,



<P>without its being much to the purpose, that on quitting their



<P>box at Astley's, my brother took charge of Mrs. John Knightley



<P>and little John, and he followed with Miss Smith and Henry;



<P>and that at one time they were in such a crowd, as to make Miss Smith



<P>rather uneasy."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He stopped.--Emma dared not attempt any immediate reply.&nbsp; To speak,



<P>she was sure would be to betray a most unreasonable degree



<P>of happiness.&nbsp; She must wait a moment, or he would think her mad.



<P>Her silence disturbed him; and after observing her a little while,



<P>he added,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Emma, my love, you said that this circumstance would not now make



<P>you unhappy; but I am afraid it gives you more pain than you expected.



<P>His situation is an evil--but you must consider it as what satisfies



<P>your friend; and I will answer for your thinking better and better



<P>of him as you know him more.&nbsp; His good sense and good principles

would



<P>delight you.--As far as the man is concerned, you could not wish your



<P>friend in better hands.&nbsp; His rank in society I would alter if I

could,



<P>which is saying a great deal I assure you, Emma.--You laugh at me



<P>about William Larkins; but I could quite as ill spare Robert Martin."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He wanted her to look up and smile; and having now brought herself



<P>not to smile too broadly--she did--cheerfully answering,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You need not be at any pains to reconcile me to the match.&nbsp; I

think



<P>Harriet is doing extremely well.&nbsp; Her connexions may be worse than

his.



<P>In respectability of character, there can be no doubt that they are.



<P>I have been silent from surprize merely, excessive surprize.



<P>You cannot imagine how suddenly it has come on me! how peculiarly



<P>unprepared I was!--for I had reason to believe her very lately more



<P>determined against him, much more, than she was before."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You ought to know your friend best," replied Mr. Knightley;



<P>"but I should say she was a good-tempered, soft-hearted girl,



<P>not likely to be very, very determined against any young man who told



<P>her he loved her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma could not help laughing as she answered, "Upon my word,



<P>I believe you know her quite as well as I do.--But, Mr. Knightley,



<P>are you perfectly sure that she has absolutely and downright



<P>accepted him.&nbsp; I could suppose she might in time--but can she already?--



<P>Did not you misunderstand him?--You were both talking of other things;



<P>of business, shows of cattle, or new drills--and might not you,



<P>in the confusion of so many subjects, mistake him?--It was not



<P>Harriet's hand that he was certain of--it was the dimensions of some



<P>famous ox."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The contrast between the countenance and air of Mr. Knightley and



<P>Robert Martin was, at this moment, so strong to Emma's feelings,



<P>and so strong was the recollection of all that had so recently



<P>passed on Harriet's side, so fresh the sound of those words,



<P>spoken with such emphasis, "No, I hope I know better than to think



<P>of Robert Martin," that she was really expecting the intelligence



<P>to prove, in some measure, premature.&nbsp; It could not be otherwise.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do you dare say this?" cried Mr. Knightley.&nbsp; "Do you dare to suppose



<P>me so great a blockhead, as not to know what a man is talking of?--



<P>What do you deserve?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh!&nbsp; I always deserve the best treatment, because I never put



<P>up with any other; and, therefore, you must give me a plain,



<P>direct answer.&nbsp; Are you quite sure that you understand the terms



<P>on which Mr. Martin and Harriet now are?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am quite sure," he replied, speaking very distinctly, "that he



<P>told me she had accepted him; and that there was no obscurity,



<P>nothing doubtful, in the words he used; and I think I can give you



<P>a proof that it must be so.&nbsp; He asked my opinion as to what he



<P>was now to do.&nbsp; He knew of no one but Mrs. Goddard to whom he



<P>could apply for information of her relations or friends.&nbsp; Could

I



<P>mention any thing more fit to be done, than to go to Mrs. Goddard?



<P>I assured him that I could not.&nbsp; Then, he said, he would endeavour



<P>to see her in the course of this day."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am perfectly satisfied," replied Emma, with the brightest smiles,



<P>"and most sincerely wish them happy."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are materially changed since we talked on this subject before."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I hope so--for at that time I was a fool."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And I am changed also; for I am now very willing to grant you all



<P>Harriet's good qualities.&nbsp; I have taken some pains for your sake,



<P>and for Robert Martin's sake, (whom I have always had reason to believe



<P>as much in love with her as ever,) to get acquainted with her.



<P>I have often talked to her a good deal.&nbsp; You must have seen that



<P>I did.&nbsp; Sometimes, indeed, I have thought you were half suspecting

me



<P>of pleading poor Martin's cause, which was never the case; but, from

all



<P>my observations, I am convinced of her being an artless, amiable girl,



<P>with very good notions, very seriously good principles, and placing



<P>her happiness in the affections and utility of domestic life.--



<P>Much of this, I have no doubt, she may thank you for."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Me!" cried Emma, shaking her head.--"Ah! poor Harriet!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She checked herself, however, and submitted quietly to a little



<P>more praise than she deserved.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Their conversation was soon afterwards closed by the entrance of



<P>her father.&nbsp; She was not sorry.&nbsp; She wanted to be alone.&nbsp;

Her mind



<P>was in a state of flutter and wonder, which made it impossible for her



<P>to be collected.&nbsp; She was in dancing, singing, exclaiming spirits;



<P>and till she had moved about, and talked to herself, and laughed



<P>and reflected, she could be fit for nothing rational.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her father's business was to announce James's being gone out to put



<P>the horses to, preparatory to their now daily drive to Randalls;



<P>and she had, therefore, an immediate excuse for disappearing.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The joy, the gratitude, the exquisite delight of her sensations



<P>may be imagined.&nbsp; The sole grievance and alloy thus removed in

the



<P>prospect of Harriet's welfare, she was really in danger of becoming



<P>too happy for security.--What had she to wish for?&nbsp; Nothing, but

to



<P>grow more worthy of him, whose intentions and judgment had been



<P>ever so superior to her own.&nbsp; Nothing, but that the lessons



<P>of her past folly might teach her humility and circumspection in future.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Serious she was, very serious in her thankfulness, and in her resolutions;



<P>and yet there was no preventing a laugh, sometimes in the very midst



<P>of them.&nbsp; She must laugh at such a close!&nbsp; Such an end of

the doleful



<P>disappointment of five weeks back!&nbsp; Such a heart--such a Harriet!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Now there would be pleasure in her returning--Every thing would



<P>be a pleasure.&nbsp; It would be a great pleasure to know Robert Martin.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>High in the rank of her most serious and heartfelt felicities,



<P>was the reflection that all necessity of concealment from



<P>Mr. Knightley would soon be over.&nbsp; The disguise, equivocation,



<P>mystery, so hateful to her to practise, might soon be over.



<P>She could now look forward to giving him that full and perfect



<P>confidence which her disposition was most ready to welcome as a duty.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In the gayest and happiest spirits she set forward with her father;



<P>not always listening, but always agreeing to what he said;



<P>and, whether in speech or silence, conniving at the comfortable



<P>persuasion of his being obliged to go to Randalls every day,



<P>or poor Mrs. Weston would be disappointed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They arrived.--Mrs. Weston was alone in the drawing-room:--



<P>but hardly had they been told of the baby, and Mr. Woodhouse



<P>received the thanks for coming, which he asked for, when a glimpse



<P>was caught through the blind, of two figures passing near the window.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is Frank and Miss Fairfax," said Mrs. Weston.&nbsp; "I was just



<P>going to tell you of our agreeable surprize in seeing him arrive



<P>this morning.&nbsp; He stays till to-morrow, and Miss Fairfax has been



<P>persuaded to spend the day with us.--They are coming in, I hope."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In half a minute they were in the room.&nbsp; Emma was extremely glad



<P>to see him--but there was a degree of confusion--a number of



<P>embarrassing recollections on each side.&nbsp; They met readily and

smiling,



<P>but with a consciousness which at first allowed little to be said;



<P>and having all sat down again, there was for some time such a blank



<P>in the circle, that Emma began to doubt whether the wish now indulged,



<P>which she had long felt, of seeing Frank Churchill once more,



<P>and of seeing him with Jane, would yield its proportion of pleasure.



<P>When Mr. Weston joined the party, however, and when the baby



<P>was fetched, there was no longer a want of subject or animation--



<P>or of courage and opportunity for Frank Churchill to draw near her



<P>and say,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have to thank you, Miss Woodhouse, for a very kind forgiving



<P>message in one of Mrs. Weston's letters.&nbsp; I hope time has not made



<P>you less willing to pardon.&nbsp; I hope you do not retract what you



<P>then said."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, indeed," cried Emma, most happy to begin, "not in the least.



<P>I am particularly glad to see and shake hands with you--and to give



<P>you joy in person."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He thanked her with all his heart, and continued some time to speak



<P>with serious feeling of his gratitude and happiness.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Is not she looking well?" said he, turning his eyes towards Jane.



<P>"Better than she ever used to do?--You see how my father and



<P>Mrs. Weston doat upon her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But his spirits were soon rising again, and with laughing eyes,



<P>after mentioning the expected return of the Campbells, he named



<P>the name of Dixon.--Emma blushed, and forbade its being pronounced



<P>in her hearing.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I can never think of it," she cried, "without extreme shame."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The shame," he answered, "is all mine, or ought to be.&nbsp; But is

it



<P>possible that you had no suspicion?--I mean of late.&nbsp; Early, I

know,



<P>you had none."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I never had the smallest, I assure you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That appears quite wonderful.&nbsp; I was once very near--and I wish

I had--



<P>it would have been better.&nbsp; But though I was always doing wrong

things,



<P>they were very bad wrong things, and such as did me no service.--



<P>It would have been a much better transgression had I broken the bond



<P>of secrecy and told you every thing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is not now worth a regret," said Emma.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have some hope," resumed he, "of my uncle's being persuaded



<P>to pay a visit at Randalls; he wants to be introduced to her.



<P>When the Campbells are returned, we shall meet them in London,



<P>and continue there, I trust, till we may carry her northward.--But now,



<P>I am at such a distance from her--is not it hard, Miss Woodhouse?--



<P>Till this morning, we have not once met since the day of reconciliation.



<P>Do not you pity me?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma spoke her pity so very kindly, that with a sudden accession



<P>of gay thought, he cried,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah! by the bye," then sinking his voice, and looking demure for



<P>the moment--"I hope Mr. Knightley is well?"&nbsp; He paused.--She coloured



<P>and laughed.--"I know you saw my letter, and think you may remember



<P>my wish in your favour.&nbsp; Let me return your congratulations.--



<P>I assure you that I have heard the news with the warmest interest



<P>and satisfaction.--He is a man whom I cannot presume to praise."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma was delighted, and only wanted him to go on in the same style;



<P>but his mind was the next moment in his own concerns and with his



<P>own Jane, and his next words were,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Did you ever see such a skin?--such smoothness! such delicacy!--



<P>and yet without being actually fair.--One cannot call her fair.



<P>It is a most uncommon complexion, with her dark eye-lashes and hair--



<P>a most distinguishing complexion!&nbsp; So peculiarly the lady in it.--



<P>Just colour enough for beauty."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have always admired her complexion," replied Emma, archly; "but do

not



<P>I remember the time when you found fault with her for being so pale?--



<P>When we first began to talk of her.--Have you quite forgotten?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! no--what an impudent dog I was!--How could I dare--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But he laughed so heartily at the recollection, that Emma could



<P>not help saying,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do suspect that in the midst of your perplexities at that time,



<P>you had very great amusement in tricking us all.--I am sure you had.--



<P>I am sure it was a consolation to you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! no, no, no--how can you suspect me of such a thing?



<P>I was the most miserable wretch!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not quite so miserable as to be insensible to mirth.&nbsp; I am sure

it



<P>was a source of high entertainment to you, to feel that you were taking



<P>us all in.--Perhaps I am the readier to suspect, because, to tell



<P>you the truth, I think it might have been some amusement to myself



<P>in the same situation.&nbsp; I think there is a little likeness between

us."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He bowed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If not in our dispositions," she presently added, with a look of



<P>true sensibility, "there is a likeness in our destiny; the destiny



<P>which bids fair to connect us with two characters so much superior



<P>to our own."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"True, true," he answered, warmly.&nbsp; "No, not true on your side.&nbsp;

You can



<P>have no superior, but most true on mine.--She is a complete angel.



<P>Look at her.&nbsp; Is not she an angel in every gesture?&nbsp; Observe

the turn



<P>of her throat.&nbsp; Observe her eyes, as she is looking up at my father.--



<P>You will be glad to hear (inclining his head, and whispering seriously)



<P>that my uncle means to give her all my aunt's jewels.&nbsp; They are

to be



<P>new set.&nbsp; I am resolved to have some in an ornament for the head.



<P>Will not it be beautiful in her dark hair?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very beautiful, indeed," replied Emma; and she spoke so kindly,



<P>that he gratefully burst out,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How delighted I am to see you again! and to see you in such



<P>excellent looks!--I would not have missed this meeting for the world.



<P>I should certainly have called at Hartfield, had you failed to come."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The others had been talking of the child, Mrs. Weston giving an



<P>account of a little alarm she had been under, the evening before,



<P>from the infant's appearing not quite well.&nbsp; She believed she had



<P>been foolish, but it had alarmed her, and she had been within half



<P>a minute of sending for Mr. Perry.&nbsp; Perhaps she ought to be ashamed,



<P>but Mr. Weston had been almost as uneasy as herself.--In ten minutes,



<P>however, the child had been perfectly well again.&nbsp; This was



<P>her history; and particularly interesting it was to Mr. Woodhouse,



<P>who commended her very much for thinking of sending for Perry,



<P>and only regretted that she had not done it.&nbsp; "She should always

send



<P>for Perry, if the child appeared in the slightest degree disordered,



<P>were it only for a moment.&nbsp; She could not be too soon alarmed,



<P>nor send for Perry too often.&nbsp; It was a pity, perhaps, that he



<P>had not come last night; for, though the child seemed well now,



<P>very well considering, it would probably have been better if Perry



<P>had seen it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Frank Churchill caught the name.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Perry!" said he to Emma, and trying, as he spoke, to catch Miss



<P>Fairfax's eye.&nbsp; "My friend Mr. Perry!&nbsp; What are they saying



<P>about Mr. Perry?--Has he been here this morning?--And how does



<P>he travel now?--Has he set up his carriage?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma soon recollected, and understood him; and while she joined



<P>in the laugh, it was evident from Jane's countenance that she



<P>too was really hearing him, though trying to seem deaf.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Such an extraordinary dream of mine!" he cried.&nbsp; "I can never

think



<P>of it without laughing.--She hears us, she hears us, Miss Woodhouse.



<P>I see it in her cheek, her smile, her vain attempt to frown.



<P>Look at her.&nbsp; Do not you see that, at this instant, the very passage



<P>of her own letter, which sent me the report, is passing under her eye--



<P>that the whole blunder is spread before her--that she can attend to



<P>nothing else, though pretending to listen to the others?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jane was forced to smile completely, for a moment; and the smile



<P>partly remained as she turned towards him, and said in a conscious,



<P>low, yet steady voice,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How you can bear such recollections, is astonishing to me!--



<P>They will sometimes obtrude--but how you can court them!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He had a great deal to say in return, and very entertainingly;



<P>but Emma's feelings were chiefly with Jane, in the argument; and on



<P>leaving Randalls, and falling naturally into a comparison of the two

men,



<P>she felt, that pleased as she had been to see Frank Churchill,



<P>and really regarding him as she did with friendship, she had never



<P>been more sensible of Mr. Knightley's high superiority of character.



<P>The happiness of this most happy day, received its completion, in the



<P>animated contemplation of his worth which this comparison produced.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 16</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XVI</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Every body in and about Highbury who had ever visited Mr. Elton,



<P>was disposed to pay him attention on his marriage.&nbsp; Dinner-parties

and



<P>evening-parties were made for him and his lady; and invitations



<P>flowed in so fast that she had soon the pleasure of apprehending



<P>they were never to have a disengaged day.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I see how it is," said she.&nbsp; "I see what a life I am to lead



<P>among you.&nbsp; Upon my word we shall be absolutely dissipated.



<P>We really seem quite the fashion.&nbsp; If this is living in the country,



<P>it is nothing very formidable.&nbsp; From Monday next to Saturday,



<P>I assure you we have not a disengaged day!--A woman with fewer



<P>resources than I have, need not have been at a loss."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>No invitation came amiss to her.&nbsp; Her Bath habits made evening-parties



<P>perfectly natural to her, and Maple Grove had given her a taste



<P>for dinners.&nbsp; She was a little shocked at the want of two



<P>drawing rooms, at the poor attempt at rout-cakes, and there being



<P>no ice in the Highbury card-parties. Mrs. Bates, Mrs. Perry,



<P>Mrs. Goddard and others, were a good deal behind-hand in knowledge



<P>of the world, but she would soon shew them how every thing ought



<P>to be arranged.&nbsp; In the course of the spring she must return their



<P>civilities by one very superior party--in which her card-tables



<P>should be set out with their separate candles and unbroken packs



<P>in the true style--and more waiters engaged for the evening



<P>than their own establishment could furnish, to carry round



<P>the refreshments at exactly the proper hour, and in the proper order.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma, in the meanwhile, could not be satisfied without a dinner



<P>at Hartfield for the Eltons.&nbsp; They must not do less than others,



<P>or she should be exposed to odious suspicions, and imagined capable



<P>of pitiful resentment.&nbsp; A dinner there must be.&nbsp; After Emma

had



<P>talked about it for ten minutes, Mr. Woodhouse felt no unwillingness,



<P>and only made the usual stipulation of not sitting at the bottom



<P>of the table himself, with the usual regular difficulty of deciding



<P>who should do it for him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The persons to be invited, required little thought.&nbsp; Besides the

Eltons,



<P>it must be the Westons and Mr. Knightley; so far it was all of course--



<P>and it was hardly less inevitable that poor little Harriet must



<P>be asked to make the eighth:--but this invitation was not given



<P>with equal satisfaction, and on many accounts Emma was particularly



<P>pleased by Harriet's begging to be allowed to decline it.



<P>"She would rather not be in his company more than she could help.



<P>She was not yet quite able to see him and his charming happy



<P>wife together, without feeling uncomfortable.&nbsp; If Miss Woodhouse



<P>would not be displeased, she would rather stay at home."



<P>It was precisely what Emma would have wished, had she deemed it



<P>possible enough for wishing.&nbsp; She was delighted with the fortitude



<P>of her little friend--for fortitude she knew it was in her to give



<P>up being in company and stay at home; and she could now invite the



<P>very person whom she really wanted to make the eighth, Jane Fairfax.--



<P>Since her last conversation with Mrs. Weston and Mr. Knightley,



<P>she was more conscience-stricken about Jane Fairfax than she had



<P>often been.--Mr. Knightley's words dwelt with her.&nbsp; He had said



<P>that Jane Fairfax received attentions from Mrs. Elton which nobody



<P>else paid her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"This is very true," said she, "at least as far as relates to me,



<P>which was all that was meant--and it is very shameful.--Of the same

age--



<P>and always knowing her--I ought to have been more her friend.--



<P>She will never like me now.&nbsp; I have neglected her too long.&nbsp;

But I



<P>will shew her greater attention than I have done."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Every invitation was successful.&nbsp; They were all disengaged and

all happy.--



<P>The preparatory interest of this dinner, however, was not yet over.



<P>A circumstance rather unlucky occurred.&nbsp; The two eldest little



<P>Knightleys were engaged to pay their grandpapa and aunt a visit of



<P>some weeks in the spring, and their papa now proposed bringing them,



<P>and staying one whole day at Hartfield--which one day would be



<P>the very day of this party.--His professional engagements did



<P>not allow of his being put off, but both father and daughter were



<P>disturbed by its happening so.&nbsp; Mr. Woodhouse considered eight



<P>persons at dinner together as the utmost that his nerves could bear--



<P>and here would be a ninth--and Emma apprehended that it would



<P>be a ninth very much out of humour at not being able to come even



<P>to Hartfield for forty-eight hours without falling in with a dinner-party.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She comforted her father better than she could comfort herself,



<P>by representing that though he certainly would make them nine,



<P>yet he always said so little, that the increase of noise would be



<P>very immaterial.&nbsp; She thought it in reality a sad exchange for

herself,



<P>to have him with his grave looks and reluctant conversation opposed



<P>to her instead of his brother.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The event was more favourable to Mr. Woodhouse than to Emma.



<P>John Knightley came; but Mr. Weston was unexpectedly summoned to town



<P>and must be absent on the very day.&nbsp; He might be able to join them



<P>in the evening, but certainly not to dinner.&nbsp; Mr. Woodhouse was

quite



<P>at ease; and the seeing him so, with the arrival of the little boys



<P>and the philosophic composure of her brother on hearing his fate,



<P>removed the chief of even Emma's vexation.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The day came, the party were punctually assembled, and Mr. John Knightley



<P>seemed early to devote himself to the business of being agreeable.



<P>Instead of drawing his brother off to a window while they waited



<P>for dinner, he was talking to Miss Fairfax.&nbsp; Mrs. Elton, as elegant



<P>as lace and pearls could make her, he looked at in silence--



<P>wanting only to observe enough for Isabella's information--but Miss



<P>Fairfax was an old acquaintance and a quiet girl, and he could



<P>talk to her.&nbsp; He had met her before breakfast as he was returning



<P>from a walk with his little boys, when it had been just beginning



<P>to rain.&nbsp; It was natural to have some civil hopes on the subject,



<P>and he said,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I hope you did not venture far, Miss Fairfax, this morning, or I



<P>am sure you must have been wet.--We scarcely got home in time.



<P>I hope you turned directly."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I went only to the post-office," said she, "and reached home



<P>before the rain was much.&nbsp; It is my daily errand.&nbsp; I always

fetch



<P>the letters when I am here.&nbsp; It saves trouble, and is a something



<P>to get me out.&nbsp; A walk before breakfast does me good."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not a walk in the rain, I should imagine."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, but it did not absolutely rain when I set out."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. John Knightley smiled, and replied,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That is to say, you chose to have your walk, for you were not six



<P>yards from your own door when I had the pleasure of meeting you;



<P>and Henry and John had seen more drops than they could count long before.



<P>The post-office has a great charm at one period of our lives.



<P>When you have lived to my age, you will begin to think letters are



<P>never worth going through the rain for."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was a little blush, and then this answer,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I must not hope to be ever situated as you are, in the midst of



<P>every dearest connexion, and therefore I cannot expect that simply



<P>growing older should make me indifferent about letters."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Indifferent!&nbsp; Oh! no--I never conceived you could become indifferent.



<P>Letters are no matter of indifference; they are generally a very



<P>positive curse."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are speaking of letters of business; mine are letters



<P>of friendship."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have often thought them the worst of the two," replied he coolly.



<P>"Business, you know, may bring money, but friendship hardly



<P>ever does."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah! you are not serious now.&nbsp; I know Mr. John Knightley too well--



<P>I am very sure he understands the value of friendship as well as



<P>any body.&nbsp; I can easily believe that letters are very little to

you,



<P>much less than to me, but it is not your being ten years older than



<P>myself which makes the difference, it is not age, but situation.



<P>You have every body dearest to you always at hand, I, probably,



<P>never shall again; and therefore till I have outlived all my affections,



<P>a post-office, I think, must always have power to draw me out,



<P>in worse weather than to-day."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"When I talked of your being altered by time, by the progress of years,"



<P>said John Knightley, "I meant to imply the change of situation



<P>which time usually brings.&nbsp; I consider one as including the other.



<P>Time will generally lessen the interest of every attachment not within



<P>the daily circle--but that is not the change I had in view for you.



<P>As an old friend, you will allow me to hope, Miss Fairfax, that ten



<P>years hence you may have as many concentrated objects as I have."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was kindly said, and very far from giving offence.&nbsp; A pleasant



<P>"thank you" seemed meant to laugh it off, but a blush, a quivering lip,



<P>a tear in the eye, shewed that it was felt beyond a laugh.



<P>Her attention was now claimed by Mr. Woodhouse, who being,



<P>according to his custom on such occasions, making the circle of



<P>his guests, and paying his particular compliments to the ladies,



<P>was ending with her--and with all his mildest urbanity, said,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am very sorry to hear, Miss Fairfax, of your being out this



<P>morning in the rain.&nbsp; Young ladies should take care of themselves.--



<P>Young ladies are delicate plants.&nbsp; They should take care of their



<P>health and their complexion.&nbsp; My dear, did you change your stockings?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, sir, I did indeed; and I am very much obliged by your kind



<P>solicitude about me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear Miss Fairfax, young ladies are very sure to be cared for.--



<P>I hope your good grand-mama and aunt are well.&nbsp; They are some



<P>of my very old friends.&nbsp; I wish my health allowed me to be a



<P>better neighbour.&nbsp; You do us a great deal of honour to-day, I am

sure.



<P>My daughter and I are both highly sensible of your goodness,



<P>and have the greatest satisfaction in seeing you at Hartfield."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The kind-hearted, polite old man might then sit down and feel



<P>that he had done his duty, and made every fair lady welcome and easy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>By this time, the walk in the rain had reached Mrs. Elton,



<P>and her remonstrances now opened upon Jane.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear Jane, what is this I hear?--Going to the post-office



<P>in the rain!--This must not be, I assure you.--You sad girl,



<P>how could you do such a thing?--It is a sign I was not there



<P>to take care of you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jane very patiently assured her that she had not caught any cold.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! do not tell me.&nbsp; You really are a very sad girl, and do not



<P>know how to take care of yourself.--To the post-office indeed!



<P>Mrs. Weston, did you ever hear the like?&nbsp; You and I must positively



<P>exert our authority."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My advice," said Mrs. Weston kindly and persuasively, "I certainly



<P>do feel tempted to give.&nbsp; Miss Fairfax, you must not run such risks.--



<P>Liable as you have been to severe colds, indeed you ought



<P>to be particularly careful, especially at this time of year.



<P>The spring I always think requires more than common care.



<P>Better wait an hour or two, or even half a day for your letters,



<P>than run the risk of bringing on your cough again.&nbsp; Now do not

you



<P>feel that you had?&nbsp; Yes, I am sure you are much too reasonable.



<P>You look as if you would not do such a thing again."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! she shall not do such a thing again," eagerly rejoined



<P>Mrs. Elton.&nbsp; "We will not allow her to do such a thing again:"--



<P>and nodding significantly--"there must be some arrangement made,



<P>there must indeed.&nbsp; I shall speak to Mr. E. The man who fetches



<P>our letters every morning (one of our men, I forget his name)



<P>shall inquire for yours too and bring them to you.&nbsp; That will obviate



<P>all difficulties you know; and from us I really think, my dear Jane,



<P>you can have no scruple to accept such an accommodation."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are extremely kind," said Jane; "but I cannot give up my



<P>early walk.&nbsp; I am advised to be out of doors as much as I can,



<P>I must walk somewhere, and the post-office is an object; and upon



<P>my word, I have scarcely ever had a bad morning before."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear Jane, say no more about it.&nbsp; The thing is determined,



<P>that is (laughing affectedly) as far as I can presume to determine



<P>any thing without the concurrence of my lord and master.&nbsp; You know,



<P>Mrs. Weston, you and I must be cautious how we express ourselves.



<P>But I do flatter myself, my dear Jane, that my influence is not entirely



<P>worn out.&nbsp; If I meet with no insuperable difficulties therefore,



<P>consider that point as settled."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Excuse me," said Jane earnestly, "I cannot by any means consent



<P>to such an arrangement, so needlessly troublesome to your servant.



<P>If the errand were not a pleasure to me, it could be done, as it



<P>always is when I am not here, by my grandmama's."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! my dear; but so much as Patty has to do!--And it is a kindness



<P>to employ our men."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jane looked as if she did not mean to be conquered; but instead



<P>of answering, she began speaking again to Mr. John Knightley.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The post-office is a wonderful establishment!" said she.--



<P>"The regularity and despatch of it!&nbsp; If one thinks of all that

it



<P>has to do, and all that it does so well, it is really astonishing!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is certainly very well regulated."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So seldom that any negligence or blunder appears!&nbsp; So seldom



<P>that a letter, among the thousands that are constantly passing



<P>about the kingdom, is even carried wrong--and not one in a million,



<P>I suppose, actually lost!&nbsp; And when one considers the variety



<P>of hands, and of bad hands too, that are to be deciphered,



<P>it increases the wonder."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The clerks grow expert from habit.--They must begin with some



<P>quickness of sight and hand, and exercise improves them.&nbsp; If you



<P>want any farther explanation," continued he, smiling, "they are



<P>paid for it.&nbsp; That is the key to a great deal of capacity.



<P>The public pays and must be served well."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The varieties of handwriting were farther talked of, and the usual



<P>observations made.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have heard it asserted," said John Knightley, "that the same



<P>sort of handwriting often prevails in a family; and where the



<P>same master teaches, it is natural enough.&nbsp; But for that reason,



<P>I should imagine the likeness must be chiefly confined to the females,



<P>for boys have very little teaching after an early age, and scramble



<P>into any hand they can get.&nbsp; Isabella and Emma, I think, do write



<P>very much alike.&nbsp; I have not always known their writing apart."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes," said his brother hesitatingly, "there is a likeness.



<P>I know what you mean--but Emma's hand is the strongest."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Isabella and Emma both write beautifully," said Mr. Woodhouse;



<P>"and always did.&nbsp; And so does poor Mrs. Weston"--with half a sigh



<P>and half a smile at her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I never saw any gentleman's handwriting"--Emma began, looking also



<P>at Mrs. Weston; but stopped, on perceiving that Mrs. Weston was



<P>attending to some one else--and the pause gave her time to reflect,



<P>"Now, how am I going to introduce him?--Am I unequal to speaking



<P>his name at once before all these people?&nbsp; Is it necessary



<P>for me to use any roundabout phrase?--Your Yorkshire friend--



<P>your correspondent in Yorkshire;--that would be the way, I suppose,



<P>if I were very bad.--No, I can pronounce his name without the



<P>smallest distress.&nbsp; I certainly get better and better.--Now for

it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Weston was disengaged and Emma began again--"Mr. Frank Churchill



<P>writes one of the best gentleman's hands I ever saw."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;
