<P>"I do not admire it," said Mr. Knightley.&nbsp; "It is too small--



<P>wants strength.&nbsp; It is like a woman's writing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This was not submitted to by either lady.&nbsp; They vindicated him



<P>against the base aspersion.&nbsp; "No, it by no means wanted strength--



<P>it was not a large hand, but very clear and certainly strong.



<P>Had not Mrs. Weston any letter about her to produce?"&nbsp; No, she

had



<P>heard from him very lately, but having answered the letter, had put



<P>it away.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If we were in the other room," said Emma, "if I had my writing-desk,



<P>I am sure I could produce a specimen.&nbsp; I have a note of his.--



<P>Do not you remember, Mrs. Weston, employing him to write for you



<P>one day?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He chose to say he was employed"--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, well, I have that note; and can shew it after dinner



<P>to convince Mr. Knightley."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! when a gallant young man, like Mr. Frank Churchill,"



<P>said Mr. Knightley dryly, "writes to a fair lady like Miss Woodhouse,



<P>he will, of course, put forth his best."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Dinner was on table.--Mrs. Elton, before she could be spoken to,



<P>was ready; and before Mr. Woodhouse had reached her with his request



<P>to be allowed to hand her into the dining-parlour, was saying--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Must I go first?&nbsp; I really am ashamed of always leading the way."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jane's solicitude about fetching her own letters had not escaped Emma.



<P>She had heard and seen it all; and felt some curiosity to know



<P>whether the wet walk of this morning had produced any.&nbsp; She suspected



<P>that it had; that it would not have been so resolutely encountered



<P>but in full expectation of hearing from some one very dear,



<P>and that it had not been in vain.&nbsp; She thought there was an air



<P>of greater happiness than usual--a glow both of complexion and spirits.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She could have made an inquiry or two, as to the expedition



<P>and the expense of the Irish mails;--it was at her tongue's end--



<P>but she abstained.&nbsp; She was quite determined not to utter a word



<P>that should hurt Jane Fairfax's feelings; and they followed



<P>the other ladies out of the room, arm in arm, with an appearance



<P>of good-will highly becoming to the beauty and grace of each.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 02</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER II</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Jane Fairfax was an orphan, the only child of Mrs. Bates's



<P>youngest daughter.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The marriage of Lieut. Fairfax of the _______ regiment of infantry,



<P>and Miss Jane Bates, had had its day of fame and pleasure,



<P>hope and interest; but nothing now remained of it, save the melancholy



<P>remembrance of him dying in action abroad--of his widow sinking



<P>under consumption and grief soon afterwards--and this girl.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>By birth she belonged to Highbury:&nbsp; and when at three years old,



<P>on losing her mother, she became the property, the charge,



<P>the consolation, the fondling of her grandmother and aunt, there had



<P>seemed every probability of her being permanently fixed there;



<P>of her being taught only what very limited means could command,



<P>and growing up with no advantages of connexion or improvement,



<P>to be engrafted on what nature had given her in a pleasing person,



<P>good understanding, and warm-hearted, well-meaning relations.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But the compassionate feelings of a friend of her father gave



<P>a change to her destiny.&nbsp; This was Colonel Campbell, who had



<P>very highly regarded Fairfax, as an excellent officer and most



<P>deserving young man; and farther, had been indebted to him for



<P>such attentions, during a severe camp-fever, as he believed had saved



<P>his life.&nbsp; These were claims which he did not learn to overlook,



<P>though some years passed away from the death of poor Fairfax,



<P>before his own return to England put any thing in his power.



<P>When he did return, he sought out the child and took notice of her.



<P>He was a married man, with only one living child, a girl,



<P>about Jane's age:&nbsp; and Jane became their guest, paying them long

visits



<P>and growing a favourite with all; and before she was nine years old,



<P>his daughter's great fondness for her, and his own wish of being



<P>a real friend, united to produce an offer from Colonel Campbell



<P>of undertaking the whole charge of her education.&nbsp; It was accepted;



<P>and from that period Jane had belonged to Colonel Campbell's family,



<P>and had lived with them entirely, only visiting her grandmother



<P>from time to time.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The plan was that she should be brought up for educating others;



<P>the very few hundred pounds which she inherited from her father



<P>making independence impossible.&nbsp; To provide for her otherwise



<P>was out of Colonel Campbell's power; for though his income, by pay



<P>and appointments, was handsome, his fortune was moderate and must



<P>be all his daughter's; but, by giving her an education, he hoped



<P>to be supplying the means of respectable subsistence hereafter.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Such was Jane Fairfax's history.&nbsp; She had fallen into good hands,



<P>known nothing but kindness from the Campbells, and been given



<P>an excellent education.&nbsp; Living constantly with right-minded



<P>and well-informed people, her heart and understanding had received



<P>every advantage of discipline and culture; and Colonel Campbell's



<P>residence being in London, every lighter talent had been done



<P>full justice to, by the attendance of first-rate masters.



<P>Her disposition and abilities were equally worthy of all that



<P>friendship could do; and at eighteen or nineteen she was, as far



<P>as such an early age can be qualified for the care of children,



<P>fully competent to the office of instruction herself; but she



<P>was too much beloved to be parted with.&nbsp; Neither father nor mother



<P>could promote, and the daughter could not endure it.&nbsp; The evil

day



<P>was put off.&nbsp; It was easy to decide that she was still too young;



<P>and Jane remained with them, sharing, as another daughter, in all



<P>the rational pleasures of an elegant society, and a judicious



<P>mixture of home and amusement, with only the drawback of the future,



<P>the sobering suggestions of her own good understanding to remind



<P>her that all this might soon be over.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The affection of the whole family, the warm attachment of Miss



<P>Campbell in particular, was the more honourable to each party



<P>from the circumstance of Jane's decided superiority both in beauty



<P>and acquirements.&nbsp; That nature had given it in feature could not



<P>be unseen by the young woman, nor could her higher powers of mind



<P>be unfelt by the parents.&nbsp; They continued together with unabated



<P>regard however, till the marriage of Miss Campbell, who by that chance,



<P>that luck which so often defies anticipation in matrimonial affairs,



<P>giving attraction to what is moderate rather than to what is superior,



<P>engaged the affections of Mr. Dixon, a young man, rich and agreeable,



<P>almost as soon as they were acquainted; and was eligibly



<P>and happily settled, while Jane Fairfax had yet her bread to earn.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This event had very lately taken place; too lately for any thing to

be



<P>yet attempted by her less fortunate friend towards entering on her path



<P>of duty; though she had now reached the age which her own judgment



<P>had fixed on for beginning.&nbsp; She had long resolved that one-and-twenty



<P>should be the period.&nbsp; With the fortitude of a devoted novitiate,



<P>she had resolved at one-and-twenty to complete the sacrifice,



<P>and retire from all the pleasures of life, of rational intercourse,



<P>equal society, peace and hope, to penance and mortification for ever.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The good sense of Colonel and Mrs. Campbell could not oppose such



<P>a resolution, though their feelings did.&nbsp; As long as they lived,



<P>no exertions would be necessary, their home might be hers for ever;



<P>and for their own comfort they would have retained her wholly;



<P>but this would be selfishness:--what must be at last, had better



<P>be soon.&nbsp; Perhaps they began to feel it might have been kinder



<P>and wiser to have resisted the temptation of any delay, and spared



<P>her from a taste of such enjoyments of ease and leisure as must



<P>now be relinquished.&nbsp; Still, however, affection was glad to catch



<P>at any reasonable excuse for not hurrying on the wretched moment.



<P>She had never been quite well since the time of their daughter's marriage;



<P>and till she should have completely recovered her usual strength,



<P>they must forbid her engaging in duties, which, so far from being



<P>compatible with a weakened frame and varying spirits, seemed,



<P>under the most favourable circumstances, to require something



<P>more than human perfection of body and mind to be discharged with



<P>tolerable comfort.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>With regard to her not accompanying them to Ireland, her account



<P>to her aunt contained nothing but truth, though there might be some



<P>truths not told.&nbsp; It was her own choice to give the time of their



<P>absence to Highbury; to spend, perhaps, her last months of perfect



<P>liberty with those kind relations to whom she was so very dear:



<P>and the Campbells, whatever might be their motive or motives,



<P>whether single, or double, or treble, gave the arrangement



<P>their ready sanction, and said, that they depended more on a few



<P>months spent in her native air, for the recovery of her health,



<P>than on any thing else.&nbsp; Certain it was that she was to come;



<P>and that Highbury, instead of welcoming that perfect novelty which



<P>had been so long promised it--Mr. Frank Churchill--must put up for



<P>the present with Jane Fairfax, who could bring only the freshness



<P>of a two years' absence.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma was sorry;--to have to pay civilities to a person she did



<P>not like through three long months!--to be always doing more than



<P>she wished, and less than she ought!&nbsp; Why she did not like Jane



<P>Fairfax might be a difficult question to answer; Mr. Knightley



<P>had once told her it was because she saw in her the really



<P>accomplished young woman, which she wanted to be thought herself;



<P>and though the accusation had been eagerly refuted at the time,



<P>there were moments of self-examination in which her conscience could



<P>not quite acquit her.&nbsp; But "she could never get acquainted with

her:



<P>she did not know how it was, but there was such coldness and reserve--



<P>such apparent indifference whether she pleased or not--and then,



<P>her aunt was such an eternal talker!--and she was made such a fuss



<P>with by every body!--and it had been always imagined that they were



<P>to be so intimate--because their ages were the same, every body had



<P>supposed they must be so fond of each other."&nbsp; These were her reasons--



<P>she had no better.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was a dislike so little just--every imputed fault was so magnified



<P>by fancy, that she never saw Jane Fairfax the first time after any



<P>considerable absence, without feeling that she had injured her;



<P>and now, when the due visit was paid, on her arrival, after a two years'



<P>interval, she was particularly struck with the very appearance



<P>and manners, which for those two whole years she had been depreciating.



<P>Jane Fairfax was very elegant, remarkably elegant; and she had



<P>herself the highest value for elegance.&nbsp; Her height was pretty,



<P>just such as almost every body would think tall, and nobody could



<P>think very tall; her figure particularly graceful; her size a most



<P>becoming medium, between fat and thin, though a slight appearance



<P>of ill-health seemed to point out the likeliest evil of the two.



<P>Emma could not but feel all this; and then, her face--her features--



<P>there was more beauty in them altogether than she had remembered;



<P>it was not regular, but it was very pleasing beauty.&nbsp; Her eyes,



<P>a deep grey, with dark eye-lashes and eyebrows, had never been denied



<P>their praise; but the skin, which she had been used to cavil at,



<P>as wanting colour, had a clearness and delicacy which really needed



<P>no fuller bloom.&nbsp; It was a style of beauty, of which elegance



<P>was the reigning character, and as such, she must, in honour,



<P>by all her principles, admire it:--elegance, which, whether of person



<P>or of mind, she saw so little in Highbury.&nbsp; There, not to be vulgar,



<P>was distinction, and merit.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In short, she sat, during the first visit, looking at Jane Fairfax



<P>with twofold complacency; the sense of pleasure and the sense



<P>of rendering justice, and was determining that she would dislike



<P>her no longer.&nbsp; When she took in her history, indeed, her situation,



<P>as well as her beauty; when she considered what all this elegance



<P>was destined to, what she was going to sink from, how she was going



<P>to live, it seemed impossible to feel any thing but compassion



<P>and respect; especially, if to every well-known particular entitling



<P>her to interest, were added the highly probable circumstance



<P>of an attachment to Mr. Dixon, which she had so naturally started



<P>to herself.&nbsp; In that case, nothing could be more pitiable



<P>or more honourable than the sacrifices she had resolved on.



<P>Emma was very willing now to acquit her of having seduced



<P>Mr. Dixon's actions from his wife, or of any thing mischievous



<P>which her imagination had suggested at first.&nbsp; If it were love,



<P>it might be simple, single, successless love on her side alone.



<P>She might have been unconsciously sucking in the sad poison,



<P>while a sharer of his conversation with her friend; and from the best,



<P>the purest of motives, might now be denying herself this visit



<P>to Ireland, and resolving to divide herself effectually from



<P>him and his connexions by soon beginning her career of laborious duty.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Upon the whole, Emma left her with such softened, charitable feelings,



<P>as made her look around in walking home, and lament that Highbury



<P>afforded no young man worthy of giving her independence;



<P>nobody that she could wish to scheme about for her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>These were charming feelings--but not lasting.&nbsp; Before she had



<P>committed herself by any public profession of eternal friendship for



<P>Jane Fairfax, or done more towards a recantation of past prejudices



<P>and errors, than saying to Mr. Knightley, "She certainly is handsome;



<P>she is better than handsome!"&nbsp; Jane had spent an evening at Hartfield



<P>with her grandmother and aunt, and every thing was relapsing much



<P>into its usual state.&nbsp; Former provocations reappeared.&nbsp; The

aunt



<P>was as tiresome as ever; more tiresome, because anxiety for her



<P>health was now added to admiration of her powers; and they had to



<P>listen to the description of exactly how little bread and butter



<P>she ate for breakfast, and how small a slice of mutton for dinner,



<P>as well as to see exhibitions of new caps and new workbags for her



<P>mother and herself; and Jane's offences rose again.&nbsp; They had music;



<P>Emma was obliged to play; and the thanks and praise which necessarily



<P>followed appeared to her an affectation of candour, an air



<P>of greatness, meaning only to shew off in higher style her own very



<P>superior performance.&nbsp; She was, besides, which was the worst of

all,



<P>so cold, so cautious!&nbsp; There was no getting at her real opinion.



<P>Wrapt up in a cloak of politeness, she seemed determined



<P>to hazard nothing.&nbsp; She was disgustingly, was suspiciously reserved.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>If any thing could be more, where all was most, she was more



<P>reserved on the subject of Weymouth and the Dixons than any thing.



<P>She seemed bent on giving no real insight into Mr. Dixon's character,



<P>or her own value for his company, or opinion of the suitableness



<P>of the match.&nbsp; It was all general approbation and smoothness;



<P>nothing delineated or distinguished.&nbsp; It did her no service however.



<P>Her caution was thrown away.&nbsp; Emma saw its artifice, and returned



<P>to her first surmises.&nbsp; There probably was something more to conceal



<P>than her own preference; Mr. Dixon, perhaps, had been very near



<P>changing one friend for the other, or been fixed only to Miss Campbell,



<P>for the sake of the future twelve thousand pounds.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The like reserve prevailed on other topics.&nbsp; She and Mr. Frank

Churchill



<P>had been at Weymouth at the same time.&nbsp; It was known that they

were



<P>a little acquainted; but not a syllable of real information could Emma



<P>procure as to what he truly was.&nbsp; "Was he handsome?"--"She believed



<P>he was reckoned a very fine young man."&nbsp; "Was he agreeable?"--



<P>"He was generally thought so."&nbsp; "Did he appear a sensible young

man;



<P>a young man of information?"--"At a watering-place, or in a common



<P>London acquaintance, it was difficult to decide on such points.



<P>Manners were all that could be safely judged of, under a much longer



<P>knowledge than they had yet had of Mr. Churchill.&nbsp; She believed



<P>every body found his manners pleasing."&nbsp; Emma could not forgive

her.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 03</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER III</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Emma could not forgive her;--but as neither provocation nor resentment



<P>were discerned by Mr. Knightley, who had been of the party, and had



<P>seen only proper attention and pleasing behaviour on each side,



<P>he was expressing the next morning, being at Hartfield again on



<P>business with Mr. Woodhouse, his approbation of the whole; not so



<P>openly as he might have done had her father been out of the room,



<P>but speaking plain enough to be very intelligible to Emma.



<P>He had been used to think her unjust to Jane, and had now great



<P>pleasure in marking an improvement.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A very pleasant evening," he began, as soon as Mr. Woodhouse



<P>had been talked into what was necessary, told that he understood,



<P>and the papers swept away;--"particularly pleasant.&nbsp; You and Miss



<P>Fairfax gave us some very good music.&nbsp; I do not know a more



<P>luxurious state, sir, than sitting at one's ease to be entertained



<P>a whole evening by two such young women; sometimes with music



<P>and sometimes with conversation.&nbsp; I am sure Miss Fairfax must



<P>have found the evening pleasant, Emma.&nbsp; You left nothing undone.



<P>I was glad you made her play so much, for having no instrument



<P>at her grandmother's, it must have been a real indulgence."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am happy you approved," said Emma, smiling; "but I hope I am



<P>not often deficient in what is due to guests at Hartfield."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, my dear," said her father instantly; "that I am sure you



<P>are not.&nbsp; There is nobody half so attentive and civil as you are.



<P>If any thing, you are too attentive.&nbsp; The muffin last night--if

it



<P>had been handed round once, I think it would have been enough."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No," said Mr. Knightley, nearly at the same time; "you are not



<P>often deficient; not often deficient either in manner or comprehension.



<P>I think you understand me, therefore."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>An arch look expressed--"I understand you well enough;" but she



<P>said only, "Miss Fairfax is reserved."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I always told you she was--a little; but you will soon overcome



<P>all that part of her reserve which ought to be overcome, all that



<P>has its foundation in diffidence.&nbsp; What arises from discretion



<P>must be honoured."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You think her diffident.&nbsp; I do not see it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear Emma," said he, moving from his chair into one close



<P>by her, "you are not going to tell me, I hope, that you



<P>had not a pleasant evening."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! no; I was pleased with my own perseverance in asking questions;



<P>and amused to think how little information I obtained."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am disappointed," was his only answer.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I hope every body had a pleasant evening," said Mr. Woodhouse,



<P>in his quiet way.&nbsp; "I had.&nbsp; Once, I felt the fire rather too

much;



<P>but then I moved back my chair a little, a very little, and it did



<P>not disturb me.&nbsp; Miss Bates was very chatty and good-humoured,



<P>as she always is, though she speaks rather too quick.&nbsp; However,



<P>she is very agreeable, and Mrs. Bates too, in a different way.



<P>I like old friends; and Miss Jane Fairfax is a very pretty sort of



<P>young lady, a very pretty and a very well-behaved young lady indeed.



<P>She must have found the evening agreeable, Mr. Knightley, because she



<P>had Emma."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"True, sir; and Emma, because she had Miss Fairfax."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma saw his anxiety, and wishing to appease it, at least for



<P>the present, said, and with a sincerity which no one could question--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She is a sort of elegant creature that one cannot keep one's eyes from.



<P>I am always watching her to admire; and I do pity her from my heart."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Knightley looked as if he were more gratified than he cared



<P>to express; and before he could make any reply, Mr. Woodhouse,



<P>whose thoughts were on the Bates's, said--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is a great pity that their circumstances should be so confined!



<P>a great pity indeed! and I have often wished--but it is so little one



<P>can venture to do--small, trifling presents, of any thing uncommon--



<P>Now we have killed a porker, and Emma thinks of sending them



<P>a loin or a leg; it is very small and delicate--Hartfield pork is



<P>not like any other pork--but still it is pork--and, my dear Emma,



<P>unless one could be sure of their making it into steaks, nicely fried,



<P>as ours are fried, without the smallest grease, and not roast it,



<P>for no stomach can bear roast pork--I think we had better send the leg--



<P>do not you think so, my dear?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear papa, I sent the whole hind-quarter. I knew you would wish

it.



<P>There will be the leg to be salted, you know, which is so very nice,



<P>and the loin to be dressed directly in any manner they like."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's right, my dear, very right.&nbsp; I had not thought of it before,



<P>but that is the best way.&nbsp; They must not over-salt the leg; and

then,



<P>if it is not over-salted, and if it is very thoroughly boiled,



<P>just as Serle boils ours, and eaten very moderately of, with a



<P>boiled turnip, and a little carrot or parsnip, I do not consider



<P>it unwholesome."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Emma," said Mr. Knightley presently, "I have a piece of news for you.



<P>You like news--and I heard an article in my way hither that I think



<P>will interest you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"News!&nbsp; Oh! yes, I always like news.&nbsp; What is it?--why do

you



<P>smile so?--where did you hear it?--at Randalls?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He had time only to say,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, not at Randalls; I have not been near Randalls," when the door



<P>was thrown open, and Miss Bates and Miss Fairfax walked into the room.



<P>Full of thanks, and full of news, Miss Bates knew not which to



<P>give quickest.&nbsp; Mr. Knightley soon saw that he had lost his moment,



<P>and that not another syllable of communication could rest with him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! my dear sir, how are you this morning?&nbsp; My dear Miss Woodhouse--



<P>I come quite over-powered. Such a beautiful hind-quarter of pork!



<P>You are too bountiful!&nbsp; Have you heard the news?&nbsp; Mr. Elton

is going



<P>to be married."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma had not had time even to think of Mr. Elton, and she was



<P>so completely surprized that she could not avoid a little start,



<P>and a little blush, at the sound.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There is my news:--I thought it would interest you,"



<P>said Mr. Knightley, with a smile which implied a conviction



<P>of some part of what had passed between them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But where could you hear it?" cried Miss Bates.&nbsp; "Where could



<P>you possibly hear it, Mr. Knightley?&nbsp; For it is not five minutes



<P>since I received Mrs. Cole's note--no, it cannot be more than five--



<P>or at least ten--for I had got my bonnet and spencer on, just ready



<P>to come out--I was only gone down to speak to Patty again about



<P>the pork--Jane was standing in the passage--were not you, Jane?--



<P>for my mother was so afraid that we had not any salting-pan



<P>large enough.&nbsp; So I said I would go down and see, and Jane said,



<P>`Shall I go down instead? for I think you have a little cold,



<P>and Patty has been washing the kitchen.'--`Oh! my dear,'



<P>said I--well, and just then came the note.&nbsp; A Miss Hawkins--



<P>that's all I know.&nbsp; A Miss Hawkins of Bath.&nbsp; But, Mr. Knightley,



<P>how could you possibly have heard it? for the very moment Mr. Cole



<P>told Mrs. Cole of it, she sat down and wrote to me.&nbsp; A Miss Hawkins--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I was with Mr. Cole on business an hour and a half ago.



<P>He had just read Elton's letter as I was shewn in, and handed it



<P>to me directly."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well! that is quite--I suppose there never was a piece of news more



<P>generally interesting.&nbsp; My dear sir, you really are too bountiful.



<P>My mother desires her very best compliments and regards, and a



<P>thousand thanks, and says you really quite oppress her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We consider our Hartfield pork," replied Mr. Woodhouse--"indeed it



<P>certainly is, so very superior to all other pork, that Emma and I



<P>cannot have a greater pleasure than---"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! my dear sir, as my mother says, our friends are only too good



<P>to us.&nbsp; If ever there were people who, without having great wealth



<P>themselves, had every thing they could wish for, I am sure it is us.



<P>We may well say that `our lot is cast in a goodly heritage.'



<P>Well, Mr. Knightley, and so you actually saw the letter; well--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It was short--merely to announce--but cheerful, exulting, of course."--



<P>Here was a sly glance at Emma.&nbsp; "He had been so fortunate as to--



<P>I forget the precise words--one has no business to remember them.



<P>The information was, as you state, that he was going to be married



<P>to a Miss Hawkins.&nbsp; By his style, I should imagine it just settled."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mr. Elton going to be married!" said Emma, as soon as she could speak.



<P>"He will have every body's wishes for his happiness."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He is very young to settle," was Mr. Woodhouse's observation.



<P>"He had better not be in a hurry.&nbsp; He seemed to me very well off



<P>as he was.&nbsp; We were always glad to see him at Hartfield."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A new neighbour for us all, Miss Woodhouse!" said Miss Bates,



<P>joyfully; "my mother is so pleased!--she says she cannot



<P>bear to have the poor old Vicarage without a mistress.



<P>This is great news, indeed.&nbsp; Jane, you have never seen



<P>Mr. Elton!--no wonder that you have such a curiosity to see him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jane's curiosity did not appear of that absorbing nature as wholly



<P>to occupy her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No--I have never seen Mr. Elton," she replied, starting on this appeal;



<P>"is he--is he a tall man?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Who shall answer that question?" cried Emma.&nbsp; "My father would



<P>say `yes,' Mr. Knightley `no;' and Miss Bates and I that he is



<P>just the happy medium.&nbsp; When you have been here a little longer,



<P>Miss Fairfax, you will understand that Mr. Elton is the standard



<P>of perfection in Highbury, both in person and mind."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very true, Miss Woodhouse, so she will.&nbsp; He is the very best



<P>young man--But, my dear Jane, if you remember, I told you yesterday



<P>he was precisely the height of Mr. Perry.&nbsp; Miss Hawkins,--I dare

say,



<P>an excellent young woman.&nbsp; His extreme attention to my mother--



<P>wanting her to sit in the vicarage pew, that she might hear the better,



<P>for my mother is a little deaf, you know--it is not much, but she



<P>does not hear quite quick.&nbsp; Jane says that Colonel Campbell is

a



<P>little deaf.&nbsp; He fancied bathing might be good for it--the warm

bath--



<P>but she says it did him no lasting benefit.&nbsp; Colonel Campbell,



<P>you know, is quite our angel.&nbsp; And Mr. Dixon seems a very charming



<P>young man, quite worthy of him.&nbsp; It is such a happiness when good



<P>people get together--and they always do.&nbsp; Now, here will be Mr.

Elton



<P>and Miss Hawkins; and there are the Coles, such very good people;



<P>and the Perrys--I suppose there never was a happier or a better couple



<P>than Mr. and Mrs. Perry.&nbsp; I say, sir," turning to Mr. Woodhouse,



<P>"I think there are few places with such society as Highbury.



<P>I always say, we are quite blessed in our neighbours.--My dear sir,



<P>if there is one thing my mother loves better than another, it is pork--



<P>a roast loin of pork--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"As to who, or what Miss Hawkins is, or how long he has been



<P>acquainted with her," said Emma, "nothing I suppose can be known.



<P>One feels that it cannot be a very long acquaintance.&nbsp; He has been



<P>gone only four weeks."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Nobody had any information to give; and, after a few more wonderings,



<P>Emma said,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are silent, Miss Fairfax--but I hope you mean to take



<P>an interest in this news.&nbsp; You, who have been hearing and seeing



<P>so much of late on these subjects, who must have been so deep



<P>in the business on Miss Campbell's account--we shall not excuse



<P>your being indifferent about Mr. Elton and Miss Hawkins."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"When I have seen Mr. Elton," replied Jane, " I dare say I



<P>shall be interested--but I believe it requires that with me.



<P>And as it is some months since Miss Campbell married, the impression



<P>may be a little worn off."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, he has been gone just four weeks, as you observe, Miss Woodhouse,"



<P>said Miss Bates, "four weeks yesterday.--A Miss Hawkins!--Well, I had



<P>always rather fancied it would be some young lady hereabouts;



<P>not that I ever--Mrs. Cole once whispered to me--but I immediately said,



<P>`No, Mr. Elton is a most worthy young man--but'--In short, I do



<P>not think I am particularly quick at those sort of discoveries.



<P>I do not pretend to it.&nbsp; What is before me, I see.&nbsp; At the

same time,



<P>nobody could wonder if Mr. Elton should have aspired--Miss Woodhouse



<P>lets me chatter on, so good-humouredly. She knows I would not



<P>offend for the world.&nbsp; How does Miss Smith do?&nbsp; She seems

quite



<P>recovered now.&nbsp; Have you heard from Mrs. John Knightley lately?



<P>Oh! those dear little children.&nbsp; Jane, do you know I always fancy



<P>Mr. Dixon like Mr. John Knightley.&nbsp; I mean in person--tall, and

with



<P>that sort of look--and not very talkative."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Quite wrong, my dear aunt; there is no likeness at all."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very odd! but one never does form a just idea of any body beforehand.



<P>One takes up a notion, and runs away with it.&nbsp; Mr. Dixon, you say,



<P>is not, strictly speaking, handsome?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Handsome!&nbsp; Oh! no--far from it--certainly plain.&nbsp; I told

you he



<P>was plain."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear, you said that Miss Campbell would not allow him to be plain,



<P>and that you yourself--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! as for me, my judgment is worth nothing.&nbsp; Where I have a regard,



<P>I always think a person well-looking. But I gave what I believed



<P>the general opinion, when I called him plain."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, my dear Jane, I believe we must be running away.



<P>The weather does not look well, and grandmama will be uneasy.



<P>You are too obliging, my dear Miss Woodhouse; but we really must



<P>take leave.&nbsp; This has been a most agreeable piece of news indeed.



<P>I shall just go round by Mrs. Cole's; but I shall not stop three minutes:



<P>and, Jane, you had better go home directly--I would not have you



<P>out in a shower!--We think she is the better for Highbury already.



<P>Thank you, we do indeed.&nbsp; I shall not attempt calling on Mrs. Goddard,



<P>for I really do not think she cares for any thing but boiled pork:



<P>when we dress the leg it will be another thing.&nbsp; Good morning to

you,



<P>my dear sir.&nbsp; Oh!&nbsp; Mr. Knightley is coming too.&nbsp; Well,

that is



<P>so very!--I am sure if Jane is tired, you will be so kind as to



<P>give her your arm.--Mr. Elton, and Miss Hawkins!--Good morning



<P>to you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma, alone with her father, had half her attention wanted by him



<P>while he lamented that young people would be in such a hurry to marry--



<P>and to marry strangers too--and the other half she could give



<P>to her own view of the subject.&nbsp; It was to herself an amusing



<P>and a very welcome piece of news, as proving that Mr. Elton



<P>could not have suffered long; but she was sorry for Harriet:



<P>Harriet must feel it--and all that she could hope was, by giving



<P>the first information herself, to save her from hearing it abruptly



<P>from others.&nbsp; It was now about the time that she was likely to

call.



<P>If she were to meet Miss Bates in her way!--and upon its beginning



<P>to rain, Emma was obliged to expect that the weather would be



<P>detaining her at Mrs. Goddard's, and that the intelligence would



<P>undoubtedly rush upon her without preparation.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The shower was heavy, but short; and it had not been over five minutes,



<P>when in came Harriet, with just the heated, agitated look which



<P>hurrying thither with a full heart was likely to give; and the



<P>"Oh! Miss Woodhouse, what do you think has happened!" which instantly



<P>burst forth, had all the evidence of corresponding perturbation.



<P>As the blow was given, Emma felt that she could not now shew greater



<P>kindness than in listening; and Harriet, unchecked, ran eagerly



<P>through what she had to tell.&nbsp; "She had set out from Mrs. Goddard's



<P>half an hour ago--she had been afraid it would rain--she had been



<P>afraid it would pour down every moment--but she thought she might



<P>get to Hartfield first--she had hurried on as fast as possible;



<P>but then, as she was passing by the house where a young woman



<P>was making up a gown for her, she thought she would just step



<P>in and see how it went on; and though she did not seem to stay



<P>half a moment there, soon after she came out it began to rain,



<P>and she did not know what to do; so she ran on directly, as fast



<P>as she could, and took shelter at Ford's."--Ford's was the principal



<P>woollen-draper, linen-draper, and haberdasher's shop united;



<P>the shop first in size and fashion in the place.--"And so,



<P>there she had set, without an idea of any thing in the world,



<P>full ten minutes, perhaps--when, all of a sudden, who should come in--



<P>to be sure it was so very odd!--but they always dealt at Ford's--



<P>who should come in, but Elizabeth Martin and her brother!--



<P>Dear Miss Woodhouse! only think.&nbsp; I thought I should have fainted.



<P>I did not know what to do.&nbsp; I was sitting near the door--Elizabeth

saw



<P>me directly; but he did not; he was busy with the umbrella.



<P>I am sure she saw me, but she looked away directly, and took



<P>no notice; and they both went to quite the farther end of the shop;



<P>and I kept sitting near the door!--Oh! dear; I was so miserable!



<P>I am sure I must have been as white as my gown.&nbsp; I could not go

away



<P>you know, because of the rain; but I did so wish myself anywhere



<P>in the world but there.--Oh! dear, Miss Woodhouse--well, at last,



<P>I fancy, he looked round and saw me; for instead of going



<P>on with her buyings, they began whispering to one another.



<P>I am sure they were talking of me; and I could not help thinking



<P>that he was persuading her to speak to me--(do you think he was,



<P>Miss Woodhouse?)--for presently she came forward--came quite up



<P>to me, and asked me how I did, and seemed ready to shake hands,



<P>if I would.&nbsp; She did not do any of it in the same way that she

used;



<P>I could see she was altered; but, however, she seemed to try to be



<P>very friendly, and we shook hands, and stood talking some time;



<P>but I know no more what I said--I was in such a tremble!--I remember



<P>she said she was sorry we never met now; which I thought almost



<P>too kind!&nbsp; Dear, Miss Woodhouse, I was absolutely miserable!



<P>By that time, it was beginning to hold up, and I was determined



<P>that nothing should stop me from getting away--and then--only think!--



<P>I found he was coming up towards me too--slowly you know, and as



<P>if he did not quite know what to do; and so he came and spoke,



<P>and I answered--and I stood for a minute, feeling dreadfully,



<P>you know, one can't tell how; and then I took courage, and said it



<P>did not rain, and I must go; and so off I set; and I had not got



<P>three yards from the door, when he came after me, only to say,



<P>if I was going to Hartfield, he thought I had much better go round



<P>by Mr. Cole's stables, for I should find the near way quite floated



<P>by this rain.&nbsp; Oh! dear, I thought it would have been the death

of me!



<P>So I said, I was very much obliged to him:&nbsp; you know I could



<P>not do less; and then he went back to Elizabeth, and I came round



<P>by the stables--I believe I did--but I hardly knew where I was,



<P>or any thing about it.&nbsp; Oh!&nbsp; Miss Woodhouse, I would rather

done



<P>any thing than have it happen:&nbsp; and yet, you know, there was a

sort



<P>of satisfaction in seeing him behave so pleasantly and so kindly.



<P>And Elizabeth, too.&nbsp; Oh!&nbsp; Miss Woodhouse, do talk to me and

make



<P>me comfortable again."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Very sincerely did Emma wish to do so; but it was not immediately in



<P>her power.&nbsp; She was obliged to stop and think.&nbsp; She was not

thoroughly



<P>comfortable herself.&nbsp; The young man's conduct, and his sister's,



<P>seemed the result of real feeling, and she could not but pity them.



<P>As Harriet described it, there had been an interesting mixture



<P>of wounded affection and genuine delicacy in their behaviour.



<P>But she had believed them to be well-meaning, worthy people before;



<P>and what difference did this make in the evils of the connexion?



<P>It was folly to be disturbed by it.&nbsp; Of course, he must be sorry



<P>to lose her--they must be all sorry.&nbsp; Ambition, as well as love,



<P>had probably been mortified.&nbsp; They might all have hoped to rise



<P>by Harriet's acquaintance:&nbsp; and besides, what was the value of



<P>Harriet's description?--So easily pleased--so little discerning;--



<P>what signified her praise?

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She exerted herself, and did try to make her comfortable,



<P>by considering all that had passed as a mere trifle, and quite



<P>unworthy of being dwelt on,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It might be distressing, for the moment," said she; "but you seem



<P>to have behaved extremely well; and it is over--and may never--



<P>can never, as a first meeting, occur again, and therefore you need



<P>not think about it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet said, "very true," and she "would not think about it;"



<P>but still she talked of it--still she could talk of nothing else;



<P>and Emma, at last, in order to put the Martins out of her head,



<P>was obliged to hurry on the news, which she had meant to give



<P>with so much tender caution; hardly knowing herself whether



<P>to rejoice or be angry, ashamed or only amused, at such a state



<P>of mind in poor Harriet--such a conclusion of Mr. Elton's importance



<P>with her!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Elton's rights, however, gradually revived.&nbsp; Though she did

not



<P>feel the first intelligence as she might have done the day before,



<P>or an hour before, its interest soon increased; and before their



<P>first conversation was over, she had talked herself into all the



<P>sensations of curiosity, wonder and regret, pain and pleasure,



<P>as to this fortunate Miss Hawkins, which could conduce to place



<P>the Martins under proper subordination in her fancy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma learned to be rather glad that there had been such a meeting.



<P>It had been serviceable in deadening the first shock, without retaining



<P>any influence to alarm.&nbsp; As Harriet now lived, the Martins could



<P>not get at her, without seeking her, where hitherto they had wanted



<P>either the courage or the condescension to seek her; for since her



<P>refusal of the brother, the sisters never had been at Mrs. Goddard's;



<P>and a twelvemonth might pass without their being thrown together again,



<P>with any necessity, or even any power of speech.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;

   <TITLE>Chapter 17</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XVII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>When the ladies returned to the drawing-room after dinner, Emma found



<P>it hardly possible to prevent their making two distinct parties;--



<P>with so much perseverance in judging and behaving ill did Mrs. Elton



<P>engross Jane Fairfax and slight herself.&nbsp; She and Mrs. Weston were



<P>obliged to be almost always either talking together or silent together.



<P>Mrs. Elton left them no choice.&nbsp; If Jane repressed her for a



<P>little time, she soon began again; and though much that passed



<P>between them was in a half-whisper, especially on Mrs. Elton's side,



<P>there was no avoiding a knowledge of their principal subjects:



<P>The post-office--catching cold--fetching letters--and friendship,



<P>were long under discussion; and to them succeeded one, which must



<P>be at least equally unpleasant to Jane--inquiries whether she had



<P>yet heard of any situation likely to suit her, and professions of



<P>Mrs. Elton's meditated activity.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Here is April come!" said she, "I get quite anxious about you.



<P>June will soon be here."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But I have never fixed on June or any other month--merely looked



<P>forward to the summer in general."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But have you really heard of nothing?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have not even made any inquiry; I do not wish to make any yet."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! my dear, we cannot begin too early; you are not aware



<P>of the difficulty of procuring exactly the desirable thing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I not aware!" said Jane, shaking her head; "dear Mrs. Elton,



<P>who can have thought of it as I have done?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But you have not seen so much of the world as I have.&nbsp; You do

not



<P>know how many candidates there always are for the first situations.



<P>I saw a vast deal of that in the neighbourhood round Maple Grove.



<P>A cousin of Mr. Suckling, Mrs. Bragge, had such an infinity



<P>of applications; every body was anxious to be in her family,



<P>for she moves in the first circle.&nbsp; Wax-candles in the schoolroom!



<P>You may imagine how desirable!&nbsp; Of all houses in the kingdom



<P>Mrs. Bragge's is the one I would most wish to see you in."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Colonel and Mrs. Campbell are to be in town again by midsummer,"



<P>said Jane.&nbsp; "I must spend some time with them; I am sure they will



<P>want it;--afterwards I may probably be glad to dispose of myself.



<P>But I would not wish you to take the trouble of making any inquiries



<P>at present."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Trouble! aye, I know your scruples.&nbsp; You are afraid of giving



<P>me trouble; but I assure you, my dear Jane, the Campbells can



<P>hardly be more interested about you than I am.&nbsp; I shall write



<P>to Mrs. Partridge in a day or two, and shall give her a strict



<P>charge to be on the look-out for any thing eligible."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thank you, but I would rather you did not mention the subject



<P>to her; till the time draws nearer, I do not wish to be giving



<P>any body trouble."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But, my dear child, the time is drawing near; here is April,



<P>and June, or say even July, is very near, with such business



<P>to accomplish before us.&nbsp; Your inexperience really amuses me!



<P>A situation such as you deserve, and your friends would require for

you,



<P>is no everyday occurrence, is not obtained at a moment's notice;



<P>indeed, indeed, we must begin inquiring directly."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Excuse me, ma'am, but this is by no means my intention; I make no



<P>inquiry myself, and should be sorry to have any made by my friends.



<P>When I am quite determined as to the time, I am not at all afraid



<P>of being long unemployed.&nbsp; There are places in town, offices,



<P>where inquiry would soon produce something--Offices for the sale--



<P>not quite of human flesh--but of human intellect."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! my dear, human flesh!&nbsp; You quite shock me; if you mean a fling



<P>at the slave-trade, I assure you Mr. Suckling was always rather



<P>a friend to the abolition."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I did not mean, I was not thinking of the slave-trade," replied Jane;



<P>"governess-trade, I assure you, was all that I had in view;



<P>widely different certainly as to the guilt of those who carry it on;



<P>but as to the greater misery of the victims, I do not know where



<P>it lies.&nbsp; But I only mean to say that there are advertising offices,



<P>and that by applying to them I should have no doubt of very soon



<P>meeting with something that would do."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Something that would do!" repeated Mrs. Elton.&nbsp; "Aye, that may



<P>suit your humble ideas of yourself;--I know what a modest creature



<P>you are; but it will not satisfy your friends to have you taking up



<P>with any thing that may offer, any inferior, commonplace situation,



<P>in a family not moving in a certain circle, or able to command



<P>the elegancies of life."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are very obliging; but as to all that, I am very indifferent;



<P>it would be no object to me to be with the rich; my mortifications,



<P>I think, would only be the greater; I should suffer more from comparison.



<P>A gentleman's family is all that I should condition for."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I know you, I know you; you would take up with any thing; but I



<P>shall be a little more nice, and I am sure the good Campbells will



<P>be quite on my side; with your superior talents, you have a right



<P>to move in the first circle.&nbsp; Your musical knowledge alone would



<P>entitle you to name your own terms, have as many rooms as you like,



<P>and mix in the family as much as you chose;--that is--I do not know--



<P>if you knew the harp, you might do all that, I am very sure;



<P>but you sing as well as play;--yes, I really believe you might,



<P>even without the harp, stipulate for what you chose;--and you must



<P>and shall be delightfully, honourably and comfortably settled before



<P>the Campbells or I have any rest."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You may well class the delight, the honour, and the comfort



<P>of such a situation together," said Jane, "they are pretty sure



<P>to be equal; however, I am very serious in not wishing any thing



<P>to be attempted at present for me.&nbsp; I am exceedingly obliged to

you,



<P>Mrs. Elton, I am obliged to any body who feels for me, but I am



<P>quite serious in wishing nothing to be done till the summer.



<P>For two or three months longer I shall remain where I am, and as



<P>I am."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And I am quite serious too, I assure you," replied Mrs. Elton gaily,



<P>"in resolving to be always on the watch, and employing my friends



<P>to watch also, that nothing really unexceptionable may pass us."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In this style she ran on; never thoroughly stopped by any thing



<P>till Mr. Woodhouse came into the room; her vanity had then a change



<P>of object, and Emma heard her saying in the same half-whisper to Jane,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Here comes this dear old beau of mine, I protest!--Only think of his



<P>gallantry in coming away before the other men!--what a dear creature



<P>he is;--I assure you I like him excessively.&nbsp; I admire all that

quaint,



<P>old-fashioned politeness; it is much more to my taste than modern ease;



<P>modern ease often disgusts me.&nbsp; But this good old Mr. Woodhouse,



<P>I wish you had heard his gallant speeches to me at dinner.&nbsp; Oh!&nbsp;

I assure



<P>you I began to think my caro sposo would be absolutely jealous.



<P>I fancy I am rather a favourite; he took notice of my gown.



<P>How do you like it?--Selina's choice--handsome, I think, but I



<P>do not know whether it is not over-trimmed; I have the greatest



<P>dislike to the idea of being over-trimmed--quite a horror of finery.



<P>I must put on a few ornaments now, because it is expected of me.



<P>A bride, you know, must appear like a bride, but my natural taste



<P>is all for simplicity; a simple style of dress is so infinitely



<P>preferable to finery.&nbsp; But I am quite in the minority, I believe;



<P>few people seem to value simplicity of dress,--show and finery



<P>are every thing.&nbsp; I have some notion of putting such a trimming



<P>as this to my white and silver poplin.&nbsp; Do you think it will



<P>look well?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The whole party were but just reassembled in the drawing-room



<P>when Mr. Weston made his appearance among them.&nbsp; He had returned



<P>to a late dinner, and walked to Hartfield as soon as it was over.



<P>He had been too much expected by the best judges, for surprize--



<P>but there was great joy.&nbsp; Mr. Woodhouse was almost as glad to see



<P>him now, as he would have been sorry to see him before.&nbsp; John Knightley



<P>only was in mute astonishment.--That a man who might have spent



<P>his evening quietly at home after a day of business in London,



<P>should set off again, and walk half a mile to another man's house,



<P>for the sake of being in mixed company till bed-time, of finishing



<P>his day in the efforts of civility and the noise of numbers,



<P>was a circumstance to strike him deeply.&nbsp; A man who had been in

motion



<P>since eight o'clock in the morning, and might now have been still,



<P>who had been long talking, and might have been silent, who had been



<P>in more than one crowd, and might have been alone!--Such a man,



<P>to quit the tranquillity and independence of his own fireside,



<P>and on the evening of a cold sleety April day rush out again into



<P>the world!--Could he by a touch of his finger have instantly taken



<P>back his wife, there would have been a motive; but his coming would



<P>probably prolong rather than break up the party.&nbsp; John Knightley



<P>looked at him with amazement, then shrugged his shoulders, and said,



<P>"I could not have believed it even of him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Weston meanwhile, perfectly unsuspicious of the indignation



<P>he was exciting, happy and cheerful as usual, and with all



<P>the right of being principal talker, which a day spent anywhere



<P>from home confers, was making himself agreeable among the rest;



<P>and having satisfied the inquiries of his wife as to his dinner,



<P>convincing her that none of all her careful directions to the servants



<P>had been forgotten, and spread abroad what public news he had heard,



<P>was proceeding to a family communication, which, though principally



<P>addressed to Mrs. Weston, he had not the smallest doubt of being



<P>highly interesting to every body in the room.&nbsp; He gave her a letter,



<P>it was from Frank, and to herself; he had met with it in his way,



<P>and had taken the liberty of opening it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Read it, read it," said he, "it will give you pleasure;



<P>only a few lines--will not take you long; read it to Emma."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The two ladies looked over it together; and he sat smiling



<P>and talking to them the whole time, in a voice a little subdued,



<P>but very audible to every body.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, he is coming, you see; good news, I think.&nbsp; Well, what do



<P>you say to it?--I always told you he would be here again soon,



<P>did not I?--Anne, my dear, did not I always tell you so, and you would



<P>not believe me?--In town next week, you see--at the latest, I dare say;



<P>for she is as impatient as the black gentleman when any thing is



<P>to be done; most likely they will be there to-morrow or Saturday.



<P>As to her illness, all nothing of course.&nbsp; But it is an excellent



<P>thing to have Frank among us again, so near as town.&nbsp; They will

stay



<P>a good while when they do come, and he will be half his time with us.



<P>This is precisely what I wanted.&nbsp; Well, pretty good news, is not

it?



<P>Have you finished it?&nbsp; Has Emma read it all?&nbsp; Put it up, put

it up;



<P>we will have a good talk about it some other time, but it will not



<P>do now.&nbsp; I shall only just mention the circumstance to the others

in a



<P>common way."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Weston was most comfortably pleased on the occasion.



<P>Her looks and words had nothing to restrain them.&nbsp; She was happy,



<P>she knew she was happy, and knew she ought to be happy.



<P>Her congratulations were warm and open; but Emma could not speak



<P>so fluently.&nbsp; She was a little occupied in weighing her own feelings,



<P>and trying to understand the degree of her agitation, which she



<P>rather thought was considerable.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Weston, however, too eager to be very observant, too communicative



<P>to want others to talk, was very well satisfied with what she did say,



<P>and soon moved away to make the rest of his friends happy by a partial



<P>communication of what the whole room must have overheard already.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was well that he took every body's joy for granted, or he



<P>might not have thought either Mr. Woodhouse or Mr. Knightley



<P>particularly delighted.&nbsp; They were the first entitled,



<P>after Mrs. Weston and Emma, to be made happy;--from them he would



<P>have proceeded to Miss Fairfax, but she was so deep in conversation



<P>with John Knightley, that it would have been too positive



<P>an interruption; and finding himself close to Mrs. Elton, and



<P>her attention disengaged, he necessarily began on the subject with her.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
