<BODY>

<B><FONT SIZE=+1>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <U>VOLUME II</U></FONT></B>

<BR>&nbsp;



<P><B>CHAPTER I</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Emma and Harriet had been walking together one morning, and,



<P>in Emma's opinion, had been talking enough of Mr. Elton for that day.



<P>She could not think that Harriet's solace or her own sins required more;



<P>and she was therefore industriously getting rid of the subject



<P>as they returned;--but it burst out again when she thought she



<P>had succeeded, and after speaking some time of what the poor must



<P>suffer in winter, and receiving no other answer than a very plaintive--



<P>"Mr. Elton is so good to the poor!" she found something else must be

done.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They were just approaching the house where lived Mrs. and Miss Bates.



<P>She determined to call upon them and seek safety in numbers.



<P>There was always sufficient reason for such an attention; Mrs. and



<P>Miss Bates loved to be called on, and she knew she was considered



<P>by the very few who presumed ever to see imperfection in her,



<P>as rather negligent in that respect, and as not contributing what she



<P>ought to the stock of their scanty comforts.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She had had many a hint from Mr. Knightley and some from her own heart,



<P>as to her deficiency--but none were equal to counteract the persuasion



<P>of its being very disagreeable,--a waste of time--tiresome women--



<P>and all the horror of being in danger of falling in with the second-rate



<P>and third-rate of Highbury, who were calling on them for ever,



<P>and therefore she seldom went near them.&nbsp; But now she made the

sudden



<P>resolution of not passing their door without going in--observing,



<P>as she proposed it to Harriet, that, as well as she could calculate,



<P>they were just now quite safe from any letter from Jane Fairfax.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The house belonged to people in business.&nbsp; Mrs. and Miss Bates

occupied



<P>the drawing-room floor; and there, in the very moderate-sized apartment,



<P>which was every thing to them, the visitors were most cordially



<P>and even gratefully welcomed; the quiet neat old lady, who with her



<P>knitting was seated in the warmest corner, wanting even to give up



<P>her place to Miss Woodhouse, and her more active, talking daughter,



<P>almost ready to overpower them with care and kindness, thanks for



<P>their visit, solicitude for their shoes, anxious inquiries after



<P>Mr. Woodhouse's health, cheerful communications about her mother's,



<P>and sweet-cake from the beaufet--"Mrs. Cole had just been there,



<P>just called in for ten minutes, and had been so good as to sit an



<P>hour with them, and she had taken a piece of cake and been so kind



<P>as to say she liked it very much; and, therefore, she hoped Miss



<P>Woodhouse and Miss Smith would do them the favour to eat a piece too."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The mention of the Coles was sure to be followed by that of Mr. Elton.



<P>There was intimacy between them, and Mr. Cole had heard from



<P>Mr. Elton since his going away.&nbsp; Emma knew what was coming; they

must



<P>have the letter over again, and settle how long he had been gone,



<P>and how much he was engaged in company, and what a favourite he



<P>was wherever he went, and how full the Master of the Ceremonies'



<P>ball had been; and she went through it very well, with all the



<P>interest and all the commendation that could be requisite, and always



<P>putting forward to prevent Harriet's being obliged to say a word.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This she had been prepared for when she entered the house;



<P>but meant, having once talked him handsomely over, to be no farther



<P>incommoded by any troublesome topic, and to wander at large amongst



<P>all the Mistresses and Misses of Highbury, and their card-parties.



<P>She had not been prepared to have Jane Fairfax succeed Mr. Elton;



<P>but he was actually hurried off by Miss Bates, she jumped away



<P>from him at last abruptly to the Coles, to usher in a letter from



<P>her niece.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! yes--Mr. Elton, I understand--certainly as to dancing--



<P>Mrs. Cole was telling me that dancing at the rooms at Bath was--



<P>Mrs. Cole was so kind as to sit some time with us, talking of Jane;



<P>for as soon as she came in, she began inquiring after her,



<P>Jane is so very great a favourite there.&nbsp; Whenever she is with

us,



<P>Mrs. Cole does not know how to shew her kindness enough;



<P>and I must say that Jane deserves it as much as any body can.



<P>And so she began inquiring after her directly, saying, `I know you



<P>cannot have heard from Jane lately, because it is not her time



<P>for writing;' and when I immediately said, `But indeed we have,



<P>we had a letter this very morning,' I do not know that I ever saw



<P>any body more surprized.&nbsp; `Have you, upon your honour?' said she;



<P>`well, that is quite unexpected.&nbsp; Do let me hear what she says.'"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma's politeness was at hand directly, to say, with smiling interest--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Have you heard from Miss Fairfax so lately?&nbsp; I am extremely happy.



<P>I hope she is well?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thank you.&nbsp; You are so kind!" replied the happily deceived aunt,



<P>while eagerly hunting for the letter.--"Oh! here it is.&nbsp; I was

sure



<P>it could not be far off; but I had put my huswife upon it, you see,



<P>without being aware, and so it was quite hid, but I had it in my hand



<P>so very lately that I was almost sure it must be on the table.



<P>I was reading it to Mrs. Cole, and since she went away, I was



<P>reading it again to my mother, for it is such a pleasure to her--



<P>a letter from Jane--that she can never hear it often enough;



<P>so I knew it could not be far off, and here it is, only just under



<P>my huswife--and since you are so kind as to wish to hear what



<P>she says;--but, first of all, I really must, in justice to Jane,



<P>apologise for her writing so short a letter--only two pages you see--



<P>hardly two--and in general she fills the whole paper and crosses half.



<P>My mother often wonders that I can make it out so well.



<P>She often says, when the letter is first opened, `Well, Hetty,



<P>now I think you will be put to it to make out all that checker-work'--



<P>don't you, ma'am?--And then I tell her, I am sure she would contrive



<P>to make it out herself, if she had nobody to do it for her--



<P>every word of it--I am sure she would pore over it till she had



<P>made out every word.&nbsp; And, indeed, though my mother's eyes are

not



<P>so good as they were, she can see amazingly well still, thank God!



<P>with the help of spectacles.&nbsp; It is such a blessing!&nbsp; My mother's



<P>are really very good indeed.&nbsp; Jane often says, when she is here,



<P>`I am sure, grandmama, you must have had very strong eyes to see



<P>as you do--and so much fine work as you have done too!--I only wish



<P>my eyes may last me as well.'"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>All this spoken extremely fast obliged Miss Bates to stop for breath;



<P>and Emma said something very civil about the excellence of Miss



<P>Fairfax's handwriting.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are extremely kind," replied Miss Bates, highly gratified;



<P>"you who are such a judge, and write so beautifully yourself.



<P>I am sure there is nobody's praise that could give us so much pleasure



<P>as Miss Woodhouse's. My mother does not hear; she is a little deaf



<P>you know.&nbsp; Ma'am," addressing her, "do you hear what Miss Woodhouse



<P>is so obliging to say about Jane's handwriting?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>And Emma had the advantage of hearing her own silly compliment



<P>repeated twice over before the good old lady could comprehend it.



<P>She was pondering, in the meanwhile, upon the possibility, without seeming



<P>very rude, of making her escape from Jane Fairfax's letter, and had



<P>almost resolved on hurrying away directly under some slight excuse,



<P>when Miss Bates turned to her again and seized her attention.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My mother's deafness is very trifling you see--just nothing at all.



<P>By only raising my voice, and saying any thing two or three times over,



<P>she is sure to hear; but then she is used to my voice.&nbsp; But it

is very



<P>remarkable that she should always hear Jane better than she does me.



<P>Jane speaks so distinct!&nbsp; However, she will not find her grandmama



<P>at all deafer than she was two years ago; which is saying a great



<P>deal at my mother's time of life--and it really is full two years,



<P>you know, since she was here.&nbsp; We never were so long without seeing



<P>her before, and as I was telling Mrs. Cole, we shall hardly know



<P>how to make enough of her now."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Are you expecting Miss Fairfax here soon?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh yes; next week."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Indeed!--that must be a very great pleasure."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thank you.&nbsp; You are very kind.&nbsp; Yes, next week.&nbsp; Every

body is



<P>so surprized; and every body says the same obliging things.&nbsp; I

am



<P>sure she will be as happy to see her friends at Highbury, as they



<P>can be to see her.&nbsp; Yes, Friday or Saturday; she cannot say which,



<P>because Colonel Campbell will be wanting the carriage himself one



<P>of those days.&nbsp; So very good of them to send her the whole way!



<P>But they always do, you know.&nbsp; Oh yes, Friday or Saturday next.



<P>That is what she writes about.&nbsp; That is the reason of her writing

out



<P>of rule, as we call it; for, in the common course, we should not have



<P>heard from her before next Tuesday or Wednesday."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, so I imagined.&nbsp; I was afraid there could be little chance



<P>of my hearing any thing of Miss Fairfax to-day."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So obliging of you!&nbsp; No, we should not have heard, if it had not



<P>been for this particular circumstance, of her being to come here



<P>so soon.&nbsp; My mother is so delighted!--for she is to be three months



<P>with us at least.&nbsp; Three months, she says so, positively, as I



<P>am going to have the pleasure of reading to you.&nbsp; The case is,



<P>you see, that the Campbells are going to Ireland.&nbsp; Mrs. Dixon has



<P>persuaded her father and mother to come over and see her directly.



<P>They had not intended to go over till the summer, but she is so



<P>impatient to see them again--for till she married, last October,



<P>she was never away from them so much as a week, which must make



<P>it very strange to be in different kingdoms, I was going to say,



<P>but however different countries, and so she wrote a very urgent letter



<P>to her mother--or her father, I declare I do not know which it was,



<P>but we shall see presently in Jane's letter--wrote in Mr. Dixon's



<P>name as well as her own, to press their coming over directly,



<P>and they would give them the meeting in Dublin, and take them back



<P>to their country seat, Baly-craig, a beautiful place, I fancy.



<P>Jane has heard a great deal of its beauty; from Mr. Dixon, I mean--



<P>I do not know that she ever heard about it from any body else;



<P>but it was very natural, you know, that he should like to speak



<P>of his own place while he was paying his addresses--and as Jane used



<P>to be very often walking out with them--for Colonel and Mrs. Campbell



<P>were very particular about their daughter's not walking out



<P>often with only Mr. Dixon, for which I do not at all blame them;



<P>of course she heard every thing he might be telling Miss Campbell



<P>about his own home in Ireland; and I think she wrote us word



<P>that he had shewn them some drawings of the place, views that he



<P>had taken himself.&nbsp; He is a most amiable, charming young man,



<P>I believe.&nbsp; Jane was quite longing to go to Ireland, from his account



<P>of things."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>At this moment, an ingenious and animating suspicion entering



<P>Emma's brain with regard to Jane Fairfax, this charming Mr. Dixon,



<P>and the not going to Ireland, she said, with the insidious design



<P>of farther discovery,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You must feel it very fortunate that Miss Fairfax should be allowed



<P>to come to you at such a time.&nbsp; Considering the very particular



<P>friendship between her and Mrs. Dixon, you could hardly have expected



<P>her to be excused from accompanying Colonel and Mrs. Campbell."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very true, very true, indeed.&nbsp; The very thing that we have always



<P>been rather afraid of; for we should not have liked to have her



<P>at such a distance from us, for months together--not able to come



<P>if any thing was to happen.&nbsp; But you see, every thing turns out



<P>for the best.&nbsp; They want her (Mr. and Mrs. Dixon) excessively to



<P>come over with Colonel and Mrs. Campbell; quite depend upon it;



<P>nothing can be more kind or pressing than their joint invitation,



<P>Jane says, as you will hear presently; Mr. Dixon does not seem in the



<P>least backward in any attention.&nbsp; He is a most charming young man.



<P>Ever since the service he rendered Jane at Weymouth, when they were



<P>out in that party on the water, and she, by the sudden whirling



<P>round of something or other among the sails, would have been dashed



<P>into the sea at once, and actually was all but gone, if he had not,



<P>with the greatest presence of mind, caught hold of her habit--



<P>(I can never think of it without trembling!)--But ever since we



<P>had the history of that day, I have been so fond of Mr. Dixon!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But, in spite of all her friends' urgency, and her own wish



<P>of seeing Ireland, Miss Fairfax prefers devoting the time to you



<P>and Mrs. Bates?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes--entirely her own doing, entirely her own choice; and Colonel



<P>and Mrs. Campbell think she does quite right, just what they



<P>should recommend; and indeed they particularly wish her to try



<P>her native air, as she has not been quite so well as usual lately."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am concerned to hear of it.&nbsp; I think they judge wisely.



<P>But Mrs. Dixon must be very much disappointed.&nbsp; Mrs. Dixon,



<P>I understand, has no remarkable degree of personal beauty; is not,



<P>by any means, to be compared with Miss Fairfax."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! no.&nbsp; You are very obliging to say such things--but certainly

not.



<P>There is no comparison between them.&nbsp; Miss Campbell always was



<P>absolutely plain--but extremely elegant and amiable."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, that of course."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Jane caught a bad cold, poor thing! so long ago as the 7th



<P>of November, (as I am going to read to you,) and has never been



<P>well since.&nbsp; A long time, is not it, for a cold to hang upon her?



<P>She never mentioned it before, because she would not alarm us.



<P>Just like her! so considerate!--But however, she is so far from well,



<P>that her kind friends the Campbells think she had better come home,



<P>and try an air that always agrees with her; and they have no doubt



<P>that three or four months at Highbury will entirely cure her--



<P>and it is certainly a great deal better that she should come here,



<P>than go to Ireland, if she is unwell. Nobody could nurse her, as we



<P>should do."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It appears to me the most desirable arrangement in the world."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And so she is to come to us next Friday or Saturday, and the



<P>Campbells leave town in their way to Holyhead the Monday following--



<P>as you will find from Jane's letter.&nbsp; So sudden!--You may guess,



<P>dear Miss Woodhouse, what a flurry it has thrown me in!



<P>If it was not for the drawback of her illness--but I am afraid



<P>we must expect to see her grown thin, and looking very poorly.



<P>I must tell you what an unlucky thing happened to me, as to that.



<P>I always make a point of reading Jane's letters through to myself first,



<P>before I read them aloud to my mother, you know, for fear of there



<P>being any thing in them to distress her.&nbsp; Jane desired me to do

it,



<P>so I always do:&nbsp; and so I began to-day with my usual caution;



<P>but no sooner did I come to the mention of her being unwell, than I



<P>burst out, quite frightened, with `Bless me! poor Jane is ill!'--



<P>which my mother, being on the watch, heard distinctly, and was sadly



<P>alarmed at.&nbsp; However, when I read on, I found it was not near so

bad



<P>as I had fancied at first; and I make so light of it now to her,



<P>that she does not think much about it.&nbsp; But I cannot imagine



<P>how I could be so off my guard.&nbsp; If Jane does not get well soon,



<P>we will call in Mr. Perry.&nbsp; The expense shall not be thought of;



<P>and though he is so liberal, and so fond of Jane that I dare say



<P>he would not mean to charge any thing for attendance, we could not



<P>suffer it to be so, you know.&nbsp; He has a wife and family to maintain,



<P>and is not to be giving away his time.&nbsp; Well, now I have just given

you



<P>a hint of what Jane writes about, we will turn to her letter, and I

am



<P>sure she tells her own story a great deal better than I can tell it



<P>for her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am afraid we must be running away," said Emma, glancing at Harriet,



<P>and beginning to rise--"My father will be expecting us.



<P>I had no intention, I thought I had no power of staying more than



<P>five minutes, when I first entered the house.&nbsp; I merely called,



<P>because I would not pass the door without inquiring after Mrs. Bates;



<P>but I have been so pleasantly detained!&nbsp; Now, however, we must

wish



<P>you and Mrs. Bates good morning."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>And not all that could be urged to detain her succeeded.



<P>She regained the street--happy in this, that though much had been



<P>forced on her against her will, though she had in fact heard



<P>the whole substance of Jane Fairfax's letter, she had been able



<P>to escape the letter itself.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 15</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XV</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Emma was not required, by any subsequent discovery, to retract her ill



<P>opinion of Mrs. Elton.&nbsp; Her observation had been pretty correct.



<P>Such as Mrs. Elton appeared to her on this second interview,



<P>such she appeared whenever they met again,--self-important, presuming,



<P>familiar, ignorant, and ill-bred. She had a little beauty and a



<P>little accomplishment, but so little judgment that she thought herself



<P>coming with superior knowledge of the world, to enliven and improve



<P>a country neighbourhood; and conceived Miss Hawkins to have held



<P>such a place in society as Mrs. Elton's consequence only could surpass.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was no reason to suppose Mr. Elton thought at all differently



<P>from his wife.&nbsp; He seemed not merely happy with her, but proud.



<P>He had the air of congratulating himself on having brought such



<P>a woman to Highbury, as not even Miss Woodhouse could equal;



<P>and the greater part of her new acquaintance, disposed to commend,



<P>or not in the habit of judging, following the lead of Miss Bates's



<P>good-will, or taking it for granted that the bride must be as clever



<P>and as agreeable as she professed herself, were very well satisfied;



<P>so that Mrs. Elton's praise passed from one mouth to another as it



<P>ought to do, unimpeded by Miss Woodhouse, who readily continued her



<P>first contribution and talked with a good grace of her being "very



<P>pleasant and very elegantly dressed."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In one respect Mrs. Elton grew even worse than she had appeared



<P>at first.&nbsp; Her feelings altered towards Emma.--Offended, probably,



<P>by the little encouragement which her proposals of intimacy met with,



<P>she drew back in her turn and gradually became much more cold



<P>and distant; and though the effect was agreeable, the ill-will



<P>which produced it was necessarily increasing Emma's dislike.



<P>Her manners, too--and Mr. Elton's, were unpleasant towards Harriet.



<P>They were sneering and negligent.&nbsp; Emma hoped it must rapidly work



<P>Harriet's cure; but the sensations which could prompt such behaviour



<P>sunk them both very much.--It was not to be doubted that poor



<P>Harriet's attachment had been an offering to conjugal unreserve,



<P>and her own share in the story, under a colouring the least favourable



<P>to her and the most soothing to him, had in all likelihood been



<P>given also.&nbsp; She was, of course, the object of their joint dislike.--



<P>When they had nothing else to say, it must be always easy to begin



<P>abusing Miss Woodhouse; and the enmity which they dared not shew



<P>in open disrespect to her, found a broader vent in contemptuous



<P>treatment of Harriet.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Elton took a great fancy to Jane Fairfax; and from the first.



<P>Not merely when a state of warfare with one young lady might be



<P>supposed to recommend the other, but from the very first; and she



<P>was not satisfied with expressing a natural and reasonable admiration--



<P>but without solicitation, or plea, or privilege, she must be wanting



<P>to assist and befriend her.--Before Emma had forfeited her confidence,



<P>and about the third time of their meeting, she heard all Mrs. Elton's



<P>knight-errantry on the subject.--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Jane Fairfax is absolutely charming, Miss Woodhouse.--I quite



<P>rave about Jane Fairfax.--A sweet, interesting creature.&nbsp; So mild



<P>and ladylike--and with such talents!--I assure you I think she



<P>has very extraordinary talents.&nbsp; I do not scruple to say that she



<P>plays extremely well.&nbsp; I know enough of music to speak decidedly



<P>on that point.&nbsp; Oh! she is absolutely charming!&nbsp; You will

laugh at



<P>my warmth--but, upon my word, I talk of nothing but Jane Fairfax.--



<P>And her situation is so calculated to affect one!--Miss Woodhouse,



<P>we must exert ourselves and endeavour to do something for her.



<P>We must bring her forward.&nbsp; Such talent as hers must not be suffered



<P>to remain unknown.--I dare say you have heard those charming lines of



<P>the poet,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; `Full many a flower is born

to blush unseen,



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; `And waste its

fragrance on the desert air.'

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>We must not allow them to be verified in sweet Jane Fairfax."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I cannot think there is any danger of it," was Emma's calm answer--



<P>"and when you are better acquainted with Miss Fairfax's situation



<P>and understand what her home has been, with Colonel and Mrs. Campbell,



<P>I have no idea that you will suppose her talents can be unknown."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! but dear Miss Woodhouse, she is now in such retirement,



<P>such obscurity, so thrown away.--Whatever advantages she may have



<P>enjoyed with the Campbells are so palpably at an end!&nbsp; And I think



<P>she feels it.&nbsp; I am sure she does.&nbsp; She is very timid and

silent.



<P>One can see that she feels the want of encouragement.&nbsp; I like her



<P>the better for it.&nbsp; I must confess it is a recommendation to me.



<P>I am a great advocate for timidity--and I am sure one does



<P>not often meet with it.--But in those who are at all inferior,



<P>it is extremely prepossessing.&nbsp; Oh!&nbsp; I assure you, Jane Fairfax



<P>is a very delightful character, and interests me more than I



<P>can express."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You appear to feel a great deal--but I am not aware how you or any



<P>of Miss Fairfax's acquaintance here, any of those who have known



<P>her longer than yourself, can shew her any other attention than"--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear Miss Woodhouse, a vast deal may be done by those who dare



<P>to act.&nbsp; You and I need not be afraid.&nbsp; If we set the example,



<P>many will follow it as far as they can; though all have not



<P>our situations.&nbsp; We have carriages to fetch and convey her home,



<P>and we live in a style which could not make the addition of



<P>Jane Fairfax, at any time, the least inconvenient.--I should be



<P>extremely displeased if Wright were to send us up such a dinner,



<P>as could make me regret having asked more than Jane Fairfax



<P>to partake of it.&nbsp; I have no idea of that sort of thing.&nbsp;

It is



<P>not likely that I should, considering what I have been used to.



<P>My greatest danger, perhaps, in housekeeping, may be quite the



<P>other way, in doing too much, and being too careless of expense.



<P>Maple Grove will probably be my model more than it ought to be--



<P>for we do not at all affect to equal my brother, Mr. Suckling,



<P>in income.--However, my resolution is taken as to noticing Jane Fairfax.--



<P>I shall certainly have her very often at my house, shall introduce



<P>her wherever I can, shall have musical parties to draw out her talents,



<P>and shall be constantly on the watch for an eligible situation.



<P>My acquaintance is so very extensive, that I have little doubt



<P>of hearing of something to suit her shortly.--I shall introduce her,



<P>of course, very particularly to my brother and sister when they come



<P>to us.&nbsp; I am sure they will like her extremely; and when she gets



<P>a little acquainted with them, her fears will completely wear off,



<P>for there really is nothing in the manners of either but what is



<P>highly conciliating.--I shall have her very often indeed while they



<P>are with me, and I dare say we shall sometimes find a seat for her in



<P>the barouche-landau in some of our exploring parties."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Poor Jane Fairfax!"--thought Emma.--"You have not deserved this.



<P>You may have done wrong with regard to Mr. Dixon, but this is a



<P>punishment beyond what you can have merited!--The kindness and protection



<P>of Mrs. Elton!--`Jane Fairfax and Jane Fairfax.'&nbsp; Heavens!&nbsp;

Let me



<P>not suppose that she dares go about, Emma Woodhouse-ing me!--



<P>But upon my honour, there seems no limits to the licentiousness



<P>of that woman's tongue!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma had not to listen to such paradings again--to any so exclusively



<P>addressed to herself--so disgustingly decorated with a "dear Miss



<P>Woodhouse."&nbsp; The change on Mrs. Elton's side soon afterwards appeared,



<P>and she was left in peace--neither forced to be the very particular



<P>friend of Mrs. Elton, nor, under Mrs. Elton's guidance, the very



<P>active patroness of Jane Fairfax, and only sharing with others in a



<P>general way, in knowing what was felt, what was meditated, what was

done.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She looked on with some amusement.--Miss Bates's gratitude for



<P>Mrs. Elton's attentions to Jane was in the first style of guileless



<P>simplicity and warmth.&nbsp; She was quite one of her worthies--



<P>the most amiable, affable, delightful woman--just as accomplished



<P>and condescending as Mrs. Elton meant to be considered.



<P>Emma's only surprize was that Jane Fairfax should accept



<P>those attentions and tolerate Mrs. Elton as she seemed to do.



<P>She heard of her walking with the Eltons, sitting with the Eltons,



<P>spending a day with the Eltons!&nbsp; This was astonishing!--She could

not



<P>have believed it possible that the taste or the pride of Miss Fairfax



<P>could endure such society and friendship as the Vicarage had to offer.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She is a riddle, quite a riddle!" said she.--"To chuse to remain



<P>here month after month, under privations of every sort!&nbsp; And now



<P>to chuse the mortification of Mrs. Elton's notice and the penury



<P>of her conversation, rather than return to the superior companions



<P>who have always loved her with such real, generous affection."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jane had come to Highbury professedly for three months; the Campbells



<P>were gone to Ireland for three months; but now the Campbells



<P>had promised their daughter to stay at least till Midsummer,



<P>and fresh invitations had arrived for her to join them there.



<P>According to Miss Bates--it all came from her--Mrs. Dixon had



<P>written most pressingly.&nbsp; Would Jane but go, means were to be found,



<P>servants sent, friends contrived--no travelling difficulty allowed



<P>to exist; but still she had declined it!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She must have some motive, more powerful than appears, for refusing



<P>this invitation," was Emma's conclusion.&nbsp; "She must be under some



<P>sort of penance, inflicted either by the Campbells or herself.



<P>There is great fear, great caution, great resolution somewhere.--



<P>She is not to be with the Dixons.&nbsp; The decree is issued by somebody.



<P>But why must she consent to be with the Eltons?--Here is quite a



<P>separate puzzle."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Upon her speaking her wonder aloud on that part of the subject,



<P>before the few who knew her opinion of Mrs. Elton, Mrs. Weston



<P>ventured this apology for Jane.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We cannot suppose that she has any great enjoyment at the Vicarage,



<P>my dear Emma--but it is better than being always at home.



<P>Her aunt is a good creature, but, as a constant companion,



<P>must be very tiresome.&nbsp; We must consider what Miss Fairfax quits,



<P>before we condemn her taste for what she goes to."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are right, Mrs. Weston," said Mr. Knightley warmly, "Miss Fairfax



<P>is as capable as any of us of forming a just opinion of Mrs. Elton.



<P>Could she have chosen with whom to associate, she would not have



<P>chosen her.&nbsp; But (with a reproachful smile at Emma) she receives



<P>attentions from Mrs. Elton, which nobody else pays her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma felt that Mrs. Weston was giving her a momentary glance;



<P>and she was herself struck by his warmth.&nbsp; With a faint blush,



<P>she presently replied,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Such attentions as Mrs. Elton's, I should have imagined,



<P>would rather disgust than gratify Miss Fairfax.&nbsp; Mrs. Elton's



<P>invitations I should have imagined any thing but inviting."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I should not wonder," said Mrs. Weston, "if Miss Fairfax were to have



<P>been drawn on beyond her own inclination, by her aunt's eagerness



<P>in accepting Mrs. Elton's civilities for her.&nbsp; Poor Miss Bates

may



<P>very likely have committed her niece and hurried her into a greater



<P>appearance of intimacy than her own good sense would have dictated,



<P>in spite of the very natural wish of a little change."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Both felt rather anxious to hear him speak again; and after a few



<P>minutes silence, he said,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Another thing must be taken into consideration too--Mrs. Elton



<P>does not talk to Miss Fairfax as she speaks of her.&nbsp; We all know



<P>the difference between the pronouns he or she and thou, the plainest



<P>spoken amongst us; we all feel the influence of a something beyond



<P>common civility in our personal intercourse with each other--



<P>a something more early implanted.&nbsp; We cannot give any body the



<P>disagreeable hints that we may have been very full of the hour before.



<P>We feel things differently.&nbsp; And besides the operation of this,



<P>as a general principle, you may be sure that Miss Fairfax awes



<P>Mrs. Elton by her superiority both of mind and manner; and that,



<P>face to face, Mrs. Elton treats her with all the respect which she



<P>has a claim to.&nbsp; Such a woman as Jane Fairfax probably never fell



<P>in Mrs. Elton's way before--and no degree of vanity can prevent



<P>her acknowledging her own comparative littleness in action, if not



<P>in consciousness."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I know how highly you think of Jane Fairfax," said Emma.



<P>Little Henry was in her thoughts, and a mixture of alarm and delicacy



<P>made her irresolute what else to say.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes," he replied, "any body may know how highly I think of her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And yet," said Emma, beginning hastily and with an arch look,



<P>but soon stopping--it was better, however, to know the worst at once--



<P>she hurried on--"And yet, perhaps, you may hardly be aware yourself



<P>how highly it is.&nbsp; The extent of your admiration may take you by



<P>surprize some day or other."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Knightley was hard at work upon the lower buttons of his thick



<P>leather gaiters, and either the exertion of getting them together,



<P>or some other cause, brought the colour into his face, as he answered,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! are you there?--But you are miserably behindhand.&nbsp; Mr. Cole



<P>gave me a hint of it six weeks ago."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He stopped.--Emma felt her foot pressed by Mrs. Weston, and did



<P>not herself know what to think.&nbsp; In a moment he went on--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That will never be, however, I can assure you.&nbsp; Miss Fairfax,



<P>I dare say, would not have me if I were to ask her--and I am very



<P>sure I shall never ask her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma returned her friend's pressure with interest; and was pleased



<P>enough to exclaim,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are not vain, Mr. Knightley.&nbsp; I will say that for you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He seemed hardly to hear her; he was thoughtful--and in a manner



<P>which shewed him not pleased, soon afterwards said,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So you have been settling that I should marry Jane Fairfax?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No indeed I have not.&nbsp; You have scolded me too much for match-making,



<P>for me to presume to take such a liberty with you.&nbsp; What I said



<P>just now, meant nothing.&nbsp; One says those sort of things, of course,



<P>without any idea of a serious meaning.&nbsp; Oh! no, upon my word I

have not



<P>the smallest wish for your marrying Jane Fairfax or Jane any body.



<P>You would not come in and sit with us in this comfortable way,



<P>if you were married."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Knightley was thoughtful again.&nbsp; The result of his reverie

was,



<P>"No, Emma, I do not think the extent of my admiration for her will



<P>ever take me by surprize.--I never had a thought of her in that way,



<P>I assure you."&nbsp; And soon afterwards, "Jane Fairfax is a very charming



<P>young woman--but not even Jane Fairfax is perfect.&nbsp; She has a fault.



<P>She has not the open temper which a man would wish for in a wife."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma could not but rejoice to hear that she had a fault.



<P>"Well," said she, "and you soon silenced Mr. Cole, I suppose?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, very soon.&nbsp; He gave me a quiet hint; I told him he was mistaken;



<P>he asked my pardon and said no more.&nbsp; Cole does not want to be

wiser



<P>or wittier than his neighbours."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"In that respect how unlike dear Mrs. Elton, who wants to be wiser



<P>and wittier than all the world!&nbsp; I wonder how she speaks of the

Coles--



<P>what she calls them!&nbsp; How can she find any appellation for them,



<P>deep enough in familiar vulgarity?&nbsp; She calls you, Knightley--what

can



<P>she do for Mr. Cole?&nbsp; And so I am not to be surprized that Jane



<P>Fairfax accepts her civilities and consents to be with her.



<P>Mrs. Weston, your argument weighs most with me.&nbsp; I can much more



<P>readily enter into the temptation of getting away from Miss Bates,



<P>than I can believe in the triumph of Miss Fairfax's mind over



<P>Mrs. Elton.&nbsp; I have no faith in Mrs. Elton's acknowledging herself



<P>the inferior in thought, word, or deed; or in her being under any



<P>restraint beyond her own scanty rule of good-breeding. I cannot



<P>imagine that she will not be continually insulting her visitor



<P>with praise, encouragement, and offers of service; that she will not

be



<P>continually detailing her magnificent intentions, from the procuring



<P>her a permanent situation to the including her in those delightful



<P>exploring parties which are to take place in the barouche-landau."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Jane Fairfax has feeling," said Mr. Knightley--"I do not



<P>accuse her of want of feeling.&nbsp; Her sensibilities, I suspect,



<P>are strong--and her temper excellent in its power of forbearance,



<P>patience, self-controul; but it wants openness.&nbsp; She is reserved,



<P>more reserved, I think, than she used to be--And I love an



<P>open temper.&nbsp; No--till Cole alluded to my supposed attachment,



<P>it had never entered my head.&nbsp; I saw Jane Fairfax and conversed

with



<P>her, with admiration and pleasure always--but with no thought beyond."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, Mrs. Weston," said Emma triumphantly when he left them,



<P>"what do you say now to Mr. Knightley's marrying Jane Fairfax?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why, really, dear Emma, I say that he is so very much occupied



<P>by the idea of not being in love with her, that I should not wonder



<P>if it were to end in his being so at last.&nbsp; Do not beat me."



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 14</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XIV</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Mrs. Elton was first seen at church:&nbsp; but though devotion might



<P>be interrupted, curiosity could not be satisfied by a bride in a pew,



<P>and it must be left for the visits in form which were then to be paid,



<P>to settle whether she were very pretty indeed, or only rather pretty,



<P>or not pretty at all.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma had feelings, less of curiosity than of pride or propriety,



<P>to make her resolve on not being the last to pay her respects;



<P>and she made a point of Harriet's going with her, that the worst of



<P>the business might be gone through as soon as possible.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She could not enter the house again, could not be in the same room



<P>to which she had with such vain artifice retreated three months ago,



<P>to lace up her boot, without recollecting.&nbsp; A thousand vexatious



<P>thoughts would recur.&nbsp; Compliments, charades, and horrible blunders;



<P>and it was not to be supposed that poor Harriet should not be



<P>recollecting too; but she behaved very well, and was only rather



<P>pale and silent.&nbsp; The visit was of course short; and there was

so



<P>much embarrassment and occupation of mind to shorten it, that Emma



<P>would not allow herself entirely to form an opinion of the lady,



<P>and on no account to give one, beyond the nothing-meaning terms



<P>of being "elegantly dressed, and very pleasing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She did not really like her.&nbsp; She would not be in a hurry to find

fault,



<P>but she suspected that there was no elegance;--ease, but not elegance.--



<P>She was almost sure that for a young woman, a stranger, a bride,



<P>there was too much ease.&nbsp; Her person was rather good; her face



<P>not unpretty; but neither feature, nor air, nor voice, nor manner,



<P>were elegant.&nbsp; Emma thought at least it would turn out so.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As for Mr. Elton, his manners did not appear--but no, she would



<P>not permit a hasty or a witty word from herself about his manners.



<P>It was an awkward ceremony at any time to be receiving wedding visits,



<P>and a man had need be all grace to acquit himself well through it.



<P>The woman was better off; she might have the assistance of fine clothes,



<P>and the privilege of bashfulness, but the man had only his own



<P>good sense to depend on; and when she considered how peculiarly



<P>unlucky poor Mr. Elton was in being in the same room at once with



<P>the woman he had just married, the woman he had wanted to marry,



<P>and the woman whom he had been expected to marry, she must allow him



<P>to have the right to look as little wise, and to be as much affectedly,



<P>and as little really easy as could be.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, Miss Woodhouse," said Harriet, when they had quitted



<P>the house, and after waiting in vain for her friend to begin;



<P>"Well, Miss Woodhouse, (with a gentle sigh,) what do you think of her?--



<P>Is not she very charming?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was a little hesitation in Emma's answer.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! yes--very--a very pleasing young woman."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I think her beautiful, quite beautiful."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very nicely dressed, indeed; a remarkably elegant gown."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am not at all surprized that he should have fallen in love."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! no--there is nothing to surprize one at all.--A pretty fortune;



<P>and she came in his way."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I dare say," returned Harriet, sighing again, "I dare say she



<P>was very much attached to him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Perhaps she might; but it is not every man's fate to marry the



<P>woman who loves him best.&nbsp; Miss Hawkins perhaps wanted a home,



<P>and thought this the best offer she was likely to have."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes," said Harriet earnestly, "and well she might, nobody could ever



<P>have a better.&nbsp; Well, I wish them happy with all my heart.&nbsp;

And now,



<P>Miss Woodhouse, I do not think I shall mind seeing them again.



<P>He is just as superior as ever;--but being married, you know,



<P>it is quite a different thing.&nbsp; No, indeed, Miss Woodhouse, you

need



<P>not be afraid; I can sit and admire him now without any great misery.



<P>To know that he has not thrown himself away, is such a comfort!--



<P>She does seem a charming young woman, just what he deserves.



<P>Happy creature!&nbsp; He called her `Augusta.'&nbsp; How delightful!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When the visit was returned, Emma made up her mind.&nbsp; She could

then



<P>see more and judge better.&nbsp; From Harriet's happening not to be



<P>at Hartfield, and her father's being present to engage Mr. Elton,



<P>she had a quarter of an hour of the lady's conversation to herself,



<P>and could composedly attend to her; and the quarter of an hour quite



<P>convinced her that Mrs. Elton was a vain woman, extremely well



<P>satisfied with herself, and thinking much of her own importance;



<P>that she meant to shine and be very superior, but with manners which



<P>had been formed in a bad school, pert and familiar; that all her



<P>notions were drawn from one set of people, and one style of living;



<P>that if not foolish she was ignorant, and that her society would



<P>certainly do Mr. Elton no good.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet would have been a better match.&nbsp; If not wise or refined

herself,



<P>she would have connected him with those who were; but Miss Hawkins,



<P>it might be fairly supposed from her easy conceit, had been the best



<P>of her own set.&nbsp; The rich brother-in-law near Bristol was the pride



<P>of the alliance, and his place and his carriages were the pride



<P>of him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The very first subject after being seated was Maple Grove, "My brother



<P>Mr. Suckling's seat;"--a comparison of Hartfield to Maple Grove.



<P>The grounds of Hartfield were small, but neat and pretty; and the



<P>house was modern and well-built. Mrs. Elton seemed most favourably



<P>impressed by the size of the room, the entrance, and all that she



<P>could see or imagine.&nbsp; "Very like Maple Grove indeed!--She was

quite



<P>struck by the likeness!--That room was the very shape and size



<P>of the morning-room at Maple Grove; her sister's favourite room."--



<P>Mr. Elton was appealed to.--"Was not it astonishingly like?--



<P>She could really almost fancy herself at Maple Grove."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And the staircase--You know, as I came in, I observed how very like



<P>the staircase was; placed exactly in the same part of the house.



<P>I really could not help exclaiming!&nbsp; I assure you, Miss Woodhouse,



<P>it is very delightful to me, to be reminded of a place I am so



<P>extremely partial to as Maple Grove.&nbsp; I have spent so many happy



<P>months there! (with a little sigh of sentiment). A charming place,



<P>undoubtedly.&nbsp; Every body who sees it is struck by its beauty;



<P>but to me, it has been quite a home.&nbsp; Whenever you are transplanted,



<P>like me, Miss Woodhouse, you will understand how very delightful it



<P>is to meet with any thing at all like what one has left behind.



<P>I always say this is quite one of the evils of matrimony."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma made as slight a reply as she could; but it was fully sufficient



<P>for Mrs. Elton, who only wanted to be talking herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So extremely like Maple Grove!&nbsp; And it is not merely the house--



<P>the grounds, I assure you, as far as I could observe, are strikingly



<P>like.&nbsp; The laurels at Maple Grove are in the same profusion as

here,



<P>and stand very much in the same way--just across the lawn;



<P>and I had a glimpse of a fine large tree, with a bench round it,



<P>which put me so exactly in mind!&nbsp; My brother and sister will be



<P>enchanted with this place.&nbsp; People who have extensive grounds



<P>themselves are always pleased with any thing in the same style."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma doubted the truth of this sentiment.&nbsp; She had a great idea



<P>that people who had extensive grounds themselves cared very little



<P>for the extensive grounds of any body else; but it was not worth



<P>while to attack an error so double-dyed, and therefore only said



<P>in reply,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"When you have seen more of this country, I am afraid you will think



<P>you have overrated Hartfield.&nbsp; Surry is full of beauties."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! yes, I am quite aware of that.&nbsp; It is the garden of England,



<P>you know.&nbsp; Surry is the garden of England."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes; but we must not rest our claims on that distinction.



<P>Many counties, I believe, are called the garden of England,



<P>as well as Surry."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, I fancy not," replied Mrs. Elton, with a most satisfied smile."



<P>I never heard any county but Surry called so."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma was silenced.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My brother and sister have promised us a visit in the spring,



<P>or summer at farthest," continued Mrs. Elton; "and that will be



<P>our time for exploring.&nbsp; While they are with us, we shall explore



<P>a great deal, I dare say.&nbsp; They will have their barouche-landau,



<P>of course, which holds four perfectly; and therefore, without saying



<P>any thing of our carriage, we should be able to explore the different



<P>beauties extremely well.&nbsp; They would hardly come in their chaise,



<P>I think, at that season of the year.&nbsp; Indeed, when the time draws

on,



<P>I shall decidedly recommend their bringing the barouche-landau;



<P>it will be so very much preferable.&nbsp; When people come into a beautiful



<P>country of this sort, you know, Miss Woodhouse, one naturally wishes



<P>them to see as much as possible; and Mr. Suckling is extremely fond



<P>of exploring.&nbsp; We explored to King's-Weston twice last summer,



<P>in that way, most delightfully, just after their first having the



<P>barouche-landau.&nbsp; You have many parties of that kind here, I suppose,



<P>Miss Woodhouse, every summer?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No; not immediately here.&nbsp; We are rather out of distance of the

very



<P>striking beauties which attract the sort of parties you speak of;



<P>and we are a very quiet set of people, I believe; more disposed



<P>to stay at home than engage in schemes of pleasure."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah! there is nothing like staying at home for real comfort.



<P>Nobody can be more devoted to home than I am.&nbsp; I was quite



<P>a proverb for it at Maple Grove.&nbsp; Many a time has Selina said,



<P>when she has been going to Bristol, `I really cannot get this girl



<P>to move from the house.&nbsp; I absolutely must go in by myself, though

I



<P>hate being stuck up in the barouche-landau without a companion;



<P>but Augusta, I believe, with her own good-will, would never stir



<P>beyond the park paling.'&nbsp; Many a time has she said so; and yet

I



<P>am no advocate for entire seclusion.&nbsp; I think, on the contrary,



<P>when people shut themselves up entirely from society, it is a very



<P>bad thing; and that it is much more advisable to mix in the world in



<P>a proper degree, without living in it either too much or too little.



<P>I perfectly understand your situation, however, Miss Woodhouse--



<P>(looking towards Mr. Woodhouse), Your father's state of health must



<P>be a great drawback.&nbsp; Why does not he try Bath?--Indeed he should.



<P>Let me recommend Bath to you.&nbsp; I assure you I have no doubt of

its doing



<P>Mr. Woodhouse good."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My father tried it more than once, formerly; but without receiving



<P>any benefit; and Mr. Perry, whose name, I dare say, is not unknown



<P>to you, does not conceive it would be at all more likely to be



<P>useful now."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah! that's a great pity; for I assure you, Miss Woodhouse,



<P>where the waters do agree, it is quite wonderful the relief



<P>they give.&nbsp; In my Bath life, I have seen such instances of it!



<P>And it is so cheerful a place, that it could not fail of being of



<P>use to Mr. Woodhouse's spirits, which, I understand, are sometimes



<P>much depressed.&nbsp; And as to its recommendations to you, I fancy

I



<P>need not take much pains to dwell on them.&nbsp; The advantages of Bath



<P>to the young are pretty generally understood.&nbsp; It would be a charming



<P>introduction for you, who have lived so secluded a life; and I could



<P>immediately secure you some of the best society in the place.



<P>A line from me would bring you a little host of acquaintance; and my



<P>particular friend, Mrs. Partridge, the lady I have always resided



<P>with when in Bath, would be most happy to shew you any attentions,



<P>and would be the very person for you to go into public with."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was as much as Emma could bear, without being impolite.



<P>The idea of her being indebted to Mrs. Elton for what was called



<P>an introduction--of her going into public under the auspices



<P>of a friend of Mrs. Elton's--probably some vulgar, dashing widow,



<P>who, with the help of a boarder, just made a shift to live!--



<P>The dignity of Miss Woodhouse, of Hartfield, was sunk indeed!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She restrained herself, however, from any of the reproofs she could



<P>have given, and only thanked Mrs. Elton coolly; "but their going



<P>to Bath was quite out of the question; and she was not perfectly



<P>convinced that the place might suit her better than her father."



<P>And then, to prevent farther outrage and indignation, changed the



<P>subject directly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not ask whether you are musical, Mrs. Elton.&nbsp; Upon these

occasions,



<P>a lady's character generally precedes her; and Highbury has long



<P>known that you are a superior performer."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! no, indeed; I must protest against any such idea.



<P>A superior performer!--very far from it, I assure you.



<P>Consider from how partial a quarter your information came.



<P>I am doatingly fond of music--passionately fond;--and my friends



<P>say I am not entirely devoid of taste; but as to any thing else,



<P>upon my honour my performance is mediocre to the last degree.



<P>You, Miss Woodhouse, I well know, play delightfully.&nbsp; I assure

you



<P>it has been the greatest satisfaction, comfort, and delight to me,



<P>to hear what a musical society I am got into.&nbsp; I absolutely cannot



<P>do without music.&nbsp; It is a necessary of life to me; and having

always



<P>been used to a very musical society, both at Maple Grove and in Bath,



<P>it would have been a most serious sacrifice.&nbsp; I honestly said as

much



<P>to Mr. E. when he was speaking of my future home, and expressing



<P>his fears lest the retirement of it should be disagreeable;



<P>and the inferiority of the house too--knowing what I had been



<P>accustomed to--of course he was not wholly without apprehension.



<P>When he was speaking of it in that way, I honestly said that the



<P>world I could give up--parties, balls, plays--for I had no fear



<P>of retirement.&nbsp; Blessed with so many resources within myself,



<P>the world was not necessary to me.&nbsp; I could do very well without

it.



<P>To those who had no resources it was a different thing; but my



<P>resources made me quite independent.&nbsp; And as to smaller-sized rooms



<P>than I had been used to, I really could not give it a thought.



<P>I hoped I was perfectly equal to any sacrifice of that description.



<P>Certainly I had been accustomed to every luxury at Maple Grove; but

I



<P>did assure him that two carriages were not necessary to my happiness,



<P>nor were spacious apartments.&nbsp; `But,' said I, `to be quite honest,



<P>I do not think I can live without something of a musical society.



<P>I condition for nothing else; but without music, life would be a blank



<P>to me.'"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We cannot suppose," said Emma, smiling, "that Mr. Elton would hesitate



<P>to assure you of there being a very musical society in Highbury;



<P>and I hope you will not find he has outstepped the truth more than



<P>may be pardoned, in consideration of the motive."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, indeed, I have no doubts at all on that head.&nbsp; I am delighted



<P>to find myself in such a circle.&nbsp; I hope we shall have many sweet



<P>little concerts together.&nbsp; I think, Miss Woodhouse, you and I



<P>must establish a musical club, and have regular weekly meetings



<P>at your house, or ours.&nbsp; Will not it be a good plan?&nbsp; If we



<P>exert ourselves, I think we shall not be long in want of allies.



<P>Something of that nature would be particularly desirable for me,



<P>as an inducement to keep me in practice; for married women, you know--



<P>there is a sad story against them, in general.&nbsp; They are but too

apt



<P>to give up music."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But you, who are so extremely fond of it--there can



<P>be no danger, surely?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I should hope not; but really when I look around among my acquaintance,



<P>I tremble.&nbsp; Selina has entirely given up music--never touches



<P>the instrument--though she played sweetly.&nbsp; And the same may be

said



<P>of Mrs. Jeffereys--Clara Partridge, that was--and of the two Milmans,



<P>now Mrs. Bird and Mrs. James Cooper; and of more than I can enumerate.



<P>Upon my word it is enough to put one in a fright.&nbsp; I used to be



<P>quite angry with Selina; but really I begin now to comprehend



<P>that a married woman has many things to call her attention.



<P>I believe I was half an hour this morning shut up with my housekeeper."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But every thing of that kind," said Emma, "will soon



<P>be in so regular a train--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well," said Mrs. Elton, laughing, "we shall see."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma, finding her so determined upon neglecting her music,



<P>had nothing more to say; and, after a moment's pause, Mrs. Elton



<P>chose another subject.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We have been calling at Randalls," said she, "and found them



<P>both at home; and very pleasant people they seem to be.



<P>I like them extremely.&nbsp; Mr. Weston seems an excellent creature--



<P>quite a first-rate favourite with me already, I assure you.



<P>And she appears so truly good--there is something so motherly



<P>and kind-hearted about her, that it wins upon one directly.



<P>She was your governess, I think?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma was almost too much astonished to answer; but Mrs. Elton



<P>hardly waited for the affirmative before she went on.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Having understood as much, I was rather astonished to find her



<P>so very lady-like!&nbsp; But she is really quite the gentlewoman."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mrs. Weston's manners," said Emma, "were always particularly good.



<P>Their propriety, simplicity, and elegance, would make them the safest



<P>model for any young woman."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And who do you think came in while we were there?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma was quite at a loss.&nbsp; The tone implied some old acquaintance--



<P>and how could she possibly guess?

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Knightley!" continued Mrs. Elton; "Knightley himself!--Was not



<P>it lucky?--for, not being within when he called the other day,



<P>I had never seen him before; and of course, as so particular a



<P>friend of Mr. E.'s, I had a great curiosity.&nbsp; `My friend Knightley'



<P>had been so often mentioned, that I was really impatient to see him;



<P>and I must do my caro sposo the justice to say that he need not



<P>be ashamed of his friend.&nbsp; Knightley is quite the gentleman.



<P>I like him very much.&nbsp; Decidedly, I think, a very gentleman-like

man."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Happily, it was now time to be gone.&nbsp; They were off; and Emma



<P>could breathe.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Insufferable woman!" was her immediate exclamation.&nbsp; "Worse than

I



<P>had supposed.&nbsp; Absolutely insufferable!&nbsp; Knightley!--I could

not



<P>have believed it.&nbsp; Knightley!--never seen him in her life before,



<P>and call him Knightley!--and discover that he is a gentleman!



<P>A little upstart, vulgar being, with her Mr. E., and her caro sposo,



<P>and her resources, and all her airs of pert pretension and



<P>underbred finery.&nbsp; Actually to discover that Mr. Knightley is



<P>a gentleman!&nbsp; I doubt whether he will return the compliment,



<P>and discover her to be a lady.&nbsp; I could not have believed it!



<P>And to propose that she and I should unite to form a musical club!



<P>One would fancy we were bosom friends!&nbsp; And Mrs. Weston!--



<P>Astonished that the person who had brought me up should be



<P>a gentlewoman!&nbsp; Worse and worse.&nbsp; I never met with her equal.



<P>Much beyond my hopes.&nbsp; Harriet is disgraced by any comparison.



<P>Oh! what would Frank Churchill say to her, if he were here?



<P>How angry and how diverted he would be!&nbsp; Ah! there I am--



<P>thinking of him directly.&nbsp; Always the first person to be thought

of!



<P>How I catch myself out!&nbsp; Frank Churchill comes as regularly into



<P>my mind!"--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>All this ran so glibly through her thoughts, that by the time



<P>her father had arranged himself, after the bustle of the Eltons'



<P>departure, and was ready to speak, she was very tolerably capable



<P>of attending.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, my dear," he deliberately began, "considering we never saw



<P>her before, she seems a very pretty sort of young lady; and I dare say



<P>she was very much pleased with you.&nbsp; She speaks a little too quick.



<P>A little quickness of voice there is which rather hurts the ear.



<P>But I believe I am nice; I do not like strange voices; and nobody speaks



<P>like you and poor Miss Taylor.&nbsp; However, she seems a very obliging,



<P>pretty-behaved young lady, and no doubt will make him a very good wife.



<P>Though I think he had better not have married.&nbsp; I made the best



<P>excuses I could for not having been able to wait on him and Mrs. Elton



<P>on this happy occasion; I said that I hoped I should in the course



<P>of the summer.&nbsp; But I ought to have gone before.&nbsp; Not to wait

upon



<P>a bride is very remiss.&nbsp; Ah! it shews what a sad invalid I am!



<P>But I do not like the corner into Vicarage Lane."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I dare say your apologies were accepted, sir.&nbsp; Mr. Elton knows

you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes:&nbsp; but a young lady--a bride--I ought to have paid my respects



<P>to her if possible.&nbsp; It was being very deficient."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But, my dear papa, you are no friend to matrimony; and therefore



<P>why should you be so anxious to pay your respects to a bride?



<P>It ought to be no recommendation to you.&nbsp; It is encouraging people



<P>to marry if you make so much of them."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, my dear, I never encouraged any body to marry, but I would



<P>always wish to pay every proper attention to a lady--and a bride,



<P>especially, is never to be neglected.&nbsp; More is avowedly due to

her.



<P>A bride, you know, my dear, is always the first in company,



<P>let the others be who they may."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, papa, if this is not encouragement to marry, I do not know



<P>what is.&nbsp; And I should never have expected you to be lending your



<P>sanction to such vanity-baits for poor young ladies."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear, you do not understand me.&nbsp; This is a



<P>matter of mere common politeness and good-breeding,



<P>and has nothing to do with any encouragement to people to marry."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma had done.&nbsp; Her father was growing nervous, and could not



<P>understand her.&nbsp; Her mind returned to Mrs. Elton's offences,



<P>and long, very long, did they occupy her.



<P>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <TITLE>Chapter 04</TITLE>
