<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER IV</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Human nature is so well disposed towards those who are in



<P>interesting situations, that a young person, who either marries



<P>or dies, is sure of being kindly spoken of.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A week had not passed since Miss Hawkins's name was first



<P>mentioned in Highbury, before she was, by some means or other,



<P>discovered to have every recommendation of person and mind;



<P>to be handsome, elegant, highly accomplished, and perfectly amiable:



<P>and when Mr. Elton himself arrived to triumph in his happy prospects,



<P>and circulate the fame of her merits, there was very little more



<P>for him to do, than to tell her Christian name, and say whose



<P>music she principally played.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Elton returned, a very happy man.&nbsp; He had gone away rejected



<P>and mortified--disappointed in a very sanguine hope, after a series



<P>of what appeared to him strong encouragement; and not only losing



<P>the right lady, but finding himself debased to the level of a very



<P>wrong one.&nbsp; He had gone away deeply offended--he came back engaged



<P>to another--and to another as superior, of course, to the first,



<P>as under such circumstances what is gained always is to what is lost.



<P>He came back gay and self-satisfied, eager and busy, caring nothing



<P>for Miss Woodhouse, and defying Miss Smith.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The charming Augusta Hawkins, in addition to all the usual advantages



<P>of perfect beauty and merit, was in possession of an independent fortune,



<P>of so many thousands as would always be called ten; a point of



<P>some dignity, as well as some convenience:&nbsp; the story told well;



<P>he had not thrown himself away--he had gained a woman of 10,000 l.



<P>or thereabouts; and he had gained her with such delightful rapidity--



<P>the first hour of introduction had been so very soon followed by



<P>distinguishing notice; the history which he had to give Mrs. Cole



<P>of the rise and progress of the affair was so glorious--the steps



<P>so quick, from the accidental rencontre, to the dinner at Mr. Green's,



<P>and the party at Mrs. Brown's--smiles and blushes rising in importance--



<P>with consciousness and agitation richly scattered--the lady



<P>had been so easily impressed--so sweetly disposed--had in short,



<P>to use a most intelligible phrase, been so very ready to have him,



<P>that vanity and prudence were equally contented.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He had caught both substance and shadow--both fortune and affection,



<P>and was just the happy man he ought to be; talking only of himself



<P>and his own concerns--expecting to be congratulated--ready to be



<P>laughed at--and, with cordial, fearless smiles, now addressing



<P>all the young ladies of the place, to whom, a few weeks ago,



<P>he would have been more cautiously gallant.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The wedding was no distant event, as the parties had only themselves



<P>to please, and nothing but the necessary preparations to wait for;



<P>and when he set out for Bath again, there was a general expectation,



<P>which a certain glance of Mrs. Cole's did not seem to contradict,



<P>that when he next entered Highbury he would bring his bride.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>During his present short stay, Emma had barely seen him; but just



<P>enough to feel that the first meeting was over, and to give her



<P>the impression of his not being improved by the mixture of pique



<P>and pretension, now spread over his air.&nbsp; She was, in fact,



<P>beginning very much to wonder that she had ever thought him pleasing



<P>at all; and his sight was so inseparably connected with some very



<P>disagreeable feelings, that, except in a moral light, as a penance,



<P>a lesson, a source of profitable humiliation to her own mind,



<P>she would have been thankful to be assured of never seeing him again.



<P>She wished him very well; but he gave her pain, and his welfare



<P>twenty miles off would administer most satisfaction.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The pain of his continued residence in Highbury, however, must certainly



<P>be lessened by his marriage.&nbsp; Many vain solicitudes would be prevented--



<P>many awkwardnesses smoothed by it.&nbsp; A Mrs. Elton would be an excuse

for



<P>any change of intercourse; former intimacy might sink without remark.



<P>It would be almost beginning their life of civility again.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Of the lady, individually, Emma thought very little.&nbsp; She was good



<P>enough for Mr. Elton, no doubt; accomplished enough for Highbury--



<P>handsome enough--to look plain, probably, by Harriet's side.



<P>As to connexion, there Emma was perfectly easy; persuaded,



<P>that after all his own vaunted claims and disdain of Harriet,



<P>he had done nothing.&nbsp; On that article, truth seemed attainable.



<P>What she was, must be uncertain; but who she was, might be found out;



<P>and setting aside the 10,000 l., it did not appear that she was at



<P>all Harriet's superior.&nbsp; She brought no name, no blood, no alliance.



<P>Miss Hawkins was the youngest of the two daughters of a Bristol--



<P>merchant, of course, he must be called; but, as the whole of the



<P>profits of his mercantile life appeared so very moderate, it was



<P>not unfair to guess the dignity of his line of trade had been very



<P>moderate also.&nbsp; Part of every winter she had been used to spend

in Bath;



<P>but Bristol was her home, the very heart of Bristol; for though



<P>the father and mother had died some years ago, an uncle remained--



<P>in the law line--nothing more distinctly honourable was hazarded



<P>of him, than that he was in the law line; and with him the daughter



<P>had lived.&nbsp; Emma guessed him to be the drudge of some attorney,



<P>and too stupid to rise.&nbsp; And all the grandeur of the connexion



<P>seemed dependent on the elder sister, who was very well married,



<P>to a gentleman in a great way, near Bristol, who kept two carriages!



<P>That was the wind-up of the history; that was the glory of



<P>Miss Hawkins.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Could she but have given Harriet her feelings about it all!



<P>She had talked her into love; but, alas! she was not so easily to be



<P>talked out of it.&nbsp; The charm of an object to occupy the many vacancies



<P>of Harriet's mind was not to be talked away.&nbsp; He might be superseded



<P>by another; he certainly would indeed; nothing could be clearer;



<P>even a Robert Martin would have been sufficient; but nothing else,



<P>she feared, would cure her.&nbsp; Harriet was one of those, who,



<P>having once begun, would be always in love.&nbsp; And now, poor girl!



<P>she was considerably worse from this reappearance of Mr. Elton.



<P>She was always having a glimpse of him somewhere or other.&nbsp; Emma

saw



<P>him only once; but two or three times every day Harriet was sure



<P>just to meet with him, or just to miss him, just to hear his voice,



<P>or see his shoulder, just to have something occur to preserve him



<P>in her fancy, in all the favouring warmth of surprize and conjecture.



<P>She was, moreover, perpetually hearing about him; for, excepting when



<P>at Hartfield, she was always among those who saw no fault in Mr. Elton,



<P>and found nothing so interesting as the discussion of his concerns;



<P>and every report, therefore, every guess--all that had already



<P>occurred, all that might occur in the arrangement of his affairs,



<P>comprehending income, servants, and furniture, was continually



<P>in agitation around her.&nbsp; Her regard was receiving strength by



<P>invariable praise of him, and her regrets kept alive, and feelings



<P>irritated by ceaseless repetitions of Miss Hawkins's happiness,



<P>and continual observation of, how much he seemed attached!--



<P>his air as he walked by the house--the very sitting of his hat,



<P>being all in proof of how much he was in love!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Had it been allowable entertainment, had there been no pain



<P>to her friend, or reproach to herself, in the waverings of



<P>Harriet's mind, Emma would have been amused by its variations.



<P>Sometimes Mr. Elton predominated, sometimes the Martins; and each



<P>was occasionally useful as a check to the other.&nbsp; Mr. Elton's



<P>engagement had been the cure of the agitation of meeting Mr. Martin.



<P>The unhappiness produced by the knowledge of that engagement had been



<P>a little put aside by Elizabeth Martin's calling at Mrs. Goddard's



<P>a few days afterwards.&nbsp; Harriet had not been at home; but a note

had



<P>been prepared and left for her, written in the very style to touch;



<P>a small mixture of reproach, with a great deal of kindness;



<P>and till Mr. Elton himself appeared, she had been much occupied



<P>by it, continually pondering over what could be done in return,



<P>and wishing to do more than she dared to confess.&nbsp; But Mr. Elton,



<P>in person, had driven away all such cares.&nbsp; While he staid,



<P>the Martins were forgotten; and on the very morning of his setting off



<P>for Bath again, Emma, to dissipate some of the distress it occasioned,



<P>judged it best for her to return Elizabeth Martin's visit.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>How that visit was to be acknowledged--what would be necessary--



<P>and what might be safest, had been a point of some doubtful



<P>consideration.&nbsp; Absolute neglect of the mother and sisters,



<P>when invited to come, would be ingratitude.&nbsp; It must not be:



<P>and yet the danger of a renewal of the acquaintance!--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After much thinking, she could determine on nothing better, than Harriet's



<P>returning the visit; but in a way that, if they had understanding,



<P>should convince them that it was to be only a formal acquaintance.



<P>She meant to take her in the carriage, leave her at the Abbey Mill,



<P>while she drove a little farther, and call for her again so soon,



<P>as to allow no time for insidious applications or dangerous



<P>recurrences to the past, and give the most decided proof of what



<P>degree of intimacy was chosen for the future.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She could think of nothing better:&nbsp; and though there was something



<P>in it which her own heart could not approve--something of ingratitude,



<P>merely glossed over--it must be done, or what would become of Harriet?



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 10</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER X</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>The appearance of the little sitting-room as they entered,



<P>was tranquillity itself; Mrs. Bates, deprived of her usual employment,



<P>slumbering on one side of the fire, Frank Churchill, at a table



<P>near her, most deedily occupied about her spectacles, and Jane Fairfax,



<P>standing with her back to them, intent on her pianoforte.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Busy as he was, however, the young man was yet able to shew a most



<P>happy countenance on seeing Emma again.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"This is a pleasure," said he, in rather a low voice, "coming at



<P>least ten minutes earlier than I had calculated.&nbsp; You find me



<P>trying to be useful; tell me if you think I shall succeed."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What!" said Mrs. Weston, "have not you finished it yet? you would



<P>not earn a very good livelihood as a working silversmith at this rate."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have not been working uninterruptedly," he replied, "I have been



<P>assisting Miss Fairfax in trying to make her instrument stand steadily,



<P>it was not quite firm; an unevenness in the floor, I believe.



<P>You see we have been wedging one leg with paper.&nbsp; This was very

kind



<P>of you to be persuaded to come.&nbsp; I was almost afraid you would

be



<P>hurrying home."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He contrived that she should be seated by him; and was sufficiently



<P>employed in looking out the best baked apple for her, and trying



<P>to make her help or advise him in his work, till Jane Fairfax was



<P>quite ready to sit down to the pianoforte again.&nbsp; That she was

not



<P>immediately ready, Emma did suspect to arise from the state of her nerves;



<P>she had not yet possessed the instrument long enough to touch it



<P>without emotion; she must reason herself into the power of performance;



<P>and Emma could not but pity such feelings, whatever their origin,



<P>and could not but resolve never to expose them to her neighbour again.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>At last Jane began, and though the first bars were feebly given,



<P>the powers of the instrument were gradually done full justice to.



<P>Mrs. Weston had been delighted before, and was delighted again;



<P>Emma joined her in all her praise; and the pianoforte, with every



<P>proper discrimination, was pronounced to be altogether of the



<P>highest promise.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Whoever Colonel Campbell might employ," said Frank Churchill,



<P>with a smile at Emma, "the person has not chosen ill.&nbsp; I heard

a good



<P>deal of Colonel Campbell's taste at Weymouth; and the softness of the



<P>upper notes I am sure is exactly what he and all that party would



<P>particularly prize.&nbsp; I dare say, Miss Fairfax, that he either gave



<P>his friend very minute directions, or wrote to Broadwood himself.



<P>Do not you think so?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Jane did not look round.&nbsp; She was not obliged to hear.&nbsp; Mrs.

Weston



<P>had been speaking to her at the same moment.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is not fair," said Emma, in a whisper; "mine was a random guess.



<P>Do not distress her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He shook his head with a smile, and looked as if he had very little



<P>doubt and very little mercy.&nbsp; Soon afterwards he began again,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How much your friends in Ireland must be enjoying your pleasure



<P>on this occasion, Miss Fairfax.&nbsp; I dare say they often think of

you,



<P>and wonder which will be the day, the precise day of the instrument's



<P>coming to hand.&nbsp; Do you imagine Colonel Campbell knows the business



<P>to be going forward just at this time?--Do you imagine it to be



<P>the consequence of an immediate commission from him, or that he may



<P>have sent only a general direction, an order indefinite as to time,



<P>to depend upon contingencies and conveniences?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He paused.&nbsp; She could not but hear; she could not avoid answering,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Till I have a letter from Colonel Campbell," said she, in a voice



<P>of forced calmness, "I can imagine nothing with any confidence.



<P>It must be all conjecture."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Conjecture--aye, sometimes one conjectures right, and sometimes



<P>one conjectures wrong.&nbsp; I wish I could conjecture how soon I shall



<P>make this rivet quite firm.&nbsp; What nonsense one talks, Miss Woodhouse,



<P>when hard at work, if one talks at all;--your real workmen,



<P>I suppose, hold their tongues; but we gentlemen labourers if we get



<P>hold of a word--Miss Fairfax said something about conjecturing.



<P>There, it is done.&nbsp; I have the pleasure, madam, (to Mrs. Bates,)



<P>of restoring your spectacles, healed for the present."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He was very warmly thanked both by mother and daughter; to escape



<P>a little from the latter, he went to the pianoforte, and begged



<P>Miss Fairfax, who was still sitting at it, to play something more.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If you are very kind," said he, "it will be one of the waltzes



<P>we danced last night;--let me live them over again.&nbsp; You did not



<P>enjoy them as I did; you appeared tired the whole time.&nbsp; I believe



<P>you were glad we danced no longer; but I would have given worlds--



<P>all the worlds one ever has to give--for another half-hour."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She played.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What felicity it is to hear a tune again which has made one happy!--



<P>If I mistake not that was danced at Weymouth."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She looked up at him for a moment, coloured deeply, and played



<P>something else.&nbsp; He took some music from a chair near the pianoforte,



<P>and turning to Emma, said,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Here is something quite new to me.&nbsp; Do you know it?--Cramer.--



<P>And here are a new set of Irish melodies.&nbsp; That, from such a quarter,



<P>one might expect.&nbsp; This was all sent with the instrument.&nbsp;

Very thoughtful



<P>of Colonel Campbell, was not it?--He knew Miss Fairfax could have



<P>no music here.&nbsp; I honour that part of the attention particularly;



<P>it shews it to have been so thoroughly from the heart.&nbsp; Nothing

hastily



<P>done; nothing incomplete.&nbsp; True affection only could have prompted

it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma wished he would be less pointed, yet could not help being amused;



<P>and when on glancing her eye towards Jane Fairfax she caught



<P>the remains of a smile, when she saw that with all the deep blush



<P>of consciousness, there had been a smile of secret delight,



<P>she had less scruple in the amusement, and much less compunction



<P>with respect to her.--This amiable, upright, perfect Jane Fairfax



<P>was apparently cherishing very reprehensible feelings.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He brought all the music to her, and they looked it over together.--



<P>Emma took the opportunity of whispering,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You speak too plain.&nbsp; She must understand you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I hope she does.&nbsp; I would have her understand me.&nbsp; I am not



<P>in the least ashamed of my meaning."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But really, I am half ashamed, and wish I had never taken up



<P>the idea."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am very glad you did, and that you communicated it to me.



<P>I have now a key to all her odd looks and ways.&nbsp; Leave shame to

her.



<P>If she does wrong, she ought to feel it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She is not entirely without it, I think."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not see much sign of it.&nbsp; She is playing Robin Adair



<P>at this moment--his favourite."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Shortly afterwards Miss Bates, passing near the window,



<P>descried Mr. Knightley on horse-back not far off.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mr. Knightley I declare!--I must speak to him if possible,



<P>just to thank him.&nbsp; I will not open the window here; it would give



<P>you all cold; but I can go into my mother's room you know.&nbsp; I dare



<P>say he will come in when he knows who is here.&nbsp; Quite delightful



<P>to have you all meet so!--Our little room so honoured!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was in the adjoining chamber while she still spoke, and opening



<P>the casement there, immediately called Mr. Knightley's attention,



<P>and every syllable of their conversation was as distinctly heard



<P>by the others, as if it had passed within the same apartment.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How d' ye do?--how d'ye do?--Very well, I thank you.&nbsp; So obliged



<P>to you for the carriage last night.&nbsp; We were just in time;



<P>my mother just ready for us.&nbsp; Pray come in; do come in.&nbsp; You

will



<P>find some friends here."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>So began Miss Bates; and Mr. Knightley seemed determined to be heard



<P>in his turn, for most resolutely and commandingly did he say,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How is your niece, Miss Bates?--I want to inquire after you all,



<P>but particularly your niece.&nbsp; How is Miss Fairfax?--I hope she



<P>caught no cold last night.&nbsp; How is she to-day? Tell me how Miss



<P>Fairfax is."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>And Miss Bates was obliged to give a direct answer before he



<P>would hear her in any thing else.&nbsp; The listeners were amused;



<P>and Mrs. Weston gave Emma a look of particular meaning.&nbsp; But Emma



<P>still shook her head in steady scepticism.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So obliged to you!--so very much obliged to you for the carriage,"



<P>resumed Miss Bates.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He cut her short with,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am going to Kingston.&nbsp; Can I do anything for you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! dear, Kingston--are you?--Mrs. Cole was saying the other day



<P>she wanted something from Kingston."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mrs. Cole has servants to send.&nbsp; Can I do any thing for you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, I thank you.&nbsp; But do come in.&nbsp; Who do you think is here?--



<P>Miss Woodhouse and Miss Smith; so kind as to call to hear the



<P>new pianoforte.&nbsp; Do put up your horse at the Crown, and come in."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well," said he, in a deliberating manner, "for five minutes, perhaps."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And here is Mrs. Weston and Mr. Frank Churchill too!--Quite delightful;



<P>so many friends!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, not now, I thank you.&nbsp; I could not stay two minutes.



<P>I must get on to Kingston as fast as I can."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! do come in.&nbsp; They will be so very happy to see you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, no; your room is full enough.&nbsp; I will call another day,



<P>and hear the pianoforte."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, I am so sorry!--Oh!&nbsp; Mr. Knightley, what a delightful party



<P>last night; how extremely pleasant.--Did you ever see such dancing?--



<P>Was not it delightful?--Miss Woodhouse and Mr. Frank Churchill;



<P>I never saw any thing equal to it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! very delightful indeed; I can say nothing less, for I suppose



<P>Miss Woodhouse and Mr. Frank Churchill are hearing every thing



<P>that passes.&nbsp; And (raising his voice still more) I do not see why

Miss



<P>Fairfax should not be mentioned too.&nbsp; I think Miss Fairfax dances



<P>very well; and Mrs. Weston is the very best country-dance player,



<P>without exception, in England.&nbsp; Now, if your friends have any gratitude,



<P>they will say something pretty loud about you and me in return;



<P>but I cannot stay to hear it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh!&nbsp; Mr. Knightley, one moment more; something of consequence--



<P>so shocked!--Jane and I are both so shocked about the apples!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What is the matter now?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"To think of your sending us all your store apples.&nbsp; You said you

had



<P>a great many, and now you have not one left.&nbsp; We really are so

shocked!



<P>Mrs. Hodges may well be angry.&nbsp; William Larkins mentioned it here.



<P>You should not have done it, indeed you should not.&nbsp; Ah! he is

off.



<P>He never can bear to be thanked.&nbsp; But I thought he would have staid

now,



<P>and it would have been a pity not to have mentioned. . . . Well,



<P>(returning to the room,) I have not been able to succeed.



<P>Mr. Knightley cannot stop.&nbsp; He is going to Kingston.&nbsp; He asked

me



<P>if he could do any thing. . . ."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes," said Jane, "we heard his kind offers, we heard every thing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! yes, my dear, I dare say you might, because you know, the door



<P>was open, and the window was open, and Mr. Knightley spoke loud.



<P>You must have heard every thing to be sure.&nbsp; `Can I do any thing



<P>for you at Kingston?' said he; so I just mentioned. . . . Oh!



<P>Miss Woodhouse, must you be going?--You seem but just come--so very



<P>obliging of you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma found it really time to be at home; the visit had already



<P>lasted long; and on examining watches, so much of the morning was



<P>perceived to be gone, that Mrs. Weston and her companion taking



<P>leave also, could allow themselves only to walk with the two young



<P>ladies to Hartfield gates, before they set off for Randalls.

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 11</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XI</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>It may be possible to do without dancing entirely.&nbsp; Instances have



<P>been known of young people passing many, many months successively,



<P>without being at any ball of any description, and no material injury



<P>accrue either to body or mind;--but when a beginning is made--



<P>when the felicities of rapid motion have once been, though slightly,



<P>felt--it must be a very heavy set that does not ask for more.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Frank Churchill had danced once at Highbury, and longed to dance again;



<P>and the last half-hour of an evening which Mr. Woodhouse was persuaded



<P>to spend with his daughter at Randalls, was passed by the two young



<P>people in schemes on the subject.&nbsp; Frank's was the first idea;



<P>and his the greatest zeal in pursuing it; for the lady was the best



<P>judge of the difficulties, and the most solicitous for accommodation



<P>and appearance.&nbsp; But still she had inclination enough for shewing



<P>people again how delightfully Mr. Frank Churchill and Miss



<P>Woodhouse danced--for doing that in which she need not blush to compare



<P>herself with Jane Fairfax--and even for simple dancing itself,



<P>without any of the wicked aids of vanity--to assist him first



<P>in pacing out the room they were in to see what it could be made



<P>to hold--and then in taking the dimensions of the other parlour,



<P>in the hope of discovering, in spite of all that Mr. Weston could



<P>say of their exactly equal size, that it was a little the largest.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>His first proposition and request, that the dance begun at Mr. Cole's



<P>should be finished there--that the same party should be collected,



<P>and the same musician engaged, met with the readiest acquiescence.



<P>Mr. Weston entered into the idea with thorough enjoyment,



<P>and Mrs. Weston most willingly undertook to play as long as they



<P>could wish to dance; and the interesting employment had followed,



<P>of reckoning up exactly who there would be, and portioning out the



<P>indispensable division of space to every couple.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You and Miss Smith, and Miss Fairfax, will be three, and the two



<P>Miss Coxes five," had been repeated many times over.&nbsp; "And there



<P>will be the two Gilberts, young Cox, my father, and myself,



<P>besides Mr. Knightley.&nbsp; Yes, that will be quite enough for pleasure.



<P>You and Miss Smith, and Miss Fairfax, will be three, and the two Miss



<P>Coxes five; and for five couple there will be plenty of room."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But soon it came to be on one side,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But will there be good room for five couple?--I really do not think



<P>there will."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>On another,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And after all, five couple are not enough to make it worth



<P>while to stand up.&nbsp; Five couple are nothing, when one thinks



<P>seriously about it.&nbsp; It will not do to invite five couple.



<P>It can be allowable only as the thought of the moment."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Somebody said that Miss Gilbert was expected at her brother's,



<P>and must be invited with the rest.&nbsp; Somebody else believed



<P>Mrs. Gilbert would have danced the other evening, if she had



<P>been asked.&nbsp; A word was put in for a second young Cox; and at last,



<P>Mr. Weston naming one family of cousins who must be included,



<P>and another of very old acquaintance who could not be left out,



<P>it became a certainty that the five couple would be at least ten,



<P>and a very interesting speculation in what possible manner they



<P>could be disposed of.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The doors of the two rooms were just opposite each other.



<P>"Might not they use both rooms, and dance across the passage?"



<P>It seemed the best scheme; and yet it was not so good but that



<P>many of them wanted a better.&nbsp; Emma said it would be awkward;



<P>Mrs. Weston was in distress about the supper; and Mr. Woodhouse



<P>opposed it earnestly, on the score of health.&nbsp; It made him so



<P>very unhappy, indeed, that it could not be persevered in.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! no," said he; "it would be the extreme of imprudence.



<P>I could not bear it for Emma!--Emma is not strong.&nbsp; She would



<P>catch a dreadful cold.&nbsp; So would poor little Harriet.



<P>So you would all.&nbsp; Mrs. Weston, you would be quite laid up;



<P>do not let them talk of such a wild thing.&nbsp; Pray do not let them



<P>talk of it.&nbsp; That young man (speaking lower) is very thoughtless.



<P>Do not tell his father, but that young man is not quite the thing.



<P>He has been opening the doors very often this evening, and keeping



<P>them open very inconsiderately.&nbsp; He does not think of the draught.



<P>I do not mean to set you against him, but indeed he is not quite



<P>the thing!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Weston was sorry for such a charge.&nbsp; She knew the importance



<P>of it, and said every thing in her power to do it away.&nbsp; Every

door



<P>was now closed, the passage plan given up, and the first scheme



<P>of dancing only in the room they were in resorted to again;



<P>and with such good-will on Frank Churchill's part, that the space



<P>which a quarter of an hour before had been deemed barely sufficient



<P>for five couple, was now endeavoured to be made out quite enough



<P>for ten.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We were too magnificent," said he.&nbsp; "We allowed unnecessary room.



<P>Ten couple may stand here very well."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma demurred.&nbsp; "It would be a crowd--a sad crowd; and what could



<P>be worse than dancing without space to turn in?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very true," he gravely replied; "it was very bad."&nbsp; But still

he



<P>went on measuring, and still he ended with,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I think there will be very tolerable room for ten couple."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, no," said she, "you are quite unreasonable.&nbsp; It would be dreadful



<P>to be standing so close!&nbsp; Nothing can be farther from pleasure



<P>than to be dancing in a crowd--and a crowd in a little room!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There is no denying it," he replied.&nbsp; "I agree with you exactly.



<P>A crowd in a little room--Miss Woodhouse, you have the art of giving



<P>pictures in a few words.&nbsp; Exquisite, quite exquisite!--Still, however,



<P>having proceeded so far, one is unwilling to give the matter up.



<P>It would be a disappointment to my father--and altogether--I do



<P>not know that--I am rather of opinion that ten couple might stand



<P>here very well."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma perceived that the nature of his gallantry was a little



<P>self-willed, and that he would rather oppose than lose the pleasure



<P>of dancing with her; but she took the compliment, and forgave



<P>the rest.&nbsp; Had she intended ever to marry him, it might have been



<P>worth while to pause and consider, and try to understand the value



<P>of his preference, and the character of his temper; but for



<P>all the purposes of their acquaintance, he was quite amiable enough.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Before the middle of the next day, he was at Hartfield; and he entered



<P>the room with such an agreeable smile as certified the continuance



<P>of the scheme.&nbsp; It soon appeared that he came to announce an improvement.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, Miss Woodhouse," he almost immediately began, "your inclination



<P>for dancing has not been quite frightened away, I hope, by the



<P>terrors of my father's little rooms.&nbsp; I bring a new proposal



<P>on the subject:--a thought of my father's, which waits only your



<P>approbation to be acted upon.&nbsp; May I hope for the honour of your



<P>hand for the two first dances of this little projected ball,



<P>to be given, not at Randalls, but at the Crown Inn?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The Crown!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes; if you and Mr. Woodhouse see no objection, and I trust you cannot,



<P>my father hopes his friends will be so kind as to visit him there.



<P>Better accommodations, he can promise them, and not a less grateful



<P>welcome than at Randalls.&nbsp; It is his own idea.&nbsp; Mrs. Weston

sees



<P>no objection to it, provided you are satisfied.&nbsp; This is what we



<P>all feel.&nbsp; Oh! you were perfectly right!&nbsp; Ten couple, in either

of



<P>the Randalls rooms, would have been insufferable!--Dreadful!--I felt



<P>how right you were the whole time, but was too anxious for securing



<P>any thing to like to yield.&nbsp; Is not it a good exchange?--You consent--



<P>I hope you consent?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It appears to me a plan that nobody can object to, if Mr. and



<P>Mrs. Weston do not.&nbsp; I think it admirable; and, as far as I can



<P>answer for myself, shall be most happy--It seems the only improvement



<P>that could be.&nbsp; Papa, do you not think it an excellent improvement?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was obliged to repeat and explain it, before it was fully



<P>comprehended; and then, being quite new, farther representations



<P>were necessary to make it acceptable.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No; he thought it very far from an improvement--a very bad plan--



<P>much worse than the other.&nbsp; A room at an inn was always damp



<P>and dangerous; never properly aired, or fit to be inhabited.



<P>If they must dance, they had better dance at Randalls.&nbsp; He had

never



<P>been in the room at the Crown in his life--did not know the people



<P>who kept it by sight.--Oh! no--a very bad plan.&nbsp; They would catch



<P>worse colds at the Crown than anywhere."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I was going to observe, sir," said Frank Churchill,



<P>"that one of the great recommendations of this change would



<P>be the very little danger of any body's catching cold--



<P>so much less danger at the Crown than at Randalls!&nbsp; Mr. Perry



<P>might have reason to regret the alteration, but nobody else could."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Sir," said Mr. Woodhouse, rather warmly, "you are very much



<P>mistaken if you suppose Mr. Perry to be that sort of character.



<P>Mr. Perry is extremely concerned when any of us are ill.&nbsp; But I



<P>do not understand how the room at the Crown can be safer for you



<P>than your father's house."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"From the very circumstance of its being larger, sir.&nbsp; We shall

have



<P>no occasion to open the windows at all--not once the whole evening;



<P>and it is that dreadful habit of opening the windows, letting in cold



<P>air upon heated bodies, which (as you well know, sir) does the mischief."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Open the windows!--but surely, Mr. Churchill, nobody would think



<P>of opening the windows at Randalls.&nbsp; Nobody could be so imprudent!



<P>I never heard of such a thing.&nbsp; Dancing with open windows!--I am

sure,



<P>neither your father nor Mrs. Weston (poor Miss Taylor that was)



<P>would suffer it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah! sir--but a thoughtless young person will sometimes step behind



<P>a window-curtain, and throw up a sash, without its being suspected.



<P>I have often known it done myself."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Have you indeed, sir?--Bless me!&nbsp; I never could have supposed

it.



<P>But I live out of the world, and am often astonished at what I hear.



<P>However, this does make a difference; and, perhaps, when we come



<P>to talk it over--but these sort of things require a good deal



<P>of consideration.&nbsp; One cannot resolve upon them in a hurry.



<P>If Mr. and Mrs. Weston will be so obliging as to call here one morning,



<P>we may talk it over, and see what can be done."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But, unfortunately, sir, my time is so limited--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh!" interrupted Emma, "there will be plenty of time for talking



<P>every thing over.&nbsp; There is no hurry at all.&nbsp; If it can be

contrived



<P>to be at the Crown, papa, it will be very convenient for the horses.



<P>They will be so near their own stable."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So they will, my dear.&nbsp; That is a great thing.&nbsp; Not that

James



<P>ever complains; but it is right to spare our horses when we can.



<P>If I could be sure of the rooms being thoroughly aired--but is



<P>Mrs. Stokes to be trusted?&nbsp; I doubt it.&nbsp; I do not know her,



<P>even by sight."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I can answer for every thing of that nature, sir, because it will



<P>be under Mrs. Weston's care.&nbsp; Mrs. Weston undertakes to direct



<P>the whole."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There, papa!--Now you must be satisfied--Our own dear Mrs. Weston,



<P>who is carefulness itself.&nbsp; Do not you remember what Mr. Perry

said,



<P>so many years ago, when I had the measles?&nbsp; `If Miss Taylor undertakes



<P>to wrap Miss Emma up, you need not have any fears, sir.'&nbsp; How often



<P>have I heard you speak of it as such a compliment to her!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Aye, very true.&nbsp; Mr. Perry did say so.&nbsp; I shall never forget

it.



<P>Poor little Emma!&nbsp; You were very bad with the measles; that is,



<P>you would have been very bad, but for Perry's great attention.



<P>He came four times a day for a week.&nbsp; He said, from the first,



<P>it was a very good sort--which was our great comfort; but the measles



<P>are a dreadful complaint.&nbsp; I hope whenever poor Isabella's little

ones



<P>have the measles, she will send for Perry."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My father and Mrs. Weston are at the Crown at this moment,"



<P>said Frank Churchill, "examining the capabilities of the house.



<P>I left them there and came on to Hartfield, impatient for your opinion,



<P>and hoping you might be persuaded to join them and give your advice



<P>on the spot.&nbsp; I was desired to say so from both.&nbsp; It would

be the



<P>greatest pleasure to them, if you could allow me to attend you there.



<P>They can do nothing satisfactorily without you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma was most happy to be called to such a council; and her father,



<P>engaging to think it all over while she was gone, the two young



<P>people set off together without delay for the Crown.&nbsp; There were



<P>Mr. and Mrs. Weston; delighted to see her and receive her approbation,



<P>very busy and very happy in their different way; she, in some



<P>little distress; and he, finding every thing perfect.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Emma," said she, "this paper is worse than I expected.



<P>Look! in places you see it is dreadfully dirty; and the wainscot



<P>is more yellow and forlorn than any thing I could have imagined."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear, you are too particular," said her husband.&nbsp; "What does



<P>all that signify?&nbsp; You will see nothing of it by candlelight.



<P>It will be as clean as Randalls by candlelight.&nbsp; We never see any



<P>thing of it on our club-nights."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The ladies here probably exchanged looks which meant, "Men never



<P>know when things are dirty or not;" and the gentlemen perhaps



<P>thought each to himself, "Women will have their little nonsenses



<P>and needless cares."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>One perplexity, however, arose, which the gentlemen did not disdain.



<P>It regarded a supper-room.&nbsp; At the time of the ballroom's being

built,



<P>suppers had not been in question; and a small card-room adjoining,



<P>was the only addition.&nbsp; What was to be done?&nbsp; This card-room

would



<P>be wanted as a card-room now; or, if cards were conveniently voted



<P>unnecessary by their four selves, still was it not too small for



<P>any comfortable supper?&nbsp; Another room of much better size might

be



<P>secured for the purpose; but it was at the other end of the house,



<P>and a long awkward passage must be gone through to get at it.



<P>This made a difficulty.&nbsp; Mrs. Weston was afraid of draughts



<P>for the young people in that passage; and neither Emma nor the



<P>gentlemen could tolerate the prospect of being miserably crowded



<P>at supper.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Weston proposed having no regular supper; merely sandwiches,



<P>&amp;c., set out in the little room; but that was scouted as a



<P>wretched suggestion.&nbsp; A private dance, without sitting down to

supper,



<P>was pronounced an infamous fraud upon the rights of men and women;



<P>and Mrs. Weston must not speak of it again.&nbsp; She then took another



<P>line of expediency, and looking into the doubtful room, observed,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not think it is so very small.&nbsp; We shall not be many,



<P>you know."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>And Mr. Weston at the same time, walking briskly with long steps



<P>through the passage, was calling out,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You talk a great deal of the length of this passage, my dear.



<P>It is a mere nothing after all; and not the least draught from



<P>the stairs."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I wish," said Mrs. Weston, "one could know which arrangement our



<P>guests in general would like best.&nbsp; To do what would be most generally



<P>pleasing must be our object--if one could but tell what that would be."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, very true," cried Frank, "very true.&nbsp; You want your neighbours'



<P>opinions.&nbsp; I do not wonder at you.&nbsp; If one could ascertain

what the



<P>chief of them--the Coles, for instance.&nbsp; They are not far off.



<P>Shall I call upon them?&nbsp; Or Miss Bates?&nbsp; She is still nearer.--



<P>And I do not know whether Miss Bates is not as likely to understand



<P>the inclinations of the rest of the people as any body.&nbsp; I think



<P>we do want a larger council.&nbsp; Suppose I go and invite Miss Bates



<P>to join us?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well--if you please," said Mrs. Weston rather hesitating, "if you



<P>think she will be of any use."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You will get nothing to the purpose from Miss Bates," said Emma.



<P>"She will be all delight and gratitude, but she will tell you nothing.



<P>She will not even listen to your questions.&nbsp; I see no advantage

in



<P>consulting Miss Bates."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But she is so amusing, so extremely amusing!&nbsp; I am very fond



<P>of hearing Miss Bates talk.&nbsp; And I need not bring the whole family,



<P>you know."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Here Mr. Weston joined them, and on hearing what was proposed,



<P>gave it his decided approbation.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Aye, do, Frank.--Go and fetch Miss Bates, and let us end the matter



<P>at once.&nbsp; She will enjoy the scheme, I am sure; and I do not know



<P>a properer person for shewing us how to do away difficulties.



<P>Fetch Miss Bates.&nbsp; We are growing a little too nice.&nbsp; She

is



<P>a standing lesson of how to be happy.&nbsp; But fetch them both.



<P>Invite them both."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Both sir!&nbsp; Can the old lady?" . . .

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The old lady!&nbsp; No, the young lady, to be sure.&nbsp; I shall think

you



<P>a great blockhead, Frank, if you bring the aunt without the niece."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh!&nbsp; I beg your pardon, sir.&nbsp; I did not immediately recollect.



<P>Undoubtedly if you wish it, I will endeavour to persuade them both."



<P>And away he ran.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Long before he reappeared, attending the short, neat, brisk-moving aunt,



<P>and her elegant niece,--Mrs. Weston, like a sweet-tempered



<P>woman and a good wife, had examined the passage again,



<P>and found the evils of it much less than she had supposed before--



<P>indeed very trifling; and here ended the difficulties of decision.



<P>All the rest, in speculation at least, was perfectly smooth.



<P>All the minor arrangements of table and chair, lights and music,



<P>tea and supper, made themselves; or were left as mere trifles



<P>to be settled at any time between Mrs. Weston and Mrs. Stokes.--



<P>Every body invited, was certainly to come; Frank had already written



<P>to Enscombe to propose staying a few days beyond his fortnight,



<P>which could not possibly be refused.&nbsp; And a delightful dance it

was



<P>to be.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Most cordially, when Miss Bates arrived, did she agree that it must.



<P>As a counsellor she was not wanted; but as an approver, (a much



<P>safer character,) she was truly welcome.&nbsp; Her approbation, at once



<P>general and minute, warm and incessant, could not but please;



<P>and for another half-hour they were all walking to and fro,



<P>between the different rooms, some suggesting, some attending,



<P>and all in happy enjoyment of the future.&nbsp; The party did not break



<P>up without Emma's being positively secured for the two first dances



<P>by the hero of the evening, nor without her overhearing Mr. Weston



<P>whisper to his wife, "He has asked her, my dear.&nbsp; That's right.



<P>I knew he would!"

<BR>

<BR>&nbsp;

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <TITLE>Chapter 05</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER V</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Small heart had Harriet for visiting.&nbsp; Only half an hour before

her



<P>friend called for her at Mrs. Goddard's, her evil stars had led



<P>her to the very spot where, at that moment, a trunk, directed to



<P>The Rev. Philip Elton, White-Hart, Bath, was to be seen under the



<P>operation of being lifted into the butcher's cart, which was to



<P>convey it to where the coaches past; and every thing in this world,



<P>excepting that trunk and the direction, was consequently a blank.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She went, however; and when they reached the farm, and she was to



<P>be put down, at the end of the broad, neat gravel walk, which led



<P>between espalier apple-trees to the front door, the sight of every



<P>thing which had given her so much pleasure the autumn before,



<P>was beginning to revive a little local agitation; and when they parted,



<P>Emma observed her to be looking around with a sort of fearful curiosity,



<P>which determined her not to allow the visit to exceed the proposed



<P>quarter of an hour.&nbsp; She went on herself, to give that portion



<P>of time to an old servant who was married, and settled in Donwell.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The quarter of an hour brought her punctually to the white gate again;



<P>and Miss Smith receiving her summons, was with her without delay,



<P>and unattended by any alarming young man.&nbsp; She came solitarily



<P>down the gravel walk--a Miss Martin just appearing at the door,



<P>and parting with her seemingly with ceremonious civility.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet could not very soon give an intelligible account.



<P>She was feeling too much; but at last Emma collected from her



<P>enough to understand the sort of meeting, and the sort of pain it



<P>was creating.&nbsp; She had seen only Mrs. Martin and the two girls.



<P>They had received her doubtingly, if not coolly; and nothing



<P>beyond the merest commonplace had been talked almost all the time--



<P>till just at last, when Mrs. Martin's saying, all of a sudden,



<P>that she thought Miss Smith was grown, had brought on a more



<P>interesting subject, and a warmer manner.&nbsp; In that very room



<P>she had been measured last September, with her two friends.



<P>There were the pencilled marks and memorandums on the wainscot by



<P>the window.&nbsp; He had done it.&nbsp; They all seemed to remember

the day,



<P>the hour, the party, the occasion--to feel the same consciousness,



<P>the same regrets--to be ready to return to the same good understanding;



<P>and they were just growing again like themselves, (Harriet, as Emma



<P>must suspect, as ready as the best of them to be cordial and happy,)



<P>when the carriage reappeared, and all was over.&nbsp; The style of



<P>the visit, and the shortness of it, were then felt to be decisive.



<P>Fourteen minutes to be given to those with whom she had thankfully



<P>passed six weeks not six months ago!--Emma could not but picture



<P>it all, and feel how justly they might resent, how naturally



<P>Harriet must suffer.&nbsp; It was a bad business.&nbsp; She would have

given



<P>a great deal, or endured a great deal, to have had the Martins



<P>in a higher rank of life.&nbsp; They were so deserving, that a little



<P>higher should have been enough:&nbsp; but as it was, how could she have



<P>done otherwise?--Impossible!--She could not repent.&nbsp; They must



<P>be separated; but there was a great deal of pain in the process--



<P>so much to herself at this time, that she soon felt the necessity



<P>of a little consolation, and resolved on going home by way of Randalls



<P>to procure it.&nbsp; Her mind was quite sick of Mr. Elton and the Martins.



<P>The refreshment of Randalls was absolutely necessary.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was a good scheme; but on driving to the door they heard



<P>that neither "master nor mistress was at home;" they had both



<P>been out some time; the man believed they were gone to Hartfield.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"This is too bad," cried Emma, as they turned away.&nbsp; "And now we



<P>shall just miss them; too provoking!--I do not know when I have been



<P>so disappointed."&nbsp; And she leaned back in the corner, to indulge



<P>her murmurs, or to reason them away; probably a little of both--



<P>such being the commonest process of a not ill-disposed mind.



<P>Presently the carriage stopt; she looked up; it was stopt



<P>by Mr. and Mrs. Weston, who were standing to speak to her.



<P>There was instant pleasure in the sight of them, and still greater



<P>pleasure was conveyed in sound--for Mr. Weston immediately accosted



<P>her with,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How d'ye do?--how d'ye do?--We have been sitting with your father--



<P>glad to see him so well.&nbsp; Frank comes to-morrow--I had a letter



<P>this morning--we see him to-morrow by dinner-time to a certainty--



<P>he is at Oxford to-day, and he comes for a whole fortnight; I knew it

would



<P>be so.&nbsp; If he had come at Christmas he could not have staid three

days;



<P>I was always glad he did not come at Christmas; now we are going



<P>to have just the right weather for him, fine, dry, settled weather.



<P>We shall enjoy him completely; every thing has turned out exactly



<P>as we could wish."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was no resisting such news, no possibility of avoiding the



<P>influence of such a happy face as Mr. Weston's, confirmed as it all



<P>was by the words and the countenance of his wife, fewer and quieter,



<P>but not less to the purpose.&nbsp; To know that she thought his coming



<P>certain was enough to make Emma consider it so, and sincerely did



<P>she rejoice in their joy.&nbsp; It was a most delightful reanimation



<P>of exhausted spirits.&nbsp; The worn-out past was sunk in the freshness



<P>of what was coming; and in the rapidity of half a moment's thought,



<P>she hoped Mr. Elton would now be talked of no more.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Weston gave her the history of the engagements at Enscombe,



<P>which allowed his son to answer for having an entire fortnight at



<P>his command, as well as the route and the method of his journey;



<P>and she listened, and smiled, and congratulated.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I shall soon bring him over to Hartfield," said he, at the conclusion.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma could imagine she saw a touch of the arm at this speech,



<P>from his wife.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We had better move on, Mr. Weston," said she, "we are detaining



<P>the girls."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, well, I am ready;"--and turning again to Emma, "but you must



<P>not be expecting such a very fine young man; you have only had my



<P>account you know; I dare say he is really nothing extraordinary:"--



<P>though his own sparkling eyes at the moment were speaking a very



<P>different conviction.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma could look perfectly unconscious and innocent, and answer



<P>in a manner that appropriated nothing.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Think of me to-morrow, my dear Emma, about four o'clock,"



<P>was Mrs. Weston's parting injunction; spoken with some anxiety,



<P>and meant only for her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Four o'clock!--depend upon it he will be here by three," was Mr. Weston's



<P>quick amendment; and so ended a most satisfactory meeting.



<P>Emma's spirits were mounted quite up to happiness; every thing wore



<P>a different air; James and his horses seemed not half so sluggish



<P>as before.&nbsp; When she looked at the hedges, she thought the elder

at



<P>least must soon be coming out; and when she turned round to Harriet,



<P>she saw something like a look of spring, a tender smile even there.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Will Mr. Frank Churchill pass through Bath as well as Oxford?"--



<P>was a question, however, which did not augur much.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But neither geography nor tranquillity could come all at once,



<P>and Emma was now in a humour to resolve that they should both come



<P>in time.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The morning of the interesting day arrived, and Mrs. Weston's



<P>faithful pupil did not forget either at ten, or eleven, or twelve



<P>o'clock, that she was to think of her at four.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear, dear anxious friend,"--said she, in mental soliloquy,



<P>while walking downstairs from her own room, "always overcareful



<P>for every body's comfort but your own; I see you now in all your



<P>little fidgets, going again and again into his room, to be sure



<P>that all is right."&nbsp; The clock struck twelve as she passed through



<P>the hall.&nbsp; "'Tis twelve; I shall not forget to think of you four



<P>hours hence; and by this time to-morrow, perhaps, or a little later,



<P>I may be thinking of the possibility of their all calling here.



<P>I am sure they will bring him soon."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She opened the parlour door, and saw two gentlemen sitting with



<P>her father--Mr. Weston and his son.&nbsp; They had been arrived only



<P>a few minutes, and Mr. Weston had scarcely finished his explanation



<P>of Frank's being a day before his time, and her father was yet



<P>in the midst of his very civil welcome and congratulations, when



<P>she appeared, to have her share of surprize, introduction, and pleasure.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The Frank Churchill so long talked of, so high in interest,



<P>was actually before her--he was presented to her, and she did



<P>not think too much had been said in his praise; he was a very good



<P>looking young man; height, air, address, all were unexceptionable,



<P>and his countenance had a great deal of the spirit and liveliness



<P>of his father's; he looked quick and sensible.&nbsp; She felt immediately



<P>that she should like him; and there was a well-bred ease of manner,



<P>and a readiness to talk, which convinced her that he came intending



<P>to be acquainted with her, and that acquainted they soon must be.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He had reached Randalls the evening before.&nbsp; She was pleased



<P>with the eagerness to arrive which had made him alter his plan,



<P>and travel earlier, later, and quicker, that he might gain half



<P>a day.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I told you yesterday," cried Mr. Weston with exultation, "I told



<P>you all that he would be here before the time named.&nbsp; I remembered



<P>what I used to do myself.&nbsp; One cannot creep upon a journey;



<P>one cannot help getting on faster than one has planned; and the



<P>pleasure of coming in upon one's friends before the look-out begins,



<P>is worth a great deal more than any little exertion it needs."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is a great pleasure where one can indulge in it," said the young

man,



<P>"though there are not many houses that I should presume on so far;



<P>but in coming home I felt I might do any thing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The word home made his father look on him with fresh complacency.



<P>Emma was directly sure that he knew how to make himself agreeable;



<P>the conviction was strengthened by what followed.&nbsp; He was very

much



<P>pleased with Randalls, thought it a most admirably arranged house,



<P>would hardly allow it even to be very small, admired the situation,



<P>the walk to Highbury, Highbury itself, Hartfield still more,



<P>and professed himself to have always felt the sort of interest



<P>in the country which none but one's own country gives, and the



<P>greatest curiosity to visit it.&nbsp; That he should never have been



<P>able to indulge so amiable a feeling before, passed suspiciously



<P>through Emma's brain; but still, if it were a falsehood, it was a



<P>pleasant one, and pleasantly handled.&nbsp; His manner had no air of

study



<P>or exaggeration.&nbsp; He did really look and speak as if in a state

of no



<P>common enjoyment.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Their subjects in general were such as belong to an opening acquaintance.



<P>On his side were the inquiries,--"Was she a horsewoman?--Pleasant rides?--



<P>Pleasant walks?--Had they a large neighbourhood?--Highbury, perhaps,



<P>afforded society enough?--There were several very pretty houses



<P>in and about it.--Balls--had they balls?--Was it a musical society?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But when satisfied on all these points, and their acquaintance



<P>proportionably advanced, he contrived to find an opportunity,



<P>while their two fathers were engaged with each other, of introducing



<P>his mother-in-law, and speaking of her with so much handsome praise,



<P>so much warm admiration, so much gratitude for the happiness she



<P>secured to his father, and her very kind reception of himself,



<P>as was an additional proof of his knowing how to please--



<P>and of his certainly thinking it worth while to try to please her.



<P>He did not advance a word of praise beyond what she knew to be



<P>thoroughly deserved by Mrs. Weston; but, undoubtedly he could know



<P>very little of the matter.&nbsp; He understood what would be welcome;



<P>he could be sure of little else.&nbsp; "His father's marriage," he said,



<P>"had been the wisest measure, every friend must rejoice in it;



<P>and the family from whom he had received such a blessing must



<P>be ever considered as having conferred the highest obligation



<P>on him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He got as near as he could to thanking her for Miss Taylor's merits,



<P>without seeming quite to forget that in the common course of things

it



<P>was to be rather supposed that Miss Taylor had formed Miss Woodhouse's



<P>character, than Miss Woodhouse Miss Taylor's. And at last, as if resolved



<P>to qualify his opinion completely for travelling round to its object,

he



<P>wound it all up with astonishment at the youth and beauty of her person.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Elegant, agreeable manners, I was prepared for," said he;



<P>"but I confess that, considering every thing, I had not expected



<P>more than a very tolerably well-looking woman of a certain age;



<P>I did not know that I was to find a pretty young woman in Mrs. Weston."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You cannot see too much perfection in Mrs. Weston for my feelings,"



<P>said Emma; "were you to guess her to be eighteen, I should listen



<P>with pleasure; but she would be ready to quarrel with you for using



<P>such words.&nbsp; Don't let her imagine that you have spoken of her

as



<P>a pretty young woman."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I hope I should know better," he replied; "no, depend upon it,



<P>(with a gallant bow,) that in addressing Mrs. Weston I should



<P>understand whom I might praise without any danger of being thought



<P>extravagant in my terms."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma wondered whether the same suspicion of what might be expected



<P>from their knowing each other, which had taken strong possession



<P>of her mind, had ever crossed his; and whether his compliments were



<P>to be considered as marks of acquiescence, or proofs of defiance.



<P>She must see more of him to understand his ways; at present she



<P>only felt they were agreeable.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She had no doubt of what Mr. Weston was often thinking about.



<P>His quick eye she detected again and again glancing towards them



<P>with a happy expression; and even, when he might have determined not



<P>to look, she was confident that he was often listening.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her own father's perfect exemption from any thought of the kind,



<P>the entire deficiency in him of all such sort of penetration



<P>or suspicion, was a most comfortable circumstance.&nbsp; Happily he



<P>was not farther from approving matrimony than from foreseeing it.--



<P>Though always objecting to every marriage that was arranged,



<P>he never suffered beforehand from the apprehension of any;



<P>it seemed as if he could not think so ill of any two persons'



<P>understanding as to suppose they meant to marry till it were



<P>proved against them.&nbsp; She blessed the favouring blindness.



<P>He could now, without the drawback of a single unpleasant surmise,



<P>without a glance forward at any possible treachery in his guest,



<P>give way to all his natural kind-hearted civility in solicitous



<P>inquiries after Mr. Frank Churchill's accommodation on his journey,



<P>through the sad evils of sleeping two nights on the road, and express



<P>very genuine unmixed anxiety to know that he had certainly escaped



<P>catching cold--which, however, he could not allow him to feel quite



<P>assured of himself till after another night.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A reasonable visit paid, Mr. Weston began to move.--"He must be going.



<P>He had business at the Crown about his hay, and a great many errands



<P>for Mrs. Weston at Ford's, but he need not hurry any body else."



<P>His son, too well bred to hear the hint, rose immediately also,



<P>saying,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"As you are going farther on business, sir, I will take the



<P>opportunity of paying a visit, which must be paid some day or other,



<P>and therefore may as well be paid now.&nbsp; I have the honour of being



<P>acquainted with a neighbour of yours, (turning to Emma,) a lady



<P>residing in or near Highbury; a family of the name of Fairfax.



<P>I shall have no difficulty, I suppose, in finding the house;



<P>though Fairfax, I believe, is not the proper name--I should rather



<P>say Barnes, or Bates.&nbsp; Do you know any family of that name?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"To be sure we do," cried his father; "Mrs. Bates--we passed her house--



<P>I saw Miss Bates at the window.&nbsp; True, true, you are acquainted



<P>with Miss Fairfax; I remember you knew her at Weymouth, and a fine



<P>girl she is.&nbsp; Call upon her, by all means."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There is no necessity for my calling this morning," said the



<P>young man; "another day would do as well; but there was that degree



<P>of acquaintance at Weymouth which--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! go to-day, go to-day. Do not defer it.&nbsp; What is right to be

done



<P>cannot be done too soon.&nbsp; And, besides, I must give you a hint,

Frank;



<P>any want of attention to her here should be carefully avoided.



<P>You saw her with the Campbells, when she was the equal of every body



<P>she mixed with, but here she is with a poor old grandmother,



<P>who has barely enough to live on.&nbsp; If you do not call early it



<P>will be a slight."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The son looked convinced.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have heard her speak of the acquaintance," said Emma; "she is



<P>a very elegant young woman."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He agreed to it, but with so quiet a "Yes," as inclined her almost



<P>to doubt his real concurrence; and yet there must be a very distinct



<P>sort of elegance for the fashionable world, if Jane Fairfax could



<P>be thought only ordinarily gifted with it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If you were never particularly struck by her manners before,"



<P>said she, "I think you will to-day. You will see her to advantage;



<P>see her and hear her--no, I am afraid you will not hear her at all,



<P>for she has an aunt who never holds her tongue."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are acquainted with Miss Jane Fairfax, sir, are you?"



<P>said Mr. Woodhouse, always the last to make his way in conversation;



<P>"then give me leave to assure you that you will find her a very



<P>agreeable young lady.&nbsp; She is staying here on a visit to her grandmama



<P>and aunt, very worthy people; I have known them all my life.



<P>They will be extremely glad to see you, I am sure; and one of my



<P>servants shall go with you to shew you the way."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear sir, upon no account in the world; my father can direct me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But your father is not going so far; he is only going to the Crown,



<P>quite on the other side of the street, and there are a great many houses;



<P>you might be very much at a loss, and it is a very dirty walk,



<P>unless you keep on the footpath; but my coachman can tell you



<P>where you had best cross the street."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Frank Churchill still declined it, looking as serious as he could,



<P>and his father gave his hearty support by calling out, "My good friend,



<P>this is quite unnecessary; Frank knows a puddle of water when he



<P>sees it, and as to Mrs. Bates's, he may get there from the Crown



<P>in a hop, step, and jump."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They were permitted to go alone; and with a cordial nod from one,



<P>and a graceful bow from the other, the two gentlemen took leave.



<P>Emma remained very well pleased with this beginning of the acquaintance,



<P>and could now engage to think of them all at Randalls any hour of



<P>the day, with full confidence in their comfort.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 13</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XIII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Emma continued to entertain no doubt of her being in love.&nbsp; Her

ideas



<P>only varied as to the how much.&nbsp; At first, she thought it was a

good deal;



<P>and afterwards, but little.&nbsp; She had great pleasure in hearing

Frank



<P>Churchill talked of; and, for his sake, greater pleasure than ever



<P>in seeing Mr. and Mrs. Weston; she was very often thinking of him,



<P>and quite impatient for a letter, that she might know how he was,



<P>how were his spirits, how was his aunt, and what was the chance



<P>of his coming to Randalls again this spring.&nbsp; But, on the other

hand,



<P>she could not admit herself to be unhappy, nor, after the



<P>first morning, to be less disposed for employment than usual;



<P>she was still busy and cheerful; and, pleasing as he was, she could



<P>yet imagine him to have faults; and farther, though thinking of him



<P>so much, and, as she sat drawing or working, forming a thousand



<P>amusing schemes for the progress and close of their attachment,



<P>fancying interesting dialogues, and inventing elegant letters;



<P>the conclusion of every imaginary declaration on his side was that she



<P>refused him.&nbsp; Their affection was always to subside into friendship.



<P>Every thing tender and charming was to mark their parting;



<P>but still they were to part.&nbsp; When she became sensible of this,



<P>it struck her that she could not be very much in love; for in spite



<P>of her previous and fixed determination never to quit her father,



<P>never to marry, a strong attachment certainly must produce more



<P>of a struggle than she could foresee in her own feelings.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not find myself making any use of the word sacrifice," said she.--



<P>"In not one of all my clever replies, my delicate negatives,



<P>is there any allusion to making a sacrifice.&nbsp; I do suspect that

he



<P>is not really necessary to my happiness.&nbsp; So much the better.



<P>I certainly will not persuade myself to feel more than I do.&nbsp; I

am



<P>quite enough in love.&nbsp; I should be sorry to be more."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Upon the whole, she was equally contented with her view of his feelings.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He is undoubtedly very much in love--every thing denotes it--very much



<P>in love indeed!--and when he comes again, if his affection continue,



<P>I must be on my guard not to encourage it.--It would be most



<P>inexcusable to do otherwise, as my own mind is quite made up.



<P>Not that I imagine he can think I have been encouraging him hitherto.



<P>No, if he had believed me at all to share his feelings, he would



<P>not have been so wretched.&nbsp; Could he have thought himself encouraged,



<P>his looks and language at parting would have been different.--



<P>Still, however, I must be on my guard.&nbsp; This is in the supposition



<P>of his attachment continuing what it now is; but I do not know that

I



<P>expect it will; I do not look upon him to be quite the sort of man--



<P>I do not altogether build upon his steadiness or constancy.--



<P>His feelings are warm, but I can imagine them rather changeable.--



<P>Every consideration of the subject, in short, makes me thankful



<P>that my happiness is not more deeply involved.--I shall do very well



<P>again after a little while--and then, it will be a good thing over;



<P>for they say every body is in love once in their lives, and I shall



<P>have been let off easily."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When his letter to Mrs. Weston arrived, Emma had the perusal of it;



<P>and she read it with a degree of pleasure and admiration which made



<P>her at first shake her head over her own sensations, and think she



<P>had undervalued their strength.&nbsp; It was a long, well-written letter,



<P>giving the particulars of his journey and of his feelings,



<P>expressing all the affection, gratitude, and respect which was



<P>natural and honourable, and describing every thing exterior and local



<P>that could be supposed attractive, with spirit and precision.



<P>No suspicious flourishes now of apology or concern; it was the



<P>language of real feeling towards Mrs. Weston; and the transition



<P>from Highbury to Enscombe, the contrast between the places in some



<P>of the first blessings of social life was just enough touched on



<P>to shew how keenly it was felt, and how much more might have been



<P>said but for the restraints of propriety.--The charm of her own



<P>name was not wanting.&nbsp; Miss Woodhouse appeared more than once,



<P>and never without a something of pleasing connexion, either a



<P>compliment to her taste, or a remembrance of what she had said;



<P>and in the very last time of its meeting her eye, unadorned as it



<P>was by any such broad wreath of gallantry, she yet could discern



<P>the effect of her influence and acknowledge the greatest compliment



<P>perhaps of all conveyed.&nbsp; Compressed into the very lowest vacant



<P>corner were these words--"I had not a spare moment on Tuesday,



<P>as you know, for Miss Woodhouse's beautiful little friend.&nbsp; Pray

make



<P>my excuses and adieus to her."&nbsp; This, Emma could not doubt, was

all



<P>for herself.&nbsp; Harriet was remembered only from being her friend.



<P>His information and prospects as to Enscombe were neither worse nor



<P>better than had been anticipated; Mrs. Churchill was recovering,



<P>and he dared not yet, even in his own imagination, fix a time for



<P>coming to Randalls again.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Gratifying, however, and stimulative as was the letter in the



<P>material part, its sentiments, she yet found, when it was folded up



<P>and returned to Mrs. Weston, that it had not added any lasting warmth,



<P>that she could still do without the writer, and that he must learn



<P>to do without her.&nbsp; Her intentions were unchanged.&nbsp; Her resolution



<P>of refusal only grew more interesting by the addition of a scheme for



<P>his subsequent consolation and happiness.&nbsp; His recollection of

Harriet,



<P>and the words which clothed it, the "beautiful little friend,"



<P>suggested to her the idea of Harriet's succeeding her in his affections.



<P>Was it impossible?--No.--Harriet undoubtedly was greatly his



<P>inferior in understanding; but he had been very much struck with



<P>the loveliness of her face and the warm simplicity of her manner;



<P>and all the probabilities of circumstance and connexion were in



<P>her favour.--For Harriet, it would be advantageous and delightful indeed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I must not dwell upon it," said she.--"I must not think of it.



<P>I know the danger of indulging such speculations.&nbsp; But stranger



<P>things have happened; and when we cease to care for each other



<P>as we do now, it will be the means of confirming us in that sort



<P>of true disinterested friendship which I can already look forward



<P>to with pleasure."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was well to have a comfort in store on Harriet's behalf,



<P>though it might be wise to let the fancy touch it seldom; for evil



<P>in that quarter was at hand.&nbsp; As Frank Churchill's arrival had



<P>succeeded Mr. Elton's engagement in the conversation of Highbury,



<P>as the latest interest had entirely borne down the first, so now



<P>upon Frank Churchill's disappearance, Mr. Elton's concerns were



<P>assuming the most irresistible form.--His wedding-day was named.



<P>He would soon be among them again; Mr. Elton and his bride.



<P>There was hardly time to talk over the first letter from Enscombe



<P>before "Mr. Elton and his bride" was in every body's mouth,



<P>and Frank Churchill was forgotten.&nbsp; Emma grew sick at the sound.



<P>She had had three weeks of happy exemption from Mr. Elton;



<P>and Harriet's mind, she had been willing to hope, had been lately



<P>gaining strength.&nbsp; With Mr. Weston's ball in view at least,



<P>there had been a great deal of insensibility to other things;



<P>but it was now too evident that she had not attained such a state



<P>of composure as could stand against the actual approach--new carriage,



<P>bell-ringing, and all.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Poor Harriet was in a flutter of spirits which required all the



<P>reasonings and soothings and attentions of every kind that Emma



<P>could give.&nbsp; Emma felt that she could not do too much for her,



<P>that Harriet had a right to all her ingenuity and all her patience;



<P>but it was heavy work to be for ever convincing without producing



<P>any effect, for ever agreed to, without being able to make their opinions



<P>the same.&nbsp; Harriet listened submissively, and said "it was very

true--



<P>it was just as Miss Woodhouse described--it was not worth while to



<P>think about them--and she would not think about them any longer"



<P>but no change of subject could avail, and the next half-hour



<P>saw her as anxious and restless about the Eltons as before.



<P>At last Emma attacked her on another ground.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Your allowing yourself to be so occupied and so unhappy about



<P>Mr. Elton's marrying, Harriet, is the strongest reproach you can



<P>make me.&nbsp; You could not give me a greater reproof for the mistake

I



<P>fell into.&nbsp; It was all my doing, I know.&nbsp; I have not forgotten

it,



<P>I assure you.--Deceived myself, I did very miserably deceive you--



<P>and it will be a painful reflection to me for ever.&nbsp; Do not imagine



<P>me in danger of forgetting it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet felt this too much to utter more than a few words



<P>of eager exclamation.&nbsp; Emma continued,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have not said, exert yourself Harriet for my sake; think less,



<P>talk less of Mr. Elton for my sake; because for your own sake rather,



<P>I would wish it to be done, for the sake of what is more important



<P>than my comfort, a habit of self-command in you, a consideration



<P>of what is your duty, an attention to propriety, an endeavour



<P>to avoid the suspicions of others, to save your health and credit,



<P>and restore your tranquillity.&nbsp; These are the motives which I



<P>have been pressing on you.&nbsp; They are very important--and sorry



<P>I am that you cannot feel them sufficiently to act upon them.



<P>My being saved from pain is a very secondary consideration.&nbsp; I

want



<P>you to save yourself from greater pain.&nbsp; Perhaps I may sometimes



<P>have felt that Harriet would not forget what was due--or rather



<P>what would be kind by me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This appeal to her affections did more than all the rest.



<P>The idea of wanting gratitude and consideration for Miss Woodhouse,
