<P>whom she really loved extremely, made her wretched for a while,



<P>and when the violence of grief was comforted away, still remained



<P>powerful enough to prompt to what was right and support her in it



<P>very tolerably.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You, who have been the best friend I ever had in my life--



<P>Want gratitude to you!--Nobody is equal to you!--I care for nobody



<P>as I do for you!--Oh!&nbsp; Miss Woodhouse, how ungrateful I have been!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Such expressions, assisted as they were by every thing that look



<P>and manner could do, made Emma feel that she had never loved Harriet



<P>so well, nor valued her affection so highly before.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There is no charm equal to tenderness of heart," said she



<P>afterwards to herself.&nbsp; "There is nothing to be compared to it.



<P>Warmth and tenderness of heart, with an affectionate, open manner,



<P>will beat all the clearness of head in the world, for attraction,



<P>I am sure it will.&nbsp; It is tenderness of heart which makes my dear



<P>father so generally beloved--which gives Isabella all her popularity.--



<P>I have it not--but I know how to prize and respect it.--Harriet is



<P>my superior in all the charm and all the felicity it gives.



<P>Dear Harriet!--I would not change you for the clearest-headed,



<P>longest-sighted, best-judging female breathing.&nbsp; Oh! the coldness



<P>of a Jane Fairfax!--Harriet is worth a hundred such--And for a wife--



<P>a sensible man's wife--it is invaluable.&nbsp; I mention no names;



<P>but happy the man who changes Emma for Harriet!"



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 07</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER VII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Emma's very good opinion of Frank Churchill was a little shaken



<P>the following day, by hearing that he was gone off to London,



<P>merely to have his hair cut.&nbsp; A sudden freak seemed to have seized

him



<P>at breakfast, and he had sent for a chaise and set off, intending to



<P>return to dinner, but with no more important view that appeared than



<P>having his hair cut.&nbsp; There was certainly no harm in his travelling



<P>sixteen miles twice over on such an errand; but there was an air



<P>of foppery and nonsense in it which she could not approve.&nbsp; It

did



<P>not accord with the rationality of plan, the moderation in expense,



<P>or even the unselfish warmth of heart, which she had believed herself



<P>to discern in him yesterday.&nbsp; Vanity, extravagance, love of change,



<P>restlessness of temper, which must be doing something, good or bad;



<P>heedlessness as to the pleasure of his father and Mrs. Weston,



<P>indifferent as to how his conduct might appear in general; he became



<P>liable to all these charges.&nbsp; His father only called him a coxcomb,



<P>and thought it a very good story; but that Mrs. Weston did not like

it,



<P>was clear enough, by her passing it over as quickly as possible,



<P>and making no other comment than that "all young people would have



<P>their little whims."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>With the exception of this little blot, Emma found that his visit



<P>hitherto had given her friend only good ideas of him.&nbsp; Mrs. Weston



<P>was very ready to say how attentive and pleasant a companion he



<P>made himself--how much she saw to like in his disposition altogether.



<P>He appeared to have a very open temper--certainly a very cheerful



<P>and lively one; she could observe nothing wrong in his notions,



<P>a great deal decidedly right; he spoke of his uncle with warm regard,



<P>was fond of talking of him--said he would be the best man in the



<P>world if he were left to himself; and though there was no being



<P>attached to the aunt, he acknowledged her kindness with gratitude,



<P>and seemed to mean always to speak of her with respect.



<P>This was all very promising; and, but for such an unfortunate fancy



<P>for having his hair cut, there was nothing to denote him unworthy



<P>of the distinguished honour which her imagination had given him;



<P>the honour, if not of being really in love with her, of being



<P>at least very near it, and saved only by her own indifference--



<P>(for still her resolution held of never marrying)--the honour, in short,



<P>of being marked out for her by all their joint acquaintance.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Weston, on his side, added a virtue to the account which must



<P>have some weight.&nbsp; He gave her to understand that Frank admired



<P>her extremely--thought her very beautiful and very charming;



<P>and with so much to be said for him altogether, she found she must



<P>not judge him harshly.&nbsp; As Mrs. Weston observed, "all young people



<P>would have their little whims."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was one person among his new acquaintance in Surry, not so



<P>leniently disposed.&nbsp; In general he was judged, throughout the parishes



<P>of Donwell and Highbury, with great candour; liberal allowances



<P>were made for the little excesses of such a handsome young man--



<P>one who smiled so often and bowed so well; but there was one spirit



<P>among them not to be softened, from its power of censure, by bows



<P>or smiles--Mr. Knightley.&nbsp; The circumstance was told him at Hartfield;



<P>for the moment, he was silent; but Emma heard him almost immediately



<P>afterwards say to himself, over a newspaper he held in his hand,



<P>"Hum! just the trifling, silly fellow I took him for."&nbsp; She had



<P>half a mind to resent; but an instant's observation convinced



<P>her that it was really said only to relieve his own feelings,



<P>and not meant to provoke; and therefore she let it pass.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Although in one instance the bearers of not good tidings,



<P>Mr. and Mrs. Weston's visit this morning was in another respect



<P>particularly opportune.&nbsp; Something occurred while they were



<P>at Hartfield, to make Emma want their advice; and, which was



<P>still more lucky, she wanted exactly the advice they gave.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This was the occurrence:--The Coles had been settled some years



<P>in Highbury, and were very good sort of people--friendly, liberal,



<P>and unpretending; but, on the other hand, they were of low origin,



<P>in trade, and only moderately genteel.&nbsp; On their first coming into



<P>the country, they had lived in proportion to their income, quietly,



<P>keeping little company, and that little unexpensively; but the last



<P>year or two had brought them a considerable increase of means--



<P>the house in town had yielded greater profits, and fortune in general



<P>had smiled on them.&nbsp; With their wealth, their views increased;



<P>their want of a larger house, their inclination for more company.



<P>They added to their house, to their number of servants,



<P>to their expenses of every sort; and by this time were, in fortune



<P>and style of living, second only to the family at Hartfield.



<P>Their love of society, and their new dining-room, prepared every body



<P>for their keeping dinner-company; and a few parties, chiefly among



<P>the single men, had already taken place.&nbsp; The regular and best



<P>families Emma could hardly suppose they would presume to invite--



<P>neither Donwell, nor Hartfield, nor Randalls.&nbsp; Nothing should



<P>tempt her to go, if they did; and she regretted that her father's



<P>known habits would be giving her refusal less meaning than she



<P>could wish.&nbsp; The Coles were very respectable in their way, but

they



<P>ought to be taught that it was not for them to arrange the terms



<P>on which the superior families would visit them.&nbsp; This lesson,



<P>she very much feared, they would receive only from herself;



<P>she had little hope of Mr. Knightley, none of Mr. Weston.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But she had made up her mind how to meet this presumption so many



<P>weeks before it appeared, that when the insult came at last,



<P>it found her very differently affected.&nbsp; Donwell and Randalls



<P>had received their invitation, and none had come for her father



<P>and herself; and Mrs. Weston's accounting for it with "I suppose



<P>they will not take the liberty with you; they know you do not



<P>dine out," was not quite sufficient.&nbsp; She felt that she should



<P>like to have had the power of refusal; and afterwards, as the idea



<P>of the party to be assembled there, consisting precisely of those



<P>whose society was dearest to her, occurred again and again,



<P>she did not know that she might not have been tempted to accept.



<P>Harriet was to be there in the evening, and the Bateses.&nbsp; They

had



<P>been speaking of it as they walked about Highbury the day before,



<P>and Frank Churchill had most earnestly lamented her absence.



<P>Might not the evening end in a dance? had been a question of his.



<P>The bare possibility of it acted as a farther irritation on her spirits;



<P>and her being left in solitary grandeur, even supposing the omission



<P>to be intended as a compliment, was but poor comfort.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was the arrival of this very invitation while the Westons were



<P>at Hartfield, which made their presence so acceptable; for though her



<P>first remark, on reading it, was that "of course it must be declined,"



<P>she so very soon proceeded to ask them what they advised her to do,



<P>that their advice for her going was most prompt and successful.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She owned that, considering every thing, she was not absolutely



<P>without inclination for the party.&nbsp; The Coles expressed themselves



<P>so properly--there was so much real attention in the manner of it--



<P>so much consideration for her father.&nbsp; "They would have solicited

the



<P>honour earlier, but had been waiting the arrival of a folding-screen



<P>from London, which they hoped might keep Mr. Woodhouse from any draught



<P>of air, and therefore induce him the more readily to give them the



<P>honour of his company.&nbsp; "Upon the whole, she was very persuadable;



<P>and it being briefly settled among themselves how it might be



<P>done without neglecting his comfort--how certainly Mrs. Goddard,



<P>if not Mrs. Bates, might be depended on for bearing him company--



<P>Mr. Woodhouse was to be talked into an acquiescence of his daughter's



<P>going out to dinner on a day now near at hand, and spending



<P>the whole evening away from him.&nbsp; As for his going, Emma did



<P>not wish him to think it possible, the hours would be too late,



<P>and the party too numerous.&nbsp; He was soon pretty well resigned.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am not fond of dinner-visiting," said he--"I never was.



<P>No more is Emma.&nbsp; Late hours do not agree with us.&nbsp; I am sorry



<P>Mr. and Mrs. Cole should have done it.&nbsp; I think it would be



<P>much better if they would come in one afternoon next summer,



<P>and take their tea with us--take us in their afternoon walk;



<P>which they might do, as our hours are so reasonable, and yet get home



<P>without being out in the damp of the evening.&nbsp; The dews of a summer



<P>evening are what I would not expose any body to.&nbsp; However, as they



<P>are so very desirous to have dear Emma dine with them, and as you



<P>will both be there, and Mr. Knightley too, to take care of her,



<P>I cannot wish to prevent it, provided the weather be what it ought,



<P>neither damp, nor cold, nor windy."&nbsp; Then turning to Mrs. Weston,



<P>with a look of gentle reproach--"Ah!&nbsp; Miss Taylor, if you had



<P>not married, you would have staid at home with me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, sir," cried Mr. Weston, "as I took Miss Taylor away,



<P>it is incumbent on me to supply her place, if I can; and I will



<P>step to Mrs. Goddard in a moment, if you wish it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But the idea of any thing to be done in a moment, was increasing,



<P>not lessening, Mr. Woodhouse's agitation.&nbsp; The ladies knew better



<P>how to allay it.&nbsp; Mr. Weston must be quiet, and every thing



<P>deliberately arranged.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>With this treatment, Mr. Woodhouse was soon composed enough



<P>for talking as usual.&nbsp; "He should be happy to see Mrs. Goddard.



<P>He had a great regard for Mrs. Goddard; and Emma should write a line,



<P>and invite her.&nbsp; James could take the note.&nbsp; But first of

all,



<P>there must be an answer written to Mrs. Cole."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You will make my excuses, my dear, as civilly as possible.&nbsp; You

will



<P>say that I am quite an invalid, and go no where, and therefore must



<P>decline their obliging invitation; beginning with my compliments,



<P>of course.&nbsp; But you will do every thing right.&nbsp; I need not

tell you



<P>what is to be done.&nbsp; We must remember to let James know that the

carriage



<P>will be wanted on Tuesday.&nbsp; I shall have no fears for you with

him.



<P>We have never been there above once since the new approach was made;



<P>but still I have no doubt that James will take you very safely.



<P>And when you get there, you must tell him at what time you would



<P>have him come for you again; and you had better name an early hour.



<P>You will not like staying late.&nbsp; You will get very tired when tea



<P>is over."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But you would not wish me to come away before I am tired, papa?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! no, my love; but you will soon be tired.&nbsp; There will be



<P>a great many people talking at once.&nbsp; You will not like the noise."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But, my dear sir," cried Mr. Weston, "if Emma comes away early,



<P>it will be breaking up the party."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And no great harm if it does," said Mr. Woodhouse.&nbsp; "The sooner



<P>every party breaks up, the better."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But you do not consider how it may appear to the Coles.



<P>Emma's going away directly after tea might be giving offence.



<P>They are good-natured people, and think little of their own claims;



<P>but still they must feel that any body's hurrying away is no



<P>great compliment; and Miss Woodhouse's doing it would be more thought



<P>of than any other person's in the room.&nbsp; You would not wish to

disappoint



<P>and mortify the Coles, I am sure, sir; friendly, good sort of people



<P>as ever lived, and who have been your neighbours these ten years."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, upon no account in the world, Mr. Weston; I am much obliged



<P>to you for reminding me.&nbsp; I should be extremely sorry to be giving



<P>them any pain.&nbsp; I know what worthy people they are.&nbsp; Perry

tells



<P>me that Mr. Cole never touches malt liquor.&nbsp; You would not think



<P>it to look at him, but he is bilious--Mr. Cole is very bilious.



<P>No, I would not be the means of giving them any pain.&nbsp; My dear

Emma,



<P>we must consider this.&nbsp; I am sure, rather than run the risk of

hurting



<P>Mr. and Mrs. Cole, you would stay a little longer than you might wish.



<P>You will not regard being tired.&nbsp; You will be perfectly safe,



<P>you know, among your friends."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh yes, papa.&nbsp; I have no fears at all for myself; and I should

have



<P>no scruples of staying as late as Mrs. Weston, but on your account.



<P>I am only afraid of your sitting up for me.&nbsp; I am not afraid



<P>of your not being exceedingly comfortable with Mrs. Goddard.



<P>She loves piquet, you know; but when she is gone home, I am afraid



<P>you will be sitting up by yourself, instead of going to bed at your



<P>usual time--and the idea of that would entirely destroy my comfort.



<P>You must promise me not to sit up."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He did, on the condition of some promises on her side:&nbsp; such as

that,



<P>if she came home cold, she would be sure to warm herself thoroughly;



<P>if hungry, that she would take something to eat; that her own maid



<P>should sit up for her; and that Serle and the butler should see



<P>that every thing were safe in the house, as usual.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 06</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER VI</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>The next morning brought Mr. Frank Churchill again.&nbsp; He came with



<P>Mrs. Weston, to whom and to Highbury he seemed to take very cordially.



<P>He had been sitting with her, it appeared, most companionably at home,



<P>till her usual hour of exercise; and on being desired to chuse



<P>their walk, immediately fixed on Highbury.--"He did not doubt there



<P>being very pleasant walks in every direction, but if left to him,



<P>he should always chuse the same.&nbsp; Highbury, that airy, cheerful,



<P>happy-looking Highbury, would be his constant attraction."--



<P>Highbury, with Mrs. Weston, stood for Hartfield; and she trusted to



<P>its bearing the same construction with him.&nbsp; They walked thither

directly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma had hardly expected them:&nbsp; for Mr. Weston, who had called

in



<P>for half a minute, in order to hear that his son was very handsome,



<P>knew nothing of their plans; and it was an agreeable surprize



<P>to her, therefore, to perceive them walking up to the house together,



<P>arm in arm.&nbsp; She was wanting to see him again, and especially



<P>to see him in company with Mrs. Weston, upon his behaviour to whom



<P>her opinion of him was to depend.&nbsp; If he were deficient there,



<P>nothing should make amends for it.&nbsp; But on seeing them together,



<P>she became perfectly satisfied.&nbsp; It was not merely in fine words



<P>or hyperbolical compliment that he paid his duty; nothing could be



<P>more proper or pleasing than his whole manner to her--nothing could



<P>more agreeably denote his wish of considering her as a friend and



<P>securing her affection.&nbsp; And there was time enough for Emma to

form a



<P>reasonable judgment, as their visit included all the rest of the morning.



<P>They were all three walking about together for an hour or two--



<P>first round the shrubberies of Hartfield, and afterwards in Highbury.



<P>He was delighted with every thing; admired Hartfield sufficiently



<P>for Mr. Woodhouse's ear; and when their going farther was resolved on,



<P>confessed his wish to be made acquainted with the whole village,



<P>and found matter of commendation and interest much oftener than Emma



<P>could have supposed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Some of the objects of his curiosity spoke very amiable feelings.



<P>He begged to be shewn the house which his father had lived in so long,



<P>and which had been the home of his father's father; and on recollecting



<P>that an old woman who had nursed him was still living, walked in quest



<P>of her cottage from one end of the street to the other; and though



<P>in some points of pursuit or observation there was no positive merit,



<P>they shewed, altogether, a good-will towards Highbury in general,



<P>which must be very like a merit to those he was with.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma watched and decided, that with such feelings as were now shewn,



<P>it could not be fairly supposed that he had been ever voluntarily



<P>absenting himself; that he had not been acting a part, or making



<P>a parade of insincere professions; and that Mr. Knightley certainly



<P>had not done him justice.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Their first pause was at the Crown Inn, an inconsiderable house,



<P>though the principal one of the sort, where a couple of pair of



<P>post-horses were kept, more for the convenience of the neighbourhood



<P>than from any run on the road; and his companions had not expected



<P>to be detained by any interest excited there; but in passing it they



<P>gave the history of the large room visibly added; it had been built



<P>many years ago for a ball-room, and while the neighbourhood had been



<P>in a particularly populous, dancing state, had been occasionally used



<P>as such;--but such brilliant days had long passed away, and now the



<P>highest purpose for which it was ever wanted was to accommodate a whist



<P>club established among the gentlemen and half-gentlemen of the place.



<P>He was immediately interested.&nbsp; Its character as a ball-room caught

him;



<P>and instead of passing on, he stopt for several minutes at the two



<P>superior sashed windows which were open, to look in and contemplate



<P>its capabilities, and lament that its original purpose should



<P>have ceased.&nbsp; He saw no fault in the room, he would acknowledge



<P>none which they suggested.&nbsp; No, it was long enough, broad enough,



<P>handsome enough.&nbsp; It would hold the very number for comfort.



<P>They ought to have balls there at least every fortnight through



<P>the winter.&nbsp; Why had not Miss Woodhouse revived the former good



<P>old days of the room?--She who could do any thing in Highbury!



<P>The want of proper families in the place, and the conviction



<P>that none beyond the place and its immediate environs could be



<P>tempted to attend, were mentioned; but he was not satisfied.



<P>He could not be persuaded that so many good-looking houses as he saw



<P>around him, could not furnish numbers enough for such a meeting;



<P>and even when particulars were given and families described, he was



<P>still unwilling to admit that the inconvenience of such a mixture



<P>would be any thing, or that there would be the smallest difficulty



<P>in every body's returning into their proper place the next morning.



<P>He argued like a young man very much bent on dancing; and Emma



<P>was rather surprized to see the constitution of the Weston prevail



<P>so decidedly against the habits of the Churchills.&nbsp; He seemed to

have



<P>all the life and spirit, cheerful feelings, and social inclinations



<P>of his father, and nothing of the pride or reserve of Enscombe.



<P>Of pride, indeed, there was, perhaps, scarcely enough; his indifference



<P>to a confusion of rank, bordered too much on inelegance of mind.



<P>He could be no judge, however, of the evil he was holding cheap.



<P>It was but an effusion of lively spirits.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>At last he was persuaded to move on from the front of the Crown;



<P>and being now almost facing the house where the Bateses lodged,



<P>Emma recollected his intended visit the day before, and asked him



<P>if he had paid it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, oh! yes"--he replied; "I was just going to mention it.



<P>A very successful visit:--I saw all the three ladies; and felt very



<P>much obliged to you for your preparatory hint.&nbsp; If the talking

aunt



<P>had taken me quite by surprize, it must have been the death of me.



<P>As it was, I was only betrayed into paying a most unreasonable visit.



<P>Ten minutes would have been all that was necessary, perhaps all that



<P>was proper; and I had told my father I should certainly be at home



<P>before him--but there was no getting away, no pause; and, to my



<P>utter astonishment, I found, when he (finding me nowhere else)



<P>joined me there at last, that I had been actually sitting with them



<P>very nearly three-quarters of an hour.&nbsp; The good lady had not given

me



<P>the possibility of escape before."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And how did you think Miss Fairfax looking?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ill, very ill--that is, if a young lady can ever be allowed to look

ill.



<P>But the expression is hardly admissible, Mrs. Weston, is it?



<P>Ladies can never look ill.&nbsp; And, seriously, Miss Fairfax is naturally



<P>so pale, as almost always to give the appearance of ill health.--



<P>A most deplorable want of complexion."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma would not agree to this, and began a warm defence of Miss



<P>Fairfax's complexion.&nbsp; "It was certainly never brilliant, but she



<P>would not allow it to have a sickly hue in general; and there was



<P>a softness and delicacy in her skin which gave peculiar elegance



<P>to the character of her face."&nbsp; He listened with all due deference;



<P>acknowledged that he had heard many people say the same--but yet he



<P>must confess, that to him nothing could make amends for the want



<P>of the fine glow of health.&nbsp; Where features were indifferent,



<P>a fine complexion gave beauty to them all; and where they were good,



<P>the effect was--fortunately he need not attempt to describe what the



<P>effect was.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well," said Emma, "there is no disputing about taste.--At least



<P>you admire her except her complexion."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He shook his head and laughed.--"I cannot separate Miss Fairfax



<P>and her complexion."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Did you see her often at Weymouth?&nbsp; Were you often in the same

society?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>At this moment they were approaching Ford's, and he hastily exclaimed,



<P>"Ha! this must be the very shop that every body attends every day



<P>of their lives, as my father informs me.&nbsp; He comes to Highbury

himself,



<P>he says, six days out of the seven, and has always business at Ford's.



<P>If it be not inconvenient to you, pray let us go in, that I may prove



<P>myself to belong to the place, to be a true citizen of Highbury.



<P>I must buy something at Ford's. It will be taking out my freedom.--



<P>I dare say they sell gloves."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! yes, gloves and every thing.&nbsp; I do admire your patriotism.



<P>You will be adored in Highbury.&nbsp; You were very popular before you

came,



<P>because you were Mr. Weston's son--but lay out half a guinea at



<P>Ford's, and your popularity will stand upon your own virtues."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They went in; and while the sleek, well-tied parcels of "Men's Beavers"



<P>and "York Tan" were bringing down and displaying on the counter,



<P>he said--"But I beg your pardon, Miss Woodhouse, you were speaking



<P>to me, you were saying something at the very moment of this burst



<P>of my amor patriae.&nbsp; Do not let me lose it.&nbsp; I assure you

the utmost



<P>stretch of public fame would not make me amends for the loss of any



<P>happiness in private life."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I merely asked, whether you had known much of Miss Fairfax



<P>and her party at Weymouth."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And now that I understand your question, I must pronounce it to be

a



<P>very unfair one.&nbsp; It is always the lady's right to decide on the

degree



<P>of acquaintance.&nbsp; Miss Fairfax must already have given her account.--



<P>I shall not commit myself by claiming more than she may chuse to allow."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Upon my word! you answer as discreetly as she could do herself.



<P>But her account of every thing leaves so much to be guessed,



<P>she is so very reserved, so very unwilling to give the least



<P>information about any body, that I really think you may say what you



<P>like of your acquaintance with her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"May I, indeed?--Then I will speak the truth, and nothing suits me



<P>so well.&nbsp; I met her frequently at Weymouth.&nbsp; I had known the

Campbells



<P>a little in town; and at Weymouth we were very much in the same set.



<P>Colonel Campbell is a very agreeable man, and Mrs. Campbell a friendly,



<P>warm-hearted woman.&nbsp; I like them all."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You know Miss Fairfax's situation in life, I conclude; what she



<P>is destined to be?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes--(rather hesitatingly)--I believe I do."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You get upon delicate subjects, Emma," said Mrs. Weston smiling;



<P>"remember that I am here.--Mr. Frank Churchill hardly knows



<P>what to say when you speak of Miss Fairfax's situation in life.



<P>I will move a little farther off."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I certainly do forget to think of her," said Emma, "as having ever



<P>been any thing but my friend and my dearest friend."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He looked as if he fully understood and honoured such a sentiment.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When the gloves were bought, and they had quitted the shop again,



<P>"Did you ever hear the young lady we were speaking of, play?"



<P>said Frank Churchill.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ever hear her!" repeated Emma.&nbsp; "You forget how much she belongs



<P>to Highbury.&nbsp; I have heard her every year of our lives since we



<P>both began.&nbsp; She plays charmingly."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You think so, do you?--I wanted the opinion of some one who



<P>could really judge.&nbsp; She appeared to me to play well, that is,



<P>with considerable taste, but I know nothing of the matter myself.--



<P>I am excessively fond of music, but without the smallest skill



<P>or right of judging of any body's performance.--I have been used



<P>to hear her's admired; and I remember one proof of her being



<P>thought to play well:--a man, a very musical man, and in love



<P>with another woman--engaged to her--on the point of marriage--



<P>would yet never ask that other woman to sit down to the instrument,



<P>if the lady in question could sit down instead--never seemed



<P>to like to hear one if he could hear the other.&nbsp; That, I thought,



<P>in a man of known musical talent, was some proof."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Proof indeed!" said Emma, highly amused.--"Mr. Dixon is very musical,



<P>is he?&nbsp; We shall know more about them all, in half an hour, from

you,



<P>than Miss Fairfax would have vouchsafed in half a year."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, Mr. Dixon and Miss Campbell were the persons; and I thought



<P>it a very strong proof."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Certainly--very strong it was; to own the truth, a great deal



<P>stronger than, if I had been Miss Campbell, would have been at all



<P>agreeable to me.&nbsp; I could not excuse a man's having more music



<P>than love--more ear than eye--a more acute sensibility to fine



<P>sounds than to my feelings.&nbsp; How did Miss Campbell appear to like

it?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It was her very particular friend, you know."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Poor comfort!" said Emma, laughing.&nbsp; "One would rather have a

stranger



<P>preferred than one's very particular friend--with a stranger it might



<P>not recur again--but the misery of having a very particular friend



<P>always at hand, to do every thing better than one does oneself!--



<P>Poor Mrs. Dixon!&nbsp; Well, I am glad she is gone to settle in Ireland."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are right.&nbsp; It was not very flattering to Miss Campbell;



<P>but she really did not seem to feel it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So much the better--or so much the worse:--I do not know which.



<P>But be it sweetness or be it stupidity in her--quickness of friendship,



<P>or dulness of feeling--there was one person, I think, who must have



<P>felt it:&nbsp; Miss Fairfax herself.&nbsp; She must have felt the improper



<P>and dangerous distinction."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"As to that--I do not--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! do not imagine that I expect an account of Miss Fairfax's



<P>sensations from you, or from any body else.&nbsp; They are known to

no



<P>human being, I guess, but herself.&nbsp; But if she continued to play



<P>whenever she was asked by Mr. Dixon, one may guess what one chuses."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There appeared such a perfectly good understanding among them all--"



<P>he began rather quickly, but checking himself, added, "however, it



<P>is impossible for me to say on what terms they really were--



<P>how it might all be behind the scenes.&nbsp; I can only say that there



<P>was smoothness outwardly.&nbsp; But you, who have known Miss Fairfax

from



<P>a child, must be a better judge of her character, and of how she



<P>is likely to conduct herself in critical situations, than I can be."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have known her from a child, undoubtedly; we have been children



<P>and women together; and it is natural to suppose that we should



<P>be intimate,--that we should have taken to each other whenever



<P>she visited her friends.&nbsp; But we never did.&nbsp; I hardly know

how it



<P>has happened; a little, perhaps, from that wickedness on my side



<P>which was prone to take disgust towards a girl so idolized



<P>and so cried up as she always was, by her aunt and grandmother,



<P>and all their set.&nbsp; And then, her reserve--I never could attach



<P>myself to any one so completely reserved."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is a most repulsive quality, indeed," said he.&nbsp; "Oftentimes



<P>very convenient, no doubt, but never pleasing.&nbsp; There is safety



<P>in reserve, but no attraction.&nbsp; One cannot love a reserved person."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not till the reserve ceases towards oneself; and then the attraction



<P>may be the greater.&nbsp; But I must be more in want of a friend,



<P>or an agreeable companion, than I have yet been, to take



<P>the trouble of conquering any body's reserve to procure one.



<P>Intimacy between Miss Fairfax and me is quite out of the question.



<P>I have no reason to think ill of her--not the least--except that



<P>such extreme and perpetual cautiousness of word and manner,



<P>such a dread of giving a distinct idea about any body, is apt



<P>to suggest suspicions of there being something to conceal."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He perfectly agreed with her:&nbsp; and after walking together so long,



<P>and thinking so much alike, Emma felt herself so well acquainted with

him,



<P>that she could hardly believe it to be only their second meeting.



<P>He was not exactly what she had expected; less of the man of the



<P>world in some of his notions, less of the spoiled child of fortune,



<P>therefore better than she had expected.&nbsp; His ideas seemed more

moderate--



<P>his feelings warmer.&nbsp; She was particularly struck by his manner



<P>of considering Mr. Elton's house, which, as well as the church,



<P>he would go and look at, and would not join them in finding much



<P>fault with.&nbsp; No, he could not believe it a bad house; not such

a house



<P>as a man was to be pitied for having.&nbsp; If it were to be shared

with



<P>the woman he loved, he could not think any man to be pitied for having



<P>that house.&nbsp; There must be ample room in it for every real comfort.



<P>The man must be a blockhead who wanted more.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Weston laughed, and said he did not know what he was talking about.



<P>Used only to a large house himself, and without ever thinking how many



<P>advantages and accommodations were attached to its size, he could



<P>be no judge of the privations inevitably belonging to a small one.



<P>But Emma, in her own mind, determined that he did know what he



<P>was talking about, and that he shewed a very amiable inclination



<P>to settle early in life, and to marry, from worthy motives.



<P>He might not be aware of the inroads on domestic peace to be



<P>occasioned by no housekeeper's room, or a bad butler's pantry,



<P>but no doubt he did perfectly feel that Enscombe could not make



<P>him happy, and that whenever he were attached, he would willingly



<P>give up much of wealth to be allowed an early establishment.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 12</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>One thing only was wanting to make the prospect of the ball



<P>completely satisfactory to Emma--its being fixed for a day within



<P>the granted term of Frank Churchill's stay in Surry; for, in spite



<P>of Mr. Weston's confidence, she could not think it so very impossible



<P>that the Churchills might not allow their nephew to remain



<P>a day beyond his fortnight.&nbsp; But this was not judged feasible.



<P>The preparations must take their time, nothing could be properly



<P>ready till the third week were entered on, and for a few days they



<P>must be planning, proceeding and hoping in uncertainty--at the risk--



<P>in her opinion, the great risk, of its being all in vain.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Enscombe however was gracious, gracious in fact, if not in word.



<P>His wish of staying longer evidently did not please; but it was



<P>not opposed.&nbsp; All was safe and prosperous; and as the removal of

one



<P>solicitude generally makes way for another, Emma, being now certain



<P>of her ball, began to adopt as the next vexation Mr. Knightley's



<P>provoking indifference about it.&nbsp; Either because he did not



<P>dance himself, or because the plan had been formed without his



<P>being consulted, he seemed resolved that it should not interest him,



<P>determined against its exciting any present curiosity, or affording



<P>him any future amusement.&nbsp; To her voluntary communications Emma



<P>could get no more approving reply, than,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very well.&nbsp; If the Westons think it worth while to be at all this



<P>trouble for a few hours of noisy entertainment, I have nothing



<P>to say against it, but that they shall not chuse pleasures for me.--



<P>Oh! yes, I must be there; I could not refuse; and I will keep



<P>as much awake as I can; but I would rather be at home, looking over



<P>William Larkins's week's account; much rather, I confess.--



<P>Pleasure in seeing dancing!--not I, indeed--I never look at it--



<P>I do not know who does.--Fine dancing, I believe, like virtue,



<P>must be its own reward.&nbsp; Those who are standing by are usually



<P>thinking of something very different."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This Emma felt was aimed at her; and it made her quite angry.



<P>It was not in compliment to Jane Fairfax however that he was



<P>so indifferent, or so indignant; he was not guided by her feelings



<P>in reprobating the ball, for she enjoyed the thought of it



<P>to an extraordinary degree.&nbsp; It made her animated--open hearted--



<P>she voluntarily said;--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh!&nbsp; Miss Woodhouse, I hope nothing may happen to prevent the

ball.



<P>What a disappointment it would be!&nbsp; I do look forward to it, I

own,



<P>with very great pleasure."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was not to oblige Jane Fairfax therefore that he would have



<P>preferred the society of William Larkins.&nbsp; No!--she was more and

more



<P>convinced that Mrs. Weston was quite mistaken in that surmise.



<P>There was a great deal of friendly and of compassionate attachment



<P>on his side--but no love.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Alas! there was soon no leisure for quarrelling with Mr. Knightley.



<P>Two days of joyful security were immediately followed by the



<P>over-throw of every thing.&nbsp; A letter arrived from Mr. Churchill



<P>to urge his nephew's instant return.&nbsp; Mrs. Churchill was unwell--



<P>far too unwell to do without him; she had been in a very suffering



<P>state (so said her husband) when writing to her nephew two days before,



<P>though from her usual unwillingness to give pain, and constant



<P>habit of never thinking of herself, she had not mentioned it;



<P>but now she was too ill to trifle, and must entreat him to set off



<P>for Enscombe without delay.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The substance of this letter was forwarded to Emma, in a note



<P>from Mrs. Weston, instantly.&nbsp; As to his going, it was inevitable.



<P>He must be gone within a few hours, though without feeling any real



<P>alarm for his aunt, to lessen his repugnance.&nbsp; He knew her illnesses;



<P>they never occurred but for her own convenience.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Weston added, "that he could only allow himself time to



<P>hurry to Highbury, after breakfast, and take leave of the few



<P>friends there whom he could suppose to feel any interest in him;



<P>and that he might be expected at Hartfield very soon."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This wretched note was the finale of Emma's breakfast.&nbsp; When once



<P>it had been read, there was no doing any thing, but lament



<P>and exclaim.&nbsp; The loss of the ball--the loss of the young man--



<P>and all that the young man might be feeling!--It was too wretched!--



<P>Such a delightful evening as it would have been!--Every body so happy!



<P>and she and her partner the happiest!--"I said it would be so,"



<P>was the only consolation.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her father's feelings were quite distinct.&nbsp; He thought principally



<P>of Mrs. Churchill's illness, and wanted to know how she was treated;



<P>and as for the ball, it was shocking to have dear Emma disappointed;



<P>but they would all be safer at home.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma was ready for her visitor some time before he appeared;



<P>but if this reflected at all upon his impatience, his sorrowful



<P>look and total want of spirits when he did come might redeem him.



<P>He felt the going away almost too much to speak of it.&nbsp; His dejection



<P>was most evident.&nbsp; He sat really lost in thought for the first



<P>few minutes; and when rousing himself, it was only to say,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Of all horrid things, leave-taking is the worst."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But you will come again," said Emma.&nbsp; "This will not be your only



<P>visit to Randalls."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah!--(shaking his head)--the uncertainty of when I may be able



<P>to return!--I shall try for it with a zeal!--It will be the object



<P>of all my thoughts and cares!--and if my uncle and aunt go to town



<P>this spring--but I am afraid--they did not stir last spring--



<P>I am afraid it is a custom gone for ever."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Our poor ball must be quite given up."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah! that ball!--why did we wait for any thing?--why not seize the



<P>pleasure at once?--How often is happiness destroyed by preparation,



<P>foolish preparation!--You told us it would be so.--Oh!&nbsp; Miss Woodhouse,



<P>why are you always so right?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Indeed, I am very sorry to be right in this instance.&nbsp; I would



<P>much rather have been merry than wise."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If I can come again, we are still to have our ball.&nbsp; My father



<P>depends on it.&nbsp; Do not forget your engagement."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma looked graciously.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Such a fortnight as it has been!" he continued; "every day more



<P>precious and more delightful than the day before!--every day making



<P>me less fit to bear any other place.&nbsp; Happy those, who can remain



<P>at Highbury!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"As you do us such ample justice now," said Emma, laughing, "I will



<P>venture to ask, whether you did not come a little doubtfully at first?



<P>Do not we rather surpass your expectations?&nbsp; I am sure we do.



<P>I am sure you did not much expect to like us.&nbsp; You would not have

been



<P>so long in coming, if you had had a pleasant idea of Highbury."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He laughed rather consciously; and though denying the sentiment,



<P>Emma was convinced that it had been so.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And you must be off this very morning?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes; my father is to join me here:&nbsp; we shall walk back together,



<P>and I must be off immediately.&nbsp; I am almost afraid that every moment



<P>will bring him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not five minutes to spare even for your friends Miss Fairfax and



<P>Miss Bates?&nbsp; How unlucky!&nbsp; Miss Bates's powerful, argumentative

mind



<P>might have strengthened yours."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes--I have called there; passing the door, I thought it better.



<P>It was a right thing to do.&nbsp; I went in for three minutes, and was



<P>detained by Miss Bates's being absent.&nbsp; She was out; and I felt

it



<P>impossible not to wait till she came in.&nbsp; She is a woman that one

may,



<P>that one must laugh at; but that one would not wish to slight.



<P>It was better to pay my visit, then"--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He hesitated, got up, walked to a window.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"In short," said he, "perhaps, Miss Woodhouse--I think you can



<P>hardly be quite without suspicion"--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He looked at her, as if wanting to read her thoughts.&nbsp; She hardly



<P>knew what to say.&nbsp; It seemed like the forerunner of something



<P>absolutely serious, which she did not wish.&nbsp; Forcing herself



<P>to speak, therefore, in the hope of putting it by, she calmly said,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are quite in the right; it was most natural to pay your visit,

then"--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He was silent.&nbsp; She believed he was looking at her; probably reflecting



<P>on what she had said, and trying to understand the manner.



<P>She heard him sigh.&nbsp; It was natural for him to feel that he had



<P>cause to sigh.&nbsp; He could not believe her to be encouraging him.



<P>A few awkward moments passed, and he sat down again; and in a more



<P>determined manner said,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It was something to feel that all the rest of my time might be



<P>given to Hartfield.&nbsp; My regard for Hartfield is most warm"--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He stopt again, rose again, and seemed quite embarrassed.--



<P>He was more in love with her than Emma had supposed; and who can say



<P>how it might have ended, if his father had not made his appearance?



<P>Mr. Woodhouse soon followed; and the necessity of exertion made



<P>him composed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A very few minutes more, however, completed the present trial.



<P>Mr. Weston, always alert when business was to be done, and as



<P>incapable of procrastinating any evil that was inevitable,



<P>as of foreseeing any that was doubtful, said, "It was time to go;"



<P>and the young man, though he might and did sigh, could not but agree,



<P>to take leave.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I shall hear about you all," said he; that is my chief consolation.



<P>I shall hear of every thing that is going on among you.&nbsp; I have



<P>engaged Mrs. Weston to correspond with me.&nbsp; She has been so kind

as



<P>to promise it.&nbsp; Oh! the blessing of a female correspondent, when

one



<P>is really interested in the absent!--she will tell me every thing.



<P>In her letters I shall be at dear Highbury again."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A very friendly shake of the hand, a very earnest "Good-bye,"



<P>closed the speech, and the door had soon shut out Frank Churchill.



<P>Short had been the notice--short their meeting; he was gone; and Emma



<P>felt so sorry to part, and foresaw so great a loss to their little



<P>society from his absence as to begin to be afraid of being too sorry,



<P>and feeling it too much.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was a sad change.&nbsp; They had been meeting almost every day



<P>since his arrival.&nbsp; Certainly his being at Randalls had given



<P>great spirit to the last two weeks--indescribable spirit; the idea,



<P>the expectation of seeing him which every morning had brought,



<P>the assurance of his attentions, his liveliness, his manners!



<P>It had been a very happy fortnight, and forlorn must be the sinking



<P>from it into the common course of Hartfield days.&nbsp; To complete

every



<P>other recommendation, he had almost told her that he loved her.



<P>What strength, or what constancy of affection he might be subject to,



<P>was another point; but at present she could not doubt his having



<P>a decidedly warm admiration, a conscious preference of herself;



<P>and this persuasion, joined to all the rest, made her think that



<P>she must be a little in love with him, in spite of every previous



<P>determination against it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I certainly must," said she.&nbsp; "This sensation of listlessness,



<P>weariness, stupidity, this disinclination to sit down and employ myself,



<P>this feeling of every thing's being dull and insipid about the house!--



<P>I must be in love; I should be the oddest creature in the world if I



<P>were not--for a few weeks at least.&nbsp; Well! evil to some is always



<P>good to others.&nbsp; I shall have many fellow-mourners for the ball,



<P>if not for Frank Churchill; but Mr. Knightley will be happy.



<P>He may spend the evening with his dear William Larkins now if he likes."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Knightley, however, shewed no triumphant happiness.&nbsp; He could



<P>not say that he was sorry on his own account; his very cheerful look



<P>would have contradicted him if he had; but he said, and very steadily,



<P>that he was sorry for the disappointment of the others, and with



<P>considerable kindness added,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You, Emma, who have so few opportunities of dancing, you are really



<P>out of luck; you are very much out of luck!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was some days before she saw Jane Fairfax, to judge of her



<P>honest regret in this woeful change; but when they did meet,



<P>her composure was odious.&nbsp; She had been particularly unwell, however,



<P>suffering from headache to a degree, which made her aunt declare,



<P>that had the ball taken place, she did not think Jane could have



<P>attended it; and it was charity to impute some of her unbecoming



<P>indifference to the languor of ill-health.

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 08</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER VIII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Frank Churchill came back again; and if he kept his father's



<P>dinner waiting, it was not known at Hartfield; for Mrs. Weston



<P>was too anxious for his being a favourite with Mr. Woodhouse,



<P>to betray any imperfection which could be concealed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He came back, had had his hair cut, and laughed at himself with



<P>a very good grace, but without seeming really at all ashamed



<P>of what he had done.&nbsp; He had no reason to wish his hair longer,



<P>to conceal any confusion of face; no reason to wish the money unspent,



<P>to improve his spirits.&nbsp; He was quite as undaunted and as lively



<P>as ever; and, after seeing him, Emma thus moralised to herself:--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not know whether it ought to be so, but certainly silly things



<P>do cease to be silly if they are done by sensible people in an



<P>impudent way.&nbsp; Wickedness is always wickedness, but folly is not



<P>always folly.--It depends upon the character of those who handle it.



<P>Mr. Knightley, he is not a trifling, silly young man.&nbsp; If he were,



<P>he would have done this differently.&nbsp; He would either have gloried



<P>in the achievement, or been ashamed of it.&nbsp; There would have been



<P>either the ostentation of a coxcomb, or the evasions of a mind too



<P>weak to defend its own vanities.--No, I am perfectly sure that he



<P>is not trifling or silly."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>With Tuesday came the agreeable prospect of seeing him again,



<P>and for a longer time than hitherto; of judging of his general manners,



<P>and by inference, of the meaning of his manners towards herself;



<P>of guessing how soon it might be necessary for her to throw coldness



<P>into her air; and of fancying what the observations of all those



<P>might be, who were now seeing them together for the first time.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She meant to be very happy, in spite of the scene being laid at



<P>Mr. Cole's; and without being able to forget that among the failings



<P>of Mr. Elton, even in the days of his favour, none had disturbed



<P>her more than his propensity to dine with Mr. Cole.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her father's comfort was amply secured, Mrs. Bates as well as



<P>Mrs. Goddard being able to come; and her last pleasing duty,



<P>before she left the house, was to pay her respects to them as



<P>they sat together after dinner; and while her father was fondly



<P>noticing the beauty of her dress, to make the two ladies all



<P>the amends in her power, by helping them to large slices of cake



<P>and full glasses of wine, for whatever unwilling self-denial his



<P>care of their constitution might have obliged them to practise



<P>during the meal.--She had provided a plentiful dinner for them;



<P>she wished she could know that they had been allowed to eat it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She followed another carriage to Mr. Cole's door; and was pleased



<P>to see that it was Mr. Knightley's; for Mr. Knightley keeping



<P>no horses, having little spare money and a great deal of health,



<P>activity, and independence, was too apt, in Emma's opinion, to get



<P>about as he could, and not use his carriage so often as became



<P>the owner of Donwell Abbey.&nbsp; She had an opportunity now of speaking



<P>her approbation while warm from her heart, for he stopped to hand her

out.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"This is coming as you should do," said she; "like a gentleman.--



<P>I am quite glad to see you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He thanked her, observing, "How lucky that we should arrive at the same



<P>moment! for, if we had met first in the drawing-room, I doubt whether



<P>you would have discerned me to be more of a gentleman than usual.--



<P>You might not have distinguished how I came, by my look or manner."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes I should, I am sure I should.&nbsp; There is always a look of



<P>consciousness or bustle when people come in a way which they know



<P>to be beneath them.&nbsp; You think you carry it off very well, I dare

say,



<P>but with you it is a sort of bravado, an air of affected unconcern;



<P>I always observe it whenever I meet you under those circumstances.



<P>Now you have nothing to try for.&nbsp; You are not afraid of being



<P>supposed ashamed.&nbsp; You are not striving to look taller than any



<P>body else.&nbsp; Now I shall really be very happy to walk into the same



<P>room with you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nonsensical girl!" was his reply, but not at all in anger.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma had as much reason to be satisfied with the rest of the party



<P>as with Mr. Knightley.&nbsp; She was received with a cordial respect



<P>which could not but please, and given all the consequence she could



<P>wish for.&nbsp; When the Westons arrived, the kindest looks of love,



<P>the strongest of admiration were for her, from both husband and wife;



<P>the son approached her with a cheerful eagerness which marked



<P>her as his peculiar object, and at dinner she found him seated



<P>by her--and, as she firmly believed, not without some dexterity



<P>on his side.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The party was rather large, as it included one other family, a proper



<P>unobjectionable country family, whom the Coles had the advantage of



<P>naming among their acquaintance, and the male part of Mr. Cox's family,



<P>the lawyer of Highbury.&nbsp; The less worthy females were to come



<P>in the evening, with Miss Bates, Miss Fairfax, and Miss Smith;



<P>but already, at dinner, they were too numerous for any subject



<P>of conversation to be general; and, while politics and Mr. Elton



<P>were talked over, Emma could fairly surrender all her attention to



<P>the pleasantness of her neighbour.&nbsp; The first remote sound to which



<P>she felt herself obliged to attend, was the name of Jane Fairfax.



<P>Mrs. Cole seemed to be relating something of her that was expected to

be



<P>very interesting.&nbsp; She listened, and found it well worth listening

to.



<P>That very dear part of Emma, her fancy, received an amusing supply.



<P>Mrs. Cole was telling that she had been calling on Miss Bates,



<P>and as soon as she entered the room had been struck by the sight



<P>of a pianoforte--a very elegant looking instrument--not a grand,



<P>but a large-sized square pianoforte; and the substance of the story,



<P>the end of all the dialogue which ensued of surprize, and inquiry,



<P>and congratulations on her side, and explanations on Miss Bates's, was,



<P>that this pianoforte had arrived from Broadwood's the day before,



<P>to the great astonishment of both aunt and niece--entirely unexpected;



<P>that at first, by Miss Bates's account, Jane herself was quite at



<P>a loss, quite bewildered to think who could possibly have ordered it--



<P>but now, they were both perfectly satisfied that it could be from only



<P>one quarter;--of course it must be from Colonel Campbell.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"One can suppose nothing else," added Mrs. Cole, "and I was only



<P>surprized that there could ever have been a doubt.&nbsp; But Jane,



<P>it seems, had a letter from them very lately, and not a word was said



<P>about it.&nbsp; She knows their ways best; but I should not consider

their



<P>silence as any reason for their not meaning to make the present.



<P>They might chuse to surprize her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Cole had many to agree with her; every body who spoke on the



<P>subject was equally convinced that it must come from Colonel Campbell,



<P>and equally rejoiced that such a present had been made; and there



<P>were enough ready to speak to allow Emma to think her own way,



<P>and still listen to Mrs. Cole.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I declare, I do not know when I have heard any thing that has given



<P>me more satisfaction!--It always has quite hurt me that Jane Fairfax,



<P>who plays so delightfully, should not have an instrument.



<P>It seemed quite a shame, especially considering how many houses



<P>there are where fine instruments are absolutely thrown away.



<P>This is like giving ourselves a slap, to be sure! and it was



<P>but yesterday I was telling Mr. Cole, I really was ashamed



<P>to look at our new grand pianoforte in the drawing-room, while I



<P>do not know one note from another, and our little girls, who are



<P>but just beginning, perhaps may never make any thing of it;



<P>and there is poor Jane Fairfax, who is mistress of music, has not



<P>any thing of the nature of an instrument, not even the pitifullest



<P>old spinet in the world, to amuse herself with.--I was saying this



<P>to Mr. Cole but yesterday, and he quite agreed with me; only he



<P>is so particularly fond of music that he could not help indulging



<P>himself in the purchase, hoping that some of our good neighbours might



<P>be so obliging occasionally to put it to a better use than we can;



<P>and that really is the reason why the instrument was bought--



<P>or else I am sure we ought to be ashamed of it.--We are in great



<P>hopes that Miss Woodhouse may be prevailed with to try it this evening."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Woodhouse made the proper acquiescence; and finding that nothing



<P>more was to be entrapped from any communication of Mrs. Cole's,



<P>turned to Frank Churchill.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why do you smile?" said she.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nay, why do you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Me!--I suppose I smile for pleasure at Colonel Campbell's being



<P>so rich and so liberal.--It is a handsome present."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I rather wonder that it was never made before."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Perhaps Miss Fairfax has never been staying here so long before."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Or that he did not give her the use of their own instrument--



<P>which must now be shut up in London, untouched by any body."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That is a grand pianoforte, and he might think it too large



<P>for Mrs. Bates's house."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You may say what you chuse--but your countenance testifies



<P>that your thoughts on this subject are very much like mine."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not know.&nbsp; I rather believe you are giving me more credit

for



<P>acuteness than I deserve.&nbsp; I smile because you smile, and shall

probably



<P>suspect whatever I find you suspect; but at present I do not see what



<P>there is to question.&nbsp; If Colonel Campbell is not the person, who

can be?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What do you say to Mrs. Dixon?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mrs. Dixon! very true indeed.&nbsp; I had not thought of Mrs. Dixon.



<P>She must know as well as her father, how acceptable an instrument



<P>would be; and perhaps the mode of it, the mystery, the surprize,



<P>is more like a young woman's scheme than an elderly man's. It



<P>is Mrs. Dixon, I dare say.&nbsp; I told you that your suspicions would



<P>guide mine."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If so, you must extend your suspicions and comprehend Mr. Dixon



<P>in them."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mr. Dixon.--Very well.&nbsp; Yes, I immediately perceive that it must



<P>be the joint present of Mr. and Mrs. Dixon.&nbsp; We were speaking the



<P>other day, you know, of his being so warm an admirer of her performance."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, and what you told me on that head, confirmed an idea which I



<P>had entertained before.--I do not mean to reflect upon the good



<P>intentions of either Mr. Dixon or Miss Fairfax, but I cannot help



<P>suspecting either that, after making his proposals to her friend,



<P>he had the misfortune to fall in love with her, or that he became



<P>conscious of a little attachment on her side.&nbsp; One might guess



<P>twenty things without guessing exactly the right; but I am sure



<P>there must be a particular cause for her chusing to come to Highbury



<P>instead of going with the Campbells to Ireland.&nbsp; Here, she must

be



<P>leading a life of privation and penance; there it would have been



<P>all enjoyment.&nbsp; As to the pretence of trying her native air, I

look



<P>upon that as a mere excuse.--In the summer it might have passed;



<P>but what can any body's native air do for them in the months



<P>of January, February, and March?&nbsp; Good fires and carriages would



<P>be much more to the purpose in most cases of delicate health, and I



<P>dare say in her's. I do not require you to adopt all my suspicions,



<P>though you make so noble a profession of doing it, but I honestly



<P>tell you what they are."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And, upon my word, they have an air of great probability.



<P>Mr. Dixon's preference of her music to her friend's, I can answer



<P>for being very decided."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And then, he saved her life.&nbsp; Did you ever hear of that?--



<P>A water party; and by some accident she was falling overboard.



<P>He caught her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He did.&nbsp; I was there--one of the party."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Were you really?--Well!--But you observed nothing of course,



<P>for it seems to be a new idea to you.--If I had been there, I think



<P>I should have made some discoveries."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I dare say you would; but I, simple I, saw nothing but the fact,



<P>that Miss Fairfax was nearly dashed from the vessel and that Mr. Dixon



<P>caught her.--It was the work of a moment.&nbsp; And though the consequent



<P>shock and alarm was very great and much more durable--indeed I



<P>believe it was half an hour before any of us were comfortable again--



<P>yet that was too general a sensation for any thing of peculiar



<P>anxiety to be observable.&nbsp; I do not mean to say, however, that

you



<P>might not have made discoveries."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The conversation was here interrupted.&nbsp; They were called on to

share



<P>in the awkwardness of a rather long interval between the courses,



<P>and obliged to be as formal and as orderly as the others; but when



<P>the table was again safely covered, when every corner dish was placed



<P>exactly right, and occupation and ease were generally restored,



<P>Emma said,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The arrival of this pianoforte is decisive with me.&nbsp; I wanted

to know



<P>a little more, and this tells me quite enough.&nbsp; Depend upon it,



<P>we shall soon hear that it is a present from Mr. and Mrs. Dixon."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And if the Dixons should absolutely deny all knowledge of it we



<P>must conclude it to come from the Campbells."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, I am sure it is not from the Campbells.&nbsp; Miss Fairfax knows

it



<P>is not from the Campbells, or they would have been guessed at first.



<P>She would not have been puzzled, had she dared fix on them.



<P>I may not have convinced you perhaps, but I am perfectly convinced



<P>myself that Mr. Dixon is a principal in the business."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Indeed you injure me if you suppose me unconvinced.&nbsp; Your reasonings



<P>carry my judgment along with them entirely.&nbsp; At first, while I



<P>supposed you satisfied that Colonel Campbell was the giver, I saw



<P>it only as paternal kindness, and thought it the most natural thing



<P>in the world.&nbsp; But when you mentioned Mrs. Dixon, I felt how much

more



<P>probable that it should be the tribute of warm female friendship.



<P>And now I can see it in no other light than as an offering of love."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was no occasion to press the matter farther.&nbsp; The conviction



<P>seemed real; he looked as if he felt it.&nbsp; She said no more,



<P>other subjects took their turn; and the rest of the dinner passed away;



<P>the dessert succeeded, the children came in, and were talked



<P>to and admired amid the usual rate of conversation; a few clever



<P>things said, a few downright silly, but by much the larger proportion



<P>neither the one nor the other--nothing worse than everyday remarks,



<P>dull repetitions, old news, and heavy jokes.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The ladies had not been long in the drawing-room, before the other ladies,



<P>in their different divisions, arrived.&nbsp; Emma watched the entree

of her



<P>own particular little friend; and if she could not exult in her dignity



<P>and grace, she could not only love the blooming sweetness and the



<P>artless manner, but could most heartily rejoice in that light, cheerful,



<P>unsentimental disposition which allowed her so many alleviations



<P>of pleasure, in the midst of the pangs of disappointed affection.



<P>There she sat--and who would have guessed how many tears she had



<P>been lately shedding?&nbsp; To be in company, nicely dressed herself



<P>and seeing others nicely dressed, to sit and smile and look pretty,



<P>and say nothing, was enough for the happiness of the present hour.



<P>Jane Fairfax did look and move superior; but Emma suspected she



<P>might have been glad to change feelings with Harriet, very glad



<P>to have purchased the mortification of having loved--yes, of having



<P>loved even Mr. Elton in vain--by the surrender of all the dangerous



<P>pleasure of knowing herself beloved by the husband of her friend.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In so large a party it was not necessary that Emma should approach her.



<P>She did not wish to speak of the pianoforte, she felt too much



<P>in the secret herself, to think the appearance of curiosity



<P>or interest fair, and therefore purposely kept at a distance;



<P>but by the others, the subject was almost immediately introduced,



<P>and she saw the blush of consciousness with which congratulations



<P>were received, the blush of guilt which accompanied the name of "my



<P>excellent friend Colonel Campbell."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Weston, kind-hearted and musical, was particularly interested



<P>by the circumstance, and Emma could not help being amused at her



<P>perseverance in dwelling on the subject; and having so much to ask



<P>and to say as to tone, touch, and pedal, totally unsuspicious



<P>of that wish of saying as little about it as possible, which she



<P>plainly read in the fair heroine's countenance.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They were soon joined by some of the gentlemen; and the very first of

the



<P>early was Frank Churchill.&nbsp; In he walked, the first and the handsomest;



<P>and after paying his compliments en passant to Miss Bates and



<P>her niece, made his way directly to the opposite side of the circle,



<P>where sat Miss Woodhouse; and till he could find a seat by her,



<P>would not sit at all.&nbsp; Emma divined what every body present must



<P>be thinking.&nbsp; She was his object, and every body must perceive

it.



<P>She introduced him to her friend, Miss Smith, and, at convenient



<P>moments afterwards, heard what each thought of the other.&nbsp; "He

had



<P>never seen so lovely a face, and was delighted with her naivete."



<P>And she, "Only to be sure it was paying him too great a compliment,



<P>but she did think there were some looks a little like Mr. Elton."



<P>Emma restrained her indignation, and only turned from her in silence.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Smiles of intelligence passed between her and the gentleman on first



<P>glancing towards Miss Fairfax; but it was most prudent to avoid speech.



<P>He told her that he had been impatient to leave the dining-room--



<P>hated sitting long--was always the first to move when he could--



<P>that his father, Mr. Knightley, Mr. Cox, and Mr. Cole, were left



<P>very busy over parish business--that as long as he had staid,



<P>however, it had been pleasant enough, as he had found them in general



<P>a set of gentlemanlike, sensible men; and spoke so handsomely of



<P>Highbury altogether--thought it so abundant in agreeable families--



<P>that Emma began to feel she had been used to despise the place



<P>rather too much.&nbsp; She questioned him as to the society in Yorkshire--



<P>the extent of the neighbourhood about Enscombe, and the sort;



<P>and could make out from his answers that, as far as Enscombe



<P>was concerned, there was very little going on, that their visitings



<P>were among a range of great families, none very near; and that even



<P>when days were fixed, and invitations accepted, it was an even



<P>chance that Mrs. Churchill were not in health and spirits for going;



<P>that they made a point of visiting no fresh person; and that,



<P>though he had his separate engagements, it was not without difficulty,



<P>without considerable address at times, that he could get away,



<P>or introduce an acquaintance for a night.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She saw that Enscombe could not satisfy, and that Highbury,



<P>taken at its best, might reasonably please a young man who had more



<P>retirement at home than he liked.&nbsp; His importance at Enscombe was



<P>very evident.&nbsp; He did not boast, but it naturally betrayed itself,



<P>that he had persuaded his aunt where his uncle could do nothing,



<P>and on her laughing and noticing it, he owned that he believed (excepting



<P>one or two points) he could with time persuade her to any thing.



<P>One of those points on which his influence failed, he then mentioned.



<P>He had wanted very much to go abroad--had been very eager indeed



<P>to be allowed to travel--but she would not hear of it.&nbsp; This had



<P>happened the year before.&nbsp; Now, he said, he was beginning to have



<P>no longer the same wish.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The unpersuadable point, which he did not mention, Emma guessed



<P>to be good behaviour to his father.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have made a most wretched discovery," said he, after a short pause.--



<P>"I have been here a week to-morrow--half my time.&nbsp; I never knew



<P>days fly so fast.&nbsp; A week to-morrow!--And I have hardly begun to



<P>enjoy myself.&nbsp; But just got acquainted with Mrs. Weston, and others!--



<P>I hate the recollection."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Perhaps you may now begin to regret that you spent one whole day,



<P>out of so few, in having your hair cut."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No," said he, smiling, "that is no subject of regret at all.



<P>I have no pleasure in seeing my friends, unless I can believe myself



<P>fit to be seen."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The rest of the gentlemen being now in the room, Emma found herself



<P>obliged to turn from him for a few minutes, and listen to Mr. Cole.



<P>When Mr. Cole had moved away, and her attention could be restored



<P>as before, she saw Frank Churchill looking intently across the room



<P>at Miss Fairfax, who was sitting exactly opposite.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What is the matter?" said she.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He started.&nbsp; "Thank you for rousing me," he replied.&nbsp; "I believe



<P>I have been very rude; but really Miss Fairfax has done her hair



<P>in so odd a way--so very odd a way--that I cannot keep my eyes



<P>from her.&nbsp; I never saw any thing so outree!--Those curls!--This

must



<P>be a fancy of her own.&nbsp; I see nobody else looking like her!--



<P>I must go and ask her whether it is an Irish fashion.&nbsp; Shall I?--



<P>Yes, I will--I declare I will--and you shall see how she takes it;--



<P>whether she colours."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He was gone immediately; and Emma soon saw him standing before Miss



<P>Fairfax, and talking to her; but as to its effect on the young lady,



<P>as he had improvidently placed himself exactly between them, exactly



<P>in front of Miss Fairfax, she could absolutely distinguish nothing.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Before he could return to his chair, it was taken by Mrs. Weston.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"This is the luxury of a large party," said she:--"one can get



<P>near every body, and say every thing.&nbsp; My dear Emma, I am longing



<P>to talk to you.&nbsp; I have been making discoveries and forming plans,



<P>just like yourself, and I must tell them while the idea is fresh.



<P>Do you know how Miss Bates and her niece came here?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How?--They were invited, were not they?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! yes--but how they were conveyed hither?--the manner of their coming?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"They walked, I conclude.&nbsp; How else could they come?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very true.--Well, a little while ago it occurred to me how very sad



<P>it would be to have Jane Fairfax walking home again, late at night,



<P>and cold as the nights are now.&nbsp; And as I looked at her, though

I



<P>never saw her appear to more advantage, it struck me that she



<P>was heated, and would therefore be particularly liable to take cold.



<P>Poor girl!&nbsp; I could not bear the idea of it; so, as soon as Mr.

Weston



<P>came into the room, and I could get at him, I spoke to him about



<P>the carriage.&nbsp; You may guess how readily he came into my wishes;



<P>and having his approbation, I made my way directly to Miss Bates,



<P>to assure her that the carriage would be at her service before it took



<P>us home; for I thought it would be making her comfortable at once.



<P>Good soul! she was as grateful as possible, you may be sure.



<P>`Nobody was ever so fortunate as herself!'--but with many,



<P>many thanks--`there was no occasion to trouble us, for Mr. Knightley's



<P>carriage had brought, and was to take them home again.'&nbsp; I was



<P>quite surprized;--very glad, I am sure; but really quite surprized.



<P>Such a very kind attention--and so thoughtful an attention!--



<P>the sort of thing that so few men would think of.&nbsp; And, in short,



<P>from knowing his usual ways, I am very much inclined to think



<P>that it was for their accommodation the carriage was used at all.



<P>I do suspect he would not have had a pair of horses for himself,



<P>and that it was only as an excuse for assisting them."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very likely," said Emma--"nothing more likely.&nbsp; I know no man



<P>more likely than Mr. Knightley to do the sort of thing--to do any



<P>thing really good-natured, useful, considerate, or benevolent.



<P>He is not a gallant man, but he is a very humane one; and this,



<P>considering Jane Fairfax's ill-health, would appear a case



<P>of humanity to him;--and for an act of unostentatious kindness,



<P>there is nobody whom I would fix on more than on Mr. Knightley.



<P>I know he had horses to-day--for we arrived together; and I laughed

at



<P>him about it, but he said not a word that could betray."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well," said Mrs. Weston, smiling, "you give him credit for



<P>more simple, disinterested benevolence in this instance than I do;



<P>for while Miss Bates was speaking, a suspicion darted into my head,



<P>and I have never been able to get it out again.&nbsp; The more I think



<P>of it, the more probable it appears.&nbsp; In short, I have made a match



<P>between Mr. Knightley and Jane Fairfax.&nbsp; See the consequence



<P>of keeping you company!--What do you say to it?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mr. Knightley and Jane Fairfax!" exclaimed Emma.&nbsp; "Dear Mrs. Weston,



<P>how could you think of such a thing?--Mr. Knightley!--Mr. Knightley
