<P>must not marry!--You would not have little Henry cut out from Donwell?--



<P>Oh! no, no, Henry must have Donwell.&nbsp; I cannot at all consent to



<P>Mr. Knightley's marrying; and I am sure it is not at all likely.



<P>I am amazed that you should think of such a thing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear Emma, I have told you what led me to think of it.



<P>I do not want the match--I do not want to injure dear little Henry--



<P>but the idea has been given me by circumstances; and if Mr. Knightley



<P>really wished to marry, you would not have him refrain on Henry's



<P>account, a boy of six years old, who knows nothing of the matter?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, I would.&nbsp; I could not bear to have Henry supplanted.--



<P>Mr. Knightley marry!--No, I have never had such an idea, and I



<P>cannot adopt it now.&nbsp; And Jane Fairfax, too, of all women!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nay, she has always been a first favourite with him, as you



<P>very well know."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But the imprudence of such a match!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am not speaking of its prudence; merely its probability."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I see no probability in it, unless you have any better foundation



<P>than what you mention.&nbsp; His good-nature, his humanity, as I tell

you,



<P>would be quite enough to account for the horses.&nbsp; He has a great



<P>regard for the Bateses, you know, independent of Jane Fairfax--



<P>and is always glad to shew them attention.&nbsp; My dear Mrs. Weston,



<P>do not take to match-making.&nbsp; You do it very ill.&nbsp; Jane Fairfax

mistress



<P>of the Abbey!--Oh! no, no;--every feeling revolts.&nbsp; For his own

sake,



<P>I would not have him do so mad a thing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Imprudent, if you please--but not mad.&nbsp; Excepting inequality of

fortune,



<P>and perhaps a little disparity of age, I can see nothing unsuitable."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But Mr. Knightley does not want to marry.&nbsp; I am sure he has not

the



<P>least idea of it.&nbsp; Do not put it into his head.&nbsp; Why should

he marry?--



<P>He is as happy as possible by himself; with his farm, and his sheep,



<P>and his library, and all the parish to manage; and he is extremely



<P>fond of his brother's children.&nbsp; He has no occasion to marry,



<P>either to fill up his time or his heart."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear Emma, as long as he thinks so, it is so; but if he really



<P>loves Jane Fairfax--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nonsense!&nbsp; He does not care about Jane Fairfax.&nbsp; In the way



<P>of love, I am sure he does not.&nbsp; He would do any good to her,



<P>or her family; but--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well," said Mrs. Weston, laughing, "perhaps the greatest good he



<P>could do them, would be to give Jane such a respectable home."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If it would be good to her, I am sure it would be evil to himself;



<P>a very shameful and degrading connexion.&nbsp; How would he bear to

have



<P>Miss Bates belonging to him?--To have her haunting the Abbey,



<P>and thanking him all day long for his great kindness in marrying Jane?--



<P>`So very kind and obliging!--But he always had been such a very



<P>kind neighbour!'&nbsp; And then fly off, through half a sentence,



<P>to her mother's old petticoat.&nbsp; `Not that it was such a very old



<P>petticoat either--for still it would last a great while--and, indeed,



<P>she must thankfully say that their petticoats were all very strong.'"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"For shame, Emma!&nbsp; Do not mimic her.&nbsp; You divert me against



<P>my conscience.&nbsp; And, upon my word, I do not think Mr. Knightley

would



<P>be much disturbed by Miss Bates.&nbsp; Little things do not irritate

him.



<P>She might talk on; and if he wanted to say any thing himself, he would



<P>only talk louder, and drown her voice.&nbsp; But the question is not,



<P>whether it would be a bad connexion for him, but whether he wishes it;



<P>and I think he does.&nbsp; I have heard him speak, and so must you,



<P>so very highly of Jane Fairfax!&nbsp; The interest he takes in her--



<P>his anxiety about her health--his concern that she should have no



<P>happier prospect!&nbsp; I have heard him express himself so warmly on



<P>those points!--Such an admirer of her performance on the pianoforte,



<P>and of her voice!&nbsp; I have heard him say that he could listen to

her



<P>for ever.&nbsp; Oh! and I had almost forgotten one idea that occurred



<P>to me--this pianoforte that has been sent here by somebody--



<P>though we have all been so well satisfied to consider it a present



<P>from the Campbells, may it not be from Mr. Knightley?&nbsp; I cannot



<P>help suspecting him.&nbsp; I think he is just the person to do it,



<P>even without being in love."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then it can be no argument to prove that he is in love.



<P>But I do not think it is at all a likely thing for him to do.



<P>Mr. Knightley does nothing mysteriously."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have heard him lamenting her having no instrument repeatedly;



<P>oftener than I should suppose such a circumstance would, in the common



<P>course of things, occur to him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very well; and if he had intended to give her one, he would have



<P>told her so."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There might be scruples of delicacy, my dear Emma.&nbsp; I have a very



<P>strong notion that it comes from him.&nbsp; I am sure he was particularly



<P>silent when Mrs. Cole told us of it at dinner."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You take up an idea, Mrs. Weston, and run away with it; as you have



<P>many a time reproached me with doing.&nbsp; I see no sign of attachment--



<P>I believe nothing of the pianoforte--and proof only shall convince



<P>me that Mr. Knightley has any thought of marrying Jane Fairfax."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They combated the point some time longer in the same way; Emma rather



<P>gaining ground over the mind of her friend; for Mrs. Weston was



<P>the most used of the two to yield; till a little bustle in the room



<P>shewed them that tea was over, and the instrument in preparation;--



<P>and at the same moment Mr. Cole approaching to entreat Miss Woodhouse



<P>would do them the honour of trying it.&nbsp; Frank Churchill, of whom,



<P>in the eagerness of her conversation with Mrs. Weston, she had been



<P>seeing nothing, except that he had found a seat by Miss Fairfax,



<P>followed Mr. Cole, to add his very pressing entreaties; and as,



<P>in every respect, it suited Emma best to lead, she gave a very



<P>proper compliance.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She knew the limitations of her own powers too well to attempt



<P>more than she could perform with credit; she wanted neither taste



<P>nor spirit in the little things which are generally acceptable,



<P>and could accompany her own voice well.&nbsp; One accompaniment to her

song



<P>took her agreeably by surprize--a second, slightly but correctly



<P>taken by Frank Churchill.&nbsp; Her pardon was duly begged at the close



<P>of the song, and every thing usual followed.&nbsp; He was accused



<P>of having a delightful voice, and a perfect knowledge of music;



<P>which was properly denied; and that he knew nothing of the matter,



<P>and had no voice at all, roundly asserted.&nbsp; They sang together



<P>once more; and Emma would then resign her place to Miss Fairfax,



<P>whose performance, both vocal and instrumental, she never could



<P>attempt to conceal from herself, was infinitely superior to her own.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>With mixed feelings, she seated herself at a little distance from the



<P>numbers round the instrument, to listen.&nbsp; Frank Churchill sang

again.



<P>They had sung together once or twice, it appeared, at Weymouth.



<P>But the sight of Mr. Knightley among the most attentive, soon drew



<P>away half Emma's mind; and she fell into a train of thinking



<P>on the subject of Mrs. Weston's suspicions, to which the sweet



<P>sounds of the united voices gave only momentary interruptions.



<P>Her objections to Mr. Knightley's marrying did not in the least subside.



<P>She could see nothing but evil in it.&nbsp; It would be a great



<P>disappointment to Mr. John Knightley; consequently to Isabella.



<P>A real injury to the children--a most mortifying change,



<P>and material loss to them all;--a very great deduction from her



<P>father's daily comfort--and, as to herself, she could not at all



<P>endure the idea of Jane Fairfax at Donwell Abbey.&nbsp; A Mrs. Knightley



<P>for them all to give way to!--No--Mr. Knightley must never marry.



<P>Little Henry must remain the heir of Donwell.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Presently Mr. Knightley looked back, and came and sat down by her.



<P>They talked at first only of the performance.&nbsp; His admiration



<P>was certainly very warm; yet she thought, but for Mrs. Weston,



<P>it would not have struck her.&nbsp; As a sort of touchstone, however,



<P>she began to speak of his kindness in conveying the aunt and niece;



<P>and though his answer was in the spirit of cutting the matter short,



<P>she believed it to indicate only his disinclination to dwell on any



<P>kindness of his own.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I often feel concern," said she, "that I dare not make our carriage



<P>more useful on such occasions.&nbsp; It is not that I am without the

wish;



<P>but you know how impossible my father would deem it that James



<P>should put-to for such a purpose."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Quite out of the question, quite out of the question," he replied;--



<P>"but you must often wish it, I am sure."&nbsp; And he smiled with such



<P>seeming pleasure at the conviction, that she must proceed another step.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"This present from the Campbells," said she--"this pianoforte



<P>is very kindly given."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes," he replied, and without the smallest apparent embarrassment.--



<P>"But they would have done better had they given her notice of it.



<P>Surprizes are foolish things.&nbsp; The pleasure is not enhanced, and

the



<P>inconvenience is often considerable.&nbsp; I should have expected better



<P>judgment in Colonel Campbell."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>From that moment, Emma could have taken her oath that Mr. Knightley



<P>had had no concern in giving the instrument.&nbsp; But whether he



<P>were entirely free from peculiar attachment--whether there



<P>were no actual preference--remained a little longer doubtful.



<P>Towards the end of Jane's second song, her voice grew thick.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That will do," said he, when it was finished, thinking aloud--



<P>"you have sung quite enough for one evening--now be quiet."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Another song, however, was soon begged for.&nbsp; "One more;--they would



<P>not fatigue Miss Fairfax on any account, and would only ask for



<P>one more."&nbsp; And Frank Churchill was heard to say, "I think you

could



<P>manage this without effort; the first part is so very trifling.



<P>The strength of the song falls on the second."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Knightley grew angry.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That fellow," said he, indignantly, "thinks of nothing but shewing



<P>off his own voice.&nbsp; This must not be."&nbsp; And touching Miss

Bates,



<P>who at that moment passed near--"Miss Bates, are you mad, to let



<P>your niece sing herself hoarse in this manner?&nbsp; Go, and interfere.



<P>They have no mercy on her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Bates, in her real anxiety for Jane, could hardly stay even



<P>to be grateful, before she stept forward and put an end to all



<P>farther singing.&nbsp; Here ceased the concert part of the evening,



<P>for Miss Woodhouse and Miss Fairfax were the only young lady performers;



<P>but soon (within five minutes) the proposal of dancing--



<P>originating nobody exactly knew where--was so effectually promoted



<P>by Mr. and Mrs. Cole, that every thing was rapidly clearing away,



<P>to give proper space.&nbsp; Mrs. Weston, capital in her country-dances,



<P>was seated, and beginning an irresistible waltz; and Frank Churchill,



<P>coming up with most becoming gallantry to Emma, had secured her hand,



<P>and led her up to the top.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>While waiting till the other young people could pair themselves off,



<P>Emma found time, in spite of the compliments she was receiving on her



<P>voice and her taste, to look about, and see what became of Mr. Knightley.



<P>This would be a trial.&nbsp; He was no dancer in general.&nbsp; If he

were to be



<P>very alert in engaging Jane Fairfax now, it might augur something.



<P>There was no immediate appearance.&nbsp; No; he was talking to Mrs.

Cole--



<P>he was looking on unconcerned; Jane was asked by somebody else,



<P>and he was still talking to Mrs. Cole.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma had no longer an alarm for Henry; his interest was yet safe;



<P>and she led off the dance with genuine spirit and enjoyment.



<P>Not more than five couple could be mustered; but the rarity and the



<P>suddenness of it made it very delightful, and she found herself well



<P>matched in a partner.&nbsp; They were a couple worth looking at.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Two dances, unfortunately, were all that could be allowed.



<P>It was growing late, and Miss Bates became anxious to get home,



<P>on her mother's account.&nbsp; After some attempts, therefore, to be



<P>permitted to begin again, they were obliged to thank Mrs. Weston,



<P>look sorrowful, and have done.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Perhaps it is as well," said Frank Churchill, as he attended Emma



<P>to her carriage.&nbsp; "I must have asked Miss Fairfax, and her languid



<P>dancing would not have agreed with me, after your's."



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 09</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER IX</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Emma did not repent her condescension in going to the Coles.



<P>The visit afforded her many pleasant recollections the next day;



<P>and all that she might be supposed to have lost on the side



<P>of dignified seclusion, must be amply repaid in the splendour



<P>of popularity.&nbsp; She must have delighted the Coles--worthy people,



<P>who deserved to be made happy!--And left a name behind her that would



<P>not soon die away.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Perfect happiness, even in memory, is not common; and there were



<P>two points on which she was not quite easy.&nbsp; She doubted whether



<P>she had not transgressed the duty of woman by woman, in betraying



<P>her suspicions of Jane Fairfax's feelings to Frank Churchill.



<P>It was hardly right; but it had been so strong an idea, that it



<P>would escape her, and his submission to all that she told,



<P>was a compliment to her penetration, which made it difficult



<P>for her to be quite certain that she ought to have held her tongue.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The other circumstance of regret related also to Jane Fairfax;



<P>and there she had no doubt.&nbsp; She did unfeignedly and unequivocally



<P>regret the inferiority of her own playing and singing.&nbsp; She did



<P>most heartily grieve over the idleness of her childhood--and sat



<P>down and practised vigorously an hour and a half.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was then interrupted by Harriet's coming in; and if Harriet's



<P>praise could have satisfied her, she might soon have been comforted.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! if I could but play as well as you and Miss Fairfax!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't class us together, Harriet.&nbsp; My playing is no more like



<P>her's, than a lamp is like sunshine."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! dear--I think you play the best of the two.&nbsp; I think you play



<P>quite as well as she does.&nbsp; I am sure I had much rather hear you.



<P>Every body last night said how well you played."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Those who knew any thing about it, must have felt the difference.



<P>The truth is, Harriet, that my playing is just good enough to be praised,



<P>but Jane Fairfax's is much beyond it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, I always shall think that you play quite as well as she does,



<P>or that if there is any difference nobody would ever find it out.



<P>Mr. Cole said how much taste you had; and Mr. Frank Churchill talked



<P>a great deal about your taste, and that he valued taste much more



<P>than execution."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah! but Jane Fairfax has them both, Harriet."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Are you sure?&nbsp; I saw she had execution, but I did not know she

had



<P>any taste.&nbsp; Nobody talked about it.&nbsp; And I hate Italian singing.--



<P>There is no understanding a word of it.&nbsp; Besides, if she does play



<P>so very well, you know, it is no more than she is obliged to do,



<P>because she will have to teach.&nbsp; The Coxes were wondering last

night



<P>whether she would get into any great family.&nbsp; How did you think

the



<P>Coxes looked?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Just as they always do--very vulgar."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"They told me something," said Harriet rather hesitatingly;"



<P>but it is nothing of any consequence."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma was obliged to ask what they had told her, though fearful



<P>of its producing Mr. Elton.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"They told me---that Mr. Martin dined with them last Saturday."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He came to their father upon some business, and he asked him



<P>to stay to dinner."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"They talked a great deal about him, especially Anne Cox.



<P>I do not know what she meant, but she asked me if I thought I



<P>should go and stay there again next summer."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She meant to be impertinently curious, just as such an Anne Cox



<P>should be."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She said he was very agreeable the day he dined there.&nbsp; He sat



<P>by her at dinner.&nbsp; Miss Nash thinks either of the Coxes would



<P>be very glad to marry him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very likely.--I think they are, without exception, the most vulgar



<P>girls in Highbury."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet had business at Ford's.--Emma thought it most prudent to go



<P>with her.&nbsp; Another accidental meeting with the Martins was possible,



<P>and in her present state, would be dangerous.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet, tempted by every thing and swayed by half a word, was always



<P>very long at a purchase; and while she was still hanging over muslins



<P>and changing her mind, Emma went to the door for amusement.--Much could



<P>not be hoped from the traffic of even the busiest part of Highbury;--



<P>Mr. Perry walking hastily by, Mr. William Cox letting himself in at



<P>the office-door, Mr. Cole's carriage-horses returning from exercise,



<P>or a stray letter-boy on an obstinate mule, were the liveliest



<P>objects she could presume to expect; and when her eyes fell only on



<P>the butcher with his tray, a tidy old woman travelling homewards from



<P>shop with her full basket, two curs quarrelling over a dirty bone,



<P>and a string of dawdling children round the baker's little bow-window



<P>eyeing the gingerbread, she knew she had no reason to complain,



<P>and was amused enough; quite enough still to stand at the door.



<P>A mind lively and at ease, can do with seeing nothing, and can see



<P>nothing that does not answer.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She looked down the Randalls road.&nbsp; The scene enlarged;



<P>two persons appeared; Mrs. Weston and her son-in-law; they were



<P>walking into Highbury;--to Hartfield of course.&nbsp; They were stopping,



<P>however, in the first place at Mrs. Bates's; whose house was



<P>a little nearer Randalls than Ford's; and had all but knocked,



<P>when Emma caught their eye.--Immediately they crossed the road



<P>and came forward to her; and the agreeableness of yesterday's



<P>engagement seemed to give fresh pleasure to the present meeting.



<P>Mrs. Weston informed her that she was going to call on the Bateses,



<P>in order to hear the new instrument.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"For my companion tells me," said she, "that I absolutely promised



<P>Miss Bates last night, that I would come this morning.&nbsp; I was



<P>not aware of it myself.&nbsp; I did not know that I had fixed a day,



<P>but as he says I did, I am going now."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And while Mrs. Weston pays her visit, I may be allowed, I hope,"



<P>said Frank Churchill, "to join your party and wait for her at Hartfield--



<P>if you are going home."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Weston was disappointed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I thought you meant to go with me.&nbsp; They would be very much pleased."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Me!&nbsp; I should be quite in the way.&nbsp; But, perhaps--I may be

equally



<P>in the way here.&nbsp; Miss Woodhouse looks as if she did not want me.



<P>My aunt always sends me off when she is shopping.&nbsp; She says I fidget



<P>her to death; and Miss Woodhouse looks as if she could almost say



<P>the same.&nbsp; What am I to do?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am here on no business of my own," said Emma; "I am only waiting



<P>for my friend.&nbsp; She will probably have soon done, and then we



<P>shall go home.&nbsp; But you had better go with Mrs. Weston and hear



<P>the instrument."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well--if you advise it.--But (with a smile) if Colonel Campbell



<P>should have employed a careless friend, and if it should prove



<P>to have an indifferent tone--what shall I say?&nbsp; I shall be no



<P>support to Mrs. Weston.&nbsp; She might do very well by herself.



<P>A disagreeable truth would be palatable through her lips, but I



<P>am the wretchedest being in the world at a civil falsehood."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not believe any such thing," replied Emma.--"I am persuaded



<P>that you can be as insincere as your neighbours, when it is necessary;



<P>but there is no reason to suppose the instrument is indifferent.



<P>Quite otherwise indeed, if I understood Miss Fairfax's opinion



<P>last night."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do come with me," said Mrs. Weston, "if it be not very disagreeable



<P>to you.&nbsp; It need not detain us long.&nbsp; We will go to Hartfield

afterwards.



<P>We will follow them to Hartfield.&nbsp; I really wish you to call with

me.



<P>It will be felt so great an attention! and I always thought you



<P>meant it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He could say no more; and with the hope of Hartfield to reward him,



<P>returned with Mrs. Weston to Mrs. Bates's door.&nbsp; Emma watched them

in,



<P>and then joined Harriet at the interesting counter,--trying, with all



<P>the force of her own mind, to convince her that if she wanted plain



<P>muslin it was of no use to look at figured; and that a blue ribbon,



<P>be it ever so beautiful, would still never match her yellow pattern.



<P>At last it was all settled, even to the destination of the parcel.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Should I send it to Mrs. Goddard's, ma'am?" asked Mrs. Ford.--



<P>"Yes--no--yes, to Mrs. Goddard's. Only my pattern gown is



<P>at Hartfield.&nbsp; No, you shall send it to Hartfield, if you please.



<P>But then, Mrs. Goddard will want to see it.--And I could take the



<P>pattern gown home any day.&nbsp; But I shall want the ribbon directly--



<P>so it had better go to Hartfield--at least the ribbon.&nbsp; You could



<P>make it into two parcels, Mrs. Ford, could not you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is not worth while, Harriet, to give Mrs. Ford the trouble



<P>of two parcels."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No more it is."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No trouble in the world, ma'am," said the obliging Mrs. Ford.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! but indeed I would much rather have it only in one.



<P>Then, if you please, you shall send it all to Mrs. Goddard's--



<P>I do not know--No, I think, Miss Woodhouse, I may just as well



<P>have it sent to Hartfield, and take it home with me at night.



<P>What do you advise?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That you do not give another half-second to the subject.



<P>To Hartfield, if you please, Mrs. Ford."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Aye, that will be much best," said Harriet, quite satisfied,



<P>"I should not at all like to have it sent to Mrs. Goddard's."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Voices approached the shop--or rather one voice and two ladies:



<P>Mrs. Weston and Miss Bates met them at the door.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear Miss Woodhouse," said the latter, "I am just run across to



<P>entreat the favour of you to come and sit down with us a little while,



<P>and give us your opinion of our new instrument; you and Miss Smith.



<P>How do you do, Miss Smith?--Very well I thank you.--And I begged



<P>Mrs. Weston to come with me, that I might be sure of succeeding."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I hope Mrs. Bates and Miss Fairfax are--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very well, I am much obliged to you.&nbsp; My mother is delightfully

well;



<P>and Jane caught no cold last night.&nbsp; How is Mr. Woodhouse?--I am

so glad



<P>to hear such a good account.&nbsp; Mrs. Weston told me you were here.--



<P>Oh! then, said I, I must run across, I am sure Miss Woodhouse will



<P>allow me just to run across and entreat her to come in; my mother



<P>will be so very happy to see her--and now we are such a nice party,



<P>she cannot refuse.--`Aye, pray do,' said Mr. Frank Churchill,



<P>`Miss Woodhouse's opinion of the instrument will be worth having.'--



<P>But, said I, I shall be more sure of succeeding if one of you will go



<P>with me.--`Oh,' said he, `wait half a minute, till I have finished



<P>my job;'--For, would you believe it, Miss Woodhouse, there he is,



<P>in the most obliging manner in the world, fastening in the rivet of

my



<P>mother's spectacles.--The rivet came out, you know, this morning.--



<P>So very obliging!--For my mother had no use of her spectacles--



<P>could not put them on.&nbsp; And, by the bye, every body ought to have



<P>two pair of spectacles; they should indeed.&nbsp; Jane said so.



<P>I meant to take them over to John Saunders the first thing I did,



<P>but something or other hindered me all the morning; first one thing,



<P>then another, there is no saying what, you know.&nbsp; At one time Patty

came



<P>to say she thought the kitchen chimney wanted sweeping.&nbsp; Oh, said

I,



<P>Patty do not come with your bad news to me.&nbsp; Here is the rivet



<P>of your mistress's spectacles out.&nbsp; Then the baked apples came

home,



<P>Mrs. Wallis sent them by her boy; they are extremely civil and



<P>obliging to us, the Wallises, always--I have heard some people



<P>say that Mrs. Wallis can be uncivil and give a very rude answer,



<P>but we have never known any thing but the greatest attention



<P>from them.&nbsp; And it cannot be for the value of our custom now,



<P>for what is our consumption of bread, you know?&nbsp; Only three of

us.--



<P>besides dear Jane at present--and she really eats nothing--makes such



<P>a shocking breakfast, you would be quite frightened if you saw it.



<P>I dare not let my mother know how little she eats--so I say one



<P>thing and then I say another, and it passes off.&nbsp; But about the



<P>middle of the day she gets hungry, and there is nothing she likes



<P>so well as these baked apples, and they are extremely wholesome,



<P>for I took the opportunity the other day of asking Mr. Perry;



<P>I happened to meet him in the street.&nbsp; Not that I had any doubt

before--



<P>I have so often heard Mr. Woodhouse recommend a baked apple.



<P>I believe it is the only way that Mr. Woodhouse thinks the



<P>fruit thoroughly wholesome.&nbsp; We have apple-dumplings, however,



<P>very often.&nbsp; Patty makes an excellent apple-dumpling. Well,



<P>Mrs. Weston, you have prevailed, I hope, and these ladies will



<P>oblige us."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma would be "very happy to wait on Mrs. Bates, &amp;c.," and they



<P>did at last move out of the shop, with no farther delay from Miss



<P>Bates than,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How do you do, Mrs. Ford?&nbsp; I beg your pardon.&nbsp; I did not

see



<P>you before.&nbsp; I hear you have a charming collection of new ribbons



<P>from town.&nbsp; Jane came back delighted yesterday.&nbsp; Thank ye,



<P>the gloves do very well--only a little too large about the wrist;



<P>but Jane is taking them in."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What was I talking of?" said she, beginning again when they were



<P>all in the street.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma wondered on what, of all the medley, she would fix.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I declare I cannot recollect what I was talking of.--Oh! my



<P>mother's spectacles.&nbsp; So very obliging of Mr. Frank Churchill!



<P>`Oh!' said he, `I do think I can fasten the rivet; I like a job



<P>of this kind excessively.'--Which you know shewed him to be so



<P>very. . . . Indeed I must say that, much as I had heard of him



<P>before and much as I had expected, he very far exceeds any



<P>thing. . . . I do congratulate you, Mrs. Weston, most warmly.



<P>He seems every thing the fondest parent could. . . . `Oh!' said he,



<P>`I can fasten the rivet.&nbsp; I like a job of that sort excessively.'



<P>I never shall forget his manner.&nbsp; And when I brought out the baked



<P>apples from the closet, and hoped our friends would be so very



<P>obliging as to take some, `Oh!' said he directly, `there is nothing



<P>in the way of fruit half so good, and these are the finest-looking



<P>home-baked apples I ever saw in my life.'&nbsp; That, you know, was

so



<P>very. . . . And I am sure, by his manner, it was no compliment.



<P>Indeed they are very delightful apples, and Mrs. Wallis does them



<P>full justice--only we do not have them baked more than twice,



<P>and Mr. Woodhouse made us promise to have them done three times--



<P>but Miss Woodhouse will be so good as not to mention it.&nbsp; The apples



<P>themselves are the very finest sort for baking, beyond a doubt;



<P>all from Donwell--some of Mr. Knightley's most liberal supply.



<P>He sends us a sack every year; and certainly there never was such



<P>a keeping apple anywhere as one of his trees--I believe there



<P>is two of them.&nbsp; My mother says the orchard was always famous



<P>in her younger days.&nbsp; But I was really quite shocked the other

day--



<P>for Mr. Knightley called one morning, and Jane was eating these apples,



<P>and we talked about them and said how much she enjoyed them,



<P>and he asked whether we were not got to the end of our stock.



<P>`I am sure you must be,' said he, `and I will send you



<P>another supply; for I have a great many more than I can ever use.



<P>William Larkins let me keep a larger quantity than usual this year.



<P>I will send you some more, before they get good for nothing.'



<P>So I begged he would not--for really as to ours being gone, I could



<P>not absolutely say that we had a great many left--it was but half



<P>a dozen indeed; but they should be all kept for Jane; and I could



<P>not at all bear that he should be sending us more, so liberal as he



<P>had been already; and Jane said the same.&nbsp; And when he was gone,



<P>she almost quarrelled with me--No, I should not say quarrelled,



<P>for we never had a quarrel in our lives; but she was quite distressed



<P>that I had owned the apples were so nearly gone; she wished I had



<P>made him believe we had a great many left.&nbsp; Oh, said I, my dear,



<P>I did say as much as I could.&nbsp; However, the very same evening



<P>William Larkins came over with a large basket of apples, the same



<P>sort of apples, a bushel at least, and I was very much obliged,



<P>and went down and spoke to William Larkins and said every thing,



<P>as you may suppose.&nbsp; William Larkins is such an old acquaintance!



<P>I am always glad to see him.&nbsp; But, however, I found afterwards



<P>from Patty, that William said it was all the apples of that sort



<P>his master had; he had brought them all--and now his master had not



<P>one left to bake or boil.&nbsp; William did not seem to mind it himself,



<P>he was so pleased to think his master had sold so many; for William,



<P>you know, thinks more of his master's profit than any thing;



<P>but Mrs. Hodges, he said, was quite displeased at their being



<P>all sent away.&nbsp; She could not bear that her master should not be



<P>able to have another apple-tart this spring.&nbsp; He told Patty this,



<P>but bid her not mind it, and be sure not to say any thing to us



<P>about it, for Mrs. Hodges would be cross sometimes, and as long as



<P>so many sacks were sold, it did not signify who ate the remainder.



<P>And so Patty told me, and I was excessively shocked indeed!



<P>I would not have Mr. Knightley know any thing about it for



<P>the world!&nbsp; He would be so very. . . . I wanted to keep it from



<P>Jane's knowledge; but, unluckily, I had mentioned it before I was



<P>aware."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Bates had just done as Patty opened the door; and her visitors



<P>walked upstairs without having any regular narration to attend to,



<P>pursued only by the sounds of her desultory good-will.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Pray take care, Mrs. Weston, there is a step at the turning.



<P>Pray take care, Miss Woodhouse, ours is rather a dark staircase--



<P>rather darker and narrower than one could wish.&nbsp; Miss Smith,



<P>pray take care.&nbsp; Miss Woodhouse, I am quite concerned, I am sure

you



<P>hit your foot.&nbsp; Miss Smith, the step at the turning."

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 18</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XVIII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>"I hope I shall soon have the pleasure of introducing my son to you,"



<P>said Mr. Weston.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Elton, very willing to suppose a particular compliment intended



<P>her by such a hope, smiled most graciously.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You have heard of a certain Frank Churchill, I presume," he continued--



<P>"and know him to be my son, though he does not bear my name."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! yes, and I shall be very happy in his acquaintance.



<P>I am sure Mr. Elton will lose no time in calling on him; and we



<P>shall both have great pleasure in seeing him at the Vicarage."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are very obliging.--Frank will be extremely happy, I am sure.--



<P>He is to be in town next week, if not sooner.&nbsp; We have notice of

it



<P>in a letter to-day. I met the letters in my way this morning,



<P>and seeing my son's hand, presumed to open it--though it was not directed



<P>to me--it was to Mrs. Weston.&nbsp; She is his principal correspondent,



<P>I assure you.&nbsp; I hardly ever get a letter."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And so you absolutely opened what was directed to her!&nbsp; Oh!&nbsp;

Mr. Weston--



<P>(laughing affectedly) I must protest against that.--A most dangerous



<P>precedent indeed!--I beg you will not let your neighbours follow



<P>your example.--Upon my word, if this is what I am to expect,



<P>we married women must begin to exert ourselves!--Oh!&nbsp; Mr. Weston,



<P>I could not have believed it of you!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Aye, we men are sad fellows.&nbsp; You must take care of yourself,



<P>Mrs. Elton.--This letter tells us--it is a short letter--written in



<P>a hurry, merely to give us notice--it tells us that they are all



<P>coming up to town directly, on Mrs. Churchill's account--she has



<P>not been well the whole winter, and thinks Enscombe too cold for her--



<P>so they are all to move southward without loss of time."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Indeed!--from Yorkshire, I think.&nbsp; Enscombe is in Yorkshire?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, they are about one hundred and ninety miles from London.



<P>a considerable journey."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, upon my word, very considerable.&nbsp; Sixty-five miles farther



<P>than from Maple Grove to London.&nbsp; But what is distance, Mr. Weston,



<P>to people of large fortune?--You would be amazed to hear how my brother,



<P>Mr. Suckling, sometimes flies about.&nbsp; You will hardly believe me--



<P>but twice in one week he and Mr. Bragge went to London and back again



<P>with four horses."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The evil of the distance from Enscombe," said Mr. Weston, "is, that



<P>Mrs. Churchill, as we understand, has not been able to leave the



<P>sofa for a week together.&nbsp; In Frank's last letter she complained,



<P>he said, of being too weak to get into her conservatory without having



<P>both his arm and his uncle's! This, you know, speaks a great degree



<P>of weakness--but now she is so impatient to be in town, that she



<P>means to sleep only two nights on the road.--So Frank writes word.



<P>Certainly, delicate ladies have very extraordinary constitutions,



<P>Mrs. Elton.&nbsp; You must grant me that."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, indeed, I shall grant you nothing.&nbsp; I Always take the part



<P>of my own sex.&nbsp; I do indeed.&nbsp; I give you notice--You will

find me



<P>a formidable antagonist on that point.&nbsp; I always stand up for women--



<P>and I assure you, if you knew how Selina feels with respect



<P>to sleeping at an inn, you would not wonder at Mrs. Churchill's



<P>making incredible exertions to avoid it.&nbsp; Selina says it is quite



<P>horror to her--and I believe I have caught a little of her nicety.



<P>She always travels with her own sheets; an excellent precaution.



<P>Does Mrs. Churchill do the same?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Depend upon it, Mrs. Churchill does every thing that any other



<P>fine lady ever did.&nbsp; Mrs. Churchill will not be second to any lady



<P>in the land for"--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Elton eagerly interposed with,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh!&nbsp; Mr. Weston, do not mistake me.&nbsp; Selina is no fine lady,



<P>I assure you.&nbsp; Do not run away with such an idea."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Is not she?&nbsp; Then she is no rule for Mrs. Churchill, who is



<P>as thorough a fine lady as any body ever beheld."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Elton began to think she had been wrong in disclaiming so warmly.



<P>It was by no means her object to have it believed that her sister



<P>was not a fine lady; perhaps there was want of spirit in the pretence



<P>of it;--and she was considering in what way she had best retract,



<P>when Mr. Weston went on.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mrs. Churchill is not much in my good graces, as you may suspect--



<P>but this is quite between ourselves.&nbsp; She is very fond of Frank,



<P>and therefore I would not speak ill of her.&nbsp; Besides, she is out

of



<P>health now; but that indeed, by her own account, she has always been.



<P>I would not say so to every body, Mrs. Elton, but I have not much



<P>faith in Mrs. Churchill's illness."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If she is really ill, why not go to Bath, Mr. Weston?--To Bath,



<P>or to Clifton?"&nbsp; "She has taken it into her head that Enscombe

is too



<P>cold for her.&nbsp; The fact is, I suppose, that she is tired of Enscombe.



<P>She has now been a longer time stationary there, than she ever



<P>was before, and she begins to want change.&nbsp; It is a retired place.



<P>A fine place, but very retired."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Aye--like Maple Grove, I dare say.&nbsp; Nothing can stand more retired

from



<P>the road than Maple Grove.&nbsp; Such an immense plantation all round

it!



<P>You seem shut out from every thing--in the most complete retirement.--



<P>And Mrs. Churchill probably has not health or spirits like Selina



<P>to enjoy that sort of seclusion.&nbsp; Or, perhaps she may not have



<P>resources enough in herself to be qualified for a country life.



<P>I always say a woman cannot have too many resources--and I feel



<P>very thankful that I have so many myself as to be quite independent



<P>of society."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Frank was here in February for a fortnight."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So I remember to have heard.&nbsp; He will find an addition to the



<P>society of Highbury when he comes again; that is, if I may presume



<P>to call myself an addition.&nbsp; But perhaps he may never have heard



<P>of there being such a creature in the world."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This was too loud a call for a compliment to be passed by,



<P>and Mr. Weston, with a very good grace, immediately exclaimed,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear madam!&nbsp; Nobody but yourself could imagine such a



<P>thing possible.&nbsp; Not heard of you!--I believe Mrs. Weston's



<P>letters lately have been full of very little else than Mrs. Elton."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He had done his duty and could return to his son.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"When Frank left us," continued he, "it was quite uncertain when we



<P>might see him again, which makes this day's news doubly welcome.



<P>It has been completely unexpected.&nbsp; That is, I always had a strong



<P>persuasion he would be here again soon, I was sure something



<P>favourable would turn up--but nobody believed me.&nbsp; He and Mrs.

Weston



<P>were both dreadfully desponding.&nbsp; `How could he contrive to come?



<P>And how could it be supposed that his uncle and aunt would spare



<P>him again?' and so forth--I always felt that something would happen



<P>in our favour; and so it has, you see.&nbsp; I have observed, Mrs. Elton,



<P>in the course of my life, that if things are going untowardly one month,



<P>they are sure to mend the next."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very true, Mr. Weston, perfectly true.&nbsp; It is just what I used



<P>to say to a certain gentleman in company in the days of courtship,



<P>when, because things did not go quite right, did not proceed with all



<P>the rapidity which suited his feelings, he was apt to be in despair,



<P>and exclaim that he was sure at this rate it would be May before



<P>Hymen's saffron robe would be put on for us.&nbsp; Oh! the pains I have



<P>been at to dispel those gloomy ideas and give him cheerfuller views!



<P>The carriage--we had disappointments about the carriage;--one morning,



<P>I remember, he came to me quite in despair."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was stopped by a slight fit of coughing, and Mr. Weston instantly



<P>seized the opportunity of going on.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You were mentioning May.&nbsp; May is the very month which Mrs. Churchill



<P>is ordered, or has ordered herself, to spend in some warmer place



<P>than Enscombe--in short, to spend in London; so that we have the



<P>agreeable prospect of frequent visits from Frank the whole spring--



<P>precisely the season of the year which one should have chosen



<P>for it:&nbsp; days almost at the longest; weather genial and pleasant,



<P>always inviting one out, and never too hot for exercise.&nbsp; When

he



<P>was here before, we made the best of it; but there was a good deal



<P>of wet, damp, cheerless weather; there always is in February, you know,



<P>and we could not do half that we intended.&nbsp; Now will be the time.



<P>This will be complete enjoyment; and I do not know, Mrs. Elton,



<P>whether the uncertainty of our meetings, the sort of constant



<P>expectation there will be of his coming in to-day or to-morrow,



<P>and at any hour, may not be more friendly to happiness than having



<P>him actually in the house.&nbsp; I think it is so.&nbsp; I think it

is the



<P>state of mind which gives most spirit and delight.&nbsp; I hope you



<P>will be pleased with my son; but you must not expect a prodigy.



<P>He is generally thought a fine young man, but do not expect a prodigy.



<P>Mrs. Weston's partiality for him is very great, and, as you may suppose,



<P>most gratifying to me.&nbsp; She thinks nobody equal to him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And I assure you, Mr. Weston, I have very little doubt that my



<P>opinion will be decidedly in his favour.&nbsp; I have heard so much



<P>in praise of Mr. Frank Churchill.--At the same time it is fair



<P>to observe, that I am one of those who always judge for themselves,



<P>and are by no means implicitly guided by others.&nbsp; I give you notice



<P>that as I find your son, so I shall judge of him.--I am no flatterer."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Weston was musing.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I hope," said he presently, "I have not been severe upon poor



<P>Mrs. Churchill.&nbsp; If she is ill I should be sorry to do her injustice;



<P>but there are some traits in her character which make it difficult



<P>for me to speak of her with the forbearance I could wish.



<P>You cannot be ignorant, Mrs. Elton, of my connexion with the family,



<P>nor of the treatment I have met with; and, between ourselves,



<P>the whole blame of it is to be laid to her.&nbsp; She was the instigator.



<P>Frank's mother would never have been slighted as she was but for her.



<P>Mr. Churchill has pride; but his pride is nothing to his wife's:



<P>his is a quiet, indolent, gentlemanlike sort of pride that would



<P>harm nobody, and only make himself a little helpless and tiresome;



<P>but her pride is arrogance and insolence!&nbsp; And what inclines one

less



<P>to bear, she has no fair pretence of family or blood.&nbsp; She was

nobody



<P>when he married her, barely the daughter of a gentleman; but ever



<P>since her being turned into a Churchill she has out-Churchill'd them



<P>all in high and mighty claims:&nbsp; but in herself, I assure you, she

is



<P>an upstart."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Only think! well, that must be infinitely provoking!&nbsp; I have quite



<P>a horror of upstarts.&nbsp; Maple Grove has given me a thorough disgust



<P>to people of that sort; for there is a family in that neighbourhood



<P>who are such an annoyance to my brother and sister from the airs



<P>they give themselves!&nbsp; Your description of Mrs. Churchill made

me



<P>think of them directly.&nbsp; People of the name of Tupman, very lately



<P>settled there, and encumbered with many low connexions, but giving



<P>themselves immense airs, and expecting to be on a footing with the old



<P>established families.&nbsp; A year and a half is the very utmost that

they can



<P>have lived at West Hall; and how they got their fortune nobody knows.



<P>They came from Birmingham, which is not a place to promise much,



<P>you know, Mr. Weston.&nbsp; One has not great hopes from Birmingham.



<P>I always say there is something direful in the sound:&nbsp; but nothing



<P>more is positively known of the Tupmans, though a good many things



<P>I assure you are suspected; and yet by their manners they evidently



<P>think themselves equal even to my brother, Mr. Suckling, who happens



<P>to be one of their nearest neighbours.&nbsp; It is infinitely too bad.



<P>Mr. Suckling, who has been eleven years a resident at Maple Grove,



<P>and whose father had it before him--I believe, at least--I am



<P>almost sure that old Mr. Suckling had completed the purchase before



<P>his death."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They were interrupted.&nbsp; Tea was carrying round, and Mr. Weston,



<P>having said all that he wanted, soon took the opportunity of



<P>walking away.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After tea, Mr. and Mrs. Weston, and Mr. Elton sat down with Mr. Woodhouse



<P>to cards.&nbsp; The remaining five were left to their own powers,



<P>and Emma doubted their getting on very well; for Mr. Knightley seemed



<P>little disposed for conversation; Mrs. Elton was wanting notice,



<P>which nobody had inclination to pay, and she was herself



<P>in a worry of spirits which would have made her prefer being silent.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. John Knightley proved more talkative than his brother.



<P>He was to leave them early the next day; and he soon began with--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, Emma, I do not believe I have any thing more to say about



<P>the boys; but you have your sister's letter, and every thing is



<P>down at full length there we may be sure.&nbsp; My charge would be much



<P>more concise than her's, and probably not much in the same spirit;



<P>all that I have to recommend being comprised in, do not spoil them,



<P>and do not physic them."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I rather hope to satisfy you both," said Emma, "for I shall do all



<P>in my power to make them happy, which will be enough for Isabella;



<P>and happiness must preclude false indulgence and physic."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And if you find them troublesome, you must send them home again."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That is very likely.&nbsp; You think so, do not you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I hope I am aware that they may be too noisy for your father--



<P>or even may be some encumbrance to you, if your visiting engagements



<P>continue to increase as much as they have done lately."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Increase!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Certainly; you must be sensible that the last half-year has made



<P>a great difference in your way of life."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Difference!&nbsp; No indeed I am not."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There can be no doubt of your being much more engaged with company



<P>than you used to be.&nbsp; Witness this very time.&nbsp; Here am I come



<P>down for only one day, and you are engaged with a dinner-party!--



<P>When did it happen before, or any thing like it?&nbsp; Your neighbourhood



<P>is increasing, and you mix more with it.&nbsp; A little while ago,



<P>every letter to Isabella brought an account of fresh gaieties;



<P>dinners at Mr. Cole's, or balls at the Crown.&nbsp; The difference



<P>which Randalls, Randalls alone makes in your goings-on, is very great."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes," said his brother quickly, "it is Randalls that does it all."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very well--and as Randalls, I suppose, is not likely to have less



<P>influence than heretofore, it strikes me as a possible thing, Emma,



<P>that Henry and John may be sometimes in the way.&nbsp; And if they are,



<P>I only beg you to send them home."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No," cried Mr. Knightley, "that need not be the consequence.



<P>Let them be sent to Donwell.&nbsp; I shall certainly be at leisure."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Upon my word," exclaimed Emma, "you amuse me!&nbsp; I should like to

know



<P>how many of all my numerous engagements take place without your being



<P>of the party; and why I am to be supposed in danger of wanting leisure



<P>to attend to the little boys.&nbsp; These amazing engagements of mine--



<P>what have they been?&nbsp; Dining once with the Coles--and having a

ball



<P>talked of, which never took place.&nbsp; I can understand you--(nodding

at



<P>Mr. John Knightley)--your good fortune in meeting with so many of



<P>your friends at once here, delights you too much to pass unnoticed.



<P>But you, (turning to Mr. Knightley,) who know how very, very seldom



<P>I am ever two hours from Hartfield, why you should foresee such a



<P>series of dissipation for me, I cannot imagine.&nbsp; And as to my dear



<P>little boys, I must say, that if Aunt Emma has not time for them,



<P>I do not think they would fare much better with Uncle Knightley,



<P>who is absent from home about five hours where she is absent one--



<P>and who, when he is at home, is either reading to himself or settling



<P>his accounts."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Knightley seemed to be trying not to smile; and succeeded



<P>without difficulty, upon Mrs. Elton's beginning to talk to him.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 16</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XVI</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>The hair was curled, and the maid sent away, and Emma sat down to think



<P>and be miserable.--It was a wretched business indeed!--Such an overthrow



<P>of every thing she had been wishing for!--Such a development of every



<P>thing most unwelcome!--Such a blow for Harriet!--that was the worst



<P>of all.&nbsp; Every part of it brought pain and humiliation, of some

sort



<P>or other; but, compared with the evil to Harriet, all was light;



<P>and she would gladly have submitted to feel yet more mistaken--



<P>more in error--more disgraced by mis-judgment, than she actually was,



<P>could the effects of her blunders have been confined to herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If I had not persuaded Harriet into liking the man, I could have



<P>borne any thing.&nbsp; He might have doubled his presumption to me--



<P>but poor Harriet!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>How she could have been so deceived!--He protested that he



<P>had never thought seriously of Harriet--never!&nbsp; She looked back



<P>as well as she could; but it was all confusion.&nbsp; She had taken



<P>up the idea, she supposed, and made every thing bend to it.



<P>His manners, however, must have been unmarked, wavering, dubious,



<P>or she could not have been so misled.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The picture!--How eager he had been about the picture!--



<P>and the charade!--and an hundred other circumstances;--



<P>how clearly they had seemed to point at Harriet.&nbsp; To be sure,



<P>the charade, with its "ready wit"--but then the "soft eyes"--



<P>in fact it suited neither; it was a jumble without taste or truth.



<P>Who could have seen through such thick-headed nonsense?

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Certainly she had often, especially of late, thought his manners



<P>to herself unnecessarily gallant; but it had passed as his way,



<P>as a mere error of judgment, of knowledge, of taste, as one proof



<P>among others that he had not always lived in the best society,



<P>that with all the gentleness of his address, true elegance



<P>was sometimes wanting; but, till this very day, she had never,



<P>for an instant, suspected it to mean any thing but grateful respect



<P>to her as Harriet's friend.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To Mr. John Knightley was she indebted for her first idea on



<P>the subject, for the first start of its possibility.&nbsp; There was



<P>no denying that those brothers had penetration.&nbsp; She remembered



<P>what Mr. Knightley had once said to her about Mr. Elton, the caution



<P>he had given, the conviction he had professed that Mr. Elton would



<P>never marry indiscreetly; and blushed to think how much truer



<P>a knowledge of his character had been there shewn than any she



<P>had reached herself.&nbsp; It was dreadfully mortifying; but Mr. Elton



<P>was proving himself, in many respects, the very reverse of what she



<P>had meant and believed him; proud, assuming, conceited; very full



<P>of his own claims, and little concerned about the feelings of others.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Contrary to the usual course of things, Mr. Elton's wanting



<P>to pay his addresses to her had sunk him in her opinion.



<P>His professions and his proposals did him no service.&nbsp; She thought



<P>nothing of his attachment, and was insulted by his hopes.



<P>He wanted to marry well, and having the arrogance to raise his



<P>eyes to her, pretended to be in love; but she was perfectly easy



<P>as to his not suffering any disappointment that need be cared for.



<P>There had been no real affection either in his language or manners.



<P>Sighs and fine words had been given in abundance; but she could



<P>hardly devise any set of expressions, or fancy any tone of voice,



<P>less allied with real love.&nbsp; She need not trouble herself to pity

him.



<P>He only wanted to aggrandise and enrich himself; and if Miss Woodhouse



<P>of Hartfield, the heiress of thirty thousand pounds, were not quite



<P>so easily obtained as he had fancied, he would soon try for Miss



<P>Somebody else with twenty, or with ten.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But--that he should talk of encouragement, should consider her as



<P>aware of his views, accepting his attentions, meaning (in short),



<P>to marry him!--should suppose himself her equal in connexion



<P>or mind!--look down upon her friend, so well understanding the



<P>gradations of rank below him, and be so blind to what rose above,



<P>as to fancy himself shewing no presumption in addressing her!--



<P>It was most provoking.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Perhaps it was not fair to expect him to feel how very much he



<P>was her inferior in talent, and all the elegancies of mind.



<P>The very want of such equality might prevent his perception of it;



<P>but he must know that in fortune and consequence she was greatly



<P>his superior.&nbsp; He must know that the Woodhouses had been settled



<P>for several generations at Hartfield, the younger branch



<P>of a very ancient family--and that the Eltons were nobody.



<P>The landed property of Hartfield certainly was inconsiderable,



<P>being but a sort of notch in the Donwell Abbey estate, to which all



<P>the rest of Highbury belonged; but their fortune, from other sources,



<P>was such as to make them scarcely secondary to Donwell Abbey itself,



<P>in every other kind of consequence; and the Woodhouses had long



<P>held a high place in the consideration of the neighbourhood which



<P>Mr. Elton had first entered not two years ago, to make his way



<P>as he could, without any alliances but in trade, or any thing



<P>to recommend him to notice but his situation and his civility.--



<P>But he had fancied her in love with him; that evidently must



<P>have been his dependence; and after raving a little about the



<P>seeming incongruity of gentle manners and a conceited head,



<P>Emma was obliged in common honesty to stop and admit that her own



<P>behaviour to him had been so complaisant and obliging, so full of



<P>courtesy and attention, as (supposing her real motive unperceived)



<P>might warrant a man of ordinary observation and delicacy,



<P>like Mr. Elton, in fancying himself a very decided favourite.&nbsp;

If she



<P>had so misinterpreted his feelings, she had little right to wonder



<P>that he, with self-interest to blind him, should have mistaken hers.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The first error and the worst lay at her door.&nbsp; It was foolish,



<P>it was wrong, to take so active a part in bringing any two



<P>people together.&nbsp; It was adventuring too far, assuming too much,



<P>making light of what ought to be serious, a trick of what ought



<P>to be simple.&nbsp; She was quite concerned and ashamed, and resolved



<P>to do such things no more.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Here have I," said she, "actually talked poor Harriet into being



<P>very much attached to this man.&nbsp; She might never have thought of

him



<P>but for me; and certainly never would have thought of him with hope,



<P>if I had not assured her of his attachment, for she is as modest



<P>and humble as I used to think him.&nbsp; Oh! that I had been satisfied

with



<P>persuading her not to accept young Martin.&nbsp; There I was quite right.



<P>That was well done of me; but there I should have stopped, and left



<P>the rest to time and chance.&nbsp; I was introducing her into good company,



<P>and giving her the opportunity of pleasing some one worth having;



<P>I ought not to have attempted more.&nbsp; But now, poor girl, her peace



<P>is cut up for some time.&nbsp; I have been but half a friend to her;



<P>and if she were not to feel this disappointment so very much, I am



<P>sure I have not an idea of any body else who would be at all desirable



<P>for her;--William Coxe--Oh! no, I could not endure William Coxe--



<P>a pert young lawyer."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She stopt to blush and laugh at her own relapse, and then resumed



<P>a more serious, more dispiriting cogitation upon what had been,



<P>and might be, and must be.&nbsp; The distressing explanation she had



<P>to make to Harriet, and all that poor Harriet would be suffering,



<P>with the awkwardness of future meetings, the difficulties of



<P>continuing or discontinuing the acquaintance, of subduing feelings,



<P>concealing resentment, and avoiding eclat, were enough to occupy



<P>her in most unmirthful reflections some time longer, and she went



<P>to bed at last with nothing settled but the conviction of her having



<P>blundered most dreadfully.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To youth and natural cheerfulness like Emma's, though under



<P>temporary gloom at night, the return of day will hardly fail



<P>to bring return of spirits.&nbsp; The youth and cheerfulness of morning



<P>are in happy analogy, and of powerful operation; and if the



<P>distress be not poignant enough to keep the eyes unclosed, they



<P>will be sure to open to sensations of softened pain and brighter hope.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma got up on the morrow more disposed for comfort than she had



<P>gone to bed, more ready to see alleviations of the evil before her,



<P>and to depend on getting tolerably out of it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was a great consolation that Mr. Elton should not be really



<P>in love with her, or so particularly amiable as to make it shocking



<P>to disappoint him--that Harriet's nature should not be of that



<P>superior sort in which the feelings are most acute and retentive--



<P>and that there could be no necessity for any body's knowing



<P>what had passed except the three principals, and especially



<P>for her father's being given a moment's uneasiness about it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>These were very cheering thoughts; and the sight of a great deal



<P>of snow on the ground did her further service, for any thing was



<P>welcome that might justify their all three being quite asunder



<P>at present.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The weather was most favourable for her; though Christmas Day,



<P>she could not go to church.&nbsp; Mr. Woodhouse would have been miserable



<P>had his daughter attempted it, and she was therefore safe from



<P>either exciting or receiving unpleasant and most unsuitable ideas.



<P>The ground covered with snow, and the atmosphere in that unsettled



<P>state between frost and thaw, which is of all others the most



<P>unfriendly for exercise, every morning beginning in rain or snow,



<P>and every evening setting in to freeze, she was for many days a most



<P>honourable prisoner.&nbsp; No intercourse with Harriet possible but

by note;



<P>no church for her on Sunday any more than on Christmas Day; and no



<P>need to find excuses for Mr. Elton's absenting himself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was weather which might fairly confine every body at home;



<P>and though she hoped and believed him to be really taking comfort



<P>in some society or other, it was very pleasant to have her father



<P>so well satisfied with his being all alone in his own house,



<P>too wise to stir out; and to hear him say to Mr. Knightley, whom no



<P>weather could keep entirely from them,--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah!&nbsp; Mr. Knightley, why do not you stay at home like poor Mr.

Elton?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>These days of confinement would have been, but for her private



<P>perplexities, remarkably comfortable, as such seclusion exactly



<P>suited her brother, whose feelings must always be of great importance



<P>to his companions; and he had, besides, so thoroughly cleared off



<P>his ill-humour at Randalls, that his amiableness never failed him



<P>during the rest of his stay at Hartfield.&nbsp; He was always agreeable



<P>and obliging, and speaking pleasantly of every body.&nbsp; But with

all



<P>the hopes of cheerfulness, and all the present comfort of delay,



<P>there was still such an evil hanging over her in the hour of explanation



<P>with Harriet, as made it impossible for Emma to be ever perfectly at

ease.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <TITLE>Chapter 02</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER II</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Mr. Weston was a native of Highbury, and born of a respectable family,



<P>which for the last two or three generations had been rising into



<P>gentility and property.&nbsp; He had received a good education, but,



<P>on succeeding early in life to a small independence, had become



<P>indisposed for any of the more homely pursuits in which his brothers



<P>were engaged, and had satisfied an active, cheerful mind and social



<P>temper by entering into the militia of his county, then embodied.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Captain Weston was a general favourite; and when the chances



<P>of his military life had introduced him to Miss Churchill,



<P>of a great Yorkshire family, and Miss Churchill fell in love



<P>with him, nobody was surprized, except her brother and his wife,



<P>who had never seen him, and who were full of pride and importance,



<P>which the connexion would offend.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Churchill, however, being of age, and with the full command



<P>of her fortune--though her fortune bore no proportion to the



<P>family-estate--was not to be dissuaded from the marriage, and it



<P>took place, to the infinite mortification of Mr. and Mrs. Churchill,



<P>who threw her off with due decorum.&nbsp; It was an unsuitable connexion,



<P>and did not produce much happiness.&nbsp; Mrs. Weston ought to have

found



<P>more in it, for she had a husband whose warm heart and sweet temper



<P>made him think every thing due to her in return for the great goodness



<P>of being in love with him; but though she had one sort of spirit,



<P>she had not the best.&nbsp; She had resolution enough to pursue



<P>her own will in spite of her brother, but not enough to refrain



<P>from unreasonable regrets at that brother's unreasonable anger,



<P>nor from missing the luxuries of her former home.&nbsp; They lived beyond



<P>their income, but still it was nothing in comparison of Enscombe:



<P>she did not cease to love her husband, but she wanted at once



<P>to be the wife of Captain Weston, and Miss Churchill of Enscombe.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Captain Weston, who had been considered, especially by the Churchills,



<P>as making such an amazing match, was proved to have much the worst



<P>of the bargain; for when his wife died, after a three years' marriage,



<P>he was rather a poorer man than at first, and with a child to maintain.



<P>From the expense of the child, however, he was soon relieved.



<P>The boy had, with the additional softening claim of a lingering



<P>illness of his mother's, been the means of a sort of reconciliation;



<P>and Mr. and Mrs. Churchill, having no children of their own,



<P>nor any other young creature of equal kindred to care for, offered to



<P>take the whole charge of the little Frank soon after her decease.



<P>Some scruples and some reluctance the widower-father may be supposed



<P>to have felt; but as they were overcome by other considerations,



<P>the child was given up to the care and the wealth of the Churchills,



<P>and he had only his own comfort to seek, and his own situation to



<P>improve as he could.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A complete change of life became desirable.&nbsp; He quitted the militia



<P>and engaged in trade, having brothers already established in a



<P>good way in London, which afforded him a favourable opening.



<P>It was a concern which brought just employment enough.&nbsp; He had

still



<P>a small house in Highbury, where most of his leisure days were spent;



<P>and between useful occupation and the pleasures of society,



<P>the next eighteen or twenty years of his life passed cheerfully away.



<P>He had, by that time, realised an easy competence--enough to secure



<P>the purchase of a little estate adjoining Highbury, which he had



<P>always longed for--enough to marry a woman as portionless even



<P>as Miss Taylor, and to live according to the wishes of his own



<P>friendly and social disposition.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was now some time since Miss Taylor had begun to influence



<P>his schemes; but as it was not the tyrannic influence of youth



<P>on youth, it had not shaken his determination of never settling



<P>till he could purchase Randalls, and the sale of Randalls was long



<P>looked forward to; but he had gone steadily on, with these objects



<P>in view, till they were accomplished.&nbsp; He had made his fortune,



<P>bought his house, and obtained his wife; and was beginning a new



<P>period of existence, with every probability of greater happiness



<P>than in any yet passed through.&nbsp; He had never been an unhappy man;



<P>his own temper had secured him from that, even in his first marriage;



<P>but his second must shew him how delightful a well-judging and truly



<P>amiable woman could be, and must give him the pleasantest proof



<P>of its being a great deal better to choose than to be chosen,



<P>to excite gratitude than to feel it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He had only himself to please in his choice: his fortune was



<P>his own; for as to Frank, it was more than being tacitly brought



<P>up as his uncle's heir, it had become so avowed an adoption



<P>as to have him assume the name of Churchill on coming of age.



<P>It was most unlikely, therefore, that he should ever want his



<P>father's assistance.&nbsp; His father had no apprehension of it.



<P>The aunt was a capricious woman, and governed her husband entirely;



<P>but it was not in Mr. Weston's nature to imagine that any caprice



<P>could be strong enough to affect one so dear, and, as he believed,



<P>so deservedly dear.&nbsp; He saw his son every year in London,



<P>and was proud of him; and his fond report of him as a very fine



<P>young man had made Highbury feel a sort of pride in him too.



<P>He was looked on as sufficiently belonging to the place to make his



<P>merits and prospects a kind of common concern.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Frank Churchill was one of the boasts of Highbury, and a lively



<P>curiosity to see him prevailed, though the compliment was so little



<P>returned that he had never been there in his life.&nbsp; His coming



<P>to visit his father had been often talked of but never achieved.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Now, upon his father's marriage, it was very generally proposed,



<P>as a most proper attention, that the visit should take place.



<P>There was not a dissentient voice on the subject, either when



<P>Mrs. Perry drank tea with Mrs. and Miss Bates, or when Mrs. and



<P>Miss Bates returned the visit.&nbsp; Now was the time for Mr. Frank



<P>Churchill to come among them; and the hope strengthened when it was



<P>understood that he had written to his new mother on the occasion.



<P>For a few days, every morning visit in Highbury included some mention



<P>of the handsome letter Mrs. Weston had received.&nbsp; "I suppose you



<P>have heard of the handsome letter Mr. Frank Churchill has written



<P>to Mrs. Weston? I understand it was a very handsome letter, indeed.



<P>Mr. Woodhouse told me of it.&nbsp; Mr. Woodhouse saw the letter, and

he



<P>says he never saw such a handsome letter in his life."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was, indeed, a highly prized letter.&nbsp; Mrs. Weston had, of course,



<P>formed a very favourable idea of the young man; and such a pleasing



<P>attention was an irresistible proof of his great good sense,



<P>and a most welcome addition to every source and every expression



<P>of congratulation which her marriage had already secured.&nbsp; She

felt



<P>herself a most fortunate woman; and she had lived long enough



<P>to know how fortunate she might well be thought, where the only



<P>regret was for a partial separation from friends whose friendship



<P>for her had never cooled, and who could ill bear to part with her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She knew that at times she must be missed; and could not think,



<P>without pain, of Emma's losing a single pleasure, or suffering



<P>an hour's ennui, from the want of her companionableness: but dear



<P>Emma was of no feeble character; she was more equal to her situation



<P>than most girls would have been, and had sense, and energy,



<P>and spirits that might be hoped would bear her well and happily



<P>through its little difficulties and privations.&nbsp; And then there

was



<P>such comfort in the very easy distance of Randalls from Hartfield,



<P>so convenient for even solitary female walking, and in Mr. Weston's



<P>disposition and circumstances, which would make the approaching



<P>season no hindrance to their spending half the evenings in the



<P>week together.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her situation was altogether the subject of hours of gratitude



<P>to Mrs. Weston, and of moments only of regret; and her



<P>satisfaction---her more than satisfaction--her cheerful enjoyment,



<P>was so just and so apparent, that Emma, well as she knew her father,



<P>was sometimes taken by surprize at his being still able to pity



<P>`poor Miss Taylor,' when they left her at Randalls in the centre



<P>of every domestic comfort, or saw her go away in the evening



<P>attended by her pleasant husband to a carriage of her own.



<P>But never did she go without Mr. Woodhouse's giving a gentle sigh,



<P>and saying, "Ah, poor Miss Taylor! She would be very glad to stay."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was no recovering Miss Taylor--nor much likelihood of



<P>ceasing to pity her; but a few weeks brought some alleviation



<P>to Mr. Woodhouse.&nbsp; The compliments of his neighbours were over;



<P>he was no longer teased by being wished joy of so sorrowful an event;



<P>and the wedding-cake, which had been a great distress to him,



<P>was all eat up.&nbsp; His own stomach could bear nothing rich, and he



<P>could never believe other people to be different from himself.



<P>What was unwholesome to him he regarded as unfit for any body;



<P>and he had, therefore, earnestly tried to dissuade them from having



<P>any wedding-cake at all, and when that proved vain, as earnestly



<P>tried to prevent any body's eating it.&nbsp; He had been at the pains



<P>of consulting Mr. Perry, the apothecary, on the subject.&nbsp; Mr. Perry



<P>was an intelligent, gentlemanlike man, whose frequent visits were one



<P>of the comforts of Mr. Woodhouse's life; and upon being applied to,



<P>he could not but acknowledge (though it seemed rather against the



<P>bias of inclination) that wedding-cake might certainly disagree



<P>with many--perhaps with most people, unless taken moderately.



<P>With such an opinion, in confirmation of his own, Mr. Woodhouse hoped



<P>to influence every visitor of the newly married pair; but still the



<P>cake was eaten; and there was no rest for his benevolent nerves till



<P>it was all gone.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was a strange rumour in Highbury of all the little Perrys



<P>being seen with a slice of Mrs. Weston's wedding-cake in their



<P>hands: but Mr. Woodhouse would never believe it.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
