   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 03</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER III</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Mr. Woodhouse was fond of society in his own way.&nbsp; He liked very

much



<P>to have his friends come and see him; and from various united causes,



<P>from his long residence at Hartfield, and his good nature,



<P>from his fortune, his house, and his daughter, he could command the



<P>visits of his own little circle, in a great measure, as he liked.



<P>He had not much intercourse with any families beyond that circle;



<P>his horror of late hours, and large dinner-parties, made him unfit



<P>for any acquaintance but such as would visit him on his own terms.



<P>Fortunately for him, Highbury, including Randalls in the same parish,



<P>and Donwell Abbey in the parish adjoining, the seat of Mr. Knightley,



<P>comprehended many such.&nbsp; Not unfrequently, through Emma's persuasion,



<P>he had some of the chosen and the best to dine with him: but evening



<P>parties were what he preferred; and, unless he fancied himself at any



<P>time unequal to company, there was scarcely an evening in the week



<P>in which Emma could not make up a card-table for him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Real, long-standing regard brought the Westons and Mr. Knightley;



<P>and by Mr. Elton, a young man living alone without liking it,



<P>the privilege of exchanging any vacant evening of his own blank solitude



<P>for the elegancies and society of Mr. Woodhouse's drawing-room,



<P>and the smiles of his lovely daughter, was in no danger of being



<P>thrown away.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After these came a second set; among the most come-at-able



<P>of whom were Mrs. and Miss Bates, and Mrs. Goddard, three ladies



<P>almost always at the service of an invitation from Hartfield,



<P>and who were fetched and carried home so often, that Mr. Woodhouse



<P>thought it no hardship for either James or the horses.&nbsp; Had it



<P>taken place only once a year, it would have been a grievance.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Bates, the widow of a former vicar of Highbury, was a



<P>very old lady, almost past every thing but tea and quadrille.



<P>She lived with her single daughter in a very small way, and was



<P>considered with all the regard and respect which a harmless old lady,



<P>under such untoward circumstances, can excite.&nbsp; Her daughter enjoyed



<P>a most uncommon degree of popularity for a woman neither young,



<P>handsome, rich, nor married.&nbsp; Miss Bates stood in the very worst



<P>predicament in the world for having much of the public favour;



<P>and she had no intellectual superiority to make atonement to herself,



<P>or frighten those who might hate her into outward respect.



<P>She had never boasted either beauty or cleverness.&nbsp; Her youth



<P>had passed without distinction, and her middle of life was devoted



<P>to the care of a failing mother, and the endeavour to make a small



<P>income go as far as possible.&nbsp; And yet she was a happy woman,



<P>and a woman whom no one named without good-will.&nbsp; It was her own



<P>universal good-will and contented temper which worked such wonders.



<P>She loved every body, was interested in every body's happiness,



<P>quicksighted to every body's merits; thought herself a most fortunate



<P>creature, and surrounded with blessings in such an excellent mother,



<P>and so many good neighbours and friends, and a home that wanted



<P>for nothing.&nbsp; The simplicity and cheerfulness of her nature,



<P>her contented and grateful spirit, were a recommendation to every body,



<P>and a mine of felicity to herself.&nbsp; She was a great talker upon



<P>little matters, which exactly suited Mr. Woodhouse, full of trivial



<P>communications and harmless gossip.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Goddard was the mistress of a School--not of a seminary,



<P>or an establishment, or any thing which professed, in long sentences

of



<P>refined nonsense, to combine liberal acquirements with elegant morality,



<P>upon new principles and new systems--and where young ladies for



<P>enormous pay might be screwed out of health and into vanity--but



<P>a real, honest, old-fashioned Boarding-school, where a reasonable



<P>quantity of accomplishments were sold at a reasonable price,



<P>and where girls might be sent to be out of the way, and scramble



<P>themselves into a little education, without any danger of coming



<P>back prodigies.&nbsp; Mrs. Goddard's school was in high repute--and



<P>very deservedly; for Highbury was reckoned a particularly healthy



<P>spot: she had an ample house and garden, gave the children plenty



<P>of wholesome food, let them run about a great deal in the summer,



<P>and in winter dressed their chilblains with her own hands.



<P>It was no wonder that a train of twenty young couple now walked



<P>after her to church.&nbsp; She was a plain, motherly kind of woman,



<P>who had worked hard in her youth, and now thought herself entitled



<P>to the occasional holiday of a tea-visit; and having formerly



<P>owed much to Mr. Woodhouse's kindness, felt his particular claim



<P>on her to leave her neat parlour, hung round with fancy-work,



<P>whenever she could, and win or lose a few sixpences by his fireside.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>These were the ladies whom Emma found herself very frequently



<P>able to collect; and happy was she, for her father's sake,



<P>in the power; though, as far as she was herself concerned,



<P>it was no remedy for the absence of Mrs. Weston.&nbsp; She was delighted



<P>to see her father look comfortable, and very much pleased with



<P>herself for contriving things so well; but the quiet prosings



<P>of three such women made her feel that every evening so spent



<P>was indeed one of the long evenings she had fearfully anticipated.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As she sat one morning, looking forward to exactly such a close



<P>of the present day, a note was brought from Mrs. Goddard, requesting,



<P>in most respectful terms, to be allowed to bring Miss Smith with her;



<P>a most welcome request: for Miss Smith was a girl of seventeen,



<P>whom Emma knew very well by sight, and had long felt an interest in,



<P>on account of her beauty.&nbsp; A very gracious invitation was returned,



<P>and the evening no longer dreaded by the fair mistress of the mansion.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet Smith was the natural daughter of somebody.&nbsp; Somebody had



<P>placed her, several years back, at Mrs. Goddard's school,



<P>and somebody had lately raised her from the condition of scholar



<P>to that of parlour-boarder. This was all that was generally known



<P>of her history.&nbsp; She had no visible friends but what had been



<P>acquired at Highbury, and was now just returned from a long visit



<P>in the country to some young ladies who had been at school there with

her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was a very pretty girl, and her beauty happened to be of a sort



<P>which Emma particularly admired.&nbsp; She was short, plump, and fair,



<P>with a fine bloom, blue eyes, light hair, regular features,



<P>and a look of great sweetness, and, before the end of the evening,



<P>Emma was as much pleased with her manners as her person, and quite



<P>determined to continue the acquaintance.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was not struck by any thing remarkably clever in Miss Smith's



<P>conversation, but she found her altogether very engaging--not



<P>inconveniently shy, not unwilling to talk--and yet so far from pushing,



<P>shewing so proper and becoming a deference, seeming so pleasantly



<P>grateful for being admitted to Hartfield, and so artlessly



<P>impressed by the appearance of every thing in so superior a style



<P>to what she had been used to, that she must have good sense,



<P>and deserve encouragement.&nbsp; Encouragement should be given.



<P>Those soft blue eyes, and all those natural graces, should not be



<P>wasted on the inferior society of Highbury and its connexions.



<P>The acquaintance she had already formed were unworthy of her.



<P>The friends from whom she had just parted, though very good sort



<P>of people, must be doing her harm.&nbsp; They were a family of the name



<P>of Martin, whom Emma well knew by character, as renting a large farm



<P>of Mr. Knightley, and residing in the parish of Donwell--very creditably,



<P>she believed--she knew Mr. Knightley thought highly of them--but they



<P>must be coarse and unpolished, and very unfit to be the intimates



<P>of a girl who wanted only a little more knowledge and elegance



<P>to be quite perfect.&nbsp; She would notice her; she would improve her;



<P>she would detach her from her bad acquaintance, and introduce her



<P>into good society; she would form her opinions and her manners.



<P>It would be an interesting, and certainly a very kind undertaking;



<P>highly becoming her own situation in life, her leisure, and powers.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was so busy in admiring those soft blue eyes, in talking



<P>and listening, and forming all these schemes in the in-betweens, that



<P>the evening flew away at a very unusual rate; and the supper-table,



<P>which always closed such parties, and for which she had been



<P>used to sit and watch the due time, was all set out and ready,



<P>and moved forwards to the fire, before she was aware.&nbsp; With an



<P>alacrity beyond the common impulse of a spirit which yet was never



<P>indifferent to the credit of doing every thing well and attentively,



<P>with the real good-will of a mind delighted with its own ideas,



<P>did she then do all the honours of the meal, and help and recommend



<P>the minced chicken and scalloped oysters, with an urgency which she



<P>knew would be acceptable to the early hours and civil scruples of their

guests.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Upon such occasions poor Mr. Woodhouses feelings were in sad warfare.



<P>He loved to have the cloth laid, because it had been the fashion



<P>of his youth, but his conviction of suppers being very unwholesome



<P>made him rather sorry to see any thing put on it; and while his



<P>hospitality would have welcomed his visitors to every thing,



<P>his care for their health made him grieve that they would eat.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Such another small basin of thin gruel as his own was all that



<P>he could, with thorough self-approbation, recommend; though he



<P>might constrain himself, while the ladies were comfortably clearing



<P>the nicer things, to say:

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mrs. Bates, let me propose your venturing on one of these eggs.



<P>An egg boiled very soft is not unwholesome.&nbsp; Serle understands

boiling



<P>an egg better than any body.&nbsp; I would not recommend an egg boiled



<P>by any body else; but you need not be afraid, they are very small,



<P>you see--one of our small eggs will not hurt you.&nbsp; Miss Bates,



<P>let Emma help you to a little bit of tart--a very little bit.



<P>Ours are all apple-tarts. You need not be afraid of unwholesome



<P>preserves here.&nbsp; I do not advise the custard.&nbsp; Mrs. Goddard,

what say



<P>you to half a glass of wine? A small half-glass, put into a tumbler



<P>of water? I do not think it could disagree with you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma allowed her father to talk--but supplied her visitors in



<P>a much more satisfactory style, and on the present evening had



<P>particular pleasure in sending them away happy.&nbsp; The happiness



<P>of Miss Smith was quite equal to her intentions.&nbsp; Miss Woodhouse



<P>was so great a personage in Highbury, that the prospect of the



<P>introduction had given as much panic as pleasure; but the humble,



<P>grateful little girl went off with highly gratified feelings,



<P>delighted with the affability with which Miss Woodhouse had treated



<P>her all the evening, and actually shaken hands with her at last!



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 17</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XVII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Mr. and Mrs. John Knightley were not detained long at Hartfield.



<P>The weather soon improved enough for those to move who must move;



<P>and Mr. Woodhouse having, as usual, tried to persuade his daughter



<P>to stay behind with all her children, was obliged to see the whole



<P>party set off, and return to his lamentations over the destiny



<P>of poor Isabella;--which poor Isabella, passing her life with



<P>those she doated on, full of their merits, blind to their faults,



<P>and always innocently busy, might have been a model of right



<P>feminine happiness.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The evening of the very day on which they went brought a note



<P>from Mr. Elton to Mr. Woodhouse, a long, civil, ceremonious note,



<P>to say, with Mr. Elton's best compliments, "that he was proposing



<P>to leave Highbury the following morning in his way to Bath;



<P>where, in compliance with the pressing entreaties of some friends,



<P>he had engaged to spend a few weeks, and very much regretted



<P>the impossibility he was under, from various circumstances of



<P>weather and business, of taking a personal leave of Mr. Woodhouse,



<P>of whose friendly civilities he should ever retain a grateful sense--



<P>and had Mr. Woodhouse any commands, should be happy to attend to them."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma was most agreeably surprized.--Mr. Elton's absence just



<P>at this time was the very thing to be desired.&nbsp; She admired



<P>him for contriving it, though not able to give him much credit



<P>for the manner in which it was announced.&nbsp; Resentment could not



<P>have been more plainly spoken than in a civility to her father,



<P>from which she was so pointedly excluded.&nbsp; She had not even a



<P>share in his opening compliments.--Her name was not mentioned;--



<P>and there was so striking a change in all this, and such an



<P>ill-judged solemnity of leave-taking in his graceful acknowledgments,



<P>as she thought, at first, could not escape her father's suspicion.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It did, however.--Her father was quite taken up with the surprize



<P>of so sudden a journey, and his fears that Mr. Elton might never get



<P>safely to the end of it, and saw nothing extraordinary in his language.



<P>It was a very useful note, for it supplied them with fresh matter



<P>for thought and conversation during the rest of their lonely evening.



<P>Mr. Woodhouse talked over his alarms, and Emma was in spirits



<P>to persuade them away with all her usual promptitude.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She now resolved to keep Harriet no longer in the dark.&nbsp; She had



<P>reason to believe her nearly recovered from her cold, and it was



<P>desirable that she should have as much time as possible for getting



<P>the better of her other complaint before the gentleman's return.



<P>She went to Mrs. Goddard's accordingly the very next day, to undergo



<P>the necessary penance of communication; and a severe one it was.--



<P>She had to destroy all the hopes which she had been so industriously



<P>feeding--to appear in the ungracious character of the one preferred--



<P>and acknowledge herself grossly mistaken and mis-judging in all her



<P>ideas on one subject, all her observations, all her convictions,



<P>all her prophecies for the last six weeks.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The confession completely renewed her first shame--and the sight



<P>of Harriet's tears made her think that she should never be in charity



<P>with herself again.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet bore the intelligence very well--blaming nobody--



<P>and in every thing testifying such an ingenuousness of disposition



<P>and lowly opinion of herself, as must appear with particular



<P>advantage at that moment to her friend.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma was in the humour to value simplicity and modesty to the utmost;



<P>and all that was amiable, all that ought to be attaching,



<P>seemed on Harriet's side, not her own.&nbsp; Harriet did not consider



<P>herself as having any thing to complain of.&nbsp; The affection of such



<P>a man as Mr. Elton would have been too great a distinction.--



<P>She never could have deserved him--and nobody but so partial



<P>and kind a friend as Miss Woodhouse would have thought it possible.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her tears fell abundantly--but her grief was so truly artless,



<P>that no dignity could have made it more respectable in Emma's eyes--



<P>and she listened to her and tried to console her with all her heart



<P>and understanding--really for the time convinced that Harriet was



<P>the superior creature of the two--and that to resemble her would



<P>be more for her own welfare and happiness than all that genius or



<P>intelligence could do.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was rather too late in the day to set about being simple-minded



<P>and ignorant; but she left her with every previous resolution



<P>confirmed of being humble and discreet, and repressing imagination



<P>all the rest of her life.&nbsp; Her second duty now, inferior only to

her



<P>father's claims, was to promote Harriet's comfort, and endeavour



<P>to prove her own affection in some better method than by match-making.



<P>She got her to Hartfield, and shewed her the most unvarying kindness,



<P>striving to occupy and amuse her, and by books and conversation,



<P>to drive Mr. Elton from her thoughts.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Time, she knew, must be allowed for this being thoroughly done; and

she



<P>could suppose herself but an indifferent judge of such matters in general,



<P>and very inadequate to sympathise in an attachment to Mr. Elton



<P>in particular; but it seemed to her reasonable that at Harriet's age,



<P>and with the entire extinction of all hope, such a progress might be



<P>made towards a state of composure by the time of Mr. Elton's return,



<P>as to allow them all to meet again in the common routine of acquaintance,



<P>without any danger of betraying sentiments or increasing them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet did think him all perfection, and maintained the non-existence



<P>of any body equal to him in person or goodness--and did, in truth,



<P>prove herself more resolutely in love than Emma had foreseen;



<P>but yet it appeared to her so natural, so inevitable to strive



<P>against an inclination of that sort unrequited, that she could not



<P>comprehend its continuing very long in equal force.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>If Mr. Elton, on his return, made his own indifference as evident



<P>and indubitable as she could not doubt he would anxiously do,



<P>she could not imagine Harriet's persisting to place her happiness



<P>in the sight or the recollection of him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Their being fixed, so absolutely fixed, in the same place, was bad



<P>for each, for all three.&nbsp; Not one of them had the power of removal,



<P>or of effecting any material change of society.&nbsp; They must encounter



<P>each other, and make the best of it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet was farther unfortunate in the tone of her companions at



<P>Mrs. Goddard's; Mr. Elton being the adoration of all the teachers



<P>and great girls in the school; and it must be at Hartfield only



<P>that she could have any chance of hearing him spoken of with cooling



<P>moderation or repellent truth.&nbsp; Where the wound had been given,



<P>there must the cure be found if anywhere; and Emma felt that,



<P>till she saw her in the way of cure, there could be no true peace



<P>for herself.

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 1</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B><FONT SIZE=+2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Emma</FONT></B>



<P><B><FONT SIZE=+1>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

by Jane Austen</FONT></B>



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P><B>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

<U>VOLUME I</U></B>

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P><B>CHAPTER I</B>

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma Woodhouse, handsome, clever, and rich, with a comfortable home



<P>and happy disposition, seemed to unite some of the best blessings



<P>of existence; and had lived nearly twenty-one years in the world



<P>with very little to distress or vex her.



<P>She was the youngest of the two daughters of a most affectionate,



<P>indulgent father; and had, in consequence of her sister's marriage,



<P>been mistress of his house from a very early period.&nbsp; Her mother



<P>had died too long ago for her to have more than an indistinct



<P>remembrance of her caresses; and her place had been supplied



<P>by an excellent woman as governess, who had fallen little short



<P>of a mother in affection.



<P>Sixteen years had Miss Taylor been in Mr. Woodhouse's family,



<P>less as a governess than a friend, very fond of both daughters,



<P>but particularly of Emma.&nbsp; Between them it was more the intimacy



<P>of sisters.&nbsp; Even before Miss Taylor had ceased to hold the nominal



<P>office of governess, the mildness of her temper had hardly allowed



<P>her to impose any restraint; and the shadow of authority being



<P>now long passed away, they had been living together as friend and



<P>friend very mutually attached, and Emma doing just what she liked;



<P>highly esteeming Miss Taylor's judgment, but directed chiefly by



<P>her own.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The real evils, indeed, of Emma's situation were the power of having



<P>rather too much her own way, and a disposition to think a little



<P>too well of herself; these were the disadvantages which threatened



<P>alloy to her many enjoyments.&nbsp; The danger, however, was at present



<P>so unperceived, that they did not by any means rank as misfortunes



<P>with her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sorrow came--a gentle sorrow--but not at all in the shape of any



<P>disagreeable consciousness.--Miss Taylor married.&nbsp; It was Miss



<P>Taylor's loss which first brought grief.&nbsp; It was on the wedding-day



<P>of this beloved friend that Emma first sat in mournful thought



<P>of any continuance.&nbsp; The wedding over, and the bride-people gone,



<P>her father and herself were left to dine together, with no prospect



<P>of a third to cheer a long evening.&nbsp; Her father composed himself



<P>to sleep after dinner, as usual, and she had then only to sit



<P>and think of what she had lost.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The event had every promise of happiness for her friend.&nbsp; Mr. Weston



<P>was a man of unexceptionable character, easy fortune, suitable age,



<P>and pleasant manners; and there was some satisfaction in considering



<P>with what self-denying, generous friendship she had always wished



<P>and promoted the match; but it was a black morning's work for her.



<P>The want of Miss Taylor would be felt every hour of every day.



<P>She recalled her past kindness--the kindness, the affection of sixteen



<P>years--how she had taught and how she had played with her from five



<P>years old--how she had devoted all her powers to attach and amuse



<P>her in health--and how nursed her through the various illnesses



<P>of childhood.&nbsp; A large debt of gratitude was owing here; but the



<P>intercourse of the last seven years, the equal footing and perfect



<P>unreserve which had soon followed Isabella's marriage, on their



<P>being left to each other, was yet a dearer, tenderer recollection.



<P>She had been a friend and companion such as few possessed: intelligent,



<P>well-informed, useful, gentle, knowing all the ways of the family,



<P>interested in all its concerns, and peculiarly interested in herself,



<P>in every pleasure, every scheme of hers--one to whom she could speak



<P>every thought as it arose, and who had such an affection for her



<P>as could never find fault.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>How was she to bear the change?--It was true that her friend was



<P>going only half a mile from them; but Emma was aware that great must



<P>be the difference between a Mrs. Weston, only half a mile from them,



<P>and a Miss Taylor in the house; and with all her advantages,



<P>natural and domestic, she was now in great danger of suffering



<P>from intellectual solitude.&nbsp; She dearly loved her father, but he



<P>was no companion for her.&nbsp; He could not meet her in conversation,



<P>rational or playful.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The evil of the actual disparity in their ages (and Mr. Woodhouse had



<P>not married early) was much increased by his constitution and habits;



<P>for having been a valetudinarian all his life, without activity



<P>of mind or body, he was a much older man in ways than in years;



<P>and though everywhere beloved for the friendliness of his heart



<P>and his amiable temper, his talents could not have recommended him



<P>at any time.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her sister, though comparatively but little removed by matrimony,



<P>being settled in London, only sixteen miles off, was much beyond



<P>her daily reach; and many a long October and November evening must



<P>be struggled through at Hartfield, before Christmas brought the next



<P>visit from Isabella and her husband, and their little children,



<P>to fill the house, and give her pleasant society again.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Highbury, the large and populous village, almost amounting to a town,



<P>to which Hartfield, in spite of its separate lawn, and shrubberies,



<P>and name, did really belong, afforded her no equals.&nbsp; The Woodhouses



<P>were first in consequence there.&nbsp; All looked up to them.&nbsp;

She had



<P>many acquaintance in the place, for her father was universally civil,



<P>but not one among them who could be accepted in lieu of Miss



<P>Taylor for even half a day.&nbsp; It was a melancholy change; and Emma



<P>could not but sigh over it, and wish for impossible things,



<P>till her father awoke, and made it necessary to be cheerful.



<P>His spirits required support.&nbsp; He was a nervous man, easily depressed;



<P>fond of every body that he was used to, and hating to part with them;



<P>hating change of every kind.&nbsp; Matrimony, as the origin of change,



<P>was always disagreeable; and he was by no means yet reconciled



<P>to his own daughter's marrying, nor could ever speak of her but



<P>with compassion, though it had been entirely a match of affection,



<P>when he was now obliged to part with Miss Taylor too; and from



<P>his habits of gentle selfishness, and of being never able to



<P>suppose that other people could feel differently from himself,



<P>he was very much disposed to think Miss Taylor had done as sad



<P>a thing for herself as for them, and would have been a great deal



<P>happier if she had spent all the rest of her life at Hartfield.



<P>Emma smiled and chatted as cheerfully as she could, to keep him



<P>from such thoughts; but when tea came, it was impossible for him



<P>not to say exactly as he had said at dinner,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Poor Miss Taylor!--I wish she were here again.&nbsp; What a pity it



<P>is that Mr. Weston ever thought of her!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I cannot agree with you, papa; you know I cannot.&nbsp; Mr. Weston

is such



<P>a good-humoured, pleasant, excellent man, that he thoroughly deserves



<P>a good wife;--and you would not have had Miss Taylor live with us



<P>for ever, and bear all my odd humours, when she might have a house of

her own?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A house of her own!--But where is the advantage of a house of her own?



<P>This is three times as large.--And you have never any odd humours,



<P>my dear."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How often we shall be going to see them, and they coming to see



<P>us!--We shall be always meeting! We must begin; we must go and pay



<P>wedding visit very soon."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear, how am I to get so far? Randalls is such a distance.



<P>I could not walk half so far."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, papa, nobody thought of your walking.&nbsp; We must go in the carriage,



<P>to be sure."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The carriage! But James will not like to put the horses to for



<P>such a little way;--and where are the poor horses to be while we



<P>are paying our visit?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"They are to be put into Mr. Weston's stable, papa.&nbsp; You know we



<P>have settled all that already.&nbsp; We talked it all over with Mr.

Weston



<P>last night.&nbsp; And as for James, you may be very sure he will always

like



<P>going to Randalls, because of his daughter's being housemaid there.



<P>I only doubt whether he will ever take us anywhere else.&nbsp; That

was



<P>your doing, papa.&nbsp; You got Hannah that good place.&nbsp; Nobody

thought



<P>of Hannah till you mentioned her--James is so obliged to you!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am very glad I did think of her.&nbsp; It was very lucky, for I would



<P>not have had poor James think himself slighted upon any account;



<P>and I am sure she will make a very good servant: she is a civil,



<P>pretty-spoken girl; I have a great opinion of her.&nbsp; Whenever I

see her,



<P>she always curtseys and asks me how I do, in a very pretty manner;



<P>and when you have had her here to do needlework, I observe she



<P>always turns the lock of the door the right way and never bangs it.



<P>I am sure she will be an excellent servant; and it will be a great



<P>comfort to poor Miss Taylor to have somebody about her that she is



<P>used to see.&nbsp; Whenever James goes over to see his daughter, you

know,



<P>she will be hearing of us.&nbsp; He will be able to tell her how we



<P>all are."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma spared no exertions to maintain this happier flow of ideas,



<P>and hoped, by the help of backgammon, to get her father tolerably



<P>through the evening, and be attacked by no regrets but her own.



<P>The backgammon-table was placed; but a visitor immediately afterwards



<P>walked in and made it unnecessary.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Knightley, a sensible man about seven or eight-and-thirty, was not



<P>only a very old and intimate friend of the family, but particularly



<P>connected with it, as the elder brother of Isabella's husband.



<P>He lived about a mile from Highbury, was a frequent visitor,



<P>and always welcome, and at this time more welcome than usual,



<P>as coming directly from their mutual connexions in London.&nbsp; He

had



<P>returned to a late dinner, after some days' absence, and now walked



<P>up to Hartfield to say that all were well in Brunswick Square.



<P>It was a happy circumstance, and animated Mr. Woodhouse for some time.



<P>Mr. Knightley had a cheerful manner, which always did him good;



<P>and his many inquiries after "poor Isabella" and her children were



<P>answered most satisfactorily.&nbsp; When this was over, Mr. Woodhouse



<P>gratefully observed, "It is very kind of you, Mr. Knightley, to come



<P>out at this late hour to call upon us.&nbsp; I am afraid you must have



<P>had a shocking walk."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not at all, sir.&nbsp; It is a beautiful moonlight night; and so mild



<P>that I must draw back from your great fire."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But you must have found it very damp and dirty.&nbsp; I wish you may



<P>not catch cold."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Dirty, sir! Look at my shoes.&nbsp; Not a speck on them."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well! that is quite surprising, for we have had a vast deal



<P>of rain here.&nbsp; It rained dreadfully hard for half an hour



<P>while we were at breakfast.&nbsp; I wanted them to put off the wedding."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"By the bye--I have not wished you joy.&nbsp; Being pretty well aware



<P>of what sort of joy you must both be feeling, I have been in no hurry



<P>with my congratulations; but I hope it all went off tolerably well.



<P>How did you all behave? Who cried most?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah! poor Miss Taylor! 'Tis a sad business."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Poor Mr. and Miss Woodhouse, if you please; but I cannot possibly



<P>say `poor Miss Taylor.' I have a great regard for you and Emma;



<P>but when it comes to the question of dependence or independence!--At



<P>any rate, it must be better to have only one to please than two."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Especially when one of those two is such a fanciful, troublesome creature!"



<P>said Emma playfully.&nbsp; "That is what you have in your head,



<P>I know--and what you would certainly say if my father were not by."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I believe it is very true, my dear, indeed," said Mr. Woodhouse,



<P>with a sigh.&nbsp; "I am afraid I am sometimes very fanciful and troublesome."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dearest papa! You do not think I could mean you, or suppose



<P>Mr. Knightley to mean you.&nbsp; What a horrible idea! Oh no! I meant



<P>only myself.&nbsp; Mr. Knightley loves to find fault with me, you know--



<P>in a joke--it is all a joke.&nbsp; We always say what we like to one

another."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Knightley, in fact, was one of the few people who could see



<P>faults in Emma Woodhouse, and the only one who ever told her of them:



<P>and though this was not particularly agreeable to Emma herself,



<P>she knew it would be so much less so to her father, that she would



<P>not have him really suspect such a circumstance as her not being



<P>thought perfect by every body.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Emma knows I never flatter her," said Mr. Knightley, "but I



<P>meant no reflection on any body.&nbsp; Miss Taylor has been used



<P>to have two persons to please; she will now have but one.



<P>The chances are that she must be a gainer."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well," said Emma, willing to let it pass--"you want to hear



<P>about the wedding; and I shall be happy to tell you, for we all



<P>behaved charmingly.&nbsp; Every body was punctual, every body in their



<P>best looks: not a tear, and hardly a long face to be seen.&nbsp; Oh

no;



<P>we all felt that we were going to be only half a mile apart,



<P>and were sure of meeting every day."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Dear Emma bears every thing so well," said her father.



<P>"But, Mr. Knightley, she is really very sorry to lose poor Miss Taylor,



<P>and I am sure she will miss her more than she thinks for."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma turned away her head, divided between tears and smiles.



<P>"It is impossible that Emma should not miss such a companion,"



<P>said Mr. Knightley.&nbsp; "We should not like her so well as we do,

sir,



<P>if we could suppose it; but she knows how much the marriage is to



<P>Miss Taylor's advantage; she knows how very acceptable it must be,



<P>at Miss Taylor's time of life, to be settled in a home of her own,



<P>and how important to her to be secure of a comfortable provision,



<P>and therefore cannot allow herself to feel so much pain as pleasure.



<P>Every friend of Miss Taylor must be glad to have her so happily



<P>married."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And you have forgotten one matter of joy to me," said Emma,



<P>"and a very considerable one--that I made the match myself.



<P>I made the match, you know, four years ago; and to have it take place,



<P>and be proved in the right, when so many people said Mr. Weston would



<P>never marry again, may comfort me for any thing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Knightley shook his head at her.&nbsp; Her father fondly replied,



<P>"Ah! my dear, I wish you would not make matches and foretell things,



<P>for whatever you say always comes to pass.&nbsp; Pray do not make any



<P>more matches."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I promise you to make none for myself, papa; but I must, indeed,



<P>for other people.&nbsp; It is the greatest amusement in the world! And



<P>after such success, you know!--Every body said that Mr. Weston would



<P>never marry again.&nbsp; Oh dear, no! Mr. Weston, who had been a widower



<P>so long, and who seemed so perfectly comfortable without a wife,



<P>so constantly occupied either in his business in town or among his



<P>friends here, always acceptable wherever he went, always cheerful--



<P>Mr. Weston need not spend a single evening in the year alone if he did



<P>not like it.&nbsp; Oh no! Mr. Weston certainly would never marry again.



<P>Some people even talked of a promise to his wife on her deathbed,



<P>and others of the son and the uncle not letting him.&nbsp; All manner



<P>of solemn nonsense was talked on the subject, but I believed none



<P>of it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ever since the day--about four years ago--that Miss Taylor and I



<P>met with him in Broadway Lane, when, because it began to drizzle,



<P>he darted away with so much gallantry, and borrowed two umbrellas



<P>for us from Farmer Mitchell's, I made up my mind on the subject.



<P>I planned the match from that hour; and when such success has blessed



<P>me in this instance, dear papa, you cannot think that I shall leave



<P>off match-making."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not understand what you mean by `success,'" said Mr. Knightley.



<P>"Success supposes endeavour.&nbsp; Your time has been properly and



<P>delicately spent, if you have been endeavouring for the last four



<P>years to bring about this marriage.&nbsp; A worthy employment for a

young



<P>lady's mind! But if, which I rather imagine, your making the match,



<P>as you call it, means only your planning it, your saying to yourself



<P>one idle day, `I think it would be a very good thing for Miss Taylor



<P>if Mr. Weston were to marry her,' and saying it again to yourself



<P>every now and then afterwards, why do you talk of success? Where



<P>is your merit? What are you proud of? You made a lucky guess;



<P>and that is all that can be said."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And have you never known the pleasure and triumph of a lucky guess?--



<P>I pity you.--I thought you cleverer--for, depend upon it a lucky



<P>guess is never merely luck.&nbsp; There is always some talent in it.



<P>And as to my poor word `success,' which you quarrel with, I do not



<P>know that I am so entirely without any claim to it.&nbsp; You have drawn



<P>two pretty pictures; but I think there may be a third--a something



<P>between the do-nothing and the do-all. If I had not promoted Mr. Weston's



<P>visits here, and given many little encouragements, and smoothed



<P>many little matters, it might not have come to any thing after all.



<P>I think you must know Hartfield enough to comprehend that."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A straightforward, open-hearted man like Weston, and a rational,



<P>unaffected woman like Miss Taylor, may be safely left to manage their



<P>own concerns.&nbsp; You are more likely to have done harm to yourself,



<P>than good to them, by interference."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Emma never thinks of herself, if she can do good to others,"



<P>rejoined Mr. Woodhouse, understanding but in part.&nbsp; "But, my dear,



<P>pray do not make any more matches; they are silly things, and break

up



<P>one's family circle grievously."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Only one more, papa; only for Mr. Elton.&nbsp; Poor Mr. Elton! You



<P>like Mr. Elton, papa,--I must look about for a wife for him.



<P>There is nobody in Highbury who deserves him--and he has been



<P>here a whole year, and has fitted up his house so comfortably,



<P>that it would be a shame to have him single any longer--and I thought



<P>when he was joining their hands to-day, he looked so very much as if



<P>he would like to have the same kind office done for him! I think



<P>very well of Mr. Elton, and this is the only way I have of doing



<P>him a service."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mr. Elton is a very pretty young man, to be sure, and a very



<P>good young man, and I have a great regard for him.&nbsp; But if you



<P>want to shew him any attention, my dear, ask him to come



<P>and dine with us some day.&nbsp; That will be a much better thing.



<P>I dare say Mr. Knightley will be so kind as to meet him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"With a great deal of pleasure, sir, at any time," said Mr. Knightley,



<P>laughing, "and I agree with you entirely, that it will be a much



<P>better thing.&nbsp; Invite him to dinner, Emma, and help him to the

best



<P>of the fish and the chicken, but leave him to chuse his own wife.



<P>Depend upon it, a man of six or seven-and-twenty can take care



<P>of himself."



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;

</HTML>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
