   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 15</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XV</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Mr. Woodhouse was soon ready for his tea; and when he had drank his



<P>tea he was quite ready to go home; and it was as much as his three



<P>companions could do, to entertain away his notice of the lateness



<P>of the hour, before the other gentlemen appeared.&nbsp; Mr. Weston was



<P>chatty and convivial, and no friend to early separations of any sort;



<P>but at last the drawing-room party did receive an augmentation.



<P>Mr. Elton, in very good spirits, was one of the first to walk in.



<P>Mrs. Weston and Emma were sitting together on a sofa.&nbsp; He joined



<P>them immediately, and, with scarcely an invitation, seated himself



<P>between them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma, in good spirits too, from the amusement afforded her mind



<P>by the expectation of Mr. Frank Churchill, was willing to forget



<P>his late improprieties, and be as well satisfied with him as before,



<P>and on his making Harriet his very first subject, was ready to listen



<P>with most friendly smiles.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He professed himself extremely anxious about her fair friend--



<P>her fair, lovely, amiable friend.&nbsp; "Did she know?--had she



<P>heard any thing about her, since their being at Randalls?--



<P>he felt much anxiety--he must confess that the nature of her



<P>complaint alarmed him considerably."&nbsp; And in this style he talked



<P>on for some time very properly, not much attending to any answer,



<P>but altogether sufficiently awake to the terror of a bad sore throat;



<P>and Emma was quite in charity with him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But at last there seemed a perverse turn; it seemed all at once as if



<P>he were more afraid of its being a bad sore throat on her account,



<P>than on Harriet's--more anxious that she should escape the infection,



<P>than that there should be no infection in the complaint.&nbsp; He began



<P>with great earnestness to entreat her to refrain from visiting



<P>the sick-chamber again, for the present--to entreat her to promise



<P>him not to venture into such hazard till he had seen Mr. Perry



<P>and learnt his opinion; and though she tried to laugh it off



<P>and bring the subject back into its proper course, there was no



<P>putting an end to his extreme solicitude about her.&nbsp; She was vexed.



<P>It did appear--there was no concealing it--exactly like the pretence



<P>of being in love with her, instead of Harriet; an inconstancy,



<P>if real, the most contemptible and abominable! and she had difficulty



<P>in behaving with temper.&nbsp; He turned to Mrs. Weston to implore



<P>her assistance, "Would not she give him her support?--would not she



<P>add her persuasions to his, to induce Miss Woodhouse not to go



<P>to Mrs. Goddard's till it were certain that Miss Smith's disorder



<P>had no infection?&nbsp; He could not be satisfied without a promise--



<P>would not she give him her influence in procuring it?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So scrupulous for others," he continued, "and yet so careless



<P>for herself!&nbsp; She wanted me to nurse my cold by staying at home

to-day,



<P>and yet will not promise to avoid the danger of catching an ulcerated



<P>sore throat herself.&nbsp; Is this fair, Mrs. Weston?--Judge between

us.



<P>Have not I some right to complain?&nbsp; I am sure of your kind support



<P>and aid."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma saw Mrs. Weston's surprize, and felt that it must be great,



<P>at an address which, in words and manner, was assuming to himself



<P>the right of first interest in her; and as for herself, she was



<P>too much provoked and offended to have the power of directly



<P>saying any thing to the purpose.&nbsp; She could only give him a look;



<P>but it was such a look as she thought must restore him to his senses,



<P>and then left the sofa, removing to a seat by her sister, and giving



<P>her all her attention.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She had not time to know how Mr. Elton took the reproof, so rapidly



<P>did another subject succeed; for Mr. John Knightley now came



<P>into the room from examining the weather, and opened on them



<P>all with the information of the ground being covered with snow,



<P>and of its still snowing fast, with a strong drifting wind;



<P>concluding with these words to Mr. Woodhouse:

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"This will prove a spirited beginning of your winter engagements,



<P>sir.&nbsp; Something new for your coachman and horses to be making



<P>their way through a storm of snow."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Poor Mr. Woodhouse was silent from consternation; but every body else



<P>had something to say; every body was either surprized or not surprized,



<P>and had some question to ask, or some comfort to offer.&nbsp; Mrs. Weston



<P>and Emma tried earnestly to cheer him and turn his attention



<P>from his son-in-law, who was pursuing his triumph rather unfeelingly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I admired your resolution very much, sir," said he, "in venturing



<P>out in such weather, for of course you saw there would be snow



<P>very soon.&nbsp; Every body must have seen the snow coming on.



<P>I admired your spirit; and I dare say we shall get home very well.



<P>Another hour or two's snow can hardly make the road impassable;



<P>and we are two carriages; if one is blown over in the bleak part



<P>of the common field there will be the other at hand.&nbsp; I dare say

we



<P>shall be all safe at Hartfield before midnight."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Weston, with triumph of a different sort, was confessing that he



<P>had known it to be snowing some time, but had not said a word,



<P>lest it should make Mr. Woodhouse uncomfortable, and be an excuse



<P>for his hurrying away.&nbsp; As to there being any quantity of snow

fallen



<P>or likely to fall to impede their return, that was a mere joke;



<P>he was afraid they would find no difficulty.&nbsp; He wished the road

might



<P>be impassable, that he might be able to keep them all at Randalls;



<P>and with the utmost good-will was sure that accommodation might



<P>be found for every body, calling on his wife to agree with him,



<P>that with a little contrivance, every body might be lodged,



<P>which she hardly knew how to do, from the consciousness of there



<P>being but two spare rooms in the house.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What is to be done, my dear Emma?--what is to be done?"



<P>was Mr. Woodhouse's first exclamation, and all that he could say



<P>for some time.&nbsp; To her he looked for comfort; and her assurances



<P>of safety, her representation of the excellence of the horses,



<P>and of James, and of their having so many friends about them,



<P>revived him a little.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>His eldest daughter's alarm was equal to his own.&nbsp; The horror of



<P>being blocked up at Randalls, while her children were at Hartfield,



<P>was full in her imagination; and fancying the road to be now just



<P>passable for adventurous people, but in a state that admitted no delay,



<P>she was eager to have it settled, that her father and Emma should remain



<P>at Randalls, while she and her husband set forward instantly through



<P>all the possible accumulations of drifted snow that might impede them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You had better order the carriage directly, my love," said she;



<P>"I dare say we shall be able to get along, if we set off directly;



<P>and if we do come to any thing very bad, I can get out and walk.



<P>I am not at all afraid.&nbsp; I should not mind walking half the way.



<P>I could change my shoes, you know, the moment I got home; and it is

not



<P>the sort of thing that gives me cold."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Indeed!" replied he.&nbsp; "Then, my dear Isabella, it is the most



<P>extraordinary sort of thing in the world, for in general every



<P>thing does give you cold.&nbsp; Walk home!--you are prettily shod



<P>for walking home, I dare say.&nbsp; It will be bad enough for the horses."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Isabella turned to Mrs. Weston for her approbation of the plan.



<P>Mrs. Weston could only approve.&nbsp; Isabella then went to Emma;



<P>but Emma could not so entirely give up the hope of their being



<P>all able to get away; and they were still discussing the point,



<P>when Mr. Knightley, who had left the room immediately after his



<P>brother's first report of the snow, came back again, and told them



<P>that he had been out of doors to examine, and could answer for there



<P>not being the smallest difficulty in their getting home, whenever they



<P>liked it, either now or an hour hence.&nbsp; He had gone beyond the

sweep--



<P>some way along the Highbury road--the snow was nowhere above half



<P>an inch deep--in many places hardly enough to whiten the ground;



<P>a very few flakes were falling at present, but the clouds were parting,



<P>and there was every appearance of its being soon over.&nbsp; He had

seen



<P>the coachmen, and they both agreed with him in there being nothing



<P>to apprehend.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To Isabella, the relief of such tidings was very great, and they



<P>were scarcely less acceptable to Emma on her father's account,



<P>who was immediately set as much at ease on the subject as his nervous



<P>constitution allowed; but the alarm that had been raised could not



<P>be appeased so as to admit of any comfort for him while he continued



<P>at Randalls.&nbsp; He was satisfied of there being no present danger

in



<P>returning home, but no assurances could convince him that it was safe



<P>to stay; and while the others were variously urging and recommending,



<P>Mr. Knightley and Emma settled it in a few brief sentences:&nbsp; thus--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Your father will not be easy; why do not you go?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am ready, if the others are."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Shall I ring the bell?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, do."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>And the bell was rung, and the carriages spoken for.&nbsp; A few



<P>minutes more, and Emma hoped to see one troublesome companion



<P>deposited in his own house, to get sober and cool, and the other



<P>recover his temper and happiness when this visit of hardship were over.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The carriage came:&nbsp; and Mr. Woodhouse, always the first object

on



<P>such occasions, was carefully attended to his own by Mr. Knightley



<P>and Mr. Weston; but not all that either could say could prevent some



<P>renewal of alarm at the sight of the snow which had actually fallen,



<P>and the discovery of a much darker night than he had been prepared for.



<P>"He was afraid they should have a very bad drive.&nbsp; He was afraid



<P>poor Isabella would not like it.&nbsp; And there would be poor Emma



<P>in the carriage behind.&nbsp; He did not know what they had best do.



<P>They must keep as much together as they could;" and James was talked

to,



<P>and given a charge to go very slow and wait for the other carriage.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Isabella stept in after her father; John Knightley, forgetting that

he



<P>did not belong to their party, stept in after his wife very naturally;



<P>so that Emma found, on being escorted and followed into the second



<P>carriage by Mr. Elton, that the door was to be lawfully shut on them,



<P>and that they were to have a tete-a-tete drive.&nbsp; It would not have

been



<P>the awkwardness of a moment, it would have been rather a pleasure,



<P>previous to the suspicions of this very day; she could have talked



<P>to him of Harriet, and the three-quarters of a mile would have



<P>seemed but one.&nbsp; But now, she would rather it had not happened.



<P>She believed he had been drinking too much of Mr. Weston's good wine,



<P>and felt sure that he would want to be talking nonsense.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To restrain him as much as might be, by her own manners, she was



<P>immediately preparing to speak with exquisite calmness and gravity



<P>of the weather and the night; but scarcely had she begun, scarcely had



<P>they passed the sweep-gate and joined the other carriage, than she



<P>found her subject cut up--her hand seized--her attention demanded,



<P>and Mr. Elton actually making violent love to her:&nbsp; availing himself



<P>of the precious opportunity, declaring sentiments which must be already



<P>well known, hoping--fearing--adoring--ready to die if she refused him;



<P>but flattering himself that his ardent attachment and unequalled



<P>love and unexampled passion could not fail of having some effect,



<P>and in short, very much resolved on being seriously accepted as soon



<P>as possible.&nbsp; It really was so.&nbsp; Without scruple--without

apology--



<P>without much apparent diffidence, Mr. Elton, the lover of Harriet,



<P>was professing himself her lover.&nbsp; She tried to stop him; but vainly;



<P>he would go on, and say it all.&nbsp; Angry as she was, the thought

of



<P>the moment made her resolve to restrain herself when she did speak.



<P>She felt that half this folly must be drunkenness, and therefore



<P>could hope that it might belong only to the passing hour.



<P>Accordingly, with a mixture of the serious and the playful, which she



<P>hoped would best suit his half and half state, she replied,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am very much astonished, Mr. Elton.&nbsp; This to me! you forget

yourself--



<P>you take me for my friend--any message to Miss Smith I shall



<P>be happy to deliver; but no more of this to me, if you please."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Miss Smith!--message to Miss Smith!--What could she possibly mean!"--



<P>And he repeated her words with such assurance of accent, such boastful



<P>pretence of amazement, that she could not help replying with quickness,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mr. Elton, this is the most extraordinary conduct! and I can account



<P>for it only in one way; you are not yourself, or you could not speak



<P>either to me, or of Harriet, in such a manner.&nbsp; Command yourself



<P>enough to say no more, and I will endeavour to forget it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But Mr. Elton had only drunk wine enough to elevate his spirits,



<P>not at all to confuse his intellects.&nbsp; He perfectly knew his own

meaning;



<P>and having warmly protested against her suspicion as most injurious,



<P>and slightly touched upon his respect for Miss Smith as her friend,--



<P>but acknowledging his wonder that Miss Smith should be mentioned



<P>at all,--he resumed the subject of his own passion, and was very



<P>urgent for a favourable answer.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As she thought less of his inebriety, she thought more of his inconstancy



<P>and presumption; and with fewer struggles for politeness, replied,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is impossible for me to doubt any longer.&nbsp; You have made



<P>yourself too clear.&nbsp; Mr. Elton, my astonishment is much beyond



<P>any thing I can express.&nbsp; After such behaviour, as I have witnessed



<P>during the last month, to Miss Smith--such attentions as I



<P>have been in the daily habit of observing--to be addressing me



<P>in this manner--this is an unsteadiness of character, indeed,



<P>which I had not supposed possible!&nbsp; Believe me, sir, I am far,



<P>very far, from gratified in being the object of such professions."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Good Heaven!" cried Mr. Elton, "what can be the meaning of this?--



<P>Miss Smith!--I never thought of Miss Smith in the whole course



<P>of my existence--never paid her any attentions, but as your friend:



<P>never cared whether she were dead or alive, but as your friend.



<P>If she has fancied otherwise, her own wishes have misled her,



<P>and I am very sorry--extremely sorry--But, Miss Smith, indeed!--Oh!



<P>Miss Woodhouse! who can think of Miss Smith, when Miss Woodhouse



<P>is near!&nbsp; No, upon my honour, there is no unsteadiness of character.



<P>I have thought only of you.&nbsp; I protest against having paid the

smallest



<P>attention to any one else.&nbsp; Every thing that I have said or done,



<P>for many weeks past, has been with the sole view of marking my



<P>adoration of yourself.&nbsp; You cannot really, seriously, doubt it.



<P>No!--(in an accent meant to be insinuating)--I am sure you have seen



<P>and understood me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It would be impossible to say what Emma felt, on hearing this--



<P>which of all her unpleasant sensations was uppermost.&nbsp; She was



<P>too completely overpowered to be immediately able to reply:



<P>and two moments of silence being ample encouragement for Mr. Elton's



<P>sanguine state of mind, he tried to take her hand again, as he



<P>joyously exclaimed--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Charming Miss Woodhouse! allow me to interpret this interesting silence.



<P>It confesses that you have long understood me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, sir," cried Emma, "it confesses no such thing.&nbsp; So far from



<P>having long understood you, I have been in a most complete error



<P>with respect to your views, till this moment.&nbsp; As to myself, I

am



<P>very sorry that you should have been giving way to any feelings--



<P>Nothing could be farther from my wishes--your attachment to my



<P>friend Harriet--your pursuit of her, (pursuit, it appeared,) gave me



<P>great pleasure, and I have been very earnestly wishing you success:



<P>but had I supposed that she were not your attraction to Hartfield,



<P>I should certainly have thought you judged ill in making your visits



<P>so frequent.&nbsp; Am I to believe that you have never sought to recommend



<P>yourself particularly to Miss Smith?--that you have never thought



<P>seriously of her?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Never, madam," cried he, affronted in his turn:&nbsp; "never, I assure

you.



<P>I think seriously of Miss Smith!--Miss Smith is a very good sort



<P>of girl; and I should be happy to see her respectably settled.



<P>I wish her extremely well:&nbsp; and, no doubt, there are men who might

not



<P>object to--Every body has their level:&nbsp; but as for myself, I am

not,



<P>I think, quite so much at a loss.&nbsp; I need not so totally despair



<P>of an equal alliance, as to be addressing myself to Miss Smith!--



<P>No, madam, my visits to Hartfield have been for yourself only;



<P>and the encouragement I received--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Encouragement!--I give you encouragement!--Sir, you have been entirely



<P>mistaken in supposing it.&nbsp; I have seen you only as the admirer



<P>of my friend.&nbsp; In no other light could you have been more to me

than



<P>a common acquaintance.&nbsp; I am exceedingly sorry:&nbsp; but it is

well that



<P>the mistake ends where it does.&nbsp; Had the same behaviour continued,



<P>Miss Smith might have been led into a misconception of your views;



<P>not being aware, probably, any more than myself, of the very



<P>great inequality which you are so sensible of.&nbsp; But, as it is,



<P>the disappointment is single, and, I trust, will not be lasting.



<P>I have no thoughts of matrimony at present."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He was too angry to say another word; her manner too decided



<P>to invite supplication; and in this state of swelling resentment,



<P>and mutually deep mortification, they had to continue together a few



<P>minutes longer, for the fears of Mr. Woodhouse had confined them



<P>to a foot-pace. If there had not been so much anger, there would have



<P>been desperate awkwardness; but their straightforward emotions left



<P>no room for the little zigzags of embarrassment.&nbsp; Without knowing



<P>when the carriage turned into Vicarage Lane, or when it stopped,



<P>they found themselves, all at once, at the door of his house;



<P>and he was out before another syllable passed.--Emma then felt it



<P>indispensable to wish him a good night.&nbsp; The compliment was just

returned,



<P>coldly and proudly; and, under indescribable irritation of spirits,



<P>she was then conveyed to Hartfield.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There she was welcomed, with the utmost delight, by her father,



<P>who had been trembling for the dangers of a solitary drive from



<P>Vicarage Lane--turning a corner which he could never bear to think of--



<P>and in strange hands--a mere common coachman--no James; and there it



<P>seemed as if her return only were wanted to make every thing go well:



<P>for Mr. John Knightley, ashamed of his ill-humour, was now all



<P>kindness and attention; and so particularly solicitous for the comfort



<P>of her father, as to seem--if not quite ready to join him in a basin



<P>of gruel--perfectly sensible of its being exceedingly wholesome;



<P>and the day was concluding in peace and comfort to all their little

party,



<P>except herself.--But her mind had never been in such perturbation;



<P>and it needed a very strong effort to appear attentive and cheerful

till



<P>the usual hour of separating allowed her the relief of quiet reflection.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 14</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XIV</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Some change of countenance was necessary for each gentleman



<P>as they walked into Mrs. Weston's drawing-room;--Mr. Elton must



<P>compose his joyous looks, and Mr. John Knightley disperse his



<P>ill-humour. Mr. Elton must smile less, and Mr. John Knightley more,



<P>to fit them for the place.--Emma only might be as nature prompted,



<P>and shew herself just as happy as she was.&nbsp; To her it was real



<P>enjoyment to be with the Westons.&nbsp; Mr. Weston was a great favourite,



<P>and there was not a creature in the world to whom she spoke with



<P>such unreserve, as to his wife; not any one, to whom she related



<P>with such conviction of being listened to and understood, of being



<P>always interesting and always intelligible, the little affairs,



<P>arrangements, perplexities, and pleasures of her father and herself.



<P>She could tell nothing of Hartfield, in which Mrs. Weston had not



<P>a lively concern; and half an hour's uninterrupted communication



<P>of all those little matters on which the daily happiness of private



<P>life depends, was one of the first gratifications of each.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This was a pleasure which perhaps the whole day's visit might



<P>not afford, which certainly did not belong to the present half-hour;



<P>but the very sight of Mrs. Weston, her smile, her touch, her voice



<P>was grateful to Emma, and she determined to think as little as



<P>possible of Mr. Elton's oddities, or of any thing else unpleasant,



<P>and enjoy all that was enjoyable to the utmost.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The misfortune of Harriet's cold had been pretty well gone through



<P>before her arrival.&nbsp; Mr. Woodhouse had been safely seated long



<P>enough to give the history of it, besides all the history of his own



<P>and Isabella's coming, and of Emma's being to follow, and had indeed



<P>just got to the end of his satisfaction that James should come



<P>and see his daughter, when the others appeared, and Mrs. Weston,



<P>who had been almost wholly engrossed by her attentions to him,



<P>was able to turn away and welcome her dear Emma.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma's project of forgetting Mr. Elton for a while made her rather



<P>sorry to find, when they had all taken their places, that he was



<P>close to her.&nbsp; The difficulty was great of driving his strange



<P>insensibility towards Harriet, from her mind, while he not only sat



<P>at her elbow, but was continually obtruding his happy countenance



<P>on her notice, and solicitously addressing her upon every occasion.



<P>Instead of forgetting him, his behaviour was such that she could



<P>not avoid the internal suggestion of "Can it really be as my brother



<P>imagined? can it be possible for this man to be beginning to transfer



<P>his affections from Harriet to me?--Absurd and insufferable!"--



<P>Yet he would be so anxious for her being perfectly warm, would be



<P>so interested about her father, and so delighted with Mrs. Weston;



<P>and at last would begin admiring her drawings with so much zeal



<P>and so little knowledge as seemed terribly like a would-be lover,



<P>and made it some effort with her to preserve her good manners.



<P>For her own sake she could not be rude; and for Harriet's, in the hope



<P>that all would yet turn out right, she was even positively civil;



<P>but it was an effort; especially as something was going on amongst



<P>the others, in the most overpowering period of Mr. Elton's nonsense,



<P>which she particularly wished to listen to.&nbsp; She heard enough



<P>to know that Mr. Weston was giving some information about his son;



<P>she heard the words "my son," and "Frank," and "my son,"



<P>repeated several times over; and, from a few other half-syllables



<P>very much suspected that he was announcing an early visit from



<P>his son; but before she could quiet Mr. Elton, the subject was



<P>so completely past that any reviving question from her would have



<P>been awkward.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Now, it so happened that in spite of Emma's resolution of never marrying,



<P>there was something in the name, in the idea of Mr. Frank Churchill,



<P>which always interested her.&nbsp; She had frequently thought--especially

since



<P>his father's marriage with Miss Taylor--that if she were to marry,



<P>he was the very person to suit her in age, character and condition.



<P>He seemed by this connexion between the families, quite to belong to

her.



<P>She could not but suppose it to be a match that every body who knew



<P>them must think of.&nbsp; That Mr. and Mrs. Weston did think of it,

she was



<P>very strongly persuaded; and though not meaning to be induced by him,



<P>or by any body else, to give up a situation which she believed more



<P>replete with good than any she could change it for, she had a great



<P>curiosity to see him, a decided intention of finding him pleasant,



<P>of being liked by him to a certain degree, and a sort of pleasure



<P>in the idea of their being coupled in their friends' imaginations.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>With such sensations, Mr. Elton's civilities were dreadfully ill-timed;



<P>but she had the comfort of appearing very polite, while feeling



<P>very cross--and of thinking that the rest of the visit could not



<P>possibly pass without bringing forward the same information again,



<P>or the substance of it, from the open-hearted Mr. Weston.--So it proved;--



<P>for when happily released from Mr. Elton, and seated by Mr. Weston,



<P>at dinner, he made use of the very first interval in the cares



<P>of hospitality, the very first leisure from the saddle of mutton,



<P>to say to her,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We want only two more to be just the right number.&nbsp; I should



<P>like to see two more here,--your pretty little friend, Miss Smith,



<P>and my son--and then I should say we were quite complete.



<P>I believe you did not hear me telling the others in the drawing-room



<P>that we are expecting Frank.&nbsp; I had a letter from him this morning,



<P>and he will be with us within a fortnight."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma spoke with a very proper degree of pleasure; and fully assented



<P>to his proposition of Mr. Frank Churchill and Miss Smith making



<P>their party quite complete.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He has been wanting to come to us," continued Mr. Weston,



<P>"ever since September:&nbsp; every letter has been full of it;



<P>but he cannot command his own time.&nbsp; He has those to please



<P>who must be pleased, and who (between ourselves) are sometimes



<P>to be pleased only by a good many sacrifices.&nbsp; But now



<P>I have no doubt of seeing him here about the second week in January."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What a very great pleasure it will be to you! and Mrs. Weston



<P>is so anxious to be acquainted with him, that she must be almost



<P>as happy as yourself."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, she would be, but that she thinks there will be another



<P>put-off. She does not depend upon his coming so much as I do:



<P>but she does not know the parties so well as I do.&nbsp; The case,



<P>you see, is--(but this is quite between ourselves:&nbsp; I did not mention



<P>a syllable of it in the other room.&nbsp; There are secrets in all families,



<P>you know)--The case is, that a party of friends are invited to pay



<P>a visit at Enscombe in January; and that Frank's coming depends upon



<P>their being put off.&nbsp; If they are not put off, he cannot stir.



<P>But I know they will, because it is a family that a certain lady,



<P>of some consequence, at Enscombe, has a particular dislike to:



<P>and though it is thought necessary to invite them once in two or



<P>three years, they always are put off when it comes to the point.



<P>I have not the smallest doubt of the issue.&nbsp; I am as confident



<P>of seeing Frank here before the middle of January, as I am



<P>of being here myself:&nbsp; but your good friend there (nodding



<P>towards the upper end of the table) has so few vagaries herself,



<P>and has been so little used to them at Hartfield, that she cannot



<P>calculate on their effects, as I have been long in the practice



<P>of doing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am sorry there should be any thing like doubt in the case,"



<P>replied Emma; "but am disposed to side with you, Mr. Weston.&nbsp; If

you



<P>think he will come, I shall think so too; for you know Enscombe."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes--I have some right to that knowledge; though I have never been



<P>at the place in my life.--She is an odd woman!--But I never allow



<P>myself to speak ill of her, on Frank's account; for I do believe



<P>her to be very fond of him.&nbsp; I used to think she was not capable



<P>of being fond of any body, except herself:&nbsp; but she has always

been



<P>kind to him (in her way--allowing for little whims and caprices,



<P>and expecting every thing to be as she likes). And it is no small credit,



<P>in my opinion, to him, that he should excite such an affection;



<P>for, though I would not say it to any body else, she has no more



<P>heart than a stone to people in general; and the devil of a temper."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma liked the subject so well, that she began upon it, to Mrs. Weston,



<P>very soon after their moving into the drawing-room: wishing her joy--



<P>yet observing, that she knew the first meeting must be rather alarming.--



<P>Mrs. Weston agreed to it; but added, that she should be very



<P>glad to be secure of undergoing the anxiety of a first meeting



<P>at the time talked of:&nbsp; "for I cannot depend upon his coming.



<P>I cannot be so sanguine as Mr. Weston.&nbsp; I am very much afraid



<P>that it will all end in nothing.&nbsp; Mr. Weston, I dare say, has been



<P>telling you exactly how the matter stands?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes--it seems to depend upon nothing but the ill-humour



<P>of Mrs. Churchill, which I imagine to be the most certain



<P>thing in the world."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My Emma!" replied Mrs. Weston, smiling, "what is the certainty



<P>of caprice?"&nbsp; Then turning to Isabella, who had not been



<P>attending before--"You must know, my dear Mrs. Knightley,



<P>that we are by no means so sure of seeing Mr. Frank Churchill,



<P>in my opinion, as his father thinks.&nbsp; It depends entirely upon



<P>his aunt's spirits and pleasure; in short, upon her temper.



<P>To you--to my two daughters--I may venture on the truth.



<P>Mrs. Churchill rules at Enscombe, and is a very odd-tempered woman;



<P>and his coming now, depends upon her being willing to spare him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, Mrs. Churchill; every body knows Mrs. Churchill,"



<P>replied Isabella:&nbsp; "and I am sure I never think of that poor young



<P>man without the greatest compassion.&nbsp; To be constantly living



<P>with an ill-tempered person, must be dreadful.&nbsp; It is what we



<P>happily have never known any thing of; but it must be a life



<P>of misery.&nbsp; What a blessing, that she never had any children!



<P>Poor little creatures, how unhappy she would have made them!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma wished she had been alone with Mrs. Weston.&nbsp; She should then

have



<P>heard more:&nbsp; Mrs. Weston would speak to her, with a degree of unreserve



<P>which she would not hazard with Isabella; and, she really believed,



<P>would scarcely try to conceal any thing relative to the Churchills



<P>from her, excepting those views on the young man, of which her own



<P>imagination had already given her such instinctive knowledge.



<P>But at present there was nothing more to be said.&nbsp; Mr. Woodhouse



<P>very soon followed them into the drawing-room. To be sitting



<P>long after dinner, was a confinement that he could not endure.



<P>Neither wine nor conversation was any thing to him; and gladly did



<P>he move to those with whom he was always comfortable.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>While he talked to Isabella, however, Emma found an opportunity



<P>of saying,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And so you do not consider this visit from your son as by any



<P>means certain.&nbsp; I am sorry for it.&nbsp; The introduction must

be unpleasant,



<P>whenever it takes place; and the sooner it could be over, the better."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes; and every delay makes one more apprehensive of other delays.



<P>Even if this family, the Braithwaites, are put off, I am still



<P>afraid that some excuse may be found for disappointing us.



<P>I cannot bear to imagine any reluctance on his side; but I am sure



<P>there is a great wish on the Churchills' to keep him to themselves.



<P>There is jealousy.&nbsp; They are jealous even of his regard for his

father.



<P>In short, I can feel no dependence on his coming, and I wish Mr. Weston



<P>were less sanguine."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He ought to come," said Emma.&nbsp; "If he could stay only a couple



<P>of days, he ought to come; and one can hardly conceive a young man's



<P>not having it in his power to do as much as that.&nbsp; A young woman,



<P>if she fall into bad hands, may be teazed, and kept at a distance



<P>from those she wants to be with; but one cannot comprehend a young



<P>man's being under such restraint, as not to be able to spend a week



<P>with his father, if he likes it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"One ought to be at Enscombe, and know the ways of the family,



<P>before one decides upon what he can do," replied Mrs. Weston.



<P>"One ought to use the same caution, perhaps, in judging of the



<P>conduct of any one individual of any one family; but Enscombe,



<P>I believe, certainly must not be judged by general rules:



<P>she is so very unreasonable; and every thing gives way to her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But she is so fond of the nephew:&nbsp; he is so very great a favourite.



<P>Now, according to my idea of Mrs. Churchill, it would be most natural,



<P>that while she makes no sacrifice for the comfort of the husband,



<P>to whom she owes every thing, while she exercises incessant caprice



<P>towards him, she should frequently be governed by the nephew,



<P>to whom she owes nothing at all."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dearest Emma, do not pretend, with your sweet temper,



<P>to understand a bad one, or to lay down rules for it:&nbsp; you must



<P>let it go its own way.&nbsp; I have no doubt of his having, at times,



<P>considerable influence; but it may be perfectly impossible for him



<P>to know beforehand when it will be."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma listened, and then coolly said, "I shall not be satisfied,



<P>unless he comes."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He may have a great deal of influence on some points,"



<P>continued Mrs. Weston, "and on others, very little:&nbsp; and among

those,



<P>on which she is beyond his reach, it is but too likely, may be



<P>this very circumstance of his coming away from them to visit us."



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 04</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER IV</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Harriet Smith's intimacy at Hartfield was soon a settled thing.



<P>Quick and decided in her ways, Emma lost no time in inviting, encouraging,



<P>and telling her to come very often; and as their acquaintance increased,



<P>so did their satisfaction in each other.&nbsp; As a walking companion,



<P>Emma had very early foreseen how useful she might find her.



<P>In that respect Mrs. Weston's loss had been important.&nbsp; Her father



<P>never went beyond the shrubbery, where two divisions of the ground



<P>sufficed him for his long walk, or his short, as the year varied;



<P>and since Mrs. Weston's marriage her exercise had been too much confined.



<P>She had ventured once alone to Randalls, but it was not pleasant;



<P>and a Harriet Smith, therefore, one whom she could summon at any



<P>time to a walk, would be a valuable addition to her privileges.



<P>But in every respect, as she saw more of her, she approved her,



<P>and was confirmed in all her kind designs.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet certainly was not clever, but she had a sweet, docile,



<P>grateful disposition, was totally free from conceit, and only desiring



<P>to be guided by any one she looked up to.&nbsp; Her early attachment



<P>to herself was very amiable; and her inclination for good company,



<P>and power of appreciating what was elegant and clever, shewed that



<P>there was no want of taste, though strength of understanding must



<P>not be expected.&nbsp; Altogether she was quite convinced of Harriet



<P>Smith's being exactly the young friend she wanted--exactly the



<P>something which her home required.&nbsp; Such a friend as Mrs. Weston



<P>was out of the question.&nbsp; Two such could never be granted.



<P>Two such she did not want.&nbsp; It was quite a different sort of thing,



<P>a sentiment distinct and independent.&nbsp; Mrs. Weston was the object



<P>of a regard which had its basis in gratitude and esteem.



<P>Harriet would be loved as one to whom she could be useful.



<P>For Mrs. Weston there was nothing to be done; for Harriet every thing.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her first attempts at usefulness were in an endeavour to find out who



<P>were the parents, but Harriet could not tell.&nbsp; She was ready to

tell



<P>every thing in her power, but on this subject questions were vain.



<P>Emma was obliged to fancy what she liked--but she could never



<P>believe that in the same situation she should not have discovered



<P>the truth.&nbsp; Harriet had no penetration.&nbsp; She had been satisfied



<P>to hear and believe just what Mrs. Goddard chose to tell her;



<P>and looked no farther.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Goddard, and the teachers, and the girls and the affairs of the



<P>school in general, formed naturally a great part of the conversation--and



<P>but for her acquaintance with the Martins of Abbey-Mill Farm,



<P>it must have been the whole.&nbsp; But the Martins occupied her thoughts



<P>a good deal; she had spent two very happy months with them,



<P>and now loved to talk of the pleasures of her visit, and describe



<P>the many comforts and wonders of the place.&nbsp; Emma encouraged her



<P>talkativeness-- amused by such a picture of another set of beings,



<P>and enjoying the youthful simplicity which could speak with so much



<P>exultation of Mrs. Martin's having "two parlours, two very good parlours,



<P>indeed; one of them quite as large as Mrs. Goddard's drawing-room;



<P>and of her having an upper maid who had lived five-and-twenty years



<P>with her; and of their having eight cows, two of them Alderneys,



<P>and one a little Welch cow, a very pretty little Welch cow indeed;



<P>and of Mrs. Martin's saying as she was so fond of it, it should be



<P>called her cow; and of their having a very handsome summer-house



<P>in their garden, where some day next year they were all to drink



<P>tea:-- a very handsome summer-house, large enough to hold a dozen people."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>For some time she was amused, without thinking beyond the immediate

cause;



<P>but as she came to understand the family better, other feelings arose.



<P>She had taken up a wrong idea, fancying it was a mother and daughter,



<P>a son and son's wife, who all lived together; but when it appeared



<P>that the Mr. Martin, who bore a part in the narrative, and was always



<P>mentioned with approbation for his great good-nature in doing something



<P>or other, was a single man; that there was no young Mrs. Martin,



<P>no wife in the case; she did suspect danger to her poor little



<P>friend from all this hospitality and kindness, and that, if she



<P>were not taken care of, she might be required to sink herself forever.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>With this inspiriting notion, her questions increased in number



<P>and meaning; and she particularly led Harriet to talk more of Mr. Martin,



<P>and there was evidently no dislike to it.&nbsp; Harriet was very ready



<P>to speak of the share he had had in their moonlight walks and merry



<P>evening games; and dwelt a good deal upon his being so very good-humoured



<P>and obliging.&nbsp; He had gone three miles round one day in order to

bring



<P>her some walnuts, because she had said how fond she was of them,



<P>and in every thing else he was so very obliging.&nbsp; He had his



<P>shepherd's son into the parlour one night on purpose to sing to her.



<P>She was very fond of singing.&nbsp; He could sing a little himself.



<P>She believed he was very clever, and understood every thing.



<P>He had a very fine flock, and, while she was with them,



<P>he had been bid more for his wool than any body in the country.



<P>She believed every body spoke well of him.&nbsp; His mother and sisters



<P>were very fond of him.&nbsp; Mrs. Martin had told her one day (and there



<P>was a blush as she said it,) that it was impossible for any body



<P>to be a better son, and therefore she was sure, whenever he married,



<P>he would make a good husband.&nbsp; Not that she wanted him to marry.



<P>She was in no hurry at all.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well done, Mrs. Martin!" thought Emma.&nbsp; "You know what you are

about."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And when she had come away, Mrs. Martin was so very kind as to send



<P>Mrs. Goddard a beautiful goose--the finest goose Mrs. Goddard had



<P>ever seen.&nbsp; Mrs. Goddard had dressed it on a Sunday, and asked

all



<P>the three teachers, Miss Nash, and Miss Prince, and Miss Richardson,



<P>to sup with her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mr. Martin, I suppose, is not a man of information beyond the line



<P>of his own business? He does not read?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh yes!--that is, no--I do not know--but I believe he has



<P>read a good deal--but not what you would think any thing of.



<P>He reads the Agricultural Reports, and some other books that lay



<P>in one of the window seats--but he reads all them to himself.



<P>But sometimes of an evening, before we went to cards, he would read



<P>something aloud out of the Elegant Extracts, very entertaining.



<P>And I know he has read the Vicar of Wakefield.&nbsp; He never read the



<P>Romance of the Forest, nor The Children of the Abbey.&nbsp; He had never



<P>heard of such books before I mentioned them, but he is determined



<P>to get them now as soon as ever he can."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The next question was--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What sort of looking man is Mr. Martin?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! not handsome--not at all handsome.&nbsp; I thought him very plain



<P>at first, but I do not think him so plain now.&nbsp; One does not, you

know,



<P>after a time.&nbsp; But did you never see him? He is in Highbury every



<P>now and then, and he is sure to ride through every week in his way



<P>to Kingston.&nbsp; He has passed you very often."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That may be, and I may have seen him fifty times, but without



<P>having any idea of his name.&nbsp; A young farmer, whether on horseback



<P>or on foot, is the very last sort of person to raise my curiosity.



<P>The yeomanry are precisely the order of people with whom I feel I



<P>can have nothing to do.&nbsp; A degree or two lower, and a creditable



<P>appearance might interest me; I might hope to be useful to their



<P>families in some way or other.&nbsp; But a farmer can need none of my

help,



<P>and is, therefore, in one sense, as much above my notice as in every



<P>other he is below it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"To be sure.&nbsp; Oh yes! It is not likely you should ever have



<P>observed him; but he knows you very well indeed--I mean by sight."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have no doubt of his being a very respectable young man.



<P>I know, indeed, that he is so, and, as such, wish him well.



<P>What do you imagine his age to be?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He was four-and-twenty the 8th of last June, and my birthday is



<P>the 23rd just a fortnight and a day's difference--which is very odd."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Only four-and-twenty. That is too young to settle.&nbsp; His mother

is



<P>perfectly right not to be in a hurry.&nbsp; They seem very comfortable



<P>as they are, and if she were to take any pains to marry him,



<P>she would probably repent it.&nbsp; Six years hence, if he could meet



<P>with a good sort of young woman in the same rank as his own,



<P>with a little money, it might be very desirable."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Six years hence! Dear Miss Woodhouse, he would be thirty years old!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, and that is as early as most men can afford to marry,



<P>who are not born to an independence.&nbsp; Mr. Martin, I imagine,



<P>has his fortune entirely to make--cannot be at all beforehand with



<P>the world.&nbsp; Whatever money he might come into when his father died,



<P>whatever his share of the family property, it is, I dare say,



<P>all afloat, all employed in his stock, and so forth; and though,



<P>with diligence and good luck, he may be rich in time, it is next to



<P>impossible that he should have realised any thing yet."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"To be sure, so it is.&nbsp; But they live very comfortably.



<P>They have no indoors man, else they do not want for any thing;



<P>and Mrs. Martin talks of taking a boy another year."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I wish you may not get into a scrape, Harriet, whenever he does



<P>marry;--I mean, as to being acquainted with his wife--for though



<P>his sisters, from a superior education, are not to be altogether



<P>objected to, it does not follow that he might marry any body at all

fit



<P>for you to notice.&nbsp; The misfortune of your birth ought to make

you



<P>particularly careful as to your associates.&nbsp; There can be no doubt



<P>of your being a gentleman's daughter, and you must support your



<P>claim to that station by every thing within your own power, or there



<P>will be plenty of people who would take pleasure in degrading you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, to be sure, I suppose there are.&nbsp; But while I visit



<P>at Hartfield, and you are so kind to me, Miss Woodhouse,



<P>I am not afraid of what any body can do."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You understand the force of influence pretty well, Harriet; but I



<P>would have you so firmly established in good society, as to be



<P>independent even of Hartfield and Miss Woodhouse.&nbsp; I want to see

you



<P>permanently well connected, and to that end it will be advisable



<P>to have as few odd acquaintance as may be; and, therefore, I say



<P>that if you should still be in this country when Mr. Martin marries,



<P>I wish you may not be drawn in by your intimacy with the sisters,



<P>to be acquainted with the wife, who will probably be some mere



<P>farmer's daughter, without education."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"To be sure.&nbsp; Yes.&nbsp; Not that I think Mr. Martin would ever

marry any body



<P>but what had had some education--and been very well brought up.



<P>However, I do not mean to set up my opinion against your's--and I



<P>am sure I shall not wish for the acquaintance of his wife.&nbsp; I shall



<P>always have a great regard for the Miss Martins, especially Elizabeth,



<P>and should be very sorry to give them up, for they are quite as well



<P>educated as me.&nbsp; But if he marries a very ignorant, vulgar woman,



<P>certainly I had better not visit her, if I can help it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma watched her through the fluctuations of this speech,



<P>and saw no alarming symptoms of love.&nbsp; The young man had been



<P>the first admirer, but she trusted there was no other hold,



<P>and that there would be no serious difficulty, on Harriet's side,



<P>to oppose any friendly arrangement of her own.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They met Mr. Martin the very next day, as they were walking on the



<P>Donwell road.&nbsp; He was on foot, and after looking very respectfully



<P>at her, looked with most unfeigned satisfaction at her companion.



<P>Emma was not sorry to have such an opportunity of survey;



<P>and walking a few yards forward, while they talked together, soon made



<P>her quick eye sufficiently acquainted with Mr. Robert Martin.



<P>His appearance was very neat, and he looked like a sensible young man,



<P>but his person had no other advantage; and when he came to be



<P>contrasted with gentlemen, she thought he must lose all the ground



<P>he had gained in Harriet's inclination.&nbsp; Harriet was not insensible



<P>of manner; she had voluntarily noticed her father's gentleness



<P>with admiration as well as wonder.&nbsp; Mr. Martin looked as if he



<P>did not know what manner was.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They remained but a few minutes together, as Miss Woodhouse must



<P>not be kept waiting; and Harriet then came running to her with a



<P>smiling face, and in a flutter of spirits, which Miss Woodhouse



<P>hoped very soon to compose.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Only think of our happening to meet him!--How very odd! It was



<P>quite a chance, he said, that he had not gone round by Randalls.



<P>He did not think we ever walked this road.&nbsp; He thought we walked



<P>towards Randalls most days.&nbsp; He has not been able to get the



<P>Romance of the Forest yet.&nbsp; He was so busy the last time he was



<P>at Kingston that he quite forgot it, but he goes again to-morrow.



<P>So very odd we should happen to meet! Well, Miss Woodhouse, is he



<P>like what you expected? What do you think of him? Do you think him



<P>so very plain?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He is very plain, undoubtedly--remarkably plain:--but that is



<P>nothing compared with his entire want of gentility.&nbsp; I had no



<P>right to expect much, and I did not expect much; but I had no



<P>idea that he could be so very clownish, so totally without air.



<P>I had imagined him, I confess, a degree or two nearer gentility."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"To be sure," said Harriet, in a mortified voice, "he is not



<P>so genteel as real gentlemen."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I think, Harriet, since your acquaintance with us, you have been



<P>repeatedly in the company of some such very real gentlemen,



<P>that you must yourself be struck with the difference in Mr. Martin.



<P>At Hartfield, you have had very good specimens of well educated,



<P>well bred men.&nbsp; I should be surprized if, after seeing them,



<P>you could be in company with Mr. Martin again without perceiving



<P>him to be a very inferior creature--and rather wondering at



<P>yourself for having ever thought him at all agreeable before.



<P>Do not you begin to feel that now? Were not you struck? I am sure



<P>you must have been struck by his awkward look and abrupt manner,



<P>and the uncouthness of a voice which I heard to be wholly unmodulated



<P>as I stood here."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Certainly, he is not like Mr. Knightley.&nbsp; He has not such a fine



<P>air and way of walking as Mr. Knightley.&nbsp; I see the difference



<P>plain enough.&nbsp; But Mr. Knightley is so very fine a man!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mr. Knightley's air is so remarkably good that it is not fair



<P>to compare Mr. Martin with him.&nbsp; You might not see one in a hundred



<P>with gentleman so plainly written as in Mr. Knightley.&nbsp; But he

is



<P>not the only gentleman you have been lately used to.&nbsp; What say

you



<P>to Mr. Weston and Mr. Elton? Compare Mr. Martin with either of them.



<P>Compare their manner of carrying themselves; of walking; of speaking;



<P>of being silent.&nbsp; You must see the difference."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh yes!--there is a great difference.&nbsp; But Mr. Weston is almost



<P>an old man.&nbsp; Mr. Weston must be between forty and fifty."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Which makes his good manners the more valuable.&nbsp; The older a



<P>person grows, Harriet, the more important it is that their manners



<P>should not be bad; the more glaring and disgusting any loudness,



<P>or coarseness, or awkwardness becomes.&nbsp; What is passable in youth



<P>is detestable in later age.&nbsp; Mr. Martin is now awkward and abrupt;



<P>what will he be at Mr. Weston's time of life?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There is no saying, indeed," replied Harriet rather solemnly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But there may be pretty good guessing.&nbsp; He will be a completely

gross,



<P>vulgar farmer, totally inattentive to appearances, and thinking



<P>of nothing but profit and loss."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Will he, indeed? That will be very bad."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How much his business engrosses him already is very plain from the



<P>circumstance of his forgetting to inquire for the book you recommended.



<P>He was a great deal too full of the market to think of any thing



<P>else--which is just as it should be, for a thriving man.&nbsp; What

has



<P>he to do with books? And I have no doubt that he will thrive,



<P>and be a very rich man in time--and his being illiterate and coarse



<P>need not disturb us."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I wonder he did not remember the book"--was all Harriet's answer,



<P>and spoken with a degree of grave displeasure which Emma thought might



<P>be safely left to itself.&nbsp; She, therefore, said no more for some

time.



<P>Her next beginning was,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"In one respect, perhaps, Mr. Elton's manners are superior



<P>to Mr. Knightley's or Mr. Weston's. They have more gentleness.



<P>They might be more safely held up as a pattern.&nbsp; There is an openness,



<P>a quickness, almost a bluntness in Mr. Weston, which every body



<P>likes in him, because there is so much good-humour with it--but



<P>that would not do to be copied.&nbsp; Neither would Mr. Knightley's



<P>downright, decided, commanding sort of manner, though it suits



<P>him very well; his figure, and look, and situation in life seem



<P>to allow it; but if any young man were to set about copying him,



<P>he would not be sufferable.&nbsp; On the contrary, I think a young man



<P>might be very safely recommended to take Mr. Elton as a model.



<P>Mr. Elton is good-humoured, cheerful, obliging, and gentle.



<P>He seems to me to be grown particularly gentle of late.&nbsp; I do not



<P>know whether he has any design of ingratiating himself with either



<P>of us, Harriet, by additional softness, but it strikes me that his



<P>manners are softer than they used to be.&nbsp; If he means any thing,



<P>it must be to please you.&nbsp; Did not I tell you what he said of you



<P>the other day?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She then repeated some warm personal praise which she had drawn



<P>from Mr. Elton, and now did full justice to; and Harriet blushed



<P>and smiled, and said she had always thought Mr. Elton very agreeable.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Elton was the very person fixed on by Emma for driving



<P>the young farmer out of Harriet's head.&nbsp; She thought it would



<P>be an excellent match; and only too palpably desirable, natural,



<P>and probable, for her to have much merit in planning it.



<P>She feared it was what every body else must think of and predict.



<P>It was not likely, however, that any body should have equalled



<P>her in the date of the plan, as it had entered her brain during



<P>the very first evening of Harriet's coming to Hartfield.&nbsp; The longer



<P>she considered it, the greater was her sense of its expediency.



<P>Mr. Elton's situation was most suitable, quite the gentleman himself,



<P>and without low connexions; at the same time, not of any family



<P>that could fairly object to the doubtful birth of Harriet.&nbsp; He

had a



<P>comfortable home for her, and Emma imagined a very sufficient income;



<P>for though the vicarage of Highbury was not large, he was known



<P>to have some independent property; and she thought very highly



<P>of him as a good-humoured, well-meaning, respectable young man,



<P>without any deficiency of useful understanding or knowledge of the world.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She had already satisfied herself that he thought Harriet a beautiful



<P>girl, which she trusted, with such frequent meetings at Hartfield,



<P>was foundation enough on his side; and on Harriet's there could be



<P>little doubt that the idea of being preferred by him would have all



<P>the usual weight and efficacy.&nbsp; And he was really a very pleasing



<P>young man, a young man whom any woman not fastidious might like.



<P>He was reckoned very handsome; his person much admired in general,



<P>though not by her, there being a want of elegance of feature which



<P>she could not dispense with:--but the girl who could be gratified



<P>by a Robert Martin's riding about the country to get walnuts



<P>for her might very well be conquered by Mr. Elton's admiration.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
