   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 10</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER X</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Though now the middle of December, there had yet been no weather



<P>to prevent the young ladies from tolerably regular exercise;



<P>and on the morrow, Emma had a charitable visit to pay to a poor



<P>sick family, who lived a little way out of Highbury.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Their road to this detached cottage was down Vicarage Lane, a lane



<P>leading at right angles from the broad, though irregular, main street



<P>of the place; and, as may be inferred, containing the blessed abode



<P>of Mr. Elton.&nbsp; A few inferior dwellings were first to be passed,



<P>and then, about a quarter of a mile down the lane rose the Vicarage,



<P>an old and not very good house, almost as close to the road as it



<P>could be.&nbsp; It had no advantage of situation; but had been very

much



<P>smartened up by the present proprietor; and, such as it was,



<P>there could be no possibility of the two friends passing it without



<P>a slackened pace and observing eyes.--Emma's remark was--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There it is.&nbsp; There go you and your riddle-book one of these days."--



<P>Harriet's was--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, what a sweet house!--How very beautiful!--There are the yellow



<P>curtains that Miss Nash admires so much."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not often walk this way now," said Emma, as they proceeded,



<P>"but then there will be an inducement, and I shall gradually get



<P>intimately acquainted with all the hedges, gates, pools and pollards



<P>of this part of Highbury."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet, she found, had never in her life been within side the Vicarage,



<P>and her curiosity to see it was so extreme, that, considering exteriors



<P>and probabilities, Emma could only class it, as a proof of love,



<P>with Mr. Elton's seeing ready wit in her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I wish we could contrive it," said she; "but I cannot think



<P>of any tolerable pretence for going in;--no servant that I want



<P>to inquire about of his housekeeper--no message from my father."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She pondered, but could think of nothing.&nbsp; After a mutual silence



<P>of some minutes, Harriet thus began again--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do so wonder, Miss Woodhouse, that you should not be married,



<P>or going to be married! so charming as you are!"--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma laughed, and replied,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My being charming, Harriet, is not quite enough to induce me to marry;



<P>I must find other people charming--one other person at least.



<P>And I am not only, not going to be married, at present, but have



<P>very little intention of ever marrying at all."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah!--so you say; but I cannot believe it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I must see somebody very superior to any one I have seen yet,



<P>to be tempted; Mr. Elton, you know, (recollecting herself,)



<P>is out of the question:&nbsp; and I do not wish to see any such person.



<P>I would rather not be tempted.&nbsp; I cannot really change for the

better.



<P>If I were to marry, I must expect to repent it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Dear me!--it is so odd to hear a woman talk so!"--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have none of the usual inducements of women to marry.



<P>Were I to fall in love, indeed, it would be a different thing!



<P>but I never have been in love; it is not my way, or my nature;



<P>and I do not think I ever shall.&nbsp; And, without love, I am sure

I



<P>should be a fool to change such a situation as mine.&nbsp; Fortune I



<P>do not want; employment I do not want; consequence I do not want:



<P>I believe few married women are half as much mistress of their



<P>husband's house as I am of Hartfield; and never, never could I expect



<P>to be so truly beloved and important; so always first and always



<P>right in any man's eyes as I am in my father's."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But then, to be an old maid at last, like Miss Bates!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That is as formidable an image as you could present, Harriet; and if

I



<P>thought I should ever be like Miss Bates! so silly--so satisfied--



<P>so smiling--so prosing--so undistinguishing and unfastidious--



<P>and so apt to tell every thing relative to every body about me,



<P>I would marry to-morrow. But between us, I am convinced there never



<P>can be any likeness, except in being unmarried."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But still, you will be an old maid! and that's so dreadful!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Never mind, Harriet, I shall not be a poor old maid; and it is



<P>poverty only which makes celibacy contemptible to a generous public!



<P>A single woman, with a very narrow income, must be a ridiculous,



<P>disagreeable old maid! the proper sport of boys and girls,



<P>but a single woman, of good fortune, is always respectable,



<P>and may be as sensible and pleasant as any body else.&nbsp; And the



<P>distinction is not quite so much against the candour and common



<P>sense of the world as appears at first; for a very narrow income



<P>has a tendency to contract the mind, and sour the temper.



<P>Those who can barely live, and who live perforce in a very small,



<P>and generally very inferior, society, may well be illiberal and cross.



<P>This does not apply, however, to Miss Bates; she is only too good



<P>natured and too silly to suit me; but, in general, she is very



<P>much to the taste of every body, though single and though poor.



<P>Poverty certainly has not contracted her mind:&nbsp; I really believe,



<P>if she had only a shilling in the world, she would be very likely



<P>to give away sixpence of it; and nobody is afraid of her:&nbsp; that

is a



<P>great charm."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Dear me! but what shall you do? how shall you employ yourself



<P>when you grow old?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If I know myself, Harriet, mine is an active, busy mind, with a great



<P>many independent resources; and I do not perceive why I should be



<P>more in want of employment at forty or fifty than one-and-twenty.



<P>Woman's usual occupations of hand and mind will be as open to me then



<P>as they are now; or with no important variation.&nbsp; If I draw less,



<P>I shall read more; if I give up music, I shall take to carpet-work.



<P>And as for objects of interest, objects for the affections,



<P>which is in truth the great point of inferiority, the want of which



<P>is really the great evil to be avoided in not marrying, I shall



<P>be very well off, with all the children of a sister I love so much,



<P>to care about.&nbsp; There will be enough of them, in all probability,



<P>to supply every sort of sensation that declining life can need.



<P>There will be enough for every hope and every fear; and though my



<P>attachment to none can equal that of a parent, it suits my ideas



<P>of comfort better than what is warmer and blinder.&nbsp; My nephews



<P>and nieces!--I shall often have a niece with me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do you know Miss Bates's niece?&nbsp; That is, I know you must have



<P>seen her a hundred times--but are you acquainted?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! yes; we are always forced to be acquainted whenever she comes



<P>to Highbury.&nbsp; By the bye, that is almost enough to put one out



<P>of conceit with a niece.&nbsp; Heaven forbid! at least, that I should



<P>ever bore people half so much about all the Knightleys together,



<P>as she does about Jane Fairfax.&nbsp; One is sick of the very name



<P>of Jane Fairfax.&nbsp; Every letter from her is read forty times over;



<P>her compliments to all friends go round and round again; and if she



<P>does but send her aunt the pattern of a stomacher, or knit a pair



<P>of garters for her grandmother, one hears of nothing else for a month.



<P>I wish Jane Fairfax very well; but she tires me to death."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They were now approaching the cottage, and all idle topics



<P>were superseded.&nbsp; Emma was very compassionate; and the distresses



<P>of the poor were as sure of relief from her personal attention



<P>and kindness, her counsel and her patience, as from her purse.



<P>She understood their ways, could allow for their ignorance and



<P>their temptations, had no romantic expectations of extraordinary



<P>virtue from those for whom education had done so little; entered into



<P>their troubles with ready sympathy, and always gave her assistance



<P>with as much intelligence as good-will.&nbsp; In the present instance,



<P>it was sickness and poverty together which she came to visit;



<P>and after remaining there as long as she could give comfort or advice,



<P>she quitted the cottage with such an impression of the scene



<P>as made her say to Harriet, as they walked away,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"These are the sights, Harriet, to do one good.&nbsp; How trifling they



<P>make every thing else appear!--I feel now as if I could think of



<P>nothing but these poor creatures all the rest of the day; and yet,



<P>who can say how soon it may all vanish from my mind?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very true," said Harriet.&nbsp; "Poor creatures! one can think



<P>of nothing else."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And really, I do not think the impression will soon be over,"



<P>said Emma, as she crossed the low hedge, and tottering footstep



<P>which ended the narrow, slippery path through the cottage garden,



<P>and brought them into the lane again.&nbsp; "I do not think it will,"



<P>stopping to look once more at all the outward wretchedness of the place,



<P>and recall the still greater within.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! dear, no," said her companion.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They walked on.&nbsp; The lane made a slight bend; and when that bend



<P>was passed, Mr. Elton was immediately in sight; and so near



<P>as to give Emma time only to say farther,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah!&nbsp; Harriet, here comes a very sudden trial of our stability



<P>in good thoughts.&nbsp; Well, (smiling,) I hope it may be allowed that



<P>if compassion has produced exertion and relief to the sufferers,



<P>it has done all that is truly important.&nbsp; If we feel for the wretched,



<P>enough to do all we can for them, the rest is empty sympathy,



<P>only distressing to ourselves."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet could just answer, "Oh! dear, yes," before the gentleman



<P>joined them.&nbsp; The wants and sufferings of the poor family, however,



<P>were the first subject on meeting.&nbsp; He had been going to call



<P>on them.&nbsp; His visit he would now defer; but they had a very



<P>interesting parley about what could be done and should be done.



<P>Mr. Elton then turned back to accompany them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"To fall in with each other on such an errand as this," thought Emma;



<P>"to meet in a charitable scheme; this will bring a great increase



<P>of love on each side.&nbsp; I should not wonder if it were to bring



<P>on the declaration.&nbsp; It must, if I were not here.&nbsp; I wish

I were



<P>anywhere else."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Anxious to separate herself from them as far as she could, she soon



<P>afterwards took possession of a narrow footpath, a little raised



<P>on one side of the lane, leaving them together in the main road.



<P>But she had not been there two minutes when she found that Harriet's



<P>habits of dependence and imitation were bringing her up too, and that,



<P>in short, they would both be soon after her.&nbsp; This would not do;



<P>she immediately stopped, under pretence of having some alteration



<P>to make in the lacing of her half-boot, and stooping down in complete



<P>occupation of the footpath, begged them to have the goodness to walk

on,



<P>and she would follow in half a minute.&nbsp; They did as they were desired;



<P>and by the time she judged it reasonable to have done with her boot,



<P>she had the comfort of farther delay in her power, being overtaken



<P>by a child from the cottage, setting out, according to orders,



<P>with her pitcher, to fetch broth from Hartfield.&nbsp; To walk by the

side



<P>of this child, and talk to and question her, was the most natural



<P>thing in the world, or would have been the most natural, had she been



<P>acting just then without design; and by this means the others were



<P>still able to keep ahead, without any obligation of waiting for her.



<P>She gained on them, however, involuntarily:&nbsp; the child's pace was

quick,



<P>and theirs rather slow; and she was the more concerned at it,



<P>from their being evidently in a conversation which interested them.



<P>Mr. Elton was speaking with animation, Harriet listening with a very



<P>pleased attention; and Emma, having sent the child on, was beginning



<P>to think how she might draw back a little more, when they both



<P>looked around, and she was obliged to join them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Elton was still talking, still engaged in some interesting detail;



<P>and Emma experienced some disappointment when she found that he



<P>was only giving his fair companion an account of the yesterday's



<P>party at his friend Cole's, and that she was come in herself for



<P>the Stilton cheese, the north Wiltshire, the butter, the cellery,



<P>the beet-root, and all the dessert.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"This would soon have led to something better, of course," was her



<P>consoling reflection; "any thing interests between those who love;



<P>and any thing will serve as introduction to what is near the heart.



<P>If I could but have kept longer away!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They now walked on together quietly, till within view of the vicarage



<P>pales, when a sudden resolution, of at least getting Harriet into



<P>the house, made her again find something very much amiss about her boot,



<P>and fall behind to arrange it once more.&nbsp; She then broke the lace



<P>off short, and dexterously throwing it into a ditch, was presently



<P>obliged to entreat them to stop, and acknowledged her inability to



<P>put herself to rights so as to be able to walk home in tolerable comfort.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Part of my lace is gone," said she, "and I do not know how I am



<P>to contrive.&nbsp; I really am a most troublesome companion to you both,



<P>but I hope I am not often so ill-equipped. Mr. Elton, I must beg



<P>leave to stop at your house, and ask your housekeeper for a bit



<P>of ribband or string, or any thing just to keep my boot on."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Elton looked all happiness at this proposition; and nothing



<P>could exceed his alertness and attention in conducting them into



<P>his house and endeavouring to make every thing appear to advantage.



<P>The room they were taken into was the one he chiefly occupied,



<P>and looking forwards; behind it was another with which it immediately



<P>communicated; the door between them was open, and Emma passed



<P>into it with the housekeeper to receive her assistance in the most



<P>comfortable manner.&nbsp; She was obliged to leave the door ajar as

she



<P>found it; but she fully intended that Mr. Elton should close it.



<P>It was not closed, however, it still remained ajar; but by engaging



<P>the housekeeper in incessant conversation, she hoped to make it



<P>practicable for him to chuse his own subject in the adjoining room.



<P>For ten minutes she could hear nothing but herself.&nbsp; It could



<P>be protracted no longer.&nbsp; She was then obliged to be finished,



<P>and make her appearance.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The lovers were standing together at one of the windows.&nbsp; It had

a



<P>most favourable aspect; and, for half a minute, Emma felt the glory



<P>of having schemed successfully.&nbsp; But it would not do; he had not



<P>come to the point.&nbsp; He had been most agreeable, most delightful;



<P>he had told Harriet that he had seen them go by, and had purposely



<P>followed them; other little gallantries and allusions had been dropt,



<P>but nothing serious.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Cautious, very cautious," thought Emma; "he advances inch by inch,



<P>and will hazard nothing till he believes himself secure."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Still, however, though every thing had not been accomplished



<P>by her ingenious device, she could not but flatter herself



<P>that it had been the occasion of much present enjoyment to both,



<P>and must be leading them forward to the great event.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 11</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XI</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Mr. Elton must now be left to himself.&nbsp; It was no longer in Emma's



<P>power to superintend his happiness or quicken his measures.



<P>The coming of her sister's family was so very near at hand,



<P>that first in anticipation, and then in reality, it became henceforth



<P>her prime object of interest; and during the ten days of their stay



<P>at Hartfield it was not to be expected--she did not herself expect--



<P>that any thing beyond occasional, fortuitous assistance could



<P>be afforded by her to the lovers.&nbsp; They might advance rapidly



<P>if they would, however; they must advance somehow or other whether



<P>they would or no.&nbsp; She hardly wished to have more leisure for them.



<P>There are people, who the more you do for them, the less they will



<P>do for themselves.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. and Mrs. John Knightley, from having been longer than usual



<P>absent from Surry, were exciting of course rather more than the



<P>usual interest.&nbsp; Till this year, every long vacation since their



<P>marriage had been divided between Hartfield and Donwell Abbey;



<P>but all the holidays of this autumn had been given to sea-bathing



<P>for the children, and it was therefore many months since they had



<P>been seen in a regular way by their Surry connexions, or seen at all



<P>by Mr. Woodhouse, who could not be induced to get so far as London,



<P>even for poor Isabella's sake; and who consequently was now most



<P>nervously and apprehensively happy in forestalling this too short visit.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He thought much of the evils of the journey for her, and not a



<P>little of the fatigues of his own horses and coachman who were to



<P>bring some of the party the last half of the way; but his alarms



<P>were needless; the sixteen miles being happily accomplished,



<P>and Mr. and Mrs. John Knightley, their five children, and a competent



<P>number of nursery-maids, all reaching Hartfield in safety.



<P>The bustle and joy of such an arrival, the many to be talked to,



<P>welcomed, encouraged, and variously dispersed and disposed of,



<P>produced a noise and confusion which his nerves could not have borne



<P>under any other cause, nor have endured much longer even for this;



<P>but the ways of Hartfield and the feelings of her father were



<P>so respected by Mrs. John Knightley, that in spite of maternal



<P>solicitude for the immediate enjoyment of her little ones,



<P>and for their having instantly all the liberty and attendance,



<P>all the eating and drinking, and sleeping and playing,



<P>which they could possibly wish for, without the smallest delay,



<P>the children were never allowed to be long a disturbance to him,



<P>either in themselves or in any restless attendance on them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. John Knightley was a pretty, elegant little woman, of gentle,



<P>quiet manners, and a disposition remarkably amiable and affectionate;



<P>wrapt up in her family; a devoted wife, a doating mother,



<P>and so tenderly attached to her father and sister that, but for



<P>these higher ties, a warmer love might have seemed impossible.



<P>She could never see a fault in any of them.&nbsp; She was not a woman



<P>of strong understanding or any quickness; and with this resemblance



<P>of her father, she inherited also much of his constitution;



<P>was delicate in her own health, over-careful of that of her children,



<P>had many fears and many nerves, and was as fond of her own Mr. Wingfield



<P>in town as her father could be of Mr. Perry.&nbsp; They were alike too,



<P>in a general benevolence of temper, and a strong habit of regard



<P>for every old acquaintance.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. John Knightley was a tall, gentleman-like, and very clever man;



<P>rising in his profession, domestic, and respectable in his



<P>private character; but with reserved manners which prevented his being



<P>generally pleasing; and capable of being sometimes out of humour.



<P>He was not an ill-tempered man, not so often unreasonably cross



<P>as to deserve such a reproach; but his temper was not his



<P>great perfection; and, indeed, with such a worshipping wife,



<P>it was hardly possible that any natural defects in it should not



<P>be increased.&nbsp; The extreme sweetness of her temper must hurt his.



<P>He had all the clearness and quickness of mind which she wanted,



<P>and he could sometimes act an ungracious, or say a severe thing.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He was not a great favourite with his fair sister-in-law. Nothing



<P>wrong in him escaped her.&nbsp; She was quick in feeling the little



<P>injuries to Isabella, which Isabella never felt herself.



<P>Perhaps she might have passed over more had his manners been



<P>flattering to Isabella's sister, but they were only those of a calmly



<P>kind brother and friend, without praise and without blindness;



<P>but hardly any degree of personal compliment could have made her



<P>regardless of that greatest fault of all in her eyes which he sometimes



<P>fell into, the want of respectful forbearance towards her father.



<P>There he had not always the patience that could have been wished.



<P>Mr. Woodhouse's peculiarities and fidgetiness were sometimes provoking



<P>him to a rational remonstrance or sharp retort equally ill-bestowed.



<P>It did not often happen; for Mr. John Knightley had really a great



<P>regard for his father-in-law, and generally a strong sense of what was



<P>due to him; but it was too often for Emma's charity, especially as



<P>there was all the pain of apprehension frequently to be endured,



<P>though the offence came not.&nbsp; The beginning, however, of every

visit



<P>displayed none but the properest feelings, and this being of necessity



<P>so short might be hoped to pass away in unsullied cordiality.



<P>They had not been long seated and composed when Mr. Woodhouse,



<P>with a melancholy shake of the head and a sigh, called his daughter's



<P>attention to the sad change at Hartfield since she had been there last.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah, my dear," said he, "poor Miss Taylor--It is a grievous business."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh yes, sir," cried she with ready sympathy, "how you must



<P>miss her!&nbsp; And dear Emma, too!--What a dreadful loss to you both!--



<P>I have been so grieved for you.--I could not imagine how you could



<P>possibly do without her.--It is a sad change indeed.--But I hope



<P>she is pretty well, sir."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Pretty well, my dear--I hope--pretty well.--I do not know



<P>but that the place agrees with her tolerably."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. John Knightley here asked Emma quietly whether there were any



<P>doubts of the air of Randalls.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! no--none in the least.&nbsp; I never saw Mrs. Weston better in

my life--



<P>never looking so well.&nbsp; Papa is only speaking his own regret."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very much to the honour of both," was the handsome reply.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And do you see her, sir, tolerably often?" asked Isabella



<P>in the plaintive tone which just suited her father.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Woodhouse hesitated.--"Not near so often, my dear, as I could wish."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! papa, we have missed seeing them but one entire day since



<P>they married.&nbsp; Either in the morning or evening of every day,



<P>excepting one, have we seen either Mr. Weston or Mrs. Weston,



<P>and generally both, either at Randalls or here--and as you



<P>may suppose, Isabella, most frequently here.&nbsp; They are very,



<P>very kind in their visits.&nbsp; Mr. Weston is really as kind as herself.



<P>Papa, if you speak in that melancholy way, you will be giving



<P>Isabella a false idea of us all.&nbsp; Every body must be aware that

Miss



<P>Taylor must be missed, but every body ought also to be assured



<P>that Mr. and Mrs. Weston do really prevent our missing her by any



<P>means to the extent we ourselves anticipated--which is the exact truth."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Just as it should be," said Mr. John Knightley, "and just as I hoped



<P>it was from your letters.&nbsp; Her wish of shewing you attention could



<P>not be doubted, and his being a disengaged and social man makes it



<P>all easy.&nbsp; I have been always telling you, my love, that I had

no idea



<P>of the change being so very material to Hartfield as you apprehended;



<P>and now you have Emma's account, I hope you will be satisfied."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why, to be sure," said Mr. Woodhouse--"yes, certainly--I cannot deny



<P>that Mrs. Weston, poor Mrs. Weston, does come and see us pretty often--



<P>but then--she is always obliged to go away again."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It would be very hard upon Mr. Weston if she did not, papa.--



<P>You quite forget poor Mr. Weston."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I think, indeed," said John Knightley pleasantly, "that Mr. Weston



<P>has some little claim.&nbsp; You and I, Emma, will venture to take the

part



<P>of the poor husband.&nbsp; I, being a husband, and you not being a wife,



<P>the claims of the man may very likely strike us with equal force.



<P>As for Isabella, she has been married long enough to see the convenience



<P>of putting all the Mr. Westons aside as much as she can."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Me, my love," cried his wife, hearing and understanding only in part.--



<P>"Are you talking about me?--I am sure nobody ought to be, or can be,



<P>a greater advocate for matrimony than I am; and if it had not been



<P>for the misery of her leaving Hartfield, I should never have thought



<P>of Miss Taylor but as the most fortunate woman in the world;



<P>and as to slighting Mr. Weston, that excellent Mr. Weston, I think



<P>there is nothing he does not deserve.&nbsp; I believe he is one of the



<P>very best-tempered men that ever existed.&nbsp; Excepting yourself



<P>and your brother, I do not know his equal for temper.&nbsp; I shall



<P>never forget his flying Henry's kite for him that very windy day



<P>last Easter--and ever since his particular kindness last September



<P>twelvemonth in writing that note, at twelve o'clock at night,



<P>on purpose to assure me that there was no scarlet fever at Cobham,



<P>I have been convinced there could not be a more feeling heart nor



<P>a better man in existence.--If any body can deserve him, it must be



<P>Miss Taylor."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Where is the young man?" said John Knightley.&nbsp; "Has he been here



<P>on this occasion--or has he not?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He has not been here yet," replied Emma.&nbsp; "There was a strong



<P>expectation of his coming soon after the marriage, but it ended



<P>in nothing; and I have not heard him mentioned lately."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But you should tell them of the letter, my dear," said her father.



<P>"He wrote a letter to poor Mrs. Weston, to congratulate her,



<P>and a very proper, handsome letter it was.&nbsp; She shewed it to me.



<P>I thought it very well done of him indeed.&nbsp; Whether it was his

own idea



<P>you know, one cannot tell.&nbsp; He is but young, and his uncle, perhaps--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear papa, he is three-and-twenty. You forget how time passes."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Three-and-twenty!--is he indeed?--Well, I could not have thought it--



<P>and he was but two years old when he lost his poor mother!&nbsp; Well,



<P>time does fly indeed!--and my memory is very bad.&nbsp; However, it

was



<P>an exceeding good, pretty letter, and gave Mr. and Mrs. Weston



<P>a great deal of pleasure.&nbsp; I remember it was written from Weymouth,



<P>and dated Sept. 28th--and began, `My dear Madam,' but I forget



<P>how it went on; and it was signed `F. C. Weston Churchill.'--



<P>I remember that perfectly."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How very pleasing and proper of him!" cried the good-hearted Mrs. John



<P>Knightley.&nbsp; "I have no doubt of his being a most amiable young

man.



<P>But how sad it is that he should not live at home with his father!



<P>There is something so shocking in a child's being taken away from his



<P>parents and natural home!&nbsp; I never could comprehend how Mr. Weston



<P>could part with him.&nbsp; To give up one's child!&nbsp; I really never



<P>could think well of any body who proposed such a thing to any body else."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nobody ever did think well of the Churchills, I fancy,"



<P>observed Mr. John Knightley coolly.&nbsp; "But you need not imagine



<P>Mr. Weston to have felt what you would feel in giving up Henry



<P>or John.&nbsp; Mr. Weston is rather an easy, cheerful-tempered man,



<P>than a man of strong feelings; he takes things as he finds them,



<P>and makes enjoyment of them somehow or other, depending, I suspect,



<P>much more upon what is called society for his comforts, that is,



<P>upon the power of eating and drinking, and playing whist with his



<P>neighbours five times a week, than upon family affection, or any



<P>thing that home affords."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma could not like what bordered on a reflection on Mr. Weston,



<P>and had half a mind to take it up; but she struggled, and let



<P>it pass.&nbsp; She would keep the peace if possible; and there was



<P>something honourable and valuable in the strong domestic habits,



<P>the all-sufficiency of home to himself, whence resulted her brother's



<P>disposition to look down on the common rate of social intercourse,



<P>and those to whom it was important.--It had a high claim to forbearance.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
