   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 05</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER V</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>"I do not know what your opinion may be, Mrs. Weston," said Mr. Knightley,

"of



<P>this great intimacy between Emma and Harriet Smith, but I think it a

bad thing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A bad thing! Do you really think it a bad thing?-- why so?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I think they will neither of them do the other any good."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You surprize me! Emma must do Harriet good: and by supplying her



<P>with a new object of interest, Harriet may be said to do Emma good.



<P>I have been seeing their intimacy with the greatest pleasure.



<P>How very differently we feel!--Not think they will do each other any



<P>good! This will certainly be the beginning of one of our quarrels



<P>about Emma, Mr. Knightley."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Perhaps you think I am come on purpose to quarrel with you,



<P>knowing Weston to be out, and that you must still fight your own battle."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mr. Weston would undoubtedly support me, if he were here,



<P>for he thinks exactly as I do on the subject.&nbsp; We were speaking



<P>of it only yesterday, and agreeing how fortunate it was for Emma,



<P>that there should be such a girl in Highbury for her to associate with.



<P>Mr. Knightley, I shall not allow you to be a fair judge in this case.



<P>You are so much used to live alone, that you do not know the value



<P>of a companion; and, perhaps no man can be a good judge of the comfort



<P>a woman feels in the society of one of her own sex, after being used



<P>to it all her life.&nbsp; I can imagine your objection to Harriet Smith.



<P>She is not the superior young woman which Emma's friend ought to be.



<P>But on the other hand, as Emma wants to see her better informed,



<P>it will be an inducement to her to read more herself.&nbsp; They will



<P>read together.&nbsp; She means it, I know."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Emma has been meaning to read more ever since she was twelve



<P>years old.&nbsp; I have seen a great many lists of her drawing-up at



<P>various times of books that she meant to read regularly through--and



<P>very good lists they were--very well chosen, and very neatly



<P>arranged--sometimes alphabetically, and sometimes by some other rule.



<P>The list she drew up when only fourteen--I remember thinking it



<P>did her judgment so much credit, that I preserved it some time;



<P>and I dare say she may have made out a very good list now.&nbsp; But

I



<P>have done with expecting any course of steady reading from Emma.



<P>She will never submit to any thing requiring industry and patience,



<P>and a subjection of the fancy to the understanding.&nbsp; Where Miss

Taylor



<P>failed to stimulate, I may safely affirm that Harriet Smith will do



<P>nothing.-- You never could persuade her to read half so much as you



<P>wished.--You know you could not."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I dare say," replied Mrs. Weston, smiling, "that I thought



<P>so then;--but since we have parted, I can never remember Emma's



<P>omitting to do any thing I wished."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There is hardly any desiring to refresh such a memory as that,"--said



<P>Mr. Knightley, feelingly; and for a moment or two he had done.&nbsp;

"But I,"



<P>he soon added, "who have had no such charm thrown over my senses,



<P>must still see, hear, and remember.&nbsp; Emma is spoiled by being the



<P>cleverest of her family.&nbsp; At ten years old, she had the misfortune

of



<P>being able to answer questions which puzzled her sister at seventeen.



<P>She was always quick and assured: Isabella slow and diffident.



<P>And ever since she was twelve, Emma has been mistress of the house



<P>and of you all.&nbsp; In her mother she lost the only person able to

cope



<P>with her.&nbsp; She inherits her mother's talents, and must have been



<P>under subjection to her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I should have been sorry, Mr. Knightley, to be dependent on



<P>your recommendation, had I quitted Mr. Woodhouse's family and wanted



<P>another situation; I do not think you would have spoken a good word

for



<P>me to any body.&nbsp; I am sure you always thought me unfit for the

office I held."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes," said he, smiling.&nbsp; "You are better placed here; very fit



<P>for a wife, but not at all for a governess.&nbsp; But you were preparing



<P>yourself to be an excellent wife all the time you were at Hartfield.



<P>You might not give Emma such a complete education as your powers would



<P>seem to promise; but you were receiving a very good education from her,



<P>on the very material matrimonial point of submitting your own will,



<P>and doing as you were bid; and if Weston had asked me to recommend



<P>him a wife, I should certainly have named Miss Taylor."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thank you.&nbsp; There will be very little merit in making a good wife



<P>to such a man as Mr. Weston."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why, to own the truth, I am afraid you are rather thrown away,



<P>and that with every disposition to bear, there will be nothing



<P>to be borne.&nbsp; We will not despair, however.&nbsp; Weston may grow

cross



<P>from the wantonness of comfort, or his son may plague him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I hope not that.--It is not likely.&nbsp; No, Mr. Knightley, do not



<P>foretell vexation from that quarter."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not I, indeed.&nbsp; I only name possibilities.&nbsp; I do not pretend

to Emma's



<P>genius for foretelling and guessing.&nbsp; I hope, with all my heart,



<P>the young man may be a Weston in merit, and a Churchill in fortune.--But



<P>Harriet Smith--I have not half done about Harriet Smith.&nbsp; I think



<P>her the very worst sort of companion that Emma could possibly have.



<P>She knows nothing herself, and looks upon Emma as knowing every thing.



<P>She is a flatterer in all her ways; and so much the worse,



<P>because undesigned.&nbsp; Her ignorance is hourly flattery.&nbsp; How

can



<P>Emma imagine she has any thing to learn herself, while Harriet



<P>is presenting such a delightful inferiority? And as for Harriet,



<P>I will venture to say that she cannot gain by the acquaintance.



<P>Hartfield will only put her out of conceit with all the other places



<P>she belongs to.&nbsp; She will grow just refined enough to be uncomfortable



<P>with those among whom birth and circumstances have placed her home.



<P>I am much mistaken if Emma's doctrines give any strength of mind,



<P>or tend at all to make a girl adapt herself rationally to the varieties



<P>of her situation in life.--They only give a little polish."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I either depend more upon Emma's good sense than you do, or am more



<P>anxious for her present comfort; for I cannot lament the acquaintance.



<P>How well she looked last night!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! you would rather talk of her person than her mind, would you?



<P>Very well; I shall not attempt to deny Emma's being pretty."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Pretty! say beautiful rather.&nbsp; Can you imagine any thing nearer



<P>perfect beauty than Emma altogether-- face and figure?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not know what I could imagine, but I confess that I have



<P>seldom seen a face or figure more pleasing to me than hers.



<P>But I am a partial old friend."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Such an eye!--the true hazle eye--and so brilliant! regular features,



<P>open countenance, with a complexion! oh! what a bloom of full health,



<P>and such a pretty height and size; such a firm and upright figure!



<P>There is health, not merely in her bloom, but in her air, her head,



<P>her glance.&nbsp; One hears sometimes of a child being `the picture



<P>of health;' now, Emma always gives me the idea of being the complete



<P>picture of grown-up health.&nbsp; She is loveliness itself.&nbsp; Mr.

Knightley,



<P>is not she?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have not a fault to find with her person," he replied.



<P>"I think her all you describe.&nbsp; I love to look at her; and I



<P>will add this praise, that I do not think her personally vain.



<P>Considering how very handsome she is, she appears to be little



<P>occupied with it; her vanity lies another way.&nbsp; Mrs. Weston, I

am



<P>not to be talked out of my dislike of Harriet Smith, or my dread



<P>of its doing them both harm."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And I, Mr. Knightley, am equally stout in my confidence of its



<P>not doing them any harm.&nbsp; With all dear Emma's little faults,



<P>she is an excellent creature.&nbsp; Where shall we see a better daughter,



<P>or a kinder sister, or a truer friend? No, no; she has qualities



<P>which may be trusted; she will never lead any one really wrong;



<P>she will make no lasting blunder; where Emma errs once, she is in the



<P>right a hundred times."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very well; I will not plague you any more.&nbsp; Emma shall be an angel,



<P>and I will keep my spleen to myself till Christmas brings John



<P>and Isabella.&nbsp; John loves Emma with a reasonable and therefore



<P>not a blind affection, and Isabella always thinks as he does;



<P>except when he is not quite frightened enough about the children.



<P>I am sure of having their opinions with me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I know that you all love her really too well to be unjust or unkind;



<P>but excuse me, Mr. Knightley, if I take the liberty (I consider myself,



<P>you know, as having somewhat of the privilege of speech that Emma's



<P>mother might have had) the liberty of hinting that I do not think



<P>any possible good can arise from Harriet Smith's intimacy being made



<P>a matter of much discussion among you.&nbsp; Pray excuse me; but supposing



<P>any little inconvenience may be apprehended from the intimacy,



<P>it cannot be expected that Emma, accountable to nobody but her father,



<P>who perfectly approves the acquaintance, should put an end to it,



<P>so long as it is a source of pleasure to herself.&nbsp; It has been

so



<P>many years my province to give advice, that you cannot be surprized,



<P>Mr. Knightley, at this little remains of office."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not at all," cried he; "I am much obliged to you for it.



<P>It is very good advice, and it shall have a better fate than your



<P>advice has often found; for it shall be attended to."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mrs. John Knightley is easily alarmed, and might be made unhappy



<P>about her sister."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Be satisfied," said he, "I will not raise any outcry.&nbsp; I will

keep



<P>my ill-humour to myself.&nbsp; I have a very sincere interest in Emma.



<P>Isabella does not seem more my sister; has never excited a



<P>greater interest; perhaps hardly so great.&nbsp; There is an anxiety,



<P>a curiosity in what one feels for Emma.&nbsp; I wonder what will become



<P>of her!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So do I," said Mrs. Weston gently, "very much."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She always declares she will never marry, which, of course,



<P>means just nothing at all.&nbsp; But I have no idea that she has yet



<P>ever seen a man she cared for.&nbsp; It would not be a bad thing for

her



<P>to be very much in love with a proper object.&nbsp; I should like to

see



<P>Emma in love, and in some doubt of a return; it would do her good.



<P>But there is nobody hereabouts to attach her; and she goes so seldom



<P>from home."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There does, indeed, seem as little to tempt her to break



<P>her resolution at present," said Mrs. Weston, "as can well be;



<P>and while she is so happy at Hartfield, I cannot wish her to be



<P>forming any attachment which would be creating such difficulties



<P>on poor Mr. Woodhouse's account.&nbsp; I do not recommend matrimony



<P>at present to Emma, though I mean no slight to the state, I assure you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Part of her meaning was to conceal some favourite thoughts of



<P>her own and Mr. Weston's on the subject, as much as possible.



<P>There were wishes at Randalls respecting Emma's destiny, but it



<P>was not desirable to have them suspected; and the quiet transition



<P>which Mr. Knightley soon afterwards made to "What does Weston



<P>think of the weather; shall we have rain?" convinced her that he



<P>had nothing more to say or surmise about Hartfield.

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 13</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XIII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>There could hardly be a happier creature in the world than Mrs. John



<P>Knightley, in this short visit to Hartfield, going about every morning



<P>among her old acquaintance with her five children, and talking



<P>over what she had done every evening with her father and sister.



<P>She had nothing to wish otherwise, but that the days did not pass



<P>so swiftly.&nbsp; It was a delightful visit;--perfect, in being much

too short.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In general their evenings were less engaged with friends than



<P>their mornings; but one complete dinner engagement, and out



<P>of the house too, there was no avoiding, though at Christmas.



<P>Mr. Weston would take no denial; they must all dine at Randalls



<P>one day;--even Mr. Woodhouse was persuaded to think it a possible



<P>thing in preference to a division of the party.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>How they were all to be conveyed, he would have made a difficulty



<P>if he could, but as his son and daughter's carriage and horses



<P>were actually at Hartfield, he was not able to make more than



<P>a simple question on that head; it hardly amounted to a doubt;



<P>nor did it occupy Emma long to convince him that they might in one



<P>of the carriages find room for Harriet also.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet, Mr. Elton, and Mr. Knightley, their own especial set,



<P>were the only persons invited to meet them;--the hours were to be early,



<P>as well as the numbers few; Mr. Woodhouse's habits and inclination



<P>being consulted in every thing.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The evening before this great event (for it was a very great event



<P>that Mr. Woodhouse should dine out, on the 24th of December) had been



<P>spent by Harriet at Hartfield, and she had gone home so much indisposed



<P>with a cold, that, but for her own earnest wish of being nursed



<P>by Mrs. Goddard, Emma could not have allowed her to leave the house.



<P>Emma called on her the next day, and found her doom already signed



<P>with regard to Randalls.&nbsp; She was very feverish and had a bad



<P>sore throat:&nbsp; Mrs. Goddard was full of care and affection, Mr.

Perry



<P>was talked of, and Harriet herself was too ill and low to resist



<P>the authority which excluded her from this delightful engagement,



<P>though she could not speak of her loss without many tears.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma sat with her as long as she could, to attend her in Mrs. Goddard's



<P>unavoidable absences, and raise her spirits by representing how much



<P>Mr. Elton's would be depressed when he knew her state; and left her



<P>at last tolerably comfortable, in the sweet dependence of his having



<P>a most comfortless visit, and of their all missing her very much.



<P>She had not advanced many yards from Mrs. Goddard's door, when she



<P>was met by Mr. Elton himself, evidently coming towards it, and as



<P>they walked on slowly together in conversation about the invalid--



<P>of whom he, on the rumour of considerable illness, had been going



<P>to inquire, that he might carry some report of her to Hartfield--



<P>they were overtaken by Mr. John Knightley returning from the



<P>daily visit to Donwell, with his two eldest boys, whose healthy,



<P>glowing faces shewed all the benefit of a country run, and seemed



<P>to ensure a quick despatch of the roast mutton and rice pudding they



<P>were hastening home for.&nbsp; They joined company and proceeded together.



<P>Emma was just describing the nature of her friend's complaint;--



<P>"a throat very much inflamed, with a great deal of heat about her,



<P>a quick, low pulse, &amp;c.&nbsp; and she was sorry to find from Mrs.

Goddard



<P>that Harriet was liable to very bad sore-throats, and had often



<P>alarmed her with them."&nbsp; Mr. Elton looked all alarm on the occasion,



<P>as he exclaimed,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A sore-throat!--I hope not infectious.&nbsp; I hope not of a putrid



<P>infectious sort.&nbsp; Has Perry seen her?&nbsp; Indeed you should take

care



<P>of yourself as well as of your friend.&nbsp; Let me entreat you to run



<P>no risks.&nbsp; Why does not Perry see her?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma, who was not really at all frightened herself, tranquillised this



<P>excess of apprehension by assurances of Mrs. Goddard's experience



<P>and care; but as there must still remain a degree of uneasiness



<P>which she could not wish to reason away, which she would rather



<P>feed and assist than not, she added soon afterwards--as if quite



<P>another subject,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is so cold, so very cold--and looks and feels so very much



<P>like snow, that if it were to any other place or with any other party,



<P>I should really try not to go out to-day--and dissuade my father



<P>from venturing; but as he has made up his mind, and does not seem



<P>to feel the cold himself, I do not like to interfere, as I know it



<P>would be so great a disappointment to Mr. and Mrs. Weston.&nbsp; But,

upon



<P>my word, Mr. Elton, in your case, I should certainly excuse myself.



<P>You appear to me a little hoarse already, and when you consider



<P>what demand of voice and what fatigues to-morrow will bring,



<P>I think it would be no more than common prudence to stay at home



<P>and take care of yourself to-night."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Elton looked as if he did not very well know what answer to make;



<P>which was exactly the case; for though very much gratified by the kind



<P>care of such a fair lady, and not liking to resist any advice of



<P>her's, he had not really the least inclination to give up the visit;--



<P>but Emma, too eager and busy in her own previous conceptions



<P>and views to hear him impartially, or see him with clear vision,



<P>was very well satisfied with his muttering acknowledgment of its



<P>being "very cold, certainly very cold," and walked on, rejoicing in



<P>having extricated him from Randalls, and secured him the power



<P>of sending to inquire after Harriet every hour of the evening.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You do quite right," said she;--"we will make your apologies



<P>to Mr. and Mrs. Weston."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But hardly had she so spoken, when she found her brother was civilly



<P>offering a seat in his carriage, if the weather were Mr. Elton's



<P>only objection, and Mr. Elton actually accepting the offer with much



<P>prompt satisfaction.&nbsp; It was a done thing; Mr. Elton was to go,



<P>and never had his broad handsome face expressed more pleasure than



<P>at this moment; never had his smile been stronger, nor his eyes



<P>more exulting than when he next looked at her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well," said she to herself, "this is most strange!--After I



<P>had got him off so well, to chuse to go into company, and leave



<P>Harriet ill behind!--Most strange indeed!--But there is, I believe,



<P>in many men, especially single men, such an inclination--



<P>such a passion for dining out--a dinner engagement is so high in



<P>the class of their pleasures, their employments, their dignities,



<P>almost their duties, that any thing gives way to it--and this must



<P>be the case with Mr. Elton; a most valuable, amiable, pleasing young



<P>man undoubtedly, and very much in love with Harriet; but still,



<P>he cannot refuse an invitation, he must dine out wherever he is asked.



<P>What a strange thing love is! he can see ready wit in Harriet,



<P>but will not dine alone for her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Soon afterwards Mr. Elton quitted them, and she could not but do him



<P>the justice of feeling that there was a great deal of sentiment



<P>in his manner of naming Harriet at parting; in the tone of his



<P>voice while assuring her that he should call at Mrs. Goddard's



<P>for news of her fair friend, the last thing before he prepared



<P>for the happiness of meeting her again, when he hoped to be



<P>able to give a better report; and he sighed and smiled himself



<P>off in a way that left the balance of approbation much in his favour.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After a few minutes of entire silence between them, John Knightley



<P>began with--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I never in my life saw a man more intent on being agreeable than



<P>Mr. Elton.&nbsp; It is downright labour to him where ladies are concerned.



<P>With men he can be rational and unaffected, but when he has ladies



<P>to please, every feature works."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mr. Elton's manners are not perfect," replied Emma; "but where there



<P>is a wish to please, one ought to overlook, and one does overlook



<P>a great deal.&nbsp; Where a man does his best with only moderate powers,



<P>he will have the advantage over negligent superiority.&nbsp; There is



<P>such perfect good-temper and good-will in Mr. Elton as one cannot



<P>but value."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes," said Mr. John Knightley presently, with some slyness,



<P>"he seems to have a great deal of good-will towards you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Me!" she replied with a smile of astonishment, "are you imagining



<P>me to be Mr. Elton's object?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Such an imagination has crossed me, I own, Emma; and if it never



<P>occurred to you before, you may as well take it into consideration now."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mr. Elton in love with me!--What an idea!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not say it is so; but you will do well to consider whether



<P>it is so or not, and to regulate your behaviour accordingly.



<P>I think your manners to him encouraging.&nbsp; I speak as a friend,



<P>Emma.&nbsp; You had better look about you, and ascertain what you do,



<P>and what you mean to do."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I thank you; but I assure you you are quite mistaken.&nbsp; Mr. Elton



<P>and I are very good friends, and nothing more;" and she walked on,



<P>amusing herself in the consideration of the blunders which often



<P>arise from a partial knowledge of circumstances, of the mistakes



<P>which people of high pretensions to judgment are for ever falling into;



<P>and not very well pleased with her brother for imagining her blind



<P>and ignorant, and in want of counsel.&nbsp; He said no more.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Woodhouse had so completely made up his mind to the visit,



<P>that in spite of the increasing coldness, he seemed to have no idea



<P>of shrinking from it, and set forward at last most punctually



<P>with his eldest daughter in his own carriage, with less apparent



<P>consciousness of the weather than either of the others; too full



<P>of the wonder of his own going, and the pleasure it was to afford at



<P>Randalls to see that it was cold, and too well wrapt up to feel it.



<P>The cold, however, was severe; and by the time the second carriage



<P>was in motion, a few flakes of snow were finding their way down,



<P>and the sky had the appearance of being so overcharged as to want only



<P>a milder air to produce a very white world in a very short time.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma soon saw that her companion was not in the happiest humour.



<P>The preparing and the going abroad in such weather, with the sacrifice



<P>of his children after dinner, were evils, were disagreeables at least,



<P>which Mr. John Knightley did not by any means like; he anticipated



<P>nothing in the visit that could be at all worth the purchase;



<P>and the whole of their drive to the vicarage was spent by him in



<P>expressing his discontent.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A man," said he, "must have a very good opinion of himself when



<P>he asks people to leave their own fireside, and encounter such



<P>a day as this, for the sake of coming to see him.&nbsp; He must think



<P>himself a most agreeable fellow; I could not do such a thing.



<P>It is the greatest absurdity--Actually snowing at this moment!--



<P>The folly of not allowing people to be comfortable at home--and the



<P>folly of people's not staying comfortably at home when they can!



<P>If we were obliged to go out such an evening as this, by any call of



<P>duty or business, what a hardship we should deem it;--and here are we,



<P>probably with rather thinner clothing than usual, setting forward



<P>voluntarily, without excuse, in defiance of the voice of nature,



<P>which tells man, in every thing given to his view or his feelings,



<P>to stay at home himself, and keep all under shelter that he can;--



<P>here are we setting forward to spend five dull hours in another



<P>man's house, with nothing to say or to hear that was not said



<P>and heard yesterday, and may not be said and heard again to-morrow.



<P>Going in dismal weather, to return probably in worse;--four horses



<P>and four servants taken out for nothing but to convey five idle,



<P>shivering creatures into colder rooms and worse company than they



<P>might have had at home."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma did not find herself equal to give the pleased assent, which no

doubt



<P>he was in the habit of receiving, to emulate the "Very true, my love,"



<P>which must have been usually administered by his travelling companion;



<P>but she had resolution enough to refrain from making any answer



<P>at all.&nbsp; She could not be complying, she dreaded being quarrelsome;



<P>her heroism reached only to silence.&nbsp; She allowed him to talk,



<P>and arranged the glasses, and wrapped herself up, without opening



<P>her lips.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They arrived, the carriage turned, the step was let down,



<P>and Mr. Elton, spruce, black, and smiling, was with them instantly.



<P>Emma thought with pleasure of some change of subject.&nbsp; Mr. Elton



<P>was all obligation and cheerfulness; he was so very cheerful



<P>in his civilities indeed, that she began to think he must have



<P>received a different account of Harriet from what had reached her.



<P>She had sent while dressing, and the answer had been, "Much the same--



<P>not better."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My report from Mrs. Goddard's," said she presently, "was not



<P>so pleasant as I had hoped--`Not better' was my answer."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>His face lengthened immediately; and his voice was the voice



<P>of sentiment as he answered.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! no--I am grieved to find--I was on the point of telling you that



<P>when I called at Mrs. Goddard's door, which I did the very last thing



<P>before I returned to dress, I was told that Miss Smith was not better,



<P>by no means better, rather worse.&nbsp; Very much grieved and concerned--



<P>I had flattered myself that she must be better after such a cordial



<P>as I knew had been given her in the morning."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma smiled and answered--"My visit was of use to the nervous part



<P>of her complaint, I hope; but not even I can charm away a sore throat;



<P>it is a most severe cold indeed.&nbsp; Mr. Perry has been with her,



<P>as you probably heard."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes--I imagined--that is--I did not--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He has been used to her in these complaints, and I hope to-morrow



<P>morning will bring us both a more comfortable report.&nbsp; But it is



<P>impossible not to feel uneasiness.&nbsp; Such a sad loss to our party

to-day!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Dreadful!--Exactly so, indeed.--She will be missed every moment."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This was very proper; the sigh which accompanied it was really estimable;



<P>but it should have lasted longer.&nbsp; Emma was rather in dismay when



<P>only half a minute afterwards he began to speak of other things,



<P>and in a voice of the greatest alacrity and enjoyment.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What an excellent device," said he, "the use of a sheepskin



<P>for carriages.&nbsp; How very comfortable they make it;--impossible

to



<P>feel cold with such precautions.&nbsp; The contrivances of modern days



<P>indeed have rendered a gentleman's carriage perfectly complete.



<P>One is so fenced and guarded from the weather, that not a breath



<P>of air can find its way unpermitted.&nbsp; Weather becomes absolutely



<P>of no consequence.&nbsp; It is a very cold afternoon--but in this carriage



<P>we know nothing of the matter.--Ha! snows a little I see."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes," said John Knightley, "and I think we shall have a good deal



<P>of it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Christmas weather," observed Mr. Elton.&nbsp; "Quite seasonable;



<P>and extremely fortunate we may think ourselves that it did not



<P>begin yesterday, and prevent this day's party, which it might very



<P>possibly have done, for Mr. Woodhouse would hardly have ventured had



<P>there been much snow on the ground; but now it is of no consequence.



<P>This is quite the season indeed for friendly meetings.&nbsp; At Christmas



<P>every body invites their friends about them, and people think little



<P>of even the worst weather.&nbsp; I was snowed up at a friend's house

once



<P>for a week.&nbsp; Nothing could be pleasanter.&nbsp; I went for only

one night,



<P>and could not get away till that very day se'nnight."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. John Knightley looked as if he did not comprehend the pleasure,



<P>but said only, coolly,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I cannot wish to be snowed up a week at Randalls."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>At another time Emma might have been amused, but she was too



<P>much astonished now at Mr. Elton's spirits for other feelings.



<P>Harriet seemed quite forgotten in the expectation of a pleasant party.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We are sure of excellent fires," continued he, "and every thing



<P>in the greatest comfort.&nbsp; Charming people, Mr. and Mrs. Weston;--



<P>Mrs. Weston indeed is much beyond praise, and he is exactly



<P>what one values, so hospitable, and so fond of society;--



<P>it will be a small party, but where small parties are select,



<P>they are perhaps the most agreeable of any.&nbsp; Mr. Weston's dining-room



<P>does not accommodate more than ten comfortably; and for my part,



<P>I would rather, under such circumstances, fall short by two than



<P>exceed by two.&nbsp; I think you will agree with me, (turning with a

soft



<P>air to Emma,) I think I shall certainly have your approbation,



<P>though Mr. Knightley perhaps, from being used to the large parties



<P>of London, may not quite enter into our feelings."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I know nothing of the large parties of London, sir--I never dine



<P>with any body."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Indeed! (in a tone of wonder and pity,) I had no idea that the



<P>law had been so great a slavery.&nbsp; Well, sir, the time must come



<P>when you will be paid for all this, when you will have little



<P>labour and great enjoyment."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My first enjoyment," replied John Knightley, as they passed through



<P>the sweep-gate, "will be to find myself safe at Hartfield again."



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 07</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER VII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>The very day of Mr. Elton's going to London produced a fresh occasion



<P>for Emma's services towards her friend.&nbsp; Harriet had been at Hartfield,



<P>as usual, soon after breakfast; and, after a time, had gone home



<P>to return again to dinner: she returned, and sooner than had been



<P>talked of, and with an agitated, hurried look, announcing something



<P>extraordinary to have happened which she was longing to tell.



<P>Half a minute brought it all out.&nbsp; She had heard, as soon as she

got



<P>back to Mrs. Goddard's, that Mr. Martin had been there an hour before,



<P>and finding she was not at home, nor particularly expected, had left



<P>a little parcel for her from one of his sisters, and gone away;



<P>and on opening this parcel, she had actually found, besides the two



<P>songs which she had lent Elizabeth to copy, a letter to herself;



<P>and this letter was from him, from Mr. Martin, and contained a direct



<P>proposal of marriage.&nbsp; "Who could have thought it? She was so surprized



<P>she did not know what to do.&nbsp; Yes, quite a proposal of marriage;



<P>and a very good letter, at least she thought so.&nbsp; And he wrote



<P>as if he really loved her very much--but she did not know--and so,



<P>she was come as fast as she could to ask Miss Woodhouse what she



<P>should do.--" Emma was half-ashamed of her friend for seeming so



<P>pleased and so doubtful.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Upon my word," she cried, "the young man is determined not to lose



<P>any thing for want of asking.&nbsp; He will connect himself well if

he can."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Will you read the letter?" cried Harriet.&nbsp; "Pray do.&nbsp; I'd

rather



<P>you would."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma was not sorry to be pressed.&nbsp; She read, and was surprized.



<P>The style of the letter was much above her expectation.



<P>There were not merely no grammatical errors, but as a composition it



<P>would not have disgraced a gentleman; the language, though plain,



<P>was strong and unaffected, and the sentiments it conveyed very much



<P>to the credit of the writer.&nbsp; It was short, but expressed good

sense,



<P>warm attachment, liberality, propriety, even delicacy of feeling.



<P>She paused over it, while Harriet stood anxiously watching for



<P>her opinion, with a "Well, well," and was at last forced to add,



<P>"Is it a good letter? or is it too short?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, indeed, a very good letter," replied Emma rather slowly--"so



<P>good a letter, Harriet, that every thing considered, I think one of



<P>his sisters must have helped him.&nbsp; I can hardly imagine the young



<P>man whom I saw talking with you the other day could express himself



<P>so well, if left quite to his own powers, and yet it is not the



<P>style of a woman; no, certainly, it is too strong and concise;



<P>not diffuse enough for a woman.&nbsp; No doubt he is a sensible man,



<P>and I suppose may have a natural talent for--thinks strongly and



<P>clearly--and when he takes a pen in hand, his thoughts naturally find



<P>proper words.&nbsp; It is so with some men.&nbsp; Yes, I understand

the sort



<P>of mind.&nbsp; Vigorous, decided, with sentiments to a certain point,



<P>not coarse.&nbsp; A better written letter, Harriet (returning it,)



<P>than I had expected."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well," said the still waiting Harriet;--" well--and-- and what



<P>shall I do?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What shall you do! In what respect? Do you mean with regard



<P>to this letter?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But what are you in doubt of? You must answer it of course--and speedily."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes. But what shall I say? Dear Miss Woodhouse, do advise me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh no, no! the letter had much better be all your own.&nbsp; You will



<P>express yourself very properly, I am sure.&nbsp; There is no danger

of your



<P>not being intelligible, which is the first thing.&nbsp; Your meaning

must



<P>be unequivocal; no doubts or demurs: and such expressions of gratitude



<P>and concern for the pain you are inflicting as propriety requires,



<P>will present themselves unbidden to your mind, I am persuaded.



<P>You need not be prompted to write with the appearance of sorrow



<P>for his disappointment."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You think I ought to refuse him then," said Harriet, looking down.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ought to refuse him! My dear Harriet, what do you mean? Are you



<P>in any doubt as to that? I thought--but I beg your pardon, perhaps I



<P>have been under a mistake.&nbsp; I certainly have been misunderstanding



<P>you, if you feel in doubt as to the purport of your answer.



<P>I had imagined you were consulting me only as to the wording of it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet was silent.&nbsp; With a little reserve of manner, Emma continued:

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You mean to return a favourable answer, I collect."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, I do not; that is, I do not mean--What shall I do? What would



<P>you advise me to do? Pray, dear Miss Woodhouse, tell me what I



<P>ought to do."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I shall not give you any advice, Harriet.&nbsp; I will have nothing

to



<P>do with it.&nbsp; This is a point which you must settle with your feelings."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I had no notion that he liked me so very much," said Harriet,



<P>contemplating the letter.&nbsp; For a little while Emma persevered



<P>in her silence; but beginning to apprehend the bewitching flattery



<P>of that letter might be too powerful, she thought it best to say,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I lay it down as a general rule, Harriet, that if a woman doubts



<P>as to whether she should accept a man or not, she certainly ought



<P>to refuse him.&nbsp; If she can hesitate as to `Yes,' she ought to say



<P>`No' directly.&nbsp; It is not a state to be safely entered into



<P>with doubtful feelings, with half a heart.&nbsp; I thought it my duty



<P>as a friend, and older than yourself, to say thus much to you.



<P>But do not imagine that I want to influence you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! no, I am sure you are a great deal too kind to--but if you



<P>would just advise me what I had best do--No, no, I do not mean



<P>that--As you say, one's mind ought to be quite made up--One should



<P>not be hesitating--It is a very serious thing.--It will be safer



<P>to say `No,' perhaps.--Do you think I had better say `No?'"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not for the world," said Emma, smiling graciously, "would I advise



<P>you either way.&nbsp; You must be the best judge of your own happiness.



<P>If you prefer Mr. Martin to every other person; if you think him



<P>the most agreeable man you have ever been in company with, why should



<P>you hesitate? You blush, Harriet.--Does any body else occur to you



<P>at this moment under such a definition? Harriet, Harriet, do not



<P>deceive yourself; do not be run away with by gratitude and compassion.



<P>At this moment whom are you thinking of?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The symptoms were favourable.--Instead of answering, Harriet turned



<P>away confused, and stood thoughtfully by the fire; and though



<P>the letter was still in her hand, it was now mechanically twisted



<P>about without regard.&nbsp; Emma waited the result with impatience,



<P>but not without strong hopes.&nbsp; At last, with some hesitation,



<P>Harriet said--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Miss Woodhouse, as you will not give me your opinion, I must



<P>do as well as I can by myself; and I have now quite determined,



<P>and really almost made up my mind--to refuse Mr. Martin.&nbsp; Do you



<P>think I am right?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Perfectly, perfectly right, my dearest Harriet; you are doing just



<P>what you ought.&nbsp; While you were at all in suspense I kept my feelings



<P>to myself, but now that you are so completely decided I have no



<P>hesitation in approving.&nbsp; Dear Harriet, I give myself joy of this.



<P>It would have grieved me to lose your acquaintance, which must have



<P>been the consequence of your marrying Mr. Martin.&nbsp; While you were

in



<P>the smallest degree wavering, I said nothing about it, because I would



<P>not influence; but it would have been the loss of a friend to me.



<P>I could not have visited Mrs. Robert Martin, of Abbey-Mill Farm.



<P>Now I am secure of you for ever."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet had not surmised her own danger, but the idea of it struck



<P>her forcibly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You could not have visited me!" she cried, looking aghast.



<P>"No, to be sure you could not; but I never thought of that before.



<P>That would have been too dreadful!--What an escape!--Dear Miss Woodhouse,



<P>I would not give up the pleasure and honour of being intimate with you



<P>for any thing in the world."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Indeed, Harriet, it would have been a severe pang to lose you;



<P>but it must have been.&nbsp; You would have thrown yourself out of all



<P>good society.&nbsp; I must have given you up."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Dear me!--How should I ever have borne it! It would have killed



<P>me never to come to Hartfield any more!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Dear affectionate creature!--You banished to Abbey-Mill Farm!--You



<P>confined to the society of the illiterate and vulgar all your life!



<P>I wonder how the young man could have the assurance to ask it.



<P>He must have a pretty good opinion of himself."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not think he is conceited either, in general," said Harriet,



<P>her conscience opposing such censure; "at least, he is very good natured,



<P>and I shall always feel much obliged to him, and have a great regard



<P>for-- but that is quite a different thing from--and you know,



<P>though he may like me, it does not follow that I should--and



<P>certainly I must confess that since my visiting here I have seen



<P>people--and if one comes to compare them, person and manners,



<P>there is no comparison at all, one is so very handsome and agreeable.



<P>However, I do really think Mr. Martin a very amiable young man,



<P>and have a great opinion of him; and his being so much attached



<P>to me--and his writing such a letter--but as to leaving you,



<P>it is what I would not do upon any consideration."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thank you, thank you, my own sweet little friend.&nbsp; We will not



<P>be parted.&nbsp; A woman is not to marry a man merely because she is

asked,



<P>or because he is attached to her, and can write a tolerable letter."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh no;--and it is but a short letter too."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma felt the bad taste of her friend, but let it pass with a



<P>"very true; and it would be a small consolation to her, for the



<P>clownish manner which might be offending her every hour of the day,



<P>to know that her husband could write a good letter."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! yes, very.&nbsp; Nobody cares for a letter; the thing is, to be

always



<P>happy with pleasant companions.&nbsp; I am quite determined to refuse

him.



<P>But how shall I do? That shall I say?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma assured her there would be no difficulty in the answer,



<P>and advised its being written directly, which was agreed to,



<P>in the hope of her assistance; and though Emma continued to protest



<P>against any assistance being wanted, it was in fact given in the



<P>formation of every sentence.&nbsp; The looking over his letter again,



<P>in replying to it, had such a softening tendency, that it was



<P>particularly necessary to brace her up with a few decisive expressions;



<P>and she was so very much concerned at the idea of making him unhappy,



<P>and thought so much of what his mother and sisters would think and say,



<P>and was so anxious that they should not fancy her ungrateful,



<P>that Emma believed if the young man had come in her way at that moment,



<P>he would have been accepted after all.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This letter, however, was written, and sealed, and sent.



<P>The business was finished, and Harriet safe.&nbsp; She was rather low



<P>all the evening, but Emma could allow for her amiable regrets,



<P>and sometimes relieved them by speaking of her own affection,



<P>sometimes by bringing forward the idea of Mr. Elton.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I shall never be invited to Abbey-Mill again," was said in rather



<P>a sorrowful tone.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nor, if you were, could I ever bear to part with you, my Harriet.



<P>You are a great deal too necessary at Hartfield to be spared



<P>to Abbey-Mill."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And I am sure I should never want to go there; for I am never happy



<P>but at Hartfield."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Some time afterwards it was, "I think Mrs. Goddard would be very



<P>much surprized if she knew what had happened.&nbsp; I am sure Miss Nash



<P>would--for Miss Nash thinks her own sister very well married,



<P>and it is only a linen-draper."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"One should be sorry to see greater pride or refinement in the



<P>teacher of a school, Harriet.&nbsp; I dare say Miss Nash would envy

you



<P>such an opportunity as this of being married.&nbsp; Even this conquest



<P>would appear valuable in her eyes.&nbsp; As to any thing superior for

you,



<P>I suppose she is quite in the dark.&nbsp; The attentions of a certain



<P>person can hardly be among the tittle-tattle of Highbury yet.



<P>Hitherto I fancy you and I are the only people to whom his looks



<P>and manners have explained themselves."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet blushed and smiled, and said something about wondering



<P>that people should like her so much.&nbsp; The idea of Mr. Elton was



<P>certainly cheering; but still, after a time, she was tender-hearted



<P>again towards the rejected Mr. Martin.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now he has got my letter," said she softly.&nbsp; "I wonder what they



<P>are all doing--whether his sisters know--if he is unhappy,



<P>they will be unhappy too.&nbsp; I hope he will not mind it so very much."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Let us think of those among our absent friends who are more



<P>cheerfully employed," cried Emma.&nbsp; "At this moment, perhaps, Mr.

Elton



<P>is shewing your picture to his mother and sisters, telling how much



<P>more beautiful is the original, and after being asked for it five



<P>or six times, allowing them to hear your name, your own dear name."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My picture!--But he has left my picture in Bond-street."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Has he so!--Then I know nothing of Mr. Elton.&nbsp; No, my dear



<P>little modest Harriet, depend upon it the picture will not be



<P>in Bond-street till just before he mounts his horse to-morrow.



<P>It is his companion all this evening, his solace, his delight.



<P>It opens his designs to his family, it introduces you among them,



<P>it diffuses through the party those pleasantest feelings of our nature,



<P>eager curiosity and warm prepossession.&nbsp; How cheerful, how animated,



<P>how suspicious, how busy their imaginations all are!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet smiled again, and her smiles grew stronger.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 07</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER VI</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Emma could not feel a doubt of having given Harriet's fancy



<P>a proper direction and raised the gratitude of her young vanity



<P>to a very good purpose, for she found her decidedly more sensible



<P>than before of Mr. Elton's being a remarkably handsome man, with most



<P>agreeable manners; and as she had no hesitation in following up



<P>the assurance of his admiration by agreeable hints, she was soon



<P>pretty confident of creating as much liking on Harriet's side,



<P>as there could be any occasion for.&nbsp; She was quite convinced



<P>of Mr. Elton's being in the fairest way of falling in love,



<P>if not in love already.&nbsp; She had no scruple with regard to him.



<P>He talked of Harriet, and praised her so warmly, that she could



<P>not suppose any thing wanting which a little time would not add.



<P>His perception of the striking improvement of Harriet's manner,



<P>since her introduction at Hartfield, was not one of the least



<P>agreeable proofs of his growing attachment.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You have given Miss Smith all that she required," said he;



<P>"you have made her graceful and easy.&nbsp; She was a beautiful creature



<P>when she came to you, but, in my opinion, the attractions you have



<P>added are infinitely superior to what she received from nature."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am glad you think I have been useful to her; but Harriet



<P>only wanted drawing out, and receiving a few, very few hints.



<P>She had all the natural grace of sweetness of temper and artlessness



<P>in herself.&nbsp; I have done very little."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If it were admissible to contradict a lady," said the gallant



<P>Mr. Elton--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have perhaps given her a little more decision of character,



<P>have taught her to think on points which had not fallen in her



<P>way before."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Exactly so; that is what principally strikes me.&nbsp; So much superadded



<P>decision of character! Skilful has been the hand!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Great has been the pleasure, I am sure.&nbsp; I never met with



<P>a disposition more truly amiable."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have no doubt of it." And it was spoken with a sort



<P>of sighing animation, which had a vast deal of the lover.



<P>She was not less pleased another day with the manner



<P>in which he seconded a sudden wish of hers, to have Harriet's picture.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Did you ever have your likeness taken, Harriet?" said she: "did



<P>you ever sit for your picture?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet was on the point of leaving the room, and only stopt to say,



<P>with a very interesting naivete,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! dear, no, never."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>No sooner was she out of sight, than Emma exclaimed,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What an exquisite possession a good picture of her would be! I would



<P>give any money for it.&nbsp; I almost long to attempt her likeness myself.



<P>You do not know it I dare say, but two or three years ago I had



<P>a great passion for taking likenesses, and attempted several of



<P>my friends, and was thought to have a tolerable eye in general.



<P>But from one cause or another, I gave it up in disgust.



<P>But really, I could almost venture, if Harriet would sit to me.



<P>It would be such a delight to have her picture!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Let me entreat you," cried Mr. Elton; "it would indeed be a delight!



<P>Let me entreat you, Miss Woodhouse, to exercise so charming a



<P>talent in favour of your friend.&nbsp; I know what your drawings are.



<P>How could you suppose me ignorant? Is not this room rich in



<P>specimens of your landscapes and flowers; and has not Mrs. Weston



<P>some inimitable figure-pieces in her drawing-room, at Randalls?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Yes, good man!--thought Emma--but what has all that to do with taking



<P>likenesses? You know nothing of drawing.&nbsp; Don't pretend to be



<P>in raptures about mine.&nbsp; Keep your raptures for Harriet's face.



<P>"Well, if you give me such kind encouragement, Mr. Elton, I believe



<P>I shall try what I can do.&nbsp; Harriet's features are very delicate,



<P>which makes a likeness difficult; and yet there is a peculiarity



<P>in the shape of the eye and the lines about the mouth which one ought



<P>to catch."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Exactly so--The shape of the eye and the lines about the mouth--I



<P>have not a doubt of your success.&nbsp; Pray, pray attempt it.



<P>As you will do it, it will indeed, to use your own words,



<P>be an exquisite possession."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But I am afraid, Mr. Elton, Harriet will not like to sit.



<P>She thinks so little of her own beauty.&nbsp; Did not you observe her



<P>manner of answering me? How completely it meant, `why should my



<P>picture be drawn?'"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! yes, I observed it, I assure you.&nbsp; It was not lost on me.



<P>But still I cannot imagine she would not be persuaded."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet was soon back again, and the proposal almost immediately made;



<P>and she had no scruples which could stand many minutes against the earnest



<P>pressing of both the others.&nbsp; Emma wished to go to work directly,



<P>and therefore produced the portfolio containing her various attempts



<P>at portraits, for not one of them had ever been finished, that they



<P>might decide together on the best size for Harriet.&nbsp; Her many



<P>beginnings were displayed.&nbsp; Miniatures, half-lengths, whole-lengths,



<P>pencil, crayon, and water-colours had been all tried in turn.



<P>She had always wanted to do every thing, and had made more progress



<P>both in drawing and music than many might have done with so little



<P>labour as she would ever submit to.&nbsp; She played and sang;--and

drew



<P>in almost every style; but steadiness had always been wanting;



<P>and in nothing had she approached the degree of excellence which she



<P>would have been glad to command, and ought not to have failed of.



<P>She was not much deceived as to her own skill either as an artist



<P>or a musician, but she was not unwilling to have others deceived,



<P>or sorry to know her reputation for accomplishment often higher



<P>than it deserved.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was merit in every drawing--in the least finished, perhaps the

most;



<P>her style was spirited; but had there been much less, or had there



<P>been ten times more, the delight and admiration of her two companions



<P>would have been the same.&nbsp; They were both in ecstasies.&nbsp; A

likeness



<P>pleases every body; and Miss Woodhouse's performances must be capital.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No great variety of faces for you," said Emma.&nbsp; "I had only my



<P>own family to study from.&nbsp; There is my father--another of my



<P>father--but the idea of sitting for his picture made him so nervous,



<P>that I could only take him by stealth; neither of them very



<P>like therefore.&nbsp; Mrs. Weston again, and again, and again, you see.



<P>Dear Mrs. Weston! always my kindest friend on every occasion.



<P>She would sit whenever I asked her.&nbsp; There is my sister; and really



<P>quite her own little elegant figure!--and the face not unlike.



<P>I should have made a good likeness of her, if she would have



<P>sat longer, but she was in such a hurry to have me draw her four



<P>children that she would not be quiet.&nbsp; Then, here come all my



<P>attempts at three of those four children;--there they are,



<P>Henry and John and Bella, from one end of the sheet to the other,



<P>and any one of them might do for any one of the rest.&nbsp; She was

so



<P>eager to have them drawn that I could not refuse; but there is no



<P>making children of three or four years old stand still you know;



<P>nor can it be very easy to take any likeness of them, beyond the



<P>air and complexion, unless they are coarser featured than any



<P>of mama's children ever were.&nbsp; Here is my sketch of the fourth,



<P>who was a baby.&nbsp; I took him as he was sleeping on the sofa, and

it



<P>is as strong a likeness of his cockade as you would wish to see.



<P>He had nestled down his head most conveniently.&nbsp; That's very like.



<P>I am rather proud of little George.&nbsp; The corner of the sofa is

very good.



<P>Then here is my last,"--unclosing a pretty sketch of a gentleman



<P>in small size, whole-length-- "my last and my best--my brother,



<P>Mr. John Knightley.&nbsp; --This did not want much of being finished,

when I



<P>put it away in a pet, and vowed I would never take another likeness.



<P>I could not help being provoked; for after all my pains, and when I



<P>had really made a very good likeness of it--(Mrs. Weston and I



<P>were quite agreed in thinking it very like)--only too handsome--too



<P>flattering--but that was a fault on the right side-- after



<P>all this, came poor dear Isabella's cold approbation of--"Yes,



<P>it was a little like--but to be sure it did not do him justice."



<P>We had had a great deal of trouble in persuading him to sit at all.



<P>It was made a great favour of; and altogether it was more than I



<P>could bear; and so I never would finish it, to have it apologised



<P>over as an unfavourable likeness, to every morning visitor in



<P>Brunswick Square;--and, as I said, I did then forswear ever drawing



<P>any body again.&nbsp; But for Harriet's sake, or rather for my own,



<P>and as there are no husbands and wives in the case at present,



<P>I will break my resolution now."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Elton seemed very properly struck and delighted by the idea,



<P>and was repeating, "No husbands and wives in the case at present



<P>indeed, as you observe.&nbsp; Exactly so.&nbsp; No husbands and wives,"



<P>with so interesting a consciousness, that Emma began to consider



<P>whether she had not better leave them together at once.&nbsp; But as

she



<P>wanted to be drawing, the declaration must wait a little longer.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She had soon fixed on the size and sort of portrait.



<P>It was to be a whole-length in water-colours, like Mr. John



<P>Knightley's, and was destined, if she could please herself,



<P>to hold a very honourable station over the mantelpiece.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The sitting began; and Harriet, smiling and blushing, and afraid



<P>of not keeping her attitude and countenance, presented a very sweet



<P>mixture of youthful expression to the steady eyes of the artist.



<P>But there was no doing any thing, with Mr. Elton fidgeting behind



<P>her and watching every touch.&nbsp; She gave him credit for stationing



<P>himself where he might gaze and gaze again without offence;



<P>but was really obliged to put an end to it, and request him to



<P>place himself elsewhere.&nbsp; It then occurred to her to employ him



<P>in reading.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If he would be so good as to read to them, it would be a kindness



<P>indeed! It would amuse away the difficulties of her part, and lessen



<P>the irksomeness of Miss Smith's."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Elton was only too happy.&nbsp; Harriet listened, and Emma drew



<P>in peace.&nbsp; She must allow him to be still frequently coming to

look;



<P>any thing less would certainly have been too little in a lover;



<P>and he was ready at the smallest intermission of the pencil,



<P>to jump up and see the progress, and be charmed.--There was no



<P>being displeased with such an encourager, for his admiration



<P>made him discern a likeness almost before it was possible.



<P>She could not respect his eye, but his love and his complaisance



<P>were unexceptionable.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The sitting was altogether very satisfactory; she was quite



<P>enough pleased with the first day's sketch to wish to go on.



<P>There was no want of likeness, she had been fortunate in the attitude,



<P>and as she meant to throw in a little improvement to the figure,



<P>to give a little more height, and considerably more elegance, she had



<P>great confidence of its being in every way a pretty drawing at last,



<P>and of its filling its destined place with credit to them both--a



<P>standing memorial of the beauty of one, the skill of the other,



<P>and the friendship of both; with as many other agreeable associations



<P>as Mr. Elton's very promising attachment was likely to add.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet was to sit again the next day; and Mr. Elton, just as he ought,



<P>entreated for the permission of attending and reading to them again.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"By all means.&nbsp; We shall be most happy to consider you as one



<P>of the party."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The same civilities and courtesies, the same success and satisfaction,



<P>took place on the morrow, and accompanied the whole progress



<P>of the picture, which was rapid and happy.&nbsp; Every body who saw

it



<P>was pleased, but Mr. Elton was in continual raptures, and defended



<P>it through every criticism.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Miss Woodhouse has given her friend the only beauty she



<P>wanted,"--observed Mrs. Weston to him--not in the least suspecting



<P>that she was addressing a lover.--"The expression of the eye is



<P>most correct, but Miss Smith has not those eyebrows and eyelashes.



<P>It is the fault of her face that she has them not."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do you think so?" replied he.&nbsp; "I cannot agree with you.



<P>It appears to me a most perfect resemblance in every feature.



<P>I never saw such a likeness in my life.&nbsp; We must allow for the

effect



<P>of shade, you know."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You have made her too tall, Emma," said Mr. Knightley.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma knew that she had, but would not own it; and Mr. Elton warmly added,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh no! certainly not too tall; not in the least too tall.&nbsp; Consider,



<P>she is sitting down--which naturally presents a different--which



<P>in short gives exactly the idea--and the proportions must



<P>be preserved, you know.&nbsp; Proportions, fore-shortening.--Oh no!

it



<P>gives one exactly the idea of such a height as Miss Smith's. Exactly

so indeed!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is very pretty," said Mr. Woodhouse.&nbsp; "So prettily done! Just



<P>as your drawings always are, my dear.&nbsp; I do not know any body who

draws



<P>so well as you do.&nbsp; The only thing I do not thoroughly like is,



<P>that she seems to be sitting out of doors, with only a little shawl



<P>over her shoulders--and it makes one think she must catch cold."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But, my dear papa, it is supposed to be summer; a warm day in summer.



<P>Look at the tree."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But it is never safe to sit out of doors, my dear."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You, sir, may say any thing," cried Mr. Elton, "but I must confess



<P>that I regard it as a most happy thought, the placing of Miss



<P>Smith out of doors; and the tree is touched with such inimitable



<P>spirit! Any other situation would have been much less in character.



<P>The naivete of Miss Smith's manners--and altogether--Oh, it is



<P>most admirable! I cannot keep my eyes from it.&nbsp; I never saw such



<P>a likeness."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The next thing wanted was to get the picture framed; and here were a



<P>few difficulties.&nbsp; It must be done directly; it must be done in

London;



<P>the order must go through the hands of some intelligent person whose

taste



<P>could be depended on; and Isabella, the usual doer of all commissions,



<P>must not be applied to, because it was December, and Mr. Woodhouse



<P>could not bear the idea of her stirring out of her house in the fogs



<P>of December.&nbsp; But no sooner was the distress known to Mr. Elton,



<P>than it was removed.&nbsp; His gallantry was always on the alert.



<P>"Might he be trusted with the commission, what infinite pleasure



<P>should he have in executing it! he could ride to London at any time.



<P>It was impossible to say how much he should be gratified by being



<P>employed on such an errand."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He was too good!--she could not endure the thought!-- she would



<P>not give him such a troublesome office for the world,"--brought



<P>on the desired repetition of entreaties and assurances,--and



<P>a very few minutes settled the business.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Elton was to take the drawing to London, chuse the frame,



<P>and give the directions; and Emma thought she could so pack it



<P>as to ensure its safety without much incommoding him, while he



<P>seemed mostly fearful of not being incommoded enough.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What a precious deposit!" said he with a tender sigh, as he



<P>received it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"This man is almost too gallant to be in love," thought Emma.



<P>"I should say so, but that I suppose there may be a hundred different



<P>ways of being in love.&nbsp; He is an excellent young man, and will

suit



<P>Harriet exactly; it will be an `Exactly so,' as he says himself;



<P>but he does sigh and languish, and study for compliments rather more



<P>than I could endure as a principal.&nbsp; I come in for a pretty good



<P>share as a second.&nbsp; But it is his gratitude on Harriet's account."



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 12</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Mr. Knightley was to dine with them--rather against the inclination



<P>of Mr. Woodhouse, who did not like that any one should share with him



<P>in Isabella's first day.&nbsp; Emma's sense of right however had decided

it;



<P>and besides the consideration of what was due to each brother,



<P>she had particular pleasure, from the circumstance of the late



<P>disagreement between Mr. Knightley and herself, in procuring him



<P>the proper invitation.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She hoped they might now become friends again.&nbsp; She thought it



<P>was time to make up.&nbsp; Making-up indeed would not do.&nbsp; She

certainly



<P>had not been in the wrong, and he would never own that he had.



<P>Concession must be out of the question; but it was time to appear



<P>to forget that they had ever quarrelled; and she hoped it might rather



<P>assist the restoration of friendship, that when he came into the room



<P>she had one of the children with her--the youngest, a nice little girl



<P>about eight months old, who was now making her first visit to Hartfield,



<P>and very happy to be danced about in her aunt's arms.&nbsp; It did assist;



<P>for though he began with grave looks and short questions, he was soon



<P>led on to talk of them all in the usual way, and to take the child



<P>out of her arms with all the unceremoniousness of perfect amity.



<P>Emma felt they were friends again; and the conviction giving



<P>her at first great satisfaction, and then a little sauciness,



<P>she could not help saying, as he was admiring the baby,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What a comfort it is, that we think alike about our nephews and nieces.



<P>As to men and women, our opinions are sometimes very different;



<P>but with regard to these children, I observe we never disagree."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If you were as much guided by nature in your estimate of men



<P>and women, and as little under the power of fancy and whim in your



<P>dealings with them, as you are where these children are concerned,



<P>we might always think alike."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"To be sure--our discordancies must always arise from my being



<P>in the wrong."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes," said he, smiling--"and reason good.&nbsp; I was sixteen years



<P>old when you were born."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A material difference then," she replied--"and no doubt you were



<P>much my superior in judgment at that period of our lives; but does



<P>not the lapse of one-and-twenty years bring our understandings



<P>a good deal nearer?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes--a good deal nearer."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But still, not near enough to give me a chance of being right,



<P>if we think differently."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have still the advantage of you by sixteen years' experience, and

by



<P>not being a pretty young woman and a spoiled child.&nbsp; Come, my dear

Emma,



<P>let us be friends, and say no more about it.&nbsp; Tell your aunt, little

Emma,



<P>that she ought to set you a better example than to be renewing



<P>old grievances, and that if she were not wrong before, she is now."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's true," she cried--"very true.&nbsp; Little Emma, grow up



<P>a better woman than your aunt.&nbsp; Be infinitely cleverer and not



<P>half so conceited.&nbsp; Now, Mr. Knightley, a word or two more, and

I



<P>have done.&nbsp; As far as good intentions went, we were both right,



<P>and I must say that no effects on my side of the argument have yet



<P>proved wrong.&nbsp; I only want to know that Mr. Martin is not very,



<P>very bitterly disappointed."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A man cannot be more so," was his short, full answer.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah!--Indeed I am very sorry.--Come, shake hands with me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This had just taken place and with great cordiality, when John



<P>Knightley made his appearance, and "How d'ye do, George?" and "John,



<P>how are you?" succeeded in the true English style, burying under



<P>a calmness that seemed all but indifference, the real attachment



<P>which would have led either of them, if requisite, to do every thing



<P>for the good of the other.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The evening was quiet and conversable, as Mr. Woodhouse declined



<P>cards entirely for the sake of comfortable talk with his



<P>dear Isabella, and the little party made two natural divisions;



<P>on one side he and his daughter; on the other the two Mr. Knightleys;



<P>their subjects totally distinct, or very rarely mixing--and Emma



<P>only occasionally joining in one or the other.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The brothers talked of their own concerns and pursuits, but principally



<P>of those of the elder, whose temper was by much the most communicative,



<P>and who was always the greater talker.&nbsp; As a magistrate, he had



<P>generally some point of law to consult John about, or, at least,



<P>some curious anecdote to give; and as a farmer, as keeping in hand



<P>the home-farm at Donwell, he had to tell what every field was to bear



<P>next year, and to give all such local information as could not fail



<P>of being interesting to a brother whose home it had equally been



<P>the longest part of his life, and whose attachments were strong.



<P>The plan of a drain, the change of a fence, the felling of a tree,



<P>and the destination of every acre for wheat, turnips, or spring corn,



<P>was entered into with as much equality of interest by John, as his



<P>cooler manners rendered possible; and if his willing brother ever



<P>left him any thing to inquire about, his inquiries even approached



<P>a tone of eagerness.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>While they were thus comfortably occupied, Mr. Woodhouse was enjoying



<P>a full flow of happy regrets and fearful affection with his daughter.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My poor dear Isabella," said he, fondly taking her hand,



<P>and interrupting, for a few moments, her busy labours for some one



<P>of her five children--"How long it is, how terribly long since you



<P>were here!&nbsp; And how tired you must be after your journey!&nbsp;

You must



<P>go to bed early, my dear--and I recommend a little gruel to you



<P>before you go.--You and I will have a nice basin of gruel together.



<P>My dear Emma, suppose we all have a little gruel."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma could not suppose any such thing, knowing as she did,



<P>that both the Mr. Knightleys were as unpersuadable on that article



<P>as herself;--and two basins only were ordered.&nbsp; After a little



<P>more discourse in praise of gruel, with some wondering at its



<P>not being taken every evening by every body, he proceeded to say,



<P>with an air of grave reflection,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It was an awkward business, my dear, your spending the autumn



<P>at South End instead of coming here.&nbsp; I never had much opinion



<P>of the sea air."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mr. Wingfield most strenuously recommended it, sir--or we



<P>should not have gone.&nbsp; He recommended it for all the children,



<P>but particularly for the weakness in little Bella's throat,--



<P>both sea air and bathing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah! my dear, but Perry had many doubts about the sea doing her



<P>any good; and as to myself, I have been long perfectly convinced,



<P>though perhaps I never told you so before, that the sea is very



<P>rarely of use to any body.&nbsp; I am sure it almost killed me once."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Come, come," cried Emma, feeling this to be an unsafe subject, "I must



<P>beg you not to talk of the sea.&nbsp; It makes me envious and miserable;--



<P>I who have never seen it!&nbsp; South End is prohibited, if you please.



<P>My dear Isabella, I have not heard you make one inquiry about



<P>Mr. Perry yet; and he never forgets you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! good Mr. Perry--how is he, sir?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why, pretty well; but not quite well.&nbsp; Poor Perry is bilious,



<P>and he has not time to take care of himself--he tells me he has



<P>not time to take care of himself--which is very sad--but he is



<P>always wanted all round the country.&nbsp; I suppose there is not a

man



<P>in such practice anywhere.&nbsp; But then there is not so clever a man



<P>any where."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And Mrs. Perry and the children, how are they? do the children grow?



<P>I have a great regard for Mr. Perry.&nbsp; I hope he will be calling

soon.



<P>He will be so pleased to see my little ones."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I hope he will be here to-morrow, for I have a question or two to ask



<P>him about myself of some consequence.&nbsp; And, my dear, whenever he

comes,



<P>you had better let him look at little Bella's throat."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! my dear sir, her throat is so much better that I have hardly



<P>any uneasiness about it.&nbsp; Either bathing has been of the greatest



<P>service to her, or else it is to be attributed to an excellent



<P>embrocation of Mr. Wingfield's, which we have been applying



<P>at times ever since August."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is not very likely, my dear, that bathing should have been



<P>of use to her--and if I had known you were wanting an embrocation,



<P>I would have spoken to--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You seem to me to have forgotten Mrs. and Miss Bates," said Emma,



<P>"I have not heard one inquiry after them."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! the good Bateses--I am quite ashamed of myself--but you



<P>mention them in most of your letters.&nbsp; I hope they are quite well.



<P>Good old Mrs. Bates--I will call upon her to-morrow, and take



<P>my children.--They are always so pleased to see my children.--



<P>And that excellent Miss Bates!--such thorough worthy people!--



<P>How are they, sir?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why, pretty well, my dear, upon the whole.&nbsp; But poor Mrs. Bates



<P>had a bad cold about a month ago."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How sorry I am!&nbsp; But colds were never so prevalent as they have

been



<P>this autumn.&nbsp; Mr. Wingfield told me that he has never known them



<P>more general or heavy--except when it has been quite an influenza."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That has been a good deal the case, my dear; but not to the degree



<P>you mention.&nbsp; Perry says that colds have been very general,



<P>but not so heavy as he has very often known them in November.



<P>Perry does not call it altogether a sickly season."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, I do not know that Mr. Wingfield considers it very sickly except--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah! my poor dear child, the truth is, that in London it is always



<P>a sickly season.&nbsp; Nobody is healthy in London, nobody can be.



<P>It is a dreadful thing to have you forced to live there! so far off!--



<P>and the air so bad!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, indeed--we are not at all in a bad air.&nbsp; Our part of London

is



<P>very superior to most others!--You must not confound us with London



<P>in general, my dear sir.&nbsp; The neighbourhood of Brunswick Square



<P>is very different from almost all the rest.&nbsp; We are so very airy!



<P>I should be unwilling, I own, to live in any other part of the town;--



<P>there is hardly any other that I could be satisfied to have my



<P>children in:&nbsp; but we are so remarkably airy!--Mr. Wingfield thinks



<P>the vicinity of Brunswick Square decidedly the most favourable as



<P>to air."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah! my dear, it is not like Hartfield.&nbsp; You make the best of it--



<P>but after you have been a week at Hartfield, you are all of you



<P>different creatures; you do not look like the same.&nbsp; Now I cannot

say,



<P>that I think you are any of you looking well at present."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am sorry to hear you say so, sir; but I assure you, excepting those



<P>little nervous head-aches and palpitations which I am never entirely



<P>free from anywhere, I am quite well myself; and if the children were



<P>rather pale before they went to bed, it was only because they were
