<P>a little more tired than usual, from their journey and the happiness



<P>of coming.&nbsp; I hope you will think better of their looks to-morrow;



<P>for I assure you Mr. Wingfield told me, that he did not believe



<P>he had ever sent us off altogether, in such good case.&nbsp; I trust,



<P>at least, that you do not think Mr. Knightley looking ill,"



<P>turning her eyes with affectionate anxiety towards her husband.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Middling, my dear; I cannot compliment you.&nbsp; I think Mr. John



<P>Knightley very far from looking well."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What is the matter, sir?--Did you speak to me?" cried Mr. John



<P>Knightley, hearing his own name.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am sorry to find, my love, that my father does not think you



<P>looking well--but I hope it is only from being a little fatigued.



<P>I could have wished, however, as you know, that you had seen



<P>Mr. Wingfield before you left home."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear Isabella,"--exclaimed he hastily--"pray do not concern



<P>yourself about my looks.&nbsp; Be satisfied with doctoring and coddling



<P>yourself and the children, and let me look as I chuse."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I did not thoroughly understand what you were telling your brother,"



<P>cried Emma, "about your friend Mr. Graham's intending to have a bailiff



<P>from Scotland, to look after his new estate.&nbsp; What will it answer?



<P>Will not the old prejudice be too strong?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>And she talked in this way so long and successfully that, when forced



<P>to give her attention again to her father and sister, she had nothing



<P>worse to hear than Isabella's kind inquiry after Jane Fairfax;



<P>and Jane Fairfax, though no great favourite with her in general,



<P>she was at that moment very happy to assist in praising.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That sweet, amiable Jane Fairfax!" said Mrs. John Knightley.--



<P>"It is so long since I have seen her, except now and then for a moment



<P>accidentally in town!&nbsp; What happiness it must be to her good old



<P>grandmother and excellent aunt, when she comes to visit them!



<P>I always regret excessively on dear Emma's account that she cannot



<P>be more at Highbury; but now their daughter is married, I suppose



<P>Colonel and Mrs. Campbell will not be able to part with her at all.



<P>She would be such a delightful companion for Emma."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Woodhouse agreed to it all, but added,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Our little friend Harriet Smith, however, is just such another



<P>pretty kind of young person.&nbsp; You will like Harriet.&nbsp; Emma

could



<P>not have a better companion than Harriet."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am most happy to hear it--but only Jane Fairfax one knows to be



<P>so very accomplished and superior!--and exactly Emma's age."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This topic was discussed very happily, and others succeeded of



<P>similar moment, and passed away with similar harmony; but the evening



<P>did not close without a little return of agitation.&nbsp; The gruel

came



<P>and supplied a great deal to be said--much praise and many comments--



<P>undoubting decision of its wholesomeness for every constitution,



<P>and pretty severe Philippics upon the many houses where it was



<P>never met with tolerable;--but, unfortunately, among the failures



<P>which the daughter had to instance, the most recent, and therefore



<P>most prominent, was in her own cook at South End, a young woman



<P>hired for the time, who never had been able to understand what she



<P>meant by a basin of nice smooth gruel, thin, but not too thin.



<P>Often as she had wished for and ordered it, she had never been able



<P>to get any thing tolerable.&nbsp; Here was a dangerous opening.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah!" said Mr. Woodhouse, shaking his head and fixing his eyes on



<P>her with tender concern.--The ejaculation in Emma's ear expressed,



<P>"Ah! there is no end of the sad consequences of your going to



<P>South End.&nbsp; It does not bear talking of."&nbsp; And for a little

while



<P>she hoped he would not talk of it, and that a silent rumination



<P>might suffice to restore him to the relish of his own smooth gruel.



<P>After an interval of some minutes, however, he began with,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I shall always be very sorry that you went to the sea this autumn,



<P>instead of coming here."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But why should you be sorry, sir?--I assure you, it did the children



<P>a great deal of good."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And, moreover, if you must go to the sea, it had better not



<P>have been to South End.&nbsp; South End is an unhealthy place.



<P>Perry was surprized to hear you had fixed upon South End."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I know there is such an idea with many people, but indeed it is



<P>quite a mistake, sir.--We all had our health perfectly well there,



<P>never found the least inconvenience from the mud; and Mr. Wingfield



<P>says it is entirely a mistake to suppose the place unhealthy;



<P>and I am sure he may be depended on, for he thoroughly understands



<P>the nature of the air, and his own brother and family have been



<P>there repeatedly."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You should have gone to Cromer, my dear, if you went anywhere.--



<P>Perry was a week at Cromer once, and he holds it to be the best



<P>of all the sea-bathing places.&nbsp; A fine open sea, he says, and very



<P>pure air.&nbsp; And, by what I understand, you might have had lodgings

there



<P>quite away from the sea--a quarter of a mile off--very comfortable.



<P>You should have consulted Perry."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But, my dear sir, the difference of the journey;--only consider how



<P>great it would have been.--An hundred miles, perhaps, instead of forty."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah! my dear, as Perry says, where health is at stake, nothing else



<P>should be considered; and if one is to travel, there is not much



<P>to chuse between forty miles and an hundred.--Better not move at all,



<P>better stay in London altogether than travel forty miles to get



<P>into a worse air.&nbsp; This is just what Perry said.&nbsp; It seemed

to him



<P>a very ill-judged measure."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma's attempts to stop her father had been vain; and when he



<P>had reached such a point as this, she could not wonder at her



<P>brother-in-law's breaking out.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mr. Perry," said he, in a voice of very strong displeasure,



<P>"would do as well to keep his opinion till it is asked for.



<P>Why does he make it any business of his, to wonder at what I do?--



<P>at my taking my family to one part of the coast or another?--I may



<P>be allowed, I hope, the use of my judgment as well as Mr. Perry.--



<P>I want his directions no more than his drugs."&nbsp; He paused--



<P>and growing cooler in a moment, added, with only sarcastic dryness,



<P>"If Mr. Perry can tell me how to convey a wife and five children



<P>a distance of an hundred and thirty miles with no greater expense



<P>or inconvenience than a distance of forty, I should be as willing to



<P>prefer Cromer to South End as he could himself."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"True, true," cried Mr. Knightley, with most ready interposition--



<P>"very true.&nbsp; That's a consideration indeed.--But John, as to what

I



<P>was telling you of my idea of moving the path to Langham, of turning



<P>it more to the right that it may not cut through the home meadows,



<P>I cannot conceive any difficulty.&nbsp; I should not attempt it,



<P>if it were to be the means of inconvenience to the Highbury people,



<P>but if you call to mind exactly the present line of the path. . . .



<P>The only way of proving it, however, will be to turn to our maps.



<P>I shall see you at the Abbey to-morrow morning I hope, and then we



<P>will look them over, and you shall give me your opinion."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Woodhouse was rather agitated by such harsh reflections on



<P>his friend Perry, to whom he had, in fact, though unconsciously,



<P>been attributing many of his own feelings and expressions;--



<P>but the soothing attentions of his daughters gradually removed



<P>the present evil, and the immediate alertness of one brother,



<P>and better recollections of the other, prevented any renewal of it.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 08</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER VIII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Harriet slept at Hartfield that night.&nbsp; For some weeks past she



<P>had been spending more than half her time there, and gradually



<P>getting to have a bed-room appropriated to herself; and Emma



<P>judged it best in every respect, safest and kindest, to keep her



<P>with them as much as possible just at present.&nbsp; She was obliged



<P>to go the next morning for an hour or two to Mrs. Goddard's,



<P>but it was then to be settled that she should return to Hartfield,



<P>to make a regular visit of some days.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>While she was gone, Mr. Knightley called, and sat some time with



<P>Mr. Woodhouse and Emma, till Mr. Woodhouse, who had previously made

up



<P>his mind to walk out, was persuaded by his daughter not to defer it,



<P>and was induced by the entreaties of both, though against the scruples



<P>of his own civility, to leave Mr. Knightley for that purpose.



<P>Mr. Knightley, who had nothing of ceremony about him, was offering



<P>by his short, decided answers, an amusing contrast to the protracted



<P>apologies and civil hesitations of the other.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, I believe, if you will excuse me, Mr. Knightley, if you



<P>will not consider me as doing a very rude thing, I shall take



<P>Emma's advice and go out for a quarter of an hour.&nbsp; As the sun



<P>is out, I believe I had better take my three turns while I can.



<P>I treat you without ceremony, Mr. Knightley.&nbsp; We invalids think

we



<P>are privileged people."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear sir, do not make a stranger of me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I leave an excellent substitute in my daughter.&nbsp; Emma will be

happy



<P>to entertain you.&nbsp; And therefore I think I will beg your excuse



<P>and take my three turns--my winter walk."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You cannot do better, sir."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I would ask for the pleasure of your company, Mr. Knightley,



<P>but I am a very slow walker, and my pace would be tedious to you;



<P>and, besides, you have another long walk before you, to Donwell Abbey."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thank you, sir, thank you; I am going this moment myself; and I



<P>think the sooner you go the better.&nbsp; I will fetch your greatcoat



<P>and open the garden door for you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Woodhouse at last was off; but Mr. Knightley, instead of being



<P>immediately off likewise, sat down again, seemingly inclined



<P>for more chat.&nbsp; He began speaking of Harriet, and speaking



<P>of her with more voluntary praise than Emma had ever heard before.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I cannot rate her beauty as you do," said he; "but she is a



<P>pretty little creature, and I am inclined to think very well of



<P>her disposition.&nbsp; Her character depends upon those she is with;



<P>but in good hands she will turn out a valuable woman."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am glad you think so; and the good hands, I hope, may not be wanting."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Come," said he, "you are anxious for a compliment, so I will



<P>tell you that you have improved her.&nbsp; You have cured her of her



<P>school-girl's giggle; she really does you credit."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thank you.&nbsp; I should be mortified indeed if I did not believe

I



<P>had been of some use; but it is not every body who will bestow



<P>praise where they may.&nbsp; You do not often overpower me with it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are expecting her again, you say, this morning?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Almost every moment.&nbsp; She has been gone longer already than



<P>she intended."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Something has happened to delay her; some visitors perhaps."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Highbury gossips!--Tiresome wretches!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Harriet may not consider every body tiresome that you would."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma knew this was too true for contradiction, and therefore



<P>said nothing.&nbsp; He presently added, with a smile,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not pretend to fix on times or places, but I must tell you



<P>that I have good reason to believe your little friend will soon



<P>hear of something to her advantage."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Indeed! how so? of what sort?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A very serious sort, I assure you;" still smiling.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very serious! I can think of but one thing--Who is in love



<P>with her? Who makes you their confidant?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma was more than half in hopes of Mr. Elton's having dropt a hint.



<P>Mr. Knightley was a sort of general friend and adviser, and she knew



<P>Mr. Elton looked up to him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have reason to think," he replied, "that Harriet Smith will



<P>soon have an offer of marriage, and from a most unexceptionable



<P>quarter:--Robert Martin is the man.&nbsp; Her visit to Abbey-Mill,



<P>this summer, seems to have done his business.&nbsp; He is desperately



<P>in love and means to marry her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He is very obliging," said Emma; "but is he sure that Harriet



<P>means to marry him?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, well, means to make her an offer then.&nbsp; Will that do? He

came



<P>to the Abbey two evenings ago, on purpose to consult me about it.



<P>He knows I have a thorough regard for him and all his family, and,



<P>I believe, considers me as one of his best friends.&nbsp; He came to

ask



<P>me whether I thought it would be imprudent in him to settle so early;



<P>whether I thought her too young: in short, whether I approved his



<P>choice altogether; having some apprehension perhaps of her being



<P>considered (especially since your making so much of her) as in a line



<P>of society above him.&nbsp; I was very much pleased with all that he

said.



<P>I never hear better sense from any one than Robert Martin.



<P>He always speaks to the purpose; open, straightforward, and very



<P>well judging.&nbsp; He told me every thing; his circumstances and plans,



<P>and what they all proposed doing in the event of his marriage.&nbsp;

He is



<P>an excellent young man, both as son and brother.&nbsp; I had no hesitation



<P>in advising him to marry.&nbsp; He proved to me that he could afford

it;



<P>and that being the case, I was convinced he could not do better.



<P>I praised the fair lady too, and altogether sent him away very happy.



<P>If he had never esteemed my opinion before, he would have thought



<P>highly of me then; and, I dare say, left the house thinking me the



<P>best friend and counsellor man ever had.&nbsp; This happened the night



<P>before last.&nbsp; Now, as we may fairly suppose, he would not allow



<P>much time to pass before he spoke to the lady, and as he does not



<P>appear to have spoken yesterday, it is not unlikely that he should



<P>be at Mrs. Goddard's to-day; and she may be detained by a visitor,



<P>without thinking him at all a tiresome wretch."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Pray, Mr. Knightley," said Emma, who had been smiling to herself



<P>through a great part of this speech, "how do you know that Mr. Martin



<P>did not speak yesterday?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Certainly," replied he, surprized, "I do not absolutely know it;



<P>but it may be inferred.&nbsp; Was not she the whole day with you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Come," said she, "I will tell you something, in return for what



<P>you have told me.&nbsp; He did speak yesterday--that is, he wrote,



<P>and was refused."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This was obliged to be repeated before it could be believed;



<P>and Mr. Knightley actually looked red with surprize and displeasure,



<P>as he stood up, in tall indignation, and said,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then she is a greater simpleton than I ever believed her.



<P>What is the foolish girl about?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! to be sure," cried Emma, "it is always incomprehensible



<P>to a man that a woman should ever refuse an offer of marriage.



<P>A man always imagines a woman to be ready for any body who asks her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nonsense! a man does not imagine any such thing.&nbsp; But what is



<P>the meaning of this? Harriet Smith refuse Robert Martin? madness,



<P>if it is so; but I hope you are mistaken."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I saw her answer!--nothing could be clearer."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You saw her answer!--you wrote her answer too.&nbsp; Emma, this is



<P>your doing.&nbsp; You persuaded her to refuse him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And if I did, (which, however, I am far from allowing) I should



<P>not feel that I had done wrong.&nbsp; Mr. Martin is a very respectable



<P>young man, but I cannot admit him to be Harriet's equal; and am



<P>rather surprized indeed that he should have ventured to address her.



<P>By your account, he does seem to have had some scruples.&nbsp; It is



<P>a pity that they were ever got over."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not Harriet's equal!" exclaimed Mr. Knightley loudly and warmly;



<P>and with calmer asperity, added, a few moments afterwards, "No, he



<P>is not her equal indeed, for he is as much her superior in sense



<P>as in situation.&nbsp; Emma, your infatuation about that girl blinds

you.



<P>What are Harriet Smith's claims, either of birth, nature or education,



<P>to any connexion higher than Robert Martin? She is the natural



<P>daughter of nobody knows whom, with probably no settled provision



<P>at all, and certainly no respectable relations.&nbsp; She is known only



<P>as parlour-boarder at a common school.&nbsp; She is not a sensible girl,



<P>nor a girl of any information.&nbsp; She has been taught nothing useful,



<P>and is too young and too simple to have acquired any thing herself.



<P>At her age she can have no experience, and with her little wit,



<P>is not very likely ever to have any that can avail her.



<P>She is pretty, and she is good tempered, and that is all.



<P>My only scruple in advising the match was on his account, as being



<P>beneath his deserts, and a bad connexion for him.&nbsp; I felt that,



<P>as to fortune, in all probability he might do much better; and that

as



<P>to a rational companion or useful helpmate, he could not do worse.



<P>But I could not reason so to a man in love, and was willing



<P>to trust to there being no harm in her, to her having that sort



<P>of disposition, which, in good hands, like his, might be easily led



<P>aright and turn out very well.&nbsp; The advantage of the match I felt



<P>to be all on her side; and had not the smallest doubt (nor have I now)



<P>that there would be a general cry-out upon her extreme good luck.



<P>Even your satisfaction I made sure of.&nbsp; It crossed my mind immediately



<P>that you would not regret your friend's leaving Highbury, for the



<P>sake of her being settled so well.&nbsp; I remember saying to myself,



<P>`Even Emma, with all her partiality for Harriet, will think this a



<P>good match.'"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I cannot help wondering at your knowing so little of Emma as to say



<P>any such thing.&nbsp; What! think a farmer, (and with all his sense

and all



<P>his merit Mr. Martin is nothing more,) a good match for my intimate



<P>friend! Not regret her leaving Highbury for the sake of marrying



<P>a man whom I could never admit as an acquaintance of my own! I



<P>wonder you should think it possible for me to have such feelings.



<P>I assure you mine are very different.&nbsp; I must think your statement



<P>by no means fair.&nbsp; You are not just to Harriet's claims.



<P>They would be estimated very differently by others as well as myself;



<P>Mr. Martin may be the richest of the two, but he is undoubtedly



<P>her inferior as to rank in society.--The sphere in which she moves



<P>is much above his.--It would be a degradation."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A degradation to illegitimacy and ignorance, to be married



<P>to a respectable, intelligent gentleman-farmer!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"As to the circumstances of her birth, though in a legal sense



<P>she may be called Nobody, it will not hold in common sense.



<P>She is not to pay for the offence of others, by being held below



<P>the level of those with whom she is brought up.--There can scarcely



<P>be a doubt that her father is a gentleman--and a gentleman of



<P>fortune.--Her allowance is very liberal; nothing has ever been grudged



<P>for her improvement or comfort.--That she is a gentleman's daughter,



<P>is indubitable to me; that she associates with gentlemen's daughters,



<P>no one, I apprehend, will deny.--She is superior to Mr. Robert Martin."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Whoever might be her parents," said Mr. Knightley, "whoever may



<P>have had the charge of her, it does not appear to have been any part



<P>of their plan to introduce her into what you would call good society.



<P>After receiving a very indifferent education she is left in



<P>Mrs. Goddard's hands to shift as she can;--to move, in short,



<P>in Mrs. Goddard's line, to have Mrs. Goddard's acquaintance.



<P>Her friends evidently thought this good enough for her; and it was



<P>good enough.&nbsp; She desired nothing better herself.&nbsp; Till you

chose



<P>to turn her into a friend, her mind had no distaste for her own set,



<P>nor any ambition beyond it.&nbsp; She was as happy as possible with

the



<P>Martins in the summer.&nbsp; She had no sense of superiority then.



<P>If she has it now, you have given it.&nbsp; You have been no friend

to



<P>Harriet Smith, Emma.&nbsp; Robert Martin would never have proceeded

so far,



<P>if he had not felt persuaded of her not being disinclined to him.



<P>I know him well.&nbsp; He has too much real feeling to address any



<P>woman on the haphazard of selfish passion.&nbsp; And as to conceit,



<P>he is the farthest from it of any man I know.&nbsp; Depend upon it he



<P>had encouragement."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was most convenient to Emma not to make a direct reply to this



<P>assertion; she chose rather to take up her own line of the subject again.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are a very warm friend to Mr. Martin; but, as I said before,



<P>are unjust to Harriet.&nbsp; Harriet's claims to marry well are not



<P>so contemptible as you represent them.&nbsp; She is not a clever girl,



<P>but she has better sense than you are aware of, and does not



<P>deserve to have her understanding spoken of so slightingly.



<P>Waiving that point, however, and supposing her to be, as you



<P>describe her, only pretty and good-natured, let me tell you, that in



<P>the degree she possesses them, they are not trivial recommendations



<P>to the world in general, for she is, in fact, a beautiful girl,



<P>and must be thought so by ninety-nine people out of an hundred;



<P>and till it appears that men are much more philosophic on the subject



<P>of beauty than they are generally supposed; till they do fall



<P>in love with well-informed minds instead of handsome faces, a girl,



<P>with such loveliness as Harriet, has a certainty of being admired



<P>and sought after, of having the power of chusing from among many,



<P>consequently a claim to be nice.&nbsp; Her good-nature, too, is not

so very



<P>slight a claim, comprehending, as it does, real, thorough sweetness



<P>of temper and manner, a very humble opinion of herself, and a great



<P>readiness to be pleased with other people.&nbsp; I am very much mistaken



<P>if your sex in general would not think such beauty, and such temper,



<P>the highest claims a woman could possess."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Upon my word, Emma, to hear you abusing the reason you have,



<P>is almost enough to make me think so too.&nbsp; Better be without sense,



<P>than misapply it as you do."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"To be sure!" cried she playfully.&nbsp; "I know that is the feeling



<P>of you all.&nbsp; I know that such a girl as Harriet is exactly



<P>what every man delights in--what at once bewitches his senses



<P>and satisfies his judgment.&nbsp; Oh! Harriet may pick and chuse.



<P>Were you, yourself, ever to marry, she is the very woman for you.



<P>And is she, at seventeen, just entering into life, just beginning



<P>to be known, to be wondered at because she does not accept the first



<P>offer she receives? No--pray let her have time to look about her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have always thought it a very foolish intimacy," said Mr. Knightley



<P>presently, "though I have kept my thoughts to myself; but I now



<P>perceive that it will be a very unfortunate one for Harriet.



<P>You will puff her up with such ideas of her own beauty, and of what



<P>she has a claim to, that, in a little while, nobody within her



<P>reach will be good enough for her.&nbsp; Vanity working on a weak head,



<P>produces every sort of mischief.&nbsp; Nothing so easy as for a young

lady



<P>to raise her expectations too high.&nbsp; Miss Harriet Smith may not

find



<P>offers of marriage flow in so fast, though she is a very pretty girl.



<P>Men of sense, whatever you may chuse to say, do not want silly wives.



<P>Men of family would not be very fond of connecting themselves



<P>with a girl of such obscurity-- and most prudent men would be



<P>afraid of the inconvenience and disgrace they might be involved in,



<P>when the mystery of her parentage came to be revealed.&nbsp; Let her

marry



<P>Robert Martin, and she is safe, respectable, and happy for ever;



<P>but if you encourage her to expect to marry greatly, and teach



<P>her to be satisfied with nothing less than a man of consequence



<P>and large fortune, she may be a parlour-boarder at Mrs. Goddard's



<P>all the rest of her life--or, at least, (for Harriet Smith is a



<P>girl who will marry somebody or other,) till she grow desperate,



<P>and is glad to catch at the old writing-master's son."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We think so very differently on this point, Mr. Knightley,



<P>that there can be no use in canvassing it.&nbsp; We shall only be making



<P>each other more angry.&nbsp; But as to my letting her marry Robert Martin,



<P>it is impossible; she has refused him, and so decidedly, I think,



<P>as must prevent any second application.&nbsp; She must abide by the

evil



<P>of having refused him, whatever it may be; and as to the refusal itself,



<P>I will not pretend to say that I might not influence her a little;



<P>but I assure you there was very little for me or for any body to do.



<P>His appearance is so much against him, and his manner so bad,



<P>that if she ever were disposed to favour him, she is not now.



<P>I can imagine, that before she had seen any body superior,



<P>she might tolerate him.&nbsp; He was the brother of her friends,



<P>and he took pains to please her; and altogether, having seen



<P>nobody better (that must have been his great assistant)



<P>she might not, while she was at Abbey-Mill, find him disagreeable.



<P>But the case is altered now.&nbsp; She knows now what gentlemen are;



<P>and nothing but a gentleman in education and manner has any chance



<P>with Harriet."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nonsense, errant nonsense, as ever was talked!" cried Mr. Knightley.--"Robert



<P>Martin's manners have sense, sincerity, and good-humour to recommend



<P>them; and his mind has more true gentility than Harriet Smith could

understand."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma made no answer, and tried to look cheerfully unconcerned, but was



<P>really feeling uncomfortable and wanting him very much to be gone.



<P>She did not repent what she had done; she still thought herself



<P>a better judge of such a point of female right and refinement than he



<P>could be; but yet she had a sort of habitual respect for his judgment



<P>in general, which made her dislike having it so loudly against her;



<P>and to have him sitting just opposite to her in angry state,



<P>was very disagreeable.&nbsp; Some minutes passed in this unpleasant

silence,



<P>with only one attempt on Emma's side to talk of the weather,



<P>but he made no answer.&nbsp; He was thinking.&nbsp; The result of his

thoughts



<P>appeared at last in these words.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Robert Martin has no great loss--if he can but think so; and I



<P>hope it will not be long before he does.&nbsp; Your views for Harriet



<P>are best known to yourself; but as you make no secret of your love



<P>of match-making, it is fair to suppose that views, and plans,



<P>and projects you have;--and as a friend I shall just hint to you



<P>that if Elton is the man, I think it will be all labour in vain."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma laughed and disclaimed.&nbsp; He continued,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Depend upon it, Elton will not do.&nbsp; Elton is a very good sort

of man,



<P>and a very respectable vicar of Highbury, but not at all likely



<P>to make an imprudent match.&nbsp; He knows the value of a good income



<P>as well as any body.&nbsp; Elton may talk sentimentally, but he will



<P>act rationally.&nbsp; He is as well acquainted with his own claims,

as you



<P>can be with Harriet's. He knows that he is a very handsome young man,



<P>and a great favourite wherever he goes; and from his general way



<P>of talking in unreserved moments, when there are only men present,



<P>I am convinced that he does not mean to throw himself away.



<P>I have heard him speak with great animation of a large family



<P>of young ladies that his sisters are intimate with, who have all



<P>twenty thousand pounds apiece."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am very much obliged to you," said Emma, laughing again.



<P>"If I had set my heart on Mr. Elton's marrying Harriet, it would



<P>have been very kind to open my eyes; but at present I only want



<P>to keep Harriet to myself.&nbsp; I have done with match-making indeed.



<P>I could never hope to equal my own doings at Randalls.&nbsp; I shall

leave



<P>off while I am well."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Good morning to you,"--said he, rising and walking off abruptly.



<P>He was very much vexed.&nbsp; He felt the disappointment of the young

man,



<P>and was mortified to have been the means of promoting it, by the



<P>sanction he had given; and the part which he was persuaded Emma had



<P>taken in the affair, was provoking him exceedingly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma remained in a state of vexation too; but there was more



<P>indistinctness in the causes of her's, than in his.&nbsp; She did not

always



<P>feel so absolutely satisfied with herself, so entirely convinced that



<P>her opinions were right and her adversary's wrong, as Mr. Knightley.



<P>He walked off in more complete self-approbation than he left for her.



<P>She was not so materially cast down, however, but that a little



<P>time and the return of Harriet were very adequate restoratives.



<P>Harriet's staying away so long was beginning to make her uneasy.



<P>The possibility of the young man's coming to Mrs. Goddard's



<P>that morning, and meeting with Harriet and pleading his own cause,



<P>gave alarming ideas.&nbsp; The dread of such a failure after all became

the



<P>prominent uneasiness; and when Harriet appeared, and in very good spirits,



<P>and without having any such reason to give for her long absence,



<P>she felt a satisfaction which settled her with her own mind,



<P>and convinced her, that let Mr. Knightley think or say what he would,



<P>she had done nothing which woman's friendship and woman's feelings



<P>would not justify.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He had frightened her a little about Mr. Elton; but when she considered



<P>that Mr. Knightley could not have observed him as she had done,



<P>neither with the interest, nor (she must be allowed to tell herself,



<P>in spite of Mr. Knightley's pretensions) with the skill of such



<P>an observer on such a question as herself, that he had spoken it



<P>hastily and in anger, she was able to believe, that he had rather



<P>said what he wished resentfully to be true, than what he knew



<P>any thing about.&nbsp; He certainly might have heard Mr. Elton speak



<P>with more unreserve than she had ever done, and Mr. Elton might not



<P>be of an imprudent, inconsiderate disposition as to money matters;



<P>he might naturally be rather attentive than otherwise to them;



<P>but then, Mr. Knightley did not make due allowance for the influence



<P>of a strong passion at war with all interested motives.&nbsp; Mr. Knightley



<P>saw no such passion, and of course thought nothing of its effects;



<P>but she saw too much of it to feel a doubt of its overcoming any



<P>hesitations that a reasonable prudence might originally suggest;



<P>and more than a reasonable, becoming degree of prudence, she was very



<P>sure did not belong to Mr. Elton.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet's cheerful look and manner established hers: she came back,



<P>not to think of Mr. Martin, but to talk of Mr. Elton.&nbsp; Miss Nash



<P>had been telling her something, which she repeated immediately



<P>with great delight.&nbsp; Mr. Perry had been to Mrs. Goddard's to attend



<P>a sick child, and Miss Nash had seen him, and he had told Miss Nash,



<P>that as he was coming back yesterday from Clayton Park, he had met



<P>Mr. Elton, and found to his great surprize, that Mr. Elton was



<P>actually on his road to London, and not meaning to return till



<P>the morrow, though it was the whist-club night, which he had been



<P>never known to miss before; and Mr. Perry had remonstrated with him



<P>about it, and told him how shabby it was in him, their best player,



<P>to absent himself, and tried very much to persuade him to put off



<P>his journey only one day; but it would not do; Mr. Elton had been



<P>determined to go on, and had said in a very particular way indeed,



<P>that he was going on business which he would not put off for any



<P>inducement in the world; and something about a very enviable commission,



<P>and being the bearer of something exceedingly precious.&nbsp; Mr. Perry



<P>could not quite understand him, but he was very sure there must



<P>be a lady in the case, and he told him so; and Mr. Elton only



<P>looked very conscious and smiling, and rode off in great spirits.



<P>Miss Nash had told her all this, and had talked a great deal more



<P>about Mr. Elton; and said, looking so very significantly at her,



<P>"that she did not pretend to understand what his business might be,



<P>but she only knew that any woman whom Mr. Elton could prefer,



<P>she should think the luckiest woman in the world; for, beyond a doubt,



<P>Mr. Elton had not his equal for beauty or agreeableness."



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.03 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 09</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER IX</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Mr. Knightley might quarrel with her, but Emma could not quarrel



<P>with herself.&nbsp; He was so much displeased, that it was longer than



<P>usual before he came to Hartfield again; and when they did meet,



<P>his grave looks shewed that she was not forgiven.&nbsp; She was sorry,



<P>but could not repent.&nbsp; On the contrary, her plans and proceedings



<P>were more and more justified and endeared to her by the general



<P>appearances of the next few days.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The Picture, elegantly framed, came safely to hand soon after



<P>Mr. Elton's return, and being hung over the mantelpiece of the common



<P>sitting-room, he got up to look at it, and sighed out his half sentences



<P>of admiration just as he ought; and as for Harriet's feelings, they

were



<P>visibly forming themselves into as strong and steady an attachment



<P>as her youth and sort of mind admitted.&nbsp; Emma was soon perfectly



<P>satisfied of Mr. Martin's being no otherwise remembered, than as



<P>he furnished a contrast with Mr. Elton, of the utmost advantage to the

latter.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her views of improving her little friend's mind, by a great deal



<P>of useful reading and conversation, had never yet led to more than



<P>a few first chapters, and the intention of going on to-morrow.



<P>It was much easier to chat than to study; much pleasanter to let



<P>her imagination range and work at Harriet's fortune, than to be



<P>labouring to enlarge her comprehension or exercise it on sober facts;



<P>and the only literary pursuit which engaged Harriet at present,



<P>the only mental provision she was making for the evening of life,



<P>was the collecting and transcribing all the riddles of every sort



<P>that she could meet with, into a thin quarto of hot-pressed paper,



<P>made up by her friend, and ornamented with ciphers and trophies.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In this age of literature, such collections on a very grand scale



<P>are not uncommon.&nbsp; Miss Nash, head-teacher at Mrs. Goddard's,



<P>had written out at least three hundred; and Harriet, who had taken



<P>the first hint of it from her, hoped, with Miss Woodhouse's help,



<P>to get a great many more.&nbsp; Emma assisted with her invention,



<P>memory and taste; and as Harriet wrote a very pretty hand,



<P>it was likely to be an arrangement of the first order, in form



<P>as well as quantity.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Woodhouse was almost as much interested in the business as the girls,



<P>and tried very often to recollect something worth their putting in.



<P>"So many clever riddles as there used to be when he was young-- he



<P>wondered he could not remember them! but he hoped he should in time."



<P>And it always ended in "Kitty, a fair but frozen maid."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>His good friend Perry, too, whom he had spoken to on the subject,



<P>did not at present recollect any thing of the riddle kind;



<P>but he had desired Perry to be upon the watch, and as he went about



<P>so much, something, he thought, might come from that quarter.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was by no means his daughter's wish that the intellects of



<P>Highbury in general should be put under requisition.&nbsp; Mr. Elton



<P>was the only one whose assistance she asked.&nbsp; He was invited



<P>to contribute any really good enigmas, charades, or conundrums



<P>that he might recollect; and she had the pleasure of seeing him



<P>most intently at work with his recollections; and at the same time,



<P>as she could perceive, most earnestly careful that nothing ungallant,



<P>nothing that did not breathe a compliment to the sex should pass



<P>his lips.&nbsp; They owed to him their two or three politest puzzles;



<P>and the joy and exultation with which at last he recalled,



<P>and rather sentimentally recited, that well-known charade,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; My first doth affliction denote,



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Which my second is destin'd to feel



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; And my whole is the best antidote



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; That affliction to soften and heal.--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>made her quite sorry to acknowledge that they had transcribed it



<P>some pages ago already.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why will not you write one yourself for us, Mr. Elton?" said she;



<P>"that is the only security for its freshness; and nothing could be



<P>easier to you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh no! he had never written, hardly ever, any thing of the kind



<P>in his life.&nbsp; The stupidest fellow! He was afraid not even Miss



<P>Woodhouse"--he stopt a moment-- "or Miss Smith could inspire him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The very next day however produced some proof of inspiration.



<P>He called for a few moments, just to leave a piece of paper on the



<P>table containing, as he said, a charade, which a friend of his had



<P>addressed to a young lady, the object of his admiration, but which,



<P>from his manner, Emma was immediately convinced must be his own.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not offer it for Miss Smith's collection," said he.



<P>"Being my friend's, I have no right to expose it in any degree



<P>to the public eye, but perhaps you may not dislike looking at it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The speech was more to Emma than to Harriet, which Emma



<P>could understand.&nbsp; There was deep consciousness about him,



<P>and he found it easier to meet her eye than her friend's.



<P>He was gone the next moment:--after another moment's pause,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Take it," said Emma, smiling, and pushing the paper towards



<P>Harriet--"it is for you.&nbsp; Take your own."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But Harriet was in a tremor, and could not touch it; and Emma,



<P>never loth to be first, was obliged to examine it herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; To Miss--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; CHARADE.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; My first displays the wealth and pomp of kings,



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Lords of the earth! their luxury and

ease.



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Another view of man, my second brings,



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Behold him there, the monarch of the

seas!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; But ah! united, what reverse we have!



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Man's boasted power and freedom, all

are flown;



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Lord of the earth and sea, he bends a slave,



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; And woman, lovely woman, reigns alone.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Thy ready wit the word will soon supply,



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; May its approval beam in that soft eye!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She cast her eye over it, pondered, caught the meaning, read it through



<P>again to be quite certain, and quite mistress of the lines, and then



<P>passing it to Harriet, sat happily smiling, and saying to herself,



<P>while Harriet was puzzling over the paper in all the confusion



<P>of hope and dulness, "Very well, Mr. Elton, very well indeed.



<P>I have read worse charades.&nbsp; Courtship--a very good hint.&nbsp;

I give



<P>you credit for it.&nbsp; This is feeling your way.&nbsp; This is saying

very



<P>plainly-- `Pray, Miss Smith, give me leave to pay my addresses to you.



<P>Approve my charade and my intentions in the same glance.'

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; May its approval beam in that soft eye!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet exactly.&nbsp; Soft is the very word for her eye--of all epithets,



<P>the justest that could be given.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Thy ready wit the word will soon supply.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Humph--Harriet's ready wit! All the better.&nbsp; A man must be very

much



<P>in love, indeed, to describe her so.&nbsp; Ah! Mr. Knightley, I wish



<P>you had the benefit of this; I think this would convince you.



<P>For once in your life you would be obliged to own yourself mistaken.



<P>An excellent charade indeed! and very much to the purpose.



<P>Things must come to a crisis soon now."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was obliged to break off from these very pleasant observations,



<P>which were otherwise of a sort to run into great length, by the



<P>eagerness of Harriet's wondering questions.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What can it be, Miss Woodhouse?--what can it be? I have not an idea--I



<P>cannot guess it in the least.&nbsp; What can it possibly be? Do try



<P>to find it out, Miss Woodhouse.&nbsp; Do help me.&nbsp; I never saw

any thing



<P>so hard.&nbsp; Is it kingdom? I wonder who the friend was--and who could



<P>be the young lady.&nbsp; Do you think it is a good one? Can it be woman?

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; And woman, lovely woman, reigns alone.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Can it be Neptune?

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Behold him there, the monarch of the

seas!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Or a trident? or a mermaid? or a shark? Oh, no! shark is only



<P>one syllable.&nbsp; It must be very clever, or he would not have brought

it.



<P>Oh! Miss Woodhouse, do you think we shall ever find it out?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mermaids and sharks! Nonsense! My dear Harriet, what are you



<P>thinking of? Where would be the use of his bringing us a charade made



<P>by a friend upon a mermaid or a shark? Give me the paper and listen.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>For Miss ----------, read Miss Smith.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; My first displays the wealth and pomp of kings,



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Lords of the earth! their luxury and

ease.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>That is court.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Another view of man, my second brings;



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Behold him there, the monarch of the

seas!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>That is ship;--plain as it can be.--Now for the cream.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; But ah! united, (courtship, you know,) what reverse

we have!



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Man's boasted power and freedom, all

are flown.



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Lord of the earth and sea, he bends a slave,



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; And woman, lovely woman, reigns alone.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A very proper compliment!--and then follows the application,



<P>which I think, my dear Harriet, you cannot find much difficulty



<P>in comprehending.&nbsp; Read it in comfort to yourself.&nbsp; There

can



<P>be no doubt of its being written for you and to you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet could not long resist so delightful a persuasion.



<P>She read the concluding lines, and was all flutter and happiness.



<P>She could not speak.&nbsp; But she was not wanted to speak.&nbsp; It

was enough



<P>for her to feel.&nbsp; Emma spoke for her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There is so pointed, and so particular a meaning in this compliment,"



<P>said she, "that I cannot have a doubt as to Mr. Elton's intentions.



<P>You are his object-- and you will soon receive the completest proof



<P>of it.&nbsp; I thought it must be so.&nbsp; I thought I could not be

so deceived;



<P>but now, it is clear; the state of his mind is as clear and decided,



<P>as my wishes on the subject have been ever since I knew you.



<P>Yes, Harriet, just so long have I been wanting the very circumstance



<P>to happen what has happened.&nbsp; I could never tell whether an attachment



<P>between you and Mr. Elton were most desirable or most natural.



<P>Its probability and its eligibility have really so equalled each



<P>other! I am very happy.&nbsp; I congratulate you, my dear Harriet, with

all



<P>my heart.&nbsp; This is an attachment which a woman may well feel pride



<P>in creating.&nbsp; This is a connexion which offers nothing but good.



<P>It will give you every thing that you want--consideration, independence,



<P>a proper home--it will fix you in the centre of all your real friends,



<P>close to Hartfield and to me, and confirm our intimacy for ever.



<P>This, Harriet, is an alliance which can never raise a blush in either



<P>of us."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Dear Miss Woodhouse!"--and "Dear Miss Woodhouse," was all that Harriet,



<P>with many tender embraces could articulate at first; but when they



<P>did arrive at something more like conversation, it was sufficiently



<P>clear to her friend that she saw, felt, anticipated, and remembered



<P>just as she ought.&nbsp; Mr. Elton's superiority had very ample acknowledgment.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Whatever you say is always right," cried Harriet, "and therefore



<P>I suppose, and believe, and hope it must be so; but otherwise I could



<P>not have imagined it.&nbsp; It is so much beyond any thing I deserve.



<P>Mr. Elton, who might marry any body! There cannot be two opinions



<P>about him.&nbsp; He is so very superior.&nbsp; Only think of those sweet



<P>verses--"To Miss --------." Dear me, how clever!--Could it really



<P>be meant for me?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I cannot make a question, or listen to a question about that.



<P>It is a certainty.&nbsp; Receive it on my judgment.&nbsp; It is a sort



<P>of prologue to the play, a motto to the chapter; and will be soon



<P>followed by matter-of-fact prose."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is a sort of thing which nobody could have expected.&nbsp; I am

sure,



<P>a month ago, I had no more idea myself!--The strangest things do



<P>take place!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"When Miss Smiths and Mr. Eltons get acquainted--they do indeed--and



<P>really it is strange; it is out of the common course that what is



<P>so evidently, so palpably desirable--what courts the pre-arrangement



<P>of other people, should so immediately shape itself into the proper

form.



<P>You and Mr. Elton are by situation called together; you belong



<P>to one another by every circumstance of your respective homes.



<P>Your marrying will be equal to the match at Randalls.&nbsp; There does



<P>seem to be a something in the air of Hartfield which gives love



<P>exactly the right direction, and sends it into the very channel



<P>where it ought to flow.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The course of true love never did run

smooth--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A Hartfield edition of Shakespeare would have a long note on that passage."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That Mr. Elton should really be in love with me,--me, of all people,



<P>who did not know him, to speak to him, at Michaelmas! And he,



<P>the very handsomest man that ever was, and a man that every body



<P>looks up to, quite like Mr. Knightley! His company so sought after,



<P>that every body says he need not eat a single meal by himself if he



<P>does not chuse it; that he has more invitations than there are days



<P>in the week.&nbsp; And so excellent in the Church! Miss Nash has put

down



<P>all the texts he has ever preached from since he came to Highbury.



<P>Dear me! When I look back to the first time I saw him! How little



<P>did I think!-- The two Abbots and I ran into the front room and



<P>peeped through the blind when we heard he was going by, and Miss



<P>Nash came and scolded us away, and staid to look through herself;



<P>however, she called me back presently, and let me look too,



<P>which was very good-natured. And how beautiful we thought he looked!



<P>He was arm-in-arm with Mr. Cole."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"This is an alliance which, whoever--whatever your friends may be,



<P>must be agreeable to them, provided at least they have common sense;



<P>and we are not to be addressing our conduct to fools.&nbsp; If they



<P>are anxious to see you happily married, here is a man whose amiable



<P>character gives every assurance of it;--if they wish to have you



<P>settled in the same country and circle which they have chosen



<P>to place you in, here it will be accomplished; and if their only



<P>object is that you should, in the common phrase, be well married,



<P>here is the comfortable fortune, the respectable establishment,



<P>the rise in the world which must satisfy them."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, very true.&nbsp; How nicely you talk; I love to hear you.



<P>You understand every thing.&nbsp; You and Mr. Elton are one as clever



<P>as the other.&nbsp; This charade!--If I had studied a twelvemonth,



<P>I could never have made any thing like it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I thought he meant to try his skill, by his manner of declining



<P>it yesterday."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do think it is, without exception, the best charade I ever read."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I never read one more to the purpose, certainly."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is as long again as almost all we have had before."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not consider its length as particularly in its favour.



<P>Such things in general cannot be too short."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet was too intent on the lines to hear.&nbsp; The most satisfactory



<P>comparisons were rising in her mind.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is one thing," said she, presently--her cheeks in a glow--"to



<P>have very good sense in a common way, like every body else,



<P>and if there is any thing to say, to sit down and write a letter,



<P>and say just what you must, in a short way; and another, to write



<P>verses and charades like this."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma could not have desired a more spirited rejection of Mr. Martin's

prose.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Such sweet lines!" continued Harriet--"these two last!--But



<P>how shall I ever be able to return the paper, or say I have found



<P>it out?--Oh! Miss Woodhouse, what can we do about that?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Leave it to me.&nbsp; You do nothing.&nbsp; He will be here this evening,



<P>I dare say, and then I will give it him back, and some nonsense



<P>or other will pass between us, and you shall not be committed.--Your



<P>soft eyes shall chuse their own time for beaming.&nbsp; Trust to me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! Miss Woodhouse, what a pity that I must not write this beautiful



<P>charade into my book! I am sure I have not got one half so good."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Leave out the two last lines, and there is no reason why you



<P>should not write it into your book."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! but those two lines are"--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>--"The best of all.&nbsp; Granted;--for private enjoyment; and for private



<P>enjoyment keep them.&nbsp; They are not at all the less written you

know,



<P>because you divide them.&nbsp; The couplet does not cease to be, nor

does



<P>its meaning change.&nbsp; But take it away, and all appropriation ceases,



<P>and a very pretty gallant charade remains, fit for any collection.



<P>Depend upon it, he would not like to have his charade slighted,



<P>much better than his passion.&nbsp; A poet in love must be encouraged

in



<P>both capacities, or neither.&nbsp; Give me the book, I will write it

down,



<P>and then there can be no possible reflection on you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet submitted, though her mind could hardly separate the parts,



<P>so as to feel quite sure that her friend were not writing down



<P>a declaration of love.&nbsp; It seemed too precious an offering for

any



<P>degree of publicity.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I shall never let that book go out of my own hands," said she.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very well," replied Emma; "a most natural feeling; and the longer



<P>it lasts, the better I shall be pleased.&nbsp; But here is my father



<P>coming: you will not object to my reading the charade to him.



<P>It will be giving him so much pleasure! He loves any thing of



<P>the sort, and especially any thing that pays woman a compliment.



<P>He has the tenderest spirit of gallantry towards us all!-- You must



<P>let me read it to him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Harriet looked grave.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear Harriet, you must not refine too much upon this



<P>charade.--You will betray your feelings improperly, if you are



<P>too conscious and too quick, and appear to affix more meaning,



<P>or even quite all the meaning which may be affixed to it.



<P>Do not be overpowered by such a little tribute of admiration.



<P>If he had been anxious for secrecy, he would not have left the paper



<P>while I was by; but he rather pushed it towards me than towards you.



<P>Do not let us be too solemn on the business.&nbsp; He has encouragement



<P>enough to proceed, without our sighing out our souls over this charade."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! no--I hope I shall not be ridiculous about it.&nbsp; Do as you

please."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Woodhouse came in, and very soon led to the subject again,



<P>by the recurrence of his very frequent inquiry of "Well, my dears,



<P>how does your book go on?--Have you got any thing fresh?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, papa; we have something to read you, something quite fresh.



<P>A piece of paper was found on the table this morning--(dropt,



<P>we suppose, by a fairy)-- containing a very pretty charade, and we



<P>have just copied it in."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She read it to him, just as he liked to have any thing read,



<P>slowly and distinctly, and two or three times over, with explanations



<P>of every part as she proceeded-- and he was very much pleased, and,



<P>as she had foreseen, especially struck with the complimentary conclusion.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Aye, that's very just, indeed, that's very properly said.



<P>Very true.&nbsp; `Woman, lovely woman.' It is such a pretty charade,



<P>my dear, that I can easily guess what fairy brought it.-- Nobody



<P>could have written so prettily, but you, Emma."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma only nodded, and smiled.--After a little thinking,



<P>and a very tender sigh, he added,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah! it is no difficulty to see who you take after! Your dear mother



<P>was so clever at all those things! If I had but her memory! But I



<P>can remember nothing;--not even that particular riddle which you



<P>have heard me mention; I can only recollect the first stanza;



<P>and there are several.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Kitty, a fair but frozen maid,



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Kindled a flame I yet deplore,



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The hood-wink'd boy I called to aid,



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Though of his near approach afraid,



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; So fatal to my suit before.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>And that is all that I can recollect of it--but it is very clever



<P>all the way through.&nbsp; But I think, my dear, you said you had got

it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, papa, it is written out in our second page.&nbsp; We copied it



<P>from the Elegant Extracts.&nbsp; It was Garrick's, you know."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Aye, very true.--I wish I could recollect more of it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Kitty, a fair but frozen maid.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The name makes me think of poor Isabella; for she was very near



<P>being christened Catherine after her grandmama.&nbsp; I hope we shall



<P>have her here next week.&nbsp; Have you thought, my dear, where you



<P>shall put her--and what room there will be for the children?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! yes--she will have her own room, of course; the room she always



<P>has;--and there is the nursery for the children,--just as usual,



<P>you know.&nbsp; Why should there be any change?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not know, my dear--but it is so long since she was here!--not



<P>since last Easter, and then only for a few days.--Mr. John Knightley's



<P>being a lawyer is very inconvenient.--Poor Isabella!--she is sadly



<P>taken away from us all!--and how sorry she will be when she comes,



<P>not to see Miss Taylor here!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She will not be surprized, papa, at least."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not know, my dear.&nbsp; I am sure I was very much surprized



<P>when I first heard she was going to be married."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We must ask Mr. and Mrs. Weston to dine with us, while Isabella



<P>is here."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, my dear, if there is time.--But--(in a very depressed tone)--she



<P>is coming for only one week.&nbsp; There will not be time for any thing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is unfortunate that they cannot stay longer--but it seems a case



<P>of necessity.&nbsp; Mr. John Knightley must be in town again on the

28th,



<P>and we ought to be thankful, papa, that we are to have the whole



<P>of the time they can give to the country, that two or three days



<P>are not to be taken out for the Abbey.&nbsp; Mr. Knightley promises



<P>to give up his claim this Christmas-- though you know it is longer



<P>since they were with him, than with us."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It would be very hard, indeed, my dear, if poor Isabella were



<P>to be anywhere but at Hartfield."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Woodhouse could never allow for Mr. Knightley's claims on



<P>his brother, or any body's claims on Isabella, except his own.



<P>He sat musing a little while, and then said,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But I do not see why poor Isabella should be obliged to go back



<P>so soon, though he does.&nbsp; I think, Emma, I shall try and persuade



<P>her to stay longer with us.&nbsp; She and the children might stay very

well."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah! papa--that is what you never have been able to accomplish,



<P>and I do not think you ever will.&nbsp; Isabella cannot bear to stay



<P>behind her husband."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This was too true for contradiction.&nbsp; Unwelcome as it was, Mr.

Woodhouse



<P>could only give a submissive sigh; and as Emma saw his spirits



<P>affected by the idea of his daughter's attachment to her husband,



<P>she immediately led to such a branch of the subject as must raise them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Harriet must give us as much of her company as she can while



<P>my brother and sister are here.&nbsp; I am sure she will be pleased



<P>with the children.&nbsp; We are very proud of the children, are not

we,



<P>papa? I wonder which she will think the handsomest, Henry or John?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Aye, I wonder which she will.&nbsp; Poor little dears, how glad they



<P>will be to come.&nbsp; They are very fond of being at Hartfield, Harriet."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I dare say they are, sir.&nbsp; I am sure I do not know who is not."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Henry is a fine boy, but John is very like his mama.&nbsp; Henry is

the eldest,



<P>he was named after me, not after his father.&nbsp; John, the second,



<P>is named after his father.&nbsp; Some people are surprized, I believe,



<P>that the eldest was not, but Isabella would have him called Henry,



<P>which I thought very pretty of her.&nbsp; And he is a very clever boy,



<P>indeed.&nbsp; They are all remarkably clever; and they have so many



<P>pretty ways.&nbsp; They will come and stand by my chair, and say,



<P>`Grandpapa, can you give me a bit of string?' and once Henry asked me



<P>for a knife, but I told him knives were only made for grandpapas.



<P>I think their father is too rough with them very often."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He appears rough to you," said Emma, "because you are so very



<P>gentle yourself; but if you could compare him with other papas,



<P>you would not think him rough.&nbsp; He wishes his boys to be active

and hardy;



<P>and if they misbehave, can give them a sharp word now and then;



<P>but he is an affectionate father--certainly Mr. John Knightley



<P>is an affectionate father.&nbsp; The children are all fond of him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And then their uncle comes in, and tosses them up to the ceiling



<P>in a very frightful way!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But they like it, papa; there is nothing they like so much.



<P>It is such enjoyment to them, that if their uncle did not lay down



<P>the rule of their taking turns, whichever began would never give way



<P>to the other."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, I cannot understand it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That is the case with us all, papa.&nbsp; One half of the world cannot



<P>understand the pleasures of the other."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Later in the morning, and just as the girls were going to separate



<P>in preparation for the regular four o'clock dinner, the hero



<P>of this inimitable charade walked in again.&nbsp; Harriet turned away;



<P>but Emma could receive him with the usual smile, and her quick eye



<P>soon discerned in his the consciousness of having made a push--of



<P>having thrown a die; and she imagined he was come to see how it



<P>might turn up.&nbsp; His ostensible reason, however, was to ask whether



<P>Mr. Woodhouse's party could be made up in the evening without him,



<P>or whether he should be in the smallest degree necessary at Hartfield.



<P>If he were, every thing else must give way; but otherwise his friend



<P>Cole had been saying so much about his dining with him--had made



<P>such a point of it, that he had promised him conditionally to come.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma thanked him, but could not allow of his disappointing his



<P>friend on their account; her father was sure of his rubber.



<P>He re-urged --she re-declined; and he seemed then about to make



<P>his bow, when taking the paper from the table, she returned it--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! here is the charade you were so obliging as to leave with us;



<P>thank you for the sight of it.&nbsp; We admired it so much, that I have



<P>ventured to write it into Miss Smith's collection.&nbsp; Your friend



<P>will not take it amiss I hope.&nbsp; Of course I have not transcribed



<P>beyond the first eight lines."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Elton certainly did not very well know what to say.



<P>He looked rather doubtingly--rather confused; said something about



<P>"honour,"--glanced at Emma and at Harriet, and then seeing the book



<P>open on the table, took it up, and examined it very attentively.



<P>With the view of passing off an awkward moment, Emma smilingly said,

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You must make my apologies to your friend; but so good a charade



<P>must not be confined to one or two.&nbsp; He may be sure of every woman's



<P>approbation while he writes with such gallantry."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have no hesitation in saying," replied Mr. Elton, though hesitating



<P>a good deal while he spoke; "I have no hesitation in saying--at



<P>least if my friend feels at all as I do--I have not the smallest



<P>doubt that, could he see his little effusion honoured as I see it,



<P>(looking at the book again, and replacing it on the table), he



<P>would consider it as the proudest moment of his life."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After this speech he was gone as soon as possible.&nbsp; Emma could

not



<P>think it too soon; for with all his good and agreeable qualities,



<P>there was a sort of parade in his speeches which was very apt



<P>to incline her to laugh.&nbsp; She ran away to indulge the inclination,



<P>leaving the tender and the sublime of pleasure to Harriet's share.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 18</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XVIII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Mr. Frank Churchill did not come.&nbsp; When the time proposed



<P>drew near, Mrs. Weston's fears were justified in the arrival



<P>of a letter of excuse.&nbsp; For the present, he could not be spared,



<P>to his "very great mortification and regret; but still he looked



<P>forward with the hope of coming to Randalls at no distant period."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Weston was exceedingly disappointed--much more disappointed,



<P>in fact, than her husband, though her dependence on seeing the



<P>young man had been so much more sober:&nbsp; but a sanguine temper,



<P>though for ever expecting more good than occurs, does not



<P>always pay for its hopes by any proportionate depression.



<P>It soon flies over the present failure, and begins to hope again.



<P>For half an hour Mr. Weston was surprized and sorry; but then he



<P>began to perceive that Frank's coming two or three months later



<P>would be a much better plan; better time of year; better weather;



<P>and that he would be able, without any doubt, to stay considerably



<P>longer with them than if he had come sooner.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>These feelings rapidly restored his comfort, while Mrs. Weston,



<P>of a more apprehensive disposition, foresaw nothing but a repetition



<P>of excuses and delays; and after all her concern for what her husband



<P>was to suffer, suffered a great deal more herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Emma was not at this time in a state of spirits to care really



<P>about Mr. Frank Churchill's not coming, except as a disappointment



<P>at Randalls.&nbsp; The acquaintance at present had no charm for her.



<P>She wanted, rather, to be quiet, and out of temptation; but still, as

it



<P>was desirable that she should appear, in general, like her usual self,



<P>she took care to express as much interest in the circumstance,



<P>and enter as warmly into Mr. and Mrs. Weston's disappointment,



<P>as might naturally belong to their friendship.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was the first to announce it to Mr. Knightley; and exclaimed



<P>quite as much as was necessary, (or, being acting a part, perhaps



<P>rather more,) at the conduct of the Churchills, in keeping him away.



<P>She then proceeded to say a good deal more than she felt, of the



<P>advantage of such an addition to their confined society in Surry;



<P>the pleasure of looking at somebody new; the gala-day to Highbury entire,



<P>which the sight of him would have made; and ending with reflections



<P>on the Churchills again, found herself directly involved in a



<P>disagreement with Mr. Knightley; and, to her great amusement,



<P>perceived that she was taking the other side of the question from her



<P>real opinion, and making use of Mrs. Weston's arguments against herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The Churchills are very likely in fault," said Mr. Knightley,



<P>coolly; "but I dare say he might come if he would."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not know why you should say so.&nbsp; He wishes exceedingly to

come;



<P>but his uncle and aunt will not spare him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I cannot believe that he has not the power of coming, if he made



<P>a point of it.&nbsp; It is too unlikely, for me to believe it without

proof."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How odd you are!&nbsp; What has Mr. Frank Churchill done, to make you



<P>suppose him such an unnatural creature?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am not supposing him at all an unnatural creature, in suspecting



<P>that he may have learnt to be above his connexions, and to care



<P>very little for any thing but his own pleasure, from living with



<P>those who have always set him the example of it.&nbsp; It is a great

deal



<P>more natural than one could wish, that a young man, brought up



<P>by those who are proud, luxurious, and selfish, should be proud,



<P>luxurious, and selfish too.&nbsp; If Frank Churchill had wanted to see



<P>his father, he would have contrived it between September and January.



<P>A man at his age--what is he?--three or four-and-twenty--cannot be



<P>without the means of doing as much as that.&nbsp; It is impossible."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's easily said, and easily felt by you, who have always



<P>been your own master.&nbsp; You are the worst judge in the world,



<P>Mr. Knightley, of the difficulties of dependence.&nbsp; You do not know



<P>what it is to have tempers to manage."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is not to be conceived that a man of three or four-and-twenty



<P>should not have liberty of mind or limb to that amount.&nbsp; He cannot



<P>want money--he cannot want leisure.&nbsp; We know, on the contrary,



<P>that he has so much of both, that he is glad to get rid of them at



<P>the idlest haunts in the kingdom.&nbsp; We hear of him for ever at some



<P>watering-place or other.&nbsp; A little while ago, he was at Weymouth.



<P>This proves that he can leave the Churchills."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, sometimes he can."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And those times are whenever he thinks it worth his while;



<P>whenever there is any temptation of pleasure."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is very unfair to judge of any body's conduct, without an



<P>intimate knowledge of their situation.&nbsp; Nobody, who has not been



<P>in the interior of a family, can say what the difficulties



<P>of any individual of that family may be.&nbsp; We ought to be



<P>acquainted with Enscombe, and with Mrs. Churchill's temper,



<P>before we pretend to decide upon what her nephew can do.



<P>He may, at times, be able to do a great deal more than he can at others."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There is one thing, Emma, which a man can always do, if he chuses,



<P>and that is, his duty; not by manoeuvring and finessing, but by vigour



<P>and resolution.&nbsp; It is Frank Churchill's duty to pay this attention



<P>to his father.&nbsp; He knows it to be so, by his promises and messages;



<P>but if he wished to do it, it might be done.&nbsp; A man who felt rightly



<P>would say at once, simply and resolutely, to Mrs. Churchill--



<P>`Every sacrifice of mere pleasure you will always find me ready to make



<P>to your convenience; but I must go and see my father immediately.



<P>I know he would be hurt by my failing in such a mark of respect to him



<P>on the present occasion.&nbsp; I shall, therefore, set off to-morrow.'--



<P>If he would say so to her at once, in the tone of decision becoming



<P>a man, there would be no opposition made to his going."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No," said Emma, laughing; "but perhaps there might be some made to

his



<P>coming back again.&nbsp; Such language for a young man entirely dependent,



<P>to use!--Nobody but you, Mr. Knightley, would imagine it possible.



<P>But you have not an idea of what is requisite in situations directly



<P>opposite to your own.&nbsp; Mr. Frank Churchill to be making such



<P>a speech as that to the uncle and aunt, who have brought him up,



<P>and are to provide for him!--Standing up in the middle of the room,



<P>I suppose, and speaking as loud as he could!--How can you imagine



<P>such conduct practicable?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Depend upon it, Emma, a sensible man would find no difficulty in it.



<P>He would feel himself in the right; and the declaration--made,



<P>of course, as a man of sense would make it, in a proper manner--



<P>would do him more good, raise him higher, fix his interest stronger



<P>with the people he depended on, than all that a line of shifts



<P>and expedients can ever do.&nbsp; Respect would be added to affection.



<P>They would feel that they could trust him; that the nephew who had



<P>done rightly by his father, would do rightly by them; for they know,



<P>as well as he does, as well as all the world must know, that he



<P>ought to pay this visit to his father; and while meanly exerting



<P>their power to delay it, are in their hearts not thinking the better



<P>of him for submitting to their whims.&nbsp; Respect for right conduct



<P>is felt by every body.&nbsp; If he would act in this sort of manner,



<P>on principle, consistently, regularly, their little minds would bend



<P>to his."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I rather doubt that.&nbsp; You are very fond of bending little minds;



<P>but where little minds belong to rich people in authority,



<P>I think they have a knack of swelling out, till they are quite as



<P>unmanageable as great ones.&nbsp; I can imagine, that if you, as you

are,



<P>Mr. Knightley, were to be transported and placed all at once in



<P>Mr. Frank Churchill's situation, you would be able to say and do



<P>just what you have been recommending for him; and it might have



<P>a very good effect.&nbsp; The Churchills might not have a word to say



<P>in return; but then, you would have no habits of early obedience



<P>and long observance to break through.&nbsp; To him who has, it might



<P>not be so easy to burst forth at once into perfect independence,



<P>and set all their claims on his gratitude and regard at nought.



<P>He may have as strong a sense of what would be right, as you can have,



<P>without being so equal, under particular circumstances, to act up



<P>to it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then it would not be so strong a sense.&nbsp; If it failed to produce



<P>equal exertion, it could not be an equal conviction."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, the difference of situation and habit!&nbsp; I wish you would try



<P>to understand what an amiable young man may be likely to feel



<P>in directly opposing those, whom as child and boy he has been



<P>looking up to all his life."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Our amiable young man is a very weak young man, if this be the first



<P>occasion of his carrying through a resolution to do right against



<P>the will of others.&nbsp; It ought to have been a habit with him by



<P>this time, of following his duty, instead of consulting expediency.



<P>I can allow for the fears of the child, but not of the man.



<P>As he became rational, he ought to have roused himself and shaken off
