<P>all that was unworthy in their authority.&nbsp; He ought to have opposed



<P>the first attempt on their side to make him slight his father.



<P>Had he begun as he ought, there would have been no difficulty now."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We shall never agree about him," cried Emma; "but that is



<P>nothing extraordinary.&nbsp; I have not the least idea of his being



<P>a weak young man:&nbsp; I feel sure that he is not.&nbsp; Mr. Weston

would



<P>not be blind to folly, though in his own son; but he is very likely



<P>to have a more yielding, complying, mild disposition than would suit



<P>your notions of man's perfection.&nbsp; I dare say he has; and though



<P>it may cut him off from some advantages, it will secure him many others."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes; all the advantages of sitting still when he ought to move,



<P>and of leading a life of mere idle pleasure, and fancying himself



<P>extremely expert in finding excuses for it.&nbsp; He can sit down and



<P>write a fine flourishing letter, full of professions and falsehoods,



<P>and persuade himself that he has hit upon the very best method



<P>in the world of preserving peace at home and preventing his father's



<P>having any right to complain.&nbsp; His letters disgust me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Your feelings are singular.&nbsp; They seem to satisfy every body else."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I suspect they do not satisfy Mrs. Weston.&nbsp; They hardly can



<P>satisfy a woman of her good sense and quick feelings:&nbsp; standing

in



<P>a mother's place, but without a mother's affection to blind her.



<P>It is on her account that attention to Randalls is doubly due,



<P>and she must doubly feel the omission.&nbsp; Had she been a person



<P>of consequence herself, he would have come I dare say; and it would



<P>not have signified whether he did or no.&nbsp; Can you think your friend



<P>behindhand in these sort of considerations?&nbsp; Do you suppose she



<P>does not often say all this to herself?&nbsp; No, Emma, your amiable



<P>young man can be amiable only in French, not in English.&nbsp; He may

be



<P>very `aimable,' have very good manners, and be very agreeable; but he



<P>can have no English delicacy towards the feelings of other people:



<P>nothing really amiable about him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You seem determined to think ill of him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Me!--not at all," replied Mr. Knightley, rather displeased; "I do



<P>not want to think ill of him.&nbsp; I should be as ready to acknowledge



<P>his merits as any other man; but I hear of none, except what are



<P>merely personal; that he is well-grown and good-looking, with smooth,



<P>plausible manners."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, if he have nothing else to recommend him, he will be a



<P>treasure at Highbury.&nbsp; We do not often look upon fine young men,



<P>well-bred and agreeable.&nbsp; We must not be nice and ask for all



<P>the virtues into the bargain.&nbsp; Cannot you imagine, Mr. Knightley,



<P>what a sensation his coming will produce?&nbsp; There will be but one

subject



<P>throughout the parishes of Donwell and Highbury; but one interest--



<P>one object of curiosity; it will be all Mr. Frank Churchill;



<P>we shall think and speak of nobody else."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You will excuse my being so much over-powered. If I find him



<P>conversable, I shall be glad of his acquaintance; but if he is only



<P>a chattering coxcomb, he will not occupy much of my time or thoughts."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My idea of him is, that he can adapt his conversation to the taste



<P>of every body, and has the power as well as the wish of being



<P>universally agreeable.&nbsp; To you, he will talk of farming; to me,



<P>of drawing or music; and so on to every body, having that general



<P>information on all subjects which will enable him to follow the lead,



<P>or take the lead, just as propriety may require, and to speak



<P>extremely well on each; that is my idea of him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And mine," said Mr. Knightley warmly, "is, that if he turn out any



<P>thing like it, he will be the most insufferable fellow breathing!



<P>What! at three-and-twenty to be the king of his company--the great man--



<P>the practised politician, who is to read every body's character,



<P>and make every body's talents conduce to the display of his



<P>own superiority; to be dispensing his flatteries around, that he



<P>may make all appear like fools compared with himself!&nbsp; My dear

Emma,



<P>your own good sense could not endure such a puppy when it came



<P>to the point."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I will say no more about him," cried Emma, "you turn every



<P>thing to evil.&nbsp; We are both prejudiced; you against, I for him;



<P>and we have no chance of agreeing till he is really here."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Prejudiced!&nbsp; I am not prejudiced."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But I am very much, and without being at all ashamed of it.



<P>My love for Mr. and Mrs. Weston gives me a decided prejudice in



<P>his favour."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He is a person I never think of from one month's end to another,"



<P>said Mr. Knightley, with a degree of vexation, which made Emma



<P>immediately talk of something else, though she could not comprehend



<P>why he should be angry.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To take a dislike to a young man, only because he appeared to be



<P>of a different disposition from himself, was unworthy the real



<P>liberality of mind which she was always used to acknowledge in him;



<P>for with all the high opinion of himself, which she had often laid



<P>to his charge, she had never before for a moment supposed it could



<P>make him unjust to the merit of another.



<P>
